exercises.description: Sit-Up performed 3/4 of the way up
instructions: Lie down on the floor and secure your feet. Your legs should be bent at the knees.
Place your hands behind or to the side of your head. You will begin with your back on the ground. This will be your starting position.
Flex your hips and spine to raise your torso toward your knees.
At the top of the contraction your torso should be perpendicular to the ground. Reverse the motion, going only  of the way down.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: 3/4 Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat - imagine you're making a triangle with your legs
Place hands lightly behind your head with elbows wide - pretend you're cradling a basketball
Curl up like you're closing a book, leading with your chest until your shoulder blades lift completely off the ground
Stop when your torso is about 3/4 of the way up (45-60 degrees), then slowly lower back down but stop before your shoulders touch the floor
Keep constant tension - your abs should feel like they're burning the entire set
form_cues: Think about pulling your ribcage toward your pelvis, not just lifting your head
Exhale hard at the top like you're blowing out birthday candles - this maximizes ab contraction
Keep your chin neutral by imagining you're holding an apple between your chin and chest
Your lower back should stay pressed to the floor - pretend you're squashing a bug underneath
common_mistakes: Pulling on the neck with hands - this causes neck strain and takes tension off the abs
Using momentum to swing up - the movement should be slow and controlled, taking 2 seconds up and 2 seconds down
Letting shoulders fully rest on the ground between reps - this releases all tension from your abs
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel neck pain, cross your arms over your chest instead of placing hands behind your head
Stop immediately if you feel lower back discomfort - your abs may not be strong enough yet, try knee raises instead

exercises.description: Hamstring stretch with legs split
instructions: Lie on your back, with one leg extended straight out.
With the other leg, bend the hip and knee to 90 degrees. You may brace your leg with your hands if necessary. This will be your starting position.
Extend your leg straight into the air, pausing briefly at the top. Return the leg to the starting position.
Repeat for 10-20 repetitions, and then switch to the other leg.
exercises.name: 90/90 Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with one leg extended straight on the ground and the other bent at 90 degrees (knee and hip both at right angles)
Hold the bent leg behind your thigh with both hands - imagine you're hugging your knee toward your chest
Slowly straighten the raised leg toward the ceiling, keeping your knee as straight as possible without forcing it
Feel the stretch peak when your leg is straight up, hold for 2 seconds, then bend back to the starting 90-degree position
Complete all reps on one side before switching to the other leg
form_cues: Point your toes toward your shin (dorsiflexion) to intensify the hamstring stretch
Keep your lower back flat on the ground - imagine you're trying to press your spine through the floor
Think about pushing your heel toward the ceiling rather than pulling your leg down
Your extended leg should stay relaxed and glued to the floor throughout
common_mistakes: Letting the lower back arch off the ground - this shifts tension away from the hamstrings and can strain your back
Bouncing or jerking the leg to gain momentum - stretching should be smooth and controlled
Bending the knee of the raised leg too much - keep it as straight as comfortable to properly stretch the hamstring
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel sharp pain behind your knee, reduce the range of motion and focus on the stretch in the muscle belly
Never force your leg past a comfortable stretch - hamstrings are injury-prone when overstretched

exercises.description: Crunch performed with a machine
instructions: Select a light resistance and sit down on the ab machine placing your feet under the pads provided and grabbing the top handles. Your arms should be bent at a 90 degree angle as you rest the triceps on the pads provided. This will be your starting position.

At the same time, begin to lift the legs up as you crunch your upper torso. Breathe out as you perform this movement. Tip: Be sure to use a slow and controlled motion. Concentrate on using your abs to move the weight while relaxing your legs and feet.
After a second pause, slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Machine Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in the ab machine with your feet secured under the pads and grab the handles above your head
Rest your triceps on the arm pads with your elbows bent at 90 degrees - like you're sitting in a throne
Crunch forward by pulling the handles down while simultaneously lifting your knees up toward your chest - imagine you're folding in half like a lawn chair
Squeeze hard at the peak contraction for 1 second, feeling your abs completely cramped
Slowly return to the starting position with control, taking 2-3 seconds to resist the weight
form_cues: Exhale forcefully as you crunch - think about forcefully blowing all the air out of your lungs
Focus on bringing your ribcage and pelvis together, not just pulling with your arms
At the bottom, don't let the weight stack touch - keep constant tension on your abs
Imagine crushing a walnut between your abs at the top of each rep
common_mistakes: Using your arms and legs to pull the weight instead of your abs - relax your limbs and focus purely on ab contraction
Letting the weight drop too fast on the way down - the negative (lowering) portion is crucial for ab development
Selecting too much weight - your abs should be doing the work, not momentum or other muscles
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight to master the mind-muscle connection before adding resistance
If you feel lower back strain, reduce the weight and focus on keeping your spine neutral throughout

exercises.description: Rolling from a knee plank to extension
instructions: Hold the Ab Roller with both hands and kneel on the floor.
Now place the ab roller on the floor in front of you so that you are on all your hands and knees (as in a kneeling push up position). This will be your starting position.

Slowly roll the ab roller straight forward, stretching your body into a straight position. Tip: Go down as far as you can without touching the floor with your body. Breathe in during this portion of the movement.
After a pause at the stretched position, start pulling yourself back to the starting position as you breathe out. Tip: Go slowly and keep your abs tight at all times.
exercises.name: Ab Roller
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on your knees with the ab roller on the floor in front of you, hands gripping the handles directly under your shoulders
Brace your core hard like someone's about to punch you in the stomach
Roll forward slowly, extending your arms and body while keeping your hips high - imagine you're trying to push the floor away from you
Roll out as far as you can while maintaining a straight line from knees to shoulders (don't let your hips sag or lower back arch)
Pull yourself back to the starting position by thinking about dragging your elbows back into your ribcage
form_cues: Keep your glutes squeezed tight throughout - imagine you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Think about pulling the roller back with your abs, not your arms - like you're doing a crunch while extended
Your head should stay neutral - imagine balancing a cup of water on the back of your head
Roll out only as far as you can while keeping your lower back completely flat
common_mistakes: Letting your hips drop and lower back arch - this is dangerous and shifts work away from your abs to your spine
Rolling out too far too soon - start with shorter ranges and gradually increase as you get stronger
Using momentum to pull back - the return should be slow and controlled, taking 2-3 seconds
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel any lower back pain, reduce your range of motion immediately - roll out only halfway until you build more core strength
Beginners should start by rolling out to a wall to limit range of motion and build control gradually

exercises.description: One leg adductor foam roll
instructions: Lie face down with one leg on a foam roll.
Rotate the leg so that the foam roll contacts against your inner thigh. Shift as much weight onto the foam roll as can be tolerated.
While trying to relax the muscles if the inner thigh, roll over the foam between your hip and knee, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat with the other leg.
exercises.name: Adductor
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down with one leg extended to the side and place a foam roller under your inner thigh
Rotate your leg so the inner thigh muscle (adductor) is in full contact with the foam roller
Shift as much of your body weight onto the roller as you can tolerate - use your arms and other leg for support
Slowly roll from your hip down toward your knee, pausing for 10-30 seconds on any tight or tender spots
Keep breathing deeply and try to relax the muscle as you roll - tension makes it harder to release
form_cues: Think about melting into the roller rather than tensing up against it
Your extended leg should be completely relaxed - imagine it's dead weight
Roll very slowly, about 1 inch per second, to give the muscle time to release
When you find a tender spot, stay there and take 5 deep breaths before moving on
common_mistakes: Rolling too quickly - this doesn't give the muscle tissue time to respond and release
Tensing up the muscle you're rolling - you need to actively relax for the foam rolling to be effective
Applying too much pressure too soon - start light and gradually increase pressure as the muscle releases
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid rolling directly on your groin attachment point near the pelvis - stay in the muscle belly to prevent irritation
If you experience sharp, shooting pain (not just discomfort), move to a different spot - you may be on a nerve

exercises.description: Groin Split Leg Stretch
instructions: Lie on your back with your feet raised towards the ceiling.
Have your partner hold your feet or ankles. Abduct your legs as far as you can. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to squeeze your legs together for 10 or more seconds, while your partner prevents you from doing so.

Now, relax the muscles in your legs as your partner pushes your feet apart, stretching as far as is comfortable for you. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is adequate to prevent overstretching or injury.
exercises.name: Adductor/Groin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with legs raised straight up toward the ceiling while your partner holds your ankles
Let your legs spread apart as far as is comfortable - like you're doing a split in the air
Push your legs together (squeezing inward) as hard as you can for 10 seconds while your partner resists, preventing any movement
After 10 seconds, completely relax your legs and let your partner gently push your feet further apart to deepen the stretch
Communicate clearly with your partner about when the stretch feels adequate - never push past mild discomfort
form_cues: During the contraction phase, imagine you're trying to squeeze a beach ball between your ankles
Keep your lower back pressed flat to the floor throughout - don't let it arch
During the stretch phase, breathe deeply and think about releasing all tension in your inner thighs
Your knees should stay completely straight during both the contraction and stretch phases
common_mistakes: Not contracting hard enough during the squeeze phase - this is what makes the stretch more effective afterward
Letting your partner push too far too fast - overstretching can cause groin strains
Holding your breath during the contraction - breathe normally to avoid unnecessary tension
injury_prevention_tips: Establish a verbal signal with your partner (like 'stop') to immediately halt the stretch if needed
Never bounce or force the stretch - the adductors are highly prone to strains and tears

instructions: Clean and press a kettlebell overhead with one arm.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, push your butt out in the direction of the locked out kettlebell. Keep the non-working arm behind your back and turn your feet out at a forty-five degree angle from the arm with the kettlebell.
Lower yourself as far as possible.
Pause for a second and reverse the motion back to the starting position.
exercises.name: Advanced Kettlebell Windmill
beginner_friendly_instructions: Press a kettlebell overhead with one arm and lock it out completely - your arm should be like a steel beam
Turn your feet out 45 degrees away from the kettlebell side and keep your eyes glued to the kettlebell throughout
Push your hips back toward the kettlebell side (like closing a car door with your butt) while keeping your arm locked overhead
Lower your torso down and away from the kettlebell, reaching your free hand toward the floor, until you feel a deep stretch in your side
Pause at the bottom, then drive through your hips to return to standing while keeping the kettlebell locked overhead the entire time
form_cues: Your eyes should never leave the kettlebell - if it moves out of your vision, you're losing position
Think about creating space between your ribcage and hip on the kettlebell side
The movement is a hip hinge, not a side bend - your hips should move laterally, not just tip forward
Keep your shoulder packed down away from your ear - imagine someone is pulling your shoulder blade down your back
common_mistakes: Bending the overhead arm - the elbow must stay locked for shoulder safety throughout the entire movement
Rushing the descent - this is a slow, controlled movement that requires constant tension and stability
Not maintaining hip drive - the power should come from pushing your hips, not just folding your torso
injury_prevention_tips: Master the regular kettlebell windmill (without weight in the bottom hand) before attempting this advanced variation
If your shoulder feels unstable or painful, reduce the weight immediately - this exercise requires excellent shoulder mobility

instructions: Lie flat on the floor with your lower back pressed to the ground. For this exercise, you will need to put your hands beside your head. Be careful however to not strain with the neck as you perform it. Now lift your shoulders into the crunch position.
Bring knees up to where they are perpendicular to the floor, with your lower legs parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position.

Now simultaneously, slowly go through a cycle pedal motion kicking forward with the right leg and bringing in the knee of the left leg. Bring your right elbow close to your left knee by crunching to the side, as you breathe out.
Go back to the initial position as you breathe in.
Crunch to the opposite side as you cycle your legs and bring closer your left elbow to your right knee and exhale.
Continue alternating in this manner until all of the recommended repetitions for each side have been completed.
exercises.name: Air Bike
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with hands beside your head (not pulling on it) and lift your shoulder blades off the ground into a crunch position
Raise your legs with knees bent at 90 degrees - imagine you're sitting in an invisible chair while lying down
Simultaneously extend your right leg straight out (like pedaling a bike) while bringing your left knee toward your chest and rotating your right elbow to meet it
Pause briefly when your elbow and opposite knee are closest, squeezing your obliques hard
Switch sides in a smooth pedaling motion, bringing your left elbow to your right knee while extending the left leg
form_cues: Think about driving your elbow across your body toward the opposite knee, not just twisting your shoulders
Your legs should move like you're pedaling a bike in slow motion - smooth and controlled
Keep your lower back pressed flat to the floor - imagine squashing a pancake underneath you
Exhale sharply each time your elbow and knee come together to maximize oblique contraction
common_mistakes: Pulling on your neck with your hands - keep your hands light and let your abs do all the work
Going too fast and losing the mind-muscle connection - slow down and feel each rep in your obliques
Letting your extended leg drop too low to the ground - keep it elevated to maintain constant ab tension
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel neck strain, place your hands across your chest instead or support your head with one hand at a time
Stop if you feel lower back pain - this likely means your abs are fatiguing and your back is compensating

instructions: Start off on your hands and knees, then lift your leg off the floor and hold the foot with your hand.
Use your hand to hold the foot or ankle, keeping the knee fully flexed, stretching the quadriceps and hip flexors.
Focus on extending your hips, thrusting them towards the floor. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.
exercises.name: All Fours Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position with your spine neutral
Reach back with one hand and grab your foot or ankle on the same side, bending your knee fully
Pull your heel toward your glute while simultaneously pushing your hips forward and down toward the floor - like you're trying to flatten your hips into the ground
Keep your supporting arm straight and your chest lifted to maximize the hip flexor stretch
Hold for 10-20 seconds, feeling the stretch along the front of your thigh and hip, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about driving your hips forward and down rather than just pulling your foot toward your butt
Your knee should point straight down to the floor, not out to the side
Keep your chest proud and shoulder blades pulled back - imagine you're showing off a logo on your shirt
Focus on the stretch in your hip flexor (front of hip) as much as your quad
common_mistakes: Only pulling the foot without pushing the hips forward - this limits the stretch effectiveness
Letting your shoulders round forward - this reduces the hip flexor component of the stretch
Forcing the knee into excessive flexion - if you have knee issues, don't pull your heel all the way to your glute
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel sharp pain in the front of your knee, reduce the amount you bend it and focus more on the hip drive
Keep your supporting wrist directly under your shoulder to avoid wrist strain

exercises.description: Hammer curl performed with dumbbells and one arm at a time
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
The palms of the hands should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the right weight forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Continue the movement until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat the movement with the left hand. This equals one repetition.
Continue alternating in this manner for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Alternate Hammer Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging straight down with palms facing your thighs (neutral grip)
Pin your elbows to your sides - imagine they're glued to your ribcage and can't move
Curl one dumbbell up by bending only at the elbow, keeping your palm facing inward the entire time, until the dumbbell reaches shoulder height
Squeeze your bicep and forearm hard at the top like you're trying to show off your arm, then slowly lower for 2-3 seconds
As one arm lowers, begin curling the other arm up, alternating in a smooth rhythm
form_cues: Think about driving your pinky finger up toward your shoulder to maximize bicep engagement
Keep your wrists straight and strong - imagine you're holding a hammer and driving a nail
Your torso should stay completely still - pretend you're pressed against a wall from head to heels
At the top, finish like you're flexing your bicep in the mirror - squeeze hard for maximum contraction
common_mistakes: Swinging your elbows forward or letting them drift away from your sides - this recruits your front delts instead of isolating your biceps
Using momentum by rocking your torso or leaning back - the movement should be pure arm, no body English
Dropping the weight too quickly on the way down - the lowering phase builds just as much muscle as the lifting phase
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel elbow pain, reduce the weight and ensure you're not hyperextending at the bottom of the movement
Keep tension on the bicep even at the bottom - don't let your arms go completely straight and loose

instructions: Lie on the floor with the knees bent and the feet on the floor around 18-24 inches apart. Your arms should be extended by your side. This will be your starting position.
Crunch over your torso forward and up about 3-4 inches to the right side and touch your right heel as you hold the contraction for a second. Exhale while performing this movement.
Now go back slowly to the starting position as you inhale.

Now crunch over your torso forward and up around 3-4 inches to the left side and touch your left heel as you hold the contraction for a second. Exhale while performing this movement and then go back to the starting position as you inhale. Now that both heels have been touched, that is considered 1 repetition.
Continue alternating sides in this manner until all prescribed repetitions are done.
exercises.name: Alternate Heel Touchers
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with knees bent, feet planted hip-width apart, arms straight by your sides like you're about to make a snow angel
Lift your shoulder blades off the ground like someone's gently pulling your chest toward the ceiling - keep your lower back glued down
Crunch to the right, sliding your right hand down to tap your right heel - imagine you're trying to touch your heel without moving your feet
Return to center with control, then immediately crunch left and tap your left heel - that's one full rep
Keep your neck neutral by imagining you're holding an orange under your chin throughout the movement
form_cues: Think 'shoulder to hip' not 'elbow to knee' - slide your hand straight down your side
Keep your abs tight like you're bracing for a punch the entire time
Exhale hard as you crunch to each side, like you're blowing out birthday candles
common_mistakes: Yanking the neck forward instead of lifting from the abs - keep that orange under your chin
Moving the feet or knees to meet the hands instead of crunching the torso
Rushing through reps without holding the contraction at each heel touch
injury_prevention_tips: Press your lower back into the floor throughout - no arching or space underneath
If you feel neck strain, place one hand behind your head for light support

instructions: Sit down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. Tip: Keep the elbows close to the torso.This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the right weight forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. As you do so, rotate the hand so that the palm is facing up. Continue the movement until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbell back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat the movement with the left hand. This equals one repetition.
Continue alternating in this manner for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Alternate Incline Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set an incline bench to 45-60 degrees and sit back with dumbbells hanging straight down, arms fully extended like a scarecrow
Pin your elbows to your sides and keep them there - imagine they're glued to your ribs
Curl one dumbbell up while rotating your palm to face the ceiling, like you're showing someone your watch at the top
Squeeze hard at the top for a full second - finish like a single-arm bicep pose
Lower with control, then repeat on the other side while keeping the resting arm completely still
form_cues: Let your arms hang back behind your torso at the start - feel that deep stretch in your biceps
Think 'curl to your shoulder' not 'curl to your face' - keep the movement tight
Squeeze your bicep at the top like you're crushing a walnut in your elbow crease
common_mistakes: Letting the elbow drift forward as you curl - this kills the stretch advantage of the incline
Using momentum or swinging the weights up instead of controlled curling
Not fully extending the arm at the bottom - you need that full stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - the incline makes this much harder than regular curls due to the stretch
Keep your back pressed firmly against the bench - no arching or leaning forward

instructions: Move the cables to the bottom of the tower and select an appropriate weight.
Grasp the cables and hold them at shoulder height, palms facing forward. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your head and chest up, extend through the elbow to press one side directly over head.
After pausing at the top, return to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Alternating Cable Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cables at the lowest position, grab both handles and bring them to shoulder height with palms forward
Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart, chest up like a proud superhero, core braced
Press one handle straight overhead following a slight arc back, like you're drawing a rainbow above your head
Lock out fully at the top with your bicep by your ear, pause for a beat
Lower with control back to shoulder height, then immediately press the other side
form_cues: Imagine pushing the ceiling away from you, not just lifting the handle up
Keep your ribs down - don't let them flare out as you press overhead
Think 'press through the roof' while keeping your shoulder blade pulled down and back
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively to help press the weight - keep your core tight
Pressing forward instead of straight up - the handle should finish over your head, not in front
Leaning or shifting weight from side to side - stay centered and stable
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your core like you're about to take a punch before each press
If you feel pinching in your shoulder, lower the weight or check that you're not shrugging

instructions: In a standing position, hold a pair of dumbbells at your side.
Keeping your elbows slightly bent, raise the weights directly in front of you to shoulder height, avoiding any swinging or cheating.
Return the weights to your side.
On the next repetition, raise the weights laterally, raising them out to your side to about shoulder height.
Return the weights to the starting position and continue alternating to the front and side.
exercises.name: Alternating Deltoid Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with dumbbells hanging at your sides, palms facing your thighs, slight bend in your elbows
First rep: raise both dumbbells straight out in front to shoulder height, like you're holding a serving tray
Lower controlled back to your sides, keeping tension in your shoulders the whole way down
Second rep: raise dumbbells out to your sides like you're making a 'T' shape with your body
Continue alternating: front raise, side raise, front raise, side raise throughout the set
form_cues: Lead with your elbows slightly higher than your hands - pour imaginary water pitchers out at the top
Keep your torso completely still like a statue - only your arms should move
Think 'lift with your elbows' not your hands to better engage your delts
common_mistakes: Using momentum or swinging the weights up by leaning back - this steals gains from your shoulders
Shrugging your traps at the top instead of keeping shoulders down and back
Raising the weights too high (above shoulder level) which shifts tension to your traps
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter weight than you think - your delts fatigue fast on this combo movement
Stop at shoulder height to keep constant tension on your delts and avoid shoulder impingement

instructions: Lie on the floor with two kettlebells next to your shoulders.
Position one in place on your chest and then the other, gripping the kettlebells on the handle with the palms facing forward.
Extend both arms, so that the kettlebells are being held above your chest. Lower one kettlebell, bringing it to your chest and turn the wrist in the direction of the locked out kettlebell.
Raise the kettlebell and repeat on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Alternating Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor and position two kettlebells on your chest, gripping the handles with palms facing forward
Press both kettlebells straight up to lockout, arms fully extended like you're bench pressing
Lower one kettlebell slowly until your elbow gently touches the floor, while the other stays locked out overhead
As you lower, slightly rotate your torso toward the locked-out side to stay stable
Press the lowered kettlebell back up, then immediately lower the opposite side and repeat
form_cues: Let your elbows kiss the floor gently - don't crash them down
Keep the locked-out arm actively pressing toward the ceiling like it's holding up the roof
Think 'chest up, shoulder blades pinched together' even though you're on the floor
common_mistakes: Letting the locked-out arm drift or lose tension while focusing on the working side
Bouncing elbows off the floor to generate momentum instead of controlled lowering
Flaring elbows out too wide (past 45 degrees) instead of keeping them at a press-friendly angle
injury_prevention_tips: The floor limits your range of motion naturally - use this to build pressing strength safely
Keep your core tight and don't let your lower back arch off the floor

instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder and hold on to the other kettlebell in a hanging position. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so.
Lower the cleaned kettlebell to a hanging position and clean the alternate kettlebell. Repeat.
exercises.name: Alternating Hang Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with two kettlebells between your feet, hinge at the hips pushing your butt back like you're closing a car door with it
Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder using an explosive hip thrust and pull - catch it in the rack position
Hold the cleaned kettlebell at your shoulder while the other hangs down in a dead hang
Lower the racked kettlebell back to the hanging position with control
Immediately clean the opposite kettlebell to your other shoulder and repeat the alternating pattern
form_cues: Think 'explode through your hips' like you're jumping - the power comes from your lower body, not your arms
Imagine your arm is a rope and the kettlebell is a weight at the end - let your hips do the pulling
Catch the kettlebell softly in the rack position like you're cradling a baby on your shoulder
common_mistakes: Arm curling the weight up instead of letting hip drive generate the power
Starting with a rounded back instead of maintaining a flat, neutral spine
Not rotating the wrist at the top - the kettlebell should rest comfortably on your forearm
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight throughout like you're wearing a weightlifting belt
Master the hip hinge pattern with lighter weight before adding explosive speed

instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.
Press one directly overhead by extending through the elbow, turning it so the palm faces forward while holding the other kettlebell stationary .
Lower the pressed kettlebell to the starting position and immediately press with your other arm.
exercises.name: Alternating Kettlebell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to the rack position at your shoulders, elbows tucked close to your ribs
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, core braced like you're about to get punched
Press one kettlebell straight overhead by extending your elbow and rotating your palm forward at the top
Lock out completely with your bicep by your ear while keeping the other kettlebell stable at shoulder height
Lower the pressed kettlebell back to the rack position and immediately press the opposite side
form_cues: Think 'punch through the ceiling' with an aggressive press, not a gentle lift
Keep your ribs down and core tight - imagine you're wearing a corset that won't let you arch
The non-working kettlebell should stay glued to the rack position like it's velcroed there
common_mistakes: Arching the back or leaning away from the working side to help press the weight
Losing tension in the racked kettlebell by letting it drift away from the shoulder
Pressing on an angle instead of straight up - track should be vertical from shoulder to overhead
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your entire body before each press - treat it like a full-body tension exercise
Don't let the kettlebell roll back onto your wrist - keep a neutral wrist throughout

instructions: Place two kettlebells in front of your feet. Bend your knees slightly and push your butt out as much as possible. As you bend over to get into the starting position grab both kettlebells by the handles.

Pull one kettlebell off of the floor while holding on to the other kettlebell. Retract the shoulder blade of the working side, as you flex the elbow, drawing the kettlebell towards your stomach or rib cage.
Lower the kettlebell in the working arm and repeat with your other arm.
exercises.name: Alternating Kettlebell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two kettlebells in front of your feet, hinge at the hips pushing your butt way back with knees slightly bent
Grab both kettlebell handles with a flat back - imagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
Row one kettlebell up toward your hip/ribcage by pulling your elbow back like you're starting a lawnmower
Squeeze your shoulder blade toward your spine at the top and hold for a beat
Lower controlled, then immediately row the other side while keeping your torso still and stable
form_cues: Think 'elbow to back pocket' - drive the elbow back and slightly up, not out wide
Keep the non-working kettlebell planted on the ground for stability, like a kickstand
Imagine crushing a walnut between your shoulder blade and spine at the top of each row
common_mistakes: Rotating the torso or rocking back and forth to help row the weight
Pulling with the bicep instead of initiating the movement with the shoulder blade
Letting the lower back round - maintain that flat, neutral spine throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced the entire time like you're doing a plank
If your lower back gets tired, reduce the weight or take a brief rest - form is critical here

instructions: Place two kettlebells on the floor about shoulder width apart. Position yourself on your toes and your hands as though you were doing a pushup, with the body straight and extended. Use the handles of the kettlebells to support your upper body. You may need to position your feet wide for support.
Push one kettlebell into the floor and row the other kettlebell, retracting the shoulder blade of the working side as you flex the elbow, pulling it to your side.
Then lower the kettlebell to the floor and begin the kettlebell in the opposite hand. Repeat for several reps.
exercises.name: Alternating Renegade Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up in a push-up position with hands gripping two kettlebells, body straight from head to heels like a plank
Widen your feet for stability - think of creating a tripod with your feet and working hand
Push one kettlebell hard into the floor while rowing the other up to your ribcage, pulling your elbow back
Keep your hips square to the ground - imagine you're balancing a glass of water on your lower back
Lower the kettlebell with control and immediately row the opposite side
form_cues: Squeeze your glutes hard to keep your hips level - pretend you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Think 'anti-rotation' - fight the twist with your entire core as you row
Press the grounded kettlebell into the floor like you're doing a one-arm push-up hold
common_mistakes: Hips rotating or sagging as you row - this turns it into a twisting row instead of an anti-rotation exercise
Rowing with a rounded upper back instead of maintaining perfect plank posture
Feet too close together, making it nearly impossible to stay stable
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular kettlebell rows and planks separately before combining them in this exercise
If your hips sag, widen your stance more or drop to your knees until you build more core strength

instructions: Use a sturdy object like a squat rack to hold yourself.

Lift the right leg in the air (just around 2 inches from the floor) and perform a circular motion with the big toe. Pretend that you are drawing a big circle with it. Tip: One circle equals 1 repetition. Breathe normally as you perform the movement.
When you are done with the right foot, then repeat with the left leg.
exercises.name: Ankle Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand near a wall or sturdy object for balance, hold on with one or both hands
Lift one foot slightly off the ground (just 2-3 inches), keeping your leg straight but not locked
Draw big circles in the air with your big toe, like you're tracing the edge of a dinner plate
Complete all reps in one direction (clockwise), then switch to the other direction (counterclockwise)
Switch feet and repeat the same pattern on the other ankle
form_cues: Make the circles as big as possible - really exaggerate the range of motion
Keep your leg still and let all the movement come from your ankle joint
Imagine your big toe has a marker and you're trying to draw a perfect circle on a wall
common_mistakes: Making tiny circles instead of using the full range of motion in your ankle
Moving your entire leg instead of isolating just the ankle joint
Going too fast - slow, controlled circles are more effective for mobility
injury_prevention_tips: This is a mobility drill, not strength training - there should be zero pain
If you feel sharp pain or clicking, reduce the circle size and see a professional if it persists

instructions: From a lying position, bend your knees and keep your feet on the floor.
Place your ankle of one foot on your opposite knee.
Grasp the thigh or knee of the bottom leg and pull both of your legs into the chest. Relax your neck and shoulders. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Ankle On The Knee
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with both knees bent and feet flat on the floor
Place your right ankle on top of your left knee, letting your right knee fall open to the side - like you're sitting cross-legged but lying down
Reach through the triangle gap created by your legs and clasp both hands behind your left thigh
Gently pull your left thigh toward your chest until you feel a stretch deep in your right glute
Hold for 10-20 seconds breathing deeply, then switch sides
form_cues: Keep your head and shoulders relaxed on the floor - don't tense your neck
Your right knee should point away from your body at about 45 degrees
Think about pulling your knee closer to your opposite shoulder rather than straight to your chest
The stretch should be felt deep in your glute, like you're opening up your hip socket
common_mistakes: Lifting your head and shoulders off the ground - this creates unnecessary neck tension
Not letting the top knee fall open enough - your hip needs to externally rotate for an effective stretch
Pulling too aggressively - this stretch should be gentle and sustained, not forced
injury_prevention_tips: If you have knee issues, hold behind your thigh instead of in front of your shin to reduce knee joint stress
Stop immediately if you feel pinching in the front of your hip - this may indicate impingement

instructions: Begin seated on the ground with your legs bent and your feet on the floor.

Using a Muscle Roller or a rolling pin, apply pressure to the muscles on the outside of your shins. Work from just below the knee to above the ankle, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.
exercises.name: Anterior Tibialis-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the ground with your knees bent and feet flat, holding a muscle roller or rolling pin
Place the roller on the outside front of your shin (the muscle that runs alongside your shin bone)
Apply moderate pressure and slowly roll from just below your knee down to just above your ankle
When you find a tender spot, pause and hold pressure for 10-30 seconds while taking deep breaths
Complete the entire shin on one leg before switching to the other
form_cues: The muscle is on the outside edge of your shin bone, not directly on the bone itself
Roll very slowly - about 1 inch per second - to allow the tissue to respond
Think about pressing into the muscle, not just rolling over it quickly
Your foot should be relaxed throughout - let it hang loose
common_mistakes: Rolling directly on the shin bone - this is painful and ineffective, stay on the muscle to the outside
Going too fast - rapid rolling doesn't allow the muscle to release tension
Using too much pressure initially - start light and gradually increase as the muscle relaxes
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid this if you have shin splints currently healing - wait until acute pain subsides
If you feel sharp, shooting pain, stop immediately - you may be on a nerve

instructions: Place a bar on the ground behind the head of an incline bench.
Lay on the bench face down. With a pronated grip, pick the barbell up from the floor. Flex the elbows, performing a reverse curl to bring the bar near your chest. This will be your starting position.
To begin, press the barbell out in front of your head by extending your elbows. Keep your arms parallel to the ground throughout the movement.
Return to the starting position and repeat to complete the set.
exercises.name: Anti-Gravity Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up an incline bench and lie face down on it with a barbell on the floor behind the top of the bench
Reach down and grab the bar with an overhand grip, then reverse curl it up so the bar is near your chest with elbows bent
Your upper arms should be parallel to the ground, pointing forward - this is your starting position
Press the bar straight forward by extending your elbows, keeping your arms parallel to the floor the entire time
Slowly return the bar to your chest and repeat, keeping constant tension throughout
form_cues: Imagine you're punching the bar straight forward, not pressing it up or down
Your upper arms should stay glued at shoulder height - like they're on railroad tracks
Keep your chest pressed into the bench throughout - don't let your torso lift
Think about squeezing your shoulder blades together as you press forward
common_mistakes: Letting your arms drift upward or downward - they must stay perfectly parallel to the ground
Using momentum by bouncing off your chest - the movement should be slow and controlled
Lifting your chest off the bench - this turns it into a different exercise and reduces shoulder engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight to master the movement pattern - this is an unusual angle for your shoulders
If you feel shoulder pain, reduce the weight and check that your arms stay parallel to the ground

instructions: Stand up and extend your arms straight out by the sides. The arms should be parallel to the floor and perpendicular (90-degree angle) to your torso. This will be your starting position.
Slowly start to make circles of about 1 foot in diameter with each outstretched arm. Breathe normally as you perform the movement.
Continue the circular motion of the outstretched arms for about ten seconds. Then reverse the movement, going the opposite direction.
exercises.name: Arm Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with your arms extended straight out to your sides at shoulder height - make a T-shape with your body
Keep your arms completely straight and locked out
Make small circles (about 12 inches in diameter) with your hands, moving forward like you're stirring two pots
After 10 seconds, reverse direction and circle backward
Gradually increase circle size if desired, or keep them small for shoulder activation
form_cues: Your arms should stay perfectly parallel to the floor - imagine they're resting on a table
Think about creating tension in your shoulders, not just loosely swinging your arms
Keep your palms facing down and fingers extended - don't make fists
Your torso should stay completely still - only your arms move
common_mistakes: Letting your arms drop below shoulder height - this reduces the effectiveness
Making circles that are too large too quickly - start small and build up
Shrugging your shoulders up toward your ears - keep them down and relaxed
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel shoulder impingement or pinching, reduce the circle size or lower your arms slightly
Keep movements smooth and controlled - jerky movements can strain the rotator cuff

instructions: Sit on an exercise bench with back support and hold two dumbbells in front of you at about upper chest level with your palms facing your body and your elbows bent. Tip: Your arms should be next to your torso. The starting position should look like the contracted portion of a dumbbell curl.
Now to perform the movement, raise the dumbbells as you rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward.
Continue lifting the dumbbells until your arms are extended above you in straight arm position. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement.

After a second pause at the top, begin to lower the dumbbells to the original position by rotating the palms of your hands towards you. Tip: The left arm will be rotated in a counter clockwise manner while the right one will be rotated clockwise. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Arnold Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support holding dumbbells at chest height with palms facing you - like you just finished a bicep curl
As you press up, simultaneously rotate your wrists outward so your palms turn forward
Press all the way overhead until your arms are fully extended and palms face forward
Reverse the motion by rotating your palms back toward you as you lower, finishing back at the curl position
The rotation should be smooth and continuous throughout the entire press
form_cues: Think about unscrewing a jar lid as you press up - your hands rotate outward smoothly
Your elbows should stay in front of your body at the bottom, not flared out to the sides
At the top, your biceps should be by your ears - don't stop the press short
The rotation creates a longer range of motion than a regular press - use the full arc
common_mistakes: Rotating too quickly at the bottom instead of smoothly throughout - the rotation should be gradual
Using too much weight - this exercise requires control, start lighter than a standard press
Not fully extending overhead - complete the press with arms locked out at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced and back against the bench to prevent arching your lower back
If you feel shoulder clicking or pain during rotation, reduce weight and slow down the movement

instructions: Lay down on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand with the palms of the hands facing towards the ceiling. Tip: Your arms should be parallel to the floor and next to your thighs. To avoid injury, make sure that you keep your elbows slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now move the dumbbells by creating a semi-circle as you displace them from the initial position to over the head. All of the movement should happen with the arms parallel to the floor at all times. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Reverse the movement to return the weight to the starting position as you exhale.
exercises.name: Around The Worlds
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding light dumbbells with arms extended out to your sides at shoulder height, palms facing up
Keep a slight bend in your elbows (like you're hugging a beach ball) and lock them there
Sweep the dumbbells in a wide arc up and over your head, keeping your arms parallel to the floor throughout
Continue the arc until the dumbbells meet above your head, then reverse to bring them back to the starting position
The movement should look like you're drawing a semicircle in the air
form_cues: Think about moving the weights in a perfect rainbow arc from side to side
Your arms should stay at the same height (parallel to floor) the entire time - don't let them dip or rise
Keep your chest up and shoulder blades pulled back against the bench
The movement is slow and controlled - this isn't a swinging motion
common_mistakes: Using too much weight - this is a chest stretch/pump exercise, not a heavy pressing movement
Letting arms drift upward toward the ceiling - they should stay parallel to the ground
Straightening arms completely - keep elbows slightly bent to protect the joint
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight - 5-10 lbs per hand is plenty for most people
If you feel shoulder strain, reduce the range of motion and don't go past your head

instructions: Run a band around a stationary post like that of a squat rack.
Grab the band by the handles and stand back so that the tension in the band rises.

Extend and lift the arms straight in front of you. Tip: Your arms should be straight and parallel to the floor while perpendicular to your torso. Your feet should be firmly planted on the floor spread at shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, move your arms to the sides and back. Keep your arms extended and parallel to the floor. Continue the movement until the arms are extended to your sides.
After a pause, go back to the original position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Back Flyes - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a resistance band to a sturdy post at chest height and grab both handles
Step back until there's tension in the band with arms extended straight in front of you at shoulder height
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, core braced, arms parallel to the ground
Pull the handles out to your sides and back, keeping your arms straight like you're opening a curtain
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end, pause, then return to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about pinching a pencil between your shoulder blades at the peak contraction
Your arms should move in a horizontal plane - don't let them rise up or drop down
Lead with your elbows, pulling them back behind your body
Keep your chest up and proud throughout - imagine showing off a logo on your shirt
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows during the movement - arms should stay straight (slight bend is OK)
Letting arms drift upward or downward - maintain shoulder height throughout
Using momentum by rocking your torso - your body should stay completely still
injury_prevention_tips: Don't overstretch at the end - stop when your hands are in line with your body or slightly behind
If you feel front shoulder pain, reduce band tension and focus on controlled movement

instructions: Place a balance board in front of you.
Stand up on it and try to balance yourself.
Hold the balance for as long as desired.
exercises.name: Balance Board
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the balance board on a flat, non-slip surface with plenty of clear space around you
Step onto the board one foot at a time, placing your feet about shoulder-width apart near the center
Bend your knees slightly and keep your core engaged - imagine you're trying to balance on a surfboard
Focus your eyes on a fixed point straight ahead (not down at your feet) to help maintain balance
Try to keep the board level without letting the edges touch the ground
form_cues: Make tiny micro-adjustments with your ankles and feet rather than big movements
Think about spreading your weight evenly through the entire sole of your foot
Keep your arms out to the sides for balance - like a tightrope walker
Your core should be tight like someone's about to push you - this is key for stability
common_mistakes: Looking down at your feet - this throws off your balance, keep eyes forward
Standing too stiff and rigid - you need slight knee bend and flexibility to adjust
Placing feet too close together - wider stance provides more stability when learning
injury_prevention_tips: Start near a wall or sturdy object you can grab if needed
Wear shoes with good grip if you're a beginner - barefoot is fine once you're comfortable

instructions: Begin on the floor laying on your back with your feet on top of the ball.
Position the ball so that when your legs are extended your ankles are on top of the ball. This will be your starting position.
Raise your hips off of the ground, keeping your weight on the shoulder blades and your feet.
Flex the knees, pulling the ball as close to you as you can, contracting the hamstrings.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Ball Leg Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with your heels on top of an exercise ball and arms at your sides for stability
Lift your hips off the ground until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to feet - this is your starting position
Keeping your hips elevated, dig your heels into the ball and pull it toward your butt by bending your knees
Squeeze your hamstrings hard at the peak when the ball is closest to you
Slowly extend your legs to roll the ball back out while keeping your hips up the entire time
form_cues: Think about digging your heels down into the ball as you curl it in
Your hips should stay high throughout - imagine someone has a string pulling your hips toward the ceiling
Squeeze your glutes to help keep your hips elevated
At the peak, your shins should be nearly vertical with knees pointing straight up
common_mistakes: Letting hips drop or sag during the curl - this takes tension off the hamstrings
Curling the ball too far under you - your feet should stay on top of the ball, not roll underneath
Going too fast - control the ball on both the curl and extension phases
injury_prevention_tips: If you get cramping in your hamstrings, reduce the range of motion and build up gradually
Keep your neck relaxed on the floor - don't strain by lifting your head

instructions: Choke the band around the center of the pullup bar. You can use different bands to provide varying levels of assistance.
Pull the end of the band down, and place one bent knee into the loop, ensuring it won't slip out. Take a medium to wide grip on the bar. This will be your starting position.

Pull yourself upward by contracting the lats as you flex the elbow. The elbow should be driven to your side. Pull to the front, attempting to get your chin over the bar. Avoid swinging or jerking movements.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Band Assisted Pull-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Loop a resistance band over a pull-up bar and pull one end through the other to secure it
Place one knee (or foot) into the hanging loop - the band will provide upward assistance
Grab the bar with a medium-wide overhand grip, hang with arms fully extended
Pull yourself up by driving your elbows down to your sides, thinking about pulling the bar to your chest
Get your chin over the bar, pause briefly, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows into your back pockets rather than just bending your arms
Lead with your chest - imagine trying to touch your chest to the bar
Keep your core tight and avoid swinging or kicking - pretend your legs are cement blocks
At the bottom, come to a dead hang with arms fully straight before starting the next rep
common_mistakes: Using momentum by swinging your body - each rep should start from a dead stop
Not going to full extension at the bottom - partial reps don't build full strength
Craning your neck to get your chin over - lead with your chest, your chin follows naturally
injury_prevention_tips: Use a thicker band for more assistance if you can't maintain good form for at least 5 reps
If you feel shoulder pain, check your grip width - too wide can cause impingement

instructions: Using a 41 inch band, stand on one end, spreading your feet a small amount. Bend at the hips to loop the end of the band behind your neck. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your legs straight, extend through the hips to come to a near vertical position.
Ensure that you do not round your back as you go down back to the starting position.
exercises.name: Band Good Morning
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on one end of a band with feet hip-width apart, loop the other end behind your neck and hold it in place
Stand tall with chest up, core braced, and a slight bend in your knees - this is your starting position
Push your hips back like you're closing a car door with your butt, hinging forward until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground
Keep your back flat like a table throughout - imagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
Drive through your heels and thrust your hips forward to stand back up tall, squeezing your glutes hard at the top
form_cues: Think 'hips back first' not 'bend over' - the movement starts at your hips, not your waist
Keep the band tension constant by maintaining a proud chest throughout the movement
Squeeze your glutes at the top like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back instead of maintaining a neutral spine throughout
Bending the knees too much, turning it into a squat instead of a hip hinge
Leading with the shoulders instead of pushing the hips back first
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light band tension to master the hip hinge pattern before progressing
Stop immediately if you feel any lower back pain - this should feel like a hamstring and glute stretch

instructions: Loop the band around a post. Standing a little ways away, loop the opposite end around the neck. Your hands can help hold the band in position.
Begin by bending at the hips, getting your butt back as far as possible. Keep your back flat and bend forward to about 90 degrees. Your knees should be only slightly bent.
Return to the starting position be driving through with the hips to come back to a standing position.
exercises.name: Band Good Morning (Pull Through)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Loop a band around a sturdy post at ground level, stand facing away and loop the other end around your neck
Walk forward until you feel tension, then stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hands helping hold the band in place
Push your hips way back like you're trying to touch the wall behind you with your butt, hinging to about 90 degrees
Keep your back flat and knees only slightly bent - feel the stretch in your hamstrings
Drive your hips forward explosively to return to standing, fighting against the band trying to pull you backward
form_cues: Imagine someone has a rope tied to your hips pulling you backward - resist it by driving forward
Think 'push the floor away with your heels' as you stand up, not just 'stand up straight'
Keep your chest proud and shoulders back like you're showing off a medal
common_mistakes: Rounding the spine instead of maintaining a neutral, flat back position
Not getting the hips back far enough - your butt should move way behind your heels
Using the arms to help instead of keeping them relaxed and letting the hips do all the work
injury_prevention_tips: The band pulling you creates instability - start with light tension until you master balance
Brace your core tight like you're wearing a weightlifting belt throughout the entire movement

instructions: Anchor a band around a solid post or other object.
Stand with your left side to the post, and put your right foot through the band, getting it around the ankle.
Stand up straight and hold onto the post if needed. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the knee straight, raise your right legs out to the side as far as you can.
Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired rep count.
Switch sides.
exercises.name: Band Hip Adductions
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a band around a post at ankle height, stand with your left side to the post
Put your right foot through the band around your ankle, stand up straight holding the post for balance
Start with your right leg slightly out to the side with tension on the band - this is your starting position
Keeping your leg straight, sweep it across your body past your standing leg as far as comfortable
Control the return back to the starting position, fighting the band resistance the entire way
form_cues: Think 'sweep across the floor' like you're pushing something with the inside of your foot
Keep your hips square and facing forward - don't let them rotate as you move your leg
Squeeze your inner thigh at the peak of the movement like you're trying to hold a coin between your legs
common_mistakes: Rotating the hips or leaning away to help swing the leg - stay tall and stable
Bending the working knee instead of keeping it straight throughout
Going too fast and using momentum instead of controlled, deliberate movement
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light resistance - your adductors are smaller muscles that fatigue quickly
Hold onto something stable throughout - this is about isolation, not balance training

instructions: Begin with your arms extended straight out in front of you, holding the band with both hands.
Initiate the movement by performing a reverse fly motion, moving your hands out laterally to your sides.
Keep your elbows extended as you perform the movement, bringing the band to your chest. Ensure that you keep your shoulders back during the exercise.
Pause as you complete the movement, returning to the starting position under control.
exercises.name: Band Pull Apart
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a resistance band with both hands at shoulder height, arms extended straight out in front of you
Grip the band with hands about shoulder-width apart, palms facing down or toward each other
Pull the band apart by moving your hands out to your sides in a reverse fly motion, bringing the band to your chest
Keep your elbows locked and shoulders pulled back - imagine pinching a pencil between your shoulder blades
Control the return to starting position, maintaining tension on the band the entire time
form_cues: Think 'break the band in half' by pulling straight apart, not down or up
Keep your shoulders down and back like you're tucking them into your back pockets
Imagine you're trying to touch your elbows behind your back at the end of the movement
common_mistakes: Shrugging the shoulders up toward the ears instead of keeping them depressed
Bending the elbows to make the movement easier - keep them locked throughout
Using too much resistance and compensating with body lean or momentum
injury_prevention_tips: This is a postural exercise - use lighter resistance and focus on the squeeze at the end
Keep your core engaged to prevent arching your lower back as you pull

exercises.description: Skullcrusher performed with bands
instructions: Secure a band to the base of a rack or the bench. Lay on the bench so that the band is lined up with your head.
Take hold of the band, raising your elbows so that the upper arm is perpendicular to the floor. With the elbow flexed, the band should be above your head. This will be your starting position.
Extend through the elbow to straighten your arm, keeping your upper arm in place. Pause at the top of the motion, and return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Band Skullcrusher
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a band to the base of a bench or rack, lie on the bench with the band lined up behind your head
Grab the band with both hands and raise your upper arms perpendicular to the floor, elbows bent so the band is above your forehead
Keep your upper arms completely still and extend your elbows to straighten your arms overhead
Pause at full extension with arms locked out, squeezing your triceps hard
Lower back down with control, stopping just before the band touches your forehead
form_cues: Think 'elbows glued to the ceiling' - only your forearms should move, upper arms stay fixed
Squeeze your triceps at the top like you're flexing for a photo - full contraction
Imagine you're pushing something heavy away from your forehead, not just extending your arms
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows flare out to the sides instead of keeping them tight and pointing up
Moving the upper arms back and forth - they should remain perpendicular to the floor
Not getting full extension at the top - you need to lock out completely for max tricep engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light band resistance - the constant tension makes this harder than it looks
If you feel elbow discomfort, slightly angle your upper arms back toward your head (not perfectly vertical)

exercises.description: Skullcrusher performed with dumbbells
instructions: Hold the dumbbells and lay down on a flat bench in such a way that around 1/4 of your head is over the edge.
Stretch your arms with the weights and bend them so that the dumbbells are lowered (make sure they don't touch each other).
Just before they touch your forehead, push them up.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Skullcrusher
tips: Pay attention to your elbows and arms: only the triceps are doing the work, the rest of the arms should not move
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with about 1/4 of your head hanging over the edge, dumbbells held above your chest
Press the dumbbells up so your arms are fully extended, then keep your upper arms still in that vertical position
Bend at the elbows to lower the dumbbells down toward your forehead in an arc, stopping just before they touch
Keep your upper arms locked in place - imagine they're in a cast and can't move
Press the dumbbells back up by extending your elbows until your arms are straight again
form_cues: Think 'hinge at the elbow only' - your upper arms should stay frozen pointing at the ceiling
Lower the weights on either side of your head like you're framing your face
Squeeze your triceps hard at the top like you're showing off your horseshoe muscle
common_mistakes: Letting the upper arms drift back toward your head as you lower - keep them vertical
Banging the dumbbells together at the top - keep them parallel, not touching
Going too heavy and having to move the upper arms to help - this kills tricep isolation
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than you think - this exercise puts significant stress on the elbow joint
If you feel sharp elbow pain, reduce weight or switch to a different tricep exercise

instructions: For this exercise you will need to get into a pushup position, but instead of having your hands of the floor, you will be grabbing on to an Olympic barbell (loaded with 5-10 lbs on each side) instead. This will be your starting position.

While keeping a slight arch on your back, lift your hips and roll the barbell towards your feet as you exhale. Tip: As you perform the movement, your glutes should be coming up, you should be keeping the abs tight and should maintain your back posture at all times. Also your arms should be staying perpendicular to the floor throughout the movement. If you don't, you will work out your shoulders and back more than the abs.
After a second contraction at the top, start to roll the barbell back forward to the starting position slowly as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Ab Rollout
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load a barbell with 5-10lb plates on each side, get into a push-up position with hands gripping the barbell
Start with the barbell under your shoulders, body in a straight plank position from head to heels
Keeping your core braced tight, roll the barbell forward by lifting your hips up and back, like a pike position
Your arms should stay perpendicular to the floor as you roll - don't let them angle back
Contract your abs hard at the top, then slowly roll the barbell back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'pull the barbell toward your feet' with your abs, not your arms or shoulders
Keep your abs tight like you're bracing for a punch throughout the entire movement
Imagine you're doing a pike yoga pose - hips go up and back, not down toward the floor
common_mistakes: Rolling forward instead of lifting the hips up and back - this makes it a shoulder exercise
Letting the lower back sag or arch - maintain that rigid plank position
Using momentum or bouncing at the top instead of controlled, deliberate movement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced so tight you could take a punch - no relaxing at any point
If this bothers your lower back, you may be arching - focus on posterior pelvic tilt

instructions: Hold an Olympic barbell loaded with 5-10lbs on each side and kneel on the floor.
Now place the barbell on the floor in front of you so that you are on all your hands and knees (as in a kneeling push up position). This will be your starting position.

Slowly roll the barbell straight forward, stretching your body into a straight position. Tip: Go down as far as you can without touching the floor with your body. Breathe in during this portion of the movement.
After a second pause at the stretched position, start pulling yourself back to the starting position as you breathe out. Tip: Go slowly and keep your abs tight at all times.
exercises.name: Barbell Ab Rollout - On Knees
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load a barbell with 5-10lb plates, kneel on the floor and place your hands on the barbell directly under your shoulders
Start in a kneeling position with your body in a straight line from knees to head, core braced tight
Slowly roll the barbell forward, extending your body while keeping your knees planted on the ground
Go as far forward as you can without letting your hips sag or your body touch the floor
Pause at full extension, then pull yourself back to the starting position using your abs, not your arms
form_cues: Think 'push the barbell away' as you roll out, like you're trying to reach something far away
Keep your abs braced so tight you could withstand a punch to the stomach
Imagine a string pulling your belly button toward your spine - maintain that tension throughout
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag toward the floor as you extend - this strains your lower back
Using the arms to pull back instead of contracting the abs to drag yourself back
Going too far too soon - start with smaller ranges and build up as you get stronger
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced ab exercise - if you can't maintain a flat back, reduce your range of motion
Breathe out forcefully as you pull back to help engage your core maximally

exercises.description: Bench press performed with a medium grip on a barbell
instructions: Lie back on a flat bench. Using a medium width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
From the starting position, breathe in and begin coming down slowly until the bar touches your middle chest.

After a brief pause, push the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out. Focus on pushing the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position at the top of the motion, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: Ideally, lowering the weight should take about twice as long as raising it.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench, grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width, creating a 90-degree angle at the elbow when the bar is on your chest
Unrack the bar and hold it directly over your chest with arms locked, shoulder blades pinched together
Lower the bar slowly and controlled to touch your mid-chest, keeping your elbows at about a 45-degree angle to your body
Press the bar back up explosively, driving through your chest muscles until your arms are fully locked
Pause briefly at the top, squeeze your chest hard like you're doing a double bicep pose, then repeat
form_cues: Think 'bend the bar' by trying to pull the ends apart - this engages your lats and keeps you tight
Imagine pushing yourself into the bench, not just pushing the bar up
Keep your feet glued to the floor and drive through them - leg drive helps stabilize
common_mistakes: Bouncing the bar off your chest instead of controlled touch-and-press
Flaring elbows out to 90 degrees - this puts excessive stress on your shoulders
Lifting your butt off the bench to help press the weight - keep your glutes down
injury_prevention_tips: Always use a spotter when lifting heavy or near failure
Keep your shoulder blades retracted and depressed throughout - this protects your shoulders

exercises.description: A biceps curl performed with a barbell
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a barbell at a shoulder-width grip. The palm of your hands should be facing forward and the elbows should be close to the torso. This will be your starting position.
While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a barbell with an underhand grip at shoulder-width
Start with arms fully extended, elbows tucked close to your sides, barbell resting against your thighs
Keep your upper arms completely still and curl the bar up by bending at the elbows, contracting your biceps hard
Continue curling until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level
Squeeze hard at the top for one second, then lower the bar slowly and controlled back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'elbows pinned to your ribs' - they shouldn't move forward or backward at all
Squeeze your biceps at the top like you're flexing for a photo - really contract them hard
Lower the weight taking twice as long as the curl up - that eccentric phase builds muscle
common_mistakes: Swinging the weight up by leaning back or using momentum - keep your torso upright and still
Letting the elbows drift forward as you curl - they should stay locked by your sides
Not fully extending at the bottom - you need that full range of motion for maximum gains
injury_prevention_tips: Don't use your wrists to curl - keep them straight and neutral throughout
If you feel pain in your elbows, reduce weight or try an EZ-bar for a more joint-friendly angle

instructions: Lie against an incline bench, with your arms holding a barbell and hanging down in a horizontal line. This will be your starting position.

While keeping the upper arms stationary, curl the weight up as high as you can while squeezing the biceps. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Only the forearms should move. Do not swing the arms.
After a second contraction, slowly go back to the starting position as you inhale. Tip: Make sure that you go all of the way down.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an incline bench set at about 45-60 degrees with a barbell in your hands, arms hanging straight down
Your upper arms should be perpendicular to the floor, not resting against your body
Keeping your upper arms completely still, curl the barbell up by bending only at the elbows
Squeeze your biceps hard at the top when your forearms are nearly vertical
Lower the bar slowly back to the starting position until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about pinning your upper arms in space - they should be frozen like steel beams
At the top, squeeze like you're trying to touch your biceps to your forearms
Your elbows should stay pointing straight down to the floor throughout - don't let them drift forward
Lower the weight taking 2-3 seconds to maximize the stretch in your biceps at the bottom
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows drift forward as you curl - this recruits your front delts instead of isolating biceps
Not going to full extension at the bottom - partial reps limit growth and strength
Using momentum by rocking your body - your torso should stay glued to the bench
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - the incline makes this significantly harder than standing curls
If you feel elbow pain, ensure you're not hyperextending at the bottom - stop just short of lockout

instructions: Stand in front of a loaded barbell.

While keeping the back as straight as possible, bend your knees, bend forward and grasp the bar using a medium (shoulder width) overhand grip. This will be the starting position of the exercise. Tip: If it is difficult to hold on to the bar with this grip, alternate your grip or use wrist straps.

While holding the bar, start the lift by pushing with your legs while simultaneously getting your torso to the upright position as you breathe out. In the upright position, stick your chest out and contract the back by bringing the shoulder blades back. Think of how the soldiers in the military look when they are in standing in attention.

Go back to the starting position by bending at the knees while simultaneously leaning the torso forward at the waist while keeping the back straight. When the weights on the bar touch the floor you are back at the starting position and ready to perform another repetition.
Perform the amount of repetitions prescribed in the program.
exercises.name: Barbell Deadlift
