beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, barbell over the middle of your feet (bar should be about 1 inch from your shins)
Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grip the bar just outside your legs with an overhand grip
Set your back flat, chest up, and shoulders slightly in front of the bar - imagine you're showing off a logo on your chest
Drive through your entire foot (especially heels) and stand up by extending your hips and knees simultaneously - think about pushing the floor away
At the top, stand tall with shoulders back and hips fully extended, then reverse the motion to lower the bar back down
form_cues: The bar should travel in a straight vertical line, brushing your shins and thighs as it goes up
Think about 'pushing the floor away' rather than 'pulling the bar up' - this keeps proper mechanics
Keep the bar close to your body the entire time - imagine you're zipping up a tight jacket
Your hips and shoulders should rise at the same rate - don't shoot your hips up first
common_mistakes: Letting your back round - this is dangerous and puts all stress on your spine instead of your muscles
Starting with hips too low (like a squat) or too high - hips should be above knees but below shoulders
Letting the bar drift away from your body - this creates massive leverage disadvantage and back strain
injury_prevention_tips: Master the hip hinge pattern with lighter weight before loading heavy - your back position is everything
If you feel sharp lower back pain, stop immediately and check your form - slight soreness is normal, sharp pain is not

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack just above shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder-width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position.

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and sitting back with your hips as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your hamstrings are on your calves. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel or middle of your foot as you straighten the legs and extend the hips to go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Full Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the barbell on a rack at upper chest height, step under it and position it across your upper traps (not your neck)
Grip the bar firmly, lift it off the rack by standing up, and step back with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out
Take a deep breath, brace your core hard, and descend by pushing your hips back and bending your knees
Go all the way down until your hip crease is below your knee (full squat depth) or hamstrings touch calves
Drive through your midfoot and heels to stand back up, keeping your chest proud throughout
form_cues: Think about sitting back into a chair that's too far behind you - this keeps your weight on your heels
Your knees should track over your toes - don't let them cave inward like you're knocking your knees together
Keep your chest up by imagining a string pulling your sternum toward the ceiling
At the bottom, your knees will go forward over your toes - this is normal and safe in a full squat
common_mistakes: Letting your knees cave inward (valgus collapse) - this stresses the knee joint, push them out actively
Rounding your lower back at the bottom - maintain your neutral spine arch throughout
Coming up on your toes or heels lifting off the ground - weight should be on your midfoot/heels
injury_prevention_tips: Use a weight that allows you to maintain perfect form for all reps - ego lifting leads to injury
If your heels lift off the ground, work on ankle mobility or use squat shoes with elevated heels

instructions: Begin seated on the ground with a loaded barbell over your legs. Using a fat bar or having a pad on the bar can greatly reduce the discomfort caused by this exercise. Roll the bar so that it is directly above your hips, and lay down flat on the floor.
Begin the movement by driving through with your heels, extending your hips vertically through the bar. Your weight should be supported by your upper back and the heels of your feet.
Extend as far as possible, then reverse the motion to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Barbell Glute Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and roll a padded barbell over your legs to your hip crease
Plant your feet flat on the floor about hip-width apart, positioned so your shins are vertical at the top
Drive through your heels and squeeze your glutes hard to lift your hips up until your body forms a straight line from knees to shoulders
Your upper back should be resting on the bench with your shoulder blades pinned back
Pause at the top squeezing your glutes as hard as possible, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Think about driving your hips straight up toward the ceiling - not forward
At the top, squeeze your glutes like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Your shins should be vertical at the top - if knees are too far forward, adjust foot position
Keep your chin tucked slightly - imagine holding an orange under your chin
common_mistakes: Overextending and arching your lower back at the top - the movement comes from hip extension, not back arching
Not squeezing glutes hard enough at the top - this is a glute isolation exercise, really focus on the contraction
Letting your knees cave inward - actively push them out to keep them tracking over your feet
injury_prevention_tips: Use a pad or bar cushion - this exercise can be extremely uncomfortable on bare hip bones
If you feel lower back pain, reduce the weight and focus on glute contraction, not back arching

exercises.description: Bench press performed with a barbell over the neck
instructions: Using a medium width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over your neck with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, bring the bar down slowly until it is about 1 inch from your neck.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Barbell Guillotine Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench and grip the barbell with a medium width grip (forearms vertical at the bottom)
Unrack the bar and position it over your neck/upper chest area with arms locked out
Lower the bar slowly toward your neck (stopping about 1 inch above) while keeping your elbows flared out wide
Press the bar back up powerfully, focusing on squeezing your chest at the top
The bar path should be vertical - straight down to your neck and straight back up
form_cues: Think about spreading the bar apart as you lower it - this cue helps keep your elbows flared for chest activation
Lower the bar to your neck/clavicle area, not your mid-chest like a regular bench press
Your elbows should flare out at about 70-80 degrees from your body - wider than a standard bench press
Imagine trying to bend the bar into a U-shape to engage your chest maximally
common_mistakes: Actually touching the bar to your neck - stop 1 inch away for safety while maintaining tension
Letting the bar drift toward your mid-chest - this turns it into a regular bench press and defeats the purpose
Using too much weight - this is a strict chest isolation exercise, use 20-30% less than your regular bench press
injury_prevention_tips: ALWAYS use a spotter or safety bars - this variation is dangerous if you fail a rep
If you feel shoulder pain, reduce the weight or try a slightly narrower grip

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell behind you at arms length and your feet at shoulder width. Tip: A shoulder width grip is best with the palms of your hands facing back. You can use wrist wraps for this exercise for a better grip. This will be your starting position.
While keeping your head and eyes up and back straight, squat until your upper thighs are parallel to the floor. Breathe in as you slowly go down.
Pressing mainly with the heel of the foot and squeezing the thighs, go back up as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Hack Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell behind your body at arm's length with an overhand grip, bar resting against your glutes
Position your feet shoulder-width apart with toes slightly pointed out
Keeping your torso upright and chest up, squat down by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the floor
Your weight should shift slightly forward onto the balls of your feet compared to a regular squat
Drive through your feet to stand back up, keeping the bar close to your legs throughout
form_cues: Think about sitting straight down rather than back - this keeps the bar path close to your legs
Your torso will naturally be more upright than a regular squat due to the bar position
Keep your knees tracking over your toes - they'll travel forward more than in a back squat
The bar should lightly brush your calves and hamstrings as you move
common_mistakes: Leaning too far forward - the back bar position requires a more vertical torso
Letting the bar swing away from your body - this creates an unstable weight shift
Using straps or grip aids when starting - master the movement with light weight first
injury_prevention_tips: Use wrist wraps if grip becomes an issue - grip failure can cause you to drop the bar dangerously
Start very light to get used to the awkward bar position - it feels nothing like a front or back squat

instructions: Begin seated on the ground with a bench directly behind you. Have a loaded barbell over your legs. Using a fat bar or having a pad on the bar can greatly reduce the discomfort caused by this exercise.
Roll the bar so that it is directly above your hips, and lean back against the bench so that your shoulder blades are near the top of it.

Begin the movement by driving through your feet, extending your hips vertically through the bar. Your weight should be supported by your shoulder blades and your feet. Extend as far as possible, then reverse the motion to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Barbell Hip Thrust
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the ground with your upper back leaning against a bench, roll a padded barbell over your legs to your hip crease
Position your feet flat, about hip-width apart, so that your shins are vertical when your hips are fully extended
Drive through your heels and thrust your hips upward, using the bench as a pivot point for your upper back
Extend your hips fully until your body forms a straight line from knees to shoulders, squeezing your glutes maximally
Lower back down with control and repeat without resting the bar on the ground between reps
form_cues: Think about driving your hips straight up toward the ceiling - not thrusting them forward
At the top, squeeze your glutes as if you're trying to leave a butt print on the ceiling
Your chin should stay tucked (not looking up) to keep your spine neutral
Push through your heels, not the balls of your feet, to maximize glute activation
common_mistakes: Overextending your lower back at the top - the movement should come from hip extension, not lumbar hyperextension
Not achieving full hip extension - go all the way up until your torso is nearly horizontal
Letting your knees cave inward during the movement - actively push them out
injury_prevention_tips: Use a thick pad or bar cushion - this exercise puts significant pressure on your hip bones
If you feel lower back pain, reduce weight and focus on glute contraction rather than arching your back

exercises.description: Incline bench press performed with a medium grip on the barbell
instructions: Lie back on an incline bench. Using a medium-width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on you upper chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: it should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Barbell Incline Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set an incline bench to 30-45 degrees, lie back and grip the barbell with a medium width grip
Unrack the bar and hold it over your upper chest with arms locked out
Lower the bar slowly to your upper chest (around your collarbone area) keeping your elbows at about 45 degrees from your body
Press the bar back up powerfully, thinking about pushing it slightly back toward the rack (not straight up)
Lock out at the top and squeeze your chest before starting the next rep
form_cues: The bar should travel in a slight arc - down to your upper chest and back toward the rack on the way up
Think about pushing yourself into the bench rather than pushing the bar away
Your shoulder blades should stay retracted (pinched together) throughout - imagine pinching a pencil between them
Lower the bar taking 2-3 seconds, then explode up in 1 second
common_mistakes: Lowering the bar to your mid-chest instead of upper chest - this reduces the incline benefit
Setting the bench too steep (over 45 degrees) - this shifts emphasis to shoulders instead of upper chest
Bouncing the bar off your chest - maintain control throughout the entire movement
injury_prevention_tips: Use less weight than your flat bench press - incline is mechanically harder
If you feel front shoulder pain, lower the angle of the bench or bring your grip slightly wider

instructions: Lie back on an Incline Bench. Using a medium width grip (a grip that is slightly wider than shoulder width), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms straight. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the arms straight, lift the bar by protracting your shoulder blades, raising the shoulders from the bench as you breathe out.
Bring back the bar to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Incline Shoulder Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an incline bench set at 30-45 degrees, unrack a light barbell and hold it over your chest with straight arms
Keep your arms completely locked out throughout the movement - no elbow bending at all
Raise the bar higher by lifting your shoulders off the bench, like you're reaching the bar toward the ceiling
You should feel your shoulder blades protract (spread apart) as you raise
Lower back down by allowing your shoulders to sink back into the bench
form_cues: Think about reaching your hands toward the ceiling, not pushing - the movement is small (only a few inches)
Your shoulder blades should spread apart at the top like you're opening wings
This is a serratus anterior exercise - focus on the movement coming from your shoulder blades, not your arms
The range of motion is short - you're only lifting your shoulders, not performing a press
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows and turning it into a press - arms must stay locked straight
Using too much weight - this is a small isolation movement, use very light weight
Making the movement too large - it's only a 2-4 inch range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start with just the bar or very light weight - this movement is harder than it looks
If you feel shoulder clicking or pain, reduce the weight and ensure your arms stay straight

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack just below shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and step forward with your right leg and squat down through your hips, while keeping the torso upright and maintaining balance. Inhale as you go down. Note: Do not allow your knee to go forward beyond your toes as you come down, as this will put undue stress on the knee joint.
Using mainly the heel of your foot, push up and go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat the movement for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.
exercises.name: Barbell Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell on your upper back like you're doing a squat, unrack it and step back to clear the rack
Stand with feet hip-width apart, take a large step forward with one leg (about 2-3 feet)
Lower your body straight down by bending both knees until your back knee nearly touches the ground
Your front shin should be vertical and your front knee shouldn't go past your toes
Push through your front heel to step back to the starting position, then repeat on the other leg
form_cues: Think about dropping your hips straight down like an elevator, not lunging forward
Your torso should stay upright - imagine a string pulling your chest up toward the ceiling
Your front heel should stay planted - all the power comes from pushing through that heel
Take a big enough step that your shin stays vertical - too short a step puts stress on your knee
common_mistakes: Letting your front knee travel forward past your toes - this loads the knee joint excessively
Taking too small a step - this doesn't allow proper depth and puts your front knee in a bad position
Leaning your torso forward - keep your chest up and torso as vertical as possible
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight or very light weight to master the balance and mechanics first
If you feel knee pain, check your step length and ensure your shin stays vertical

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell using a wide (higher than shoulder width) and overhand (palms facing your body) grip.

Bend knees slightly and bend over as you keep the natural arch of your back. Let the arms hang in front of you as they hold the bar. Once your torso is parallel to the floor, flare the elbows out and away from your body. Tip: Your torso and your arms should resemble the letter T. Now you are ready to begin the exercise.

While keeping the upper arms perpendicular to the torso, pull the barbell up towards your upper chest as you squeeze the rear delts and you breathe out. Tip: When performed correctly, this exercise should resemble a bench press in reverse. Also, refrain from using your biceps to do the work. Focus on targeting the rear delts; the arms should only act as hooks.
Slowly go back to the initial position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Rear Delt Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip wider than shoulder-width
Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips until your torso is parallel to the floor, keeping your back flat
Let your arms hang straight down, then flare your elbows out wide to the sides - your body should look like the letter T from above
Pull the barbell straight up toward your upper chest by driving your elbows back and out, squeezing your rear delts hard
Lower the bar back down with control to the starting position, maintaining the T-position throughout
form_cues: Think 'elbows high and wide' - they should move perpendicular to your torso, not close to your sides
Imagine doing a reverse bench press - the bar path should go straight up toward your chest
Squeeze your rear delts at the top like you're trying to pinch a pencil between your shoulder blades
common_mistakes: Pulling with your biceps instead of leading with your elbows - arms are just hooks
Letting your elbows drop close to your body, turning it into a regular row instead of targeting rear delts
Rounding your back or changing torso position during the lift
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight throughout to protect your lower back in this hinged position
Start light to master the T-arm position - this is about rear delt isolation, not moving heavy weight

instructions: Place a loaded barbell on the ground, near the end of a bench. Kneel with both legs on the bench, and take a medium to narrow grip on the barbell. This will be your starting position.
To begin, extend through the hips to slowly roll the bar forward. As you roll out, flex the shoulder to roll the bar above your head. Ensure that your arms remain extended throughout the movement.
When the bar has been moved as far forward as possible, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Barbell Rollout from Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel on a bench with both knees, position a loaded barbell on the ground near the end of the bench
Grip the barbell with a medium to narrow grip, arms extended straight down
Keeping your arms locked straight, slowly extend your hips and roll the barbell forward
As you roll out, the bar should move in an arc above your head while you flex at the shoulder
When you've gone as far as possible without losing form, pull yourself back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'push the bar away and overhead' in one smooth arc motion
Keep your arms completely straight like steel rods - no bending at the elbows
Imagine your body is a lever rotating at the knees, extending out into a long line
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows to make the movement easier - they must stay locked
Going too far and losing core tension, letting your hips sag toward the ground
Using momentum or bouncing instead of slow, controlled movement
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced progression - master regular ab rollouts first
Keep your core braced extremely tight throughout to protect your lower back

instructions: Place a block about 12 inches in front of a flat bench.
Sit on the bench and place the ball of your feet on the block.
Have someone place a barbell over your upper thighs about 3 inches above your knees and hold it there. This will be your starting position.
Raise up on your toes as high as possible as you squeeze the calves and as you breathe out.
After a second contraction, slowly go back to the starting position. Tip: To get maximum benefit stretch your calves as far as you can.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Seated Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a block or step about 12 inches in front of a flat bench, sit on the bench
Position the balls of your feet on the block with your heels hanging off, toes pointed forward
Have a spotter place a barbell across your thighs about 3 inches above your knees and hold it steady
Raise up on your toes as high as possible, lifting your heels up like you're trying to stand on your tippy-toes while seated
Squeeze your calves hard at the top, then lower your heels below the block level to get a deep stretch
form_cues: Think 'push through the balls of your feet' to lift your heels as high as possible
Squeeze your calves at the top like you're trying to show off your calf muscles for a photo
Get a deep stretch at the bottom by letting your heels drop below the block - feel that burn
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of controlled stretch and contraction
Not going through full range of motion - you need both the deep stretch and high rise
Using too much weight and sacrificing form or range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Always use a spotter to place and remove the barbell safely
If you feel Achilles tendon pain, reduce the stretch depth or weight

instructions: Sit on a bench with back support in a squat rack. Position a barbell at a height that is just above your head. Grab the barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing forward).

Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip width, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms. Hold at about shoulder level and slightly in front of your head. This is your starting position.
Lower the bar down to the shoulders slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support, position a barbell in a rack at just above head height
Grip the bar with a pronated grip (palms forward), hands slightly wider than shoulder-width
Unrack the bar and hold it at shoulder level, slightly in front of your head with arms locked - this is your starting position
Lower the bar slowly and controlled down to shoulder level, keeping it in front of your face
Press the bar back up overhead until your arms are fully locked out, then repeat
form_cues: Think 'press up and slightly back' so the bar finishes over your head, not in front
Keep your core braced tight like you're wearing a weightlifting belt
Imagine pushing the ceiling away from you with explosive power on the way up
common_mistakes: Leaning back excessively to help press the weight - keep your torso upright against the pad
Lowering the bar behind your head which can stress the shoulders - keep it in front
Not locking out fully at the top - you need full extension for complete shoulder engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Use the back support to maintain proper posture and protect your spine
If you feel shoulder pinching, check your grip width or reduce the weight

instructions: Stand up straight with your feet at shoulder width as you hold a barbell with both hands in front of you using a pronated grip (palms facing the thighs). Tip: Your hands should be a little wider than shoulder width apart. You can use wrist wraps for this exercise for a better grip. This will be your starting position.
Raise your shoulders up as far as you can go as you breathe out and hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Refrain from trying to lift the barbell by using your biceps.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand up straight with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a barbell in front of your thighs with an overhand grip
Keep your arms completely straight and hanging down - grip slightly wider than shoulder-width
Raise your shoulders straight up toward your ears as high as possible, like you're doing an exaggerated shrug gesture
Squeeze hard at the top for a full second, feeling your traps contract
Lower your shoulders back down slowly to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'shoulders to ears' - straight up, not rolling forward or backward
Squeeze your traps at the top like you're trying to touch your shoulders to your earlobes
Keep your arms like dead weight - this is all trap work, no bicep involvement
common_mistakes: Bending the arms and using biceps to help lift the weight
Rolling the shoulders in a circular motion instead of straight up and down
Using too much weight and getting minimal range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral - don't crane it forward or look up during the movement
Use wrist straps if grip is limiting your ability to work your traps effectively

instructions: Stand up straight with your feet at shoulder width as you hold a barbell with both hands behind your back using a pronated grip (palms facing back). Tip: Your hands should be a little wider than shoulder width apart. You can use wrist wraps for this exercise for better grip. This will be your starting position.

Raise your shoulders up as far as you can go as you breathe out and hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Refrain from trying to lift the barbell by using your biceps. The arms should remain stretched out at all times.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Shrug Behind The Back
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand up straight with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a barbell behind your back with an overhand grip
Let the bar rest against your glutes with arms fully extended, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width
Raise your shoulders straight up as high as possible, like you're doing an exaggerated shrug
Hold the contraction at the top for a full second, squeezing your traps hard
Slowly lower your shoulders back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'lift your shoulder blades straight up your spine' - pure vertical movement
Keep the bar close to your body, lightly touching your glutes and back throughout
Squeeze at the top like someone's pulling your shoulders up with strings
common_mistakes: Trying to use your arms to lift - keep them completely straight and relaxed
Leaning forward to compensate for the bar position - stay upright
Rolling shoulders instead of pure vertical shrugging motion
injury_prevention_tips: This variation can be awkward - start with lighter weight than regular shrugs
Use wrist straps for better grip since the bar position makes holding it more challenging

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell placed on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck). Your feet should be shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your back straight and your head up, bend only at the waist to the right as far as possible. Breathe in as you bend to the side. Then hold for a second and come back up to the starting position as you exhale. Tip: Keep the rest of the body stationary.
Now repeat the movement but bending to the left instead. Hold for a second and come back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Side Bend
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand up straight with a barbell resting on your upper back (slightly below the neck), feet shoulder-width apart
Keep your head up, back straight, and core engaged - this is your starting position
Bend only at the waist to your right side as far as comfortable, keeping everything else stationary
Hold for a second at the bottom, then return to the upright starting position
Repeat the same movement bending to your left side, alternating sides for each rep
form_cues: Think 'slide your ribcage toward your hip' - pure lateral flexion, no forward or backward lean
Keep your shoulders, hips, and feet locked in place - only your torso should bend sideways
Imagine you're bending between two panes of glass - can't move forward or back
common_mistakes: Twisting or rotating the torso instead of pure side-to-side bending
Leaning forward at the hips instead of maintaining an upright posture
Using too much weight and getting minimal range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - this exercise can be hard on the spine if done with heavy weight
Avoid this exercise if you have lower back issues - it can compress the spine laterally

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell placed on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck). Your feet should be placed wide apart with the foot of the lead leg angled out to the side. This will be your starting position.
Lower your body towards the side of your angled foot by bending the knee and hip of your lead leg and while keeping the opposite leg only slightly bent. Breathe in as you lower your body.
Return to the starting position by extending the hip and knee of the lead leg. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
After performing the recommended amount of reps, repeat the movement with the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Barbell Side Split Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with a barbell on your upper back, feet placed very wide apart with your lead foot angled out to the side
Your trail leg should be only slightly bent while your lead leg is positioned like a side lunge stance
Lower your body toward the side of your angled lead leg by bending that knee and hip
Go down until your lead thigh is roughly parallel to the ground while keeping your back straight
Push through your lead heel to extend back up to the starting position, then repeat for all reps before switching sides
form_cues: Think 'sit back and to the side into your hip' like you're doing a lateral lunge
Keep your chest up and eyes forward like you're showing off a medal
Push through the heel of your working leg like you're trying to push the floor away
common_mistakes: Letting the knee cave inward instead of tracking over the toes of the angled foot
Rounding the back or leaning too far forward - maintain an upright posture
Not going deep enough - you need to get that lead thigh parallel for full engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Start with just the bar to learn the movement pattern - this is a complex unilateral exercise
Keep your trail leg only slightly bent to maintain balance and support

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack to just below shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and hips as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell in a rack just below shoulder height, step under it and position it on your upper back (not your neck)
Grip the bar on both sides, unrack it by pushing up with your legs and step back with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out
Keep your chest up, head forward, and back straight - take a deep breath and brace your core
Lower down by bending your knees and hips simultaneously until your thighs are just below parallel to the ground
Drive through your heels to push the floor away and stand back up, squeezing your glutes at the top
form_cues: Think 'sit back into a chair' - push your hips back as you descend, don't just bend your knees
Keep your knees tracking over your toes - imagine you have lasers shooting from your knees that stay aligned with your toes
Chest up, eyes forward the entire time - imagine you're wearing a crown that can't fall off
common_mistakes: Knees drifting forward past your toes - this puts excessive stress on the knee joint
Rounding the lower back at the bottom - maintain that neutral spine throughout
Looking down or letting your chest collapse - this throws off your balance and form
injury_prevention_tips: Always use a squat rack with safety bars set at an appropriate height
Drive through your heels, not your toes - this protects your knees and engages your posterior chain

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first place a flat bench or a box behind you. The flat bench is used to teach you to set your hips back and to hit depth.

Then, set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and sitting your hips back as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs and extend the hips to go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Barbell Squat To A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a flat bench or box behind you in a squat rack, set the barbell at just below shoulder height
Position the bar on your upper back, unrack it and step back until the bench is directly behind you
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out, chest up and core braced
Sit your hips back and lower down until your glutes lightly touch the bench - don't actually sit down
As soon as you touch the bench, drive through your heels to explode back up to standing
form_cues: Think 'reach back for the bench with your butt' - this teaches proper hip hinge mechanics
Barely kiss the bench - don't relax or collapse onto it, maintain tension
Imagine the bench is a hot stove - touch it and immediately spring back up
common_mistakes: Actually sitting down and relaxing on the bench - you should just barely touch it
Letting your knees drift forward past your toes instead of sitting back properly
Using the bench as a crutch instead of using it as a depth gauge
injury_prevention_tips: The bench teaches you to set your hips back properly - this protects your knees
Start with a higher bench and gradually lower it as you gain mobility and strength

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell placed on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) and stand upright behind an elevated platform (such as the one used for spotting behind a flat bench). This is your starting position.

Place the right foot on the elevated platform. Step on the platform by extending the hip and the knee of your right leg. Use the heel mainly to lift the rest of your body up and place the foot of the left leg on the platform as well. Breathe out as you execute the force required to come up.

Step down with the left leg by flexing the hip and knee of the right leg as you inhale. Return to the original standing position by placing the right foot of to next to the left foot on the initial position.
Repeat with the right leg for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.
exercises.name: Barbell Step Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with the barbell across your upper back, facing a box or bench about knee height - imagine you're a soldier standing at attention
Plant your entire right foot flat on the box, keeping your knee tracking over your toes like a train on rails
Drive through your right heel like you're pushing the box into the ground, bringing your left foot up to meet it at the top
Step back down with the left foot first in a controlled manner, then bring your right foot down to return to start
Complete all reps on one leg before switching - this builds balanced strength
form_cues: Lead with your chest up and proud - imagine a string pulling your sternum toward the ceiling
Drive through the heel of your working leg like you're crushing a can under your foot
Keep your torso vertical throughout - think about balancing a cup of water on your head
common_mistakes: Pushing off with the bottom foot instead of letting the top leg do all the work - this defeats the purpose of the exercise
Letting the knee cave inward on the step-up, which stresses the joint unnecessarily
Leaning forward excessively, turning it into a good morning instead of keeping tension on the quads
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a lower box height (12-16 inches) before progressing to higher platforms to protect your knees
Keep your core braced tight like you're about to take a punch - this protects your lower back under the barbell load

instructions: Begin standing with your feet shoulder width apart and a barbell across your upper back.

Step forward with one leg, flexing the knees to drop your hips. Descend until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. Your posture should remain upright, and your front knee should stay above the front foot.
Drive through the heel of your lead foot and extend both knees to raise yourself back up.
Step forward with your rear foot, repeating the lunge on the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Barbell Walking Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up with the barbell across your upper traps, feet hip-width apart, standing tall like you own the room
Take a controlled step forward (about 2-3 feet) and plant your foot flat, creating a solid base
Drop your hips straight down like you're sitting into a chair, descending until your back knee hovers just above the floor
Explode through your front heel to stand up, then bring your back foot forward to meet it
Continue walking forward, alternating legs with each step - focus on smooth, controlled movement
form_cues: Think about dropping your hips straight down between your feet, not lunging forward - imagine descending in an elevator
Your front shin should be nearly vertical at the bottom - picture a wall right in front of your knee
Drive through the front heel like you're pushing the floor away from you to power back up
common_mistakes: Taking too short of a stride, which puts excessive stress on the front knee by letting it travel past the toes
Leaning the torso forward instead of keeping it upright, which shifts load away from the legs onto the lower back
Letting the back knee slam into the ground instead of controlling the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout like you're wearing a tight lifting belt - this stabilizes your spine under load
If you feel unstable, master stationary lunges first before adding the walking component

instructions: For this exercise you will need a heavy rope anchored at its center 15-20 feet away. Standing in front of the rope, take an end in each hand with your arms extended at your side. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by rapidly raising one arm to shoulder level as quickly as you can.
As you let that arm drop to the starting position, raise the opposite side.
Continue alternating your left and right arms, whipping the ropes up and down as fast as you can.
exercises.name: Battling Ropes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab one end of the rope in each hand with a firm grip, standing about 15-20 feet from the anchor point
Get into an athletic stance - feet shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent, hips pushed back like a linebacker ready to move
Start whipping one arm up to shoulder height explosively while the other arm drops down
As soon as the first arm reaches the top, reverse it - create a continuous alternating wave pattern like you're drumming rapidly
Keep the waves coming fast and aggressive for your work interval - aim for maximum speed and power
form_cues: Stay in your athletic stance with your weight in your heels - imagine you're a tree with roots planted firmly in the ground
Create big, violent waves in the rope - think about slamming the ropes down with authority, not just wiggling them
Keep your shoulders pulled back and down - imagine pinching a pencil between your shoulder blades throughout
common_mistakes: Standing too upright with straight legs, which fatigues your shoulders prematurely instead of engaging your whole body
Using tiny, weak arm movements instead of generating power from your core and hips
Gripping the rope too tight and burning out your forearms - maintain a firm but not death-grip hold
injury_prevention_tips: Start with shorter work intervals (15-20 seconds) to build shoulder endurance before attempting longer efforts
Keep your core tight and engaged throughout - think about bracing like someone's about to push you

instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you.
Place your hands behind your hand, and push your elbows back as far as you can. Your partner should hold your elbows. This will be your starting position.
Gently attempt to pull your elbows forward with your hands still behind your head for 10 or more seconds. Your partner should prevent your elbows from moving.

Now, relax your muscles and have your partner gently pull the elbows back as far as it comfortable for you. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is adequate to prevent overstretching or injury.
exercises.name: Behind Head Chest Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your legs comfortable, with your partner positioned directly behind you
Clasp your hands behind your head and push your elbows back as far as comfortable, opening your chest wide
Have your partner gently hold your elbows in this stretched position - they should apply steady, light pressure
Push your elbows forward against your partner's resistance for 10 seconds (like you're trying to bring them together) without actually moving
Relax completely, then have your partner gently pull your elbows further back into a deeper stretch for 20-30 seconds
form_cues: Keep your chest proud and tall throughout - imagine a spotlight shining on your sternum
During the contraction phase, push against your partner's hands like you're trying to close a heavy door
When relaxing into the stretch, breathe deeply and imagine your chest expanding like a balloon
common_mistakes: Rounding the upper back forward instead of keeping the spine neutral, which defeats the purpose of the chest stretch
Holding your breath during the stretch - proper breathing helps you relax into a deeper stretch
Your partner pulling too aggressively, risking shoulder strain - communication is key
injury_prevention_tips: Use clear verbal cues with your partner - say 'stop' immediately if you feel sharp pain or excessive discomfort
Keep your shoulder blades pulled down and back throughout - don't let them shrug up toward your ears

exercises.description: Dips performed on a bench
instructions: For this exercise you will need to place a bench behind your back. With the bench perpendicular to your body, and while looking away from it, hold on to the bench on its edge with the hands fully extended, separated at shoulder width. The legs will be extended forward, bent at the waist and perpendicular to your torso. This will be your starting position.

Slowly lower your body as you inhale by bending at the elbows until you lower yourself far enough to where there is an angle slightly smaller than 90 degrees between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the elbows as close as possible throughout the movement. Forearms should always be pointing down.
Using your triceps to bring your torso up again, lift yourself back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bench Dips
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself with your hands gripping the edge of a bench behind you, fingers pointing forward, arms fully extended
Walk your feet forward until your legs are extended and your butt is hovering just in front of the bench
Lower your body by bending your elbows, keeping them pointing straight back (not flaring out), until your upper arms are roughly parallel to the floor
Press through your palms to straighten your arms, squeezing your triceps hard at the top like you're flexing in a mirror
Control the descent on each rep - don't just drop down and bounce back up
form_cues: Keep your elbows tucked close to your body - imagine you're trying to hold newspapers under your armpits
Push through your palms like you're pressing the bench away from you, not just straightening your arms
Lean slightly back and keep your shoulders down - think about pulling your shoulder blades into your back pockets
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to the sides, which shifts stress from triceps to shoulders and can cause impingement
Going too deep (past 90 degrees), which puts excessive strain on the shoulder joint capsule
Using momentum and bouncing at the bottom instead of controlling the movement with your muscles
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel shoulder discomfort, reduce range of motion and focus on the top half of the movement first
Keep your core engaged and torso relatively upright - don't let your hips sag toward the floor

exercises.description: Bench press performed with bands
instructions: Using a flat bench secure a band under the leg of the bench that is nearest to your head.
Once the band is secure, grab it by both handles and lie down on the bench.
Extend your arms so that you are holding the band handles in front of you at shoulder width.
Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.
Bring down the handles slowly until your elbow forms a 90 degree angle. Keep full control at all times.
As you breathe out, bring the handles up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
exercises.name: Band Bench Press
tips: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure a resistance band under the bench leg closest to your head, then lie down and grab both handles
Start with arms extended above your chest, hands at shoulder-width, wrists rotated so palms face away from you
Lower the handles down slowly and under control, keeping the band tension steady, until your elbows reach about 90 degrees
Press the handles back up explosively by squeezing your chest hard, like you're trying to crush something between your pecs
Lock out at the top with arms fully extended, pause for a second to squeeze, then repeat with control
form_cues: Think about pushing the handles together as you press up, like you're hugging a tree - this maximizes chest engagement
Keep your shoulder blades squeezed together and pinned to the bench - imagine you're crushing a grape between them
Fight the band tension on the way down - don't let it yank your arms down uncontrollably
common_mistakes: Letting the band snap your arms down instead of controlling the eccentric lowering phase
Flaring elbows out at a 90-degree angle to the body, which stresses the shoulder joint unnecessarily
Bouncing the handles off your chest at the bottom instead of maintaining constant tension
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your feet flat on the floor and drive through them to maintain a stable arch in your lower back
Start with lighter band resistance to master the movement pattern before progressing to heavier bands

exercises.description: Bench press performed with chains hanging from the barbell
instructions: Adjust the leader chain, shortening it to the desired length.Place the chains on the sleeves of the bar.

Lying on the bench, get your head beyond the bar if possible. Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement. However wide your grip, it should cover the ring on the bar.

Pull the bar out of the rack without protracting your shoulders. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart. Lower the bar to your lower chest or upper stomach. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times.
Pause when the barbell touches your torso, and then drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.
exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up the chains on the barbell sleeves so some links rest on the floor at the bottom position, then position yourself under the bar
Lie on the bench with your feet tucked under you, create a tight arch in your lower back, and grip the bar outside shoulder-width
Unrack the bar and bring it over your chest, then lower it with control to your lower chest or upper stomach while keeping elbows at a 45-degree angle
Pause briefly when the bar touches your torso (with chains partially on the floor), then explode upward driving the bar back to lockout
Keep maximum tension throughout - the chains add more resistance at the top, making the lockout harder
form_cues: Pull the bar apart like you're trying to bend it as you press - this engages your lats and stabilizes the bar path
Drive your feet into the floor and squeeze your glutes like you're crushing walnuts - this creates full-body tension
Think about pressing yourself into the bench, not just pressing the bar up - push through the bench with your upper back
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out wide (T-shape) instead of keeping them at 45 degrees, which increases shoulder injury risk
Losing tightness in your upper back and shoulders as you press, causing the bar to drift forward
Bouncing the bar off your chest instead of using a controlled touch-and-go or pause
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular barbell bench press with perfect form before adding chains - chains increase complexity
Keep your wrists stacked directly over your elbows throughout the movement to prevent wrist strain

instructions: Lie on a flat bench with a barbell using a shoulder grip width.
Hold the bar straight over your chest with a bend in your arms. This will be your starting position.
While keeping your arms in the bent arm position, lower the weight slowly in an arc behind your head while breathing in until you feel a stretch on the chest.
At that point, bring the barbell back to the starting position using the arc through which the weight was lowered and exhale as you perform this movement.
Hold the weight on the initial position for a second and repeat the motion for the prescribed number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent-Arm Barbell Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding a barbell above your chest with a shoulder-width grip and arms slightly bent (about 15-20 degrees)
Keep this same arm angle locked throughout - don't straighten or bend your arms more during the movement
Slowly lower the bar back over your head in a smooth arc, feeling a deep stretch across your chest and lats
Stop when you feel a strong stretch (bar should be roughly in line with your head), not when your arms are parallel to the floor
Pull the bar back to the starting position using the same arc path, exhaling and squeezing your chest and lats together
form_cues: Think about pulling with your elbows, not your hands - imagine your elbows are leading the movement back up
Keep the same elbow bend throughout like your arms are in a cast - this keeps tension on the target muscles
Focus on feeling the stretch in your ribcage and lats at the bottom - imagine opening up your chest cavity wide
common_mistakes: Straightening the arms as the bar goes back, turning it into a triceps extension instead of a chest/lat exercise
Going too far back and hyperextending the shoulders, which can strain the shoulder joint
Using too much weight and losing control of the bar as it goes behind your head - this is dangerous
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weight to learn the movement pattern - this exercise requires good shoulder mobility
Keep your hips and lower back flat on the bench - don't arch excessively or lift your butt off the bench

instructions: Place a dumbbell standing up on a flat bench.

Ensuring that the dumbbell stays securely placed at the top of the bench, lie perpendicular to the bench (torso across it as in forming a cross) with only your shoulders lying on the surface. Hips should be below the bench and legs bent with feet firmly on the floor. The head will be off the bench as well.

Grasp the dumbbell with both hands and hold it straight over your chest with a bend in your arms. Both palms should be pressing against the underside one of the sides of the dumbbell. This will be your starting position. Caution: Always ensure that the dumbbell used for this exercise is secure. Using a dumbbell with loose plates can result in the dumbbell falling apart and falling on your face.
While keeping your arms locked in the bent arm position, lower the weight slowly in an arc behind your head while breathing in until you feel a stretch on the chest.
At that point, bring the dumbbell back to the starting position using the arc through which the weight was lowered and exhale as you perform this movement.
Hold the weight on the initial position for a second and repeat the motion for the prescribed number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent-Arm Dumbbell Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a dumbbell vertically on a bench, then lie perpendicular across it so only your upper back and shoulders contact the bench
Grab the dumbbell with both hands cupped under the top plate, holding it above your chest with a slight bend in your elbows
Keep your hips low (below bench level) and feet planted firmly to create a stable bridge position
Lower the dumbbell back over your head in a wide arc, maintaining the same elbow angle, until you feel a deep stretch across your chest
Pull the dumbbell back to start position using your chest and lats, exhaling as you squeeze them together at the top
form_cues: Drop your hips slightly as the dumbbell goes back - this increases the stretch and keeps tension on your chest
Think about pulling the dumbbell back with your chest and lats, like you're doing a chest fly and pulldown simultaneously
Keep your elbows locked at the same angle throughout - imagine they're in hinges that only allow movement at the shoulder
common_mistakes: Letting the arms straighten or bend during the movement, which shifts tension to the triceps or shoulders
Raising the hips too high, which reduces the range of motion and stretch on the target muscles
Using a loose grip that allows the dumbbell to wobble or tilt, creating instability and injury risk
injury_prevention_tips: Always check that the dumbbell plates are secured tightly before starting - a plate coming loose can be catastrophic
Start light and focus on the stretch and squeeze - this is a finesse exercise, not a max-weight movement

instructions: Lay flat on the floor with your arms next to your sides.
Now bend your knees at around a 75 degree angle and lift your feet off the floor by around 2 inches.

Using your lower abs, bring your knees in towards you as you maintain the 75 degree angle bend in your legs. Continue this movement until you raise your hips off of the floor by rolling your pelvis backward. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: At the end of the movement your knees will be over your chest.
Squeeze your abs at the top of the movement for a second and then return to the starting position slowly as you breathe in. Tip: Maintain a controlled motion at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent-Knee Hip Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with arms at your sides for stability, legs bent at about 75 degrees, feet lifted 2 inches off the floor
Using your lower abs, pull your knees toward your chest while maintaining that 75-degree knee bend throughout
Continue pulling your knees in until your hips roll up off the floor - think about bringing your knees to your chin, not your chest
At the top, your knees should be over your chest and your tailbone should be lifted - squeeze your abs hard for one second
Lower your hips back down slowly and under control to the starting position, keeping tension in your abs the entire time
form_cues: Focus on rolling your pelvis backward and upward like you're trying to show someone the bottom of your shoes
Think about using your lower abs to curl your tailbone toward your ribcage - it's a curling motion, not a hip hinge
Keep your upper back and shoulders glued to the floor - don't let them rise up or shift around
common_mistakes: Using momentum and swinging the legs instead of controlling the movement with your abs
Just bringing the knees toward the chest without rolling the hips up - this misses the lower ab engagement
Straightening the legs during the movement, which makes it easier but reduces ab activation
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back pressed flat against the floor at the start position to protect your spine
If you feel neck strain, place a small towel or your hands under your head for support - but don't pull on your neck

instructions: Holding a barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing down), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The barbell should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

Now, while keeping the torso stationary, breathe out and lift the barbell to you. Keep the elbows close to the body and only use the forearms to hold the weight. At the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a brief pause.
Then inhale and slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent Over Barbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip (palms facing down), hands just outside shoulder-width
Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground, keeping your back flat
Let the barbell hang straight down from your shoulders with arms fully extended - this is your starting position
Pull the barbell up toward your lower chest by driving your elbows back and up, keeping them close to your body
Squeeze your back muscles hard at the top for a second, then lower the bar slowly back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'pull your elbows to your back pockets' - drive the elbows back, not just pull with your hands
Keep your torso locked like a statue - imagine you're balancing a cup of water on your lower back
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like you're trying to crush a grape between them
common_mistakes: Using momentum by rocking your torso up and down instead of staying stationary
Pulling with your biceps instead of initiating the movement with your back muscles
Letting your lower back round - maintain that neutral spine throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your head in a neutral position aligned with your spine - don't crane your neck up
Brace your core tight like you're about to get punched to protect your lower back in this hinged position

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell in each hand and with an incline bench in front of you.

While keeping your back straight and maintaining the natural arch of your back, lean forward until your forehead touches the bench in front of you. Let the arms hang in front of you perpendicular to the ground. The palms of your hands should be facing each other and your torso should be parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your torso forward and stationary, and the arms straight with a slight bend at the elbows, lift the dumbbells straight to the side until both arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you lift the weights. Caution: avoid swinging the torso or bringing the arms back as opposed to the side.
After a one second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.
Repeat the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent Over Dumbbell Rear Delt Raise With Head On Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, lean forward until your forehead rests on the bench
Let your arms hang straight down perpendicular to the ground, palms facing each other
Your torso should be parallel to the floor with your back flat and natural arch maintained
Keeping your arms nearly straight with just a slight elbow bend, raise the dumbbells out to your sides until parallel to the floor
Pause for a second at the top, then slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'lift straight out to the sides' like you're making a T-shape, not pulling back behind you
Lead with your elbows slightly higher than your hands - imagine pouring water out of pitchers
Keep your head pressed to the bench throughout - this stabilizes you and prevents cheating
common_mistakes: Swinging the torso or using momentum instead of pure rear delt contraction
Pulling the arms back behind your body instead of lifting straight to the sides
Bending the elbows too much to make it easier - keep them nearly locked
injury_prevention_tips: The bench support eliminates lower back stress - use it to focus purely on your rear delts
Start light - your rear delts are small muscles and fatigue quickly

instructions: Select a weight and hold the handle of the low pulley with your right hand.

Bend at the waist until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor. Your legs should be slightly bent with your left hand placed on your lower left thigh. Your right arm should be hanging from your shoulder in front of you and with a slight bend at the elbow. This will be your starting position.
Raise your right arm, elbow slightly bent, to the side until the arm is parallel to the floor and in line with your right ear. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and repeat the movement with the other arm.
exercises.name: Bent Over Low-Pulley Side Lateral
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable to the lowest position, grab the handle with your right hand and step away for tension
Bend at the waist until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor, place your left hand on your left thigh for support
Let your right arm hang down from your shoulder with a slight bend at the elbow - this is your starting position
Raise your right arm out to the side and up until it's parallel to the floor and in line with your ear
Pause briefly, then slowly lower the weight back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'raise to the side, not forward or back' - imagine sliding your arm along a wall next to you
Keep your torso completely still like a statue - only your arm should move
Lead with your elbow slightly higher than your hand at the top
common_mistakes: Rotating or twisting your torso to help lift the weight
Raising the arm forward or backward instead of purely to the side
Standing up too much or not maintaining the bent-over position throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your core and use your free hand on your thigh for stability
Use light weight - this bent-over position makes the movement much harder than standing laterals

instructions: Put weight on one of the ends of an Olympic barbell. Make sure that you either place the other end of the barbell in the corner of two walls; or put a heavy object on the ground so the barbell cannot slide backward.
Bend forward until your torso is as close to parallel with the floor as you can and keep your knees slightly bent.
Now grab the bar with one arm just behind the plates on the side where the weight was placed and put your other hand on your knee. This will be your starting position.

Pull the bar straight up with your elbow in (to maximize back stimulation) until the plates touch your lower chest. Squeeze the back muscles as you lift the weight up and hold for a second at the top of the movement. Breathe out as you lift the weight. Tip: Do not allow for any swinging of the torso. Only the arm should move.

Slowly lower the bar to the starting position getting a nice stretch on the lats. Tip: Do not let the plates touch the floor. To ensure the best range of motion, I recommend using small plates (25-lb ones) as opposed to larger plates (like 35-45lb ones).
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and switch arms.
exercises.name: Bent Over One-Arm Long Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load one end of a barbell and secure the other end in a corner or under a heavy object
Bend forward until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor with knees slightly bent
Grab the loaded end of the bar with one hand just behind the plates, place your other hand on your knee for support
Pull the bar straight up toward your lower chest by driving your elbow back close to your body
Squeeze your back hard at the top, then slowly lower the bar without letting the plates touch the floor
form_cues: Think 'elbow to ceiling' - drive the elbow straight up, pulling the bar vertically
Keep your torso locked in place - imagine you're frozen in that hinged position
Squeeze your lat like you're trying to hold a tennis ball in your armpit at the top
common_mistakes: Rotating or swinging the torso to help move the weight
Letting the elbow flare out wide instead of keeping it tight to your body
Using too large of plates which limits your range of motion at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back flat and core braced throughout to protect your lower back
Use smaller weight plates (25lb) for better range of motion and a deeper stretch

instructions: Put weight on one of the ends of an Olympic barbell. Make sure that you either place the other end of the barbell in the corner of two walls; or put a heavy object on the ground so the barbell cannot slide backward.
Bend forward until your torso is as close to parallel with the floor as you can and keep your knees slightly bent.
Now grab the bar with both arms just behind the plates on the side where the weight was placed and put your other hand on your knee. This will be your starting position.

Pull the bar straight up with your elbows in (to maximize back stimulation) until the plates touch your lower chest. Squeeze the back muscles as you lift the weight up and hold for a second at the top of the movement. Breathe out as you lift the weight. Tip: Use a stirrup or double handle cable attachment by hooking it under the end of the bar.

Slowly lower the bar to the starting position getting a nice stretch on the lats. Tip: Do not let the plates touch the floor. To ensure the best range of motion, I recommend using small plates (25-lb ones) as opposed to larger plates (like 35-45lb ones).
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent Over Two-Arm Long Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load one end of a barbell and secure the other end in a corner, attach a V-handle or double-handle grip if available
Bend forward until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor with knees slightly bent
Grab the loaded end with both hands just behind the plates (or using the attached handle)
Pull the bar straight up toward your lower chest by driving both elbows back close to your sides
Squeeze your back muscles hard at the top, then lower the bar slowly without letting plates touch the floor
form_cues: Think 'pull to your belly button' - the bar should travel in a straight vertical line
Keep your elbows tucked tight to your sides to maximize lat engagement
Squeeze your lats at the top like you're crushing a can between your elbows and ribcage
common_mistakes: Allowing your torso to rise up as you pull - stay hinged throughout
Pulling with your arms instead of driving the movement with your lats
Letting the plates crash to the floor between reps instead of maintaining tension
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your core extremely tight throughout this movement
Use smaller plates for better range of motion - you want that deep stretch at the bottom

instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand (palms facing your torso), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward by bending at the waist; as you bend make sure to keep your back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The weights should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the dumbbells to your side (as you breathe out), keeping the elbows close to the body (do not exert any force with the forearm other than holding the weights). On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand with palms facing your torso, stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor
Let the dumbbells hang straight down from your shoulders with arms fully extended
Pull both dumbbells up to your sides by driving your elbows back, keeping them close to your body
Squeeze your back hard at the top for a second, then slowly lower the dumbbells back down
form_cues: Think 'drive your elbows to the ceiling behind you' - lead with the elbows, not the hands
Keep your torso perfectly still like a tabletop - imagine balancing objects on your back
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like you're trying to hold a pencil between them
common_mistakes: Rocking your torso up and down to generate momentum
Pulling with your biceps instead of letting your back do the work - arms are just hooks
Letting your lower back round - maintain that flat, neutral spine
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your head in neutral alignment with your spine - don't crane it up or let it drop
Engage your core before each set like you're about to get punched in the stomach

instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand (palms facing each other), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The weights should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the dumbbells to your side as you breathe out, squeezing your shoulder blades together. On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand with palms facing each other (neutral grip), stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor
Let the dumbbells hang straight down from your shoulders with arms fully extended
Pull both dumbbells up to your sides by driving your elbows back, actively squeezing your shoulder blades together
Hold the contraction at the top for a full second, then slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'pinch your shoulder blades together' as you row - this neutral grip emphasizes that squeeze
Keep your elbows traveling close to your sides in a straight path up and down
Imagine you're trying to start two lawnmowers simultaneously with your elbows
common_mistakes: Using your torso to help row the weight by rocking back and forth
Letting the dumbbells drift forward away from your body instead of pulling straight up
Rushing through reps without holding the squeeze at the top
injury_prevention_tips: The neutral grip is often more shoulder-friendly than other grip variations
Keep your core locked tight throughout to protect your lower back in this hinged position

instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so. This will be your starting position.

Begin my leaning to the side opposite the kettlebell, continuing until you are able to touch the ground with your free hand, keeping your eyes on the kettlebell. As you do so, press the weight vertically be extending through the elbow, keeping your arm perpendicular to the ground.
Return to an upright position, with the kettlebell above your head. Return the kettlebell to the shoulder and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bent Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder with your wrist rotated so it rests comfortably in the rack position
Begin leaning to the side opposite the kettlebell, reaching down with your free hand toward the floor
As you lean, simultaneously press the kettlebell vertically overhead by extending your elbow, keeping your eyes on it
