Continue leaning until your free hand touches the ground while the kettlebell is locked out overhead
Return to an upright standing position with the kettlebell still overhead, then lower it back to the shoulder
form_cues: Think 'press vertically while bending laterally' - the kettlebell should always travel straight up relative to the ground
Keep your eyes glued to the kettlebell throughout the entire movement
Imagine you're sliding under the weight rather than pressing it up - your body moves, not just your arm
common_mistakes: Pressing the kettlebell on an angle instead of keeping it perpendicular to the ground
Rushing the movement instead of taking your time to maintain control and balance
Not keeping visual contact with the kettlebell which can throw off your balance
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced old-school movement - start very light to learn the coordination
Master the basic overhead press and side bend mechanics separately before combining them

instructions: Begin by lying on the bench, getting your head beyond the bar if possible. One to five boards, made out of 2x6's, can be screwed together and held in place by a training partner, bands, or just tucked under your shirt.

Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement.

You can take a standard bench grip, or shoulder width to focus on the triceps. Pull the bar out of the rack without protracting your shoulders. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart.
Lower the bar to the boards, and then drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.
exercises.name: Board Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up on a bench with 1-5 boards (made from 2x6 lumber) stacked on your chest, held by a partner or bands
Lie back and get your head beyond the bar if possible, tuck your feet under you and arch your back
Retract your shoulder blades hard, squeezing them together and driving your traps into the bench
Unrack the bar with a standard or narrow grip and lower it to the boards with control
Explode the bar back up with maximum force, keeping your elbows tucked until lockout
form_cues: Think 'squeeze the bar and try to rip it apart' with your hands to engage your lats
Keep your wrists, elbows, and bar in a straight vertical line throughout the movement
Drive through your feet into the ground like you're leg pressing the bench into your back
common_mistakes: Losing tightness in your upper back setup - maintain that retracted shoulder blade position
Bouncing off the boards instead of controlled touch and explosive press
Flaring elbows out wide instead of keeping them tucked for tricep emphasis
injury_prevention_tips: The boards limit your range of motion to focus on tricep-dominant lockout strength safely
Keep your shoulder blades retracted throughout - don't let them protract as you press

instructions: Assume a plank position on the ground. You should be supporting your bodyweight on your toes and forearms, keeping your torso straight. Your forearms should be shoulder-width apart. This will be your starting position.
Pressing your palms firmly into the ground, extend through the elbows to raise your body from the ground. Keep your torso rigid as you perform the movement.
Slowly lower your forearms back to the ground by allowing the elbows to flex.
Repeat.
exercises.name: Body-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a forearm plank position with your bodyweight supported on your toes and forearms, torso straight
Position your forearms shoulder-width apart with palms flat on the ground
Press firmly through your palms to extend your elbows, raising your body up into a straight-arm plank position
Keep your entire torso rigid like a board - no sagging or piking
Slowly lower back down to your forearms by bending your elbows with control, then repeat
form_cues: Think 'push the floor away' with your palms to extend your elbows straight
Keep your body in a perfectly straight line from head to heels like a rigid plank the entire time
Squeeze your glutes hard to prevent your hips from sagging toward the floor
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag or pike up instead of maintaining a straight body line
Using momentum or dropping quickly instead of controlled lowering
Not fully extending the elbows at the top - you need complete lockout
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced tricep and core exercise - master regular planks first
If your hips sag, stop the set - losing form puts excessive stress on your lower back

instructions: Position a bar in a rack at chest height.
Standing, take a shoulder width grip on the bar and step a yard or two back, feet together and arms extended so that you are leaning on the bar. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow, lowering yourself towards the bar.
Pause, and then reverse the motion by extending the elbows.
Progress from bodyweight by adding chains over your shoulders.
exercises.name: Body Tricep Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell in a rack at chest height, then stand facing it and grip the bar at shoulder-width
Step back 2-3 feet with feet together, leaning forward onto the bar with straight arms - your body should be at an angle like a plank
Keep your body rigid and straight from head to heels, then bend your elbows to lower your chest toward the bar
Go as low as you can control while keeping your body straight - aim for your chest to nearly touch the bar
Push through your palms to extend your elbows and return to the start, squeezing your triceps hard at the top
form_cues: Maintain a straight body line throughout - imagine you're a rigid board being lowered and raised
Keep your elbows close to your sides as you bend them - think about scraping them along your ribs
Push the bar away from you at the bottom like you're trying to push the rack backwards
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag or pike up, breaking the straight body line and reducing tricep engagement
Flaring elbows out wide instead of keeping them tucked, which shifts stress to the shoulders
Taking too big of a step back, making the angle too difficult and compromising form
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight like you're wearing a belt - this protects your lower back from sagging
Start with a higher bar position (easier angle) before lowering it as you get stronger

instructions: Position two equally loaded EZ bars on the ground next to each other. Ensure they are able to roll.
Assume a push-up position over the bars, supporting your weight on your toes and hands with your arms extended and body straight.
Place your hands on the bars. This will be your starting position.
Using a slow and controlled motion, move your hands away from the midline of your body, rolling the bars apart. Inhale during this portion of the motion.
After moving the bars as far apart as you can, return to the starting position by pulling them back together. Exhale as you perform this movement.
exercises.name: Bodyweight Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two loaded EZ bars on the floor parallel to each other about shoulder-width apart - make sure they can roll freely
Get into a push-up position with one hand on each bar, arms extended, body straight from head to heels
Slowly roll the bars outward by moving your hands away from your midline, spreading them apart like opening a book
Go as wide as you can control while maintaining a straight body - you'll feel a deep stretch across your chest
Pull the bars back together by squeezing your chest hard, like you're hugging a tree, returning to start position
form_cues: Think about spreading the floor apart as you roll the bars out - lead with your chest opening wide
Keep your body rigid like a plank throughout - don't let your hips drop or rise
Squeeze your pecs hard to bring the bars back together - imagine crushing something between your chest muscles
common_mistakes: Going too wide too fast and losing control of the bars, which can hyperextend the shoulders
Letting the hips sag toward the floor as you spread the bars, taking tension off the chest
Bending your elbows significantly during the movement, turning it into a pressing motion instead of a fly
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a narrower range of motion and gradually increase the width as your strength improves
Ensure the bars are properly loaded and secure - rolling bars can be dangerous if they're not stable

instructions: Begin by taking a medium to wide grip on a pull-up apparatus with your palms facing away from you. From a hanging position, tuck your knees to your chest, leaning back and getting your legs over your side of the pull-up apparatus. This will be your starting position.
Beginning with your arms straight, flex the elbows and retract the shoulder blades to raise your body up until your legs contact the pull-up apparatus.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Bodyweight Mid Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with a medium to wide overhand grip (palms away), hanging with straight arms
Tuck your knees to your chest and lean back, swinging your lower body up and hooking your legs over the bar on your side
From this inverted position with legs hooked over the bar, let your arms hang straight - this is your starting position
Pull yourself up by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together until your legs contact the bar
Pause briefly at the top, then lower yourself back down with control to full arm extension
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows down and back toward your hips - lead with your elbows, not your hands
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like you're trying to hold a pencil between them
Keep tension in your core throughout to maintain the inverted position - stay tight and controlled
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing yourself up instead of pulling with back and arm strength
Not fully extending your arms at the bottom, which reduces range of motion and lat activation
Losing the leg hook position and falling, which is dangerous
injury_prevention_tips: Practice getting into the inverted position safely before attempting the rowing movement
If you can't maintain the position, build up strength with standard pull-ups first

instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. You can place your hands behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue down to full depth if you are able,and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. As you squat, keep your head and chest up and push your knees out.
exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward, hands behind your head or crossed at your chest
Initiate the movement by pushing your hips back like you're reaching for a chair behind you, then bend your knees
Descend as low as you can while keeping your chest up and knees tracking over your toes - aim for thighs parallel to the floor or deeper
Keep your weight in your heels and mid-foot throughout the entire descent
Drive through your heels and push your knees out to stand back up explosively, squeezing your glutes at the top
form_cues: Chest up proud like there's a spotlight on your sternum - don't let your torso fold forward excessively
Push your knees out wide as you descend - imagine spreading the floor apart with your feet
Sit back into your hips like you're sitting into a chair that's slightly too far behind you
common_mistakes: Letting knees cave inward (valgus collapse), which stresses the knee joint and reduces power
Rising onto the balls of your feet and losing heel contact with the floor
Rounding your lower back at the bottom (butt wink), which can strain the spine
injury_prevention_tips: If you can't squat deep without rounding your back, work on ankle and hip mobility separately
Keep your core braced throughout like you're about to take a punch - this protects your spine

instructions: Begin standing with your feet shoulder width apart and your hands on your hips.

Step forward with one leg, flexing the knees to drop your hips. Descend until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. Your posture should remain upright, and your front knee should stay above the front foot.
Drive through the heel of your lead foot and extend both knees to raise yourself back up.
Step forward with your rear foot, repeating the lunge on the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Bodyweight Walking Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start standing tall with feet shoulder-width apart, hands on your hips or crossed at your chest
Take a big step forward (about 2-3 feet) with your right foot, planting it flat on the ground
Lower your hips straight down by bending both knees until your back knee hovers just above the floor
Drive powerfully through your front heel to stand up, bringing your back foot forward to meet your front foot
Step forward with the opposite leg and repeat, continuing to walk forward with alternating lunges
form_cues: Drop straight down like you're in an elevator, not forward - keep your torso vertical throughout
Your front shin should stay nearly vertical - imagine there's a wall right in front of your knee
Drive through your front heel like you're pushing the floor away to power back up
common_mistakes: Taking too small of a step, which causes the front knee to shoot past the toes excessively
Leaning forward too much, which shifts the work from your legs to your lower back
Letting your back knee slam into the ground instead of controlling the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to maintain an upright torso and protect your spine
If balance is an issue, master stationary lunges before attempting the walking variation

instructions: Connect a standard handle to each arm of a cable machine, and position them in the most downward position.
Grab a Bosu Ball and position it in front and center of the cable machine.
Lie down on the Bosu Ball with the small of your back arched around the ball. Your rear end should be close to the floor without touching it.
With both hands, reach back and grab the handle of each cable.
With your feet positioned in a wide stance, extend your arms straight out in front of you and in between your knees. Your hands should be at knee level.
Keep your arms straight and in-line with the upward angle of the cable. Elevate your torso in a crunching motion without dropping or bending your arms.
Maintain the rigid position with your arms. Slowly descend back to the starting position with your back arched around the Bosu Ball and your abdominals elongated.
Repeat the same series of movements to failure.
Once you reach failure, keep your abs tight and raise your torso into plank position so your back is elevated off the Bosu Ball.
Lower your arms down to your side; keep them straight. Start doing alternating side bends; reach for your heels! This finishing movement will focus on your obliques.
exercises.name: Bosu Ball Cable Crunch With Side Bends
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable handles at the lowest position on both sides, place a Bosu ball (dome side down) centered in front of the machine
Lie back on the Bosu with the small of your back arched over the ball, butt close to but not touching the floor
Reach back and grab both cable handles, then bring your arms straight out in front between your knees at knee height
Keeping arms straight and locked, crunch your torso up using your abs - think about bringing your ribcage toward your hips
After reaching failure on crunches, hold a high plank position on the Bosu and perform alternating side bends, reaching your hands toward your heels
form_cues: Keep your arms locked and rigid throughout the crunch - they're just hooks, your abs do the work
Think about curling your spine up like a wave, not sitting up in a straight line
On the side bends, crunch laterally while keeping your hips stable - imagine sliding your ribcage sideways
common_mistakes: Pulling with your arms instead of crunching with your abs, which defeats the purpose
Going too fast and using momentum instead of controlled ab contraction
Letting your lower back flatten against the Bosu at the start, losing the beneficial pre-stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light cable weight to master the movement pattern before progressing
Keep your neck neutral - don't yank your head forward with your hands during the crunch

instructions: Initiate the exercise by standing upright with a kettlebell in one hand.
Swing the kettlebell back forcefully and then reverse the motion forcefully. Crush the kettlebell handle as hard as possible and raise the kettlebell to your shoulder.
exercises.name: Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding a kettlebell in one hand by your side in the normal handle position
Swing the kettlebell back between your legs forcefully with a slight hip hinge, loading your posterior chain
Explosively reverse the motion by extending your hips and knees, generating power from your lower body
As the kettlebell rises, grip the handle as hard as you possibly can (crushing grip) and guide it upward
Flip the kettlebell so the bottom faces up, catching it at shoulder height with the bell balanced upside-down above your fist
form_cues: Squeeze the handle like you're trying to crush it into dust - this grip tension is absolutely critical for control
Generate power from your hips exploding forward, not from yanking with your arm
Keep your wrist straight and aligned with your forearm as you catch it - imagine a steel rod through your forearm
common_mistakes: Using arm strength to lift instead of hip drive, which reduces power and control
Not gripping hard enough, causing the kettlebell to wobble or fall when inverted
Letting your wrist bend or collapse when catching the bottoms-up position, risking wrist injury
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a lighter kettlebell to master the inverted catch position - this is a technical movement
Practice the bottoms-up hold separately before adding the dynamic clean component

instructions: Begin by lying on your back on the ground. Your legs should be straight and your arms at your side. This will be your starting position.

To perform the movement, tuck the knees toward your chest by flexing the hips and knees. Following this, extend your legs directly above you so that they are perpendicular to the ground. Rotate and elevate your pelvis to raise your glutes from the floor.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Bottoms Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with legs straight and arms at your sides for stability
Tuck your knees toward your chest by flexing your hips and knees, bringing them in close
From the tucked position, extend your legs straight up toward the ceiling until they're perpendicular to the ground
Rotate your pelvis and lift your glutes off the floor by crunching your lower abs, raising your hips toward the ceiling
Hold briefly at the top with legs vertical and hips elevated, then lower back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think about lifting your hips straight up toward the ceiling like you're stamping your feet on the roof
Use your lower abs to curl your tailbone upward - it's a rolling motion of the pelvis, not a hip thrust
Keep your legs as vertical as possible throughout - don't let them drift toward your head
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing your legs overhead instead of controlled ab contraction
Pushing with your arms to help lift your hips, which reduces ab engagement
Letting legs bend significantly during the hip lift, making it easier but less effective
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your upper back and shoulders flat on the floor - don't roll onto your neck
If you feel lower back strain, ensure you're tucking your knees first before extending legs up

instructions: The box squat allows you to squat to desired depth and develop explosive strength in the squat movement. Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Typically, you would aim for a box height that brings you to a parallel squat, but you can train higher or lower if desired.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.
Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe.
exercises.name: Box Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a box or bench at parallel squat height behind you in a power rack, then load the barbell on your upper back
Step out from the rack with a wider stance (outside shoulder-width), toes pointed slightly out, creating a tight arch in your lower back
Push your knees and hips back simultaneously, sitting back toward the box like you're reaching for a chair behind you
Sit down onto the box with control until you're fully seated - pause briefly and relax your hip flexors while keeping everything else tight
Drive explosively through your heels, pushing your knees out and leading with your head to stand back up to full extension
form_cues: Sit back onto the box, don't just drop down - think about reaching your butt back to find the box
Your shins should be vertical or near-vertical when seated - if your knees are forward, adjust your stance or box height
Drive your feet through the floor and spread the floor apart with your feet as you stand up
common_mistakes: Bouncing off the box instead of pausing - this defeats the purpose and can injure your spine
Letting your knees cave inward on the ascent, which stresses the joints and reduces power
Losing tightness in your core and upper back when seated, making it harder to restart the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Always pause on the box - never bounce, as this can compress your spine dangerously under load
Keep your head up and chest proud throughout - looking down will cause you to fold forward

instructions: Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Set up the bands on the sleeves, secured to either band pegs, the rack, or dumbbells so that there is appropriate tension. If dumbbells are used, secure them so that they don't move. Also, ensure that the dumbbells you are using are heavy enough for the bands that you are using. Additional plates can be used to hold the dumbbells down. If more tension is needed, you can either widen the base on the floor or choke the bands. Typically, you would aim for a box height that brings you to a parallel squat, but you can train higher or lower if desired.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe. Use care to return the barbell to the rack.
exercises.name: Box Squat with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up bands attached to the barbell sleeves and anchored to the rack or heavy dumbbells on the floor, then position a box behind you
Load the barbell on your upper back with band tension already pulling down, step out wide, and create a tight arch
Push your hips and knees back to sit onto the box, fighting the increasing band tension as you descend
Pause completely when seated on the box with your shins vertical - relax your hip flexors but keep everything else tight
Explode upward through your heels, driving your knees out and fighting the bands all the way to lockout at the top
form_cues: The bands make the weight heavier at the top, so accelerate aggressively through the middle range - think 'explode'
Fight to control the descent against the band pull - don't let them yank you down onto the box
Maintain maximum tightness from head to toe throughout - the bands will expose any weakness in your positioning
common_mistakes: Letting the bands pull you down too fast, losing control and slamming onto the box
Losing tension at the top of the movement where the bands are heaviest
Bouncing off the box due to the unstable load - you must pause completely
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular box squats before adding bands - bands increase complexity and instability significantly
Ensure bands are securely anchored and won't slip during the lift - safety first

instructions: Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Typically, you would aim for a box height that brings you to a parallel squat, but you can train higher or lower if desired.

To set up the chains, begin by looping the leader chain over the sleeves of the bar. The heavy chain should be attached using a snap hook. Adjust the length of the lead chain so that a few links are still on the floor at the top of the movement.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.
Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe.
exercises.name: Box Squat with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up in a power rack with a box behind you at parallel squat height, loop chains over the barbell sleeves so a few links remain on the floor at the top
Step under the bar placing it on your upper back, squeeze your shoulder blades together and create a tight arch in your lower back
Unrack the bar, step back and position your feet wide, keeping your head up and facing forward
Push your knees and butt out as you sit back onto the box until your shins are perpendicular to the ground
Pause on the box relaxing your hip flexors, then explode upward by driving through your heels and pushing knees out, leading with your head
form_cues: Think 'sit back to the box' not 'squat down' - your hips should move back first
Keep weight on your heels the entire time - imagine pushing the floor away through your heels
Drive your knees OUT as you descend and ascend - imagine pushing against bands around your knees
common_mistakes: Bouncing off the box instead of pausing and exploding from a dead stop
Knees caving inward instead of pushing out throughout the movement
Losing tightness when you sit on the box - maintain your arch and core tension
injury_prevention_tips: Never bounce off the box - this defeats the purpose and can compress your spine
The chains add accommodating resistance - start conservative as the top is much heavier than traditional squats

instructions: Lie on your side, with your upper arm against the foam roller. The upper arm should be more or less aligned with your body, with the outside of the bicep pressed against the foam roller.
Raise your hips off of the floor, supporting your weight on your arm and on your feet. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Brachialis-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with a foam roller positioned under your upper arm, aligned with your body
Place the outside/lateral part of your bicep area against the roller
Raise your hips off the floor, supporting your weight on your foam-rolled arm and your feet
Hold this position for 10-30 seconds, breathing slowly and allowing the muscle to release
Switch to the other side and repeat
form_cues: Think 'relax into the roller' - let your arm weight sink into it rather than tensing up
Adjust pressure by raising or lowering your hips - more weight equals more pressure
Breathe deeply and slowly - this helps the muscle tissue release
common_mistakes: Rolling too quickly instead of holding sustained pressure on tight spots
Tensing up the muscle being rolled instead of relaxing it
Not targeting the actual brachialis (outer bicep area) and rolling too far forward or back
injury_prevention_tips: This is self-myofascial release - it should be uncomfortable but not sharp pain
If you find an extremely tender spot, hold there for 20-30 seconds rather than rolling over it repeatedly

instructions: Sit on a Military Press Bench with a bar at shoulder level with a pronated grip (palms facing forward). Tip: Your grip should be wider than shoulder width and it should create a 90-degree angle between the forearm and the upper arm as the barbell goes down. This is your starting position.
Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms.
Now lower the bar down to the back of the head slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Lower the bar down to the starting position slowly as you inhale. This is one repetition.
Alternate in this manner until you complete the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Bradford/Rocky Presses
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a military press bench with a barbell at shoulder height, grip wider than shoulders with palms forward
Press the bar overhead by locking out your arms completely
Lower the bar slowly behind your head (behind-the-neck press) while inhaling
Press the bar back up overhead, then lower it to the front of your shoulders
Continue alternating: overhead to back, overhead to front - that's one full repetition
form_cues: Think 'constant tension' - the bar never stops moving, it just changes direction overhead
Keep your core braced tight like you're wearing a weightlifting belt throughout
Imagine drawing a smooth arc from front to back, pausing only at the top
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and not getting full range of motion in both positions
Rushing the movement instead of controlled, deliberate presses
Arching your back excessively to help press - keep your torso upright
injury_prevention_tips: Behind-the-neck movements require good shoulder mobility - use light weight and warm up thoroughly
If you feel shoulder pain going behind the neck, stick to front presses only

instructions: Begin a pushup position but with your elbows on the ground and resting on your forearms. Your arms should be bent at a 90 degree angle.
Arch your back slightly out rather than keeping your back completely straight.

Raise your glutes toward the ceiling, squeezing your abs tightly to close the distance between your ribcage and hips. The end result will be that you end up in a high bridge position. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lower back down slowly to your starting position as you breathe in. Tip: Don't let your back sag downwards.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Butt-Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a forearm plank position with elbows bent at 90 degrees, resting on your forearms
Slightly arch your back out rather than keeping it completely straight
Raise your glutes toward the ceiling by crunching your abs hard, bringing your ribcage closer to your hips
You should end in a high pike or bridge position with your butt pointing at the ceiling
Lower slowly back to the starting plank position, keeping tension in your core throughout
form_cues: Think 'push your butt to the ceiling' while crunching your abs like you're doing a reverse crunch
Imagine someone has a string tied to your hips pulling them straight up toward the sky
Squeeze your abs hard at the top like you're trying to close the distance between your ribs and pelvis
common_mistakes: Letting your back sag downward when returning to the starting position
Not getting your hips high enough - you should end up in a pronounced pike position
Using momentum instead of deliberate ab contraction to lift your hips
injury_prevention_tips: Keep constant tension on your abs - don't let your lower back take over
If you feel strain in your lower back, focus more on the ab crunch and less on the hip height

instructions: Lie flat on the floor on your back with the hands by your side and your knees bent. Your feet should be placed around shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
Pushing mainly with your heels, lift your hips off the floor while keeping your back straight. Breathe out as you perform this part of the motion and hold at the top for a second.
Slowly go back to the starting position as you breathe in.
exercises.name: Butt Lift (Bridge)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with knees bent, feet planted on the floor around shoulder-width apart, arms by your sides
Drive through your heels to lift your hips off the floor, squeezing your glutes hard
Keep your back straight as you lift - aim to create a straight line from shoulders to knees
Hold at the top for one full second, squeezing your glutes as hard as possible
Lower your hips slowly back to the floor with control
form_cues: Think 'push the floor away with your heels' to activate your glutes and hamstrings
Squeeze your glutes at the top like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Imagine driving your hips toward the ceiling - full hip extension at the top
common_mistakes: Pushing more through your toes than your heels, which shifts work to your quads
Hyperextending and arching your lower back instead of using pure glute squeeze
Not holding the contraction at the top - that squeeze is where the gains happen
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to prevent hyperextending your lower back
If you feel this in your lower back instead of glutes, focus on the posterior pelvic tilt

exercises.description: Chest fly performed on a machine
instructions: Sit on the machine with your back flat on the pad.
Take hold of the handles. This will be your starting position.
Push the handles together slowly as you squeeze your chest in the middle. Breathe out during this part of the motion and hold the contraction for a second.
Return back to the starting position slowly as you inhale until your chest muscles are fully stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Machine Chest Fly
tips: Your upper arms should be positioned parallel to the floor; adjust the machine accordingly.
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the fly machine with your back flat against the pad, adjust the seat so handles are at chest height
Grasp the handles with arms extended out to your sides, maintaining a slight bend in your elbows
Push the handles together in front of you in a hugging motion, squeezing your chest hard in the middle
Hold the peak contraction for one full second, feeling your pecs squeeze together
Slowly return the handles to the starting position, letting your chest stretch at the end
form_cues: Think 'bear hug a tree' - imagine wrapping your arms around something big in front of you
Squeeze your pecs together at the midpoint like you're trying to hold a pen between them
Keep a slight bend in your elbows throughout - they shouldn't straighten or bend more
common_mistakes: Straightening your arms and using too much tricep involvement
Using momentum or bouncing the weight instead of smooth, controlled movement
Not getting a full stretch at the starting position - let your chest open up fully
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let the weight pull your shoulders forward - keep your shoulder blades retracted against the pad
Start with lighter weight to master the squeeze and stretch before progressing

instructions: Adjust the weight to an appropriate amount and be seated, grasping the handles. Your upper arms should be about 45 degrees to the body, with your head and chest up. The elbows should be bent to about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending through the elbow, pressing the handles together straight in front of you. Keep your shoulder blades retracted as you execute the movement.
After pausing at full extension, return to th starting position, keeping tension on the cables.
You can also execute this movement with your back off the pad, at an incline or decline, or alternate hands.
exercises.name: Cable Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a cable press machine with cables at chest height, grasp both handles with upper arms at about 45 degrees
Start with elbows bent to 90 degrees, head and chest up, shoulder blades retracted
Press the handles forward and together by extending your elbows, bringing them together in front of you
Pause at full extension with your arms straight out, squeezing your chest
Return to the starting position with control, maintaining tension on the cables throughout
form_cues: Think 'push and squeeze' - press forward while bringing the handles together
Keep your shoulder blades pinned back like they're glued to the pad
Imagine pushing something heavy away from your chest while hugging it at the same time
common_mistakes: Letting your shoulders roll forward as you press - maintain that retracted position
Going too heavy and shortening your range of motion
Arching your back off the pad to help press instead of keeping it flat
injury_prevention_tips: The constant cable tension is more joint-friendly than free weights for many people
Keep your core braced and back supported against the pad throughout

instructions: To get yourself into the starting position, place the pulleys on a high position (above your head), select the resistance to be used and hold the pulleys in each hand.

Step forward in front of an imaginary straight line between both pulleys while pulling your arms together in front of you. Your torso should have a small forward bend from the waist. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend on your elbows in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon, extend your arms to the side (straight out at both sides) in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms and torso should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your arms back to the starting position as you breathe out. Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the starting position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Crossover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set both cable pulleys to high position above your head, select appropriate weight and grab both handles
Step forward into the center with a slight forward lean from the waist, arms extended out to the sides
With a slight bend in your elbows, bring your hands together in front of you in a wide arc, like you're hugging someone
Squeeze your chest hard when your hands meet in the middle, hold for a second
Slowly return your arms back out to the sides in the same arc, feeling a stretch across your chest
form_cues: Think 'big hugging motion' - imagine wrapping your arms around a large barrel in front of you
Lead with your elbows slightly, keeping them locked at the same angle throughout
Squeeze your pecs together in the middle like you're crushing something between them
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows more as you bring the hands together - maintain that fixed angle
Using your arms and shoulders instead of feeling it in your chest
Standing too upright instead of maintaining that slight forward lean
injury_prevention_tips: The movement should only occur at the shoulder joint - torso and arms stay rigid
Don't let the weight pull you backward - maintain control throughout the full range

exercises.description: Crunch performed with a cable machine
instructions: Kneel below a high pulley that contains a rope attachment.
Grasp cable rope attachment and lower the rope until your hands are placed next to your face.
Flex your hips slightly and allow the weight to hyperextend the lower back. This will be your starting position.

With the hips stationary, flex the waist as you contract the abs so that the elbows travel towards the middle of the thighs. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and hold the contraction for a second.

Slowly return to the starting position as you inhale. Tip: Make sure that you keep constant tension on the abs throughout the movement. Also, do not choose a weight so heavy that the lower back handles the brunt of the work.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel below a high pulley with a rope attachment, grasp the rope and lower it until your hands are by your face
Flex your hips slightly and allow the weight to hyperextend your lower back slightly - this is your starting position
Keeping your hips completely still, crunch your abs hard bringing your elbows down toward the middle of your thighs
Exhale forcefully and squeeze your abs at the bottom for a full second
Slowly return to the starting position with control, maintaining constant tension on your abs
form_cues: Think 'crunch your ribcage to your pelvis' - the movement comes from spinal flexion, not hip flexion
Keep your hips locked in place like they're cemented to the ground - only your torso should move
Squeeze your abs at the bottom like you're trying to show off a six-pack
common_mistakes: Using too much weight so your hip flexors and lower back do the work instead of your abs
Pulling with your arms instead of crunching with your core
Moving at your hips instead of flexing your spine - hips should stay completely stationary
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than you think - proper form is crucial to keep tension on your abs
If you feel this in your lower back, reduce weight and focus on pure spinal flexion

instructions: Move the cables to the bottom of the towers and select an appropriate weight. Stand directly in between the uprights.
To begin, squat down be flexing your hips and knees until you can reach the handles.
After grasping them, begin your ascent. Driving through your heels extend your hips and knees keeping your hands hanging at your side. Keep your head and chest up throughout the movement.
After reaching a full standing position, Return to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: Cable Deadlifts
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position cables at the bottom of the towers, stand directly between them and select appropriate weight
Squat down by flexing your hips and knees until you can grasp both handles
Keep your head and chest up, back straight, and arms hanging at your sides
Drive through your heels to extend your hips and knees simultaneously, standing up straight
At the top, squeeze your glutes and stand tall, then lower back down with control and repeat
form_cues: Think 'push the floor away with your heels' as you stand - leg drive initiates the movement
Keep the handles close to your body like they're sliding up your legs
Imagine you're standing up from a chair with heavy grocery bags in your hands
common_mistakes: Rounding your back instead of maintaining a neutral spine throughout
Pulling with your arms instead of driving with your legs and hips
Not achieving full hip extension at the top - stand completely upright
injury_prevention_tips: Cables provide constant tension which can be safer than barbell deadlifts for learning the pattern
Keep your core braced extremely tight throughout the entire movement

exercises.description: Hammer curl performed with cable machine
instructions: Attach a rope attachment to a low pulley and stand facing the machine about 12 inches away from it.
Grasp the rope with a neutral (palms-in) grip and stand straight up keeping the natural arch of the back and your torso stationary.
Put your elbows in by your side and keep them there stationary during the entire movement. Tip: Only the forearms should move; not your upper arms. This will be your starting position.
Using your biceps, pull your arms up as you exhale until your biceps touch your forearms. Tip: Remember to keep the elbows in and your upper arms stationary.
After a 1 second contraction where you squeeze your biceps, slowly start to bring the weight back to the original position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Hammer Curls (Rope Attachment)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to the low pulley, then stand facing the machine about a foot away with feet shoulder-width apart
Grab the rope ends with a neutral grip (thumbs up, like you're holding hammers) and stand tall with elbows pinned to your sides
Keep your upper arms completely still and curl the rope up by bending only at the elbows, bringing your fists toward your shoulders
Squeeze hard at the top when your forearms touch your biceps - imagine flexing in a mirror
Lower the rope back down slowly and under control to full arm extension, fighting the weight all the way down
form_cues: Pin your elbows to your sides like they're glued there - only your forearms should move
Keep your wrists neutral throughout - imagine you're holding two hammers and driving nails straight up
Squeeze your biceps at the top like you're showing off your arms in a double biceps pose
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows drift forward as you curl, which takes tension off the biceps and makes it easier
Swinging your torso back to use momentum instead of strict bicep control
Turning your wrists inward or outward during the curl instead of keeping that neutral hammer position
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced and avoid leaning back - this protects your lower back from hyperextension
Start with lighter weight to nail the form - the neutral grip hits the brachialis hard, so it may feel different than regular curls

instructions: Stand in front of a low pulley facing forward with one leg next to the pulley and the other one away.
Attach the ankle cuff to the cable and also to the ankle of the leg that is next to the pulley.
Now step out and away from the stack with a wide stance and grasp the bar of the pulley system.
Stand on the foot that does not have the ankle cuff (the far foot) and allow the leg with the cuff to be pulled towards the low pulley. This will be your starting position.
Now perform the movement by moving the leg with the ankle cuff in front of the far leg by using the inner thighs to abduct the hip. Breathe out during this portion of the movement.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then repeat the same movement with the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Cable Hip Adduction
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach an ankle cuff to the low pulley cable and strap it to the ankle closest to the machine
Step away from the machine with a wide stance, standing on your far leg (uncuffed) and holding the frame for balance
Let your cuffed leg get pulled slightly toward the machine by the cable tension - this is your starting position
Sweep your cuffed leg across your body in front of your standing leg, using your inner thigh to pull against the cable
Control the return as your leg moves back to the starting position, resisting the cable pull throughout
form_cues: Think about squeezing your inner thighs together like you're closing a pair of scissors
Keep your hips square and facing forward - don't let your body twist or rotate as you move your leg
Move your leg in a smooth arc across your body - imagine painting a rainbow on the floor in front of you
common_mistakes: Rotating your hips or twisting your torso instead of keeping everything stable and square
Using momentum to swing the leg across instead of controlled inner thigh contraction
Leaning away from the cable, which reduces the effectiveness of the adductor contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to avoid straining your groin muscles - the adductors are easy to overwork
Keep a slight bend in both knees for stability and to protect your standing knee from hyperextension

instructions: Lie on incline an bench facing away from a high pulley machine that has a straight bar attachment on it.

Grasp the straight bar attachment overhead with a pronated (overhand; palms down) shoulder width grip and extend your arms in front of you. The bar should be around 2 inches away from your upper thighs. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the upper arms stationary, lift your arms back in a semi circle until the bar is straight over your head. Breathe in during this portion of the movement.
Slowly go back to the starting position using your lats and hold the contraction once you reach the starting position. Breathe out during the execution of this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Incline Pushdown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set an incline bench facing away from a high cable pulley, attach a straight bar, then lie back on the bench
Reach overhead and grab the bar with an overhand grip at shoulder-width, arms extended with the bar about 2 inches above your upper thighs
Keep your upper arms locked in position and sweep the bar back overhead in a wide arc until it's above your head
Pull the bar back down to the starting position using your lats, following the same arc path - squeeze your lats hard at the bottom
Control the movement in both directions, maintaining constant tension on your back muscles throughout
form_cues: Think about pulling the bar down with your elbows, not your hands - lead with your elbows driving down
Keep your upper arms stationary throughout - imagine they're in casts and can only rotate at the shoulder
Squeeze your lats at the bottom position like you're trying to crush oranges in your armpits
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows significantly during the movement, turning it into an arm exercise instead of a lat movement
Using too much weight and letting the cable yank your arms overhead uncontrollably
Arching your lower back excessively off the bench to generate momentum
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to maintain contact between your lower back and the bench
Start with lighter weight to master the straight-arm pulling motion - this is an advanced lat isolation move

instructions: Lie on incline an bench facing away from a high pulley machine that has a straight bar attachment on it.

Grasp the straight bar attachment overhead with a pronated (overhand; palms down) narrow grip (less than shoulder width) and keep your elbows tucked in to your sides. Your upper arms should create around a 25 degree angle when measured from the floor.
Keeping the upper arms stationary, extend the arms as you flex the triceps. Breathe out during this portion of the movement and hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Incline Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up an incline bench facing away from a high pulley with a straight bar attached, then lie back on the bench
Reach overhead and grab the bar with a narrow overhand grip, positioning your upper arms at about a 25-degree angle from vertical
Start with your elbows bent and the bar near your forehead, with your upper arms locked in that angled position
Extend your elbows to press the bar away from you until your arms are straight, squeezing your triceps hard
Lower the bar back to the starting position with control, keeping your upper arms stationary throughout
form_cues: Keep your elbows tucked close together throughout - imagine holding a tennis ball between your elbows
Only move at the elbow joint - your upper arms should be frozen in space like they're pinned there
Think about pushing the bar away from your face by flexing your triceps as hard as you can
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows flare out wide as you press, which reduces tricep activation
Moving your upper arms forward or back during the movement instead of keeping them fixed
Using momentum and bouncing the weight instead of controlled tricep extension
injury_prevention_tips: Don't go too heavy initially - this angle puts your shoulders in a vulnerable position under load
Keep constant tension on the cable throughout; don't let it go slack at any point in the range

instructions: Sit next to a low pulley sideways (with legs stretched in front of you or crossed) and grasp the single hand cable attachment with the arm nearest to the cable. Tip: If you can adjust the pulley height, you can use a flat bench to sit on instead.
Position the elbow against your side with the elbow bent at 90 and the arm pointing towards the pulley. This will be your starting position.

Pull the single hand cable attachment toward your body by internally rotating your shoulder until your forearm is across your abs. You will be creating an imaginary semi-circle. Tip: The forearm should be perpendicular to your torso at all times.
Slowly go back to the initial position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then repeat the movement with the next arm.
exercises.name: Cable Internal Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit sideways next to a low pulley with your working arm (the one closest to the cable) holding the handle
Position your elbow against your side with your elbow bent at 90 degrees and your forearm pointing toward the pulley
Keep your upper arm pinned to your side and rotate your forearm across your body toward your belly button
Pull until your forearm is flat across your abs, creating a semicircular motion from outside to inside
Slowly return to the starting position, controlling the rotation back outward
form_cues: Keep your elbow glued to your side like it's connected by velcro - it should never leave your ribs
Think about rotating your forearm inward like you're closing a door handle toward your body
Your forearm should stay perpendicular to the floor throughout - imagine balancing a tray on your forearm
common_mistakes: Letting your elbow lift away from your side, which recruits the shoulder instead of the rotator cuff
Using your entire arm to pull instead of isolating the internal rotation at the shoulder
Going too fast and using momentum instead of controlled rotational strength
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weight - the rotator cuff muscles are small and easy to overload
Keep your torso stable and upright; don't lean or twist to help move the weight

instructions: Begin by moving the pulleys to the high position, select the resistance to be used, and take a handle in each hand.
Stand directly between both pulleys with your arms extended out to your sides. Your head and chest should be up while your arms form a . This will be your starting position.
Keeping the elbows extended, pull your arms straight to your sides.
Return your arms back to the starting position after a pause at the peak contraction.
Continue the movement for the prescribed number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Iron Cross
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set both cables to the high position and attach handles, then stand centered between them with arms extended out to the sides
Hold the handles with your arms forming a T-shape (like a crucifix), chest up, head forward, and elbows slightly bent
Keep your elbows locked at that slight bend and pull both handles down and across your body toward your centerline
Bring your hands together in front of your body at about waist height, squeezing your chest hard
Control the return as your arms move back out to the T-position, resisting the cable pull
form_cues: Think about hugging a giant tree as you bring your arms together - lead with your chest, not your arms
Keep your torso stable and upright - don't lean forward or backward as you pull
Squeeze your pecs together at the bottom like you're crushing a can between your chest muscles
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows significantly during the movement, turning it into a pressing motion
Using too much weight and losing the fly motion, compensating with body English
Letting your shoulders roll forward at the end position, which can strain the shoulder joint
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - this exercise creates significant stretch under load on the pecs and shoulders
Keep a slight bend in your elbows throughout to protect the elbow joints from hyperextension stress

instructions: Connect a rope attachment to a tower, and move the cable to the lowest pulley position. Stand with your side to the cable with a wide stance, and grab the rope with both hands.
Twist your body away from the pulley as you bring the rope over your shoulder like you performing a judo flip.
Shift your weight between your feet as you twist and crunch forward, pulling the cable downward.
Return to the starting position and repeat until failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Cable Judo Flip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to the low pulley and stand sideways to the machine with a wide, athletic stance
Grab the rope with both hands and start with it positioned low on the side closest to the machine
In one explosive motion, twist your torso away from the machine and pull the rope up and over your opposite shoulder
As you twist, shift your weight from the near foot to the far foot, crunching your abs hard and pulling the rope downward
Return to start with control, then complete all reps before switching to the other side
form_cues: Think about throwing someone over your shoulder in a judo throw - it's a powerful, rotational movement
Drive the motion from your core and hips - your arms are just along for the ride
Crunch forward at the end of the twist like you're bringing your ribcage toward your hip
common_mistakes: Using only your arms to pull instead of generating power from your core rotation
Not shifting your weight between feet, which reduces power and core engagement
Going too fast and losing the controlled crunch at the end of each rep
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter weight to master the rotational pattern - explosive rotation under heavy load can strain the spine
Keep your feet firmly planted throughout; don't let them slide or lose contact with the floor

instructions: Lie on a flat bench and grasp the straight bar attachment of a low pulley with a narrow overhand grip. Tip: The easiest way to do this is to have someone hand you the bar as you lay down.
With your arms extended, position the bar over your torso. Your arms and your torso should create a 90-degree angle. This will be your starting position.

Lower the bar by bending at the elbow while keeping the upper arms stationary and elbows in. Go down until the bar lightly touches your forehead. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Flex the triceps as you lift the bar back to its starting position. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Lying Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with your head toward a low pulley, grab the straight bar with a narrow overhand grip
Position the bar directly over your torso with arms extended, creating a 90-degree angle between your arms and body
Keep your upper arms stationary and locked in place, then bend your elbows to lower the bar toward your forehead
Stop just before the bar touches your forehead, then extend your elbows to press the bar back to the starting position
Squeeze your triceps hard at the top for a second, then repeat with control
form_cues: Think about your upper arms as stationary poles - only hinge at the elbow, nothing else moves
Keep your elbows pointing straight up toward the ceiling, not flaring out to the sides
Push the bar away by straightening your arms like you're trying to punch the ceiling
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows flare out wide instead of keeping them tucked and parallel
Dropping your upper arms toward your body as you lower the bar, losing the constant tension
Using momentum and bouncing the bar off your forehead instead of stopping short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep constant tension from the cable - adjust your position on the bench if the cable goes slack
Don't actually let the bar hit your forehead - stop just short to maintain tension and avoid injury

instructions: With your right hand, grasp a single handle attached to the high-cable pulley using a supinated (underhand; palms facing up) grip. You should be standing directly in front of the weight stack.

Now pull the handle down so that your upper arm and elbow are locked in to the side of your body. Your upper arm and forearm should form an acute angle (less than 90-degrees). You can keep the other arm by the waist and you can have one leg in front of you and the other one back for better balance. This will be your starting position.

As you contract the triceps, move the single handle attachment down to your side until your arm is straight. Breathe out as you perform this movement. Tip: Only the forearms should move. Your upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Squeeze the triceps and hold for a second in this contracted position.
Slowly return the handle to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform the same movement with the other arm.
exercises.name: Cable One Arm Tricep Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a single handle to the high pulley and stand facing the machine, grabbing it with one hand using an underhand grip
Pull the handle down until your elbow is locked to your side and your forearm creates an acute angle (less than 90 degrees)
Keep your upper arm pinned to your side and extend your elbow to push the handle down until your arm is completely straight
Squeeze your tricep hard at full extension for one second, then slowly return to the starting position
Complete all reps on one arm before switching to the other side
form_cues: Lock your elbow to your side like it's glued there - imagine a vice holding your upper arm in place
Think about pushing the handle down and slightly back, like you're reaching for your back pocket
Squeeze your tricep at the bottom like you're flexing in the mirror - make it pop
common_mistakes: Letting your elbow drift forward or away from your body as you extend, reducing tricep isolation
Using your shoulder to press the weight down instead of just extending at the elbow
Going too fast on the return and letting the cable yank your arm back up
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso upright and stable - don't lean into the movement or use body momentum
The underhand grip can be tough on the wrist under heavy load - start light and progress gradually

instructions: Place a preacher bench about 2 feet in front of a pulley machine.
Attach a straight bar to the low pulley.
Sit at the preacher bench with your elbow and upper arms firmly on top of the bench pad and have someone hand you the bar from the low pulley.
Grab the bar and fully extend your arms on top of the preacher bench pad. This will be your starting position.
Now start pilling the weight up towards your shoulders and squeeze the biceps hard at the top of the movement. Exhale as you perform this motion. Also, hold for a second at the top.
Now slowly lower the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a preacher bench about 2 feet in front of a low pulley with a straight bar attached
Sit at the bench and place your upper arms flat on the pad, grab the bar with an underhand grip with arms fully extended
Keep your upper arms and elbows firmly pressed against the pad - they should never lift off
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders by bending only at the elbows, squeezing your biceps hard at the top
Hold the squeeze for one second, then slowly lower the bar back to full extension with control
form_cues: Press your upper arms into the pad like you're trying to push through it - they should never lose contact
Think about bringing your pinky fingers toward your shoulders - this maximizes bicep peak contraction
Squeeze your biceps at the top like you're trying to touch your fist to your bicep
common_mistakes: Lifting your elbows off the pad at the top of the curl to cheat the weight up with shoulder help
Not lowering to full extension at the bottom, which reduces the range of motion and effectiveness
Leaning back or using body English to help curl the weight instead of strict bicep control
injury_prevention_tips: Lower the weight slowly to full extension - don't let the cable yank your arms straight, which can hyperextend the elbow
Keep constant tension from the cable throughout the set; adjust the bench distance if the cable goes slack at the top

instructions: Adjust the pulleys to the appropriate height and adjust the weight. The pulleys should be above your head.
Grab the left pulley with your right hand and the right pulley with your left hand, crossing them in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by moving your arms back and outward, keeping your arms straight as you execute the movement.
Pause at the end of the motion before returning the handles to the start position.
exercises.name: Cable Rear Delt Fly
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set both cable pulleys above head height, cross your arms and grab the left pulley with your right hand and right pulley with your left
Stand in the center with arms crossed in front of you, slight bend in elbows - this is your starting position
Pull both handles back and outward in a wide arc, uncrossing your arms and moving them straight out to your sides
Keep your arms nearly straight and squeeze your rear delts hard when your arms are out wide
Pause briefly, then return to the crossed position with control
form_cues: Think 'open your arms wide' like you're spreading your chest - reverse fly motion
Keep your elbows locked at the same slight bend throughout - no bending or straightening
Squeeze your rear delts at the end like you're pinching your shoulder blades together
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows more as you pull, turning it into a rowing motion
Using your lats and back instead of isolating the rear delts
Standing too close to the cables which reduces the range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - rear delts are small muscles that fatigue quickly
Keep your torso still and upright - don't lean forward or backward

instructions: Connect an ankle strap attachment to a low pulley cable and position a mat on the floor in front of it.
Sit down with your feet toward the pulley and attach the cable to your ankles.
Lie down, elevate your legs and bend your knees at a 90-degree angle. Your legs and the cable should be aligned. If not, adjust the pulley up or down until they are.
With your hands behind your head, bring your knees inward to your torso and elevate your hips off the floor.
Pause for a moment and in a slow and controlled manner drop your hips and bring your legs back to the starting 90-degree angle. You should still have tension on your abs in the resting position.
Repeat the same movement to failure.
exercises.name: Cable Reverse Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach ankle straps to a low pulley, lie on a mat with feet toward the cable and secure straps to your ankles
Lie back with legs elevated and knees bent at 90 degrees, hands behind your head for support
Crunch by bringing your knees toward your chest while lifting your hips off the floor
Squeeze your lower abs hard at the peak, pause for a second
Lower your hips back down slowly until legs return to 90 degrees while maintaining tension
form_cues: Think 'curl your pelvis toward your ribcage' - it's a lower ab crunch, not a leg raise
Keep tension on your abs even in the starting position - don't let them relax
Imagine trying to bring your pubic bone toward your belly button
common_mistakes: Just moving your legs instead of actually crunching and lifting your hips
Going too heavy and losing the ab contraction
Letting your lower back arch off the floor - keep it pressed down
injury_prevention_tips: The cable adds resistance throughout - start lighter than bodyweight reverse crunches
If you feel strain in your hip flexors, reduce weight and focus on the ab curl

instructions: Attach a rope to the bottom pulley of the pulley machine.

Grasping the rope with both hands, extend your arms with your hands directly above your head using a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Your elbows should be in close to your head and the arms should be perpendicular to the floor with the knuckles aimed at the ceiling. This will be your starting position.
Slowly lower the rope behind your head as you hold the upper arms stationary. Inhale as you perform this movement and pause when your triceps are fully stretched.
Return to the starting position by flexing your triceps as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Rope Overhead Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a low pulley, grab it with both hands and extend your arms straight overhead
Position your elbows close to your head pointing at the ceiling, arms perpendicular to the floor - starting position
Lower the rope behind your head by bending only at the elbows, keeping upper arms completely still
Go down until you feel a full stretch in your triceps, pause briefly
Extend your elbows to press the rope back to the starting position, squeezing your triceps at the top
form_cues: Think 'elbows glued in place pointing up' - only your forearms should move
Squeeze your triceps at the top like you're flexing the back of your arms
Imagine your upper arms are in a cast - they can't move at all
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows flare out to the sides instead of staying tight to your head
Moving your upper arms forward or back - they should stay perpendicular to the floor
Not getting full extension at the top - lock out completely for maximum tricep engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Constant cable tension makes this harder than it looks - start lighter than dumbbell versions
If you feel elbow discomfort, slightly adjust the angle of your upper arms

instructions: Sit in the same position on a low pulley row station as you would if you were doing seated cable rows for the back.
Attach a rope to the pulley and grasp it with an overhand grip. Your arms should be extended and parallel to the floor with the elbows flared out.
Keep your lower back upright and slide your hips back so that your knees are slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Pull the cable attachment towards your upper chest, just below the neck, as you keep your elbows up and out to the sides. Continue this motion as you exhale until the elbows travel slightly behind the back. Tip: Keep your upper arms horizontal, perpendicular to the torso and parallel to the floor throughout the motion.
Go back to the initial position where the arms are extended and the shoulders are stretched forward. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Rope Rear-Delt Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a low cable row station with a rope attachment, grasp it with an overhand grip
Start with arms extended parallel to the floor and elbows flared out to the sides
Keep your lower back upright with knees slightly bent - this is your starting position
Pull the rope toward your upper chest (just below neck level) keeping your elbows high and wide
Your elbows should travel back slightly past your torso at full contraction, then return with control
form_cues: Think 'elbows high and wide' throughout - your upper arms should stay horizontal and parallel to the floor
Pull to your face/upper chest level, not to your stomach like a regular row
Imagine doing a reverse bench press - squeeze your rear delts at the back
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows drop down, turning it into a regular back row
Pulling to your stomach instead of your upper chest/face
Rounding your back or using momentum instead of controlled pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your upper arms horizontal throughout - this isolates your rear delts properly
Start light and focus on form - this is a rear delt exercise, not a strength move

instructions: Connect a standard handle attachment, and position the cable to a middle pulley position.
Lie on a stability ball perpendicular to the cable and grab the handle with one hand. You should be approximately arm length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable.
Grab the handle with both hands and fully extend your arms above your chest. You hands should be directly in-line with the pulley. If not, adjust the pulley up or down until they are.
Keep your hips elevated and abs engaged. Rotate your torso away from the pulley for a full-quarter rotation. Your body should be flat from head to knees.
Pause for a moment and in a slow and controlled manner reset to the starting position. You should still have side tension on the cable in the resting position.
Repeat the same movement to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Cable Russian Twists
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable to middle height, lie on a stability ball perpendicular to the cable, about arm's length away
Grab the handle with both hands and extend your arms straight above your chest, in line with the cable
Keep your hips elevated and body flat from head to knees, abs engaged tight
Rotate your torso away from the cable for a quarter turn, keeping your arms straight and hips level
Pause, then rotate back to the starting position with control, maintaining tension throughout
form_cues: Think 'twist from your core' while keeping your hips completely still and level
Keep your body rigid like a plank rotating on the ball - no sagging or twisting at the hips
Imagine someone is pulling your hands to the side and you're resisting with your obliques
common_mistakes: Letting your hips drop or rotate instead of keeping them elevated and stable
Bending your arms or using them to help instead of rotating from your core
Going too fast - this should be slow and controlled with constant tension
injury_prevention_tips: The stability ball makes this challenging - start with very light weight
If you can't keep your hips level, reduce weight or use a firmer surface

instructions: Seat on a flat bench with your back facing a high pulley.

Grasp the cable rope attachment with both hands (with the palms of the hands facing each other) and place your hands securely over both shoulders. Tip: Allow the weight to hyperextend the lower back slightly. This will be your starting position.
With the hips stationary, flex the waist so the elbows travel toward the hips. Breathe out as you perform this step.
As you inhale, go back to the initial position slowly.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cable Seated Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a flat bench facing away from a high pulley with a rope attachment
Grasp the rope with both hands and place your hands over both shoulders, letting the weight pull you back slightly
With hips stationary, crunch your waist forward bringing your elbows toward your hips
Exhale forcefully and squeeze your abs hard at the bottom
Slowly return to the starting position, maintaining tension on your abs throughout
form_cues: Think 'crunch your ribcage to your pelvis' - pure spinal flexion, hips don't move
Keep your hips glued to the bench - only your torso should flex forward
Squeeze your abs like you're trying to show off a six-pack at the bottom
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and pulling with your arms instead of crunching with your abs
Moving at your hips instead of flexing your spine
Not keeping constant tension on your abs between reps
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than you think - your abs should do all the work, not your arms
If you feel this in your lower back, reduce weight and focus on pure ab contraction

instructions: Stand in the middle of two low pulleys that are opposite to each other and place a flat bench right behind you (in perpendicular fashion to you; the narrow edge of the bench should be the one behind you). Select the weight to be used on each pulley.
Now sit at the edge of the flat bench behind you with your feet placed in front of your knees.
Bend forward while keeping your back flat and rest your torso on the thighs.

Have someone give you the single handles attached to the pulleys. Grasp the left pulley with the right hand and the right pulley with the left after you select your weight. The pulleys should run under your knees and your arms will be extended with palms facing each other and a slight bend at the elbows. This will be the starting position.

While keeping the arms stationary, raise the upper arms to the sides until they are parallel to the floor and at shoulder height. Exhale during the execution of this movement and hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly lower your arms to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions. Tip: Maintain upper arms perpendicular to torso and a fixed elbow position (10 degree to 30 degree angle) throughout exercise.
exercises.name: Cable Seated Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the edge of a bench between two low pulleys, lean forward resting your torso on your thighs
