To initiate the movement, externally rotate the shoulders to move the upper arm 180 degrees. Keep the upper arms in place, rotating the upper arms until the wrists are directly above the elbows, the forearms perpendicular to the floor.
Now press the dumbbells by extending at the elbows, straightening your arms overhead.
Return to the starting position as you breathe in by reversing the steps.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Cuban Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells with arms up at shoulder height, elbows bent 90 degrees in the scarecrow position
Rotate your forearms up like you're closing a book, keeping your upper arms parallel to the floor
Once the dumbbells are overhead with forearms vertical, press them straight up by extending your elbows
Lower back down by reversing the motion - bend elbows, then rotate forearms back down to scarecrow
Keep your upper arms at shoulder height throughout the entire movement
form_cues: Think 'scarecrow to waiter to press' - three distinct positions
Keep your upper arms glued at shoulder height like they're resting on an invisible shelf
Rotate slowly and controlled - imagine your shoulders are rusty hinges you're oiling
At the top of the press, push your head through like you're looking out a window
common_mistakes: Dropping the elbows below shoulder height during the rotation phase
Rushing through the external rotation instead of moving with control
Using too much weight and compensating with momentum or back arch
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - this exercise is about shoulder health and control, not ego lifting
If you feel any pinching in the shoulder during rotation, reduce the weight immediately

instructions: Sit up on the floor.
Cross your right leg over your left, keeping the knee bent. Your left leg is straight and down on the floor.
Place your left arm on your right leg and your right hand on the floor.
Rotate your upper body to the right, and hold for 10-20 seconds. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Dancer's Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your left leg straight out in front and your right leg crossed over it with knee bent
Place your left elbow/forearm on the outside of your right knee
Put your right hand on the floor behind you for support
Gently rotate your upper body to the right, using your left arm to deepen the twist
Hold for 10-20 seconds feeling the stretch in your lower back and glutes, then switch sides
form_cues: Sit tall like there's a string pulling the crown of your head toward the ceiling
Think about rotating from your belly button, not just turning your head
Use your arm as gentle leverage - don't force the twist
common_mistakes: Rounding the back forward instead of maintaining an upright, tall spine
Cranking the twist too hard with the arm instead of rotating naturally
Holding the breath - remember to breathe deeply throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the twist gentle and progressive - never force it beyond mild tension
If you have any disc issues, consult a professional before doing spinal rotations

instructions: Begin lying on your back with your hands extended above you toward the ceiling.
Bring your feet, knees, and hips up to 90 degrees.

Exhale hard to bring your ribcage down and flatten your back onto the floor, rotating your pelvis up and squeezing your glutes. Hold this position throughout the movement. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the exercise by extending one leg, straightening the knee and hip to bring the leg just above the ground.
Maintain the position of your lumbar and pelvis as you perform the movement, as your back is going to want to arch.
Stay tight and return the working leg to the starting position.
Repeat on the opposite side, alternating until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Dead Bug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with arms extended straight up toward the ceiling
Bring both knees up so hips and knees are bent to 90 degrees, like sitting in a chair on your back
Exhale hard and press your lower back completely flat into the floor by tilting your pelvis up
Slowly extend one leg out straight, hovering just above the ground, while keeping your back flat
Return that leg back to start position and repeat with the other leg, alternating sides
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to flatten a piece of paper with your lower back against the floor
Keep your ribs down - don't let your chest puff up as you extend your leg
Move your leg like it's moving through thick honey - slow and controlled
If your back arches even slightly, you've gone too far - bring the leg back
common_mistakes: Letting the lower back arch off the floor as the leg extends - this defeats the purpose
Moving too fast and using momentum instead of core control
Breathing irregularly - exhale as you extend the leg to help keep the core engaged
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back glued to the floor at all times - if it arches, don't lower the leg as far
Start with smaller leg movements and progress to fuller extensions as you get stronger

instructions: To deadlift with short bands, simply loop them over the bar before you start, and step into them to set up. For long bands, they will need to be anchored to a secure base, such as heavy dumbbells or a rack.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.
exercises.name: Deadlift with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up resistance bands under your feet or anchored to the rack, looped over the barbell
Approach the bar with feet hip-width, bend down and grip the bar at shoulder width
Take a big breath, lower your hips, and press your lower back flat while keeping chest up
Drive through your heels to stand up, keeping the bar close to your body as it rises
Once past your knees, thrust your hips forward and squeeze your glutes hard at the top
Lower the bar back down by pushing your hips back first, then bending your knees
form_cues: Think 'push the floor away' rather than pulling the bar up
Keep the bar scraping your shins and thighs - imagine zipping up tight jeans
At the top, squeeze your glutes like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
The bands make it harder at the top, so really focus on explosive hip drive
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift forward away from the body, which strains the lower back
Starting with hips too high, turning it into a stiff-legged deadlift
Rounding the back under the increased band tension at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced hard throughout - imagine someone's about to punch your stomach
The bands add accommodating resistance - don't max out until you're comfortable with the tension curve

instructions: You can attach the chains to the sleeves of the bar, or just drape the middle over the bar so there is a greater weight increase as you lift.

Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets. With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar.

Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.
exercises.name: Deadlift with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Drape chains over the barbell so more links lift off the ground as you rise
Stand with feet hip-width apart, toes under the bar, and grip it at shoulder width
Take a deep breath, drop your hips down, and set your back flat with chest proud
Push through your heels to lift the bar, keeping it close to your legs as you stand
Drive your hips forward aggressively as the bar passes your knees and squeeze your glutes at the top
Lower the bar by hinging at the hips first, then bending the knees to guide it down
form_cues: The weight gets heavier as you lift - accelerate through the top portion with explosive hips
Think 'leg press the floor' at the bottom, then 'hip thrust' at the top
Keep the bar glued to your body like you're dragging it up your legs
Finish tall with shoulders back like a soldier at attention
common_mistakes: Starting too explosively at the bottom before the chains add weight - save power for the top
Letting the increasing weight pull you forward - fight to keep the bar close
Hyperextending the back at lockout instead of finishing with neutral spine and tight glutes
injury_prevention_tips: The chains teach you to accelerate through lockout - this is great for power but requires solid technique first
Keep your entire core braced throughout, especially as the weight increases near the top

exercises.description: Decline bench press performed with a medium grip on a barbell
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.

Using a medium width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: In order to protect your rotator cuff, it is best if you have a spotter help you lift the barbell off the rack.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your lower chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up).
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Barbell Decline Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and carefully lie back with the bar above you
Grip the bar at a medium width where your forearms are vertical at the bottom of the rep
Unrack the bar with a spotter's help and hold it over your lower chest with arms extended
Lower the bar with control to your lower chest, keeping your elbows at about 45 degrees
Press the bar back up explosively until your arms lock out, pause briefly, then repeat
form_cues: Touch the bar to your lower chest near your sternum - not up by your neck
Think about pushing the bar slightly toward your feet at the top to keep it over your shoulders
Drive your feet into the foot pads to create tension through your whole body
At the top, squeeze your chest like you're doing a most muscular pose
common_mistakes: Lowering the bar too high toward the neck instead of the lower chest
Bouncing the bar off the chest instead of controlling the descent
Pressing the bar straight up instead of slightly back, which pulls you off balance on the decline
injury_prevention_tips: Always use a spotter on decline bench - it's harder to self-bail if you fail a rep
The decline angle is easier on shoulders but can cause lightheadedness - unrack slowly

instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.

Using a close grip (a grip that is slightly less than shoulder width), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked and elbows in. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: In order to protect your rotator cuff, it is best if you have a spotter help you lift the barbell off the rack.
Now lower the bar down to your lower chest as you breathe in. Keep the elbows in as you perform this movement.
Using the triceps to push the bar back up, press it back to the starting position as you exhale.

As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary, bring the bar down slowly by moving your forearms in a semicircular motion towards you until you feel the bar slightly touch your forehead. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lift the bar back to the starting position by contracting the triceps and exhaling.
Repeat steps 3-6 until the recommended amount of repetitions is performed.
exercises.name: Decline Close-Grip Bench To Skull Crusher
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs on the decline bench and lie back, gripping the bar slightly narrower than shoulders
Start with the bar pressed over your chest, then lower it to your lower chest with elbows tucked
Press it back up to lockout - this is the close-grip bench portion
Now keep your upper arms still and lower the bar toward your forehead by bending only at the elbows
Extend your elbows back to lockout - that's the skull crusher portion - then repeat the whole sequence
form_cues: Think 'press and extend' - two distinct movements that flow together
During the skull crusher, keep your upper arms locked in position like they're in a cast
Lower the bar to your forehead or just above - imagine you're trying to tap your hairline
Control is everything - this is a slow, deliberate movement, not a momentum exercise
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows flare out during the bench portion instead of keeping them tucked
Dropping the upper arms back during skull crushers instead of keeping them perpendicular to the floor
Using too much weight and losing control of the bar path
injury_prevention_tips: This combo exercise is advanced - master close-grip bench and skull crushers separately first
The decline angle adds complexity - use a spotter and start with very light weight

instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down.
Now place your hands lightly on either side of your head keeping your elbows in. Tip: Don't lock your fingers behind your head.
While pushing the small of your back down in the bench to better isolate your abdominal muscles, begin to roll your shoulders off it.

Continue to push down as hard as you can with your lower back as you contract your abdominals and exhale. Your shoulders should come up off the bench only about four inches, and your lower back should remain on the bench. At the top of the movement, contract your abdominals hard and keep the contraction for a second. Tip: Focus on slow, controlled movement - don't cheat yourself by using momentum.
After the one second contraction, begin to come down slowly again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Decline Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your feet at the top of the decline bench and lie back with your head lower than your feet
Place your fingertips lightly behind your ears with elbows pointing out to the sides
Press your lower back into the bench and begin to curl your shoulders up off the bench
Lift only your shoulder blades up about 4 inches, keeping your lower back pressed down
Squeeze your abs hard at the top for a full second, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Think about shortening the distance between your ribcage and your pelvis
Imagine you're trying to look at your belly button - curl up, don't just lift your head
Exhale forcefully at the top like you're blowing out birthday candles - this maximizes ab contraction
Keep your lower back glued to the bench like it's magnetized there
common_mistakes: Pulling on the neck with hands instead of letting the abs do the work
Coming up too high and lifting the lower back off the bench, which uses hip flexors
Using momentum to swing up and down instead of controlling each rep
injury_prevention_tips: Never yank on your neck - your hands are just there for light support
The decline increases the difficulty significantly - start with a small angle if you're new to these

exercises.description: Decline bench press performed with a dumbbells
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.
Once you are laying down, move the dumbbells in front of you at shoulder width.
Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.
Bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe out. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times. Tip: Throughout the motion, the forearms should always be perpendicular to the floor.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up..
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Decline Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs on the decline bench and sit down with dumbbells resting on your thighs
Carefully lie back while bringing the dumbbells to your chest, then press them up to arm's length
Rotate your wrists so palms face away from you (forward) at the top with dumbbells over your lower chest
Lower the dumbbells out to the sides with control, keeping forearms vertical throughout
Press the dumbbells back up until your arms lock out, squeeze your chest, then repeat
form_cues: Think about pushing the dumbbells up and slightly toward your feet at the top
At the bottom, your elbows should be slightly below the level of your chest for a good stretch
Drive your feet hard into the foot holds to create full-body tension
Squeeze the dumbbells together at the top like you're trying to crush something between them
common_mistakes: Pressing the dumbbells straight up instead of slightly toward your feet, throwing off balance
Letting the dumbbells drift too far apart at the top instead of keeping them over your shoulders
Lowering too fast and losing control - the eccentric should be twice as long as the press
injury_prevention_tips: Getting into position on a decline is tricky - practice with light weights first
Keep your feet locked in tight - you don't want to slide down during the set

instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

Once you are laying down, move the dumbbells in front of you at shoulder width. The palms of the hands should be facing each other and the arms should be perpendicular to the floor and fully extended. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend on your elbows in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon, lower your arms out at both sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your arms back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and breathe out. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Decline Dumbbell Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs on the decline bench and lie back with dumbbells held at arm's length above your chest
Start with palms facing each other and a slight bend in your elbows to protect your bicep tendons
Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, keeping that elbow bend constant
Go down until you feel a deep stretch across your chest - dumbbells should be level with your torso
Squeeze your chest to bring the dumbbells back up using the same arc, like you're hugging a tree
form_cues: Think about opening and closing a big barrel - that's the arc you want
Keep your elbows at the same angle throughout - only your shoulders should move
At the bottom, feel the stretch across your chest like someone's pulling your arms apart
At the top, squeeze like you're crushing a beach ball between your arms
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows more as you lower, turning it into a press instead of a fly
Lowering the dumbbells too far down, which can stress the shoulder joint
Using too much weight and losing the smooth arc motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a consistent elbow bend - too straight puts dangerous tension on the bicep tendon
Start light and focus on the stretch and squeeze - this is an isolation exercise, not a strength move

instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

Once you are laying down, move the dumbbells in front of you at shoulder width. The palms of the hands should be facing each other and the arms should be perpendicular to the floor and fully extended. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary (and elbows in), bring the dumbbells down slowly by moving your forearms in a semicircular motion towards you until your thumbs are next to your ears. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lift the dumbbells back to the starting position by contracting the triceps and exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Decline Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie back with a dumbbell in each hand resting on your thighs
Press the dumbbells up to shoulder width with arms fully extended perpendicular to the floor, palms facing each other
Keep your upper arms locked in place and elbows tucked - imagine your upper arms are bolted to the bench
Lower the dumbbells in a smooth arc by bending only at the elbows until your thumbs reach your ears
Drive the dumbbells back up by squeezing your triceps hard, like you're trying to straighten out a resistant spring
form_cues: Pin your upper arms in space - only your forearms should move like windshield wipers
Think about driving your elbows toward the ceiling on the way up
Keep your elbows slightly angled inward throughout - imagine holding a beach ball between your elbows
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows flare out wide, which shifts tension away from the triceps
Moving the upper arms during the rep instead of keeping them stationary
Arching the lower back excessively - keep your core braced like you're about to be pushed
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the movement pattern before progressing
Keep wrists neutral and aligned with forearms - don't let them bend backward under the weight

instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.

Using a close grip (a grip that is slightly less than shoulder width), lift the EZ bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked and elbows in. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: In order to protect your rotator cuff, it is best if you have a spotter help you lift the barbell off the rack.

As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary, bring the bar down slowly by moving your forearms in a semicircular motion towards you until you feel the bar slightly touch your forehead. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lift the bar back to the starting position by contracting the triceps and exhaling.
Repeat until the recommended amount of repetitions is performed.
exercises.name: Decline EZ Bar Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs and lie back on the decline bench, having a spotter hand you the EZ bar
Hold the bar with a close grip (narrower than shoulders) with arms fully locked out perpendicular to the floor
Lock your upper arms in position and slowly lower the bar in an arc toward your forehead by bending only at the elbows
Stop just before the bar lightly touches your forehead - feel the deep stretch in your triceps
Press the bar back up by extending your elbows, focusing on squeezing your triceps at the top
form_cues: Imagine your upper arms are frozen solid - all movement comes from the elbows down
Think about pulling the bar apart as you press up to keep tension on the triceps
Lower under control like you're trying not to wake someone sleeping beneath you
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drift back toward your head during the movement
Using momentum to bounce the bar off the forehead instead of controlled movement
Dropping the shoulders forward instead of keeping them pinned to the bench
injury_prevention_tips: Always use a spotter to hand off the bar and take it back at the end
Keep the descent slow and controlled to protect your elbows from sudden stress

instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.
Raise your upper body off the bench until your torso is about 35-45 degrees if measured from the floor.
Put one hand beside your head and the other on your thigh. This will be your starting position.

Raise your upper body slowly from the starting position while turning your torso to the left. Continue crunching up as you exhale until your right elbow touches your left knee. Hold this contracted position for a second. Tip: Focus on keeping your abs tight and keeping the movement slow and controlled.
Lower your body back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.

After completing one set on the right for the recommended amount of repetitions, switch to your left side. Tip: Focus on really twisting your torso and feeling the contraction when you are in the up position.
exercises.name: Decline Oblique Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs at the decline bench and lie back, raising your torso to about 35-45 degrees from the floor
Place one hand beside your head (don't pull on it) and the other hand on your thigh as a guide
Crunch up while rotating your torso, bringing your elbow across toward the opposite knee
Focus on twisting from your core - imagine wringing out a wet towel as you rotate
Lower back down with control and complete all reps on one side before switching
form_cues: Lead with your elbow driving toward the opposite hip pocket
Think about your obliques as a zipper closing diagonally across your torso
Keep your chin off your chest - imagine holding an apple under your chin throughout
common_mistakes: Pulling on the neck with the hand instead of letting the core do the work
Rushing the movement and using momentum instead of muscle contraction
Not rotating enough - the movement should be diagonal, not straight up
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the hand by your head light - fingertips only, no yanking on your neck
Move slowly and deliberately to maintain control on the decline angle

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart while holding your torso up at arms length. Move your feet up to a box or bench. This will be your starting position.
Next, lower yourself downward until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Now breathe out and press your upper body back up to the starting position while squeezing your chest.
After a brief pause at the top contracted position, you can begin to lower yourself downward again for as many repetitions as needed.
exercises.name: Decline Push-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into push-up position with hands shoulder-width apart and feet elevated on a box or bench
Your body should form a straight line from head to heels - engage your core like you're bracing for a punch
Lower yourself down by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the floor
Think about pulling yourself down into the floor rather than just dropping
Press back up explosively, squeezing your chest at the top like you're trying to push the floor away
form_cues: Imagine screwing your hands into the ground to create tension and stability
Keep your elbows at about 45 degrees - not tucked tight or flared completely out
Think about pushing your chest through your hands on the way up
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag or pike up instead of maintaining a rigid plank position
Flaring the elbows out to 90 degrees, which stresses the shoulders
Not going deep enough - your chest should come within an inch of the floor
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout to protect your lower back from hyperextension
Start with feet at a lower height if the full decline is too challenging

instructions: Lie on your back on a decline bench and hold on to the top of the bench with both hands. Don't let your body slip down from this position.

Hold your legs parallel to the floor using your abs to hold them there while keeping your knees and feet together. Tip: Your legs should be fully extended with a slight bend on the knee. This will be your starting position.
While exhaling, move your legs towards the torso as you roll your pelvis backwards and you raise your hips off the bench. At the end of this movement your knees will be touching your chest.
Hold the contraction for a second and move your legs back to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Decline Reverse Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a decline bench and grip the top firmly with both hands behind your head
Extend your legs parallel to the floor with a slight bend in the knees, engaging your abs to hold them there
Roll your pelvis backward while pulling your knees toward your chest - think about curling your tailbone up toward your ribcage
At the top, your knees should touch your chest and your hips should be off the bench
Lower your legs back to the starting position with control, fighting gravity all the way down
form_cues: Think about scooping your lower abs to curl your hips up, not swinging your legs
Imagine your abs are a rope pulling your knees and chest together
Focus on the pelvis rotation - your butt should lift off the bench at the top
common_mistakes: Using leg momentum to swing up instead of contracting the abs
Not lifting the hips off the bench - just bringing knees in without pelvic rotation
Letting the legs drop too fast on the way down, losing all tension
injury_prevention_tips: Grip the bench firmly to prevent sliding down during the movement
Keep the movement controlled - don't let gravity slam your legs down

instructions: Place a decline bench underneath the Smith machine. Now place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Using a pronated grip that is wider than shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, lower the bar under control by allowing the elbows to flex, lightly contacting the torso.
After a brief pause, bring the bar back to the starting position by extending the elbows, exhaling as you do so.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When the set is complete, lock the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Decline Smith Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a decline bench under the Smith machine and position the bar at arm's length height when lying down
Lie back and grip the bar wider than shoulder-width, unlock it, and hold it with arms extended over your lower chest
Lower the bar under control to lightly touch your lower chest, keeping your elbows at about 45 degrees
Think about pulling the bar down to your chest rather than letting it drop
Press the bar back up explosively, squeezing your chest hard at the top like you're doing a most muscular pose
form_cues: Drive through your heels and squeeze your glutes to stay stable on the decline
Imagine trying to bend the bar in half as you press to engage your chest fully
Think about pushing yourself into the bench rather than pushing the bar up
common_mistakes: Bouncing the bar off the chest instead of using a controlled touch
Flaring elbows out to 90 degrees, which puts excessive stress on the shoulders
Letting your butt come off the bench, losing stability and power
injury_prevention_tips: Use the Smith machine's safety catches as a backup in case you fail
Keep your shoulder blades squeezed together and pinned to the bench throughout

instructions: Begin by having a platform or weight plates that you can stand on, usually 1-3 inches in height. Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.
exercises.name: Deficit Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on a 1-3 inch platform with the barbell centered over the middle of your feet, which are hip-width apart
Hinge at the hips and grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to reach forward
Take a deep breath, lower your hips until your shins touch the bar, and create tension by pulling the slack out
Keep your chest up, back flat like a table, and drive through your heels to pull the weight up
Once the bar passes your knees, aggressively drive your hips forward and squeeze your glutes hard at the top
form_cues: Think about pushing the floor away rather than pulling the bar up
Imagine zipping your lats down into your back pockets before you pull
Keep the bar glued to your shins and thighs - it should scrape your legs on the way up
common_mistakes: Starting with hips too high, turning it into a stiff-legged deadlift
Letting the bar drift away from the body, which increases lower back strain
Rounding the lower back instead of maintaining a neutral spine throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to build strength in the extended range of motion - the deficit makes it harder
Keep your core braced like you're about to be punched throughout the entire lift

exercises.description: Dips performed on a machine
instructions: Sit securely in a dip machine, select the weight and firmly grasp the handles.
Now keep your elbows in at your sides in order to place emphasis on the triceps. The elbows should be bent at a 90 degree angle.
As you contract the triceps, extend your arms downwards as you exhale. Tip: At the bottom of the movement, focus on keeping a little bend in your arms to keep tension on the triceps muscle.
Now slowly let your arms come back up to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Machine Dips
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in the dip machine and select your weight, then firmly grasp the handles with arms bent at 90 degrees
Keep your elbows tucked close to your sides - imagine squeezing a newspaper between your elbows and ribs
Press down by extending your arms, focusing on contracting your triceps hard
Stop just before full lockout to keep constant tension on the triceps
Control the handles back up to the starting position, resisting the weight all the way
form_cues: Think about driving your hands down toward your hips, not away from your body
Imagine your triceps are springs compressing and extending with each rep
Keep a slight lean forward to maintain balance and tricep engagement
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows flare out wide, which shifts emphasis away from triceps
Locking out completely at the bottom and resting instead of maintaining tension
Using momentum to bounce through reps instead of controlled movement
injury_prevention_tips: Don't lock out completely at the bottom - keep a micro-bend to protect your elbows
Start with lighter weight to perfect the form before loading heavy

exercises.description: Dips with a chest focus performed on parallel bars (or similar)
instructions: For this exercise you will need access to parallel bars. To get yourself into the starting position, hold your body at arms length (arms locked) above the bars.
While breathing in, lower yourself slowly with your torso leaning forward around 30 degrees or so and your elbows flared out slightly until you feel a slight stretch in the chest.
Once you feel the stretch, use your chest to bring your body back to the starting position as you breathe out. Tip: Remember to squeeze the chest at the top of the movement for a second.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dips (Chest Focus)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Jump or step up to support yourself on parallel bars with arms locked and body at arm's length
Lean your torso forward about 30 degrees and let your elbows flare out slightly wider than your body
Lower yourself down under control until you feel a stretch across your chest - go deeper than 90 degrees
Think about opening up your chest like you're stretching out a rubber band
Drive back up by squeezing your chest hard, as if you're doing a bear hug at the top
form_cues: Lead with your chest forward and down - imagine diving into the dip
Think about pushing the bars apart (even though they don't move) to engage your chest
At the top, squeeze like you're finishing a cable fly, crushing your pecs together
common_mistakes: Staying too upright, which turns it into a triceps-dominant movement
Not going deep enough - you need to stretch the chest below 90 degrees
Shrugging the shoulders up toward the ears instead of keeping them depressed
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blades pulled down and back throughout to protect the shoulder joint
Don't descend beyond your natural flexibility - stop at a comfortable stretch point

exercises.description: Dips with a triceps focus performed on parallel bars (or similar)
instructions: To get into the starting position, hold your body at arm's length with your arms nearly locked above the bars.

Now, inhale and slowly lower yourself downward. Your torso should remain upright and your elbows should stay close to your body. This helps to better focus on tricep involvement. Lower yourself until there is a 90 degree angle formed between the upper arm and forearm.
Then, exhale and push your torso back up using your triceps to bring your body back to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dips (Triceps Focus)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Support yourself on parallel bars with arms nearly locked and your body upright at arm's length
Keep your torso vertical (not leaning forward) and elbows tucked close to your sides
Lower yourself down by bending at the elbows until you reach 90 degrees - upper and lower arm form an L
Think about your body going straight down like an elevator, not forward
Press back up by straightening your arms, focusing on squeezing your triceps hard at the top
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are glued to your sides - they shouldn't flare out at all
Think about pushing the bars straight down toward the ground, not away from you
Keep your chest up and proud - don't let your shoulders roll forward
common_mistakes: Leaning too far forward, which shifts the work to your chest instead of triceps
Letting the elbows drift outward instead of staying tight to the body
Going too deep past 90 degrees, which can stress the shoulder joint unnecessarily
injury_prevention_tips: Stop at 90 degrees - going deeper doesn't add tricep work and risks shoulder strain
Keep your core engaged to prevent your lower back from arching excessively

instructions: For this exercise you will need access to a donkey calf raise machine. Start by positioning your lower back and hips under the padded lever provided. The tailbone area should be the one making contact with the pad.

Place both of your arms on the side handles and place the balls of your feet on the calf block with the heels extending off. Align the toes forward, inward or outward, depending on the area you wish to target, and straighten the knees without locking them. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Donkey Calf Raises
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself in the donkey calf raise machine with your lower back and hips under the padded lever
Place the balls of your feet on the calf block with heels hanging off, holding the side handles for support
Keep your knees straight (but not locked) and your core engaged throughout the movement
Rise up on your toes as high as possible by pushing through the balls of your feet
Lower your heels back down with control until you feel a deep stretch in your calves
form_cues: Push up like you're trying to reach the ceiling with your heels - get as tall as possible
At the top, pause and squeeze your calves like you're flexing for a photo
Lower slowly and get a full stretch at the bottom - imagine your heels sinking below the floor
Keep your legs straight like iron rods - no knee bend at any point
common_mistakes: Bending the knees during the movement which takes tension off the calves
Bouncing at the bottom instead of controlling the stretch and contraction
Not going through full range of motion - both at the top and bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to protect your lower back under the pad's pressure
Start with lighter weight to master the full range of motion before loading heavy

instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.
Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder and hold on to the other kettlebell.
With a fluid motion, lower the top kettlebell while driving the bottom kettlebell up.
exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Alternating Hang Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two kettlebells on the floor between your feet, then hinge at the hips to grab both handles
Clean one kettlebell up to your shoulder while keeping the other one hanging at arm's length
In one fluid motion, lower the top kettlebell while simultaneously cleaning the bottom one to your shoulder
Continue alternating in a seesaw pattern - as one goes up, the other comes down
Keep your hips loaded and back flat throughout the alternating motion
form_cues: Think of it like a seesaw - smooth, rhythmic exchange between high and low positions
Keep both kettlebells close to your body - imagine tracing a line up and down your center
Use your hips to generate power - think 'hip hinge and explode' on each clean
Your torso should stay relatively still - the power comes from your lower body
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arms instead of driving through the hips and legs
Losing the rhythm and pausing between exchanges instead of fluid transitions
Rounding the back when lowering the kettlebell - maintain that hip hinge position
injury_prevention_tips: Master single kettlebell cleans before attempting the alternating version
Keep your core braced tight throughout - this protects your lower back during the dynamic movement

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle in each hand.

Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so, so that the palms face forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.
Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum.
As you do so, press the kettlebells overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weights.
Return your feet to the ground in a split fashion, with one foot forward and one foot back.
Keeping the weights overhead, return to a standing position, bringing your feet together. Lower the weights to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders with palms facing forward in the rack position
Dip down by bending your knees slightly while keeping your torso upright
Explosively drive through your heels like you're jumping, using that momentum to press the kettlebells overhead
As the kettlebells go up, split your feet into a lunge position (one forward, one back) and lock out your arms
Stand back up by bringing your feet together, then lower the kettlebells to your shoulders for the next rep
form_cues: Think 'dip and drive' - the leg power does most of the work, not your arms
The dip should be quick and shallow - about a quarter squat depth
Split your feet fast and land with confidence - like catching yourself after a jump
At the top, finish with arms locked and kettlebells stacked over your shoulders
common_mistakes: Dipping too deep or too slow, losing the elastic rebound effect
Pressing with the arms instead of using leg drive to launch the weights
Landing with feet too narrow in the split position, compromising stability
injury_prevention_tips: Practice the split footwork with light weights until it becomes automatic
Keep your core braced throughout - especially during the explosive drive phase

instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders.
Squat down a few inches and reverse the motion rapidly. Use the momentum from the legs to drive the kettlebells overhead.
Once the kettlebells are locked out, lower the kettlebells to your shoulders and repeat.
exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Push Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders in the rack position with elbows tucked
Dip down by bending your knees a few inches while keeping your torso vertical
Explosively reverse direction by driving through your heels, using that momentum
As you extend your legs, press the kettlebells overhead until your arms lock out
Lower the kettlebells back to your shoulders with control and repeat
form_cues: Think 'quick dip, explosive drive' - it's like a small jump that launches the kettlebells
Your legs do the heavy lifting - the arms just guide the kettlebells overhead
At the top, push your head through your arms like you're looking out a window
The dip should be fast and shallow - imagine compressing a spring and letting it explode
common_mistakes: Dipping too slowly or too deep, losing the stretch reflex benefit
Pressing primarily with the arms instead of using leg drive for momentum
Leaning back during the press which can strain the lower back
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core locked tight throughout to protect your spine
Don't exceed a 4-6 inch dip - deeper doesn't help and can break your rhythm

instructions: Place two kettlebells behind your feet. Bend your knees and sit back to pick up the kettlebells.
Swing the kettlebells between your legs forcefully and reverse the direction.
Drive through with your hips and lock the ketttlebells overhead in one uninterrupted motion.
exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Snatch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two kettlebells on the floor behind your feet and hinge at the hips to grab them
Hike the kettlebells back between your legs like a hiking pass in football
Explosively drive your hips forward and pull the kettlebells up close to your body
As they reach chest height, punch your hands through and catch them overhead with arms locked
The motion should be one continuous, explosive movement from floor to overhead
form_cues: Think 'hike, explode, punch through' - three phases that flow together seamlessly
Your hips are the engine - drive them forward violently like a standing broad jump
Keep the kettlebells close to your body throughout - imagine zipping up a jacket
At the top, finish tall with arms locked and kettlebells stacked over your shoulders
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arms too early instead of letting the hips generate all the power
Letting the kettlebells swing too far away from the body, making them harder to control
Catching the kettlebells with bent arms instead of punching straight through to lockout
injury_prevention_tips: Master single kettlebell snatches before attempting doubles - the coordination is much more complex
The kettlebells will flip and rest on your forearms at the top - wear long sleeves initially to avoid bruising

instructions: Place a kettlebell in front of your front foot and clean and press a kettlebell overhead with your opposite arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, push your butt out in the direction of the locked out kettlebell. Turn your feet out at a forty-five degree angle from the arm with the locked out kettlebell.
Bending at the hip to one side, sticking your butt out, slowly lean until you can retrieve the kettlebell from the floor. Keep your eyes on the kettlebell that you hold over your head at all times.
Pause for a second after retrieving the kettlebell from the ground and reverse the motion back to the starting position.
exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Windmill
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean and press one kettlebell overhead and pick up another kettlebell with the opposite hand from the floor
Turn your feet out 45 degrees away from the overhead arm and keep your eyes on the top kettlebell
Push your hips out toward the side of the overhead kettlebell while keeping that arm locked straight
Hinge at your hip and lean to the side, lowering the bottom kettlebell toward the floor with control
Keep your eyes on the overhead kettlebell the entire time, then reverse to stand back up
form_cues: Imagine your overhead arm is a steel rod that never bends - it stays locked throughout
Push your butt out toward the overhead kettlebell side like you're closing a door with your hip
Keep staring at the top kettlebell - this keeps your shoulder packed and safe
Think about moving in one plane - like you're sliding between two sheets of glass
common_mistakes: Bending the overhead arm instead of keeping it locked out completely
Twisting or rotating instead of moving in a pure side bend
Looking away from the overhead kettlebell which can compromise shoulder stability
injury_prevention_tips: Master single kettlebell windmills before adding the second kettlebell
Keep the overhead shoulder packed down - don't let it shrug up toward your ear

instructions: Lie facedown on top of an exercise ball.
While resting on your stomach on the ball, walk your hands forward along the floor and lift your legs, extending your elbows and knees.
exercises.name: Downward Facing Balance
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie facedown across an exercise ball with the ball under your stomach and hips
Place your hands on the floor in front of you and walk them forward slowly
As you walk forward, lift your legs off the ground and extend them straight behind you
Continue until your body forms a straight line with only your hands and the ball supporting you
Hold this position while maintaining balance, keeping your core engaged and body stable
form_cues: Keep your body rigid like a plank - imagine you're a steel beam balancing on the ball
Squeeze your glutes hard to keep your legs elevated and straight
Engage your core like someone's about to punch you in the stomach
Your body should be one straight line from hands to heels - no sagging or piking
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag down or pike up instead of maintaining a straight line
Holding the breath - remember to breathe normally throughout the hold
Walking the hands out too far or not far enough, losing the balance point
injury_prevention_tips: Start close to the ball and gradually walk out as you build confidence
If you feel unstable, walk your hands back slightly toward the ball

instructions: Grab a barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing forward) and get your elbows close to your torso and back. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, curl the bar up while keeping the elbows to the back as you Drag the bar up by keeping it in contact with your torso. Tip: As you can see, you will not be keeping the elbows pinned to your sides, but instead you will be bringing them back. Also, do not lift your shoulders.
Slowly go back to the starting position as you keep the bar in contact with the torso at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Drag Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an underhand grip, arms straight and bar resting against your thighs
Instead of curling forward, pull your elbows back behind your body as you curl
Drag the bar up your torso, keeping it in contact with your body the entire way up
Continue curling until the bar reaches your upper chest, squeezing your biceps hard
Lower the bar back down along your torso, maintaining contact all the way
form_cues: Think 'drag the bar up your shirt' - it should scrape your torso the entire time
Pull your elbows back like you're trying to elbow someone behind you
Keep your shoulders down and back - don't let them roll forward
At the top, your elbows should be behind your torso, not at your sides
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift away from the body, turning it into a regular curl
Keeping elbows pinned at your sides instead of pulling them back
Leaning back to help lift the weight instead of keeping torso upright
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than regular curls - the dragging motion makes it harder than it looks
Keep your wrists neutral - don't let them bend back excessively

instructions: Stand (torso upright) with a dumbbell in each hand held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso and the palms of your hand should be facing your thighs.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the right weight as you rotate the palm of the hands until they are facing forward. At this point continue contracting the biceps as you breathe out until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbell back to the starting position as your breathe in. Tip: Remember to twist the palms back to the starting position (facing your thighs) as you come down.
Repeat the movement with the left hand. This equals one repetition.
Continue alternating in this manner for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Alternate Bicep Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand, arms straight and palms facing your thighs
Curl one dumbbell up while rotating your wrist so your palm faces forward at the top
Squeeze your bicep hard at the top when the dumbbell reaches shoulder height
Lower that dumbbell back down while rotating your wrist back to the starting position
As you lower, begin curling the opposite arm up - alternate sides with each rep
form_cues: Think 'twist and lift' - the rotation happens as you curl up
Pin your elbows to your sides like they're glued to your ribcage
Lower twice as slowly as you lift - fight gravity on the way down
At the top, squeeze like you're trying to show off your bicep peak
common_mistakes: Swinging the dumbbells up using momentum instead of controlled bicep contraction
Letting the elbows drift forward as you curl instead of keeping them locked in place
Forgetting to rotate the wrist back to neutral on the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back straight - no leaning backward to help lift the weight
Control the eccentric (lowering) phase to protect your bicep tendons from strain

exercises.description: Bench press performed with dumbbells
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand resting on top of your thighs. The palms of your hands will be facing each other.
Then, using your thighs to help raise the dumbbells up, lift the dumbbells one at a time so that you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width.

Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. The dumbbells should be just to the sides of your chest, with your upper arm and forearm creating a 90 degree angle. Be sure to maintain full control of the dumbbells at all times. This will be your starting position.

Then, as you breathe out, use your chest to push the dumbbells up. Lock your arms at the top of the lift and squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then begin coming down slowly. Tip: Ideally, lowering the weight should take about twice as long as raising it.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the bench with dumbbells resting on your thighs, then lie back while bringing them to your chest
Position the dumbbells at shoulder width with arms bent to 90 degrees, palms facing forward
Press both dumbbells up simultaneously until your arms are fully extended above your chest
Lock out at the top and squeeze your chest hard for a second
Lower the dumbbells back down with control to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Think about pushing the dumbbells up and slightly together - like you're hugging a tree
At the bottom, your elbows should be at about chest level for a good stretch
Drive your feet into the floor to create full-body tension
Lower twice as slowly as you press - control the descent
common_mistakes: Letting the dumbbells drift too far apart at the top instead of keeping them over your shoulders
Bouncing at the bottom instead of using controlled strength
Arching the lower back excessively off the bench - keep your core engaged
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blades squeezed together and pressed into the bench throughout
Don't lower the dumbbells too far below chest level - this can strain the shoulders

instructions: Take a dumbbell in each hand and lay back onto a flat bench. Your feet should be flat on the floor and your shoulder blades retracted.
Maintaining a neutral grip, palms facing each other, begin with your arms extended directly above you, perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the elbow, lowering the upper arms to the side. Descend until the dumbbells are to your torso.
Pause, then extend the elbow and return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Bench Press with Neutral Grip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a dumbbell in each hand and lie back on a flat bench with your feet flat on the floor
Pull your shoulder blades together and down - imagine pinching a pencil between them
Hold the dumbbells directly above your chest with arms extended and palms facing each other (neutral grip)
Lower the dumbbells down by bending your elbows, bringing them to the sides of your torso
Press back up by driving through your chest, finishing like you're flexing in a most muscular pose
form_cues: Think about bringing your elbows down toward your hips, not flaring them out wide
Imagine crushing an orange in your armpit at the bottom to engage your lats
Drive the dumbbells up and slightly together, as if you're hugging a tree
common_mistakes: Flaring the elbows out perpendicular to the body instead of keeping them at 45 degrees
Lifting your shoulder blades off the bench during the press
Letting the dumbbells drift apart or touch each other at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blades retracted and pressed into the bench throughout
Don't bounce the weights off your chest - use a controlled touch at the bottom

exercises.description: A biceps curl performed with dumbbells
instructions: Stand up straight with a dumbbell in each hand at arm's length. Keep your elbows close to your torso and rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward. This will be your starting position.

Now, keeping the upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the weights while contracting your biceps. Continue to raise the weights until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a brief pause as you squeeze your biceps.
Then, inhale and slowly begin to lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Bicep Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended by your sides, palms facing forward
Pin your elbows to your sides - imagine they're glued to your ribs throughout the movement
Curl the weights up by bending at the elbows, keeping your upper arms completely still
Squeeze hard at the top when the dumbbells reach shoulder height - finish like a double biceps pose
Lower the weights back down slowly with control, resisting gravity all the way
form_cues: Think about bringing your pinky finger toward your shoulder to maximize the bicep contraction
Imagine your upper arms are nailed to a wall - only your forearms should move
Squeeze at the top like you're trying to touch your biceps to your forearms
common_mistakes: Swinging the weights up using momentum from your hips or back
Letting the elbows drift forward or back instead of staying locked at your sides
Dropping the weight too fast on the way down, missing out on the eccentric contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists in a neutral position - don't excessively flex them backward
Start with lighter weight to perfect the form before adding load

instructions: Begin standing with a dumbbell in each hand with your feet shoulder width apart.
Lower the weights to the floor by flexing at the hips and knees, pushing your hips back until the dumbbells reach the floor. This will be your starting position.

To initiate the movement, violently jump upward by extending the hips, knees, and ankles to acclerate the weights upward. Maintaining a neutral grip on the dumbbells, keep the arms straight until full extension is reached.
After full extension, rebend the hips and knees to receive the weight in a squat position. Allow the arms to bend, guiding the dumbbells to your shoulders.
Upon receiving the weight in the squat position, extend the hips and knees to finish in a standing position with the weights on your shoulders.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start standing with dumbbells at your sides, then hinge at the hips and knees to lower them to the floor
Explosively extend your hips, knees, and ankles to jump upward - think about launching yourself off the ground
Keep the dumbbells close to your body as you shrug your shoulders up aggressively
As you reach full extension, quickly drop under the weights by bending your hips and knees into a squat
Catch the dumbbells on your shoulders and stand up to complete the movement
form_cues: Think triple extension - ankles, knees, and hips all open powerfully at once
Imagine you're trying to jump through the ceiling as you explode up
Pull the dumbbells up close to your body like you're zipping up a jacket aggressively
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arms too early instead of letting the legs and hips generate the power
Letting the dumbbells swing away from the body instead of staying close
Not dropping into a full squat to receive the weight, catching it too high
injury_prevention_tips: Master the hip hinge and squat patterns separately before attempting cleans
Start light to learn the explosive timing before adding heavy weight

instructions: Lay on the floor holding dumbbells in your hands. Your knees can be bent. Begin with the weights fully extended above you.
Lower the weights until your upper arm comes in contact with the floor. You can tuck your elbows to emphasize triceps size and strength, or to focus on your chest angle your arms to the side.
Pause at the bottom, and then bring the weight together at the top by extending through the elbows.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back on the floor with knees bent and dumbbells held above your chest with arms extended
Lower the weights by bending your elbows until your upper arms touch the floor - this is your natural stopping point
For triceps focus, keep elbows tucked close; for chest focus, let them angle out at 45 degrees
Pause briefly when your arms touch the floor without relaxing
Drive the weights back up by pressing through your chest and triceps, bringing them together at the top
form_cues: Think about pulling the floor apart with your back to create tension
Imagine pushing yourself through the floor rather than pushing the weights up
Keep your upper back tight - don't let your shoulder blades slide around
common_mistakes: Bouncing your arms off the floor instead of pausing and pressing from a dead stop
Relaxing at the bottom instead of maintaining tension throughout
Letting the dumbbells drift too far apart or bang together at the top
injury_prevention_tips: The floor naturally limits your range of motion, making this shoulder-friendly
Keep your core engaged to prevent your lower back from arching excessively

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell on each hand resting on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

Then using your thighs to help raise the dumbbells, lift the dumbbells one at a time so you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width with the palms of your hands facing each other. Raise the dumbbells up like you're pressing them, but stop and hold just before you lock out. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend on your elbows in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon, lower your arms out at both sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your arms back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and breathe out. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with dumbbells held above your chest, palms facing each other, with a slight bend in your elbows
Keep that elbow bend locked throughout - imagine your arms are frozen in a slight curve
Lower the dumbbells out to your sides in a wide arc until you feel a deep stretch across your chest
Think about opening your arms like you're spreading your wings or giving someone a big hug
Bring the weights back up using the same arc, squeezing your chest like you're crushing a can between your pecs
form_cues: Imagine you're hugging a large barrel - your arms should move in that curved path
Think about pouring water from the dumbbells at the bottom to feel the stretch
At the top, squeeze like you're trying to bring your elbows together through your chest
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows too much, turning it into a press instead of a fly
Going too heavy and not getting a full stretch at the bottom
Letting the dumbbells crash together at the top instead of a controlled squeeze
injury_prevention_tips: Keep that slight elbow bend constant - straightening them fully puts stress on the elbow joint
Don't go lower than feels comfortable - stop at a stretch, not pain

instructions: Using a neutral grip, lean into an incline bench.
Take a dumbbell in each hand with a neutral grip, beginning with the arms straight. This will be your starting position.
Retract the shoulder blades and flex the elbows to row the dumbbells to your side.
Pause at the top of the motion, and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Incline Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lean chest-down into an incline bench set at about 45 degrees with a dumbbell in each hand
Let your arms hang straight down with palms facing each other (neutral grip)
Pull your shoulder blades together first - think about pinching a pencil between them
Row the dumbbells up to your sides by bending your elbows, driving them toward the ceiling
Pause at the top with a hard squeeze, then lower with control back to the start
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows into your back pockets
Imagine someone placed a quarter on your upper back and you're trying to squeeze it between your shoulder blades
Lead with your elbows, not your hands - the dumbbells are just along for the ride
common_mistakes: Using too much arm and not enough back - the biceps shouldn't dominate
Shrugging your shoulders up toward your ears instead of pulling them back
Letting momentum do the work instead of controlled, deliberate pulls
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your chest pressed into the bench to prevent lower back strain
Don't jerk the weights up - smooth and controlled wins the day

instructions: Sit on an Incline Bench while holding a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs.

Lift your legs up to kick the weights to your shoulders and lean back. Position the dumbbells above your shoulders with your arms extended. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor with your palms facing forward and knuckles pointing towards the ceiling. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the arms straight and locked, lift the dumbbells by raising the shoulders from the bench as you breathe out.
Bring back the dumbbells to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Incline Shoulder Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit back on an incline bench with dumbbells held above your shoulders, arms fully extended, palms facing forward
Keep your arms locked straight throughout - no bending at the elbows
Raise the dumbbells by lifting your shoulders off the bench, as if you're shrugging upward
Think about reaching for the ceiling while keeping your arms completely straight
Lower back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to touch the ceiling by elevating your shoulders, not by moving your arms
Think about pushing the dumbbells straight up toward the sky
Keep your arms like rigid poles - all movement comes from the shoulder elevation
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows and turning it into a shoulder press
Arching your back off the bench instead of moving only at the shoulders
Using too much weight and losing the strict form
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light - this is an isolation exercise for shoulder stability
Don't lock your elbows aggressively; keep them straight but not hyperextended

instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding two dumbbells in your hands by your sides. This will be your starting position.

Step forward with your right leg around 2 feet or so from the foot being left stationary behind and lower your upper body down, while keeping the torso upright and maintaining balance. Inhale as you go down. Note: As in the other exercises, do not allow your knee to go forward beyond your toes as you come down, as this will put undue stress on the knee joint. Make sure that you keep your front shin perpendicular to the ground.
Using mainly the heel of your foot, push up and go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat the movement for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Lunges
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with dumbbells at your sides, chest up, and core braced
Step forward about 2-3 feet with your right leg and plant your foot firmly
Lower your body straight down by bending both knees until your front thigh is parallel to the ground
Keep your front shin vertical - your knee should stay directly above your ankle
Drive through your front heel to push back to the starting position and repeat on the other leg
form_cues: Think about dropping your back knee straight down toward the floor like an elevator
Imagine you're moving between two panes of glass - no leaning forward or backward
Drive through your front heel like you're pushing the floor away from you
common_mistakes: Letting your front knee cave inward or push too far forward past your toes
Taking too short of a step, which cramps your range of motion
Leaning your torso forward instead of keeping it upright
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your front shin perpendicular to the floor to protect your knee
Engage your core throughout to maintain an upright torso and protect your lower back

instructions: While holding a dumbbell in one hand, lay with your chest down on a slightly inclined (around 15 degrees when measured from the floor) adjustable bench. The other hand can be used to hold to the leg of the bench for stability.

Position the palm of the hand that is holding the dumbbell in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arm extended with the elbow slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arm with the dumbbell to the side until your elbow is at shoulder height and your arm is roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arm perpendicular to the torso while keeping your arm extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbell to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Lying One-Arm Rear Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie chest-down on a slightly inclined bench (about 15 degrees) with a dumbbell in one hand
Let your working arm hang straight down with palm facing your torso, elbow slightly bent
Raise the dumbbell out to the side until your elbow reaches shoulder height and your arm is parallel to the floor
Think about leading with your elbow, not your hand - like you're elbowing someone behind you
Lower the weight back down with control and repeat for all reps before switching sides
form_cues: Imagine your arm is a gate hinge opening to the side
Think about driving your elbow up and back toward the wall behind you
Keep your arm perpendicular to your body throughout - don't let it drift forward
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight up instead of controlled muscle contraction
Raising the weight too high, bringing traps into play instead of rear delts
Letting the arm drift forward, turning it into a lateral raise instead of rear delt work
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight - the rear delts are small muscles and don't need heavy loads
Keep the movement smooth and controlled to avoid shoulder impingement

instructions: Lie on a flat bench face down with one arm holding a dumbbell and the other hand on top of the bench folded so that you can rest your head on it.
Bend the elbows of the arm holding the dumbbell so that it creates a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm.

Now raise the upper arm so that the forearm is perpendicular to the floor and the upper arm is perpendicular to your torso. Tip: The upper arm should be parallel to the floor and also creating a 90-degree angle with your torso. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, externally rotate your forearm so that the dumbbell is lifted forward as you maintain the 90 degree angle bend between the upper arms and the forearm. You will continue this external rotation until the forearm is parallel to the floor. At this point you will hold the contraction for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Lying Pronation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on a flat bench with one arm holding a dumbbell, elbow bent at 90 degrees
Position your upper arm parallel to the floor and perpendicular to your torso, with your forearm hanging down perpendicular to the floor
Rotate your forearm forward (externally rotate) until your forearm becomes parallel to the floor
Think about rotating your hand like you're revving a motorcycle throttle
Slowly rotate back to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Imagine your forearm is a windshield wiper rotating on a fixed point at the elbow
Keep the 90-degree angle at your elbow locked throughout
Think about turning your palm to face the ceiling at the top of the movement
common_mistakes: Moving the upper arm instead of keeping it locked in position
Using too much weight and losing the rotation quality
Rushing the movement instead of performing slow, controlled rotations
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weight - this is a small muscle group with delicate tendons
Keep the rotation smooth and within a comfortable range of motion

instructions: While holding a dumbbell in each hand, lay with your chest down on a slightly inclined (around 15 degrees when measured from the floor) adjustable bench.
Position the palms of the hands in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arms extended with the elbows slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arms to the side until your elbows are at shoulder height and your arms are roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arms perpendicular to the torso while keeping them extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbells to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Lying Rear Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie chest-down on a bench set to a slight incline (about 15 degrees), holding dumbbells with arms hanging straight down
Keep palms facing each other with a slight bend in your elbows throughout the entire movement
Lift the weights out to the sides until your elbows reach shoulder height and your arms are parallel to the floor
Squeeze your rear delts hard at the top like you're trying to pinch a pencil between your shoulder blades
Lower slowly back to the start, keeping tension in your shoulders the entire way down
form_cues: Think about leading with your elbows, not your hands - imagine your elbows are pulling the weights up
Keep your arms perpendicular to your body like airplane wings throughout the movement
