Pretend you're trying to touch your elbows behind your back at the top of the movement
Focus on your rear delts doing the work - imagine painting a horizontal arc on the wall beside you with your elbows
common_mistakes: Using momentum or swinging the weights up instead of controlled lifting with the rear delts
Raising the weights too high above shoulder level, which shifts tension away from the rear delts
Turning this into a rowing motion by bending the elbows more during the lift
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weights - your rear delts are small muscles and easy to overtrain
Keep your chest pressed firmly into the bench to prevent lower back arching and strain

instructions: Lie sideways on a flat bench with one arm holding a dumbbell and the other hand on top of the bench folded so that you can rest your head on it.
Bend the elbows of the arm holding the dumbbell so that it creates a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm.

Now raise the upper arm so that the forearm is parallel to the floor and perpendicular to your torso (Tip: So the forearm will be directly in front of you). The upper arm will be stationary by your torso and should be parallel to the floor (aligned with your torso at all times). This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, externally rotate your forearm so that the dumbbell is lifted up in a semicircle motion as you maintain the 90 degree angle bend between the upper arms and the forearm. You will continue this external rotation until the forearm is perpendicular to the floor and the torso pointing towards the ceiling. At this point you will hold the contraction for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Lying Supination
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie sideways on a bench with one arm holding a dumbbell and rest your head on your other hand
Bend your working elbow to 90 degrees and position your forearm perpendicular to your body, pointing straight ahead
Keep your upper arm locked against your side - it stays glued to your torso the entire time
Rotate your forearm upward in an arc until it's pointing straight up at the ceiling
Lower back down slowly to the starting position, maintaining the 90-degree elbow bend
form_cues: Imagine your elbow is a door hinge that's bolted to your side - only your forearm moves
Think about drawing a half-circle in the air with the dumbbell, like opening a door
Keep that 90-degree angle locked - pretend there's a brace holding your elbow bent
Visualize unscrewing a massive jar lid as you rotate your forearm upward
common_mistakes: Allowing the upper arm to move away from the torso, which defeats the isolation of the forearm muscles
Using too much weight and losing the 90-degree elbow angle during the rotation
Rushing the movement instead of controlling the rotation through the full range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weight initially - your forearm muscles are small and this is an unfamiliar movement pattern
Stop immediately if you feel any elbow pain and reduce the weight or range of motion

instructions: Grab a dumbbell and either sit on a military press bench or a utility bench that has a back support on it as you place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs or stand up straight.
Clean the dumbbell up to bring it to shoulder height. The other hand can be kept fully extended to the side, by the waist or grabbing a fixed surface.
Rotate the wrist so that the palm of your hand is facing forward. This is your starting position.
As you exhale, push the dumbbell up until your arm is fully extended.
After a second pause, slowly come down back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch arms.
exercises.name: Dumbbell One-Arm Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support or stand tall, holding one dumbbell at shoulder height with palm facing forward
Keep your core tight and brace your free hand against your side or hold something stable for balance
Press the dumbbell straight up until your arm is fully extended overhead
Hold for a brief moment at the top with your bicep near your ear
Lower the weight back to shoulder height with control, resisting gravity on the way down
form_cues: Imagine pushing the ceiling away from you rather than pushing the weight up
Keep your shoulder packed down - don't let it shrug up toward your ear as you press
Think about pressing in a perfectly straight line, like the dumbbell is sliding up a pole
Finish strong at the top like you're reaching to place a book on a high shelf
common_mistakes: Leaning sideways away from the working arm, which reduces shoulder activation and stresses the spine
Pressing at an angle instead of straight up, which can strain the shoulder joint
Using leg drive or momentum to push the weight up instead of strict shoulder pressing
injury_prevention_tips: Engage your core hard throughout to prevent excessive spinal lean or arching
Start with lighter weight than you'd use for two-arm presses since unilateral work is more challenging for stability

instructions: Grab a dumbbell and either sit on a military press bench or a utility bench that has a back support on it as you place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs or stand up straight.

Clean the dumbbell up to bring it to shoulder height and then extend the arm over your head so that the whole arm is perpendicular to the floor and next to your head. The dumbbell should be on top of you. The other hand can be kept fully extended to the side, by the waist, supporting the upper arm that has the dumbbell or grabbing a fixed surface.
Rotate the wrist so that the palm of your hand is facing forward and the pinkie is facing the ceiling. This will be your starting position.
Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head as you hold the upper arm stationary. Inhale as you perform this movement and pause when your triceps are fully stretched.
Return to the starting position by flexing your triceps as you breathe out. Tip: It is imperative that only the forearm moves. The upper arm should remain at all times stationary next to your head.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and switch arms.
exercises.name: Dumbbell One-Arm Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit or stand with one dumbbell held overhead, arm fully extended with the weight directly above your head
Keep your upper arm completely vertical and locked in place next to your ear - it doesn't move at all
Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending only at the elbow until you feel a deep stretch in your triceps
Press the weight back up by extending your elbow until your arm is straight again
Keep your elbow pointing forward the entire time - don't let it flare out to the side
form_cues: Imagine your upper arm is a flagpole cemented into the ground - completely stationary
Think about only moving your forearm, like your elbow is a hinge that opens and closes
Pretend you're hammering a nail straight up into the ceiling at the top of each rep
Keep your elbow pointing forward like it's a laser beam that must stay aimed at the wall in front of you
common_mistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out to the side, which reduces triceps tension and can stress the shoulder
Moving the upper arm forward and backward instead of keeping it locked vertically
Using too much weight and cutting the range of motion short at the bottom stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Use your free hand to stabilize your working upper arm if needed to keep it from moving
Go light and focus on the stretch - forcing heavy weight behind your head can strain the elbow

instructions: Grab a dumbbell and stand up straight with your arm extended in front of you with a slight bend at the elbows and your back straight. This will be your starting position. Tip: The dumbbell should be resting on top of your thigh with the palm of your hands facing your thighs.
Keep the other hand can be kept fully extended to the side, by the waist or grabbing a fixed surface. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the dumbbell as you exhale. The dumbbell should be close to the body as you move it up. Continue to lift it until the dumbbell is nearly in line with your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the dumbbell, your elbow should always be higher than your forearm. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the dumbbell back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and switch arms.
exercises.name: Dumbbell One-Arm Upright Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall holding one dumbbell in front of your thigh with a slight bend in your elbow
Keep the dumbbell close to your body as you pull it straight up along your torso
Lead with your elbow, raising it high until the dumbbell reaches chin level
Your elbow should always be higher than your hand throughout the entire movement
Lower the weight back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Imagine your elbow is a puppet string being pulled straight up toward the ceiling
Keep the dumbbell traveling close to your body like it's on a vertical rail
Think about driving your elbow up and back, not just lifting the weight
Pretend you're zipping up a tight jacket from your hip to your chin
common_mistakes: Pulling the dumbbell away from the body, which shifts the work away from the shoulders
Using momentum to swing the weight up instead of controlled shoulder elevation
Raising the elbow too high above shoulder level, which can impinge the shoulder joint
injury_prevention_tips: Don't pull higher than chin level - going too high can cause shoulder impingement over time
Keep your shoulders down and back, avoiding excessive shrugging at the top of the movement

instructions: Grab a dumbbell on each hand and lie face down on an incline bench with your shoulders near top of the incline. Your knees can rest on the seat or your legs can be straddled to the sides (my preferred way).
Let your arms extend and hang naturally in front of you so that they are perpendicular to the floor.
Now keep your elbows in by your side and face the palms forward. This will be your starting position.

Raise the dumbbells by contracting the biceps until your arms are fully flexed. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and ensure that only the forearms move. The upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Lower the dumbbells until your arms are fully extended.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Prone Incline Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on an incline bench with your chest near the top, letting your arms hang straight down
Hold dumbbells with palms facing forward and keep your upper arms completely still
Curl the weights up by contracting your biceps until your forearms are vertical
Squeeze your biceps hard at the top like you're flexing for a photo
Lower the weights slowly back to full arm extension, feeling the stretch in your biceps
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are pinned in place - they stay in the same spot the entire time
Think about bringing your knuckles up to your shoulders, not just lifting the weight
Pretend you're trying to touch your fists to your ears at the top of the curl
Focus on squeezing your biceps like you're crushing golf balls in your armpits
common_mistakes: Swinging the dumbbells up by moving the upper arms forward instead of keeping them stationary
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom, which reduces the effective range of motion
Using body momentum or rocking instead of isolating the biceps
injury_prevention_tips: Press your chest firmly into the bench to prevent rocking or using momentum
Control the eccentric (lowering) phase to protect your biceps tendons from excessive stress

instructions: Grab a dumbbell in each arm and stand up straight with your arms extended by your sides with a slight bend at the elbows and your back straight. This will be your starting position. Tip: The dumbbell should be next to your thighs with the palm of your hands facing back.

Use your side shoulders to lift the dumbbells as you exhale. The dumbbells should be to the side of the body as you move them up. Continue to lift it until the dumbbells are nearly in line with your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the dumbbell, your elbow should always be higher than your forearm. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with dumbbells at your sides, palms facing back, with a slight bend in your elbows
Lift both dumbbells out to the sides, leading with your elbows
Continue raising until the dumbbells reach about chin height and your arms are parallel to the floor
Keep your elbows slightly higher than your wrists throughout the entire range of motion
Lower the weights slowly back to your sides with control
form_cues: Imagine you're pouring water out of two pitchers as you lift - lead with your elbows
Think about your arms as wingtips spreading wide to the sides
Pretend there are strings attached to your elbows pulling them up toward the ceiling
Keep a slight forward lean in your torso, like you're leaning into a strong wind
common_mistakes: Lifting the weights straight up with the hands instead of leading with the elbows
Shrugging the shoulders up toward the ears, which brings the traps into play instead of side delts
Using momentum by swinging the weights or rocking the torso back and forth
injury_prevention_tips: Don't raise the weights above shoulder height as this can cause shoulder impingement
Keep the movement controlled - avoid jerking or using heavy momentum that stresses the shoulder joint

instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding two dumbbells in your hands by your sides. This will be your starting position.

Step backward with your right leg around two feet or so from the left foot and lower your upper body down, while keeping the torso upright and maintaining balance. Inhale as you go down. Tip: As in the other exercises, do not allow your knee to go forward beyond your toes as you come down, as this will put undue stress on the knee joint. Make sure that you keep your front shin perpendicular to the ground. Keep the torso upright during the lunge; flexible hip flexors are important. A long lunge emphasizes the Gluteus Maximus; a short lunge emphasizes Quadriceps.
Push up and go back to the starting position as you exhale. Tip: Use the ball of your feet to push in order to accentuate the quadriceps. To focus on the glutes, press with your heels.
Now repeat with the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Rear Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall holding dumbbells at your sides with your feet hip-width apart
Step backward with one leg, landing on the ball of that foot
Lower your body straight down until your back knee nearly touches the floor and your front thigh is parallel to the ground
Keep your torso upright throughout - imagine balancing a cup of water on your head
Push through your front foot to return to the starting position, then repeat on the other side
form_cues: Think about sitting straight down between your legs, not leaning forward
Keep your front shin vertical - imagine there's a wall in front of your knee that you can't touch
Pretend you're descending on an elevator, moving straight down and up
Drive through your front heel to stand back up, like you're pushing the floor away
common_mistakes: Allowing the front knee to travel forward past the toes, which stresses the knee joint
Leaning the torso too far forward, which reduces glute and quad activation
Taking too short a step backward, which doesn't allow for proper depth or muscle engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight throughout to protect your lower back from excessive movement
Control the descent - don't drop down quickly as this can jar the knee joint

instructions: This corrective exercise strengthens the muscles that stabilize your shoulder blade. Hold a light weight in each hand, hanging at your sides. Your thumbs should pointing up.
Begin the movement raising your arms out in front of you, about 30 degrees off center. Your arms should be fully extended as you perform the movement.
Continue until your arms are parallel to the ground, and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Scaption
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding light dumbbells at your sides with thumbs pointing up
Raise both arms out at a 30-degree angle in front of you (halfway between straight ahead and directly out to the side)
Keep your arms completely straight as you lift them up to shoulder height
Pause briefly when your arms are parallel to the floor
Lower the weights back down slowly to the starting position
form_cues: Imagine forming a 'Y' shape with your body at the top - arms angled slightly forward
Think about reaching out to touch two walls that are slightly in front of you on each side
Keep your thumbs pointing up the entire time like you're giving two thumbs-up
Pretend you're lifting two trays at an angle, not straight in front or directly to the sides
common_mistakes: Raising the arms straight forward or directly to the sides instead of at the proper 30-degree angle
Using too much weight and bending the elbows to compensate
Shrugging the shoulders up as you lift, which defeats the stabilizer strengthening purpose
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weights - this is a corrective exercise focused on shoulder stability, not strength
Keep your shoulder blades down and back throughout to properly engage the stabilizing muscles

instructions: Place a block on the floor about 12 inches from a flat bench.
Sit on a flat bench and place a dumbbell on your upper left thigh about 3 inches above your knee.
Now place the ball of your left foot on the block. This will be your starting position.
Raise your toes up as high as possible as you exhale and you contract your calf muscle. Hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly return to the starting position, stretching as far down as possible.
Repeat for your prescribed number of repetitions and then repeat with the right leg.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Seated One-Leg Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with a block or plate on the floor about 12 inches in front of you
Place a dumbbell on your thigh about 3 inches above your knee and position the ball of that foot on the block
Let your heel drop down as low as possible to get a deep stretch in your calf
Press through the ball of your foot to raise your heel as high as you can, contracting your calf hard at the top
Pause for a moment at the peak, then slowly lower back to the stretched position
form_cues: Think about trying to stand on your tiptoes as high as possible - reach for the ceiling with your heel
Imagine there's a spring under your heel that you're compressing at the bottom and releasing at the top
Squeeze your calf at the top like you're trying to cramp it on purpose
Control the descent and feel the deep stretch at the bottom - pretend you're stretching a rubber band
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of pausing to feel the stretch in the calf
Using too much weight and cutting the range of motion short at both ends
Rushing through reps instead of using slow, controlled movements with pauses
injury_prevention_tips: Get a full stretch at the bottom but don't force it painfully - ease into the deepest position gradually
Keep the dumbbell secure on your thigh and don't let it roll forward onto your knee joint

instructions: While holding a dumbbell in each hand, sit on a military press bench or utility bench that has back support. Place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs.
Now raise the dumbbells to shoulder height one at a time using your thighs to help propel them up into position.
Make sure to rotate your wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing forward. This is your starting position.
Now, exhale and push the dumbbells upward until they touch at the top.
Then, after a brief pause at the top contracted position, slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support holding dumbbells on your thighs, then use your legs to help kick them up to shoulder height
Rotate your wrists so palms face forward with dumbbells at shoulder level - this is your power position
Press the dumbbells straight overhead until they touch at the top - think about pushing the ceiling away
Pause at the top and squeeze your shoulders like you're flexing them
Lower the dumbbells back down with control to shoulder height, keeping tension the whole way
form_cues: Think about pressing the weights up and slightly inward so they meet at the top
Imagine pushing yourself down into the bench as you press up
Keep your core tight like someone's about to punch you in the stomach
common_mistakes: Arching your back excessively to help press the weight - keep your back against the pad
Letting the dumbbells drift too far forward or backward instead of staying in line with your body
Pressing the weights straight up without bringing them together at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists stacked directly over your elbows throughout the movement
Don't let your lower back arch away from the bench - maintain contact with the pad

instructions: Stand erect with a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing your torso), arms extended on the sides.

Lift the dumbbells by elevating the shoulders as high as possible while you exhale. Hold the contraction at the top for a second. Tip: The arms should remain extended at all times. Refrain from using the biceps to help lift the dumbbells. Only the shoulders should be moving up and down.
Lower the dumbbells back to the original position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, arms fully extended, palms facing your body
Keep your arms completely straight - imagine they're locked rods that can't bend
Shrug your shoulders straight up toward your ears as high as possible - think about touching your ears with your shoulders
Hold the squeeze at the top for a full second, really contracting your traps
Lower your shoulders back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think about lifting your shoulders straight up to the ceiling, not rolling them forward or backward
Imagine you're a puppet and someone is pulling strings attached to your shoulders upward
At the top, squeeze like you're trying to pinch your traps into your neck
common_mistakes: Rolling the shoulders in a circular motion instead of moving straight up and down
Bending the arms and using biceps instead of pure shoulder elevation
Not going high enough - you should feel your ears get closer to your shoulders
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement vertical - no rolling or rotating of the shoulders
Don't jerk the weight up - use smooth, controlled elevation

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on the left hand (palms facing the torso) as you have the right hand holding your waist. Your feet should be placed at shoulder width. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your back straight and your head up, bend only at the waist to the right as far as possible. Breathe in as you bend to the side. Then hold for a second and come back up to the starting position as you exhale. Tip: Keep the rest of the body stationary.
Now repeat the movement but bending to the left instead. Hold for a second and come back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then change hands.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Side Bend
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand with the other hand on your waist
Keep your back straight and head up, then bend sideways away from the weight as far as comfortable
Think about sliding your body straight to the side, like you're between two walls
Hold the stretched position for a second, feeling the obliques working
Return to upright and repeat, then switch to bending toward the weight side before switching hands
form_cues: Imagine you're sliding between two panes of glass - move purely sideways, no twisting
Think about creating distance between your ribcage and hip on the stretched side
Keep your hips and shoulders square - don't rotate or lean forward
common_mistakes: Leaning forward or backward instead of bending purely to the side
Using momentum to swing rather than controlled bending
Not keeping the rest of your body stationary - only your torso should move
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to ensure proper form without compensation
Keep your core engaged to protect your spine during the side bend

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise your torso as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly turned out, holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing in
Keep your chest up and eyes forward - imagine a string pulling your chest toward the ceiling
Lower down by bending your knees and hips simultaneously until your thighs are parallel to the floor
Keep your knees tracking over your toes - they should form a vertical line with your toes at the bottom
Drive through your heels to stand back up, squeezing your glutes hard at the top
form_cues: Think about sitting back into a chair rather than just bending your knees
Imagine spreading the floor apart with your feet to activate your glutes
Drive through your heels like you're pushing the Earth away from you
common_mistakes: Letting your knees cave inward instead of tracking over your toes
Allowing your knees to shoot forward past your toes, putting stress on the joint
Rounding your back or looking down, which compromises your spine position
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your weight distributed through your full foot, with emphasis on your heels
Maintain a neutral spine throughout - don't round your lower back at the bottom

instructions: Stand up straight with a flat bench behind you while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Squat To A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with a bench behind you, holding dumbbells at your sides, feet shoulder-width with toes slightly out
Keep your chest proud and head up, maintaining a straight back throughout
Lower down by sitting back and bending your knees until your glutes lightly touch the bench
Use the bench touch as a depth cue - don't actually sit down or relax
Drive through your heels to stand back up immediately after touching the bench
form_cues: Think about reaching back with your hips to find the bench, not just dropping straight down
Imagine you're barely kissing the bench with your glutes - don't collapse onto it
Keep your shins as vertical as possible by sitting back into the movement
common_mistakes: Sitting down on the bench and relaxing instead of using it as a touch point
Letting your knees shoot too far forward beyond your toes
Rocking forward as you stand up instead of driving through your heels
injury_prevention_tips: The bench serves as a safety and depth guide - tap it lightly, don't crash into it
Keep your core braced throughout to protect your lower back

instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Place the right foot on the elevated platform. Step on the platform by extending the hip and the knee of your right leg. Use the heel mainly to lift the rest of your body up and place the foot of the left leg on the platform as well. Breathe out as you execute the force required to come up.

Step down with the left leg by flexing the hip and knee of the right leg as you inhale. Return to the original standing position by placing the right foot of to next to the left foot on the initial position.
Repeat with the right leg for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Step Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a box or bench holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing in
Place one foot fully on the platform - your entire foot should be planted, not just your toes
Drive through your heel on the platform to lift your body up, bringing your other foot up to meet it
Think about pushing the platform down rather than pulling yourself up
Step back down with the trailing leg first, then the working leg, and repeat on the same leg
form_cues: Lead with your heel on the platform - imagine you're pushing through your heel to elevate
Keep your torso upright like you're balancing a book on your head
Think about the working leg doing all the work - don't push off with your ground leg
common_mistakes: Pushing off explosively with the bottom leg instead of using only the top leg
Leaning forward excessively, which shifts work away from your glutes
Placing only your toes on the platform instead of your full foot
injury_prevention_tips: Choose a box height where your knee doesn't go past 90 degrees at the bottom
Step down controlled - don't jump or drop off the platform

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench holding two dumbbells directly above your shoulders. Your arms should be fully extended and form a 90 degree angle from your torso and the floor.
The palms of your hands should be facing forward, and your elbows should be tucked in. This will be your starting position.
Now, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells until they are near your ears. Be sure to keep your upper arms stationary and your elbows tucked in.
Then, exhale and use your triceps to return the weight to the starting position.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Tricep Extension - Pronated Grip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with dumbbells held directly above your shoulders, arms fully extended, palms facing forward
Tuck your elbows in close to your body - imagine squeezing oranges in your armpits
Keep your upper arms locked in place and lower the dumbbells by bending only at the elbows until they're near your ears
Think about your upper arms being bolted to the bench - only your forearms move
Press the dumbbells back up by extending your elbows, squeezing your triceps hard at the top
form_cues: Imagine your upper arms are frozen solid - all movement comes from the elbow joint down
Think about pointing your elbows at the ceiling throughout the entire movement
At the top, squeeze like you're trying to extend your arms through concrete
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows flare out wide instead of staying tucked
Dropping the upper arms back toward your head instead of keeping them perpendicular
Using momentum to bounce the weights instead of controlled tricep contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the descent slow and controlled to protect your elbow joints
Don't let the weights drop behind your head - stop when they're level with your ears

instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, swing them straight up in front of you 5-10 times, increasing the range of motion each time until your arms are above your head.
exercises.name: Dynamic Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, arms hanging relaxed at your sides
Keeping your arms completely straight, swing them forward and up in front of your body
Start with smaller swings and gradually increase the height with each rep
Build momentum over 5-10 reps until your arms are swinging all the way overhead
Keep the movement smooth and controlled - don't force the range of motion
form_cues: Think about your arms as pendulums swinging from your shoulder joints
Imagine you're painting a rainbow arc in front of you that gets bigger each time
Let momentum help you, but stay in control - don't jerk or force it
common_mistakes: Bending the arms instead of keeping them straight throughout
Starting with too much range of motion instead of gradually building up
Arching your back excessively as your arms go overhead
injury_prevention_tips: Start with small swings and let your body naturally increase the range
Keep your core engaged to prevent excessive back arching

instructions: Stand with your hands together, arms extended directly in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, quickly move your arms back as far as possible and back in again, similar to an exaggerated clapping motion. Repeat 5-10 times, increasing speed as you do so.
exercises.name: Dynamic Chest Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with arms extended straight in front of you, hands together
Quickly swing your arms back and out to your sides, opening your chest wide
Immediately bring them back together in front - like an exaggerated clapping motion
Repeat for 5-10 reps, gradually increasing your speed and range of motion
Feel your chest and shoulders warming up with each repetition
form_cues: Think about trying to touch your shoulder blades together as your arms go back
Imagine you're pushing two walls apart as you open your arms
Keep your arms at shoulder height throughout - parallel to the ground
common_mistakes: Letting the arms drop below shoulder height during the movement
Not bringing the arms far enough back to feel a chest stretch
Rounding your shoulders forward instead of keeping your chest up
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement controlled even as you increase speed
Don't force the range of motion - stop where you feel a comfortable stretch

exercises.description: A biceps curl performed with an ez-bar
instructions: Stand up straight while holding an EZ curl bar at the wide outer handle. The palms of your hands should be facing forward and slightly tilted inward due to the shape of the bar. Keep your elbows close to your torso. This will be your starting position.
Now, while keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps. Focus on only moving your forearms.
Continue to raise the weight until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the top contracted position for a moment and squeeze the biceps.
Then inhale and slowly lower the bar back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: EZ-Bar Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall holding an EZ curl bar with hands at the wide outer grips, palms angled slightly inward
Pin your elbows tight to your sides - imagine they're glued to your ribs
Curl the bar up by bending only at the elbows, keeping your upper arms completely still
Squeeze hard at the top when the bar reaches shoulder level - finish like a double biceps pose
Lower the bar back down slowly with control, fighting gravity all the way
form_cues: Think about bringing the bar up in an arc toward your face, not straight up
Imagine your upper arms are nailed to a wall behind you - only your forearms move
Squeeze at the top like you're trying to touch your biceps to your forearms
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows drift forward as you curl, which reduces bicep tension
Using momentum from your hips or back to swing the weight up
Dropping the weight too fast on the way down instead of controlling the eccentric
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists neutral - the EZ bar should feel comfortable, not strained
Don't hyperextend your elbows at the bottom - keep a slight bend

exercises.description: Skullcrusher performed with an ez-bar
instructions: Using a close grip, lift the EZ bar and hold it with your elbows in as you lie on the bench. Your arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the upper arms stationary, lower the bar by allowing the elbows to flex. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Pause once the bar is directly above the forehead.
Lift the bar back to the starting position by extending the elbow and exhaling.
Repeat.
exercises.name: EZ-Bar Skullcrusher
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding an EZ-bar with a narrow grip directly above your chest with arms fully extended
Keep your upper arms completely still and perpendicular to the floor - they stay locked in this position
Lower the bar by bending only at the elbows until the bar is about 1-2 inches above your forehead
Pause briefly at the bottom, feeling the stretch in your triceps
Extend your elbows to press the bar back to the starting position, squeezing your triceps at the top
form_cues: Imagine your upper arms are frozen in concrete - only your forearms move like windshield wipers
Think about pulling the bar apart as you lower it to keep tension in your triceps
Pretend you're trying to show off the underside of your upper arms the entire time
Keep your elbows pointed at the ceiling, not flaring out to the sides
common_mistakes: Allowing the upper arms to drift back toward the head instead of staying perpendicular to the floor
Flaring the elbows out to the sides, which reduces triceps activation
Lowering the bar too quickly without control, risking elbow strain or hitting yourself in the face
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than you think - this exercise puts significant stress on the elbow joints
Keep the movement slow and controlled, especially on the lowering phase to protect your elbows

instructions: Sit or stand with your feet slightly apart.
Place your hands on your shoulders with your elbows at shoulder level and pointing out.
Slowly make a circle with your elbows. Breathe out as you start the circle and breathe in as you complete the circle.
exercises.name: Elbow Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit or stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place your hands on your shoulders
Position your elbows at shoulder height, pointing straight out to the sides
Slowly draw large circles with your elbows, moving them forward, up, back, and down
Breathe out as you start each circle and breathe in as you complete it
Perform circles in both directions (forward and backward)
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are paintbrushes drawing perfect circles on the walls beside you
Think about making the circles as large as possible without straining
Keep your hands glued to your shoulders throughout - they're just passengers
Visualize tracing the edge of a dinner plate with each elbow
common_mistakes: Making tiny circles instead of using the full range of motion available
Moving too quickly and losing the stretch benefit of the movement
Letting the hands slide off the shoulders or hunching the upper back
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly and gently - this is a mobility drill, not a strength exercise
Stop if you feel any sharp pain or pinching in the shoulder joint

instructions: Lie on the floor, crossing your right leg across your bent left knee. Clasp your hands behind your head, beginning with your shoulder blades on the ground. This will be your starting position.
Perform the motion by flexing the spine and rotating your torso to bring the left elbow to the right knee.
Return to the starting position and repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.
exercises.name: Elbow to Knee
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with your left knee bent and your right ankle crossed over it, hands behind your head
Keep your shoulder blades slightly off the ground to maintain tension in your abs
Rotate your torso and crunch up, bringing your left elbow toward your right knee
Focus on twisting through your core, not just pulling with your neck or arms
Return to the starting position and repeat for reps before switching sides
form_cues: Think about rotating your ribcage toward your opposite hip, not just lifting your shoulder
Imagine trying to touch your elbow to the outside of your knee
Keep your lower back pressed against the floor - no arching
Pretend you're wringing out a towel with your torso as you twist
common_mistakes: Pulling on the neck with your hands instead of rotating from the core
Only lifting the shoulder without actually twisting the torso
Using momentum to rock up instead of controlled ab contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your hands lightly touching your head - don't yank on your neck
Move slowly and deliberately to protect your spine during the rotation

instructions: Stand up straight.
Place both hands on your lower back, fingers pointing downward and elbows out.
Then gently pull your elbows back aiming to touch them together.
exercises.name: Elbows Back
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand up straight with good posture, chest up and shoulders back
Place both hands on your lower back with fingers pointing down and elbows out to the sides
Gently squeeze your shoulder blades together, trying to bring your elbows closer behind your back
Hold the stretch position for 20-30 seconds while breathing normally
Release slowly and repeat as needed
form_cues: Imagine trying to hold a pencil between your shoulder blades as you pull your elbows back
Think about opening up your chest like you're trying to show off a superhero logo on your shirt
Pretend there's a string attached to each elbow pulling them toward each other behind your back
Keep your chest lifted and proud throughout the stretch
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively instead of focusing on the chest and shoulder stretch
Forcing the elbows too aggressively, which can cause shoulder discomfort
Holding your breath instead of maintaining steady breathing
injury_prevention_tips: Stretch gently - this should feel good, not painful in the shoulders
Keep your core engaged to prevent excessive lower back arching

instructions: Position a bar onto a rack at shoulder height loaded to an appropriate weight. Place a short, raised platform behind you.
Rack the bar onto your upper back, keeping your back arched and tight. Step onto your raised platform with both feet. This will be your starting position.
Begin by stepping backwards with one leg. Descend by flexing your hips and knees until your knee touches the floor.
Pause, and extend through the hips and knees to rise up, returning all the way to the starting position before alternating.
exercises.name: Elevated Back Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on a raised platform (4-6 inches) with a barbell across your upper back, feet hip-width apart
Step backward off the platform with one leg, landing on the ball of your foot
Lower your body until your back knee touches the floor and your front thigh is parallel to the platform
Keep your torso upright and core braced throughout the entire movement
Push through your front foot to return to the starting position on the platform
form_cues: Think about dropping your back knee straight down toward the floor, not stepping back too far
Imagine sitting straight down into the lunge - keep your chest up like you're wearing a medal
Pretend your front shin is a wall that stays vertical the entire time
Drive through your front heel to stand back up, like you're pushing the platform down
common_mistakes: Leaning the torso forward excessively, which reduces quad and glute activation
Taking too short of a step backward, limiting the range of motion and effectiveness
Allowing the front knee to cave inward instead of tracking over the toes
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight or light weight until you're comfortable with the elevated position
Control the descent - don't drop quickly onto your back knee as this can jar the joint

instructions: Get a platform of some sort (it can be an aerobics or calf raise platform) that is around 4-6 inches in height.
Place it on the seat of the cable row machine.
Sit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided making sure that your knees are slightly bent and not locked.
Lean over as you keep the natural alignment of your back and grab the V-bar handles.

With your arms extended pull back until your torso is at a 90-degree angle from your legs. Your back should be slightly arched and your chest should be sticking out. You should be feeling a nice stretch on your lats as you hold the bar in front of you. This is the starting position of the exercise.

Keeping the torso stationary, pull the handles back towards your torso while keeping the arms close to it until you touch the abdominals. Breathe out as you perform that movement. At that point you should be squeezing your back muscles hard. Hold that contraction for a second and slowly go back to the original position while breathing in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Elevated Cable Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a 4-6 inch platform on the seat of a cable row machine and sit on it with feet braced
Lean forward to grab the V-bar handles with arms extended, then sit back to a 90-degree torso angle
Keep your back slightly arched and chest up - you should feel a stretch in your lats at the start
Pull the handles toward your abdomen, driving your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades together
Hold the contraction for a second, then slowly return to the stretched starting position
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows into your back pockets, not just bending your arms
Imagine squeezing a penny between your shoulder blades at the peak contraction
Keep your torso rock-solid - pretend your midsection is encased in concrete
Lead with your elbows and think about driving them back behind your body
common_mistakes: Using momentum by rocking the torso back and forth instead of keeping it stationary
Pulling with the arms and biceps rather than initiating the movement with the back muscles
Not achieving a full stretch at the start or cutting the range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back in a neutral, slightly arched position - avoid rounding forward
Don't jerk or yank the weight - use smooth, controlled pulling motion to protect your back

instructions: Lie on an exercise ball with your lower back curvature pressed against the spherical surface of the ball. Your feet should be bent at the knee and pressed firmly against the floor. The upper torso should be hanging off the top of the ball. The arms should either be kept alongside the body or crossed on top of your chest as these positions avoid neck strains (as opposed to the hands behind the back of the head position).
Lower your torso into a stretch position keeping the neck stationary at all times. This will be your starting position.

With the hips stationary, flex the waist by contracting the abdominals and curl the shoulders and trunk upward until you feel a nice contraction on your abdominals. The arms should simply slide up the side of your legs if you have them at the side or just stay on top of your chest if you have them crossed. The lower back should always stay in contact with the ball. Exhale as you perform this movement and hold the contraction for a second.
As you inhale, go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Exercise Ball Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an exercise ball with your lower back curved around the ball and feet flat on the floor
Position yourself so your upper back and shoulders are hanging off the ball, arms crossed over chest or at sides
Lower your torso back into a stretch, keeping your lower back in contact with the ball
Crunch up by contracting your abs, curling your shoulders and upper back toward your hips
Hold the peak contraction for a second, then lower back to the stretched position with control
form_cues: Think about curling your ribcage down toward your pelvis, not just lifting your shoulders
Imagine trying to shorten the distance between your sternum and belly button
Keep your lower back glued to the ball throughout - it stays in contact the entire time
Pretend you're trying to crunch an empty soda can between your chest and abs
common_mistakes: Using neck flexion to lift up instead of contracting the abdominals
Lifting the lower back off the ball, which reduces the effectiveness and stability
Bouncing up using momentum rather than controlled ab contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral - don't pull your chin to your chest or crane it backward
Make sure the ball is properly inflated and stable before performing the exercise

instructions: Place an exercise ball nearby and lay on the floor in front of it with your hands on the floor shoulder width apart in a push-up position.

Now place your lower shins on top of an exercise ball. Tip: At this point your legs should be fully extended with the shins on top of the ball and the upper body should be in a push-up type of position being supported by your two extended arms in front of you. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your back completely straight and the upper body stationary, pull your knees in towards your chest as you exhale, allowing the ball to roll forward under your ankles. Squeeze your abs and hold that position for a second.
Now slowly straighten your legs, rolling the ball back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Exercise Ball Pull-In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a push-up position with your hands on the floor and your shins resting on top of an exercise ball
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels with your core engaged
Pull your knees toward your chest by contracting your abs, rolling the ball forward under your feet
Hold the tucked position for a second, squeezing your abs hard
Extend your legs back to the starting position, rolling the ball back under your shins
form_cues: Think about bringing your knees to your elbows, not just bending your legs
Imagine you're trying to touch your knees to your forehead at the top
Keep your shoulders directly over your hands - don't let them shift backward
Pretend you're a ball rolling up into a tight position, then unrolling
common_mistakes: Piking the hips up too high or sagging them down, losing the straight body line
Using momentum to swing the ball in instead of controlled ab contraction
Letting the shoulders shift back away from the hands during the pull-in
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight throughout to protect your lower back from sagging
Start with small ranges of motion until you build the stability and strength needed

instructions: Lie on the floor and position a kettlebell for one arm to press. The kettlebell should be held by the handle. The leg on the same side that you are pressing should be bent, with the knee crossing over the midline of the body.
Press the kettlebell by extending the elbow and adducting the arm, pressing it above your body. Return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Extended Range One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back on the floor holding a kettlebell by the handle in one hand at chest level
Bend the leg on the same side as the kettlebell and cross it over your body for stability
Press the kettlebell up by extending your elbow, moving your arm across your body until it's directly above your chest
Hold briefly at the top with your arm fully extended
Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about pressing the kettlebell up and slightly across your body toward the centerline
Imagine pushing yourself into the floor as you press the weight up
Keep your shoulder blade packed down and back - don't let it lift off the floor
Pretend you're punching the ceiling at an angle
common_mistakes: Pressing straight up instead of across the body, which limits the extended range of motion
Allowing the shoulder to roll forward or lift off the floor during the press
Using leg drive or momentum instead of strict chest and arm pressing
injury_prevention_tips: Let your elbow touch the floor briefly at the bottom to reset and protect the shoulder joint
Keep your wrist straight and neutral - don't let the kettlebell pull it into a bent position

instructions: Lie sideways on a flat bench with one arm holding a dumbbell and the other hand on top of the bench folded so that you can rest your head on it.
Bend the elbows of the arm holding the dumbbell so that it creates a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the arm parallel to your torso.

Now bend the elbow while keeping the upper arm stationary. In this manner, the forearm will be parallel to the floor and perpendicular to your torso (Tip: So the forearm will be directly in front of you). The upper arm will be stationary by your torso and should be parallel to the floor (aligned with your torso at all times). This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, externally rotate your forearm so that the dumbbell is lifted up in a semicircle motion as you maintain the 90 degree angle bend between the upper arms and the forearm. You will continue this external rotation until the forearm is perpendicular to the floor and the torso pointing towards the ceiling. At this point you will hold the contraction for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.
exercises.name: External Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie sideways on a bench with your lower arm holding a light dumbbell, upper arm against your torso
Bend your elbow to 90 degrees so your forearm points straight ahead, parallel to the floor
Keep your upper arm glued to your side as you rotate your forearm upward in an arc
Continue rotating until your forearm points straight up at the ceiling
Lower back down slowly to the starting position, maintaining the 90-degree elbow bend throughout
form_cues: Imagine your elbow is a hinge bolted to your ribs - it doesn't move at all
Think about rotating from your shoulder joint like you're opening a door
Pretend you're drawing a half-circle in the air with the dumbbell
Keep that 90-degree angle locked like your forearm is on a track
common_mistakes: Allowing the upper arm to lift away from the torso during the rotation
Using too much weight and compensating by changing the elbow angle
Moving too quickly without controlling the rotation through the full range
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weight - this targets the small rotator cuff muscles that are easily overtrained
Move slowly and deliberately to avoid straining the delicate shoulder stabilizer muscles

instructions: Choke the band around a post. The band should be at the same height as your elbow. Stand with your left side to the band a couple of feet away.
Grasp the end of the band with your right hand, and keep your elbow pressed firmly to your side. We recommend you hold a pad or foam roll in place with your elbow to keep it firmly in position.
With your upper arm in position, your elbow should be flexed to 90 degrees with your hand reaching across the front of your torso. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by rotating your arm in a backhand motion, keeping your elbow in place.
Continue as far as you are able, pause, and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: External Rotation with Band
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a resistance band to a post at elbow height and stand with your left side to the band, a couple feet away
Grab the band with your right hand and pin your elbow to your side - hold a pad or foam roller with your elbow against your ribs
Start with your elbow bent at 90 degrees and your hand across the front of your body
Rotate your forearm outward like you're doing a backhand motion, keeping your elbow glued to your side
Go as far as comfortable, pause, then return slowly to the starting position
form_cues: Think about your forearm as a door swinging open on a hinge at your elbow
Imagine turning a doorknob away from your body
Keep your upper arm completely still - imagine it's in a cast against your side
common_mistakes: Letting the elbow drift away from the body during rotation
Using the shoulder to rotate instead of just the rotator cuff muscles
Moving too fast or jerking the movement instead of smooth, controlled rotation
injury_prevention_tips: Use light resistance - this targets small rotator cuff muscles
Keep the movement slow and controlled within a pain-free range

instructions: Adjust the cable to the same height as your elbow. Stand with your left side to the band a couple of feet away.
Grasp the handle with your right hand, and keep your elbow pressed firmly to your side. We recommend you hold a pad or foam roll in place with your elbow to keep it firmly in position.
With your upper arm in position, your elbow should be flexed to 90 degrees with your hand reaching across the front of your torso. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by rotating your arm in a backhand motion, keeping your elbow in place.
exercises.name: External Rotation with Cable
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable at elbow height and stand sideways to it, a couple feet away
Grab the handle with your far hand and pin your elbow firmly to your side using a pad
Start with elbow bent 90 degrees and hand across your torso
Rotate your forearm out in a backhand motion while keeping your elbow locked at your side
Pause at the end range and return with control
form_cues: Think about opening a car door from the inside using only your forearm
Imagine your elbow is nailed to your ribs - it shouldn't move at all
Feel the work in your shoulder blade area, not your bicep or forearm
common_mistakes: Letting the elbow pop away from the body as you rotate
Using momentum to swing the weight instead of controlled rotation
Rotating too far and compensating with shoulder movement
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - these are small stabilizer muscles
Stop at the point where you feel tension, don't force past your natural range

instructions: Facing a high pulley with a rope or dual handles attached, pull the weight directly towards your face, separating your hands as you do so. Keep your upper arms parallel to the ground.
exercises.name: Face Pull
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable pulley to upper chest or face height with a rope attachment
Grab the rope with both hands and step back to create tension
Pull the rope directly toward your face while separating your hands outward
Think about pulling the rope apart as you bring it to your face - finish with hands by your ears
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end position, then return with control
form_cues: Think about pulling the rope to split it apart on either side of your face
Imagine trying to touch your elbows to the wall behind you
Keep your upper arms parallel to the ground throughout - like you're flexing your rear delts
common_mistakes: Pulling down toward your chest instead of straight to your face
Letting your elbows drop below parallel with the ground
Not separating the handles enough - they should end up wide by your ears
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulders pulled down and back, don't shrug them up
Use a weight that allows full range of motion without compensating

instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing up; hands spaced about shoulder width.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible by extending the fingers. Allowing the bar to roll down the hands, catch the bar with the final joint in the fingers.
Now curl bar up as high as possible by closing your hands while exhaling. Hold the contraction at the top.
exercises.name: Finger Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a barbell with an underhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart, palms facing up
Stand or sit with the bar resting in your palms, fingers extended
Let the bar roll down your fingers by opening your hand until it's held only by your fingertips
Curl your fingers closed to roll the bar back up into your palm as tight as possible
Squeeze at the top and repeat the opening and closing motion
form_cues: Think about the bar rolling like a wave from your palm down to your fingertips and back
Imagine you're gripping the life out of the bar at the top
Feel your forearms burn as you close your fingers tight
common_mistakes: Not letting the bar roll far enough down to the fingertips
Using wrist movement instead of pure finger flexion
Rushing the movement instead of controlled opening and closing
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight - finger flexors are smaller muscles
Don't let the bar slip completely out of your hands

instructions: Position a flat bench between two low pulleys so that when you are laying on it, your chest will be lined up with the cable pulleys.
Lay flat on the bench and keep your feet on the ground.
Have someone hand you the handles on each hand. You will grab each single handle attachment with a palms up grip.

Extend your arms by your side with a slight bend on your elbows. Tip: You will keep this bend constant through the whole movement. Your arms should be parallel to the floor. This is your starting position.

Now start lifting the arms in a semi-circle motion directly in front of you by pulling the cables together until both hands meet at the top of the movement. Squeeze your chest as you perform this motion and breathe out during this movement. Also, hold the contraction for a second at the top. Tip: When performed correctly, at the top position of this movement, your arms should be perpendicular to your torso and the floor touching above your chest.
Slowly come back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Flat Bench Cable Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a flat bench between two low cable pulleys and lie back with a handle in each hand, palms facing up
Start with arms extended out to your sides, parallel to the floor, with a slight bend in your elbows
Pull the cables together in a wide arc until your hands meet above your chest
Think about hugging a large tree as you bring your arms together
Squeeze your chest hard at the top, then slowly return to the stretched position
form_cues: Imagine you're wrapping your arms around a barrel as you bring the cables together
Think about your chest doing all the work - lead with your elbows, not your hands
At the top, squeeze like you're crushing a can between your pecs
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows too much, turning it into a press instead of a fly
Letting the cables pull your arms too far back, straining the shoulders
Bringing your hands together too low (at stomach) instead of above your chest
injury_prevention_tips: Keep that constant slight bend in your elbows - don't straighten or bend them more
Don't let the weight pull your shoulders off the bench at the bottom

instructions: Lie on an exercise mat or a flat bench with your legs off the end.

Place your hands either under your glutes with your palms down or by the sides holding on to the bench (or with palms down by the side on an exercise mat). Also extend your legs straight out. This will be your starting position.
Bend your knees and pull your upper thighs into your midsection as you breathe out. Continue this movement until your knees are near your chest. Hold the contracted position for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Flat Bench Leg Pull-In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench with your legs hanging off the end and hands under your glutes or holding the bench sides
Extend your legs straight out in front of you - this is your starting position
Pull your knees toward your chest by bending them and bringing your thighs into your midsection
Think about curling your lower body into a ball, using your lower abs to pull
Squeeze when your knees reach your chest, then extend back out with control
form_cues: Think about pulling your knees to your elbows using your abs
Imagine your legs are being pulled by a string attached to your belly button
Focus on the crunch in your lower abs as you pull in
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing your legs instead of controlled ab contraction
Not bringing your knees high enough - they should get close to your chest
Letting your legs drop too fast on the way out
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back pressed into the bench throughout
Don't jerk or swing the legs - maintain smooth control

instructions: Lie with your back flat on a bench and your legs extended in front of you off the end.
Place your hands either under your glutes with your palms down or by the sides holding on to the bench. This will be your starting position.

As you keep your legs extended, straight as possible with your knees slightly bent but locked raise your legs until they make a 90-degree angle with the floor. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and hold the contraction at the top for a second.
Now, as you inhale, slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position.
exercises.name: Flat Bench Lying Leg Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench with legs extended off the end and hands under your glutes or holding the bench
Keep your legs as straight as possible with knees slightly bent and locked
Raise your legs up until they're perpendicular to the floor (90-degree angle)
Think about using your lower abs to lift your legs straight up toward the ceiling
Hold the top position for a second, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Imagine your legs are a drawbridge lifting straight up
Think about your lower abs pulling your legs up like a crane
Keep your legs rigid - they're one solid piece moving together
common_mistakes: Bending your knees too much, making it easier and less effective
Using momentum to swing the legs up instead of controlled lifting
Letting your lower back arch off the bench during the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Press your lower back into the bench - don't let it arch up
Lower the legs slowly to keep constant tension and protect your back

instructions: Hold the dumbbell towards the side farther from you so that you have more weight on the side closest to you. (This can be done for a good effect on all bicep dumbbell exercises). Now do a normal incline dumbbell curl, but keep your wrists as far back as possible so as to neutralize any stress that is placed on them.
Sit on an incline bench that is angled at 45-degrees while holding a dumbbell on each hand.

Let your arms hang down on your sides, with the elbows in, and turn the palms of your hands forward with the thumbs pointing away from the body. Tip: You will keep this hand position throughout the movement as there should not be any twisting of the hands as they come up. This will be your starting position.

Curl up the two dumbbells at the same time until your biceps are fully contracted and exhale. Tip: Do not swing the arms or use momentum. Keep a controlled motion at all times. Hold the contracted position for a second at the top.
As you inhale, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Flexor Incline Dumbbell Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit back on a 45-degree incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging straight down
Hold the dumbbells with palms facing forward and keep your wrists extended back throughout
Keep your elbows pinned at your sides and curl both dumbbells up simultaneously
Focus on keeping your wrists in that extended-back position to target the forearm flexors
Squeeze at the top when biceps are fully contracted, then lower with control
form_cues: Think about keeping your wrists bent back like you're showing someone your watch
Imagine your elbows are pinned to the bench - don't let them drift forward
Squeeze your biceps at the top like you're flexing for a photo
common_mistakes: Letting your wrists flex forward instead of staying extended back
Allowing your elbows to come forward off the bench
Using momentum to swing the weights up instead of strict curls
injury_prevention_tips: The incline puts your biceps in a stretched position - start lighter than flat curls
Keep the wrist position consistent to avoid strain

instructions: You can use a partner for this exercise or brace your feet under something stable.
Begin on your knees with your upper legs and torso upright. If using a partner, they will firmly hold your feet to keep you in position. This will be your starting position.
Lower yourself by extending at the knee, taking care to NOT flex the hips as you go forward.

Place your hands in front of you as you reach the floor. This movement is very difficult and you may be unable to do it unaided. Use your arms to lightly push off the floor to aid your return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Floor Glute-Ham Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on your knees with torso upright and have a partner hold your ankles firmly, or anchor your feet under something stable
Keep your body in a straight line from knees to head - engage your core
Slowly lower your torso forward by straightening your knees, keeping your hips locked (don't bend at the hips)
Think about falling forward like a rigid plank - your body stays straight
Use your hands to catch yourself at the bottom and push off to help return to the start
form_cues: Imagine your body is a board rotating at the knee joint only
Think about your hamstrings acting as a brake to control your descent
Keep your hips locked - don't pike or fold at the waist
common_mistakes: Bending at the hips instead of keeping your body in a straight line
Lowering too fast and slamming into the floor
Not using your hamstrings to control the descent
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced exercise - most beginners will need to use their hands to push back up
Lower slowly and under control to prevent hamstring strain

instructions: Adjust the j-hooks so they are at the appropriate height to rack the bar. Begin lying on the floor with your head near the end of a power rack. Keeping your shoulder blades pulled together; pull the bar off of the hooks.

Lower the bar towards the bottom of your chest or upper stomach, squeezing the bar and attempting to pull it apart as you do so. Ensure that you tuck your elbows throughout the movement. Lower the bar until your upper arm contacts the ground and pause, preventing any slamming or bouncing of the weight.
Press the bar back up as fast as you can, keeping the bar, your wrists, and elbows in line as you do so.
exercises.name: Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor in a power rack with the bar racked just within reach, shoulder blades squeezed together
Unrack the bar and hold it over your chest with arms extended
Lower the bar to your lower chest/upper stomach with elbows tucked, squeezing the bar like you're trying to bend it
Let your upper arms touch the floor and pause without bouncing or relaxing
Drive the bar back up explosively, keeping everything tight and aligned
form_cues: Think about pulling the bar apart as you lower it to engage your lats
Imagine pushing yourself through the floor rather than pressing the bar up
At the bottom, pause on the floor - don't bounce or lose tension
common_mistakes: Bouncing your elbows off the floor instead of pausing at the bottom
Flaring elbows out wide instead of tucking them at 45 degrees
Losing tightness in your upper back and shoulders
injury_prevention_tips: The floor provides a natural stopping point, making this shoulder-friendly
Keep your shoulder blades squeezed together throughout to protect your shoulders

instructions: Adjust the j-hooks so they are at the appropriate height to rack the bar. For this exercise, drape the chains directly over the end of the bar, trying to keep the ends away from the plates.
Begin lying on the floor with your head near the end of a power rack. Keeping your shoulder blades pulled together, pull the bar off of the hooks.

Lower the bar towards the bottom of your chest or upper stomach, squeezing the bar and attempting to pull it apart as you do so. Ensure that you tuck your elbows throughout the movement. Lower the bar until your upper arm contacts the ground and pause, preventing any slamming or bouncing of the weight.
Press the bar back up as fast as you can, keeping the bar, your wrists, and elbows in line as you do so.
exercises.name: Floor Press with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor under a power rack with the barbell racked above you, chains draped over the bar ends
Pull your shoulder blades together and unrack the bar, holding it with arms extended above your chest
Lower the bar toward your lower chest or upper stomach with elbows tucked, squeezing the bar hard
Pause when your upper arms touch the floor - don't bounce or slam down
Explosively press the bar back up, keeping your wrists, bar, and elbows aligned
form_cues: Think about trying to bend the bar in half as you lower it, keeping tension in your chest and triceps
Imagine pulling the bar apart like you're trying to rip it in two throughout the movement
Keep your elbows tucked at about 45 degrees - pretend you're trying to squeeze oranges in your armpits
Press the bar up as explosively as possible, like you're trying to throw it through the ceiling
common_mistakes: Flaring the elbows out wide instead of keeping them tucked, which reduces triceps engagement
Bouncing the elbows off the floor instead of pausing, which removes the stabilization benefit
Losing tension in the upper back and letting the shoulder blades spread apart
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blades retracted and pressed into the floor throughout the entire movement
Control the descent and pause on the floor - don't slam your elbows down as this can cause joint damage

instructions: On a flat bench lie facedown with the hips on the edge of the bench, the legs straight with toes high off the floor and with the arms on top of the bench holding on to the front edge.
Squeeze your glutes and hamstrings and straighten the legs until they are level with the hips. This will be your starting position.
Start the movement by lifting the left leg higher than the right leg.
Then lower the left leg as you lift the right leg.

Continue alternating in this manner (as though you are doing a flutter kick in water) until you have done the recommended amount of repetitions for each leg. Make sure that you keep a controlled movement at all times. Tip: You will breathe normally as you perform this movement.
exercises.name: Flutter Kicks
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on a flat bench with your hips at the edge, legs extended straight behind you off the bench
Hold the front edge of the bench for stability and squeeze your glutes to lift your legs to hip level
Raise your left leg higher while keeping the right leg at hip level
Lower your left leg as you simultaneously raise your right leg in a controlled alternating pattern
Continue alternating legs in a flutter kick motion while maintaining tension in your glutes and hamstrings
form_cues: Imagine your legs are scissors opening and closing in small, controlled movements
Keep your glutes squeezed tight the entire time like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Think about lifting from your glutes and hamstrings, not just moving your legs
Pretend you're swimming in water with small, quick flutter kicks
common_mistakes: Letting the legs drop below hip level, which reduces glute and hamstring tension
Moving too fast with jerky motions instead of controlled, deliberate movements
Relaxing the glutes between reps instead of maintaining constant tension
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back from hyperextension
Start with a smaller range of motion until you build strength and control in the glutes

instructions: This exercise stretches the fascia of the muscles in the feet. Start off seated with your shoes removed. Using a foot roller or a similar object, such as a small section of pvc pipe, place your foot against the roller across the arch of your foot. This will be your starting position.
Press down firmly, rolling across the arch of your foot. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and then switch feet.
exercises.name: Foot-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in a chair with your shoes off and place a foot roller or small PVC pipe under your foot
Position the roller across the arch of your foot, under the middle portion
Press down firmly through your foot into the roller, applying moderate pressure
