Slowly roll back and forth across the arch, exploring tender spots
Hold on any particularly tight or sore areas for 10-30 seconds before switching feet
form_cues: Think about rolling out the fascia like you're flattening dough with a rolling pin
Imagine melting into the roller when you find a tight spot
Apply enough pressure to feel it working, but not so much that you tense up
Breathe deeply and relax - tension defeats the purpose of this release work
common_mistakes: Rolling too quickly without spending time on tight spots
Using too little pressure, which won't effectively release the fascia
Tensing up the entire body instead of relaxing into the pressure
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light pressure and gradually increase as your foot adapts to the sensation
Avoid rolling over bony areas or joints - focus on the soft tissue of the arch

instructions: Cross your arms over your chest.
With your head up and your back straight, position your feet at shoulder width.
Keeping your back straight and chest up, squat down as you inhale until your upper thighs are parallel, or lower, to the floor.
Now pressing mainly with the ball of your feet, jump straight up in the air as high as possible, using the thighs like springs. Exhale during this portion of the movement.
When you touch the floor again, immediately squat down and jump again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Freehand Jump Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, arms crossed over your chest, and back straight
Squat down until your thighs are parallel to the floor or slightly lower, keeping your chest up
Explode upward, jumping as high as possible by driving through the balls of your feet
Use your thighs like springs to generate maximum power
Land softly with bent knees, immediately descending into the next squat and repeating
form_cues: Think about loading a spring as you squat down, then exploding upward with all your power
Imagine the floor is hot lava and you need to jump off it as quickly as possible
Keep your chest proud and eyes forward - pretend you're trying to reach up and touch the ceiling
Land like a cat - soft, quiet, and immediately ready for the next jump
common_mistakes: Jumping for height instead of focusing on explosive power from the legs
Landing stiff-legged, which can cause knee and ankle injuries
Pausing too long between reps instead of maintaining a continuous rhythm
injury_prevention_tips: Land with soft knees to absorb the impact and immediately descend into the next squat
Start with smaller jumps and focus on perfect landing mechanics before going for max height

instructions: Stand with your hands behind your head, and squat down keeping your torso upright and your head up. This will be your starting position.
Jump forward several feet, avoiding jumping unnecessarily high. As your feet contact the ground, absorb the impact through your legs, and jump again. Repeat this action 5-10 times.
exercises.name: Frog Hops
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with your hands behind your head and squat down to a low position, keeping your torso upright
Jump forward several feet, focusing on distance rather than height
Land softly on the balls of your feet with bent knees to absorb the impact
Immediately load into the next jump without standing up fully
Continue hopping forward for 5-10 consecutive jumps
form_cues: Think about being a frog launching forward across lily pads
Imagine you're trying to cover as much ground as possible with each hop
Keep your chest up and eyes forward - don't look down at the ground
Land and reload like a spring compressing and releasing
common_mistakes: Jumping too high instead of focusing on forward distance and horizontal power
Standing up fully between jumps instead of staying in a squat position
Landing heavily on the heels instead of absorbing impact through the balls of the feet
injury_prevention_tips: Land with bent knees and absorb the impact through your legs, not your joints
Start with shorter hops until you develop the strength and coordination for longer jumps

instructions: Lie with your back flat on the floor (or exercise mat) and your legs extended in front of you.
Now bend at the knees and place your outer thighs by the floor (or mat) as you make the soles of your feet touch each other.

Now try pushing both soles and bringing them up as near you as possible while you keep the outer thighs on the floor (or at least almost touching it). Tip: In this position your legs should create a diamond shape.
Now, cross your arms in front of you by touching the opposite shoulders. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale flatten your lower back to the floor while curling the torso upwards. Tip: This will be like performing the first 1/4 movement of a sit up. Hold at the top position for a second.
As you inhale, slowly lower back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Frog Sit-Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with the soles of your feet together, knees dropped out to the sides in a diamond shape
Bring your feet as close to your body as comfortable while keeping your outer thighs near the floor
Cross your arms over your chest, touching opposite shoulders
Curl your torso upward about a quarter of the way up, flattening your lower back to the floor
Hold at the top for a second, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Think about peeling your upper back off the floor one vertebra at a time
Imagine shortening the distance between your ribs and pelvis by crunching your abs
Keep your lower back glued to the floor - pretend you're trying to press a penny flat beneath it
Focus on your abs doing all the work, not your hip flexors or momentum
common_mistakes: Sitting all the way up instead of performing a controlled quarter crunch
Letting the lower back arch off the floor, which reduces ab activation
Using momentum or rocking instead of controlled ab contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement small and controlled - this is about ab isolation, not a full sit-up
Press your lower back flat to the floor throughout to protect your spine

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.
Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the middle of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Front Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the bar at shoulder height in a rack, bring your arms under it with elbows high, and rest it on your front delts
Cross your arms to secure the bar, unrack it by standing up, and step back with feet shoulder-width apart
Keep your chest up, head facing forward, and back straight as you begin to descend
Lower down until your thighs are just below parallel, keeping your knees tracking over your toes
Drive through the middle of your feet to stand back up, maintaining an upright torso throughout
form_cues: Imagine you're sitting back into a chair while keeping your chest as vertical as possible
Think about leading with your elbows - keep them high throughout the movement like you're showing off your biceps
Pretend there's a wall in front of your knees that you can't let them touch
Keep your core braced like you're about to get punched in the stomach
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drop down, which causes the bar to roll forward off the shoulders
Leaning too far forward, which shifts weight to the toes and reduces quad activation
Allowing the knees to cave inward instead of tracking in line with the toes
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your elbows high and your core braced to maintain the upright torso position
Start with light weight to master the form - front squats are technically demanding

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set a flat bench behind you and set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.
Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until you touch the bench with your glutes. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Front Barbell Squat To A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a bench behind you and the bar at shoulder height, then position the bar on your front delts with arms crossed
Unrack the bar, step back to the bench with feet shoulder-width apart, chest up and head forward
Lower yourself down by bending at the knees and hips until your glutes touch the bench
Pause briefly on the bench without fully relaxing, keeping tension in your legs
Drive through your heels to stand back up, maintaining an upright torso position
form_cues: Think about sitting back to the bench while keeping your torso as upright as a flagpole
Imagine barely kissing the bench with your glutes - don't fully collapse onto it
Keep your elbows high like you're a marionette with strings pulling them up
Drive through your heels to stand up, like you're pushing the floor away from you
common_mistakes: Collapsing onto the bench and losing all tension instead of lightly touching it
Allowing the knees to shoot forward past the toes as you sit back
Dropping the elbows as you descend, which causes the bar to roll forward
injury_prevention_tips: Use a higher bench initially if you lack the mobility to descend safely to a lower one
Touch the bench lightly to maintain tension - don't relax completely as this can stress the knees when you stand

instructions: Select the weight on a low pulley machine and grasp the single hand cable attachment that is attached to the low pulley with your left hand.

Face away from the pulley and put your arm straight down with the hand cable attachment in front of your thighs at arms' length with the palms of the hand facing your thighs. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the left arm to the front with a slight bend on the elbow and the palms of the hand always faces down. Continue to go up until you arm is slightly above parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this portion of the movement and pause for a second at the top.
Now as you inhale lower the arm back down slowly to the starting position.
Once all of the recommended amount of repetitions have been performed for this arm, switch arms and perform the exercise with the right one.
exercises.name: Front Cable Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a single handle to a low pulley, face away from the machine, and hold the handle in one hand at thigh level
Stand with your arm straight down, palm facing your thigh, and torso stationary
Lift your arm forward with a slight elbow bend, keeping your palm facing down throughout
Raise until your arm is slightly above parallel to the floor, then pause for a second
Lower the handle back down slowly to the starting position with control
form_cues: Imagine your arm is a crane lifting a heavy load smoothly upward
Think about leading with your knuckles, keeping your palm facing down the entire time
Keep your torso rock-solid - pretend you're frozen in place from the neck down
Visualize drawing an arc in the air from your thigh to eye level
common_mistakes: Using momentum by swinging the torso or leaning back to help lift the weight
Raising the arm too high above shoulder level, which reduces front delt tension
Bending the elbow excessively during the lift, turning it into a curl
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blade stable and don't let it shrug up as you lift
Use a weight that allows strict form - this is an isolation exercise, not a power movement

instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and stand with a straight torso and the dumbbells on front of your thighs at arms length with the palms of the hand facing your thighs. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the left dumbbell to the front with a slight bend on the elbow and the palms of the hands always facing down. Continue to go up until you arm is slightly above parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this portion of the movement and pause for a second at the top. Inhale after the second pause.
Now lower the dumbbell back down slowly to the starting position as you simultaneously lift the right dumbbell.
Continue alternating in this fashion until all of the recommended amount of repetitions have been performed for each arm.
exercises.name: Front Dumbbell Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with dumbbells in front of your thighs, arms straight, palms facing your legs
Keep your torso stationary and lift one dumbbell forward with a slight elbow bend and palm facing down
Raise until your arm is slightly above parallel to the floor, pause for a second at the top
Lower that dumbbell back down as you simultaneously lift the other arm up
Continue alternating arms in a smooth, controlled rhythm
form_cues: Think about your arms as pendulums swinging up one at a time in perfect rhythm
Imagine you're conducting an orchestra, raising one baton at a time
Keep your palms facing down like you're patting two invisible dogs on the head
Pretend your torso is a statue - completely still while only your arms move
common_mistakes: Using momentum by rocking or swinging the torso back and forth
Raising the dumbbells too high, which brings the traps into play instead of isolating the front delts
Turning the palms up during the lift, which shifts tension away from the front deltoids
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to prevent lower back arching as you lift
Don't use momentum or swing the weights - control the entire range of motion

instructions: Sit down on an incline bench with the incline set anywhere between 30 to 60 degrees while holding a dumbbell on each hand. Tip: You can change the angle to hit the muscle a little differently each time.
Extend your arms straight in front of you and have your palms facing down with the dumbbells raised about 1 inch above your thighs. This will be your starting position.

Slowly raise the dumbbells straight up until they are slightly above your shoulders, while keeping your elbows locked. Squeeze at the top for a second and make sure you breathe out during this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep your head resting down against the bench and your legs on the floor at all times.
Lower the arms back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Front Incline Dumbbell Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set an incline bench to 30-60 degrees and sit with your back firmly against the pad, dumbbells in hand
Extend your arms straight in front of you with palms facing down, dumbbells hovering just above your thighs - imagine you're about to shake someone's hand below you
Raise the dumbbells in a straight line until they're slightly above shoulder height, keeping your elbows locked - think about pushing the weights through an invisible wall in front of you
Squeeze hard at the top like you're flexing for a photo, then lower back down with control
Keep your head resting on the bench and feet planted throughout - your body should stay glued to the bench
form_cues: Lock your elbows and keep them locked - imagine your arms are steel rods that can't bend
Lead with your knuckles, not your elbows - pretend you're punching the ceiling in slow motion
Keep the movement in a perfectly straight vertical line - like the dumbbells are sliding up and down a pane of glass
Squeeze your shoulders forward at the top - think about trying to touch your front delts together
common_mistakes: Swinging the dumbbells or using momentum by rocking the torso off the bench
Bending the elbows during the movement, which turns it into a front press
Raising the weights too high (above the head) which shifts tension away from the front delts
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - this isolated movement is harder than it looks and can stress the shoulder joint
Keep your shoulder blades pinned back against the bench to maintain stable shoulders throughout

instructions: Stand next to a chair or other support, holding on with one hand.
Swing your leg forward, keeping the leg straight. Continue with a downward swing, bringing the leg as far back as your flexibility allows. Repeat 5-10 times, and then switch legs.
exercises.name: Front Leg Raises
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand next to a sturdy chair or wall, holding on lightly with one hand for balance
Keep your standing leg slightly bent and your core engaged - imagine bracing like someone's about to push you
Swing your outside leg forward like a pendulum, keeping it completely straight - think about kicking a soccer ball gently
Let the leg swing naturally back behind you as far as your flexibility allows without arching your lower back
Perform 5-10 smooth, controlled swings, then switch legs
form_cues: Move like a pendulum - smooth, rhythmic swings with no jerky movements
Lead with your heel going forward and your toes going back - imagine you're drawing a straight line on the ground
Keep your torso tall and still - pretend you're balancing a book on your head
Point your toes up toward your shin on the forward swing to feel the hamstring stretch
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back when swinging the leg behind you instead of stopping at your natural range
Bending the swinging leg at the knee, which reduces the stretch and effectiveness
Leaning the torso forward and back with the leg swing instead of keeping it stationary
injury_prevention_tips: Start with small swings and gradually increase range as you warm up - don't force flexibility
Keep the movement smooth and controlled, never forcing the leg beyond what feels comfortable

instructions: While standing straight, hold a barbell plate in both hands at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions. Your palms should be facing each other and your arms should be extended and locked with a slight bend at the elbows and the plate should be down near your waist in front of you as far as you can go. Tip: The arms will remain in this position throughout the exercise. This will be your starting position.

Slowly raise the plate as you exhale until it is a little above shoulder level. Hold the contraction for a second. Tip: make sure that you do not swing the weight or bend at the elbows. Your torso should remain stationary throughout the movement as well.
As you inhale, slowly lower the plate back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Front Plate Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions (sides)
Start with the plate down near your waist, arms extended with just a slight bend in the elbows - imagine holding a pizza level
Raise the plate straight up in front of you until it's just above shoulder level, keeping your arms locked - think about pushing the plate away from you as you lift
Squeeze at the top for one second, then lower back down with control
Keep your torso completely still - no swinging or leaning back
form_cues: Grip the plate like a steering wheel and keep it level throughout - imagine you're holding a tray of drinks
Lead with the top edge of the plate - think about showing the plate to the ceiling
Keep your shoulders down and back - don't let them shrug up toward your ears
Lock your elbows early and maintain that slight bend throughout - no changing angles mid-rep
common_mistakes: Swinging the weight up using momentum from leaning back instead of using strict shoulder strength
Bending and straightening the elbows during the movement, turning it into a partial press
Raising the plate too high (overhead) which reduces tension on the front delts
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a lighter plate (10-25 lbs) - this movement is more challenging than it looks
If you feel the need to swing or lean back, the weight is too heavy

instructions: Lie on a flat bench while holding a barbell using a palms down grip that is about 15 inches apart.
Place the bar on your upper thighs, extend your arms and lock them while keeping a slight bend on the elbows. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the weight using a semicircular motion and keeping your arms straight as you inhale. Continue the same movement until the bar is on the other side above your head . (Tip: the bar will travel approximately 180-degrees). At this point your arms should be parallel to the floor with the palms of your hands facing the ceiling.
Now return the barbell to the starting position by reversing the motion as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Front Raise And Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench with a barbell on your upper thighs, hands about 15 inches apart with palms down
Extend your arms straight up with locked elbows and a slight bend - imagine holding a beach ball above your thighs
Raise the bar in a big rainbow arc over your head until your arms are parallel to the floor above you, keeping them straight throughout - think about drawing a semicircle in the air
The bar should travel approximately 180 degrees from thighs to overhead with palms ending up facing the ceiling
Reverse the arc to bring the bar back to the starting position
form_cues: Move in one smooth rainbow motion - like you're tracing the inside of a giant barrel above you
Keep your elbows locked throughout - your arms should feel like long lever arms
At the top, your arms should be parallel to the floor with palms facing up - think about being in a 'stick-em-up' position lying down
Keep your lower back pressed into the bench - imagine you're trying to flatten a piece of paper under you
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows during the movement, which reduces the stretch on the chest and lats
Arching the lower back excessively when the bar goes overhead
Using too much weight and losing the smooth semicircular motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - this is a stretch-focused movement that can stress the shoulders
Keep constant tension and control throughout - never let the weight pull you into an uncomfortable stretch

instructions: To begin, first set the bar in a rack slightly below shoulder level. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids, pushing into the clavicles, and lightly touching the throat. Your hands should be in a clean grip, touching the bar only with your fingers to help keep it in position.

Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso. Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head and elbows up at all times. This will be your starting position.

Bend at the knees, sitting down between your legs. Continue down until your hamstrings are on your calves. Keep your knees aligned with your feet by consciously using your abductors to push your knees out as you squat.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the heel or middle of your foot as you straighten the legs again and return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Front Squat (Clean Grip)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up with the bar resting on your front delts and lightly touching your throat, fingertips barely touching the bar to hold it in place (clean grip)
Unrack and step back, feet shoulder-width apart with toes slightly out, chest and elbows high - imagine you're wearing a cape and showing it off
Squat down by sitting between your legs, keeping your torso upright and elbows pointing forward the entire time - think about dropping straight down an elevator shaft
Push your knees out consciously as you descend, going until your hamstrings touch your calves
Drive through your heels and mid-foot to stand back up, keeping elbows and chest high throughout
form_cues: Elbows high and forward at all times - imagine you're doing a zombie walk with your arms out front
Sit between your legs, not back onto a chair - think about dropping your hips straight down through a hole
Push your knees out actively like you're spreading the floor apart with your feet
Lead with your chest - imagine a rope pulling your sternum toward the ceiling
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drop down during the squat, which causes the bar to roll forward off the shoulders
Leaning forward excessively with the torso instead of staying upright
Not actively pushing the knees out, allowing them to cave inward (valgus collapse)
injury_prevention_tips: Front squats demand mobility - if you can't keep your torso upright, work on ankle and thoracic mobility first
The bar should feel secure on your delts without your hands holding it tightly - adjust your rack position if it feels like it's choking you

instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.

Looking straight ahead at all times, squat as low as you can and pause at the bottom. As you squat down, push your knees out. You should squat between your legs, keeping an upright torso, with your head and chest up.
Rise back up by driving through your heels and repeat.
exercises.name: Front Squats With Two Kettlebells
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders by explosively pulling them up and rotating your wrists so the bells rest on your forearms/shoulders
Stand with the kettlebells in the 'rack' position, elbows tucked in, chest and head up - imagine you're a statue showing off perfect posture
Squat down as low as you can by sitting between your legs, actively pushing your knees out as you descend
Keep your torso completely upright with your head and chest up throughout - think about keeping your chest proud
Pause briefly at the bottom, then drive through your heels to stand back up
form_cues: Keep the kettlebells 'glued' to your shoulders in the rack position - they shouldn't bounce or move
Squat between your legs, not back - imagine dropping through a trapdoor
Spread the floor with your feet - actively push your knees out like you're trying to tear the ground apart
Eyes and chest forward and up - pretend you're looking just above the horizon
common_mistakes: Letting the kettlebells pull forward away from the body, which causes forward lean
Not pushing the knees out, allowing them to collapse inward
Rounding the upper back or letting the chest drop forward
injury_prevention_tips: Master the kettlebell rack position first - the bells should feel comfortable and secure on your shoulders
If you feel your wrists bending back uncomfortably, work on wrist and forearm flexibility

instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and stand with a straight torso and the dumbbells on front of your thighs at arms length with the palms of the hand facing your thighs. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the dumbbells to the front with a slight bend on the elbow and the palms of the hands always facing down. Continue to go up until you arms are slightly above parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this portion of the movement and pause for a second at the top.
As you inhale, lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Front Two-Dumbbell Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, dumbbells resting against your front thighs with palms facing your legs
Keep your torso completely still and lift both dumbbells straight up in front of you with a slight bend in your elbows - imagine you're lifting a tray
Raise until your arms are slightly above parallel to the floor, palms always facing down
Squeeze at the top for one second, then lower back down with control
No swinging or rocking - your body should stay rock solid throughout
form_cues: Lead with your knuckles - think about punching the wall in front of you in slow motion
Keep a slight bend in your elbows and lock it there - don't change the angle during the movement
Stop just above shoulder height - imagine there's a shelf there you're placing the weights on
Keep your shoulder blades down and back - don't let your shoulders shrug up toward your ears
common_mistakes: Using momentum by leaning back and swinging the weights up instead of strict lifting
Raising the dumbbells too high (above head level), which reduces tension on the front delts
Bending and straightening the elbows during reps, turning it into a pressing motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - front raises are harder than they look and can strain the shoulder joint
If you need to swing to get the weight up, it's too heavy

instructions: Either standing or seated on a high bench, grasp two stirrup cables that are attached to the high pulleys. Grab with the opposing hand so your arms are crisscrossed about you and your palms are facing forward.

Keeping your chest up and maintaining a slight arch in your lower back, pull the handles down as if you were doing a regular pulldown. The range of motion will be more of an arc. During the movement, rotate your hands so that in the bottom position your palms face each other rather than forward. Return slowly to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: Full Range-Of-Motion Lat Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit on a high bench and grab two stirrup cable handles attached to high pulleys with a crisscross grip (right hand to left cable, left hand to right cable), palms forward
Keep your chest up and maintain a slight arch in your lower back - imagine sticking your chest out proudly
Pull the handles down in an arc motion as you rotate your hands so palms face each other at the bottom
Think about pulling your elbows down and back toward your hips rather than just moving your hands
Control the weight back up slowly to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Pull in an arc, not straight down - imagine drawing a rainbow from above your head to your sides
Rotate your wrists smoothly during the pull so palms end facing each other at the bottom
Lead with your elbows - think about driving your elbows into your back pockets
Keep your chest up and out throughout - imagine someone's pulling your sternum forward with a string
common_mistakes: Pulling straight down instead of in an arcing motion, which reduces the stretch and range of motion
Rounding the upper back and letting the chest collapse forward
Using momentum by rocking the torso instead of keeping it stationary
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a controlled tempo - don't let the weight snap back up at the top
Maintain that slight lower back arch throughout to protect your spine and engage your lats better

instructions: Grasp the pull-up bar with a shoulder width underhand grip.
Now hang with your arms fully extended and stick your chest out and lean back. Tip: You will be leaning back throughout the entire movement. This will be your starting position.

Start pulling yourself towards the bar with your spine arched throughout the movement and your head leaning back as far away from the bar as possible. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: At the upper end of the movement, your hips and legs will be at about a 45-degree angle to the floor.

Keep pulling until your collarbone passes the bar and your lower chest or sternum area touches it. Hold that contraction for a second. Tip: By the time you've completed this portion of the movement; your head will be parallel to the floor.
Slowly start going back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Gironda Sternum Chins
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with an underhand (supinated) grip at shoulder width
Hang with arms fully extended, then lean back and stick your chest out - imagine you're trying to show off your chest to someone in front of you
Pull yourself up while maintaining that lean back position, keeping your head as far from the bar as possible - think about doing a chin-up in reverse lean
Keep pulling until your collarbone passes the bar and your lower chest/sternum actually touches the bar - at this point your head will be nearly parallel to the floor
Lower yourself back down with control while maintaining the lean
form_cues: Lean back throughout the entire movement - imagine someone's pulling your chest forward with a rope
Keep your spine arched like a bow - think about sticking your chest out and ribs forward
At the top, touch your sternum to the bar, not your chin - this is a chest-to-bar movement
Your body should finish at about 45 degrees to the floor with head parallel to the ground
common_mistakes: Pulling straight up like a regular chin-up instead of maintaining the backward lean
Stopping at chin-over-bar instead of continuing until the sternum touches
Letting the head come forward toward the bar instead of keeping it back
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced movement - build up to it with regular chin-ups first
Use slow, controlled negatives if you can't complete full reps yet

instructions: Begin by adjusting the equipment to fit your body. Place your feet against the footplate in between the rollers as you lie facedown. Your knees should be just behind the pad.

Start from the bottom of the movement. Keep your back arched as you begin the movement by flexing the knees. Drive your toes into the foot plate as you do so. Keep your upper body straight, and continue until your body is upright.
Return to the starting position, keeping your descent under control.
exercises.name: Glute Ham Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the machine so your knees are just behind the pad and your feet are secured against the footplate between the rollers
Start facedown at the bottom position with your torso hanging down, keeping your back arched - imagine showing off your lower back
Drive your toes hard into the footplate and squeeze your hamstrings to pull your torso up, keeping your body in a straight line
Continue pulling until your body is completely upright (torso perpendicular to the floor)
Lower yourself back down with control, fighting gravity the entire way
form_cues: Push your toes through the footplate like you're trying to break it - this activates your hamstrings and calves
Keep your body rigid like a plank - no hinging at the hips, move as one solid piece
Lead with your chest on the way up - imagine someone's pulling your sternum toward the ceiling with a string
Squeeze your glutes and hamstrings hard at the top - think about a full-body posterior chain cramp
common_mistakes: Hinging at the hips and using hip extension to cheat the movement up
Rounding the back instead of keeping it arched throughout
Dropping down too fast on the eccentric instead of controlling the descent
injury_prevention_tips: This is one of the hardest hamstring exercises - start with assisted variations (band or partner assist) if needed
The eccentric portion is incredibly challenging - don't be afraid to use your hands to push off the floor to get back up while you build strength

instructions: Kneel on the floor or an exercise mat and bend at the waist with your arms extended in front of you (perpendicular to the torso) in order to get into a kneeling push-up position but with the arms spaced at shoulder width. Your head should be looking forward and the bend of the knees should create a 90-degree angle between the hamstrings and the calves. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, lift up your right leg until the hamstrings are in line with the back while maintaining the 90-degree angle bend. Contract the glutes throughout this movement and hold the contraction at the top for a second. Tip: At the end of the movement the upper leg should be parallel to the floor while the calf should be perpendicular to it.
Go back to the initial position as you inhale and now repeat with the left leg.
Continue to alternate legs until all of the recommended repetitions have been performed.
exercises.name: Glute Kickback
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get on all fours with hands directly under shoulders and knees under hips
Keep your right knee bent at 90 degrees and lift your right leg up behind you until your thigh is parallel to the floor
Squeeze your glutes hard at the top and hold for a second - your calf should be perpendicular to the floor
Lower your leg back to the starting position with control
Complete all reps on one side, then switch to the other leg
form_cues: Think about stamping your footprint on the ceiling behind you as you kick up
Squeeze your glutes like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks at the top
Keep your back flat like a table - imagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
Lead with your heel, not your toes, as you lift your leg
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively instead of isolating the glute contraction
Kicking the leg too high and losing the 90-degree knee bend
Using momentum to swing the leg up rather than controlled glute contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout to prevent excessive lower back arching
Focus on quality contractions over high reps - this is about glute isolation, not leg swinging

instructions: Stand holding a light kettlebell by the horns close to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Squat down between your legs until your hamstrings are on your calves. Keep your chest and head up and your back straight.
At the bottom position, pause and use your elbows to push your knees out. Return to the starting position, and repeat for 10-20 repetitions.
exercises.name: Goblet Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the horns (the handles) close to your chest with elbows pointed down
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and toes slightly turned out
Squat down deep between your legs until your hamstrings touch your calves
At the bottom, use your elbows to gently push your knees out wider
Drive through your heels to stand back up, keeping the kettlebell close to your chest
form_cues: Imagine sitting down between your legs into a deep squat, not back onto a chair
Think about spreading the floor apart with your feet as you drive up
Keep the kettlebell close like you're hugging it to your chest
Use your elbows as crowbars to pry your knees out at the bottom
common_mistakes: Letting the chest collapse forward instead of staying upright
Not squatting deep enough - this exercise requires a full ass-to-grass squat
Allowing the knees to cave inward instead of pushing them out
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your weight on your heels and midfoot - don't let your heels lift off the ground
Start with a light kettlebell to master the deep squat pattern before adding significant weight

instructions: Begin with a bar on a rack at shoulder height. Rack the bar across the rear of your shoulders as you would a power squat, not on top of your shoulders. Keep your back tight, shoulder blades pinched together, and your knees slightly bent. Step back from the rack.
Begin by bending at the hips, moving them back as you bend over to near parallel. Keep your back arched and your cervical spine in proper alignment.
Reverse the motion by extending through the hips with your glutes and hamstrings. Continue until you have returned to the starting position.
exercises.name: Good Morning
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a barbell across your upper back (not on your neck), stand with feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent
Keep your back tight, shoulder blades squeezed together, and chest up
Hinge at your hips, pushing them back as you bend forward until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor
Keep your back arched and neck neutral throughout the movement - don't round your spine
Drive your hips forward to stand back up, squeezing your glutes and hamstrings
form_cues: Think about closing a car door with your butt as you push your hips back
Imagine you're bowing to royalty - hinge at the hips with a proud chest
Keep your shins vertical - pretend your knees are locked in place
Drive your hips through at the top like you're humping the air
common_mistakes: Rounding the back instead of maintaining a proud, arched position
Bending at the knees too much, turning it into a squat rather than a hip hinge
Going too heavy before mastering the hip hinge pattern
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - this exercise can strain the lower back if form breaks down
Keep your core braced hard and your back arched throughout to protect your spine

instructions: Begin with a bar on a rack at about the same height as your stomach. Bend over underneath the bar and rack the bar across the rear of your shoulders as you would a power squat, not on top of your shoulders. At the proper height, you should be near parallel to the floor when bent over. Keep your back tight, shoulder blades pinched together, and your knees slightly bent. Keep your back arched and your cervical spine in proper alignment.
Begin the motion by extending through the hips with your glutes and hamstrings, and you are standing with the weight. Slowly lower the weight back to the pins returning to the starting position.
exercises.name: Good Morning off Pins
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set pins in a rack at stomach height and position yourself bent over with the bar across your upper back
Start in a nearly parallel position with your back tight, shoulder blades pinched, and knees slightly bent
Extend your hips by driving through your glutes and hamstrings to stand up with the weight
Stand tall at the top, then slowly lower back down to the pins in a controlled manner
Pause briefly on the pins before beginning the next rep
form_cues: Think about thrusting your hips forward to stand up, like you're closing a heavy door with your pelvis
Imagine your hamstrings and glutes are rubber bands being stretched at the bottom and snapping back at the top
Keep your chest proud and back arched like you're showing off a superhero logo on your shirt
Drive your heels into the ground to generate power from the floor
common_mistakes: Rounding the back when starting from the bottom position on the pins
Using too much weight and losing the arched back position
Bending the knees excessively rather than emphasizing the hip hinge
injury_prevention_tips: The pins eliminate the eccentric portion - use this to focus on explosive hip drive without back stress
Reset your position on the pins between each rep to ensure perfect form on every lift

instructions: Hang from a chin-up bar using an underhand grip (palms facing you) that is slightly wider than shoulder width.
Now bend your knees at a 90 degree angle so that the calves are parallel to the floor while the thighs remain perpendicular to it. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, pull yourself up while crunching your knees up at the same time until your knees are at chest level. You will stop going up as soon as your nose is at the same level as the bar. Tip: When you get to this point you should also be finishing the crunch at the same time.
Slowly start to inhale as you return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Gorilla Chin/Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width
Bend your knees to 90 degrees so your thighs are vertical and calves are parallel to the floor
Pull yourself up while simultaneously crunching your knees up toward your chest
Stop when your nose reaches bar height and your knees are at chest level
Lower back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows down to your hips while bringing your knees to your elbows
Imagine you're trying to touch your knees to your chin at the top
Squeeze everything - abs, lats, biceps - all at once at the peak
Pretend you're rolling into a tight ball as you pull up and crunch
common_mistakes: Performing the chin-up and crunch separately instead of simultaneously
Swinging or using momentum rather than controlled muscle contraction
Not bringing the knees high enough to get proper ab engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular chin-ups and hanging knee raises separately before combining them
Control the descent - don't drop down quickly as this can strain the shoulders

instructions: Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet together.
Interlock your fingers behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Curl downwards, bringing your elbows to the inside of your thighs. After a brief pause, return to the starting position with your head up and your back straight. Repeat for 10-20 repetitions.
exercises.name: Groin and Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet together in front of you
Interlace your fingers behind your head
Curl forward, bringing your elbows down toward the inside of your thighs
Hold the stretched position briefly, feeling the stretch in your groin and back
Return to an upright position with your back straight and head up, then repeat
form_cues: Think about pulling your chest down toward your feet using your core
Imagine trying to touch your elbows to your inner thighs
Keep your feet pressed together throughout - pretend they're glued
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch - don't force it
common_mistakes: Pulling on the neck with the hands instead of using core muscles to curl forward
Holding your breath instead of breathing normally through the stretch
Bouncing or forcing the stretch instead of easing into it gradually
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your hands lightly interlaced - don't pull on your neck or head
Move slowly and gently - this is a mobility drill, not a strength exercise

instructions: Begin in a pushup position on the floor. This will be your starting position.
Using both legs, jump forward landing with your feet next to your hands. Keep your head up as you do so.
Return to the starting position and immediately repeat the movement, continuing for 10-20 repetitions.
exercises.name: Groiners
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a push-up position with hands on the floor and body in a straight line
Jump both feet forward simultaneously, landing with your feet next to your hands
Keep your head up and hips low as you land in this deep squat position
Jump both feet back to the starting push-up position immediately
Continue jumping in and out for the prescribed number of reps
form_cues: Think about being a frog hopping your feet up to your hands and back out
Imagine there's a bar you need to duck under as you bring your feet forward
Keep your hands planted - pretend they're glued to the floor
Land softly with your feet close to your hands each time
common_mistakes: Landing with feet too far from hands, which reduces the groin stretch
Lifting the hands or shifting weight backward instead of keeping them planted
Moving too slowly - this should be a dynamic, continuous movement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to protect your lower back during the jumping
Land softly on the balls of your feet to avoid jarring your ankles or knees

instructions: Place the back of your torso against the back pad of the machine and hook your shoulders under the shoulder pads provided.
Position your legs in the platform using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Tip: Keep your head up at all times and also maintain the back on the pad at all times.
Place your arms on the side handles of the machine and disengage the safety bars (which on most designs is done by moving the side handles from a facing front position to a diagonal position).

Now straighten your legs without locking the knees. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Begin to slowly lower the unit by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up (back on the pad at all times). Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the unit as you exhale by pushing the floor with mainly with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Hack Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position your back against the pad and shoulders under the shoulder pads of the hack squat machine
Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform with toes slightly turned out
Disengage the safety bars and straighten your legs to hold the weight - this is your starting position
Lower down by bending your knees until your thighs are just below parallel to the platform
Drive through your heels to push the platform away and return to the starting position
form_cues: Think about sitting back and down, keeping your back flat against the pad the entire time
Imagine pushing the platform away from you with your heels, not your toes
Keep your knees tracking in line with your toes - pretend they're on railroad tracks
Press your back into the pad like you're trying to leave an imprint
common_mistakes: Letting the knees travel too far forward past the toes, which stresses the knee joint
Lifting the back off the pad during the descent or ascent
Locking out the knees completely at the top, which removes tension from the quads
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back pressed firmly against the pad throughout to protect your spine
Control the descent - don't drop down quickly as this can jar the knees

exercises.description: Hammer curl performed with dumbbells
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
The palms of the hands should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

Now, while holding your upper arm stationary, exhale and curl the weight forward while contracting the biceps. Continue to raise the weight until the biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbell is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a brief moment as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Focus on keeping the elbow stationary and only moving your forearm.
After the brief pause, inhale and slowly begin the lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Hammer Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing your body (neutral grip)
Keep your upper arms stationary against your sides with elbows slightly in front of your body
Curl one dumbbell up toward your shoulder, keeping the neutral grip throughout
Squeeze your biceps and forearms at the top, then lower back down with control
Alternate arms or do both simultaneously, maintaining the neutral grip
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are pinned to your sides - they don't move at all
Think about bringing your thumbs up to your shoulders, not rotating your wrists
Keep the dumbbells in a handshake position throughout - like you're hammering a nail
Squeeze your biceps and forearms at the top like you're crushing golf balls in your armpits
common_mistakes: Rotating the wrists during the curl instead of maintaining the neutral grip
Swinging the weights up using momentum from the back or shoulders
Letting the elbows drift backward instead of keeping them slightly forward
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists straight and neutral - don't let them bend or twist under the load
Control both the lifting and lowering phases to protect your biceps tendons

instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.
By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbells up, clean the dumbbells one arm at a time so that you can hold them at shoulder width.

Once at shoulder width, keep the palms of your hands with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Keep your elbows flared out with the upper arms in line with the shoulders (perpendicular to the torso) and the elbows bent creating a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm. This will be your starting position.
Now bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe in. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the dumbbells back in your thighs and then on the floor. This is the safest manner to dispose of the dumbbells.
exercises.name: Hammer Grip Incline DB Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with dumbbells resting on your thighs
Use your thighs to help kick the dumbbells up to shoulder level with palms facing each other
Position dumbbells at shoulder width with elbows bent 90 degrees and flared out to the sides
Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, keeping the neutral grip
Lower the weights slowly to the starting position, taking twice as long to descend as to press up
form_cues: Think about pressing the dumbbells up and slightly together, like you're hugging a tree
Imagine driving the weights through the ceiling at an angle
Keep your shoulder blades squeezed back and down - pretend you're pinching a pencil between them
Lower like you're resisting gravity with every muscle fiber - slow and controlled
common_mistakes: Pressing the dumbbells straight up instead of at a slight angle toward each other
Letting the dumbbells rotate inward or outward instead of maintaining the neutral grip
Dropping the weights quickly on the eccentric instead of controlling the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blades retracted and pressed into the bench throughout to protect your shoulders
Use your thighs to help get the dumbbells into position - don't try to muscle them up from the floor

instructions: In a seated position, extend your legs over a foam roll so that it is position on the back of the upper legs. Place your hands to the side or behind you to help support your weight. This will be your starting position.
Using your hands, lift your hips off of the floor and shift your weight on the foam roll to one leg. Relax the hamstrings of the leg you are stretching.
Roll over the foam from below the hip to above the back of the knee, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat for the other leg.
exercises.name: Hamstring-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor and extend your legs straight out with a foam roller positioned under the back of your upper thighs
Place your hands on the floor beside or slightly behind you to support your weight and lift your hips off the ground
Shift your weight onto one leg to focus pressure on that hamstring - keep that leg relaxed and heavy
Slowly roll from just below your hip down to just above the back of your knee, pausing 10-30 seconds on any tight or tender spots
Switch to the other leg and repeat the process
form_cues: Let your hamstring be dead weight on the roller - don't tense up or you'll miss the tight spots
Use your hands to control how much pressure you apply - lift your hips higher to reduce pressure, lower them to increase it
Roll slowly like a steamroller - about one inch per second so you don't miss problem areas
When you find a tender spot, stop and breathe deeply - imagine breathing into that specific area to help it release
common_mistakes: Rolling too fast, which doesn't give tissues time to respond and release
Tensing the hamstring muscle instead of letting it relax completely into the roller
Rolling directly over the back of the knee joint, which can be uncomfortable and isn't necessary
injury_prevention_tips: If you find an extremely painful spot, ease off the pressure - it should be uncomfortable but tolerable
Avoid rolling if you have acute hamstring strains or tears - wait until they're healed

instructions: Lie on your back with one leg extended above you, with the hip at ninety degrees. Keep the other leg flat on the floor.
Loop a belt, band, or rope over the ball of your foot. This will be your starting position.
Pull on the belt to create tension in the calves and hamstrings. Hold this stretch for 10-30 seconds, and repeat with the other leg.
exercises.name: Hamstring Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with one leg straight on the floor and the other raised straight up toward the ceiling, hip at 90 degrees
Loop a belt, resistance band, or towel around the ball of your raised foot (not the arch or toes)
Hold the ends of the belt with both hands and gently pull to create tension down the back of your leg
Keep the raised leg as straight as possible and hold the stretch for 10-30 seconds, breathing deeply
Switch legs and repeat on the other side
form_cues: Keep your lower back flat on the floor - imagine pressing your spine into the ground
Point your toes slightly toward your shin to intensify the stretch in your calf and hamstring
Pull with your arms, not by tensing your hip flexors - let the belt do the work
The leg on the floor should stay completely relaxed and flat - don't let it bend or lift
common_mistakes: Bending the knee of the raised leg, which reduces the hamstring stretch significantly
Arching the lower back off the floor, which can create tension in the spine
Pulling too aggressively and bouncing, which can trigger the stretch reflex and tighten the muscle
injury_prevention_tips: Stretch to the point of mild tension, not pain - you should feel a pulling sensation but not sharp discomfort
Keep your movements smooth and controlled - never bounce or jerk into a deeper stretch

instructions: With your back to the wall bend at the waist and place both hands on the floor at shoulder width.

Kick yourself up against the wall with your arms straight. Your body should be upside down with the arms and legs fully extended. Keep your whole body as straight as possible. Tip: If doing this for the first time, have a spotter help you. Also, make sure that you keep facing the wall with your head, rather than looking down.
Slowly lower yourself to the ground as you inhale until your head almost touches the floor. Tip: It is of utmost importance that you come down slow in order to avoid head injury.
Push yourself back up slowly as you exhale until your elbows are nearly locked.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Handstand Push-Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Face away from a wall, bend at the waist and place both hands flat on the floor at shoulder width
Kick your feet up against the wall until you're in a handstand position with arms straight and body vertical - have a spotter help if this is your first time
Keep your body completely straight from hands to heels, head facing the wall (not looking down) - imagine being a plank standing on end
Slowly lower yourself by bending your elbows until your head nearly touches the floor - this should take at least 3-4 seconds
Press back up slowly until your arms are nearly locked, then repeat
form_cues: Keep your core tight like you're bracing for a punch - this prevents your back from arching
Lower yourself in a straight line - imagine sliding down between two panes of glass
Look at the wall, not down - this keeps your neck neutral and spine aligned
Press through your entire palm, not just your fingertips - think about pushing the floor away
common_mistakes: Descending too quickly and crashing down, which risks head and neck injury
Arching the lower back and letting the hips sag forward instead of staying in a straight line
Looking down at the floor instead of at the wall, which hyperextends the neck
injury_prevention_tips: Build up to this with pike push-ups and wall walks first - this is an advanced movement requiring significant strength
Always control the descent - use a spotter or stop short of the floor if you can't slow yourself down

instructions: Begin with a bar on a rack at about the same height as your stomach. Suspend the bar using chains or suspension straps.

Bend over underneath the bar and rack the bar across the rear of your shoulders as you would a power squat, not on top of your traps. At the proper height, you should be near parallel to the floor when bent over. Keep your back tight, shoulder blades pinched together, and your knees slightly bent. Keep your back arched and your cervical spine in proper alignment.
Begin the motion by extending through the hips with your glutes and hamstrings, and you are standing with the weight.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position, where it is supported by the chains.
exercises.name: Hanging Bar Good Morning
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell suspended by chains or straps at about stomach height on a rack
Bend over and position the bar across the back of your shoulders (like a back squat, not on your traps), so you're nearly parallel to the floor
Keep your knees slightly bent, back arched, chest up, and shoulder blades squeezed together - imagine showing off your chest even though you're bent over
Drive through your hips by squeezing your glutes and hamstrings to stand up straight with the bar
Lower back down slowly to the starting parallel position where the chains catch the weight, then repeat
form_cues: Lead with your hips, not your chest - think about humping the air as you drive up
Keep your back locked in an arch the entire time - imagine a broomstick taped to your spine
Push your hips back as you descend like you're trying to close a car door with your butt
Squeeze your glutes hard at the top - think about cracking a walnut between your cheeks
common_mistakes: Rounding the back instead of maintaining a tight arch, which puts dangerous stress on the spine
Bending and straightening the knees too much, turning it into a squat instead of a hip hinge
Looking up or down instead of maintaining a neutral neck position aligned with the spine
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light to master the hip hinge pattern - this exercise can strain the lower back if done incorrectly
The chains should catch the bar at the bottom so you're not supporting the full weight in the weakest position

instructions: Hang from a chin-up bar with both arms extended at arms length in top of you using either a wide grip or a medium grip. The legs should be straight down with the pelvis rolled slightly backwards. This will be your starting position.
Raise your legs until the torso makes a 90-degree angle with the legs. Exhale as you perform this movement and hold the contraction for a second or so.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Hanging Leg Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar with arms fully extended, using a medium to wide grip
Start with legs straight down and your pelvis rolled slightly backward - imagine tucking your tailbone under slightly
Keeping your legs as straight as possible, raise them up in front of you until they form a 90-degree angle with your torso
Hold the top position for one second while squeezing your abs hard, then lower slowly with control
Avoid any swinging or momentum - move with pure abdominal strength
form_cues: Tilt your pelvis backward first before raising your legs - think about starting the movement from your lower abs, not your hip flexors
Keep your legs glued together like they're in a cast - no separation or bending
Stop at 90 degrees - imagine your legs are reaching for a bar directly in front of you at hip height
Lower slowly like you're fighting the weight of sandbags attached to your feet
common_mistakes: Swinging and using momentum instead of controlled ab contraction
Bending the knees to make the movement easier, which reduces ab engagement
Raising the legs too high (past 90 degrees) which shifts work away from the abs to the hip flexors
injury_prevention_tips: If you can't do these with straight legs, start with bent knee raises and progress gradually
Use lifting straps if your grip gives out before your abs - don't let grip be the limiting factor

instructions: Hang from a chin-up bar with your legs and feet together using an overhand grip (palms facing away from you) that is slightly wider than shoulder width. Tip: You may use wrist wraps in order to facilitate holding on to the bar.

Now bend your knees at a 90 degree angle and bring the upper legs forward so that the calves are perpendicular to the floor while the thighs remain parallel to it. This will be your starting position.
Pull your legs up as you exhale until you almost touch your shins with the bar above you. Tip: Try to straighten your legs as much as possible while at the top.
Lower your legs as slowly as possible until you reach the starting position. Tip: Avoid swinging and using momentum at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Hanging Pike
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width, legs and feet together
Bend your knees to 90 degrees and bring your upper legs forward so your thighs are parallel to the floor and calves perpendicular - this is your starting 'L' position
Pull your legs up toward the bar while trying to straighten them, aiming to bring your shins as close to the bar as possible
Hold the top position briefly, then lower your legs back down slowly to the starting 'L' position with full control
Avoid swinging - every rep should be smooth and deliberate
form_cues: Think about doing a reverse crunch while hanging - curl your pelvis up toward your ribs
Straighten your legs as much as possible at the top - imagine trying to kick the ceiling
Keep your shoulders active and engaged - don't let yourself hang completely dead
Lower with a 3-second count - fight gravity all the way down
common_mistakes: Using momentum and swinging wildly instead of controlled movement
Not attempting to straighten the legs at the top, keeping them bent throughout
Letting the legs drop below the starting 'L' position, which reduces constant tension on the abs
injury_prevention_tips: Use wrist wraps or lifting straps if your grip fails before your abs fatigue
If the starting position is too difficult, master regular hanging knee raises first

instructions: Stand between a couple of high pulleys and grab a handle in each arm. Position your upper arms in a way that they are parallel to the floor with the palms of your hands facing you. This will be your starting position.

Curl the handles towards you until they are next to your ears. Make sure that as you do so you flex your biceps and exhale. The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Hold for a second in the contracted position as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly bring back the arms to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: High Cable Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand centered between two high cable pulleys and grab a handle in each hand
Step forward slightly and position your upper arms parallel to the floor, extended out to your sides like a 'T', with palms facing you
Curl both handles toward your ears by bending only at the elbows - think about doing a double biceps pose
Squeeze hard at the top when the handles are next to your ears, then slowly extend your arms back to the starting position
Keep your upper arms completely locked in place - only your forearms should move
form_cues: Finish like a double biceps flex pose - really squeeze and show off your biceps at the top
Keep your upper arms glued parallel to the floor - imagine them resting on invisible shelves
Curl in a semicircular arc toward your ears, not straight forward
Don't let your elbows drift forward or back - they should stay in the same spot throughout
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drop down as you curl instead of keeping them locked at shoulder height
Using your shoulders and pulling with your whole arm instead of isolating the biceps
Leaning back or forward with your torso to generate momentum
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the form - this position creates significant tension on the biceps
Keep your shoulders stable and packed - don't let them roll forward or shrug up

instructions: Position yourself on your hands and knees on the ground. Maintaining good posture, raise one bent knee off of the ground. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the knee in a bent position, rotate the femur in an arc, attempting to make a big circle with your knee.
Perform this slowly for a number of repetitions, and repeat on the other side.
exercises.name: Hip Circles (prone)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get on your hands and knees in a tabletop position with your back flat and core engaged
Lift one bent knee off the ground while maintaining good posture and a neutral spine
Keeping that knee bent at 90 degrees, rotate your entire thigh in a big circular motion - imagine drawing a large circle with your knee
Move slowly and deliberately, making the biggest circles your hip flexibility allows
Complete all reps in one direction, then switch directions, then repeat on the other leg
form_cues: Make the circle as big as possible - imagine you're trying to draw on a giant canvas with your knee
Keep your planted knee and hands completely stable - don't rock or shift your weight
Your back should stay flat like a table throughout - imagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
Move smoothly like you're stirring a giant pot with your knee
common_mistakes: Making tiny circles instead of using full hip range of motion
Allowing the torso to rock side to side or rotate with the leg movement
Straightening or changing the knee angle during the circles
injury_prevention_tips: Start with smaller circles and gradually increase the size as you warm up
If you feel pinching in the front of your hip, reduce the circle size or check your form

instructions: Secure one end of the band to the lower portion of a post and attach the other to one ankle.
Facing the attachment point of the band, hold on to the column to stabilize yourself.
Keeping your head and your chest up, move the resisted leg back as far as you can while keeping the knee straight.
Return the leg to the starting position.
exercises.name: Hip Extension with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach one end of a resistance band to a low anchor point (like a power rack) and the other end around one ankle
Face the anchor point and hold onto it or the rack for stability
Stand tall with chest up and core braced - imagine standing at attention
Keeping your knee completely straight, drive your banded leg straight back behind you as far as you can
Squeeze your glute hard at the end position, then return your leg forward with control to the starting position
form_cues: Lead with your heel going back - think about stamping your heel through a wall behind you
Squeeze your glute hard like you're trying to crush a walnut in your butt cheek
Keep your planted leg slightly bent and stable - imagine it's rooted into the ground
Don't lean forward with your chest - keep your torso upright throughout
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively to get more range instead of using pure hip extension
Bending the working knee during the movement
Leaning the torso forward to swing the leg back instead of isolating the glute
injury_prevention_tips: Stop the leg extension when you feel your lower back starting to arch - that's your end range
Keep your core braced throughout to protect your spine

instructions: Secure one end of the band to the lower portion of a post and attach the other to one ankle.
Face away from the attachment point of the band.
Keeping your head and your chest up, raise your knee up to 90 degrees and pause.
Return the leg to the starting position.
exercises.name: Hip Flexion with Band
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach one end of a resistance band to a low anchor and the other end around one ankle
Face away from the anchor point so the band is pulling your leg backward
Stand tall with chest up and core engaged
Drive your banded knee straight up in front of you to 90 degrees (thigh parallel to floor) and pause at the top
Lower your leg back down with control to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Drive your knee up like you're marching - think about bringing your knee to your chest
Keep your chest proud and upright - don't lean back to help lift the leg
The standing leg should stay slightly bent and stable - imagine it's a tree trunk
Pause and squeeze at the top for a full second - think about holding a coin between your thigh and abs
common_mistakes: Leaning back with the torso to help lift the leg instead of using hip flexor strength
Not raising the knee high enough - should reach 90 degrees or thigh parallel to floor
Letting the standing leg lock out and become rigid, which reduces stability
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light band resistance - hip flexors are smaller muscles that fatigue quickly
Keep your movements controlled - don't let the band snap your leg back down

instructions: After choosing a suitable band, lay down in the middle of the rack, after securing the band on either side of you. If your rack doesn't have pegs, the band can be secured using heavy dumbbells or similar objects, just ensure they won't move.
Adjust your position so that the band is directly over your hips. Bend your knees and place your feet flat on the floor. Your hands can be on the floor or holding the band in position.
Keeping your shoulders on the ground, drive through your heels to raise your hips, pushing into the band as high as you can.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Hip Lift with Band
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure a resistance band on both sides of a rack and lie down with the band positioned directly over your hips
Bend your knees with feet flat on the floor, hands either on the floor or holding the band in place
Keep your shoulders planted on the ground and drive through your heels to lift your hips up into the band
Push as high as possible, squeezing your glutes hard at the top
Pause for a moment at peak contraction, then lower back to the starting position
form_cues: Think about pushing your hips through the band toward the ceiling as high as possible
Squeeze your glutes at the top like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Imagine stamping your heels through the floor to generate power
Keep your core braced tight - pretend someone's about to drop something on your stomach
common_mistakes: Hyperextending the lower back at the top instead of driving through with the glutes
Pushing through the toes instead of the heels, which reduces glute activation
Not pausing at the top to maximize the glute contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your ribs down and core engaged to prevent excessive lower back arching
Start with lighter band resistance and progress gradually to avoid straining the hip flexors

instructions: Seat yourself on the floor.
Straddle an exercise ball between both legs and lower your hips down toward the floor.

Hug your arms around the ball to support your body. Adjust your legs so that your feet are flat on the floor and your knees line up over your ankles. Keep a good grip on the ball so it doesn't roll away from you and send you back onto your buttocks.
exercises.name: Hug A Ball
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor and position an exercise ball between your legs
Straddle the ball and lower your hips down toward the floor
