Wrap your arms around the ball and lean forward into it for support
Adjust your feet so they're flat on the floor with knees aligned over ankles
Hold this position for the desired duration while breathing deeply
form_cues: Think about melting into the ball, letting your body weight create the stretch
Imagine the ball is giving you a gentle hug back as you relax into it
Keep your grip firm on the ball so it doesn't roll away
Breathe deeply into your lower back and hips, feeling them open up
common_mistakes: Tensing up instead of relaxing into the stretch
Placing feet too close or too far, which affects stability
Gripping the ball too loosely, which can cause it to roll and you to fall backward
injury_prevention_tips: Make sure the ball is properly inflated and stable before beginning
Move slowly into the position - don't drop suddenly onto the ball

instructions: Lie down on your back and pull both knees up to your chest.
Hold your arms under the knees, not over (that would put to much pressure on your knee joints).
Slowly pull the knees toward your shoulders. This also stretches your buttocks muscles.
exercises.name: Hug Knees To Chest
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back on the floor or a mat
Bend both knees and pull them up toward your chest
Wrap your arms under your knees (not over) and clasp your hands or forearms
Gently pull your knees toward your shoulders, feeling the stretch in your lower back and glutes
Hold for 20-30 seconds while breathing normally
form_cues: Think about creating space in your lower back as you pull your knees in
Imagine making yourself into a tight ball, like you're trying to become as small as possible
Keep your head and shoulders relaxed on the floor - don't strain your neck
Breathe deeply into your lower back, feeling it stretch with each breath
common_mistakes: Gripping over the knees instead of under, which puts pressure on the knee joints
Pulling too aggressively, which can cause discomfort rather than a gentle stretch
Lifting the head and straining the neck instead of keeping it relaxed on the floor
injury_prevention_tips: Pull gently and progressively - don't yank your knees toward your chest
If you have knee issues, hold behind your thighs instead of at the knees

instructions: Lie face down on a hyperextension bench, tucking your ankles securely under the footpads.
Adjust the upper pad if possible so your upper thighs lie flat across the wide pad, leaving enough room for you to bend at the waist without any restriction.

With your body straight, cross your arms in front of you (my preference) or behind your head. This will be your starting position. Tip: You can also hold a weight plate for extra resistance in front of you under your crossed arms.

Start bending forward slowly at the waist as far as you can while keeping your back flat. Inhale as you perform this movement. Keep moving forward until you feel a nice stretch on the hamstrings and you can no longer keep going without a rounding of the back. Tip: Never round the back as you perform this exercise. Also, some people can go farther than others. The key thing is that you go as far as your body allows you to without rounding the back.

Slowly raise your torso back to the initial position as you inhale. Tip: Avoid the temptation to arch your back past a straight line. Also, do not swing the torso at any time in order to protect the back from injury.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Hyperextensions (Back Extensions)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself face-down on a hyperextension bench with ankles secured under the footpads
Adjust so your upper thighs lie flat on the pad, with your hips free to bend at the waist
Cross your arms in front of your chest or behind your head to start
Bend forward slowly at the waist as far as you can while keeping your back flat, until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings
Raise your torso back to the starting position until your body forms a straight line - don't hyperextend past straight
form_cues: Think about hinging at the hips like a seesaw, keeping your back flat the entire time
Imagine you're trying to touch your forehead to the floor while maintaining a proud chest
Squeeze your glutes and hamstrings to pull yourself back up, not your lower back
Keep your back flat like a tabletop - never let it round or arch excessively
common_mistakes: Rounding the back during the descent, which can strain the spine
Hyperextending past a straight line at the top, which stresses the lower back
Using momentum to swing up and down instead of controlled movement
injury_prevention_tips: Never round your back - keep it flat or slightly arched throughout the entire movement
Stop at a straight body position at the top - don't arch backward past neutral

instructions: With someone holding down your legs, slide yourself down to the edge a flat bench until your hips hang off the end of the bench. Tip: Your entire upper body should be hanging down towards the floor. Also, you will be in the same position as if you were on a hyperextension bench but the range of motion will be shorter due to the height of the flat bench vs. that of the hyperextension bench.

With your body straight, cross your arms in front of you (my preference) or behind your head. This will be your starting position. Tip: You can also hold a weight plate for extra resistance in front of you under your crossed arms.

Start bending forward slowly at the waist as far as you can while keeping your back flat. Inhale as you perform this movement. Keep moving forward until you almost touch the floor or you feel a nice stretch on the hamstrings (whichever comes first). Tip: Never round the back as you perform this exercise.

Slowly raise your torso back to the initial position as you exhale. Tip: Avoid the temptation to arch your back past a straight line. Also, do not swing the torso at any time in order to protect the back from injury.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Hyperextensions With No Hyperextension Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on a flat bench with your hips at the edge and upper body hanging off
Have a partner hold your legs down for stability, with your entire upper body suspended
Cross your arms in front of your chest or behind your head
Bend forward at the waist as far as you comfortably can while keeping your back flat
Raise your torso back to a straight position by squeezing your glutes and hamstrings, then repeat
form_cues: Think about maintaining a flat back like you're balancing a broomstick along your spine
Imagine your glutes and hamstrings are rubber bands pulling you back to the starting position
Keep your neck neutral - don't crane your head up or let it drop down
Focus on the stretch in your hamstrings at the bottom, not just the lower back
common_mistakes: Rounding the back as you lower down, which defeats the purpose and risks injury
Arching too far back at the top instead of stopping at a straight body line
Moving too quickly or using swinging momentum
injury_prevention_tips: Make sure your partner has a secure grip on your legs before starting
Keep your back flat at all times - never allow it to round under load

instructions: Loop a belt, rope, or band around one of your feet, and swing that leg across your body to the opposite side, keeping the leg extended as you lay on the ground. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your foot off of the floor, pull on the belt, using the tension to pull the toes up. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and repeat on the other side.
exercises.name: IT Band and Glute Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back and loop a belt, band, or rope around one foot
Swing that leg across your body to the opposite side, keeping the leg extended
Keep your foot off the floor, holding the belt with your hands
Pull on the belt to create tension, pulling your toes up toward your shin
Hold the stretch for 10-20 seconds, then switch to the other side
form_cues: Think about pulling your toes toward your shin while keeping your leg straight
Imagine trying to touch the floor with your foot on the opposite side of your body
Keep your shoulders flat on the ground - don't let them lift up
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch, letting gravity help
common_mistakes: Bending the knee of the stretching leg instead of keeping it extended
Letting the shoulders lift off the ground, which reduces the effectiveness
Pulling too aggressively instead of gradually easing into the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly into the stretch position - don't force your leg across your body
If you feel sharp pain in your hip or knee, reduce the range of motion

instructions: Lay on your side, with the bottom leg placed onto a foam roller between the hip and the knee. The other leg can be crossed in front of you.
Place as much of your weight as is tolerable onto your bottom leg; there is no need to keep your bottom leg in contact with the ground. Be sure to relax the muscles of the leg you are stretching.
Roll your leg over the foam from you hip to your knee, pausing for 10-30 seconds at points of tension. Repeat with the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Iliotibial Tract-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with a foam roller positioned between your hip and knee on your bottom leg
Cross your top leg in front of you and place that foot flat on the floor for support
Place as much body weight as tolerable onto the bottom leg on the roller
Roll slowly from your hip down to your knee, pausing on any tender or tight spots
Hold on tight areas for 10-30 seconds before continuing, then switch legs
form_cues: Think about relaxing the muscles you're rolling - tension defeats the purpose
Imagine you're ironing out knots in the side of your leg with the roller
Breathe deeply when you hit a tender spot - don't hold your breath
Use your top leg and arms to control how much pressure you apply
common_mistakes: Rolling too quickly without spending time on tight or tender areas
Tensing the muscles of the leg being rolled instead of relaxing them
Rolling over the hip bone or knee joint instead of staying on soft tissue
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light pressure and gradually increase as your tissue adapts
Avoid rolling directly over your hip bone or the outside of your knee - focus on the IT band between them

instructions: Stand with your feet close together. Keeping your legs straight, stretch down and put your hands on the floor directly in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Begin by walking your hands forward slowly, alternating your left and your right. As you do so, bend only at the hip, keeping your legs straight.
Keep going until your body is parallel to the ground in a pushup position.
Now, keep your hands in place and slowly take short steps with your feet, moving only a few inches at a time.
Continue walking until your feet are by hour hands, keeping your legs straight as you do so.
exercises.name: Inchworm
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet close together and bend forward to place your hands flat on the floor in front of you, keeping legs straight
Walk your hands forward, alternating left and right, while keeping your legs straight and hips high
Continue walking your hands out until you're in a push-up position with your body parallel to the ground
Now keep your hands planted and take tiny steps with your feet, walking them toward your hands
Walk your feet all the way up to your hands with legs straight, then repeat the sequence
form_cues: Think about being an inchworm moving across the ground in waves
Imagine your hips are a mountain peak that stays high as you walk your hands out
Keep your legs locked straight throughout - pretend you have braces on your knees
Take small steps with your feet, like you're tiptoeing forward
common_mistakes: Bending the knees during the hand-walking or foot-walking phases
Letting the hips sag down when in the push-up position
Taking large steps instead of small, controlled movements
injury_prevention_tips: If your hamstrings are tight, don't force your hands all the way to the floor - go as far as comfortable
Keep your core engaged when in the plank position to protect your lower back

instructions: Hold a barbell with an overhand grip (palms down) that is a little closer together than shoulder width.
Lie back on an incline bench set at any angle between 45-75-degrees.
Bring the bar overhead with your arms extended and elbows in. The arms should be in line with the torso above the head. This will be your starting position.

Now lower the bar in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Inhale as you perform this movement. Tip: Keep your upper arms stationary and close to your head at all times. Only the forearms should move.
Return to the starting position as you breathe out and you contract the triceps. Hold the contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Incline Barbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an incline bench set between 45-75 degrees, holding a barbell with a narrow overhand grip
Extend your arms overhead so the bar is above your head with arms in line with your torso
Keep your upper arms stationary and lower the bar in an arc behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps
Pause briefly at the bottom stretch, then extend your elbows to press the bar back to the starting position
Squeeze your triceps hard at the top and hold for a second
form_cues: Think about your upper arms being cemented in place - only your forearms move
Imagine lowering the bar like you're trying to touch it to the bench behind your head
Keep your elbows pointing straight ahead, not flaring out to the sides
Pretend you're closing and opening a hinge at your elbows with control
common_mistakes: Allowing the upper arms to move or drop down instead of keeping them stationary overhead
Flaring the elbows out wide instead of keeping them tight and pointed forward
Using too much weight and cutting the range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your elbows in and upper arms stable to protect the elbow joints from excessive stress
Start light - this stretched position puts significant tension on the triceps and elbows

instructions: Grab a dumbbell in each hand and lie face down on an incline bench that is set to an incline that is approximately 30 degrees.
Let the arms hang to your sides fully extended as they point to the floor.
Turn the wrists until your hands have a pronated (palms down) grip.
Now flare the elbows out. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, start to pull the dumbbells up as if you are doing a reverse bench press. You will do this by bending at the elbows and bringing the upper arms up as you let the forearms hang. Continue this motion until the upper arms are at the same level as your back. Tip: The elbows will come out to the side and your upper arms and torso should make the letter T at the top of the movement. Hold the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly go back down to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Incline Bench Pull
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on an incline bench set to about 30 degrees, holding dumbbells with arms hanging straight down
Turn your wrists so your palms face down (pronated grip) and flare your elbows out to the sides
Pull the dumbbells up by bending your elbows and bringing your upper arms up to back level
At the top, your upper arms and torso should form a 'T' shape - hold this for a second
Lower the dumbbells slowly back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows up to the ceiling, not pulling with your hands
Imagine trying to squeeze a pencil between your shoulder blades at the top
Keep your chest pressed into the bench throughout - don't arch away from it
Pretend you're trying to touch your elbows to the ceiling above you
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arms and biceps instead of initiating the movement with the back muscles
Not bringing the elbows high enough - they should reach back level
Using momentum or swinging the weights instead of controlled pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your chest firmly pressed into the bench to stabilize your torso and protect your lower back
Control the negative portion - don't let the weights drop quickly as this can strain the shoulders

instructions: Adjust the weight to an appropriate amount and be seated, grasping the handles. Your upper arms should be about 45 degrees to the body, with your head and chest up. The elbows should be bent to about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending through the elbow, pressing the handles together straight in front of you. Keep your shoulder blades retracted as you execute the movement.
After pausing at full extension, return to the starting position, keeping tension on the cables.
exercises.name: Incline Cable Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on an incline bench positioned between cable pulleys, grasping the handles with your upper arms at about 45 degrees to your body
Start with your elbows bent to 90 degrees, head and chest up, shoulder blades squeezed together
Press the handles straight forward by extending your elbows, bringing your hands together in front of you
Pause briefly at full extension while keeping your shoulder blades retracted
Return to the starting position slowly, maintaining constant tension on the cables
form_cues: Keep your shoulder blades pinned back throughout - imagine crushing a pencil between them
Press in a slight upward arc like you're pushing something onto a high shelf
Touch your hands together at the end like you're clapping in front of you
Keep your back firmly against the bench - don't let it arch or peel off
common_mistakes: Letting the shoulder blades protract forward at the end of the press instead of staying retracted
Pressing at the wrong angle - either too high or too low instead of straight forward and slightly up
Allowing the cables to pull the hands back too quickly on the return instead of controlling the negative
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists straight and neutral - don't let them bend backward under the load
Start light and focus on the squeeze at full extension before adding weight

instructions: To get yourself into the starting position, set the pulleys at the floor level (lowest level possible on the machine that is below your torso).
Place an incline bench (set at 45 degrees) in between the pulleys, select a weight on each one and grab a pulley on each hand.
With a handle on each hand, lie on the incline bench and bring your hands together at arms length in front of your face. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend of your elbows (in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon), lower your arms out at both sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms should remain stationary. The movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.

Return your arms back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and exhale. Hold the contracted position for a second. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Incline Cable Flye
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable pulleys at floor level and place an incline bench (45 degrees) between them
Grab both handles and lie back on the bench, bringing your hands together at arm's length above your face with a slight elbow bend
Lower your arms out to both sides in a wide arc, keeping the elbow angle fixed until you feel a deep stretch across your chest
Bring your arms back together using the same arc, squeezing your chest muscles hard at the top
Pause for a second in the contracted position with hands together, then repeat
form_cues: Keep the same elbow bend throughout - imagine your arms are wrapped around a big barrel and you're trying to hug it
Lower in a wide arc like you're opening your arms to give someone a hug
Lead with your elbows going down and your pinkies going up - think about showing your inner elbows to the ceiling
Squeeze your chest at the top like you're trying to crush a can between your pecs
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows more on the way down, turning it into a pressing movement
Lowering too deep beyond a comfortable chest stretch, which can stress the shoulder
Using momentum and bouncing at the bottom instead of controlled movement
injury_prevention_tips: Stop the descent when you feel a moderate stretch - never push into painful ranges
Use lighter weight than you think - this is a stretch exercise, not a strength movement

instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.
By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbells up, clean the dumbbells one arm at a time so that you can hold them at shoulder width.

Once at shoulder width, keep the palms of your hands with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Keep your elbows flared out with the upper arms in line with the shoulders (perpendicular to the torso) and the elbows bent creating a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm. This will be your starting position.
Now bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe in. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the dumbbells back in your thighs and then on the floor. This is the safest manner to dispose of the dumbbells.
exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Bench With Palms Facing In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on an incline bench with dumbbells on your thighs, then use your legs to help kick them up to shoulder width
Hold the dumbbells with palms facing each other (neutral grip), elbows flared out perpendicular to your torso at 90 degrees
Lower the dumbbells slowly to your sides with full control while breathing in
Press the dumbbells back up using your chest, locking your arms at the top and holding for one second
Take twice as long to lower as to lift - control is key
form_cues: Keep your palms facing each other the entire time - imagine holding two hammers
Elbows stay wide and perpendicular to your body - think about keeping them in line with your shoulders
Lower slowly like you're resisting the weight - count 3 seconds down, 1.5 seconds up
Drive through your chest, not your arms - imagine pushing the floor away through the dumbbells
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drift forward instead of keeping them perpendicular to the torso
Lowering too fast and losing control of the dumbbells
Rotating the wrists during the movement instead of maintaining the neutral grip
injury_prevention_tips: Use your thighs to safely get the dumbbells into starting position - don't try to lift them directly from the floor
Return the dumbbells to your thighs first before placing them on the floor at the end

instructions: Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand held at arms length. Keep your elbows close to your torso and rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand hanging at arm's length, elbows close to your torso
Rotate your wrists so your palms face forward - this is your starting position
Curl the weights forward by flexing only at the elbows while keeping your upper arms completely still
Continue until the dumbbells reach shoulder level and your biceps are fully contracted, then pause
Lower the dumbbells slowly back to the starting position
form_cues: Pin your elbows to your sides like they're glued there - imagine your upper arms are locked in place
Let your arms hang straight down with a full stretch at the bottom - feel your biceps elongate
Curl with control like you're showing off your biceps - squeeze hard at the top
Keep your back pressed firmly against the bench throughout - no rocking or leaning
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drift forward as you curl, which reduces bicep tension
Swinging the weights up using momentum from the torso instead of pure bicep strength
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom, which limits the stretch and range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than you would for standing curls - the incline provides more stretch and is harder
If you feel shoulder discomfort at the bottom, reduce the incline angle slightly

instructions: Hold a dumbbell on each hand and lie on an incline bench that is set to an incline angle of no more than 30 degrees.
Extend your arms above you with a slight bend at the elbows.
Now rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing you. Tip: The pinky fingers should be next to each other. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, start to slowly lower the arms to the side while keeping the arms extended and while rotating the wrists until the palms of the hand are facing each other. Tip: At the end of the movement the arms will be by your side with the palms facing the ceiling.

As you exhale start to bring the dumbbells back up to the starting position by reversing the motion and rotating the hands so that the pinky fingers are next to each other again. Tip: Keep in mind that the movement will only happen at the shoulder joint and at the wrist. There is no motion that happens at the elbow joint.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on an incline bench (no more than 30 degrees) with dumbbells extended above you, elbows slightly bent
Rotate your wrists so your palms face you with pinky fingers next to each other
Lower your arms out to the sides in an arc while rotating your wrists until palms face each other, ending with palms facing the ceiling
Bring the dumbbells back up by reversing the motion, rotating your hands so pinkies are together again at the top
Squeeze your chest at the top and repeat
form_cues: Keep the elbow bend constant throughout - imagine your arms are in a cast that can only move at the shoulder
Lower in a wide arc like you're spreading your wings - think about opening up your chest
Rotate smoothly as you move - at the bottom, your palms should face up like you're holding two plates
Lead with your pinkies coming back up - think about trying to touch them together above your chest
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows more as you lower the weight, turning it into a press
Going too deep and overstretching the shoulders beyond a comfortable range
Forgetting to rotate the wrists, which changes the muscle emphasis
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the bench at 30 degrees or less - steeper inclines can stress the shoulders
Use lighter weights than you think - this is a stretch movement focused on feel, not heavy loading

instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand and lie on an incline bench that is set to an incline angle of no more than 30 degrees.
Extend your arms above you with a slight bend at the elbows.
Now rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing you. Tip: The pinky fingers should be next to each other. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, start to slowly lower the arms to the side while keeping the arms extended and while rotating the wrists until the palms of the hand are facing each other. Tip: At the end of the movement the arms will be by your side with the palms facing the ceiling.

As you exhale start to bring the dumbbells back up to the starting position by reversing the motion and rotating the hands so that the pinky fingers are next to each other again. Tip: Keep in mind that the movement will only happen at the shoulder joint and at the wrist. There is no motion that happens at the elbow joint.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Flyes - With A Twist
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on an incline bench (no more than 30 degrees) with dumbbells extended above you, elbows slightly bent
Rotate your wrists so your palms face you with pinky fingers next to each other
Lower your arms out to the sides in an arc while rotating your wrists until palms face each other, ending with palms facing the ceiling
Bring the dumbbells back up by reversing the motion, rotating your hands so pinkies are together again at the top
Squeeze your chest at the top and repeat
form_cues: Keep the elbow bend constant throughout - imagine your arms are in a cast that can only move at the shoulder
Lower in a wide arc like you're spreading your wings - think about opening up your chest
Rotate smoothly as you move - at the bottom, your palms should face up like you're holding two plates
Lead with your pinkies coming back up - think about trying to touch them together above your chest
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows more as you lower the weight, turning it into a press
Going too deep and overstretching the shoulders beyond a comfortable range
Forgetting to rotate the wrists, which changes the muscle emphasis
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the bench at 30 degrees or less - steeper inclines can stress the shoulders
Use lighter weights than you think - this is a stretch movement focused on feel, not heavy loading

instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand atop your thighs. The palms of your hands will be facing each other.
Then, using your thighs to help push the dumbbells up, lift the dumbbells one at a time so that you can hold them at shoulder width.
Once you have the dumbbells raised to shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.
Be sure to keep full control of the dumbbells at all times. Then breathe out and push the dumbbells up with your chest.
Lock your arms at the top, hold for a second, and then start slowly lowering the weight. Tip Ideally, lowering the weights should take about twice as long as raising them.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the dumbbells back on your thighs and then on the floor. This is the safest manner to release the dumbbells.
exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with dumbbells resting on your thighs, palms facing each other
Use your thighs to kick the dumbbells up one at a time to shoulder width, then rotate your wrists so palms face away from you
Press the dumbbells up with your chest, keeping full control throughout, and lock your arms at the top
Hold for one second at the top, then lower slowly - taking about twice as long to lower as you did to press up
When finished, return dumbbells to your thighs first, then place them on the floor
form_cues: Press the dumbbells up and slightly together - think about pushing them toward each other as you extend
Lower slowly like you're fighting the weight down - count 3 seconds on the descent
Keep your shoulder blades squeezed back into the bench - imagine pinching them together
Drive through your chest and feel the upper pecs working - think about pressing through the handles, not just moving your arms
common_mistakes: Bouncing the dumbbells off the chest at the bottom instead of controlling the descent
Pressing straight up instead of slightly together, which reduces chest activation
Using momentum and arching the back excessively to lift heavier weight
injury_prevention_tips: Use your legs to safely get the dumbbells into position - never try to swing them up from the sides
Don't go too heavy - the incline angle already makes this significantly harder than flat pressing

exercises.description: Hammer curl performed with dumbbells and at an incline
instructions: Seat yourself on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. You should pressed firmly against he back with your feet together. Allow the dumbbells to hang straight down at your side, holding them with a neutral grip. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by flexing at the elbow, attempting to keep the upper arm stationary.
Continue to the top of the movement and pause, then slowly return to the start position.
exercises.name: Incline Hammer Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on an incline bench pressed firmly against the back, feet together, with a dumbbell in each hand
Let the dumbbells hang straight down at your sides with a neutral grip (palms facing each other)
Curl the dumbbells up by flexing at the elbows while keeping your upper arms completely still
Continue to the top of the movement and pause, squeezing your biceps and forearms
Slowly lower back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Keep your palms facing each other throughout - imagine holding two hammers the entire time
Pin your upper arms to your sides - think about having your elbows glued in place
Let your arms hang dead straight at the bottom to get a full stretch - feel the biceps elongate
Curl smoothly without swinging - think about pulling the weight up with only your forearms rotating
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drift forward during the curl instead of keeping them locked at your sides
Rotating the wrists and turning it into a regular curl instead of maintaining neutral grip
Using momentum by rocking the torso instead of strict, isolated arm movement
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than regular curls - the incline provides more stretch and makes it harder
If you feel shoulder discomfort, reduce the bench incline or check that your back is pressed firmly against the pad

instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand and lie back on an incline bench.
The dumbbells should be at arm's length hanging at your sides and your palms should be facing out. This will be your starting position.

Now as you exhale curl the weight outward and up while keeping your forearms in line with your side deltoids. Continue the curl until the dumbbells are at shoulder height and to the sides of your deltoids. Tip: The end of the movement should look similar to a double biceps pose.
After a second contraction at the top of the movement, start to inhale and slowly lower the weights back to the starting position using the same path used to bring them up.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Incline Inner Biceps Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand hanging at arm's length, palms facing out
Curl the weights outward and up while keeping your forearms in line with your side delts - they should move out to the sides, not straight forward
Continue curling until the dumbbells reach shoulder height beside your delts, ending in a double biceps pose position
Hold the contraction for one second at the top, squeezing your biceps hard
Lower the weights slowly back to the starting position using the same outward path
form_cues: Curl outward, not forward - think about curling along diagonal lines out to your sides
Finish like a double biceps pose - your hands should end up beside your shoulders, not in front of them
Keep your forearms aligned with your side delts throughout - imagine moving along fixed tracks
Squeeze hard at the top like you're showing off your bicep peak
common_mistakes: Curling straight forward instead of outward, which reduces the inner bicep emphasis
Letting the elbows drift away from being aligned with the side delts
Using too much weight and swinging the dumbbells instead of controlled movement
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - this variation is awkward at first and uses a different angle than standard curls
Keep your back pressed against the bench to avoid compensating with body English

instructions: Stand facing bench or sturdy elevated platform. Place hands on edge of bench or platform, slightly wider than shoulder width.
Position forefoot back from bench or platform with arms and body straight. Arms should be perpendicular to body. Keeping body straight, lower chest to edge of box or platform by bending arms.
Push body up until arms are extended. Repeat.
exercises.name: Incline Push-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a bench or elevated platform and place your hands on the edge slightly wider than shoulder width
Walk your feet back until your body forms a straight line from head to heels, arms perpendicular to your body
Lower your chest toward the edge of the bench by bending your arms, keeping your body completely straight
Push yourself back up until your arms are fully extended
Repeat while maintaining perfect body alignment throughout
form_cues: Keep your body rigid like a plank - imagine a broomstick running from your head through your heels
Lower your entire body as one unit - don't let your hips sag or pike up
Touch your chest to the bench, not your chin or forehead - lead with your sternum
Push through your entire palm - think about pushing the bench away from you
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag down or pike up instead of maintaining a straight body line
Only lowering partway instead of bringing the chest all the way to the bench
Flaring the elbows too wide instead of keeping them at about 45 degrees from the body
injury_prevention_tips: Engage your core throughout to maintain the straight body position
If you feel lower back strain, you're likely letting your hips sag - tighten your abs and glutes

instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands next to one another on the bar.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.
exercises.name: Incline Push-Up Close-Grip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Find a sturdy elevated surface (bench, bar, countertop) at waist to chest height - the higher it is, the easier the movement
Place your hands directly next to each other on the surface with thumbs touching, forming a diamond shape with your index fingers and thumbs
Walk your feet back until your body forms a straight line from head to heels - imagine a broomstick lying along your spine
Lower yourself by bending your elbows straight back along your sides (not flaring out) until your chest nearly touches the bar
Press powerfully through your palms to straighten your arms completely, squeezing your triceps hard at the top like you're trying to pop them
form_cues: Keep your elbows glued to your sides like you're holding newspapers in your armpits - this maximizes tricep engagement
Think about pushing the bar away from you rather than pushing yourself up
Squeeze your glutes and abs tight throughout - pretend someone's about to punch you in the stomach
common_mistakes: Elbows flaring out to the sides instead of staying tucked, which shifts work from triceps to chest
Letting hips sag or pike up, breaking the straight body line
Not going deep enough - your chest should come within an inch or two of the bar
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists stacked directly under your elbows to avoid wrist strain
If you feel shoulder discomfort, elevate the bar higher to reduce the load

instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands on the bar, with your hands about shoulder width apart.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.
exercises.name: Incline Push-Up Medium
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself facing an elevated bar or bench at waist to chest height
Place your hands on the surface shoulder-width apart with fingers pointing forward
Walk your feet back until your body is in a straight plank position with weight on your toes
Lower your chest toward the bar by bending your elbows at roughly 45 degrees from your body
Push explosively back to the starting position, fully extending your arms and squeezing your chest at the top
form_cues: Imagine trying to push the bar through the wall behind it
Keep your body rigid like a plank of wood from head to heels - nothing should bend except your arms
At the bottom, your chest should touch or come within an inch of the bar - think 'sternum to bar'
common_mistakes: Leading with the head or looking up, which hyperextends the neck - keep your head neutral
Letting the lower back sag or hips drop, creating a banana shape
Shortening the range of motion by not lowering all the way down
injury_prevention_tips: Engage your core before every rep - brace like you're about to get pushed
Start with a higher surface if you can't maintain form, then gradually lower it as you get stronger

instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands on the bar palms up, with your hands about shoulder width apart.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.
exercises.name: Incline Push-Up Reverse Grip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing an elevated bar at waist height (this variation works best on a straight bar, not a bench)
Grip the bar with palms facing up (supinated grip) about shoulder-width apart
Walk your feet back until your body forms a straight line, arms extended
Lower your chest to the bar by bending your elbows, keeping them relatively close to your sides
Press back up powerfully to full arm extension, feeling the squeeze in your lower chest and biceps
form_cues: This grip will feel awkward at first - think of it like doing a standing curl and press combined
Keep your shoulders pulled down away from your ears throughout the movement
Focus on squeezing your lower chest as you push up, like you're trying to bring your chest to your belly button
common_mistakes: Letting wrists bend backward excessively - maintain firm, neutral wrists despite the reverse grip
Flaring elbows out wide, which can stress the shoulder joint in this grip position
Rushing the movement - this variation requires more control than standard push-ups
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced variation - only attempt after mastering regular incline push-ups
If you feel wrist discomfort, this variation may not be suitable for you; stick to standard grips

instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands on the bar, with your hands wider than shoulder width.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. Your arms should be perpendicular to the body. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.
exercises.name: Incline Push-Up Wide
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself at an elevated bar or sturdy surface at waist to chest height
Place your hands significantly wider than shoulder-width - about 1.5x shoulder width
Step back into a plank position with arms fully extended and body straight
Lower yourself by bending your elbows out to the sides at roughly 60-70 degrees from your body
Push back up powerfully, focusing on squeezing your chest muscles together at the top like a bear hug
form_cues: Think about pulling the bar apart with your hands as you lower down - this engages your chest more
Your elbows should track in line with your hands, not drift inward
At the top position, imagine squeezing a beach ball between your pecs
common_mistakes: Going too wide with hand placement, which reduces range of motion and can stress shoulders
Not controlling the descent - letting yourself drop instead of lowering with control
Stopping short at the top without fully extending arms and squeezing chest
injury_prevention_tips: Don't go wider than 1.5x shoulder width - excessive width can strain shoulder joints
Keep shoulders pulled down and back, not shrugged up toward your ears

instructions: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Loop a belt, rope, or band around one of your feet, and swing that leg as far to the side as you can. This will be your starting position.
Pull gently on the belt to create tension in your groin and hamstring muscles. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and repeat on the other side.
exercises.name: Intermediate Groin Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back on a mat with both legs extended straight
Loop a yoga strap, belt, or resistance band around the arch of your right foot
Keeping your right leg straight, swing it out to the side as far as comfortable while keeping your left leg and hips flat on the ground
Gently pull on the strap to increase tension until you feel a stretch along your inner thigh and hamstring
Hold steady for 10-20 seconds breathing deeply, then repeat on the left side
form_cues: Keep your opposite hip glued to the floor - imagine it's weighted down with a sandbag
Your leg should stay straight but not locked - think of a gentle reach, not a forced pull
Breathe into the stretch - with each exhale, see if you can gently increase the range a tiny bit
common_mistakes: Letting the opposite hip lift off the ground, which reduces the effectiveness of the groin stretch
Bending the knee of the stretching leg, which shifts tension away from the groin
Pulling too aggressively with the strap - this should feel like a gentle tension, not painful
injury_prevention_tips: Never bounce or jerk the stretch - use smooth, controlled pulls only
Stop if you feel sharp pain (dull tension is okay, sharp pain is not)

instructions: Lie face down on the floor, with a rope, belt, or band looped around one foot.

Flex the knee and extend the hip of the leg to be stretched, using both hands to pull on the belt. Your knee and your hip should come off of the floor, creating tension in the hip flexors and quadriceps. Hold the stretch for 10-20 seconds, and repeat on the other leg.
exercises.name: Intermediate Hip Flexor and Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on a mat and loop a strap or belt around your right foot
Reach both hands behind you to grab the strap, then bend your right knee pulling your heel toward your glutes
Simultaneously pull the strap to lift your knee off the ground while extending your hip (pushing your thigh backward)
You should feel a deep stretch in the front of your thigh and hip - hold for 10-20 seconds
Slowly release and repeat on the other leg
form_cues: Think about pushing your hip into the ground while pulling your knee up - it's a two-directional stretch
Imagine your knee is reaching back toward your spine
Keep your opposite leg completely flat and relaxed on the ground
common_mistakes: Only bending the knee without lifting it off the ground - you need both actions for a full hip flexor stretch
Arching the lower back excessively - keep your abs engaged to protect your spine
Holding your breath - breathe steadily to help the muscles relax into the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: This is a deep stretch - start gently and progressively increase intensity over time
If you have knee pain, reduce the amount of knee flexion and focus more on the hip extension

instructions: Choke the band around a post. The band should be at the same height as your elbow. Stand with your right side to the band a couple of feet away.
Grasp the end of the band with your right hand, and keep your elbow pressed firmly to your side. We recommend you hold a pad or foam roll in place with your elbow to keep it firmly in position.
With your upper arm in position, your elbow should be flexed to 90 degrees with your hand reaching away from your torso. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by rotating your arm in a forehand motion, keeping your elbow in place.
Continue as far as you are able, pause, and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Internal Rotation with Band
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a resistance band to a sturdy post at elbow height and stand with your right side facing the anchor point, 2-3 feet away
Grab the band with your right hand and pin your right elbow firmly to your side - hold a small towel or foam roller between your elbow and ribs to keep it locked in place
Start with your forearm pointing straight ahead (90-degree elbow angle), perpendicular to your body
Rotate your forearm across your stomach like closing a door, keeping your elbow glued to your side
Pause when your hand reaches your belly, then slowly return to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think of your elbow as a hinge that never moves - only your forearm rotates
Move like you're slowly turning a doorknob inward toward your body
Keep your shoulder down and back - don't let it roll forward as you rotate
common_mistakes: Letting the elbow drift away from the body, which recruits different muscles and defeats the purpose
Using momentum or swinging the arm instead of controlled rotation
Rotating too far past your belly button, which can stress the shoulder joint
injury_prevention_tips: Use light resistance - this is a small muscle group that fatigues quickly
Stop immediately if you feel pinching or sharp pain in the shoulder

instructions: Position a bar in a rack to about waist height. You can also use a smith machine.

Take a wider than shoulder width grip on the bar and position yourself hanging underneath the bar. Your body should be straight with your heels on the ground with your arms fully extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow, pulling your chest towards the bar. Retract your shoulder blades as you perform the movement.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return yourself to the start position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Inverted Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell in a rack at about waist height (higher = easier, lower = harder)
Lie underneath the bar and grip it with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width, palms facing away
Position your body in a straight line with heels on the ground and arms fully extended - this is a reverse plank position
Pull your chest up to the bar by driving your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades together
Lower yourself back down with control until arms are fully extended, then repeat
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows into your back pockets, not just bending your arms
Lead with your chest, not your chin - imagine trying to touch the bar with your sternum
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard at the top like you're crushing a walnut between them
common_mistakes: Letting hips sag toward the ground, breaking the straight body line
Leading with the head and neck instead of the chest, which can strain the neck
Using partial range of motion - your chest should nearly touch the bar at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core tight throughout - brace your abs like someone's about to poke your stomach
If you can't maintain a straight body, elevate the bar higher to reduce difficulty

instructions: Hang a rope or suspension straps from a rack or other stable object. Grasp the ends and position yourself in a supine position hanging from the ropes. Your body should be straight with your heels on the ground with your arms fully extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow, pulling your chest to your hands. Retract your shoulder blades as you perform the movement.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return yourself to the start position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Inverted Row with Straps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang suspension straps (TRX, rings, or ropes) from a secure anchor point at chest height
Grab the handles and walk your feet forward, leaning back until your body is at an angle with arms extended
Your body should form a straight line from head to heels - the more horizontal you are, the harder the exercise
Pull your chest toward your hands by bending your elbows and pulling your shoulder blades together
Lower yourself back to the starting position with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about pulling your hands to your ribs, not to your chest - this keeps elbows tight and engages lats better
Keep your body rigid like a plank of wood - everything moves as one unit
At the top, your hands should be next to your ribs and your shoulder blades should be squeezed tight like you're holding a pencil between them
common_mistakes: Letting the straps go slack at the top, which reduces tension on the muscles
Allowing hips to sag or pike up, breaking the straight body position
Pulling with arms only instead of initiating the movement with shoulder blade retraction
injury_prevention_tips: Start at a higher angle (more upright) if you're new to this movement - you can progress to more horizontal positions over time
Keep constant tension in your core to protect your lower back

exercises.name: Iron Cross
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding a light dumbbell in each hand at your sides
Hinge forward at the hips keeping your back flat until your torso is roughly 45 degrees to the floor
Extend both arms straight out to your sides like airplane wings, forming a T-shape with your body
Hold this position briefly while squeezing your shoulder blades together and keeping dumbbells at shoulder height
Lower the dumbbells back to starting position with control and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're being pulled apart by ropes attached to each hand - create that tension
Think about pushing your chest forward and pulling your shoulder blades back to meet each other
Keep your back flat like a table - imagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and swinging the dumbbells up instead of lifting with control
Rounding the back instead of maintaining a neutral spine
Letting arms drift forward or backward - they should stay perpendicular to your torso
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight - this exercise is extremely challenging for the rear deltoids and upper back
Keep a slight bend in your elbows to reduce stress on the elbow joints

instructions: Lie face down on the floor, with your arms extended out to your side, palms pressed to the floor. This will be your starting position.
To begin, flex one knee and bring that leg across the back of your body, attempting to touch it to the ground near the opposite hand.
Promptly return the leg to the starting postion, and quickly repeat with the other leg. Continue alternating for 10-20 repetitions.
exercises.name: Iron Crosses (stretch)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor with your arms extended straight out to your sides forming a 'T', palms pressed to the floor
Bend one knee and swing that leg across the back of your body, trying to touch your foot to the floor near your opposite hand
Quickly return that leg to the starting position and immediately repeat with the other leg
Continue alternating legs back and forth in a dynamic, controlled rhythm for 10-20 reps total
form_cues: Keep your arms glued to the floor - imagine them pinned down with weights
Sweep your leg across like a windshield wiper - think about drawing a big arc with your foot
Your hips will naturally rotate as you cross over - embrace the twist through your lower back
Move with a smooth rhythm - not too slow, not too fast, like a metronome
common_mistakes: Lifting the opposite shoulder off the ground when crossing the leg over
Moving too slowly and holding the stretched position instead of keeping it dynamic
Not bringing the leg far enough across to get the full hip and lower back rotation
injury_prevention_tips: This is a dynamic stretch - keep the movements controlled but flowing, not jerky
If you feel pinching in your lower back, reduce the range and don't force your foot all the way to the floor

instructions: With your head and neck in a neutral position (normal position with head erect facing forward), place both of your hands on the front side of your head.
Now gently push forward as you contract the neck muscles but resisting any movement of your head. Start with slow tension and increase slowly. Keep breathing normally as you execute this contraction.
Hold for the recommended number of seconds.
Now release the tension slowly.
Rest for the recommended amount of time and repeat with your hands placed on the back side of your head.
exercises.name: Isometric Neck Exercise - Front And Back
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit with your head in a neutral position (looking straight ahead), and place both hands on your forehead
Gently push your head forward into your hands while resisting with your neck muscles - your head shouldn't actually move
Start with light pressure and gradually increase, breathing normally throughout the contraction
Hold for the recommended time (typically 10-30 seconds), then slowly release the tension
Rest briefly, then repeat with your hands placed on the back of your head, pushing backward
form_cues: Your head should not move at all - imagine it's frozen in space while you push against an immovable wall
Build tension gradually like turning up a dimmer switch - don't go from zero to full force instantly
Breathe normally throughout - don't hold your breath during the contraction
Keep your shoulders relaxed and down - all the tension should be in your neck, not your traps
common_mistakes: Pushing so hard that the head actually moves forward or backward
Holding the breath during the contraction, which can spike blood pressure
Tensing the shoulders and upper traps instead of isolating the neck muscles
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light pressure, especially if you have any neck issues or history of injury
If you feel any sharp pain or tingling, stop immediately - this should create tension, not pain

instructions: With your head and neck in a neutral position (normal position with head erect facing forward), place your left hand on the left side of your head.

Now gently push towards the left as you contract the left neck muscles but resisting any movement of your head. Start with slow tension and increase slowly. Keep breathing normally as you execute this contraction.
Hold for the recommended number of seconds.
Now release the tension slowly.
Rest for the recommended amount of time and repeat with your right hand placed on the right side of your head.
exercises.name: Isometric Neck Exercise - Sides
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit with your head in a neutral position, and place your left hand on the left side of your head
Gently push your head to the left into your hand while resisting with your neck muscles - your head shouldn't move
Start with light pressure and gradually increase, breathing normally throughout
Hold for the recommended time (typically 10-30 seconds), then slowly release
Rest briefly, then repeat with your right hand on the right side of your head
form_cues: Your head should stay perfectly still - imagine it's locked in a vise while you push sideways
Increase tension slowly and smoothly - like gradually pressing a gas pedal
Focus on contracting the side of your neck, not tilting your head
Keep breathing steadily - don't hold your breath
common_mistakes: Actually tilting the head to the side instead of creating pure isometric tension
Shrugging the shoulder up on the pushing side
Starting with too much force instead of building gradually
injury_prevention_tips: Use minimal pressure at first - the neck muscles are smaller and more vulnerable than you might think
Stop if you feel any sharp pain, numbness, or tingling down your arm

instructions: Assume a push-up position, supporting your weight on your hands and toes while keeping your body straight. Your hands should be just outside of shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
Begin by shifting your body weight as far to one side as possible, allowing the elbow on that side to flex as you lower your body.
Reverse the motion by extending the flexed arm, pushing yourself up and then dropping to the other side.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Isometric Wipers
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a standard push-up position with hands just outside shoulder width and body in a straight line
Shift your entire body weight to one side, allowing the elbow on that side to bend as you lower down
Push back up through the bent arm to extend it, then immediately shift to the other side and lower down
Continue alternating side to side like windshield wipers for the desired reps
form_cues: Move laterally like windshield wipers - shift your weight from side to side, not forward and back
Lower down on one side, then push up and smoothly flow to the other side without pausing
Keep your body rigid like a plank - imagine you're a board sliding side to side
One arm will be mostly straight while the other bends - think about loading one side at a time
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag or pike up instead of maintaining a straight body line
Not shifting far enough to one side, which reduces the unilateral loading
Bending both elbows simultaneously like a regular push-up instead of isolating one side
injury_prevention_tips: This is advanced - build up to it with regular push-ups and archer push-ups first
Keep your core tight throughout to prevent lower back strain from the shifting weight

instructions: Start the exercise the same way you would a close grip bench press. You will lie on a flat bench while holding a barbell at arms length (fully extended) with the elbows in. However, instead of having the arms perpendicular to the torso, make sure the bar is set in a direct line above the upper chest. This will be your starting position.

Now beginning from a fully extended position lower the bar down as if performing a lying triceps extension. Inhale as you perform this movement. When you reach the half way point, let the bar roll back about one inch by moving the upper arms towards your legs until they are perpendicular to the torso. Tip: Keep the bend at the elbows constant as you bring the upper arms forward.
As you exhale, press the bar back up by using the triceps to perform a close grip bench press.
Now go back to the starting position and start over.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: JM Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench and hold a barbell at arm's length above your upper chest (not above your shoulders) with a close grip and elbows in
Lower the bar halfway down toward your face like a skull crusher, keeping your elbows bent at the same angle throughout
Once halfway down, shift your upper arms forward (toward your legs) about an inch until they're perpendicular to your torso
Press the bar back up to the starting position using your triceps, combining the movements back into one
Return to the starting position directly above your upper chest and repeat
form_cues: Start with the bar over your upper chest, not your shoulders - this is key to the movement path
Lower the bar toward your face in the first half like a skull crusher - elbows stay locked in their bent position
At the midpoint, shift your arms forward about an inch - think about moving your elbows toward your feet slightly
Press back up like a close-grip bench press - drive through your triceps
common_mistakes: Starting with the bar over the shoulders instead of the upper chest, which changes the entire movement pattern
Letting the elbows flare out wide instead of keeping them tucked in
Not shifting the upper arms forward at the midpoint, which eliminates the unique aspect of this exercise
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light to learn the movement pattern - this is a technical exercise that feels awkward at first
If you feel elbow pain, reduce the weight or check your form - the elbows should stay stable

instructions: Lie flat on the floor (or exercise mat) on your back with your arms extended straight back behind your head and your legs extended also. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, bend at the waist while simultaneously raising your legs and arms to meet in a jackknife position. Tip: The legs should be extended and lifted at approximately a 35-45 degree angle from the floor and the arms should be extended and parallel to your legs. The upper torso should be off the floor.
While inhaling, lower your arms and legs back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Jackknife Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with arms extended straight overhead and legs extended straight
Simultaneously raise your legs and torso, bringing them together in the middle to form a 'V' or jackknife position
Your legs should be lifted at about 35-45 degrees and your arms should reach toward your feet, with your upper torso off the floor
Lower your arms and legs back down to the starting position with control
Repeat for the desired number of reps
form_cues: Fold at the waist like a book closing - bring your upper and lower body together simultaneously
Reach your hands toward your feet at the top - imagine trying to touch your toes
Keep your legs straight like steel rods - no bending at the knees
Lower slowly with control - think about resisting gravity on the way down
common_mistakes: Bending the knees to make it easier instead of keeping the legs straight
Using momentum and swinging the limbs instead of controlled ab contraction
Not lifting the upper torso high enough - your shoulder blades should come completely off the floor
injury_prevention_tips: If this is too challenging, start with bent-knee versions and progress to straight legs
Keep your lower back pressed to the floor at the start to avoid hyperextension

instructions: Position your body on the floor in the basic sit-up position; knees to a ninety degree angle with feet flat on the floor and arms either crossed over your chest or to the sides. This will be your starting position.

As you strongly tighten your glutes and hamstrings, fill your lungs with air and in a slow (three to six second count) ascent, slowly exhale. Tip: It is important to tighten the glutes and hamstrings as this will cause the hip flexors to be inactivated in a process called reciprocal inhibition, which basically means that opposite muscles to the contracted ones will relax.
As you inhale, slowly go back in a controlled manner to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Janda Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back in standard sit-up position with knees bent to 90 degrees, feet flat, arms crossed over chest or at your sides
Before initiating the sit-up, strongly contract your glutes and hamstrings - squeeze them hard like you're trying to cramp them
While maintaining that glute/hamstring contraction, slowly sit up over a 3-6 second count, exhaling as you rise
At the top, pause briefly, then slowly lower back down while inhaling
Repeat, making sure to squeeze glutes and hamstrings before each rep
form_cues: Squeeze your glutes and hamstrings HARD before you sit up - this is the secret to the exercise and turns off your hip flexors
Drive your heels into the floor as you squeeze - imagine trying to drag your feet toward your butt
Sit up slowly over 3-6 seconds - this isn't a race, think about grinding through molasses
Your abs should feel like they're doing all the work since your hip flexors are inhibited
common_mistakes: Not contracting the glutes and hamstrings hard enough before the sit-up, which defeats the purpose
Sitting up too fast instead of the slow, controlled 3-6 second ascent
Forgetting to maintain the glute/hamstring contraction throughout the entire rep
injury_prevention_tips: The glute/hamstring contraction is essential - without it, this is just a regular sit-up that can strain the hip flexors
If you feel your hip flexors taking over, reset and squeeze your glutes harder

instructions: Place a barbell on the floor.
Stand in the middle of the bar length wise.
Bend down by bending at the knees and keeping your back straight and grasp the front of the bar with your right hand. Your palm should be in (neutral grip) facing the left side.

Grasp the rear of the bar with your left hand. The palm of your hand should be in neutral grip alignment (palms facing the right side). Tip: Ensure that your grip is even on the bar. Your torso should be positioned right in the middle of the bar and the distance between your torso and your right hand (which should be at the front) should be the same as the distance between your torso and your left hand (which should be to your back).
Now stand straight up with the weight. Tip: Your feet should be shoulder width apart and your toes slightly pointed out.

Squat down by bending at the knees and keeping your back straight until your upper thighs are parallel with the floor. Tip: Keep your back as vertical as possible with the floor and your head up. Also remember to not let your knees go past your toes. Inhale during this portion of the movement.

Now drive yourself back up to the starting position by pushing with the feet . Tip: Keep the bar hanging at arm's length and your elbows locked with a slight bend. The arms only serve as hooks. Avoid doing any lifting with them. Do the lifting with your thighs; not your arms.
exercises.name: Jefferson Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a barbell on the floor and stand straddling it lengthwise in the middle
Squat down and grab the front of the bar with your right hand (palm facing left) and the back with your left hand (palm facing right), keeping your torso centered between your hands
Stand straight up with the bar hanging at arm's length, feet shoulder-width apart with toes slightly out
Squat down by bending at the knees, keeping your back straight and head up, until your thighs are parallel to the floor
Drive back up through your feet to the starting position, keeping your arms straight and acting only as hooks
form_cues: Straddle the bar right in the middle - equal distance from your torso to each hand for balance
Keep your torso as vertical as possible - imagine a string pulling the top of your head toward the ceiling
Let the bar hang dead at arm's length - your arms are just hooks, your legs do all the work
Knees track over toes, never going past them - think about sitting back into a chair
common_mistakes: Gripping the bar off-center, which creates an unbalanced load and rotation
Leaning forward excessively with the torso instead of staying upright
Using the arms to lift instead of letting the legs do all the work
injury_prevention_tips: Start light until you master the balance - this is an awkward movement that takes practice
The bar will want to rotate you - engage your core to resist twisting

instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The palm should be facing inward.
Looking straight ahead, press the kettlebell out and overhead, rotating your wrist so that your palm faces forward at the top of the motion.
Return the kettlebell to the starting position, with the palm facing in.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Arnold Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder by explosively extending through your legs and hips, catching it in the rack position with palm facing inward
From the rack position, press the kettlebell up and out overhead while rotating your wrist so your palm faces forward at the top
Lower the kettlebell back to the shoulder with control, rotating your wrist back so the palm faces inward again in the rack position
Repeat for reps, then switch sides
form_cues: Start with your palm facing you in the rack - like you're holding a phone to read a text
As you press up, rotate your wrist outward - think about unscrewing the kettlebell as it rises
Finish with palm facing forward at the top - like you're showing someone your palm in a 'stop' gesture
Reverse the rotation on the way down - screw it back inward to the rack position
common_mistakes: Not rotating the wrist enough, which reduces shoulder activation
Pressing straight up without the outward arc, turning it into a regular press
Letting the kettlebell pull your wrist backward instead of maintaining control throughout the rotation
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to master the rotation pattern - this puts the shoulder through a unique range of motion
Keep your core braced to prevent arching your back as you press overhead

instructions: Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Lower the kettlebell, keeping the hamstrings loaded by keeping your back straight and your butt out.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Dead Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor between your feet, then hinge at the hips by pushing your butt back with a straight back, looking straight ahead
Explosively extend through your legs and hips to clean the kettlebell to your shoulder, rotating your wrist as you bring it up to the rack position
Lower the kettlebell back down to the floor by hinging at the hips again, keeping your back straight and hamstrings loaded
Reset and repeat for the desired reps
form_cues: Start with your butt pushed back like you're closing a car door with it - this loads your hamstrings
Explode through your hips like you're jumping - this is a powerful, explosive movement
As the bell rises, rotate your wrist and punch through - think about threading your hand through the handle
Lower with control by pushing your butt back - don't just drop it, keep tension in the hamstrings
common_mistakes: Squatting down to pick up the kettlebell instead of hinging at the hips
Using your arms to curl the weight up instead of generating power from the hips
Rounding the back when lowering instead of maintaining a straight spine with a hip hinge
injury_prevention_tips: Master the hip hinge pattern first - this protects your lower back during the lift and lowering
The power comes from your hips, not your arms - if you're bicep curling it, you're doing it wrong

instructions: Place one kettlebell between your legs and take a wider than shoulder width stance. Bend over by pushing your butt out and keeping your back flat.
Pick up a kettlebell and pass it to your other hand between your legs. The receiving hand should reach from behind the legs. Go back and forth for several repetitions.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Figure 8
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width and place a kettlebell on the ground between your legs
Push your hips back into a partial squat position with your back flat and chest up - like sitting into a chair
Pick up the kettlebell with your right hand and swing it between your legs from front to back
As it passes behind your right leg, reach your left hand behind your left leg to grab it
Continue passing the kettlebell in a figure-8 pattern - front to back through one leg, hand-off behind, then front to back through the other leg
form_cues: Think of drawing a sideways 8 with the kettlebell as you weave it through your legs
Keep your back flat like a tabletop throughout - imagine balancing a glass of water on your lower back
Your hips should stay loaded and slightly bent - don't stand up fully between passes
common_mistakes: Rounding the back instead of maintaining a flat, neutral spine
Standing too upright between passes instead of staying in the hip hinge position
Moving too fast and losing control of the kettlebell trajectory
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light kettlebell until the movement pattern becomes smooth and natural
Keep your core braced tight throughout to protect your lower back

instructions: Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Lower kettlebell to a hanging position between your legs while keeping the hamstrings loaded. Keep your head up at all times.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Hang Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start standing with the kettlebell hanging between your legs, holding it with one hand, hips pushed back and knees slightly bent
Explosively extend your hips and knees (like jumping) while keeping the kettlebell close to your body
As you reach full extension, shrug your shoulder and pull the kettlebell up toward your shoulder
Rotate your wrist and elbow under the kettlebell as it reaches shoulder height, catching it in the rack position (resting on your forearm against your chest)
Lower the kettlebell back down between your legs by reversing the motion, keeping tension in your hamstrings
form_cues: Think 'hip power' not 'arm power' - your legs and hips do the work, your arm just guides the bell
The kettlebell should float up and land softly on your shoulder - imagine catching an egg without breaking it
Keep your eyes forward and chest proud throughout - don't look down at the kettlebell
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arm instead of driving with the hips, which wastes energy and reduces power
Letting the kettlebell bang into your forearm instead of smoothly rotating into the rack position
Standing too upright at the bottom position - maintain the hip hinge to keep hamstrings engaged
injury_prevention_tips: Master the kettlebell swing before attempting hang cleans - the hip drive is the same
Start light to practice the wrist rotation and catching mechanics before adding weight

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle in one hand. Stand on one leg, on the same side that you hold the kettlebell.
Keeping that knee slightly bent, perform a stiff legged deadlift by bending at the hip, extending your free leg behind you for balance.
