Continue lowering the kettlebell until you are parallel to the ground, and then return to the upright position.
exercises.name: Kettlebell One-Legged Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on your right leg holding a kettlebell in your right hand, with your left leg slightly off the ground
Keep a slight bend in your right knee and push your hips back while lowering the kettlebell toward the ground
As you hinge forward, extend your left leg straight behind you for balance - it should form a straight line with your torso
Lower until your torso is roughly parallel to the ground or as far as your hamstring flexibility allows
Drive through your right heel to return to standing, squeezing your glute at the top
form_cues: Imagine you're a seesaw - as your torso goes down, your back leg goes up
Keep your hips square to the ground - don't let them rotate open
Think about reaching the kettlebell toward your standing foot, not just dropping it straight down
common_mistakes: Rotating the hips open instead of keeping them square, which reduces hamstring engagement
Bending the back instead of hinging at the hip - your spine should stay neutral
Rushing the movement instead of controlling the descent and ascent
injury_prevention_tips: Use a light weight initially - this exercise challenges balance more than strength at first
If balance is difficult, lightly touch a wall or chair for support until you build stability

instructions: Place one kettlebell between your legs and take a comfortable stance. Bend over by pushing your butt out and keeping your back flat.
Pick up a kettlebell and pass it to your other hand between your legs, in the fashion of a W. Go back and forth for several repetitions.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Pass Between The Legs
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed slightly outward
Hold a kettlebell in your right hand and push your hips back into a partial squat with a flat back
Swing the kettlebell between your legs from front to back
As it passes through, release it with your right hand and catch it with your left hand behind your legs
Swing it back through to the front, then pass it back through again, alternating hands in a continuous rhythm
form_cues: Think of it like hiking a football between your legs - smooth hand-offs behind
Your hips should stay loaded in a 'ready to jump' position throughout
The kettlebell should travel in a W-pattern if you traced its path from the side
common_mistakes: Standing up too tall between passes instead of maintaining the hip hinge
Passing too far forward or backward, making the hand-off awkward
Using arms to swing instead of generating momentum from the hips
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a very light kettlebell to master the hand-off timing
Keep your core braced tight to protect your spine during the twisting motion

instructions: With a wide stance, hold a kettlebell with both hands. Allow it to hang at waist level with your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by turning to one side, swinging the kettlebell to head height. Briefly pause at the top of the motion.
Allow the bell to drop as you rotate to the opposite side, again raising the kettlebell to head height.
Repeat for the desired amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Pirate Ships
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with a wide stance holding a kettlebell with both hands at waist level, arms extended
Rotate your torso to the right while swinging the kettlebell up to head height, pivoting on your left foot
Pause briefly at the top with the kettlebell near your right ear
Allow the kettlebell to drop as you rotate to the left side, again swinging it to head height near your left ear
Continue alternating sides in a smooth, controlled rhythm
form_cues: Think of steering a ship's wheel from side to side - big, sweeping arcs
Your feet should pivot naturally - back heel lifts as you rotate toward the opposite side
The power comes from your core rotation, not your arms - arms just hold on for the ride
common_mistakes: Using arm strength to lift instead of rotational momentum from the torso
Keeping feet planted flat instead of allowing natural pivoting, which limits range of motion
Moving too fast and losing control, letting the kettlebell pull you off balance
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weight - this exercise is deceptively challenging for the shoulders and core
Keep the kettlebell close to your body throughout the arc to reduce strain on your shoulders

instructions: Pick up a kettlebell with two hands and hold it by the horns. Hold one leg off of the floor and squat down on the other.
Squat down by flexing the knee and sitting back with the hips, holding the kettlebell up in front of you.
Hold the bottom position for a second and then reverse the motion, driving through the heel and keeping your head and chest up.
Lower yourself again and repeat.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Pistol Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a kettlebell with both hands by the horns (sides of the handle) at chest height
Lift your left leg off the ground and extend it straight out in front of you
Squat down on your right leg by bending your knee and pushing your hips back, keeping your left leg elevated
Lower as far as you can while keeping your right heel on the ground and chest up - the kettlebell acts as a counterbalance
Drive through your right heel to stand back up, keeping your left leg extended throughout
form_cues: Hold the kettlebell far enough forward that it counterbalances your body - think of it as your anchor
Keep your non-working leg as straight and rigid as a broomstick
At the bottom, imagine sitting back into a tiny chair - drive your hips back, not just down
common_mistakes: Letting the knee cave inward instead of tracking over the toes
Losing balance and falling backward - use the kettlebell as a counterweight by holding it farther forward
Rounding the back at the bottom - keep your chest up and proud
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced movement - practice regular single-leg squats to a box before attempting full pistols
If you can't reach full depth, squat to a bench or box initially and gradually lower the target

instructions: Sit on the floor and spread your legs out comfortably.
Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder.
Press the kettlebell up and out until it is locked out overhead. Return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Seated Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your legs spread wide in a V-shape for stability
Clean a kettlebell to your right shoulder - it should rest on your forearm against your upper chest
Press the kettlebell straight up and slightly outward until your arm is fully locked out overhead
Your palm should finish facing forward at the top, with the kettlebell stacked over your shoulder joint
Lower the kettlebell back to the rack position with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about punching the ceiling with your fist as you press up
Pack your shoulder down and back at the start - create a stable shelf for the kettlebell to rest on
At the top, your bicep should be next to your ear - don't leave it out in front
common_mistakes: Pressing straight up without rotating the wrist, which creates an inefficient bar path
Leaning away from the weight instead of staying upright - this reduces shoulder engagement
Not achieving full lockout at the top - your elbow should be completely straight
injury_prevention_tips: Sitting eliminates leg drive, making this harder than standing - start lighter than you think
Keep your shoulder blade pulled down throughout - don't let it shrug up toward your ear

instructions: Clean two kettlebells two your shoulders.
Press one kettlebell.
Lower the kettlebell and immediately press the other kettlebell. Make sure to do the same amount of reps on both sides.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Seesaw Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders so both are resting in the rack position
Press the right kettlebell overhead to full lockout while keeping the left kettlebell in the rack position
As you lower the right kettlebell back down, immediately begin pressing the left kettlebell up
The kettlebells should pass each other at mid-height - one going up as the other comes down
Continue alternating in a smooth, rhythmic pattern like a seesaw
form_cues: Think of an old-fashioned scale - as one side goes up, the other goes down
Keep constant tension - there should never be a moment when both bells are resting
Your core should work overtime to resist rotation - brace hard like someone's about to push you
common_mistakes: Pausing with both kettlebells in the rack position, which removes the continuous tension benefit
Leaning side to side excessively instead of staying upright and stable
Rushing the movement and losing the smooth, controlled seesaw rhythm
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter weight than you'd use for regular overhead presses - the alternating pattern is fatiguing
Keep your abs braced tight to prevent excessive spinal rotation

instructions: Place a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. Position your feet in a wide stance, and grasp the kettlebell with two hands. Set your hips back as far as possible, with your knees bent. Keep your chest and head up. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending the hips and knees, simultaneously pulling the kettlebell to your shoulders, raising your elbows as you do so. Reverse the motion to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Sumo High Pull
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the ground and stand over it with feet in a wide sumo stance (toes pointed out)
Squat down and grab the kettlebell with both hands, pushing your hips back and keeping your chest up
Explosively extend your hips and knees while simultaneously pulling the kettlebell straight up toward your chin
Your elbows should rise high and wide, leading the movement - the kettlebell ends up at chest to chin height
Lower the kettlebell back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'jump and pull' - explode with your legs first, then pull with your arms
Your elbows should go high like you're zipping up a jacket all the way to your chin
Lead with your elbows, not your hands - imagine your hands are hooks just holding the weight
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms first instead of driving with legs - the power comes from your hips
Not pulling high enough - the kettlebell should reach at least chest height
Rounding the back at the bottom position instead of maintaining a neutral spine
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to master the explosive hip drive timing before adding significant weight
Keep the kettlebell close to your body throughout - don't let it swing away from you

instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so. This will be your starting position.
Begin to squat by flexing your hips and knees, lowering your hips between your legs. Maintain an upright, straight back as you descend as low as you can.

At the bottom, reverse direction and squat by extending your knees and hips, driving through your heels. As you do so, press both kettlebells overhead by extending your arms straight up, using the momentum from the squat to help drive the weights upward.
As you begin the next repetition, return the weights to the shoulders.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Thruster
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders in the rack position, standing with feet shoulder-width apart
Squat down by pushing your hips back and bending your knees, keeping your chest up and elbows high
Descend as low as your mobility allows while maintaining an upright torso
Drive explosively through your heels to stand up, and as you reach the top, continue the upward momentum by pressing both kettlebells overhead
Lower the kettlebells back to your shoulders as you begin your next squat
form_cues: Think of it as one fluid motion - squat and press should blend seamlessly together
Use the 'bounce' out of the bottom of the squat to help drive the weight overhead
Your torso should stay as vertical as possible - imagine sliding your back up and down a wall
common_mistakes: Pausing at the top of the squat before pressing, which wastes the momentum
Letting the kettlebells pull you forward - keep elbows high to maintain an upright position
Not squatting deep enough - aim for hip crease below knee level
injury_prevention_tips: This is a high-intensity full-body movement - start with light kettlebells
Keep your core braced throughout to protect your spine, especially with weight overhead

instructions: Lie on your back on the floor and press a kettlebell to the top position by extending the elbow. Bend the knee on the same side as the kettlebell.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, pivot to the opposite side and use your non- working arm to assist you in driving forward to the lunge position. Using your free hand, push yourself to a seated position, then progressing to one knee.
While looking up at the kettlebell, slowly stand up. Reverse the motion back to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up (Lunge style)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back and press a kettlebell overhead with one arm, keeping it locked out, while bending the knee on the same side
Pivot onto your opposite elbow/hand and use it to help push yourself up to a seated position, keeping your eyes on the kettlebell
From seated, post your free hand on the floor and lift your hips to thread your straight leg back into a kneeling lunge position
Stand up from the lunge while keeping the kettlebell locked overhead and your eyes on it the entire time
Reverse the entire sequence step-by-step to return to lying on your back, then repeat
form_cues: Never take your eyes off the kettlebell - imagine there's a laser pointer attached to it that you must track
Keep the kettlebell arm locked straight the entire time - think about it being in a cast
Move slowly and deliberately through each position - this isn't a race, it's a moving meditation
Pack your shoulder by actively pulling it down and back - imagine screwing your arm into the socket
common_mistakes: Bending the elbow holding the kettlebell, which is unsafe and defeats the stability purpose
Looking away from the kettlebell, which can cause loss of balance and shoulder stability
Rushing through the transitions instead of moving with control and precision
injury_prevention_tips: Master the movement with no weight first, then progress to a light kettlebell
If your shoulder feels unstable at any point, lower the weight and reset

instructions: Lie on your back on the floor and press a kettlebell to the top position by extending the elbow. Bend the knee on the same side as the kettlebell.
Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, pivot to the opposite side and use your non- working arm to assist you in driving forward to the lunge position.

Using your free hand, push yourself to a seated position, then progressing to your feet. While looking up at the kettlebell, slowly stand up. Reverse the motion back to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up (Squat style)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back and press a kettlebell overhead with one arm, keeping it locked out, while bending the knee on the same side
Pivot onto your opposite elbow/hand and use it to help push yourself up to a seated position, keeping your eyes on the kettlebell
From seated, bring your feet underneath you and come up to a deep squat position, still maintaining the overhead press
Stand up from the squat while keeping the kettlebell locked overhead and your eyes on it
Reverse the entire sequence step-by-step to return to lying on your back, then repeat
form_cues: Never take your eyes off the kettlebell throughout - track it like a hawk
Keep the kettlebell arm locked and vertical the entire time - imagine balancing a cup of water on your fist
The squat portion requires good mobility - sit deep and keep your chest up
Move through each position deliberately - think about hitting specific checkpoints
common_mistakes: Bending the elbow of the pressing arm, which compromises shoulder stability
Not squatting deep enough before standing, which makes the movement less fluid
Losing track of the kettlebell with your eyes, which affects balance
injury_prevention_tips: This variation requires more mobility than the lunge style - make sure you have adequate squat depth first
Practice the movement without weight to build the motor pattern

instructions: Place a kettlebell in front of your lead foot and clean and press it overhead with your opposite arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. Press it overhead by extending the elbow.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, push your butt out in the direction of the locked out kettlebell. Turn your feet out at a forty-five degree angle from the arm with the locked out kettlebell. Bending at the hip to one side, sticking your butt out, slowly lean until you can touch the floor with your free hand. Keep your eyes on the kettlebell that you hold over your head at all times.
Pause for a second after reaching the ground and reverse the motion back to the starting position.
exercises.name: Kettlebell Windmill
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean and press a kettlebell overhead with one arm, then turn your feet out at 45 degrees away from the pressing arm
Keep the kettlebell locked overhead and your eyes glued to it, then push your hips out in the direction of the pressing arm
Hinge at the hip and lean to the side, reaching your free hand down toward the floor while keeping the kettlebell arm vertical
Slowly lower until your free hand touches the floor (or your foot if you can't reach the floor), keeping your chest open
Reverse the motion by driving your hips back under you to return to standing, eyes still on the kettlebell
form_cues: Push your butt out toward the side of the kettlebell - imagine closing a car door with your hip
Keep your eyes locked on the kettlebell the entire time - don't look away
Hinge at the hip, don't crunch down with your side - think about sliding down a wall sideways
Your pressing arm should stay vertical like a flag pole - no bending or drifting forward
common_mistakes: Bending the pressing elbow instead of keeping the arm locked straight
Looking down or away from the kettlebell, which compromises shoulder stability
Bending sideways at the spine instead of hinging at the hip with a straight back
injury_prevention_tips: This requires significant shoulder and hip mobility - practice with no weight first
If you can't touch the floor, don't force it - reach as far as comfortable and build mobility over time

instructions: Grip the rings using a false grip, with the base of your palms on top of the rings.
Begin with a movement swinging your legs backward slightly.

Counter that movement by swinging your legs forward and up, jerking your chin and chest back, pulling yourself up with both arms as you do so. As you reach the top position of the pull-up, pull the rings to your armpits as you roll your shoulders forward, allowing your elbows to move straight back behind you. This puts you into the proper position to continue into the dip portion of the movement.
Maintaining control and stability, extend through the elbow to complete the motion.
Use care when lowering yourself to the ground.
exercises.name: Kipping Muscle Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grip the rings with a false grip (base of palms on top of rings) and hang with straight arms
Initiate a kip by swinging your legs back slightly, then powerfully forward and up
As your legs swing forward, pull your chin and chest back while simultaneously pulling with both arms
At the top of the pull, aggressively pull the rings to your armpits and roll your shoulders forward, transitioning into a dip position with elbows behind you
Complete the movement by pressing through the dip to full arm extension, then lower with control
form_cues: The kip is a hip snap - think about launching your legs up like a pendulum
At the transition, pull the rings to your armpits aggressively - imagine pulling them to your sides, not just down
Roll your shoulders forward at the top - think about doing a fast transition from pull to dip
Keep tension through the entire movement - no dead hang or relaxed positions
common_mistakes: Not using enough hip drive from the kip, making the pull-up portion much harder
Pulling the rings down instead of to the armpits, which doesn't position you for the transition
Not rolling the shoulders forward aggressively enough at the top, getting stuck in the transition
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced movement - master strict ring muscle-ups and ring dips first
Use extreme care when lowering - control the descent to avoid shoulder injury

instructions: Lie down on the floor with your right leg straight. Bend your left leg and lower it across your body, holding the knee down toward the floor with your right hand. (The knee doesn't need to touch the floor if you're tight.)

Place your left arm comfortably beside you and turn your head to the left. Imagine you have a weight tied to your tailbone. let your tailbone fall back toward the floor as your chest reaches in the opposite direction to stretch your lower back. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Knee Across The Body
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with your right leg straight and your left knee bent
Use your right hand to gently pull your left knee across your body toward the floor on the right side
Extend your left arm out to the side comfortably and turn your head to look left
Let your tailbone drop back toward the floor as your chest opens in the opposite direction, creating a spiral stretch through your lower back and glutes
Hold for 20-30 seconds, breathing deeply, then switch sides
form_cues: Let gravity help pull your knee down - don't force it, just apply gentle hand pressure
Imagine your tailbone is weighted and falling back toward the floor while your chest reaches away
Keep your opposite shoulder blade on the floor - think about pinning it down
Turn your head away from the bent knee to increase the spinal twist
common_mistakes: Forcing the knee all the way to the floor instead of working within comfortable range
Lifting the opposite shoulder off the floor, which reduces the stretch
Holding tension instead of relaxing and breathing into the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Your knee doesn't need to touch the floor - stretch to mild tension only
Breathe deeply throughout and relax into the stretch - never force or bounce

instructions: Stand with your legs together and hands by your waist.
Now move your knees in a circular motion as you breathe normally.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Knee Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with your feet together and hands on your waist or hips
Bend your knees slightly and begin moving them in circular motions, like stirring a pot with your knees
Make complete circles, moving clockwise for half the reps, then counterclockwise for the other half
Keep the movements smooth and controlled while breathing normally
form_cues: Make the circles as big as your mobility allows - think about drawing large circles with your knees
Keep your feet flat on the floor - imagine they're glued down
Move smoothly like you're grinding coffee with your knees - no jerky movements
Keep your upper body relatively still - the motion happens from the knees down
common_mistakes: Making tiny circles instead of using full available range of motion
Lifting the heels or toes off the floor during the movement
Moving too fast and losing control of the circular motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start with smaller circles and gradually increase size as you warm up
If you feel any grinding or pain in the knees, reduce the circle size or stop

instructions: Position your body on the vertical leg raise bench so that your forearms are resting on the pads next to the torso and holding on to the handles. Your arms will be bent at a 90 degree angle.
The torso should be straight with the lower back pressed against the pad of the machine and the legs extended pointing towards the floor. This will be your starting position.

Now as you breathe out, lift your legs up as you keep them extended. Continue this movement until your legs are roughly parallel to the floor and then hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Do not use any momentum or swinging as you perform this exercise.
Slowly go back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Knee/Hip Raise On Parallel Bars
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself on a captain's chair or dip station with forearms on the pads and hands gripping the handles
Keep your torso straight with lower back pressed against the pad and legs extended hanging down - this is your starting position
Lift your legs up while keeping them straight, raising them until they're roughly parallel to the floor
Hold the contraction for one second at the top, then slowly lower back to the starting position
Avoid any swinging or momentum - use pure ab strength to lift and control
form_cues: Press your lower back into the pad throughout - imagine trying to leave an imprint in the pad
Lift your legs with control - think about raising them like a crane, not swinging like a pendulum
Stop at parallel - imagine your legs reaching for a bar directly in front of you at hip height
Lower slowly over 2-3 seconds - fight gravity all the way down
common_mistakes: Using momentum and swinging the legs instead of controlled lifting
Arching the lower back away from the pad, which reduces ab engagement
Raising the legs too high past parallel, which shifts work to the hip flexors
injury_prevention_tips: If straight legs are too difficult, start with bent knee raises and progress gradually
Keep constant tension on your abs - don't let yourself hang dead between reps

instructions: Connect a rope attachment to a high pulley cable and position a mat on the floor in front of it.
Grab the rope with both hands and kneel approximately two feet back from the tower.
Position the rope behind your head with your hands by your ears.
Keep your hands in the same place, contract your abs and pull downward on the rope in a crunching movement until your elbows reach your knees.
Pause briefly at the bottom and rise up in a slow and controlled manner until you reach the starting position.
Repeat the same downward movement until you halfway down, at which time you begin rotating one of your elbows to the opposite knee.
Again, pause briefly at the bottom and rise up in a slow and controlled manner until you reach the starting position.
Repeat the same movement as before, but alternate the other elbow to the opposite knee.
Continue this series of movements to failure.
exercises.name: Kneeling Cable Crunch With Alternating Oblique Twists
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a high pulley, kneel on a mat about 2 feet back, and position the rope behind your head with hands by your ears
First rep: Pull straight down in a crunching motion until your elbows touch your knees, pause, then return to start
Second rep: Pull down halfway, then rotate one elbow toward the opposite knee, pause, then return to start
Third rep: Pull down halfway, then rotate the other elbow to the opposite knee, pause, then return to start
Continue alternating this pattern - straight crunch, left twist, right twist, straight crunch, etc.
form_cues: Keep your hands locked by your ears throughout - imagine they're glued there
Pull down by contracting your abs, not by pulling with your arms - think about crunching your ribcage to your pelvis
On the twists, lead with your elbow - think about trying to touch your elbow to the opposite knee
Pause at the bottom of each rep - really squeeze and contract before rising
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arms instead of crunching with the abs
Not rotating far enough on the oblique twists to engage the side abs
Rising up too quickly without control instead of maintaining tension
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the rotation pattern without straining
Keep the movement smooth - don't jerk or twist aggressively

instructions: Place a bench sideways in front of a high pulley machine.
Hold a straight bar attachment above your head with your hands about 6 inches apart with your palms facing down.
Face away from the machine and kneel.
Place your head and the back of your upper arms on the bench. Your elbows should be bent with the forearms pointing towards the high pulley. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your upper arms close to your head at all times with the elbows in, press the bar out in a semicircular motion until the elbows are locked and your arms are parallel to the floor. Contract the triceps hard and keep this position for a second. Exhale as you perform this movement.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Kneeling Cable Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a bench sideways in front of a high pulley and attach a straight bar
Kneel facing away from the machine, rest your head and upper arms on the bench with elbows bent and forearms pointing toward the pulley
Hold the bar above your head with hands about 6 inches apart, palms down
Press the bar out in a semicircular arc until your arms are fully extended and parallel to the floor
Hold for one second with triceps contracted, then slowly return to the starting position
form_cues: Keep your upper arms glued to your head - imagine they're taped to your ears
Press in an arc, not straight - think about drawing a rainbow with the bar
Lock out completely at the end - squeeze your triceps hard like you're trying to show off a horseshoe
Keep your elbows in tight - imagine you're squeezing a towel between your upper arms
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows flare out to the sides instead of keeping them close to the head
Not fully extending at the lockout, which reduces tricep contraction
Using momentum by jerking the weight instead of smooth, controlled pressing
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - this position creates a deep stretch on the triceps that can be stressful
If you feel elbow discomfort, reduce the weight or check your elbow positioning

instructions: Start by kneeling on a mat with your palms flat and your fingers pointing back toward your knees.
Slowly lean back keeping your palms flat on the floor until you feel a stretch in your wrists and forearms. Hold for 20-30 seconds.
exercises.name: Kneeling Forearm Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel on a mat and place your palms flat on the floor in front of you with fingers pointing back toward your knees
Slowly lean your body weight backward, keeping your palms pressed flat, until you feel a stretch in your wrists and forearms
Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds while breathing normally
To release, shift your weight forward before lifting your hands
form_cues: Keep your palms completely flat - imagine they're glued to the floor
Lean back gradually - think about slowly shifting your weight like a seesaw
The stretch should be in your forearms and wrists - imagine someone is gently pulling your hands toward your knees
Keep your fingers pointing directly at your knees - straight back, not angled
common_mistakes: Leaning back too aggressively and bouncing, which can hyperextend the wrists
Letting the palms lift off the floor or the fingers curl up
Angling the fingers to the side instead of pointing them straight back
injury_prevention_tips: If you have wrist issues, start with very light pressure and gradually increase over time
Stop if you feel sharp pain - stretch to mild tension only, not pain

instructions: Select the appropriate weight using a pulley that is above your head. Attach a rope to the cable and kneel a couple of feet away, holding the rope out in front of you with both arms extended. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by flexing the elbows and fully retracting your shoulders, pulling the rope toward your upper chest with your elbows out.
After pausing briefly, slowly return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Kneeling High Pulley Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable pulley to the highest position and attach a rope handle, selecting an appropriate weight
Kneel on a mat 2-3 feet away from the cable machine, facing it
Grab the rope with both hands and extend your arms fully overhead, leaning back slightly so there's tension on the cable
Pull the rope down toward your upper chest by driving your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades together
Pause for a moment with the rope near your collarbone, then slowly extend your arms back to the starting position
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows down and back toward your hips, not just bending your arms
Imagine trying to crack a walnut between your shoulder blades at the bottom of each rep
Keep your torso stable and upright - don't rock back and forth to create momentum
common_mistakes: Using momentum by rocking the torso instead of using controlled muscle contraction
Pulling with arms only rather than initiating with the shoulder blades
Not pulling deep enough - the rope should come down to at least upper chest level
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to maintain a stable, upright kneeling position
Start with lighter weight to master the movement pattern before progressing

instructions: Kneel on a mat and bring your right knee up so the bottom of your foot is on the floor and extend your left leg out behind you so the top of your foot is on the floor.
Shift your weight forward until you feel a stretch in your hip. Hold for 15 seconds, then repeat for your other side.
exercises.name: Kneeling Hip Flexor
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel on a soft mat with both knees on the ground
Bring your right foot forward so it's flat on the floor with your knee bent at 90 degrees - this creates a lunge position with your back knee down
Keep your left leg behind you with the top of your left foot resting on the mat
Shift your hips forward while keeping your torso upright until you feel a stretch in the front of your left hip
Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about tucking your pelvis under - imagine bringing your tailbone toward your belly button
Keep your chest tall and proud like there's a string pulling the top of your head toward the ceiling
The stretch should be felt in the front of the hip of the back leg, not in the knee
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively, which reduces the hip flexor stretch
Leaning forward with the torso instead of keeping it vertical
Pushing so far forward that the front knee goes past the toes, stressing the knee
injury_prevention_tips: Use adequate padding under your knee - this should be comfortable
Move into the stretch gradually; avoid bouncing or forcing the position

instructions: Attach a single handle to a high pulley and make your weight selection.
Kneel in front of the cable tower, taking the cable with one hand with your arm extended. This will be your starting position.

Starting with your palm facing forward, pull the weight down to your torso by flexing the elbow and retract the shoulder blade. As you do so, rotate the wrist so that at the completion of the movement, your palm is now facing you.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Kneeling Single-Arm High Pulley Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable pulley to the highest position and attach a single handle, selecting your weight
Kneel on a mat facing the cable machine, about 2-3 feet away
Grab the handle with one hand with your palm facing forward and arm fully extended overhead
Pull the handle down to your torso by driving your elbow back and rotating your wrist so your palm faces you at the bottom
Pause briefly, then return to the starting position with control
form_cues: Start the pull by squeezing your shoulder blade down and back - think 'shoulder blade first, elbow second'
As you pull, rotate your hand like you're starting a lawnmower
Keep your non-working hand on your hip or thigh to prevent twisting your torso
common_mistakes: Rotating the torso instead of keeping it square to the machine
Pulling with arm strength only without engaging the back muscles
Rushing through the wrist rotation - it should be smooth and coordinated with the pull
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core tight to resist rotation and protect your spine
Start with light weight to master the rotation pattern before increasing load

instructions: Set the bar to the proper height in a power rack. Kneel behind the bar; it may be beneficial to put a mat down to pad your knees. Slide under the bar, racking it across the back of your shoulders. Your shoulder blades should be retracted and the bar tight across your back. Unrack the weight.
With your head looking forward, sit back with your butt until you touch your calves.
Reverse the motion, returning the torso to an upright position.
exercises.name: Kneeling Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell in a squat rack at about shoulder height and place a mat or pad on the ground
Kneel behind the bar with both knees on the mat, then duck under and position the bar across your upper back
Retract your shoulder blades and create a tight shelf for the bar, then unrack the weight
Sitting back at the hips, lower your glutes toward your calves while keeping your torso upright
Once your glutes touch your calves, drive your hips forward to return to the tall kneeling starting position
form_cues: Think about sitting back into a chair - your hips move backward as you descend
Keep your chest up and eyes forward - imagine a string pulling your sternum toward the ceiling
At the bottom, your glutes should gently kiss your calves - control the descent, don't crash down
common_mistakes: Leaning too far forward with the torso, which shifts load away from glutes
Bouncing off the calves at the bottom instead of using controlled movement
Not achieving full hip extension at the top - squeeze your glutes hard to finish
injury_prevention_tips: Use adequate knee padding - this should be comfortable throughout
Start with just the bar to learn the movement pattern before adding weight

instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or securely anchor it in a corner. Load the bar to an appropriate weight.
Raise the bar from the floor, taking it to shoulder height with both hands with your arms extended in front of you. Adopt a wide stance. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by rotating the trunk and hips as you swing the weight all the way down to one side. Keep your arms extended throughout the exercise.
Reverse the motion to swing the weight all the way to the opposite side.
Continue alternating the movement until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Landmine 180's
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor one end of a barbell in a landmine attachment or corner, and load the other end with weight
Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, pick up the weighted end with both hands, and hold it at shoulder height with arms extended
Rotate your entire torso and hips to one side, swinging the barbell in a big arc down toward hip height on that side
Keep your arms straight and pivot on your feet as needed to allow full rotation
Explosively reverse direction, swinging the bar all the way across to the opposite side at hip height
form_cues: Think of painting a rainbow from one side to the other with the end of the bar
Your arms are just holding on - all the power comes from rotating your core and hips
Pivot your feet naturally - the back foot should come up onto the ball as you rotate
common_mistakes: Keeping feet planted flat, which limits range of motion and can strain knees
Using arm strength to move the bar instead of rotational core power
Moving too fast and losing control of the weight, letting it pull you around
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight - this is a dynamic, explosive movement that requires control
Keep constant tension in your core to protect your spine during rotation

instructions: Position a bar into landmine or, lacking one, securely anchor it in a corner. Load the bar to an appropriate weight and position the handle attachment on the bar.
Raise the bar from the floor, taking the handles to your shoulders. This will be your starting position.
In an athletic stance, squat by flexing your hips and setting your hips back, keeping your arms flexed.

Reverse the motion by powerfully extending through the hips, knees, and ankles, while also extending the elbows to straighten the arms. This movement should be done explosively, coming out of the squat to full extension as powerfully as possible.
Return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Landmine Linear Jammer
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell in a landmine with appropriate weight, attach handles if available
Pick up the weighted end and bring it to your shoulders in a standing position
Stand in an athletic stance with feet shoulder-width apart, then squat down by pushing hips back and bending knees
Explosively drive up through your heels, extending hips, knees, and ankles while simultaneously pressing the bar overhead
Lower the bar back to your shoulders as you descend into the next squat
form_cues: Think 'squat then press' but do it so explosively that they blend into one powerful motion
Use the upward momentum from your legs to help launch the weight overhead
Imagine you're trying to jump through the ceiling - full body explosion
common_mistakes: Pressing before fully extending the legs, which wastes the leg drive power
Pausing between the squat and press instead of using momentum
Not squatting deep enough - aim for at least parallel depth
injury_prevention_tips: This is a high-velocity movement - start light to master coordination
Keep your core braced throughout, especially when catching the weight on your shoulders

instructions: To begin, stand on an exercise band so that tension begins at arm's length. Grasp the handles using a pronated (palms facing your thighs) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The handles should be resting on the sides of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the handles to the sides as you exhale. Continue to lift the handles until they are slightly above parallel. Tip: As you lift the handles, slightly tilt the hand as if you were pouring water and keep your arms extended. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the handles back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lateral Raise - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on the middle of a resistance band with feet hip-width apart
Grab both handles with a neutral grip (palms facing your thighs), arms hanging at your sides
Keep a slight bend in your elbows and maintain it throughout the movement
Raise both handles out to your sides in a wide arc until your arms are roughly parallel to the floor
Pause briefly at the top, then slowly lower back to the starting position
form_cues: Lead with your elbows, not your hands - think about raising your elbows out to the sides
Imagine pouring water out of two pitchers as you reach the top - hands tilt down slightly
Keep your shoulders down away from your ears - don't shrug as you lift
common_mistakes: Swinging or using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction
Raising arms too high (above shoulder level), which shifts work to upper traps
Shrugging shoulders up toward ears instead of keeping them depressed
injury_prevention_tips: Use a band with appropriate resistance - start light as this is an isolation exercise
Keep your torso completely still - don't lean or rotate to help lift the weight

instructions: While lying on the floor, place a foam roll under your back and to one side, just behind your arm pit. This will be your starting position.
Keep the arm of the side being stretched behind and to the side of you as you shift your weight onto your lats, keeping your upper body off of the ground. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and switch sides.
exercises.name: Latissimus Dorsi-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a foam roller on the floor and lie on your side with the roller positioned under your armpit/lat area
Extend the arm of the side you're rolling out to the side or overhead
Keep your bottom leg bent and use it to support your weight as you shift onto the roller
Your upper body should be slightly lifted off the ground, with weight on the roller
Hold pressure on tender spots for 10-30 seconds, then switch to the other side
form_cues: Think about sinking your lat muscle into the roller like you're trying to flatten it
Breathe deeply and try to relax the muscle as you apply pressure
Adjust your body angle slightly forward or backward to target different parts of the lat
common_mistakes: Rolling too far back onto the shoulder blade or too far forward onto the ribs
Moving too quickly back and forth instead of holding pressure on tight spots
Holding your breath - continuous breathing helps the muscle relax
injury_prevention_tips: Start with gentle pressure - you can increase as tolerated
Avoid rolling directly on the armpit or ribcage - stay on the meaty part of the lat muscle

instructions: Lie on the floor with one kettlebell in place on your chest, holding it by the handle. Extend leg on working side over leg on non-working side.Your free arm can be extended out to your side for support.
Press the kettlebll into a locked out position.
Lower the weight until the elbow touches the ground, keeping the kettlebell above the elbow. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Leg-Over Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back on the floor holding a kettlebell on your chest with one hand
Cross your leg on the working side over your opposite leg (if pressing with right hand, cross right leg over left)
Extend your free arm out to the side for stability on the floor
Press the kettlebell straight up until your arm is fully locked out
Lower the kettlebell with control until your elbow touches the floor, keeping the bell directly above your elbow throughout
form_cues: The crossed leg position creates a stable base - think of it as anchoring yourself
Keep the kettlebell stacked directly over your elbow and shoulder - imagine a vertical pole
Your working shoulder blade should stay pulled down and back against the floor
common_mistakes: Letting the kettlebell drift toward your head or feet instead of staying vertical
Allowing the elbow to flare out to the side - it should move in line with your body
Bouncing the elbow off the floor instead of lightly touching and pressing back up
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light kettlebell to learn the stabilization required
The floor limits your range of motion, which actually makes this safer for shoulders than bench pressing

instructions: Lie flat on your back, bend one knee, and put that foot flat on the floor to stabilize your spine.

Extend the other leg in the air. If you're tight, you wont be able to straighten it. That's okay. Extend the knee so that the sole of the lifted foot faces the ceiling (or as close as you can get it).
Slowly straighten the legs as much as possible and then pull the leg toward your nose. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Leg-Up Hamstring Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with both legs extended
Bend your left knee and place that foot flat on the floor to stabilize your lower back
Lift your right leg straight up toward the ceiling as high as flexibility allows - it's okay if your knee is slightly bent
Reach both hands behind your right thigh or calf and gently pull your leg toward your nose
Hold for 15-30 seconds feeling the stretch in your hamstring, then switch legs
form_cues: Keep your lower back pressed flat against the floor - the bent leg helps with this
Think about pulling your toes toward your shin to intensify the stretch
The goal is to straighten the elevated leg as much as possible - work toward it gradually
common_mistakes: Lifting your lower back off the floor, which reduces the hamstring stretch
Bending the knee of the stretching leg excessively - work to straighten it over time
Pulling too aggressively - this should be a gentle, sustained stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your head relaxed on the floor - don't strain your neck
If you can't reach your leg, use a strap or towel looped around your foot

instructions: For this exercise you will need to use a leg extension machine. First choose your weight and sit on the machine with your legs under the pad (feet pointed forward) and the hands holding the side bars. This will be your starting position. Tip: You will need to adjust the pad so that it falls on top of your lower leg (just above your feet). Also, make sure that your legs form a 90-degree angle between the lower and upper leg. If the angle is less than 90-degrees then that means the knee is over the toes which in turn creates undue stress at the knee joint. If the machine is designed that way, either look for another machine or just make sure that when you start executing the exercise you stop going down once you hit the 90-degree angle.
Using your quadriceps, extend your legs to the maximum as you exhale. Ensure that the rest of the body remains stationary on the seat. Pause a second on the contracted position.
Slowly lower the weight back to the original position as you inhale, ensuring that you do not go past the 90-degree angle limit.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.
exercises.name: Leg Extensions
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and adjust the pad so it rests just above your ankles - imagine the pad is a soccer ball you're about to kick
Set your knees at a 90-degree angle (thighs parallel to ground) and grip the side handles like you're holding on during a rollercoaster
Kick your legs straight out like you're kicking a door open, squeezing your quads at the top for one second
Lower slowly back to 90 degrees - imagine lowering a heavy bucket of water without spilling it
Keep your butt glued to the seat the entire time - pretend you're sitting on wet paint
form_cues: Point your toes slightly up and out - like you're showing off new shoes
Squeeze your quads at the top like you're trying to crack a walnut between your thigh muscles
Keep your back pressed flat against the pad - imagine a hand pushing you into the seat
Control the descent - count '1-2-3' on the way down to avoid dropping the weight
common_mistakes: Letting knees go past toes at the bottom (creates more than 90-degree bend) - this puts dangerous stress on the knee joint
Using momentum by rocking the torso back and forth instead of isolated quad contraction
Dropping the weight too fast on the way down instead of controlling the negative portion
injury_prevention_tips: Never lock out your knees completely at the top - keep a micro-bend to protect the joint
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain behind the kneecap - this exercise can aggravate existing knee issues

instructions: While standing up straight with both feet next to each other at around shoulder width, grab a sturdy surface such as the sides of a squat rack or the top of a chair to brace yourself and keep balance.
With or without an ankle weight, lift one leg behind you as if performing a leg curl but standing up while keeping the other leg straight. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
Slowly bring the raised leg back to the floor as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Repeat the movement with the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Leg Lift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall holding a chair or squat rack for balance, feet hip-width apart like you're standing on railroad tracks
Keep your standing leg locked straight like a kickstand, engage your core like someone's about to poke your belly
Kick your working leg straight back like you're closing a car door with your heel, squeeze your glute at the top
Hold for one second at the top - imagine pinching a pencil between your butt cheeks
Lower slowly back to the starting position without letting your toe touch the ground between reps
form_cues: Drive through your heel, not your toe - imagine you're stamping a footprint in mud behind you
Keep your hips square to the front - don't let your hip rotate open like a gate
Think about lifting from your glute, not swinging your leg - quality over height
Maintain a tall posture - pretend you're balancing a book on your head
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively to get the leg higher - this compensates for weak glutes
Leaning forward with the torso instead of staying upright
Swinging the leg with momentum instead of controlled glute contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your core tight before each rep to protect your lower back from hyperextension
Start without ankle weights until you can do 15 reps with perfect form

instructions: Using a leg press machine, sit down on the machine and place your legs on the platform directly in front of you at a medium (shoulder width) foot stance. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Lower the safety bars holding the weighted platform in place and press the platform all the way up until your legs are fully extended in front of you. Tip: Make sure that you do not lock your knees. Your torso and the legs should make a perfect 90-degree angle. This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, slowly lower the platform until your upper and lower legs make a 90-degree angle.
Pushing mainly with the heels of your feet and using the quadriceps go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and ensure to lock the safety pins properly once you are done. You do not want that platform falling on you fully loaded.
exercises.name: Leg Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in the machine with your back and head fully pressed against the pad - imagine you're melting into the seat
Place feet shoulder-width apart in the center of the platform, toes pointing slightly out like 11 and 1 on a clock
Release the safety bars and press up to straight legs (but don't lock knees) - this is your starting position
Lower the platform slowly until your knees form 90 degrees - imagine sitting into an invisible chair
Drive through your heels (not toes) to press back up, exhaling forcefully like you're blowing out birthday candles
form_cues: Push through your heels - imagine trying to push the platform through the ceiling
Keep your lower back glued flat to the pad - never let it peel off or you risk injury
Stop at 90 degrees - your knees should never travel past your toes at the bottom
Keep your head and shoulders pressed back - imagine someone pulling your chest up with a string
common_mistakes: Letting your lower back round and lift off the pad at the bottom - this is extremely dangerous for your spine
Going too deep past 90 degrees which puts excessive stress on the knees
Locking out the knees at the top which transfers tension from muscles to joints
injury_prevention_tips: ALWAYS lock the safety bars back before exiting - never let the platform rest on your legs unsecured
If your lower back starts lifting, you're going too deep - reduce range of motion immediately

instructions: Lie on an exercise mat with your legs extended and your hands either palms facing down next to you or under your glutes. Tip: My preference is with the hands next to me. This will be your starting position.

Bend your knees and pull your upper thighs into your midsection as you breathe out. Continue the motion until your knees are around chest level. Contract your abs as you execute this movement and hold for a second at the top. Tip: As you perform the motion, the lower legs (calves) should always remain parallel to the floor.
Return to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Leg Pull-In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with legs straight out, hands either by your sides or under your butt for support
Engage your core like you're bracing for a punch, keep your lower back pressed to the floor
Pull your knees toward your chest by bending at the hips and knees - imagine pulling your knees into a cannonball position
Squeeze your abs hard at the top and hold for one second - think about crunching your ribcage toward your pelvis
Extend legs back out slowly without letting your feet touch the ground - keep constant tension on your abs
form_cues: Keep your lower legs parallel to the ground throughout - imagine you're dragging your feet along the ceiling
Pull with your abs, not your hip flexors - focus on bringing your pelvis toward your chest, not just bending your legs
Exhale forcefully as you pull in - make a 'tss' sound like you're deflating a tire
Keep your head and shoulders relaxed on the floor - don't crane your neck forward
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing legs in and out instead of controlled ab contraction
Letting lower back arch off the floor when extending legs - this shifts work away from abs and strains the spine
Pulling with hip flexors only rather than engaging the deep abdominal muscles
injury_prevention_tips: Press your lower back into the floor the entire time - if it arches, don't extend your legs as far
Place hands under your glutes for extra lower back support if you're a beginner

instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the bottom or middle of the pectorals at the beginning of the motion.
Your chest and head should be up and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles forward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Leverage Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles align with the middle or bottom of your chest, sit with your back fully pressed against the pad
Retract your shoulder blades together - imagine pinching a pencil between them - and puff your chest out
Grip the handles and press forward by straightening your arms - imagine pushing someone away from you
Stop just before lockout and squeeze your chest like you're hugging a beach ball
Return slowly to just above the start position - keep tension on your chest by not letting the weight stack touch
form_cues: Lead with your knuckles forward, not your elbows - imagine punching straight ahead
Keep your shoulder blades pinned back the entire time - they should never roll forward
Think 'chest drives the movement' - focus on squeezing your pecs, not just pushing with arms
Maintain three points of contact: head, upper back, and butt all pressed firmly into the pads
common_mistakes: Letting shoulders roll forward at the top - this shifts tension from chest to front delts and can cause impingement
Fully locking out elbows which removes tension from chest muscles
Bouncing the weight stack between reps instead of maintaining constant tension
injury_prevention_tips: Never let your shoulders shrug up toward your ears - keep them down and back to protect the rotator cuff
If you feel shoulder pain, lower the handles or reduce the weight immediately

instructions: Load the pins to an appropriate weight. Position yourself directly between the handles. Grasp the bottom handles with a comfortable grip, and then lower your hips as you take a breath. Look forward with your head and keep your chest up. This will be your starting position.
Return the weight to the starting position.
exercises.name: Leverage Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand directly between the handles, feet hip-width apart, and grip the bottom handles with a comfortable grip
Drop your hips low, chest up proud like you're showing off a logo on your shirt, and take a deep breath
Look straight ahead (not down), engage your lats by imagining squeezing oranges in your armpits
Drive through your heels and stand up explosively - imagine pushing the floor away from you
Lower the weight by pushing your hips back first, then bending knees - like closing a car trunk with your butt
form_cues: Keep the bar path close to your body - imagine dragging it up your shins and thighs
Hips and shoulders rise together - don't let your butt shoot up first like a seesaw
Squeeze your glutes hard at the top - finish like you're standing at attention
Maintain a neutral spine - imagine balancing a broomstick along your back from head to tailbone
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back by not engaging the core and lats properly
Starting with hips too high which turns it into a stiff-leg deadlift
Jerking the weight off the ground instead of building tension first
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your core hard before every rep - take a deep breath and hold it until you reach the top
If your back starts rounding, stop immediately and reduce the weight - a rounded spine under load risks serious injury

instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the bottom of the pectorals at the beginning of the motion. Your chest and head should be up and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles forward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Leverage Decline Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat and lie back on the decline bench with handles at the bottom of your pecs
Plant your feet firmly on the floor or footrests, retract your shoulder blades like you're pinching them together
Grip the handles and press forward and slightly upward - imagine pushing away a heavy door at chest level
Squeeze your lower chest hard at the top for one second - think about flexing your pecs together
Lower slowly back to starting position, stopping just before the weight stack touches
form_cues: Drive with your lower chest - imagine pushing from the bottom of your sternum
Keep your shoulder blades glued together - never let them peel apart
Press in a slight upward arc toward your chin, not straight forward
Maintain tension by not letting the plates crash together at the bottom
common_mistakes: Flaring elbows out too wide which stresses the shoulder joint instead of working the chest
Pressing straight forward instead of slightly upward, reducing lower chest activation
Letting shoulder blades protract (round forward) which causes shoulder instability
injury_prevention_tips: Keep elbows at about 45 degrees from your body - not tucked tight or flared at 90 degrees
Stop immediately if you feel pinching in the front of your shoulder

instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat height so that you can just reach the handles above you. Adjust the knee pad to help keep you down. Grasp the handles with a pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Pull the handles towards your torso, retracting your shoulder blades as you flex the elbow.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return the handles to the starting position.
For multiple repetitions, avoid completely returning the weight to the stops to keep tension on the muscles being worked.
exercises.name: Leverage High Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so you can just reach the overhead handles, secure the knee pad to keep you anchored
Grab the handles with an overhand grip (palms facing away), sit tall with chest up
Pull the handles down toward your upper chest by driving your elbows down and back - imagine doing a double bicep pose
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard at the bottom - think about pinching a pencil between them
Slowly return to the start position with arms extended overhead, but don't let the weight stack crash
form_cues: Lead with your elbows, not your hands - think 'elbows to hip pockets'
Imagine pulling your elbows through the floor behind you
Keep your chest proud and pushed forward - don't round your upper back
Focus on your upper back doing the work, not your biceps - squeeze those shoulder blades together
common_mistakes: Using momentum and rocking back and forth instead of controlled pulling
Pulling with arms only instead of retracting shoulder blades first
Letting the weight slam back to the starting position instead of controlling the eccentric
injury_prevention_tips: Don't lean back excessively - keep your torso relatively upright to protect your lower back
Adjust knee pad tight enough to keep you anchored but not so tight it cuts off circulation

instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the top of the pectorals at the beginning of the motion. Your chest and head should be up and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles forward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Leverage Incline Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so handles align with the top of your chest near your collarbones
Sit back with chest up, head and shoulders pressed into the pad, shoulder blades squeezed together
Press the handles forward and slightly upward - imagine pushing a heavy object up and away from your upper chest
Squeeze your upper chest at full extension for one second - think about flexing like you're in armor
Lower slowly back to the start, keeping tension by not letting the weight plates touch
form_cues: Drive the movement from your upper chest - feel the squeeze near your collarbones
Keep your shoulder blades retracted - imagine they're super-glued together
Press upward at a 30-45 degree angle, not straight forward
Think 'chest leads, arms follow' - don't just push with your triceps
common_mistakes: Letting shoulders roll forward and losing the shoulder blade retraction
Pressing straight forward instead of upward, reducing upper chest activation
Arching the lower back excessively to help push the weight
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your head pressed back against the pad - don't crane your neck forward
If you feel shoulder clicking or pain, the handles may be too far back - adjust the seat forward

instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. Grasp the handles with either a neutral or pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Pull the handles towards your torso, retracting your shoulder blades as you flex the elbow.

Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return the handles to the starting position. For multiple repetitions, avoid completely returning the weight to the stops to keep tension on the muscles being worked.
exercises.name: Leverage Iso Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles are at chest height, sit with your chest against the pad for support
Grab the handles with either a neutral grip (palms facing each other) or overhand grip
Pull the handles toward your torso by driving your elbows straight back - imagine elbowing someone behind you
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard for one second - think about crushing a soda can between them
Slowly extend arms back to the start without letting the weight stack crash down
form_cues: Lead with your elbows, not your hands - imagine your hands are just hooks
Keep your chest pressed firmly into the pad - don't lean back away from it
Think 'row to your hips' - pull back in a straight line, not upward or downward
Focus on your mid-back doing the work - your biceps are just along for the ride
common_mistakes: Pulling with biceps only instead of initiating the movement with shoulder blade retraction
Using momentum by rocking forward and back instead of isolated back contraction
Shrugging shoulders up toward ears instead of keeping them down and back
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulders pulled down away from your ears throughout the movement to avoid neck strain
Don't hyperextend at the end of the row - pull back to where your elbows are just behind your torso

instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the top of the shoulders at the beginning of the motion. Your chest and head should be up and handles held with a pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles upward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight to just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Leverage Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit down and adjust the seat so the handles are level with your upper shouldersthink of them being at ear height
Grab the handles with palms facing away from you, chest proud like you're showing off a medal
Press the handles straight up overhead until your arms are fully extendedimagine pushing the ceiling away
Lower back down with control until handles reach shoulder height, keeping constant tension on your delts
Stop just before the weight stack touchesdon't let the muscles rest between reps
form_cues: Keep your core braced like someone's about to punch your stomach throughout the entire press
Press the handles up and slightly backimagine following the natural arc of an overhead press, not straight up like an elevator
Squeeze your shoulder blades down and back into the padpretend you're trying to hold a pencil between them
At the top, finish strong like you're reaching for the ceiling with your head stilldon't let your head jut forward
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively when pressingthis means the weight is too heavy or core isn't engaged
Not going through full range of motionstopping too high on the descent leaves gains on the table
Using momentum or bouncing the weight at the bottomthis turns it into a push exercise instead of a controlled press
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel shoulder pinching or discomfort at the top, adjust the seat heightyour shoulder joint should feel comfortable throughout
Keep your head neutral against the back paddon't crane your neck forward as this can strain cervical spine

instructions: Load the pins to an appropriate weight. Position yourself directly between the handles.
Grasp the top handles with a comfortable grip, and then lower your hips as you take a breath. Look forward with your head and keep your chest up.

Drive through the floor with your heels, extending your hips and knees as you rise to a standing position. Keep your arms straight throughout the movement, finishing with your shoulders back. This will be your starting position.
Raise the weight by shrugging the shoulders towards your ears, moving straight up and down.
Pause at the top of the motion, and then return the weight to the starting position.
exercises.name: Leverage Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load the weight and stand directly between the handles with feet hip-width apart
Grab the top handles, drop your hips down like you're about to jump, chest up and proud
Drive through your heels to stand up explosively, keeping arms completely straightthink of your arms as hooks, not levers
Once standing tall, shrug your shoulders straight up toward your earsimagine trying to touch your ears with your shoulders
Hold the squeeze at the top for a full second, then lower your shoulders back down with control
form_cues: Think 'elevators not circles'your traps move straight up and down, no rolling shoulders forward or backward
At the top of the shrug, pretend you're trying to pinch your ears with your shoulders while keeping your head still
Keep your head neutralimagine balancing a book on your head throughout the movement
Your arms stay dead straight the entire timeif your elbows bend, you're stealing work from your traps
common_mistakes: Rolling the shoulders in a circular motion instead of straight upthis doesn't add benefit and can cause shoulder irritation
Bending the elbows and using biceps to helpthis is a trap exercise, not an arm exercise
Using momentum and bouncing at the bottomsmooth and controlled gets better trap activation
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let your head drop forwardkeep a neutral neck position to avoid cervical spine strain
Start with lighter weight to master the straight up-down motion before loading heavy

instructions: Attach a climbing rope to a high beam or cross member. Below it, ensure that the smith machine bar is locked in place with the safeties and cannot move. Alternatively, a secure box could also be utilized.
Stand on the bar, using the rope to balance yourself. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lean back and lower your body by slowly going hand over hand with the rope. Continue until you are perpendicular to the ground.
Keeping your body straight, reverse the motion, going hand over hand back to the starting position.
exercises.name: London Bridges
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a climbing rope from above with a secure bar or box below that you can stand on safely
Stand on the bar holding the rope with both hands for balance, body completely vertical
Keep your entire body rigid like a plank, then begin lowering yourself by hand-over-hand down the rope while leaning back
Continue until your body is horizontal to the ground (parallel with the floor), arms extended holding the rope
Pull yourself back up hand-over-hand until you're standing vertical again, maintaining that rigid body position
form_cues: Your body is one solid steel beam from head to toedon't let your hips sag or pike up
Imagine a laser beam shooting from your chest that stays pointed at the same spot on the ceiling as you lower
Squeeze your glutes hard like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeksthis keeps your body straight
Control the descentpretend you're slowly laying down on an invisible bed, not falling backward
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag or fold, breaking the plank positionthis makes it easier but defeats the purpose
Going too fast on the descent and losing controlthis is about controlled strength, not speed
Not going all the way to horizontalpartial reps mean partial results
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure your setup is completely secure before attemptingtest the rope and bar with partial weight first
Build up core strength with planks and hanging leg raises before attempting this advanced move

instructions: Kneel on the floor, holding your heels with both hands.
Lift your buttocks up and forward while bringing your head back to look up at the ceiling, to give an arch in your back.
exercises.name: Looking At Ceiling
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel on a mat with knees hip-width apart, reaching both hands back to grab your heels
Push your hips forward and up while keeping your hands on your heelsimagine someone pulling your hips forward with a rope
Simultaneously drop your head back gently to look up at the ceiling behind you
Hold this arched position for 20-30 seconds while breathing normally, feeling the stretch through your quads and hip flexors
form_cues: Push your hips forward like you're trying to show off your belt buckle to someone in front of you
Think 'lift and arch'your hips drive up and forward while your chest opens to the ceiling
Let your head drop back naturallyimagine your head is heavy and you're just letting gravity take it back gently
Keep breathing deeplythis stretch is intense, so don't hold your breath
common_mistakes: Collapsing the hips back instead of pushing them forwardthis reduces the stretch significantly
Cranking the head back too aggressivelylet gravity do the work, don't force it
Holding breath due to intensityremember to breathe throughout the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: If you have lower back issues, limit how far you arch back and don't force the stretch
Come out of the stretch slowlydon't snap back up quickly as this can cause dizziness

instructions: To move into the starting position, place the pulleys at the low position, select the resistance to be used and grasp a handle in each hand.
Step forward, gaining tension in the pulleys. Your palms should be facing forward, hands below the waist, and your arms straight. This will be your starting position.
With a slight bend in your arms, draw your hands upward and toward the midline of your body. Your hands should come together in front of your chest, palms facing up.
Return your arms back to the starting position after a brief pause.
exercises.name: Low Cable Crossover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set both cable pulleys to the lowest position and select a light weight to start
Grab a handle in each hand and step forward until there's tension in the cables, arms straight down by your sides
With a slight bend in your elbows (like you're hugging a beach ball), bring your hands up and together in front of your chest
Your hands should meet at chest height with palms facing up, like you're scooping water up to your chest
Slowly lower your arms back down to the starting position, maintaining that slight elbow bend throughout
form_cues: Imagine you're scooping up a huge beach ball from the ground and lifting it to your chestkeep that big arc motion
At the top, squeeze your pecs hard like you're trying to crush a can between your chest muscles
Your elbows stay slightly bent the entire timethink 'hugging motion' not 'arm curls'
Lean slightly forward from the hips for better stabilitypretend you're in a power stance
common_mistakes: Straightening the arms completely or bending them too muchthis should be a sweeping arc, not a press or curl
Using too much weight and losing the smooth arc motiongo lighter and focus on the squeeze
Leaning back instead of forwardthis can strain the lower back and reduces chest engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the arc motionheavy weight with poor form can strain shoulder joints
Keep a slight forward lean and engage your core to protect your lower back
