instructions: Select the desired weight and lay down face up on the bench of a seated row machine that has a rope attached to it. Your head should be pointing towards the attachment.
Grab the outside of the rope ends with your palms facing each other (neutral grip).

Position your elbows so that they are bent at a 90 degree angle and your upper arms are perpendicular (90 degree angle) to your torso. Tip: Keep the elbows in and make sure that the upper arms point to the ceiling while your forearms point towards the pulley above your head. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, extend your lower arms until they are straight and vertical. The upper arms and elbows remain stationary throughout the movement. Only the forearms should move. Contract the triceps hard for a second.
As you breathe in slowly return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Low Cable Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-up on a bench with your head toward a low cable attachment with a rope handle
Grab the rope ends with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) and position your upper arms perpendicular to your body, pointing at the ceiling
Bend your elbows to 90 degrees so your forearms point back toward the cablethis is your starting position
Keeping your upper arms completely still, extend your forearms straight up toward the ceiling until your arms are fully locked out
Squeeze your triceps hard at the top, then slowly lower back to the 90-degree starting position
form_cues: Your upper arms are frozen in spacepretend they're bolted to the ceiling, only your forearms move
At the top, imagine squeezing a lemon in your armpitthis maximizes triceps contraction
Think 'hammer down'you're driving your forearms straight up like hammering a nail into the ceiling
Keep your elbows pointing up the entire timeif they flare out to the sides, your form is breaking down
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drift forward or to the sides during the extensionthis reduces triceps activation
Moving the upper arms during the reponly the forearms should move from the elbow joint
Rushing the negative (lowering phase)the slow descent is where a lot of growth happens
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let the cable pull your arms back beyond 90 degrees at the startthis can strain the shoulder joint
If you feel elbow pain, reduce weight and ensure you're not locking out too aggressively

instructions: Sit on a low pulley row machine with a rope attachment.

Grab the ends of the rope using a palms-down grip and sit with your back straight and your knees slightly bent. Tip: Keep your back almost completely vertical and your arms fully extended in front of you. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your torso stationary, lift your elbows and start bending them as you pull the rope towards your neck while exhaling. Throughout the movement your upper arms should remain parallel to the floor. Tip: Continue this motion until your hands are almost next to your ears (the forearms will not be parallel to the floor at the end of the movement as they will be angled a bit upwards) and your elbows are out away from your sides.
After holding for a second or so at the contracted position, come back slowly to the starting position as you inhale. Tip: Again, during no part of the movement should the torso move.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Low Pulley Row To Neck
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a low cable row machine with a rope attachment, grab the rope ends with palms down
Sit up tall with your back straight (almost vertical), arms fully extended in front of you, knees slightly bent
Pull the rope toward your neck by raising your elbows out to the sides, keeping your upper arms parallel to the floor
Continue pulling until your hands are near your ears and your elbows are flared out wide to the sides
Hold for one second squeezing your rear delts, then slowly return to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'elbows high and wide'imagine drawing your elbows back like you're opening a curtain to your sides
Your upper arms should stay parallel to the floor throughoutpretend you're balancing a broomstick on your upper arms
At the peak, squeeze your shoulder blades together like you're crushing a grape between them
Keep your torso completely stillpretend you're wearing a back brace that prevents any forward/back movement
common_mistakes: Letting the torso rock forward and backwardthis turns it into a momentum exercise instead of isolating rear delts
Pulling with elbows down instead of out to the sidesthis shifts work to the lats instead of rear delts
Not pulling high enough toward the neckstopping at chest height misses the rear delt contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Start lightthis is a rear delt isolation move, not a heavy rowing exercise
If you feel shoulder pinching, adjust the height or reduce weight

instructions: In a seated position, place a foam roll under your lower back. Cross your arms in front of you and protract your shoulders. This will be your starting position.

Raise your hips off of the floor and lean back, keeping your weight on your lower back. Now shift your weight slightly to one side, keeping your weight off of the spine and on the muscles to the side of it. Roll over your lower back, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.name: Lower Back-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor and place a foam roller under your lower back, crossing your arms over your chest
Lift your hips off the ground and shift your weight slightly to one side, keeping weight off your spine
Slowly roll over the muscles on the side of your spine (not directly on the spine itself), moving a few inches at a time
When you hit a tender spot, pause and hold pressure there for 10-30 seconds while breathing deeply
Switch to the other side and repeat the rolling process
form_cues: Stay OFF the spineimagine the spine is lava and you're only rolling on the muscles to the sides
Move in tiny incrementsthink 'inch by inch' not 'roll back and forth quickly'
When you find a trigger point, sink into it like you're melting butterdon't tense up
Use your feet to control the pressurepush more through your feet if you need to lighten the pressure
common_mistakes: Rolling directly on the spinethis can cause injury and doesn't release the muscles properly
Rolling too fast without pausing on tender spotsslow and deliberate is more effective
Holding breath when hitting painful areasbreathe through the discomfort to help muscles release
injury_prevention_tips: NEVER roll directly on your spinealways shift to the muscles on either side
If you have acute lower back pain or injury, skip this and consult a professional first

instructions: Lie on your stomach with your arms out to your sides. This will be your starting position.
Using your lower back muscles, extend your spine lifting your chest off of the ground. Do not use your arms to push yourself up. Keep your head up during the movement. Repeat for 10-20 repetitions.
exercises.name: Lower Back Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor with your arms extended out to your sides like a 'T' shape
Keep your arms relaxed on the floordon't push with them at all during this movement
Using only your lower back muscles, lift your chest and upper body off the ground while keeping your hips on the floor
Look forward and up slightly as you lift, like you're trying to see over a fence in front of you
Lower back down with control and repeat for 10-20 controlled reps
form_cues: Pretend someone is gently pulling your chest up toward the ceiling with a stringyour lower back does all the work
Your arms are just along for the ridekeep them completely relaxed, no pushing
Squeeze your glutes lightly to protect your spinelike you're holding a credit card between your cheeks
Think 'lift and arch'your chest rises while creating a smooth arch in your lower back
common_mistakes: Pushing with the arms to assistthis defeats the purpose of isolating the lower back muscles
Hyperextending and coming up too higha moderate lift is sufficient and safer
Letting the head drop or cranking it back too farmaintain a neutral neck aligned with your spine
injury_prevention_tips: Don't lift too higha few inches off the ground is enough to work the lower back safely
If you have existing lower back issues, start with smaller range of motion or skip this exercise

instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding a kettlebell in your right hand. This will be your starting position.
Step forward with your left foot and lower your upper body down by flexing the hip and the knee, keeping the torso upright. Lower your back knee until it nearly touches the ground.
As you lunge, pass the kettlebell under your front leg to your opposite hand.
Pressing through the heel of your foot, return to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the recommended amount of repetitions, alternating legs.
exercises.name: Lunge Pass Through
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall holding a kettlebell in your right hand at your side
Step forward with your left leg and lower down into a lunge until your back knee nearly touches the ground
As you reach the bottom of the lunge, pass the kettlebell under your front thigh from right hand to left hand
Drive through your front heel to explosively return to standing position
Repeat on the opposite leg, continuing to pass the kettlebell under the front leg each rep
form_cues: The pass-through happens at the bottom of the lungethink 'lunge, pass, drive up'
Keep your torso upright like you're balancing a book on your headdon't lean forward when passing the kettlebell
Your front knee tracks over your toesimagine your knee is following a train track straight forward
Drive through your front heel like you're pushing the floor awaythis powers you back to standing
common_mistakes: Leaning forward excessively when passing the bellthis compromises balance and reduces leg activation
Letting the front knee cave inwardkeep it tracking in line with your toes
Not lowering deep enough in the lungeyour back knee should almost kiss the ground for full range
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light kettlebell to master the coordination before going heavier
If you feel knee pain, ensure your front knee isn't traveling too far past your toes

instructions: Adjust a bar in a Smith machine to an appropriate height. Position yourself under the bar, racking it across the back of your shoulders. Unrack the bar, and then split your feet, moving one foot forward and one foot back. This will be your starting position.
Lower your back knee nearly to the ground, flexing the knees and lowering your hips as you do so.

At the bottom of the descent, immediately reverse direction. Explosively drive through the heel of your front foot with light pressure from your back foot. Jump up and reverse the position of your legs.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lunge Sprint
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a Smith machine bar at shoulder height and position it across your upper back like a backpack
Step forward with one foot into a split stance - imagine you're on railroad tracks, not a tightrope
Drop your back knee toward the floor while keeping your torso upright - like you're proposing
Explosively jump up and switch your legs mid-air - drive through your front heel like you're launching off a springboard
Land softly with opposite leg forward and immediately drop into the next lunge
form_cues: Keep your chest proud and tall - imagine a string pulling your sternum toward the ceiling
Front knee stays behind your toes - think about sitting back into your front heel
Drive through the heel of your front foot - pretend you're crushing a can under your heel
Land like a ninja - control the descent to protect your knees
common_mistakes: Letting the front knee cave inward instead of tracking over the toes
Landing with stiff legs which puts excessive stress on the knees
Leaning too far forward instead of maintaining an upright torso
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight or very light load until you master the coordination of the jump
Always land with soft, bent knees - never lock out your legs on landing

instructions: Lie on your back with your knees bent and the soles of the feet pressed together. Have your partner hold your knees. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to squeeze your knees together, while your partner prevents any movement from occurring.
After 10-20 seconds, relax your muscles as your partner gently pushes your knees towards the floor. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching.
exercises.name: Lying Bent Leg Groin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back and bring the soles of your feet together with knees bent out to the sides - like a butterfly position
Have your partner place their hands on the inside of your knees for resistance
Try to squeeze your knees together against your partner's resistance for 10-20 seconds - engage your inner thighs hard
Relax completely and let your partner gently push your knees toward the floor
Communicate with your partner - tell them when to stop pushing to avoid overstretching
form_cues: During the squeeze, think about bringing your knees together like you're clapping with your legs
Keep your lower back pressed to the floor - don't arch
When relaxing, breathe out slowly and let gravity help - don't fight it
Your partner should push gradually, not forcefully - this is a gentle stretch
common_mistakes: Holding your breath during the contraction phase - remember to breathe
Partner pushing too aggressively during the stretch phase causing injury
Tensing up during the relaxation phase instead of fully releasing the muscles
injury_prevention_tips: Always communicate clearly with your partner about your comfort level
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain - stretching should feel like gentle tension, not pain

instructions: Grab a straight bar or E-Z bar attachment that is attached to the low pulley with both hands, using an underhand (palms facing up) shoulder-width grip.
Lie flat on your back on top of an exercise mat in front of the weight stack with your feet flat against the frame of the pulley machine and your legs straight.
With your arms extended and your elbows close to your body slightly bend your arms. This will be your starting position.
While keeping your upper arms stationary and the elbows close to your body, curl the bar up slowly toward your chest as you breathe out and you squeeze the biceps.
After a second squeeze at the top of the movement, slowly return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight bar to the low pulley and lie flat on your back with feet braced against the machine frame
Grab the bar with an underhand grip (palms up) at shoulder width, arms extended toward the pulley
Keep elbows pinned to your sides and slightly bend your arms to start - this is your starting position
Curl the bar toward your chest by bending only at the elbows - imagine pulling the bar into a hug
Squeeze your biceps hard at the top for one second, then slowly lower back to the start
form_cues: Pin your elbows to your sides like they're glued there - they shouldn't move at all
Curl in a smooth arc - think of your forearms as moving along the inside of a barrel
Squeeze at the top like you're flexing for a photo - really contract those biceps
Lower slowly with control - count '1-2-3' on the way down
common_mistakes: Letting elbows drift away from the body which reduces bicep isolation
Using momentum by rocking the torso instead of strict arm movement
Dropping the weight too fast on the negative instead of controlling the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Keep constant tension on the cable - don't let the weight stack crash between reps
If you feel elbow pain, reduce the weight and focus on perfect form

instructions: Place a cambered bar underneath an exercise bench.
Lie face down on the exercise bench and grab the bar using a palms down (pronated grip) that is wider than shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale row the bar up as you keep the elbows close to your body to either your chest, in order to target the upper mid back, or to your stomach if targeting the lats is your goal.
After a second hold at the top, lower back down to the starting position slowly as you inhale.
exercises.name: Lying Cambered Barbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a cambered bar under a flat bench, then lie face-down on the bench with chest and stomach pressed flat
Reach down and grab the bar with an overhand grip wider than shoulder width
Pull the bar up toward your chest (for upper back) or stomach (for lats) by driving your elbows back
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard at the top - imagine crushing a tennis ball between them
Lower slowly back down with control, but don't let the bar touch the ground until your set is done
form_cues: Lead with your elbows, not your hands - think 'elbows to ceiling'
Keep your chest glued to the bench - don't arch up to help pull
Row to your chest for upper back, to your stomach for lats - adjust your target zone
Squeeze hard at the top - pretend you're pinching a pencil between your shoulder blades
common_mistakes: Lifting chest off the bench to use momentum instead of pure back strength
Pulling with arms only instead of initiating with shoulder blade retraction
Using too much weight and getting insufficient range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral - look straight down at the floor, don't crane your head up
Start with lighter weight to master the shoulder blade squeeze pattern first

instructions: Place a flat bench in front of a high pulley or lat pulldown machine.
Hold the straight bar attachment using an underhand grip (palms up) that is about shoulder width.
Lie on your back with your head over the end of the bench.
Now extend your arms straight above your shoulders. Your torso and your arms should make a 90-degree angle and the elbows should be in. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, curl the bar down in a semicircular motion until it touches your chin. Squeeze the biceps for a second at the top contracted position. Tip: As you execute this motion only the forearms should move. At no time should the upper arms be moving at all. They are to remain perpendicular throughout the movement.
Return to starting position slowly.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Close-Grip Bar Curl On High Pulley
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a flat bench in front of a high pulley or lat machine, attach a straight bar
Lie on your back with your head near the end of the bench, grab the bar with an underhand grip at shoulder width
Extend your arms straight up so they're perpendicular to your body (90 degrees) - this is your starting position
Curl the bar down in an arc toward your chin, keeping your upper arms completely still
Squeeze your biceps at the bottom when the bar touches your chin, then slowly return to the start
form_cues: Lock your upper arms in place - imagine they're frozen in cement
Only your forearms move - pretend your elbows are hinges that don't slide
Curl in a smooth arc - like drawing a rainbow from overhead to your chin
Keep constant tension on the cable - never let the weight stack touch between reps
common_mistakes: Letting upper arms drop down toward your body instead of staying perpendicular
Using momentum by jerking the bar instead of smooth, controlled curls
Not getting full range of motion - make sure the bar touches your chin at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your elbows in - don't let them flare out wide which stresses the shoulder joint
If you feel shoulder strain, reduce the weight or adjust your arm angle slightly

instructions: While holding a barbell or EZ Curl bar with a pronated grip (palms facing forward), lie on your back on a flat bench with your head close to the end of the bench. Tip: If you are holding a barbell grab it using a shoulder-width grip and if you are using an E-Z Bar grab it on the inner handles.

Extend your arms in front of you and slowly bring the bar back in a semi circular motion (while keeping the arms extended) to a position over your head. At the end of this step your arms should be overhead and parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: Keep your elbows in at all times.
As you inhale, lower the bar by bending at the elbows and while keeping the upper arm stationary. Keep lowering the bar until your forearms are perpendicular to the floor.

As you exhale bring the bar back up to the starting position by pushing the bar up in a semi-circular motion until the lower arms are also parallel to the floor. Contract the triceps hard at the top of the movement for a second. Tip: Again, only the forearms should move. The upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Extension Behind The Head
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding an EZ bar with a shoulder-width overhand grip, head close to the bench edge
Extend arms straight up, then slowly arc the bar back overhead until your arms are parallel to the floor - this is your start position
Lower the bar by bending only at the elbows until your forearms are perpendicular to the floor
Press the bar back up in a smooth arc to the starting position, squeezing your triceps hard
Keep your upper arms locked in place overhead throughout - only your forearms should move
form_cues: Upper arms stay frozen overhead and parallel to the floor - imagine them in a cast
Elbows stay tucked in close together - think about keeping them in a narrow tunnel
Lower with control - imagine you're lowering a fragile object behind your head
Press back up with triceps, not shoulders - focus on the burn in the back of your arms
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out wide instead of staying tucked in
Allowing upper arms to drop down during the movement instead of staying parallel to the floor
Using too much weight and getting insufficient range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to prevent arching your lower back excessively
If you feel elbow pain, reduce the weight - this exercise puts significant stress on the elbow joint

instructions: While holding a barbell or EZ Curl bar with a pronated grip (palms facing forward), lie on your back on a flat bench with your head off the end of the bench. Tip: If you are holding a barbell grab it using a shoulder-width grip and if you are using an E-Z Bar grab it on the inner handles.
Extend your arms in front of you as you hold the barbell over your chest. The arms should be perpendicular to your torso (90-degree angle). This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, lower the bar in a semi-circular motion by bending at the elbows and while keeping the upper arm stationary and elbows in. Keep lowering the bar until it lightly touches your chin.

As you exhale bring the bar back up to the starting position by pushing the bar up in a semi-circular motion. Contract the triceps hard at the top of the movement for a second. Tip: Again, only the forearms should move. The upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Press To Chin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding an EZ bar with shoulder-width overhand grip, head off the end of the bench
Start with arms extended straight up perpendicular to your body (90-degree angle)
Lower the bar in an arc by bending at the elbows until it lightly touches your chin
Press the bar back up in a smooth semi-circular motion, squeezing your triceps at the top
Keep your upper arms completely stationary - only your forearms should move
form_cues: Upper arms stay perpendicular to your torso - imagine they're steel rods that don't move
Elbows stay tucked in - think about keeping them in a narrow corridor
Lower the bar to your chin in a controlled arc - like painting a rainbow
Squeeze your triceps at the top - make a mental connection to the back of your arms working
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out instead of staying tucked close to your body
Allowing upper arms to move during the exercise instead of isolating forearm movement
Bouncing the bar off your chin instead of lightly touching it
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - this exercise puts significant stress on the elbow joints
Keep movements smooth and controlled to avoid jamming the bar into your face

instructions: Lie on your back with your legs extended.

Cross one leg over your body with the knee bent, attempting to touch the knee to the ground. Your partner should kneel beside you, holding your shoulder down with one hand and controlling the crossed leg with the other. this will be your starting position.
Attempt to raise the bent knee off of the ground as your partner prevents any actual movement.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the leg as your partner gently presses the knee towards the floor. Repeat with the other side.
exercises.name: Lying Crossover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with both legs extended straight
Bend one knee and cross it over your body toward the opposite side - try to touch your knee to the floor
Your partner should kneel beside you, holding your shoulder down with one hand and your crossed leg with the other
Try to lift your bent knee off the ground while your partner prevents any movement - hold for 10-20 seconds
Relax completely and let your partner gently press your knee toward the floor for a deeper stretch
form_cues: Keep your opposite shoulder pinned to the floor - don't let it lift up
During the contraction, push firmly but don't strain - aim for about 70% effort
When relaxing, exhale slowly and let your muscles go completely limp
Look toward the side opposite your crossed leg to enhance the spinal twist
common_mistakes: Lifting the opposite shoulder off the ground which reduces the stretch effectiveness
Holding breath during the contraction instead of breathing normally
Partner pushing too hard during the stretch phase causing injury
injury_prevention_tips: Always communicate with your partner - tell them immediately if the stretch is too intense
Stop if you feel sharp pain in your lower back or hip - mild tension is good, pain is not

instructions: Lie on a flat bench while holding two dumbbells directly in front of you. Your arms should be fully extended at a 90-degree angle from your torso and the floor. The palms should be facing in and the elbows should be tucked in. This is the starting position.
As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary with the elbows in, slowly lower the weight until the dumbbells are near your ears.
At that point, while keeping the elbows in and the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to bring the weight back up to the starting position as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Dumbbell Tricep Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding two dumbbells straight up above your chest with arms fully extended
Turn your palms to face each other (neutral grip) and tuck your elbows in close to your body
Lower the dumbbells by bending only at the elbows until they're near your ears
Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position by extending your elbows, squeezing your triceps
Keep your upper arms locked in place throughout - only your forearms should move
form_cues: Upper arms stay perpendicular to the floor like posts - they should be completely still
Elbows stay tucked in tight - imagine squeezing a towel between your arms and ribs
Lower the weights like you're bringing headphones to your ears
Press up with triceps power - feel the back of your arms doing the work
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out wide instead of staying tucked in
Allowing upper arms to drop back during the movement instead of staying vertical
Using momentum and bouncing at the bottom instead of controlled movement
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter dumbbells than you think you need - this is an isolation exercise
If you feel sharp elbow pain, reduce the weight immediately

instructions: Lie face down with your whole body straight on a flat bench while holding a weight plate behind your head. Tip: You will need to position yourself so that your shoulders are slightly above the end of a flat bench in order for the upper chest, neck and face to be off the bench. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the plate secure on the back of your head slowly lower your head (as in saying yes) as you breathe in.
Raise your head back up to the starting position in a semi-circular motion as you breathe out. Hold the contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Face Down Plate Neck Resistance
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on a flat bench with your upper chest, neck, and head hanging off the end
Place a weight plate behind your head and hold it securely with both hands
Lower your head down slowly by nodding 'yes' - let your chin drop toward your chest
Raise your head back up in a smooth arc to the starting position, squeezing your neck muscles
Hold the contraction at the top for one second before repeating
form_cues: Move slowly and deliberately - this is a small, controlled nod, not a big swing
Keep the plate secure with both hands throughout - don't let it slip
Focus on your neck doing the work - imagine you're nodding emphatically
Keep your body completely still on the bench - only your neck should move
common_mistakes: Using too much weight which can strain the delicate neck muscles
Moving too quickly or using momentum instead of controlled contraction
Letting the plate slip or move during the exercise
injury_prevention_tips: Start with just a 2.5 or 5 lb plate - your neck muscles are small and easily injured
Stop immediately if you feel any sharp pain or pinching in your neck

instructions: Lie face up with your whole body straight on a flat bench while holding a weight plate on top of your forehead. Tip: You will need to position yourself so that your shoulders are slightly above the end of a flat bench in order for the traps, neck and head to be off the bench. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the plate secure on your forehead slowly lower your head back in a semi-circular motion as you breathe in.
Raise your head back up to the starting position in a semi-circular motion as you breathe out. Hold the contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Face Up Plate Neck Resistance
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on a flat bench with your shoulders slightly hanging off the end so your head, neck, and traps are unsupported
Hold a weight plate securely on your forehead with both hands, keeping your body completely straight
Slowly lower your head back in a controlled arc, like nodding 'yes' in reverse, while breathing in
Raise your head back to the starting position following the same arc path while breathing out
Hold the contraction at the top for one second before repeating
form_cues: Move your head in a smooth arc like a pendulumnot straight up and down
Keep the plate pressed firmly to your forehead throughoutimagine it's glued there
Your neck does all the workthink of your head as a heavy bowling ball your neck muscles are lifting
Control the descentpretend you're lowering your head onto a pillow in slow motion
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and jerking the movementthis exercise requires very light weight and strict control
Letting the plate slide or shift on the foreheadmaintain constant pressure with your hands
Moving too fast or using momentumslow and controlled is key for neck safety
injury_prevention_tips: Start with just the weight of your head (no plate) to learn the movement pattern safely
NEVER use heavy weight on neck exerciseseven 2.5-5 lbs is sufficient for most people

instructions: Lie on your back with your partner kneeling beside you.

Flex the hip of one leg, raising it off of the floor. Rotate the leg so the foot is over the opposite hip, the lower leg perpendicular to your body. Your partner should hold the knee and ankle in place. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to push your leg towards your partner, who should be preventing any actual movement of the leg.

After 10-20 seconds, completely relax as your partner gently pushes the ankle and knee towards your chest. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching.
exercises.name: Lying Glute
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with one leg flat and the other leg bent with foot crossed over the opposite hip
Your partner kneels beside you and holds your bent knee and ankle in place to stabilize
Push your bent leg toward your partner like you're trying to move them, while they resist and prevent movement
After 10-20 seconds, completely relax and let your partner gently push your knee and ankle toward your chest
Communicate with your partner when the stretch reaches the right intensity, then switch sides
form_cues: During the push phase, contract your glute like you're trying to squeeze a walnutgive it real effort
When you relax, go completely limp like a ragdolllet your partner do all the work
Think 'push, relax, stretch'the contraction before the stretch makes the stretch more effective
Breathe deeply during the stretch phaseexhaling helps you relax deeper into the stretch
common_mistakes: Not contracting hard enough during the push phaseyou need a genuine 70-80% effort contraction
Tensing up during the stretch phaseyou must completely relax to benefit from PNF stretching
Letting your partner push too far too fastcommunication is crucial to prevent overstretching
injury_prevention_tips: Always communicate clearly with your partnersay 'stop' immediately if it's too much
The partner should push gently and graduallynever force or bounce the stretch

instructions: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Your partner should be kneeling beside you. Raise one leg up towards the ceiling and have your partner hold the ankle. Your partner can use their shoulder to brace your leg if necessary. This will be your starting position.
With your partner holding your leg in place, attempt to flex the knee, contracting the hamstrings for 10-20 seconds.

Then relax your leg, allowing your partner to gently push the leg towards your head. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching. Switch sides once complete.
exercises.name: Lying Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with one leg raised straight up toward the ceiling while your partner kneels beside you
Your partner holds your raised ankle (and can brace with their shoulder if needed) to keep your leg vertical
Try to bend your knee and pull your heel down toward your butt while your partner prevents any movement
After 10-20 seconds, relax completely as your partner gently pushes your straight leg toward your head
Tell your partner when to stop stretching, then switch to the other leg
form_cues: During the contraction, imagine you're trying to kick your heel back to your glutes with forcereally engage those hamstrings
Keep your hips flat on the ground throughoutdon't let them twist or lift
When relaxing into the stretch, think 'melt into it'zero resistance from your muscles
Point your toes toward your shin during the stretch to also get a calf stretch
common_mistakes: Lifting the hips off the ground during the contraction or stretchthis reduces effectiveness
Not contracting the hamstring hard enough before the stretchthis is PNF, not passive stretching
Bending the knee during the stretch phasekeep the leg straight for maximum hamstring lengthening
injury_prevention_tips: Keep constant communication with your partner about intensityhamstrings are easy to overstretch
If you feel sharp pain or cramping, stop immediately and ease off the intensity

instructions: Lie face forward on a tall flat bench while holding a barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing up). Tip: If you are holding a barbell grab it using a shoulder-width grip and if you are using an E-Z Bar grab it on the inner handles. Your upper body should be positioned in a way that the upper chest is over the end of the bench and the barbell is hanging in front of you with the arms extended and perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the elbows in and the upper arms stationary, curl the weight up in a semi-circular motion as you contract the biceps and exhale. Hold at the top of the movement for a second.
As you inhale, slowly go back to the starting position. Tip: Maintain full control of the weight at all times and avoid any swinging. Remember, only the forearms should move throughout the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying High Bench Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a tall flat bench with your upper chest hanging over the edge
Grab a barbell with an underhand grip (palms up) at shoulder width, arms hanging straight down perpendicular to the floor
Keeping your upper arms completely still, curl the bar up in an arc toward your face while exhaling
Squeeze hard at the top for one second, then slowly lower the bar back down while inhaling
Keep your elbows locked in position throughoutonly your forearms should move
form_cues: Your upper arms and elbows are frozenpretend they're clamped to your sides and can't move
Think of your forearms as pistons moving in an arcsmooth and controlled, no jerking
At the top, squeeze your biceps like you're trying to touch them to your forearms
Your chest stays pressed into the benchdon't lift your torso to help curl the weight
common_mistakes: Swinging the weight or using momentumthis is a strict isolation move, not a power exercise
Letting the elbows drift forward or backwardthey should stay fixed in space
Lifting the chest off the bench to helpthis defeats the purpose of the prone position
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than standing curlsthe prone position makes it harder to cheat, so less weight is needed
Don't let the bar drop fast on the negativecontrol it down to protect your elbow joints

instructions: Adjust the machine lever to fit your height and lie face down on the leg curl machine with the pad of the lever on the back of your legs (just a few inches under the calves). Tip: Preferably use a leg curl machine that is angled as opposed to flat since an angled position is more favorable for hamstrings recruitment.

Keeping the torso flat on the bench, ensure your legs are fully stretched and grab the side handles of the machine. Position your toes straight (or you can also use any of the other two stances described on the foot positioning section). This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, curl your legs up as far as possible without lifting the upper legs from the pad. Once you hit the fully contracted position, hold it for a second.
As you inhale, bring the legs back to the initial position. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Leg Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a leg curl machine and adjust the pad to sit just below your calves
Grab the side handles for stability and fully extend your legs with toes pointed straight
Curl your heels up toward your glutes as far as possible while keeping your hips pressed to the pad
Hold the fully contracted position (heels near glutes) for one second and squeeze
Slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position with control
form_cues: At the top, imagine trying to kick your own butt with your heelsget maximum contraction
Keep your hips glued to the padif they lift, you're using too much weight or going too fast
Think 'slow down, explode up'controlled lowering, then powerful curl
Squeeze your hamstrings at the top like you're crushing tennis balls in the back of your knees
common_mistakes: Lifting the hips off the pad during the curlthis reduces hamstring tension and can strain the lower back
Not going through full range of motionpartial reps leave gains on the table
Dropping the weight too fast on the descentthe negative is where growth happens
injury_prevention_tips: If you get hamstring cramps, reduce weight and ensure you're properly hydrated
Keep your toes pointed straight or slightly outnever curl with toes pointed in as this can stress the knees

instructions: Adjust the leg machine to a height that will allow you to get inside it with your knees bent and the thighs slightly below parallel.

Once you select the weight, position yourself inside the machine face up with the knees bent and thighs slightly below parallel to the platform. Make sure that the knees do not go past the toes. The angle created between the hamstrings and the calves should be one that is slightly less than 90 degrees (since your starting position requires you to start slightly below parallel). Your back and your head should be resting on the machine while your shoulders are pressed under the shoulder pads.
Place your hands by the handles and position your feet slightly pointing out at a shoulder width position. This will be your starting position.

While pressing with the balls of the feet as you breathe out, make your whole body erect as you squeeze the quads. Hold the contracted position for a second. Tip: Since you are starting below parallel, you can opt to use your hands to help you up by pressing on your thighs only on the first repetition.

Slowly squat down as you inhale but instead of going all the way down to the starting position, just stop once your thighs are parallel to the platform. The angle between your hamstrings and calves should be a 90-degree angle.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Machine Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up in the lying squat machine with your knees bent and thighs slightly below parallel
Position your shoulders under the shoulder pads, back and head resting against the machine, hands on handles
Place your feet shoulder-width apart with toes slightly pointed outmake sure knees don't pass your toes
Drive through the balls of your feet to extend your legs fully, squeezing your quads at the top
Lower back down slowly until your thighs are parallel to the platform (90-degree angle at the knees), then repeat
form_cues: Drive through the balls of your feet like you're pushing the platform away from you
At the top, lock out completely and squeeze your quads like you're flexing for a photo
Keep your back flat against the padimagine you're trying to leave a sweat imprint
Control the descentthink 'ride the elevator down slowly' to parallel
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of stopping at parallelthis stresses the knees unnecessarily
Letting the knees cave inwardpush your knees out in line with your toes throughout
Lifting the lower back off the padkeep your core braced and back pressed flat
injury_prevention_tips: Never go below parallel on this machinestopping at 90 degrees is sufficient and safer for knees
If you feel knee pain, adjust foot position or ensure knees aren't traveling too far forward

instructions: While holding a dumbbell in one hand, lay with your chest down on a flat bench. The other hand can be used to hold to the leg of the bench for stability.

Position the palm of the hand that is holding the dumbbell in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arm extended with the elbow slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arm with the dumbbell to the side until your elbow is at shoulder height and your arm is roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arm perpendicular to the torso while keeping your arm extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbell to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying One-Arm Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie chest-down on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in one hand, using the other hand to stabilize by holding the bench leg
Let your working arm hang straight down with palm facing your body and a slight bend in the elbow
Raise the dumbbell out to the side until your elbow reaches shoulder height and your arm is parallel to the floor
Hold the contraction for one second at the top, then slowly lower back to the starting position
Complete all reps on one side, then switch arms
form_cues: Lead with your elbow, not your handimagine your elbow is pulling the dumbbell up
Keep your arm perpendicular to your bodylike you're drawing a line straight out to the side
At the top, think 'pour the pitcher'rotate your wrist slightly so your pinky is higher than your thumb
Your arm stays slightly bent the whole timethink 'hugging a beach ball' not 'straight arm'
common_mistakes: Swinging or using momentumthis is a strict isolation move requiring light weight and control
Raising the arm too high (above shoulder level)this shifts work from side delts to traps
Rotating the torso to help liftstay pressed flat against the bench
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weightthis angle is tough on the shoulder, so less weight is needed
If you feel shoulder impingement or pinching, reduce the range of motion or skip this exercise

instructions: Lay face down on the floor with your partner kneeling beside you. Flex one knee and raise that leg off the ground, attempting to touch your glutes with your foot. Your partner should hold the knee and ankle. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to extend your knee while your partner prevents any actual movement.
After 10-20 seconds, relax your muscles as your partner gently pushes the foot towards your glutes, further stretching the quadriceps and hip flexors.
After 10-20 seconds, switch sides.
exercises.name: Lying Prone Quadriceps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor with your partner kneeling beside you
Bend one knee and try to bring your heel to your glutes as your partner holds your knee and ankle
Push your foot away from your glutes (trying to straighten your leg) while your partner prevents movement
After 10-20 seconds, relax completely as your partner gently pushes your foot closer to your glutes
Hold the stretch for 10-20 seconds, then switch to the other leg
form_cues: During the push, contract your quad like you're trying to kick straightgive it real force against the resistance
When you relax, go completely limpimagine your leg is made of jelly
Keep your hips flat on the floordon't twist or lift one hip up
Breathe deeply during the stretchexhaling helps you sink deeper into the stretch
common_mistakes: Not pushing hard enough during the contraction phaseyou need 70-80% effort for PNF to work
Tensing the muscles during the stretch phasecomplete relaxation is essential
Letting the hips twist or liftmaintain alignment for proper quad and hip flexor stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Communicate clearly with your partnerif it's too intense, tell them to back off immediately
If you have knee issues, be extra cautious with how far your heel is pushed toward your glutes

instructions: While holding a dumbbell in each hand, lay with your chest down on a flat bench.
Position the palms of the hands in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arms extended with the elbows slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arms to the side until your elbows are at shoulder height and your arms are roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arms perpendicular to the torso while keeping them extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbells to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.
exercises.name: Lying Rear Delt Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie chest-down on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand
Let both arms hang straight down with palms facing each other and a slight bend in the elbows
Raise both arms out to the sides until your elbows reach shoulder height and arms are parallel to the floor
Hold the contraction for one second, squeezing your shoulder blades together
Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position
form_cues: Lead with your elbowsimagine someone is pulling your elbows up with strings
At the top, squeeze your shoulder blades together like you're crushing a grape between them
Keep your arms perpendicular to your bodythink 'T-shape' at the top of the movement
Maintain a slight elbow bend throughoutdon't lock out or curl the weight
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and swingingthis should be a controlled isolation move with light dumbbells
Raising the arms too highstop when arms are parallel to the floor
Shrugging the shoulders or using trapsfocus on rear delts, keep shoulders down
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight (5-10 lbs)rear delts are small muscles and this angle is challenging
If you feel shoulder pain or impingement, reduce range of motion or lower the weight

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench face up while holding a dumbbell in each arm on top of your thighs.
Bring the dumbbells to the sides with the arms extended and the palms of the hands facing your thighs (neutral grip).

While keeping the arms close to your torso and elbows in, slowly lower your arms (as you keep them extended with a slight bend at the elbows) as far down towards the floor as you can go. Once you cannot go down any further, lock your upper arms in that position and that will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, slowly begin to curl the weights up as you simultaneously rotate your wrists so that the palms of the hands face up. Continue curling the weight until your biceps are fully contracted and squeeze hard at the top position for a second. Tip: Only the forearms should move. Upper arms should remain stationary and elbows should stay in throughout the movement.
Return back to the starting position very slowly.
exercises.name: Lying Supine Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on a flat bench holding dumbbells, starting with them on your thighs
Bring the dumbbells to your sides with arms extended and palms facing your thighs (neutral grip)
Lower your arms down toward the floor as far as comfortable with a slight elbow bendlock your upper arms here
Curl the dumbbells up while rotating your wrists so palms face up, squeezing your biceps at the top
Slowly return to the starting position with arms extended down at your sides
form_cues: Your upper arms stay frozen in that lowered positionthink of them as being bolted down at your sides
As you curl, rotate your wrists like you're showing someone your palmsthis is a supinating curl
At the top, squeeze your biceps hard like you're trying to make them touch your forearms
Keep your elbows locked at your sidesif they drift forward or up, you're using too much weight
common_mistakes: Moving the upper arms during the curlonly the forearms should move from a fixed elbow position
Not rotating the wrists fullythe supination is key to maximizing bicep activation
Using momentum or arching the backstay flat on the bench with controlled movement
injury_prevention_tips: Don't lower your arms too far at the start if you have shoulder issuesfind a comfortable stretch point
Start with lighter weight than standing curlsthis stretched position is more challenging

instructions: Load up the T-bar Row Machine with the desired weight and adjust the leg height so that your upper chest is at the top of the pad. Tip: In some machines all you can do is stand on the appropriate step that allows you to be at a height that has the upper chest at the top of the pad.
Lay face down on the pad and grab the handles. You can either use a palms down, palms up, or palms in position depending on what part of your back you want to emphasize.
Lift the bar off the rack and extend your arms in front of you. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale slowly pull the weight up and squeeze your back at the top of the movement. Tip: Keep the upper arms as close to the torso as possible throughout the movement in order to better engage the back muscles. Also, do not lift your body off of the pad at any time and refrain from using the biceps to lift the weight.
After a second contraction at the top of the movement, as you inhale, slowly go back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying T-Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load the T-bar machine and adjust the pad height so your upper chest rests at the top of the pad
Lie face-down on the pad and grab the handles with your preferred grip (palms down, up, or neutral)
Extend your arms fully to lift the weight off the rack - this is your starting position
Pull the handles toward your torso by driving your elbows back, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top
Hold the squeeze for one second, then slowly lower back to the start with control
form_cues: Keep your elbows close to your body - imagine dragging them along your ribcage
Stay glued to the pad - your chest should never lift up
Lead with your elbows, not your hands - think 'elbows to ceiling'
Squeeze your shoulder blades like you're crushing a grape between them at the top
common_mistakes: Lifting your torso off the pad to use momentum instead of isolated back contraction
Pulling with biceps instead of initiating the movement with your back
Letting elbows flare out wide instead of staying tucked close to the body
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your body completely flat on the pad to protect your lower back
Don't use weight so heavy that you need to jerk or use momentum to lift it

instructions: Lie on a flat bench with either an e-z bar (my preference) or a straight bar placed on the floor behind your head and your feet on the floor.

Grab the bar behind you, using a medium overhand (pronated) grip, and raise the bar in front of you at arms length. Tip: The arms should be perpendicular to the torso and the floor. The elbows should be tucked in. This is the starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the weight until the bar lightly touches your forehead while keeping the upper arms and elbows stationary.
At that point, use the triceps to bring the weight back up to the starting position as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Lying Triceps Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench with an EZ bar on the floor behind your head, feet flat on the floor
Reach back and grab the bar with an overhand grip, then bring it to arms' length above you (perpendicular to floor)
Keep your elbows tucked in tight and upper arms stationary - this is your starting position
Lower the bar slowly toward your forehead by bending only at the elbows until it lightly touches
Press the bar back up by extending your elbows, squeezing your triceps at the top
form_cues: Upper arms stay frozen in place - imagine they're in a cast
Elbows point to the ceiling and stay tucked in - don't let them flare out
Lower to your forehead like you're gently placing the bar there, not dropping it
Press up with triceps power - feel the back of your arms doing all the work
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to the sides instead of staying tucked in
Allowing upper arms to drop back during the movement instead of staying perpendicular
Bouncing the bar off your forehead instead of lightly touching it
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weight to avoid accidentally hitting yourself in the face
Keep movements controlled - this is called a 'skull crusher' for a reason, so be careful

instructions: Sit down on the Chest Press Machine and select the weight.
Step on the lever provided by the machine since it will help you to bring the handles forward so that you can grab the handles and fully extend the arms.

Grab the handles with a palms-down grip and lift your elbows so that your upper arms are parallel to the floor to the sides of your torso. Tip: Your forearms will be pointing forward since you are grabbing the handles. Once you bring the handles forward and extend the arms you will be at the starting position.
Now bring the handles back towards you as you breathe in.
Push the handles away from you as you flex your pecs and you breathe out. Hold the contraction for a second before going back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of reps.
When finished step on the lever again and slowly get the handles back to their original place.
exercises.name: Machine Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the chest press machine, select your weight, and use the foot lever to bring the handles forward
Grab the handles with a palms-down grip and position your upper arms parallel to the floor
Once extended forward with arms straight, this is your starting position
Pull the handles back toward your chest as you inhale - imagine giving yourself a big hug
Push the handles away explosively as you exhale, squeezing your chest muscles at full extension
form_cues: Keep your shoulder blades pinched together - imagine holding a pencil between them
Press forward like you're pushing someone away from your chest
Squeeze your pecs at full extension - think about flexing them together
Keep your back flat against the pad - maintain three points of contact (head, upper back, butt)
common_mistakes: Letting shoulders roll forward instead of keeping shoulder blades retracted
Pressing with arms only instead of engaging chest muscles
Arching lower back excessively to help push the weight
injury_prevention_tips: Use the foot lever to safely get into and out of position - don't try to muscle the handles
Keep your wrists straight and neutral, not bent back which can cause strain

instructions: Adjust the seat to the appropriate height and make your weight selection. Place your upper arms against the pads and grasp the handles. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by flexing the elbow, pulling your lower arm towards your upper arm.
Pause at the top of the movement, and then slowly return the weight to the starting position.
Avoid returning the weight all the way to the stops until the set is complete to keep tension on the muscles being worked.
exercises.name: Machine Bicep Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat height so your upper arms rest comfortably against the pads
Place your upper arms flush against the pads and grab the handles - this is your starting position
Curl the handles toward your shoulders by bending at the elbows - imagine flexing your biceps
Pause at the top and squeeze your biceps hard for one second
Slowly lower back to the start but don't let the weight stack crash - keep tension on your muscles
form_cues: Keep your upper arms glued to the pads - they should never lift off
Only your forearms move - your upper arms are completely stationary
Squeeze at the top like you're flexing in a mirror - make that peak
Lower slowly with control - count '1-2-3' on the way down
common_mistakes: Lifting upper arms off the pads to use momentum instead of isolated bicep contraction
Dropping the weight too fast on the way down instead of controlling the negative
Letting the weight stack crash between reps which removes muscle tension
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend at the bottom - keep a slight bend in your elbows
If you feel elbow pain, reduce the weight and focus on perfect form

instructions: Sit down on the Preacher Curl Machine and select the weight.

Place the back of your upper arms (your triceps) on the preacher pad provided and grab the handles using an underhand grip (palms facing up). Tip: Make sure that when you place the arms on the pad you keep the elbows in. This will be your starting position.

Now lift the handles as you exhale and you contract the biceps. At the top of the position make sure that you hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Only the forearms should move. The upper arms should remain stationary and on the pad at all times.
Lower the handles slowly back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Machine Preacher Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the preacher curl machine and select your weight
Place the back of your upper arms (triceps) on the preacher pad and grab handles with palms facing up
Keep your elbows tucked in - this is your starting position with arms slightly bent
Curl the handles up toward your shoulders by contracting your biceps, exhaling as you go
Hold the squeeze at the top for one second, then slowly lower back down
form_cues: Keep your triceps glued to the pad - they should never peel off
Only your forearms move - upper arms stay completely still on the pad
Squeeze at the top like you're showing off your bicep peak
Control the descent - resist the weight on the way down, don't let it drop
common_mistakes: Lifting your upper arms off the pad to help curl the weight up
Dropping the weight too quickly on the negative instead of controlled lowering
Letting elbows flare out instead of keeping them tucked in
injury_prevention_tips: Don't fully straighten your arms at the bottom - keep a slight bend to protect elbow joints
Start lighter than you think - the preacher position is very strict and doesn't allow cheating

instructions: Sit down on the Shoulder Press Machine and select the weight.
Grab the handles to your sides as you keep the elbows bent and in line with your torso. This will be your starting position.
Now lift the handles as you exhale and you extend the arms fully. At the top of the position make sure that you hold the contraction for a second.
Lower the handles slowly back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Machine Shoulder (Military) Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the shoulder press machine and select your weight
Grab the handles at shoulder height with elbows bent and in line with your torso
Press the handles straight up overhead by extending your arms fully, exhaling as you press
Hold the contraction at the top for one second - squeeze your shoulders
Lower the handles slowly back to starting position at shoulder height
form_cues: Press straight up like you're pushing the ceiling away
Keep your core tight - imagine bracing for a punch to prevent arching your back
Squeeze your shoulders at the top - think about flexing your delts
Lower with control - don't let the weight drop back down
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively to help press the weight up
Using momentum by bouncing at the bottom instead of controlled pressing
Locking out elbows too hard at the top which can stress the joints
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back pressed firmly against the pad to avoid lower back strain
Don't shrug your shoulders up toward your ears - keep them down and engaged

instructions: Adjust the seat to the appropriate height and make your weight selection. Place your upper arms against the pads and grasp the handles. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by extending the elbow, pulling your lower arm away from your upper arm.
Pause at the completion of the movement, and then slowly return the weight to the starting position.
Avoid returning the weight all the way to the stops until the set is complete to keep tension on the muscles being worked.
exercises.name: Machine Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles are at a comfortable height and select your weight
Place your upper arms against the pads and grab the handles - this is your starting position
Extend your arms by pushing the handles down and away from your body, straightening your elbows
Pause at full extension and squeeze your triceps hard
Slowly bend your elbows to return to the start, but don't let the weight stack crash
form_cues: Keep your upper arms glued to the pads - only your forearms should move
Push down and away like you're straightening out a wrinkled shirt
Squeeze your triceps at the bottom - feel the contraction in the back of your arms
Control the return - count '1-2-3' on the way back up
common_mistakes: Lifting upper arms off the pads to use momentum
Dropping the weight quickly instead of controlling the eccentric portion
Not getting full extension - make sure you fully straighten your arms
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend or lock out elbows too aggressively - keep it smooth
If you feel elbow pain, reduce the weight immediately

instructions: Lie facedown on an incline bench while holding a dumbbell in each hand. Your arms should be fully extended hanging down and pointing towards the floor. The palms of your hands should be facing each other. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, squeeze your shoulder blades together and hold the contraction for a full second. Tip: This movement is just like the reverse action of a hug, or trying to perform rear laterals as if you had no arms.
As you inhale go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Middle Back Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on an incline bench holding a dumbbell in each hand with arms hanging straight down
Your palms should face each other and arms fully extended toward the floor
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard like you're pinching something between them - hold for one full second
Think about performing a reverse hug or rear lateral raise without moving your arms
Relax your shoulder blades back to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Don't bend your arms - this is all about shoulder blade retraction, not arm movement
Imagine trying to touch your shoulder blades together behind you
Squeeze hard at the top - think about crushing a walnut between your shoulder blades
Keep your chest pressed into the bench - don't arch up
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows and turning it into a row instead of pure shoulder blade squeeze
Using too heavy dumbbells which prevents proper scapular retraction
Rushing the movement instead of holding the squeeze for a full second
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light dumbbells - this is about muscle activation, not heavy weight
Keep your neck neutral - don't crane your head up or down

instructions: Stand so your feet are shoulder width apart and your hands are on your hips.
Twist at your waist until you feel a stretch. Hold for 10 to 15 seconds, then twist to the other side.
exercises.name: Middle Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place your hands on your hips
Twist your torso to one side slowly until you feel a stretch in your mid-back and obliques
Hold the stretch for 10-15 seconds while breathing normally
Return to center, then twist to the opposite side and hold for 10-15 seconds
Keep your hips facing forward - only your upper body should rotate
form_cues: Keep your hips locked forward - imagine they're in cement
Twist from your mid-back, not your lower back - think about rotating your ribcage
Breathe deeply during the stretch - don't hold your breath
Move slowly and deliberately - this isn't a fast twisting motion
common_mistakes: Rotating the hips along with the torso instead of isolating the upper body twist
Twisting too aggressively or bouncing which can strain the spine
Holding breath during the stretch instead of breathing normally
injury_prevention_tips: Never force the stretch - twist only until you feel gentle tension, not pain
Keep movements slow and controlled - no sudden jerking or bouncing

instructions: Using a spacing that is just about 1 inch wider than shoulder width, grab a pull-up bar with the palms of one hand facing forward and the palms of the other hand facing towards you. This will be your starting position.

Now start to pull yourself up as you exhale. Tip: With the arm that has the palms facing up concentrate on using the back muscles in order to perform the movement. The elbow of that arm should remain close to the torso. With the other arm that has the palms facing forward, the elbows will be away but in line with the torso. You will concentrate on using the lats to pull your body up.
After a second contraction at the top, start to slowly come down as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

On the following set, switch grips; so if you had the right hand with the palms facing you and the left one with the palms facing forward, on the next set you will have the palms facing forward for the right hand and facing you for the left.
exercises.name: Mixed Grip Chin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar slightly wider than shoulder width with one palm facing forward and one palm facing you
Hang with arms fully extended - this is your starting position
Pull yourself up by driving your elbows down and back, exhaling as you rise
Focus on using your back muscles to pull, keeping one elbow close (underhand side) and one elbow out (overhand side)
Hold at the top for one second, then slowly lower yourself back down
form_cues: Lead with your chest - imagine trying to touch your chest to the bar
On the underhand side, keep that elbow close to your body like a regular curl
On the overhand side, let that elbow flare out and pull with your lat
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top - think about pinching them
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms only instead of engaging back muscles
Not getting chin above the bar - make sure you achieve full range of motion
Swinging or using momentum instead of controlled pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Switch your grip orientation each set to balance muscle development
If you can't do bodyweight, use an assisted pull-up machine or resistance band

instructions: Place a band around both ankles and another around both knees. There should be enough tension that they are tight when your feet are shoulder width apart.
To begin, take short steps forward alternating your left and right foot.
After several steps, do just the opposite and walk backward to where you started.
exercises.name: Monster Walk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place one resistance band around both ankles and another around both kneesthey should be tight when your feet are shoulder-width apart
Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart, slight bend in your knees, and hands on your hips or out for balance
Take short, controlled steps forward by lifting one foot and placing it down, alternating left and right feet
After 10-15 steps forward, reverse direction and walk backward the same distance back to your starting point
Keep constant tension on the bands throughoutdon't let your knees collapse inward
form_cues: Push your knees out against the band like you're trying to snap itmaintain that outward pressure the entire time
Take baby stepsthink 'heel to toe' placement, not giant strides
Keep your hips level like you're balancing a tray of drinks on your pelvisno side-to-side tilting
Imagine you're walking through thick mudslow, deliberate, and controlled movements
common_mistakes: Letting the knees cave inward when steppingyou must actively push out against the bands constantly
Taking steps that are too bigthis reduces glute activation and increases the risk of losing balance
Standing too upright with locked kneesmaintain a slight athletic squat position throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter resistance bands to master the movement pattern before progressing
If you feel knee pain, ensure you're pushing your knees outward, not letting them collapse inward

instructions: Grip the rings using a false grip, with the base of your palms on top of the rings. Initiate a pull up by pulling the elbows down to your side, flexing the elbows.

As you reach the top position of the pull-up, pull the rings to your armpits as you roll your shoulders forward, allowing your elbows to move straight back behind you. This puts you into the proper position to continue into the dip portion of the movement.
Maintaining control and stability, extend through the elbow to complete the motion.
Use care when lowering yourself to the ground.
exercises.name: Muscle Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grip gymnastic rings using a false grip (base of palms on top of the rings) and hang with arms fully extended
Pull yourself up explosively by driving your elbows down to your sides, pulling the rings to your armpits
As you reach the top of the pull-up, roll your shoulders forward aggressively and drive your elbows straight back behind you
This transition puts you above the ringsnow extend your elbows completely to press yourself up into a full dip lockout
Lower yourself back down with control, reversing the movement
form_cues: The false grip is keyyour wrists should be bent over the top of the rings, not hanging below them
At the transition, think 'pull, roll, press'it's one fluid explosive movement, not three separate moves
Lean back slightly at the start of the pull to generate momentumthen snap your hips forward at the transition
The transition is like doing a chest rollyour shoulders come forward over the rings aggressively
common_mistakes: Using a regular grip instead of false gripthis makes the transition nearly impossible
Not pulling high enough before attempting the transitionyou need to get the rings to armpit level
Trying to muscle through with pure strength instead of using the hip snap and momentum
injury_prevention_tips: Master strict pull-ups and ring dips separately before attempting muscle ups
Practice the false grip hang and transitions at lower heights before going for full reps

instructions: Place the back of your torso against the back pad of the machine and hook your shoulders under the shoulder pads provided.

Position your legs in the platform using a less than shoulder width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Your feet should be around 3 inches or less apart. Tip: Keep your head up at all times and also maintain the back on the pad at all times.
Place your arms on the side handles of the machine and disengage the safety bars (which on most designs is done by moving the side handles from a facing front position to a diagonal position).
Now straighten your legs without locking the knees. This will be your starting position.

Begin to slowly lower the unit by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up (back on the pad at all times). Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Begin to raise the unit as you exhale by pushing the floor with mainly with the heels of your feet as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Narrow Stance Hack Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load the machine and position yourself with your back against the pad, shoulders under the shoulder pads
Place your feet on the platform 3 inches apart or less with toes slightly pointed out
Disengage the safety bars and straighten your legs without locking your kneesthis is your starting position
Lower the weight by bending your knees until your thighs go slightly below parallel (just past 90 degrees)
Drive through your heels to push back up to the starting position, squeezing your quads at the top
form_cues: Keep your back flat against the pad like you're glued to itdon't let it peel off
Your head stays up looking forwardimagine balancing a book on your head
Drive through your heels like you're pushing the platform away from youthink 'leg press the world away'
At the bottom, your knees should track over your toesimagine they're on train tracks going straight forward
common_mistakes: Letting the knees travel too far forward past the toesthis puts excessive stress on the knee joints
Bouncing at the bottomcontrol the descent and pause briefly before pushing back up
Locking out the knees at the topmaintain a slight bend to keep tension on the quads
injury_prevention_tips: Narrow stance increases quad emphasis but also knee stressstart light to test your comfort level
If you feel knee pain, widen your stance slightly or don't go as deep

instructions: Using a leg press machine, sit down on the machine and place your legs on the platform directly in front of you at a less-than-shoulder-width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Your feet should be around 3 inches or less apart. Tip: Keep your head up at all times and also maintain the back on the pad at all times.

Lower the safety bars holding the weighted platform in place and press the platform all the way up until your legs are fully extended in front of you. Tip: Make sure that you do not lock your knees. Your torso and the legs should make a perfect 90-degree angle. This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, slowly lower the platform until your upper and lower legs make a 90-degree angle.
Pushing mainly with the heels of your feet and using the quadriceps go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and ensure to lock the safety pins properly once you are done. You do not want that platform falling on you fully loaded.
exercises.name: Narrow Stance Leg Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in the leg press machine and place your feet on the platform 3 inches apart or less, toes slightly out
Lower the safety bars and press the platform up until your legs are extended but not lockedthis is your starting position
Slowly lower the platform by bending your knees until your upper and lower legs form a 90-degree angle
Drive through your heels to press the platform back to the starting position, squeezing your quads
After your set, lock the safety bars back in place before exiting
form_cues: Your back stays flat against the seatimagine you're trying to leave a sweat print on the pad
Think 'heels down, toes up slightly' when pressingthis maximizes quad engagement
At the top, squeeze your quads like you're flexing for a photobut don't lock your knees completely
Control the descent like you're riding an elevator downsmooth and steady, not a free fall
common_mistakes: Letting your lower back round and lift off the seat at the bottomthis is dangerous for your spine
Going too deep with narrow stancestop at 90 degrees to protect your knees
Locking the knees at the topkeep a slight bend to maintain tension on the muscles
injury_prevention_tips: Narrow stance increases quad activation but also knee stressuse moderate weight
Always re-engage safety bars after your setnever leave the platform unsecured

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.
