Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a less-than-shoulder-width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Feet should be around 3-6 inches apart. Keep your head up at all times (looking down will get you off balance) and maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Narrow Stance Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell in a squat rack at upper chest height, load your weight, and step under the bar
Position the bar on your upper back (below your neck), grab it with both hands, and stand up to unrack it
Step back and position your feet 3-6 inches apart with toes slightly pointed out, head up, back straight
Lower down by bending your knees until your thighs go slightly below parallel to the floor while inhaling
Drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position while exhaling, squeezing your quads at the top
form_cues: Your head stays up the entire timeimagine someone is pulling a string attached to the top of your head toward the ceiling
Your knees should track directly over your toesthink 'knees follow the same path as your toes point'
Chest up proud like you're showing off a medaldon't let your torso fold forward excessively
Drive through your heels like you're trying to push the floor awayimagine the floor is your enemy
common_mistakes: Letting the knees travel too far forward past the toesthis creates an imaginary line from your knee to your toes that should be perpendicular
Looking down instead of upthis throws off your balance and can round your back
Rising with your hips first instead of pushing evenlythis makes it a 'good morning' instead of a squat
injury_prevention_tips: Narrow stance emphasizes quads but increases knee stressensure proper form before loading heavy
Use a squat rack with safety bars set just below your lowest squat depth for safety

instructions: Using the leg pad of a lat pulldown machine or a preacher bench, position yourself so that your ankles are under the pads, knees on the seat, and you are facing away from the machine. You should be upright and maintaining good posture.
This will be your starting position. Lower yourself under control until your knees are almost completely straight.
Remaining in control, raise yourself back up to the starting position.
If you are unable to complete a rep, use a band, a partner, or push off of a box to aid in completing a repetition.
exercises.name: Natural Glute Ham Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself on a lat pulldown machine or preacher bench with your ankles secured under the pads, knees on the seat
Start in an upright kneeling position, body completely vertical with good posture and core braced
Slowly lower your torso forward under control, keeping your body straight, until your knees are almost fully extended
Using your hamstrings, pull yourself back up to the starting upright position with control
If needed, use a resistance band, partner assistance, or push off a box to help complete the rep
form_cues: Your body is one solid plank from knees to headdon't bend at the hips or let your butt stick out
Lower yourself like you're a falling treeslow, controlled, and in one straight line
At the bottom, your hamstrings should feel like they're about to snapthat's the stretch you want
Pull yourself back up by squeezing your hamstrings and glutes like you're trying to crush walnuts
common_mistakes: Bending at the hips instead of keeping the body straightthis turns it into a different exercise
Dropping down too fast without controlthe eccentric (lowering) phase is crucial for hamstring development
Not going deep enoughyou need to challenge the full range of motion for maximum benefit
injury_prevention_tips: This is an extremely difficult exercisemost people need assistance at first, use bands or a partner
If you feel hamstring cramping, slow down and ensure you're properly warmed up and hydrated

instructions: Using a muscle roller or a rolling pin, place the roller behind your head and against your neck. Make sure that you do not place the roller directly against the spine, but turned slightly so that the roller is pressed against the muscles to either side of the spine. This will be your starting position.
Starting at the top of your neck, slowly roll down the muscles of your neck, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds.
exercises.name: Neck-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Using a muscle roller or rolling pin, place it behind your head against the muscles on one side of your neck (not directly on spine)
Apply gentle pressure by leaning your head back into the roller slightly
Starting at the top of your neck, slowly roll down the muscles along the side of your spine
When you hit a tender spot, pause and hold pressure for 10-30 seconds while breathing deeply
Switch to the other side and repeat the process
form_cues: Stay completely OFF the spineimagine the spine is a danger zone and you're only working the muscles to the sides
Use very light pressureyour neck is delicate, so think 'gentle massage' not 'deep tissue assault'
Move in tiny incrementsthink 'millimeter by millimeter', not rolling back and forth rapidly
Breathe deeply when you find trigger pointsexhaling helps the muscles release tension
common_mistakes: Rolling directly on the spinethis can cause serious injury to cervical vertebrae
Using too much pressurethe neck muscles are small and delicate, less is more
Moving too quickly without pausing on tight spotsslow and deliberate is more effective
injury_prevention_tips: NEVER roll directly on your spinealways work the muscles to the sides
If you have any neck injuries or conditions, consult a professional before attempting this

instructions: Lie back on a flat bench. Using a medium-width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over your neck with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your neck.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up).
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Neck Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on a flat bench and grab a barbell with a medium-width grip, unracking it to hold straight over your neck
With arms locked, position the bar directly above your neck (not chest)this is your starting position
Slowly lower the bar down until it lightly touches your neck while breathing in
After a brief pause, press the bar back up to the starting position while breathing out, squeezing your chest
Lock your arms at the top, hold for one second, then repeat
form_cues: The bar path is straight up and down over your necknot an arc toward your chest
Lower the bar twice as slow as you press it upthink 'slow down, explode up'
At the bottom, the bar should barely kiss your neckdon't rest the weight on your throat
Squeeze your chest at the top like you're crushing a can between your pecs
common_mistakes: Using too much weightthis is a dangerous exercise that requires strict control and lighter loads
Lowering too fast or bouncing the bar off your neckthis can cause serious injury
Arching your back excessivelykeep your back flat on the bench
injury_prevention_tips: Use significantly lighter weight than regular bench pressthis is a high-risk movement
ALWAYS use a spotter for this exerciseif you fail, the bar is on your throat, which is extremely dangerous

instructions: Lie flat on the floor with your lower back pressed to the ground. For this exercise, you will need to put one hand beside your head and the other to the side against the floor.
Make sure your feet are elevated and resting on a flat surface.
Now lift the shoulder in which your hand is touching your head.

Simply elevate your shoulder and body upward until you touch your knee. For example, if you have your right hand besides your head, then you want to elevate your body upwards until your right elbow touches your left knee. The same variation can be applied doing the inverse and using your left elbow to touch your right knee.
After your knee touches your elbow, lower your body until you have reached the starting position.
Remember to breathe in during the eccentric (lowering) part of the exercise and to breathe out during the concentric (upward) part of the exercise.
Continue alternating in this manner until all of the recommended repetitions for each side have been completed.
exercises.name: Oblique Crunches
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with lower back pressed to the floor, one hand beside your head, the other flat on the floor for stability
Elevate your feet and rest them on a flat surface (bench or chair) with knees bent
Lift the shoulder where your hand is by your head, crunching diagonally toward the opposite knee
Touch your elbow to the opposite knee (right elbow to left knee), then lower back to starting position
Alternate sides, breathing out as you crunch up and breathing in as you lower down
form_cues: Think 'elbow to opposite knee'you're rotating and crunching diagonally, not straight up
At the top, squeeze your obliques hard like you're wringing out a wet towel on your side
Your lower back stays pressed to the floordon't arch or let it lift
Move with controlthink 'twist and crunch' not 'flail and swing'
common_mistakes: Pulling on your neck with your handyour hand is just there for light support, not to yank your head
Not rotating enoughthis should be a diagonal twisting motion, not a straight crunch
Using momentum instead of controlled contractionslow and deliberate works the obliques better
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back pressed to the floor throughout to protect your spine
If you feel neck strain, place your hand on your chest instead of behind your head

instructions: Start out by lying on your right side with your legs lying on top of each other. Make sure your knees are bent a little bit.
Place your left hand behind your head.
Once you are in this set position, begin by moving your left elbow up as you would perform a normal crunch except this time the main emphasis is on your obliques.
Crunch as high as you can, hold the contraction for a second and then slowly drop back down into the starting position.
Remember to breathe in during the eccentric (lowering) part of the exercise and to breathe out during the concentric (elevation) part of the exercise.
exercises.name: Oblique Crunches - On The Floor
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your right side with legs stacked on top of each other and knees slightly bent
Place your left hand behind your head for light supportthis is your starting position
Crunch your left elbow up toward your hip by contracting your left oblique muscles
Crunch as high as possible, hold the contraction for one second, then slowly lower back down
Complete all reps on one side, then switch to the other side
form_cues: Think of your oblique as a zipperyou're zipping up your side by crunching your ribs toward your hip
At the top, imagine you're trying to make your elbow and hip kissmaximum squeeze
Your bottom arm and legs stay stillonly your upper torso moves
Breathe out forcefully as you crunch upthis helps engage the obliques harder
common_mistakes: Pulling on your head with your handuse minimal assistance, let your obliques do the work
Rolling backward or forward instead of crunching straight upmaintain side-lying position
Not holding the contraction at the topthe squeeze is where the magic happens
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel neck strain, rest your head on your bottom arm instead of lifting it
Move slowly and with controljerking movements can strain the obliques or neck

instructions: Lie on a flat bench or step, and hang one leg and arm over the side.
Bend the knee and hold the top of the foot. As you do this, be careful not to arch your lower back.
Pull the belly button to the spine to stay in neutral. Press your foot down and into your hand. To add the hip stretch, lift the hip of the leg you're holding up toward the ceiling.
Switch sides.
exercises.name: On-Your-Back Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with one leg hanging off the side, letting your arm dangle too for balance
Bend the hanging leg's knee and reach back to grab the top of your foot with your hand
Pull your belly button toward your spine to keep your lower back flat - don't arch
Press your foot down into your hand to deepen the stretch, and lift your hip slightly toward the ceiling
Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch to the other side
form_cues: Keep your lower back flat against the bench - imagine you're trying to press a piece of paper into it
Press your foot actively into your hand rather than just pulling passively
Engage your core - think about keeping your ribcage down and belly tight
Breathe deeply throughout - don't hold your breath
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively which can cause strain instead of a proper stretch
Pulling too aggressively on the foot causing knee discomfort
Holding breath instead of breathing through the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain in your knee - only a gentle pulling sensation in the quad is normal
Keep your lower back neutral by engaging your core throughout the entire stretch

instructions: Start off by lying on your right side, with your right knee bent at a 90-degree angle resting on the floor in front of you (this stabilizes the torso).
Bend your left knee behind you and hold your left foot with your left hand. To stretch your hip flexor, press your left hip forward as you push your left foot back into your hand. Switch sides.
exercises.name: On Your Side Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your right side with your right knee bent at 90 degrees in front of you for stability
Bend your left knee behind you and grab your left foot with your left hand
Press your left hip forward while simultaneously pushing your left foot back into your hand
You should feel the stretch in the front of your left thigh and hip flexor
Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch to the other side
form_cues: Keep your hips stacked on top of each other - don't let the top hip roll backward
Push your hip forward like you're trying to touch it to the wall in front of you
Press your foot actively back into your hand for a deeper stretch
Keep your neck relaxed - your head can rest on your bottom arm
common_mistakes: Letting the top hip roll backward which reduces the effectiveness of the stretch
Pulling the foot without pressing the hip forward, missing the hip flexor stretch
Yanking on the foot too hard causing knee strain
injury_prevention_tips: Only pull until you feel a comfortable stretch - never force it to the point of pain
If you feel knee discomfort, ease up on how far you pull your foot back

instructions: Choose a flat bench and place a dumbbell on each side of it.

Place the right leg on top of the end of the bench, bend your torso forward from the waist until your upper body is parallel to the floor, and place your right hand on the other end of the bench for support.

Use the left hand to pick up the dumbbell on the floor and hold the weight while keeping your lower back straight. The palm of the hand should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

Pull the resistance straight up to the side of your chest, keeping your upper arm close to your side and keeping the torso stationary. Breathe out as you perform this step. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. Also, make sure that the force is performed with the back muscles and not the arms. Finally, the upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work except for holding the dumbbell; therefore do not try to pull the dumbbell up using the forearms.
Lower the resistance straight down to the starting position. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat the movement for the specified amount of repetitions.
Switch sides and repeat again with the other arm.
exercises.name: One-Arm Dumbbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place one knee and same-side hand on a flat bench, keep your back flat like a table
Pick up a dumbbell with your free hand, arm hanging straight down with palm facing your torso
Pull the dumbbell straight up to your ribcage by driving your elbow toward the ceiling
Squeeze your shoulder blade toward your spine at the top - imagine pinching a pencil between your shoulder blades
Lower slowly back to the start, then complete all reps before switching sides
form_cues: Keep your back flat like a tabletop - imagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
Lead with your elbow, not your hand - think 'elbow to ceiling'
Pull the weight to your hip, not your shoulder - keep it close to your body
Squeeze your lat at the top - feel your back doing the work, not your bicep
common_mistakes: Rotating your torso as you row instead of keeping it square and stable
Pulling with your bicep instead of initiating the movement with your back
Letting your shoulder round forward at the bottom instead of keeping it retracted
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back flat throughout - if it starts rounding, reduce the weight
Don't jerk the weight up - use smooth, controlled movements to protect your shoulder

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in one hand resting on top of your thigh. The palm of your hand with the dumbbell in it should be at a neutral grip.

By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbell up, clean the dumbbell so that you can hold it in front of you with your lifting arm being fully extended. Remember to maintain a neutral grip with this exercise. Your non lifting hand should be to the side holding the flat bench for better support. This will be your starting position.

Your arm with the weight should have a slight bend on your elbow in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon. Begin by lowering your arm with the weight in it out in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, your lifting arm should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your lifting arm back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and breathe out. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding a dumbbell in one hand with neutral grip (palm facing in), other hand gripping the bench for stability
Extend your working arm straight up above your chest with a slight elbow bend
Lower the dumbbell out to the side in a wide arc until you feel a stretch across your chest
Bring the dumbbell back up using the same arc, squeezing your chest muscle like you're hugging a tree
Hold at the top for one second, then repeat for all reps before switching arms
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in your elbow throughout - imagine you're hugging a barrel
Move only at the shoulder joint - your arm angle stays the same, just swings in an arc
Lower until you feel a good stretch in your chest - don't go so deep it hurts your shoulder
Squeeze your pec at the top like you're flexing it
common_mistakes: Bending and straightening the elbow which turns it into a press instead of a flye
Going too deep at the bottom which can strain the shoulder joint
Using too much weight and losing the arc motion
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you would for presses - this is a stretch movement, not a power movement
Stop immediately if you feel shoulder pain or clicking

instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower. Move cable to highest pulley position.
Stand with side to cable. With one hand, reach up and grab handle with underhand grip.
Pull down cable until elbow touches your side and the handle is by your shoulder.
Position feet hip-width apart. Place free hand on hip to help gauge pivot point.
Keep arm in static position. Contract oblique to bring the weight down in a side crunch.
Once you reach maximum contraction, slowly release the weight to the starting position. The weight stack should never be unloaded in a resting position. The aim is constant tension during the set.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: One-Arm High-Pulley Cable Side Bends
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a handle to the highest pulley position on a cable machine
Stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle with an underhand grip, pulling it down to your shoulder
Stand with feet hip-width apart, elbow touching your side, free hand on your hip
Contract your oblique to crunch sideways toward the cable, keeping your arm locked in position
Return slowly to the starting position with control, maintaining constant tension on the cable
form_cues: Your arm stays frozen - think of it as just a hook connecting you to the cable
Crunch with your oblique - imagine trying to bring your ribcage toward your hip
Keep constant tension - the weight stack should never rest during the set
Don't lean backward or forward - movement is purely sideways
common_mistakes: Bending the arm and using it to pull instead of crunching with the obliques
Twisting the torso instead of pure side bending
Letting the weight stack rest between reps which removes muscle tension
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to protect your spine during the lateral movement
Don't overstretch at the top - stop when you feel good oblique engagement

instructions: Lie down sideways on an incline bench press with a dumbbell in the hand. Make sure the shoulder is pressing against the incline bench and the arm is lying across your body with the palm around your navel.
Hold a dumbbell in your uppermost arm while keeping it extended in front of you parallel to the floor. This is your starting position.

While keeping the dumbbell parallel to the floor at all times, perform a lateral raise. Your arm should travel straight up until it is pointing at the ceiling. Tip: Exhale as you perform this movement. Hold the dumbbell in the position and feel the contraction in the shoulders for a second.
While inhaling lower the weight across your body back into the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One-Arm Incline Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie sideways on an incline bench with your lower shoulder pressed into the pad
Hold a dumbbell in your upper hand with arm extended in front of you parallel to the floor
Raise your arm straight up toward the ceiling, keeping the dumbbell parallel to the floor throughout
Hold at the top where your arm points to the ceiling, feeling the contraction in your shoulder
Lower slowly back to the starting position across your body, then complete all reps before switching sides
form_cues: Keep the dumbbell parallel to the floor the entire time - imagine balancing water on it
Raise your arm straight up - not forward or backward, just directly toward the ceiling
Lead with your elbow slightly, not your hand - your elbow should be at the same height or slightly higher
Squeeze your shoulder at the top - feel your delt working hard
common_mistakes: Letting the dumbbell tilt instead of staying parallel to the floor
Swinging the weight using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction
Not going through full range of motion - make sure your arm gets to vertical
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you think - this is an isolation exercise with limited mechanical advantage
If you feel shoulder pinching at the top, reduce your range of motion slightly

instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet. As you bend down to grab the kettlebell, push your butt back and keep your eyes looking forward.
Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Return the weight to the starting position.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor between your feet, push your butt back and hinge at the hips to grab it
Keep your eyes looking forward and back straight as you grip the handle
Explosively extend through your hips and legs to propel the kettlebell up toward your shoulder
Rotate your wrist as the kettlebell rises so it lands softly on your forearm at shoulder height
Lower it back to the floor with control and repeat
form_cues: Drive through your heels - imagine pushing the floor away explosively
Pull the kettlebell close to your body as it rises - keep it traveling in a straight line
Rotate your wrist at the top so the kettlebell 'lands' gently on your forearm, not crashes into it
Keep your elbow close to your body at the finish position - don't let it flare out
common_mistakes: Using your arm to curl the weight instead of using hip power to propel it
Letting the kettlebell swing far away from your body instead of keeping it close
Not rotating the wrist causing the kettlebell to crash painfully onto your forearm
injury_prevention_tips: Master the hip hinge pattern with lighter weight before going heavy
Practice the wrist rotation separately to avoid bruising your forearm

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle.
Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight.
Receive the weight overhead by returning to a squat position underneath the weight.
Keeping the weight overhead, return to a standing position. Lower the weight to the floor to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean and Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by exploding through your hips and rotating your wrist (palm forward)
Dip down by bending your knees slightly, keeping your torso upright
Explosively drive through your heels like you're jumping, using that momentum to press the kettlebell overhead
As the weight goes up, drop back into a partial squat underneath it to 'catch' it at full lockout
Stand up fully with the weight overhead, then lower it back down to repeat
form_cues: The dip is shallow and fast - think of coiling up like a spring
Drive explosively through your heels - use leg power, not just arm strength
Receive the weight overhead by dropping under it - don't just press it slowly
Lock out your arm completely overhead - imagine pushing your fist through the ceiling
common_mistakes: Pressing with arms only instead of using leg drive to generate momentum
Not dropping into a squat to receive the weight which makes it much harder
Poor timing between the dip and drive causing inefficient force transfer
injury_prevention_tips: Master the clean and the jerk separately before combining them
Start with lighter weight to learn the coordination of the leg drive and overhead catch

instructions: Lie on the floor holding a kettlebell with one hand, with your upper arm supported by the floor. The palm should be facing in.
Press the kettlebell straight up toward the ceiling, rotating your wrist.
Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor holding a kettlebell in one hand, upper arm resting on the floor, palm facing in
Press the kettlebell straight up toward the ceiling while rotating your wrist so your palm faces forward
Lock out your arm at the top, squeezing your chest and tricep
Lower the kettlebell back down with control, rotating your wrist back to neutral
Let your elbow touch the floor briefly, then immediately press back up
form_cues: Press straight up - imagine pushing through the ceiling directly above your shoulder
Rotate your wrist smoothly as you press - start palm in, finish palm forward
Keep your shoulder blade pulled down and back - don't let your shoulder shrug up
Touch your elbow lightly to the floor each rep - don't crash it down
common_mistakes: Pressing at an angle instead of straight up vertically
Not rotating the wrist which makes the press awkward and less effective
Bouncing the elbow off the floor instead of using a controlled touch-and-go
injury_prevention_tips: The floor limits your range of motion which protects your shoulder - don't try to go deeper
Keep your core engaged to prevent arching your lower back excessively

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight. Receive the weight overhead by returning to a squat position underneath the weight. Keeping the weight overhead, return to a standing position.
Lower the weight to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder with palm facing forward - this is your starting position
Dip down quickly by bending your knees, keeping your torso completely upright
Immediately drive up explosively through your heels and press the kettlebell overhead as you drop back into a squat
Lock out your arm overhead while in the squat position, then stand up fully
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder and repeat
form_cues: The dip is fast and shallow - think 'bounce' not 'squat'
Drive through your heels explosively - imagine jumping without your feet leaving the ground
Drop under the weight as it goes up - receiving it in a squat position
Your arm should lock out overhead as you land in the squat - they happen simultaneously
common_mistakes: Making the dip too deep or too slow which wastes energy and ruins timing
Pressing the weight all the way up with arm strength instead of using leg momentum
Not dropping low enough to receive the weight which makes lockout harder
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso vertical during the dip - leaning forward can strain your lower back
Master the timing with a light kettlebell before increasing weight

instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces inward. This will be your starting position.
Look at the kettlebell and press it up and out until it is locked out overhead.
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder under control and repeat. Make sure to contract your lat, butt, and stomach forcefully for added stability and strength.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Military Press To The Side
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder by explosively extending your hips and legs while pulling it up, rotating your wrist so palm faces inward
Look at the kettlebell (track it with your eyes) as you press it up and out to the side until your arm is fully locked overhead
Brace your core, squeeze your glutes, and engage your lat on the working side for maximum stability
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder with control, keeping tension throughout
Repeat for all reps on one side before switching
form_cues: Press 'up and out' at an anglenot straight overheadlike you're drawing a diagonal line to the side
Keep your eyes on the bell throughoutwhere your eyes go, the bell follows safely
Squeeze everything tightimagine your entire body is one solid, braced pillar from feet to fist
Your free arm can extend out for balancethink of yourself as a human letter 'T' at the top
common_mistakes: Pressing straight overhead instead of up and out to the sidethis changes the shoulder engagement pattern
Leaning away from the weight excessivelykeep your torso relatively upright with minimal side bend
Not bracing the corethis causes energy leaks and reduces pressing power
injury_prevention_tips: Master the standard kettlebell press before attempting this variation
Keep your shoulder packed (pulled down and back) throughout to avoid impingement

instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Hold the kettlebell with the elbow out to the side, and press it up and out until it is locked out overhead.
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder under control and repeat. Make sure to contract your lat, butt, and stomach forcefully for added stability and strength.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Para Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder with palm facing forward, elbow out to the side
Keeping your elbow flared out (not tucked), press the kettlebell up and out until it's locked overhead
Contract your lat, glutes, and abs forcefully throughout the press for stability
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder with control, maintaining that elbow-out position
Complete all reps on one side before switching
form_cues: Your elbow stays out to the side like you're making a 'goalpost' with your armdon't tuck it in
Press in a slight arcthink 'up and slightly forward' to finish overhead with the bell stacked over your shoulder
Brace your entire body like you're about to get punchedcreate full-body tension
At the top, your bicep should be close to your earimagine showing off your armpit to the ceiling
common_mistakes: Tucking the elbow in instead of keeping it outthis defeats the purpose of the 'para' position
Using momentum or leaning back to pressthis should be a strict, controlled press
Not maintaining wrist alignmentthe wrist should stay neutral, not bent back excessively
injury_prevention_tips: This elbow-out position can be tough on shouldersstart lighter than your standard press
If you feel shoulder pinching, reduce weight or switch to a more neutral elbow position

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight. Lower the weight to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Push Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder with palm facing forward
Dip down by bending your knees slightly (like a mini-squat) while keeping your torso completely upright
Explosively drive through your heels and jump slightly, using this leg power to propel the kettlebell overhead
As your body extends, press the kettlebell to full lockout overhead, riding the momentum from your legs
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder and repeat
form_cues: Think 'dip and drive'a quick knee bend followed by an explosive hip and leg extension
Your torso stays vertical during the dipimagine you're in a phone booth and can't lean forward or back
The leg drive does most of the workyour arm just guides and locks out the weight
Time the press with the jumpas your heels leave the ground, the bell shoots up
common_mistakes: Dipping too deep or too shallowa quarter squat dip is perfect, like loading a jump
Leaning forward during the dipthis turns it into a front squat instead of a vertical drive
Pressing before the leg drivethe sequence is dip, drive, then press as one fluid motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than your strict pressyou'll be surprised how much the legs help
Land softly after each rep to protect your knees and ankles

instructions: Place a kettlebell in front of your feet. Bend your knees slightly and then push your butt out as much as possible as you bend over to get in the starting position. Grab the kettlebell and pull it to your stomach, retracting your shoulder blade and flexing the elbow. Keep your back straight. Lower and repeat.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor in front of you, then hinge at the hips by pushing your butt back and bending knees slightly
Keep your back completely flat and chest up as you grab the kettlebell handle with one hand
Pull the kettlebell to your stomach/lower ribs by driving your elbow back and squeezing your shoulder blade
Lower the kettlebell back down with control until your arm is fully extended
Complete all reps on one side before switching
form_cues: Think 'elbow to back pocket'drive your elbow straight back, not out to the side
Your shoulder blade should moveat the top, squeeze it like you're crushing a grape between your shoulder blade and spine
Keep your back flat like a tabletopimagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
Your hips and torso stay stillno twisting or rotating, just the arm moves
common_mistakes: Rotating the torso to help pullthis turns it into a momentum exercise instead of a lat isolation move
Pulling with your bicep instead of your backlead with the elbow, not the hand
Rounding the backmaintain that flat back position throughout the entire set
injury_prevention_tips: If your lower back gets tired, reduce weight or take breaksform is more important than load
Don't jerk or swing the weightsmooth and controlled protects your spine

instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet. Bend your knees and push your butt back to get in the proper starting position.
Look straight ahead and swing the kettlebell back between your legs.

Immediately reverse the direction and drive through with your hips and knees, accelerating the kettlebell upward. As the kettlebell rises to your shoulder rotate your hand and punch straight up, using momentum to receive the weight locked out overhead.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Snatch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet, hinge at the hips with bent knees and flat back to grab it
Swing the kettlebell back between your legs, then explosively drive through your hips and knees
As the kettlebell accelerates upward to shoulder height, rotate your hand and punch straight up overhead
Use the momentum to 'catch' the weight locked out overhead with your arm fully extended
Lower back down and repeat
form_cues: Think 'hip snap, punch through'explosive hip extension launches the bell, then you punch up to catch it
The movement is all about hip poweryour arm is just guiding the kettlebell, not muscling it up
At the catch, your arm should 'punch through' the bellimagine breaking through a ceiling above you
The bell should floatif done right, there's a weightless moment at the transition where you rotate and lock out
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arm instead of driving with the hipsthis is a lower body power move, not an arm curl
Banging the bell on your wrist at the toprotate your hand earlier and punch through smoothly
Not fully extending the hipsyou need maximum hip snap for the bell to have enough momentum
injury_prevention_tips: Master kettlebell swings firstthe snatch is essentially a swing with an overhead catch
Start with a light bell to learn the timing of the hand rotation and overhead punch

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight.
Receive the weight overhead by returning to a squat position underneath the weight, positioning one leg in front of you and one leg behind you.
Keeping the weight overhead, return to a standing position and bring your feet together. Lower the weight to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder with palm facing forward
Dip down by bending your knees while keeping your torso upright
Explosively drive through your heels, jumping to create momentum as you press the kettlebell overhead
As the bell travels up, drop into a split stance (one leg forward, one back) to receive the weight overhead
Stand back up with the weight still overhead, bring your feet together, then lower to repeat
form_cues: Think 'dip, drive, drop, stand'four distinct phases in one fluid movement
The split catch is like doing a mini-lungeone foot shoots forward, one back, as you lock out overhead
Your back leg lands on the ball of the foot, front foot flatlike a fighter's stance
Keep the kettlebell locked overhead as you recover to standingimagine it's glued to the ceiling
common_mistakes: Not dropping low enough in the splityou need to actively drop under the weight, not just press it up
Landing with feet too narrowyour split should be wide enough for stability
Pressing before driving with the legsthe leg drive should propel the bell most of the way up
injury_prevention_tips: Practice the split position (lunge stance) separately to build stability before adding the overhead component
Master the push press firstthe split jerk adds a catching element that requires more coordination

instructions: Hold a kettlebell in one hand by the handle.
Squat towards the floor, and then reverse the motion, extending the hips, knees, and finally the ankles, to raise the kettlebell overhead.

After fully extending the body, descend into a lunge position to receive the weights overhead, one leg forward and one leg back. Ensure you drive through with your hips and lock the ketttlebells overhead in one uninterrupted motion.
Return to a standing position, holding the weight overhead, and bring the feet together. Lower the weight to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a kettlebell in one hand by the handle and squat down toward the floor
Explosively extend your hips, knees, and ankles to drive the kettlebell overhead in one motion
As the kettlebell travels up, drop into a lunge position (one leg forward, one back) to receive it overhead
Lock out your arm completely overhead, then stand up while keeping the weight overhead
Lower the kettlebell back down and repeat
form_cues: Think 'squat, explode, drop, stand'it's a powerful jump with an overhead catch in a split stance
The entire movement is one uninterrupted flowdon't pause at the shoulder, drive straight to overhead
Your arm should be locked out as you land in the splitnot still pressing
Imagine you're doing a jump squat but finishing in a lunge position with weight overhead
common_mistakes: Pausing at the shoulder like a cleanthis should be one continuous upward motion
Not fully extending before dropping into the splityou need maximum upward drive first
Landing with feet too close togethera proper split stance gives you stability under the weight
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced movementmaster regular kettlebell snatches and split jerks first
Use a light weight until the coordination of the split catch becomes natural

exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Swings
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor in front of you, hinge at the hips and grab it with one hand
Swing the kettlebell back between your legs by hinging at the hips, keeping your back flat
Explosively snap your hips forward and squeeze your glutes to swing the kettlebell up to chest/shoulder height
Let the kettlebell swing back down between your legs under control, then repeat the hip snap
Your arm stays relatively straight throughoutit's a pendulum, not a curl
form_cues: Think 'hip hinge, not squat'your hips shoot back and snap forward powerfully, knees bend slightly
Squeeze your glutes at the top like you're trying to crack a walnutthis is what drives the swing
Your arm is just a ropeimagine the kettlebell is attached to your hips and your arm is just holding on
At the top, the bell should float momentarily at chest/shoulder heightif it's going higher, you're using too much arm
common_mistakes: Squatting instead of hingingthis turns it into a quad exercise instead of a hip hinge pattern
Pulling with the arm instead of driving with the hipsyour arm just guides, hips power the swing
Letting the bell drop too low on the backswingyour forearm should touch your inner thigh at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Master the hip hinge pattern with a lighter weight before going heavy
If your lower back gets sore, check that you're hinging (not squatting) and bracing your core

instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or in a corner to keep it from moving. Load an appropriate weight onto your end.
Stand next to the bar, and take a grip with one hand close to the collar. Using your hips and legs, rise to a standing position.
Assume a bent-knee stance with your hips back and your chest up. Your arm should be extended. This will be your starting position.
Pull the weight to your side by retracting the shoulder and flexing the elbow. Do not jerk the weight or cheat during the movement.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: One-Arm Long Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a barbell in a landmine or corner, load weight on the free end
Stand next to the bar and grab the collar (near the weight) with one hand, then stand up with the weight
Assume a bent-knee athletic stance with hips back, chest up, and arm extendedthis is your starting position
Pull the bar to your side by retracting your shoulder blade and bending your elbow, keeping the bar close to your body
Pause briefly at the top, then lower back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'elbow to hip'drive your elbow straight back toward your hip, not out to the side
Your shoulder blade moves firstretract it before your elbow even bends, like you're starting a lawnmower
Keep your torso still and strongimagine you're a statue from the waist up, only your arm moves
At the top, squeeze your lat hardimagine crushing an orange in your armpit on the working side
common_mistakes: Jerking or using momentumthis should be a slow, controlled pull with a strong contraction at the top
Rotating the torso to helpkeep your chest facing forward, no twisting
Not pulling high enoughget the bar all the way to your hip for full lat engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter weight than you thinkthe leverage is different from dumbbell rows
Keep your lower back neutral and core braced throughout to protect your spine

instructions: Start in a standing position with a staggered, athletic stance. Hold a medicine ball in one hand, on the same side as your back leg. This will be your starting position.
Begin by winding the arm, raising the medicine ball above your head. As you do so, extend through the hips, knees, and ankles to load up for the slam.
At peak extension, flex the shoulders, spine, and hips to throw the ball hard into the ground directly in front of you.
Catch the ball on the bounce and continue for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: One-Arm Medicine Ball Slam
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand in a staggered athletic stance holding a medicine ball in one hand on the same side as your back leg
Wind up by raising the ball overhead while extending through your hips, knees, and anklesget tall and loaded
Explosively flex your shoulders, spine, and hips to slam the ball into the ground directly in front of you with maximum force
Catch the ball on the bounce and immediately reset for the next rep
Complete all reps on one side before switching
form_cues: Think 'reach and smash'get as tall as possible at the top, then explode downward with everything you have
At the top, you should be on your toes reaching highlike you're trying to touch the ceiling
The slam is a full-body crunchshoulders, core, and hips all flex together to generate maximum power
Aim for the same spot on the floor each timeabout one foot in front of your lead foot
common_mistakes: Not extending fully at the topyou need that full stretch to generate maximum power on the slam
Slamming with just your armthis is a full-body explosive movement from head to toe
Standing too upright on the catchstay athletic and ready, knees slightly bent
injury_prevention_tips: Use a ball designed for slammingregular medicine balls can break and cause injury
Brace your core on the slam to protect your lower back from the explosive flexion

instructions: Place one kettlebell between your feet.
Grab the handle with one hand and raise the kettlebell rapidly, let it flip so that the ball of the kettlebell lands in the palm of your hand.
Throw the kettlebell out in front of you and catch the handle with one hand.
Take the kettlebell to the floor and repeat. Make sure to work both arms.
exercises.name: One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor between your feet and grip the handle with one hand
Explosively clean the kettlebell up by extending through your hips and legs
As it rises, let the kettlebell flip so the ball lands in your open palm at shoulder height
Toss the kettlebell forward slightly and catch it by the handle with the same hand
Lower it back to the floor with control and repeat, then switch arms
form_cues: Drive explosively through your heels - imagine pushing the floor away
Let the kettlebell flip naturally - don't fight its rotation
Catch it with a soft, open palm - think about cushioning an egg
The toss forward should be controlled - just a few inches, not a major throw
common_mistakes: Trying to muscle the kettlebell with your arm instead of using hip power
Fighting the flip motion which makes the catch painful
Tossing the kettlebell too far forward making it hard to catch cleanly
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light kettlebell to master the flip and catch coordination
Practice the flip motion separately before adding the forward toss

instructions: Clean and press a kettlebell with one arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so. Press the weight overhead by extending through the elbow.This will be your starting position.
Looking straight ahead and keeping a kettlebell locked out above you, flex the knees and hips and lower your torso between your legs, keeping your head and chest up.
Pause at the bottom position for a second before rising back to the top, driving through the heels of your feet.
exercises.name: One-Arm Overhead Kettlebell Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean and press a kettlebell overhead with one arm, locking it out completely
Keep looking straight ahead with the kettlebell locked overhead throughout
Squat down by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and head straight
Go as deep as you can while maintaining balance with the weight overhead
Drive through your heels to stand back up, keeping the kettlebell locked out the entire time
form_cues: Keep your arm locked straight overhead - imagine it's a steel rod that can't bend
Look straight ahead - never look up at the weight
Keep your chest proud and up - imagine a string pulling your sternum forward
The overhead arm may drift slightly toward the midline for balance - that's okay
common_mistakes: Letting the overhead arm bend or drift forward during the squat
Looking up at the weight which throws off your balance
Not squatting deep enough because of poor overhead stability
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular overhead squats with a light weight or PVC pipe before using a heavy kettlebell
Keep your shoulder packed down and stable - don't let it shrug up toward your ear

instructions: Stand to the side of a barbell next to its center. Bend your knees and lower your body until you are able to reach the barbell.

Grasp the bar as if you were grabbing a briefcase (palms facing you since the bar is sideways). You may need a wrist wrap if you are using a significant amount of weight. This is your starting position.
Use your legs to help lift the barbell up while exhaling. Your arms should extend fully as bring the barbell up until you are in a standing position.
Slowly bring the barbell back down while inhaling. Tip: Make sure to bend your knees while lowering the weight to avoid any injury from occurring.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One-Arm Side Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand next to the center of a barbell positioned sideways, bend down and grab it like a briefcase
Your palm should face you since you're gripping the bar from the side
Drive through your legs to stand up straight, extending your arm fully as you rise
Keep the barbell close to your body and stand completely upright at the top
Bend your knees and lower the barbell back down with control, then repeat before switching sides
form_cues: Grip it like you're picking up a heavy suitcase - firm and neutral
Drive through your heels - imagine pushing the floor away
Keep the bar close to your leg as you lift - don't let it drift away
Stand tall at the top - imagine someone is pulling you up by a string from the crown of your head
common_mistakes: Rounding your back instead of hinging properly at the hips
Letting the bar drift far from your body which strains your side and grip
Curling your wrist or arm instead of keeping it straight and using leg power
injury_prevention_tips: Use a wrist wrap if gripping heavy weight to protect your wrist from torque
Keep your core braced tight throughout - this asymmetric load challenges your obliques and spine

instructions: Pick a dumbbell and place it in one of your hands. Your non lifting hand should be used to grab something steady such as an incline bench press. Lean towards your lifting arm and away from the hand that is gripping the incline bench as this will allow you to keep your balance.
Stand with a straight torso and have the dumbbell by your side at arm length with the palm of the hand facing you. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the dumbbell to your side with a slight bend on the elbow and your hand slightly tilted forward as if pouring water in a glass. Continue to go up until you arm is parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this movement and pause for a second at the top.
Lower the dumbbell back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: One-Arm Side Laterals
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a dumbbell in one hand and lean toward that side slightly, using your other hand to brace against a bench
Stand with the dumbbell hanging at arm's length by your side, palm facing in
Raise the dumbbell out to the side with a slight elbow bend until your arm is parallel to the floor
Tilt your hand slightly forward at the top like you're pouring water from a glass
Lower slowly back down with control, complete all reps, then switch sides
form_cues: Lead with your elbow, not your hand - think 'elbow up first'
Keep a slight bend in your elbow throughout - imagine there's a small orange in the crook of your elbow
Pour the water at the top - your pinky should be slightly higher than your thumb
No torso swing - stay locked in your leaned position
common_mistakes: Swinging the torso to generate momentum instead of isolated shoulder contraction
Raising the dumbbell too high (above shoulder level) which engages traps instead of delts
Not tilting the hand forward which reduces medial delt activation
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you think - the lean position and single-arm loading makes this harder than it looks
If you feel shoulder pinching at the top, reduce your range of motion slightly

instructions: Hook a leather ankle cuff to a low cable pulley and then attach the cuff to your ankle.
Face the weight stack from a distance of about two feet, grasping the steel frame for support.

While keeping your knees and hips bent slightly and your abs tight, contract your glutes to slowly kick the working leg back in a semicircular arc as high as it will comfortably go as you breathe out. Tip: At full extension, squeeze your glutes for a second in order to achieve a peak contraction.
Now slowly bring your working leg forward, resisting the pull of the cable until you reach the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement for the other side.
exercises.name: One-Legged Cable Kickback
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach an ankle cuff to a low cable pulley and strap it to your ankle
Face the weight stack from about two feet away, gripping the frame for support
Keep your knees and hips slightly bent, core tight, and kick your working leg back in an arc
Squeeze your glute hard at the top when your leg is fully extended behind you
Slowly bring your leg forward against the cable resistance back to the starting position
form_cues: Kick back in a smooth arc - imagine drawing a rainbow behind you with your heel
Squeeze your glute at the top like you're pinching a pencil between your butt cheeks
Keep your core braced - imagine someone is about to poke your belly
Control the return - don't let the cable snap your leg back forward
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively to get the leg higher instead of using glute power
Using momentum and swinging the leg instead of controlled contraction
Letting the cable pull your leg back quickly instead of resisting it
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core tight throughout to protect your lower back from hyperextension
Don't kick back so high that you arch your back - quality glute contraction beats height

instructions: From a standing position, place a bent arm against a wall or doorway.
Slowly lean toward your arm until you feel a stretch in your lats.
exercises.name: One Arm Against Wall
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand next to a wall or doorway and place your bent arm flat against it at about shoulder height
Slowly lean your body toward the wall until you feel a stretch along the side of your torso
Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds while breathing deeply
Release and switch to the other side
form_cues: Keep your arm bent at about 90 degrees - elbow at shoulder height
Lean gradually - think about moving your ribcage toward the wall
Breathe deeply throughout the stretch - don't hold your breath
You should feel the stretch along your lat and side body
common_mistakes: Pressing too hard into the wall causing shoulder discomfort instead of a lat stretch
Not leaning far enough to feel an effective stretch
Holding breath during the stretch which prevents relaxation
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly into the stretch - never bounce or force it
Stop if you feel sharp pain in your shoulder joint

instructions: For this exercise, start out by placing a towel around a chin up bar.
Grab the chin-up bar with your palm facing you. One hand will be grabbing the chin-up bar and the other will be grabbing the towel.
Bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.v

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Chin-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Wrap a towel around a chin-up bar and grab the bar with one hand (palm facing you) and the towel with the other
Lean back about 30 degrees with your chest out and lower back slightly arched
Pull yourself up by driving your elbow down and back until the bar touches your upper chest
Squeeze your back muscles hard at the top for one second
Lower yourself slowly back down until your arms are fully extended, then repeat before switching sides
form_cues: Lead with your chest - imagine trying to touch your chest to the bar
Drive your elbow down and back - think 'elbow to hip pocket'
Squeeze your lat hard at the top - feel your back doing the work, not just your arm
Lower slowly with control - count '1-2-3' on the way down
common_mistakes: Pulling with biceps only instead of engaging your back muscles
Not achieving full range of motion - make sure the bar touches your upper chest
Using momentum by swinging instead of controlled pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Build up to this with regular chin-ups and assisted variations first - this is an advanced movement
The towel provides assistance but still requires significant strength - don't rush progression

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in one hand on top of your thigh.

By using your thigh to help you get the dumbbell up, clean the dumbbell up so that you can hold it in front of you at shoulder width. Use the hand you are not lifting with to help position the dumbbell over you properly.
Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrist forward so that the palm of your hand is facing away from you. This will be your starting position.

Bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe in. Keep full control of the dumbbell at all times. Tip: Use the hand that you are not lifting with to help keep the dumbbell balance as you may struggle a bit at first. Only use your non-lifting hand if it is needed. Otherwise, keep it resting to the side.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Dumbbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell resting on your thigh, use your thigh to help kick it up
Position the dumbbell at shoulder width above your chest, palm facing forward
Lower the dumbbell slowly to your side, using your non-working hand for balance if needed
Press the dumbbell back up explosively by contracting your chest, locking out at the top
Squeeze your chest for one second at the top, then repeat before switching arms
form_cues: Keep your shoulder blade retracted - imagine pinching it to the bench
Lower the dumbbell in a slight arc toward your chest - not straight down
Press up and slightly inward - imagine bringing the dumbbell toward your centerline
Your non-working hand can stabilize you but shouldn't do any lifting
common_mistakes: Letting your shoulder roll forward at the bottom which reduces chest engagement
Torso rotating excessively to help press the weight instead of staying square
Lowering too fast without control which can strain the shoulder
injury_prevention_tips: Use your non-working hand for balance initially until you develop the stability
Start with lighter weight than you'd use for two-arm presses - single-arm loading is much harder to stabilize

instructions: Grab a dumbbell with the right arm and place the upper arm on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The dumbbell should be held at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbell until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.

As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbell is at shoulder height. Again, remember that to ensure full contraction you need to bring that small finger higher than the thumb.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Dumbbell Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench and place the back of your upper arm flat on the pad
Hold a dumbbell at shoulder height with your arm slightly bent - this is your starting position
Lower the dumbbell slowly until your arm is fully extended and you feel a stretch in your bicep
Curl the weight back up by contracting your bicep, bringing your pinky higher than your thumb
Squeeze your bicep hard at the top for one second, then repeat before switching arms
form_cues: Keep your upper arm glued to the pad - it should never lift off
Lower slowly with control - count '1-2-3' on the way down
Curl with your bicep, not by leaning back - your torso stays still
Rotate your pinky higher at the top for maximum contraction - think about showing someone your bicep peak
common_mistakes: Lifting your upper arm off the pad to help curl the weight
Dropping the weight too quickly on the way down instead of controlling the eccentric
Not achieving full extension at the bottom which reduces the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend at the bottom - stop just before your elbow locks out completely
The preacher position is very strict - use lighter weight than you would for standing curls

instructions: Lie down on a flat surface with your back pressing against the floor or an exercise mat. Make sure your knees are bent.

Have a partner hand you the bar on one hand. When starting, your arm should be just about fully extended, similar to the starting position of a barbell bench press. However, this time your grip will be neutral (palms facing your torso).
Make sure the hand you are not using to lift the weight is placed by your side.
Begin the exercise by lowering the barbell until your elbow touches the ground. Make sure to breathe in as this is the eccentric (lowering part of the exercise).
Then start lifting the barbell back up to the original starting position. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your recommended repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on the floor with knees bent and have a partner hand you a barbell in one hand
Hold the barbell with a neutral grip (palm facing your torso) with arm extended above your shoulder
Lower the barbell slowly until your elbow touches the floor - this limits your range of motion
Press the barbell back up to the starting position by extending your elbow and contracting your tricep
Repeat for all reps, then switch arms
form_cues: Keep your shoulder blade pulled down and back throughout
Lower in a controlled path - imagine placing your elbow softly on the floor
Press straight up - think about pushing toward the ceiling above your shoulder
Keep your non-working arm out to the side for balance
common_mistakes: Bouncing your elbow off the floor instead of using a controlled touch-and-go
Letting your shoulder shrug up toward your ear during the press
Pressing at an angle instead of straight up vertically
injury_prevention_tips: The floor provides a natural safety stop - don't try to go deeper than that
Keep your wrist neutral and strong - don't let it bend back under the load

instructions: Select an appropriate weight and adjust the knee pad to help keep you down. Grasp the handle with a pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Pull the handle down, squeezing your elbow to your side as you flex the elbow.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return the handle to the starting position.
For multiple repetitions, avoid completely returning the weight to keep tension on the muscles being worked.
exercises.name: One Arm Lat Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Select an appropriate weight on the cable machine and adjust the knee pad to keep you securely seated
Grab the handle with one hand using an overhand grip (palm facing away), arm fully extended above you
Pull the handle straight down by driving your elbow to your side, squeezing your lat as you flex your elbow
Pause at the bottom with the handle near your shoulder, feeling the contraction in your lat
Slowly return the handle upward with control, stopping just before the weights touch to maintain tension
form_cues: Think 'elbow to hip pocket'drive your elbow straight down toward your side, not backward
Imagine you're pulling your elbow through the floorthis mental cue helps engage the lat fully
At the bottom, squeeze your lat hard like you're crushing an orange in your armpit
Keep your torso relatively stilla slight lean back is okay, but don't rock back and forth
common_mistakes: Pulling with your bicep instead of your latlead with the elbow, the hand just holds on
Leaning back excessively to use momentumthis reduces lat activation
Letting the weight fully return at the topstop just before the stack touches to keep constant tension
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than bilateral pulldownsthe single arm requires more stability and control
If your shoulder feels unstable, reduce weight or use your free hand to brace your working side

instructions: Lie flat on a bench while holding a dumbbell at arms length. Your arm should be perpendicular to your body. The palm of your hand should be facing towards your feet as a pronated grip is required to perform this exercise.
Place your non lifting hand on your bicep for support.
Slowly begin to lower the dumbbell down as you breathe in.
Then, begin lifting the dumbbell upward as you contract the triceps. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your set repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding a dumbbell with one hand directly above you, arm perpendicular to your body, palm facing your feet
Place your non-working hand on your working bicep for support and stability
Slowly lower the dumbbell by bending your elbow, keeping your upper arm completely still, while breathing in
Press the dumbbell back up by extending your elbow, contracting your tricep hard while breathing out
Complete all reps on one arm, then switch sides
form_cues: Your upper arm is a statueonly your forearm moves from the elbow joint, nothing else
Think 'hammer down'you're driving your forearm straight up like pounding a nail into the ceiling
The pronated grip (palm facing feet) hits the tricep differentlyimagine pouring water forward at the top
At the top, lock out completely and squeeze your tricep like you're flexing for a photo
common_mistakes: Letting your upper arm drift forward or backwardkeep it perpendicular to your body the entire time
Not going through full rangelower until the dumbbell is near your ear, then fully extend
Rushing the movementslow and controlled gets better tricep activation than fast and sloppy
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you thinkthis isolation position is harder than it looks
If you feel elbow discomfort, slightly adjust your grip angle or reduce weight

instructions: Lie flat on a bench while holding a dumbbell at arms length. Your arm should be perpendicular to your body. The palm of your hand should be facing towards your face as a supinated grip is required to perform this exercise.
Place your non lifting hand on your bicep for support.
Slowly begin to lower the dumbbell down as you breathe in.
Then, begin lifting the dumbbell upward as you contract the triceps. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your set repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
Switch arms again and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding a dumbbell with one hand directly above you, arm perpendicular to your body, palm facing your face
Place your non-working hand on your working bicep to provide support
Slowly lower the dumbbell by bending your elbow while keeping your upper arm fixed, breathing in
Extend your elbow to press the dumbbell back up, squeezing your tricep while breathing out
Complete all reps on one side before switching
form_cues: The supinated grip (palm facing you) changes the tricep emphasisimagine showing yourself your palm at the top
Your upper arm stays frozenpretend it's bolted in place, only your forearm moves
Think 'press up and squeeze'drive the dumbbell straight up and lock out hard
At the bottom, control the descentdon't let gravity pull the weight down
common_mistakes: Allowing the upper arm to movethis reduces tricep isolation and makes it less effective
Not achieving full lockout at the topextend completely to maximize tricep contraction
Using momentum instead of musclesmooth, controlled reps are key
injury_prevention_tips: Start with the same or lighter weight than the pronated version to test comfort
If your wrist feels strained, slightly rotate to a more neutral grip angle

instructions: Lie facedown on the floor.
Put your left hand under your left hipbone to pad your hip and pubic bone.
Bend your right knee so you can hold the foot in your right hand.

Lift the foot in the air and simultaneously lift your shoulders off the floor. This also stretches the right hip flexor and the chest and shoulders. Switch sides. If it doesn't bother your back, you can try it with both arms and legs at the same time.
exercises.name: One Half Locust
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor with your left hand tucked under your left hip for padding
Bend your right knee and reach back to grab your right foot with your right hand
Simultaneously lift your right foot up into the air while lifting your chest and shoulders off the floor
Hold this position for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your right hip flexor, quad, chest, and shoulders
Switch sides and repeat
form_cues: Think 'lift and arch'as your foot goes up, your chest comes up too, creating a bow shape with your body
Pull your foot toward your glutes while liftingimagine trying to touch your foot to your head
Your chest should lift off the ground like someone is pulling it up with a string
Breathe deeply throughoutdon't hold your breath even though the stretch is intense
common_mistakes: Only lifting the leg without lifting the chestyou need both for the full stretch
Cranking the knee too aggressivelypull gently to avoid knee strain
Holding your breathsteady breathing helps you relax into the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: If you have lower back issues, limit how high you lift or skip this stretch
For the advanced version (both arms and legs), only attempt if your back feels completely healthy

instructions: Grab onto a chinup bar with one hand, using a pronated grip. Keep your feet on the floor or a step. Allow the majority of your weight to hang from that hand, while keeping your feet on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds and switch sides.
exercises.name: One Handed Hang
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with one hand using an overhand grip (palm facing away)
Keep your feet on the floor or on a stepyou're not fully hanging, just partially loading that arm
Allow most of your weight to hang from that hand, feeling the stretch in your lat and shoulder
Hold for 10-20 seconds while breathing normally, then switch to the other side
form_cues: Think 'active hang'keep some engagement in your shoulder, don't let it fully relax and shrug up
Your shoulder should be packed down (pulled down away from your ear), not hanging loosely
Use your feet to modulate the stretchmore weight on feet for less intensity, less weight for deeper stretch
Imagine your lat is lengthening like a rubber band being stretched
common_mistakes: Letting your shoulder shrug all the way up to your earmaintain some active control
Putting all your weight on the hang immediatelygradually increase the load as you adapt
Not breathingkeep steady, relaxed breathing throughout the hold
injury_prevention_tips: Start with minimal weight transferkeep most weight on your feet at first
