If you feel sharp shoulder pain, reduce the load or consult a professional

instructions: Start off by lying on the floor.
Extend one leg straight and pull the other knee to your chest. Hold under the knee joint to protect the kneecap.
Gently tug that knee toward your nose.
Switch sides. This stretches the buttocks and lower back of the bent leg and the hip flexor of the straight leg.
exercises.name: One Knee To Chest
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back on the floor with both legs initially extended
Extend one leg straight out and pull the opposite knee toward your chest with both hands
Hold under the knee joint (not on top of the kneecap) to protect the knee
Gently pull that knee toward your nose, feeling the stretch in your glutes and lower back
Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch legs
form_cues: Think 'hug your knee'pull it close to your chest like you're giving your knee a hug
The extended leg should stay flat on the groundpress it down to feel a hip flexor stretch too
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretcheach exhale allows you to pull slightly closer
Your lower back should flatten against the floorthis is a lower back release stretch
common_mistakes: Grabbing on top of the kneecapthis can compress the joint, hold behind the knee instead
Lifting the extended leg off the groundkeep it flat to maximize the stretch benefit
Holding your breathsteady breathing helps you relax deeper into the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Pull gently and graduallyno jerking or forcing the knee closer
If you feel sharp pain in the knee or hip, reduce the intensity or skip this stretch

instructions: Start by standing about 2 to 3 feet in front of a flat bench with your back facing the bench. Have a barbell in front of you on the floor. Tip: Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.
Bend the knees and use a pronated grip with your hands being wider than shoulder width apart from each other to lift the barbell up until you can rest it on your chest.

Then lift the barbell over your head and rest it on the base of your neck. Move one foot back so that your toe is resting on the flat bench. Your other foot should be stationary in front of you. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. Tip: Make sure your back is straight and chest is out while performing this exercise.
As you inhale, slowly lower your leg until your thigh is parallel to the floor. At this point, your knee should be over your toes. Your chest should be directly above the middle of your thigh.
Leading with the chest and hips and contracting the quadriceps, elevate your leg back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Leg Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand 2-3 feet in front of a flat bench facing away from it, with a barbell on the floor in front of you
Lift the barbell to your chest, press it overhead, and rest it on the base of your neck (high bar position)
Place one foot back with your toe resting on the bench behind you, the other foot stays planted in front
Keeping your head up and back straight, lower down by bending your front knee until your thigh is parallel to the floor
Drive through your front heel to return to standing, leading with your chest and hips
form_cues: Your front knee should track over your toesimagine it's following a train track straight forward
At the bottom, your chest should be directly above the middle of your front thighdon't lean too far forward
Think 'sit back and down'load your front hip like you're sitting into a chair
Drive through your front heel like you're pushing the floor awaythis maximizes quad and glute engagement
common_mistakes: Letting the front knee cave inwardpush it out in line with your toes throughout
Leaning too far forwardkeep your torso relatively upright with chest proud
Not going deep enoughyour front thigh should reach parallel for full range
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced movementmaster Bulgarian split squats without weight first
Use significantly lighter weight than regular squatsthe single leg makes it much harder

instructions: Place one kettlebell between your feet. Clean the kettlebell by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulders.
Release the kettlebell as it comes up, and let it flip so that the ball of the kettlebell lands in the palms of your hands.
Release the kettlebell out in front of you and catch the handle with both hands. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet and hinge down to grab the handle
Explosively extend through your legs and hips to clean the kettlebell up toward your shoulders
As the kettlebell rises, release your grip and let it flip so the ball lands in your open palms
Catch it with both palms, then release it back out in front of you and catch the handle
Lower back to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Think 'flip and catch'there's a weightless moment where you release the handle and catch the ball portion
The power comes from your hipssnap them forward explosively to launch the kettlebell up
Your palms should be facing up to catch the bellimagine you're catching a basketball
Trust the timingdon't grip too long or you'll miss the flip
common_mistakes: Not releasing the handle early enoughyou need to let go at shoulder height for the flip to work
Using arm strength instead of hip powerthis is a hip hinge explosive movement
Catching the bell too lowit should flip and land in your palms at chest height
injury_prevention_tips: Practice with a light kettlebell until the timing of the release and catch becomes natural
This is an advanced kettlebell skillmaster regular cleans first

instructions: Secure your feet and lay back on the floor. Your knees should be bent. Hold a weight with both hands to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by flexing the hips and spine to raise your torso up from the ground.
As you move up, press the weight up so that it is above your head at the top of the movement.
Return the weight to your chest as you reverse the sit-up motion, ensuring not to go all the way down to the floor.
exercises.name: Otis-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your feet (using a partner, equipment, or tucking under something) and lie back with knees bent
Hold a weight plate or dumbbell with both hands against your chestthis is your starting position
Flex your hips and spine to sit up from the floor, bringing your torso toward your knees
As you reach the top of the sit-up, press the weight straight overhead until your arms are fully extended
Lower the weight back to your chest as you slowly lower back down, stopping just before touching the floor
form_cues: Think 'sit up, press up'two movements flowing together in one rep
Your abs do the sit-up, your shoulders/triceps do the pressseparate but sequential
At the top, you should be sitting upright with the weight locked out overhead like a trophy
Control the descentdon't just fall backward, use your abs to lower with control
common_mistakes: Pressing the weight before reaching the topcomplete the sit-up first, then press
Letting your back touch the floor between repsstop just short to keep tension on your abs
Using momentum to swing upthis should be a controlled sit-up with an overhead press
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weighteven 10-25 lbs is challenging when combined with a sit-up
If you have lower back issues, this exercise may not be appropriateconsult a professional

instructions: To begin, set a weight that is comfortable on each side of the pulley machine. Note: Make sure that the amount of weight selected is the same on each side.
Now adjust the height of the pulleys on each side and make sure that they are positioned at a height higher than that of your shoulders.

Stand in the middle of both sides and use an underhand grip (palms facing towards the ceiling) to grab each handle. Your arms should be fully extended and parallel to the floor with your feet positioned shoulder width apart from each other. Your body should be evenly aligned the handles. This is the starting position.
While exhaling, slowly squeeze the biceps on each side until your forearms and biceps touch.
While inhaling, move your forearms back to the starting position. Note: Your entire body is stationary during this exercise except for the forearms.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.
exercises.name: Overhead Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the cable pulleys to a height above your shoulders with equal weight on each side
Stand in the middle and grab each handle with an underhand grip (palms facing up), arms fully extended out to the sides parallel to the floor
Your body should be positioned evenly between the handles with feet shoulder-width apartthis is your starting position
Squeeze your biceps and curl both handles toward your head by bending your elbows, keeping upper arms parallel to floor
Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position while inhaling, keeping your entire body still except your forearms
form_cues: At the peak contraction, your forearms should touch your bicepsthink 'squeeze and hold'
Your upper arms stay completely parallel to the floorimagine they're resting on invisible shelves
Think 'double biceps pose'at the top, you're flexing like a bodybuilder on stage
Only your forearms movefrom elbows down, everything else is frozen in place
common_mistakes: Letting your upper arms drop or move forwardthey must stay parallel to the floor throughout
Leaning or shifting your body to help curlyour torso stays completely still
Not achieving full contractioncurl until your forearms touch your biceps for maximum squeeze
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weightthis is an isolation exercise with poor leverage, so don't go heavy
If you feel shoulder discomfort, lower the pulley height slightly or reduce weight

instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your tricep and wrist. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to pull your upper arm to your side as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the lat by applying gentle pressure to the tricep. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Overhead Lat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner positioned directly behind you
Reach one arm straight up toward the ceiling, then bend your elbow to touch your hand between your shoulder blades - your partner holds your tricep and wrist
Try to pull your upper arm down to your side against your partner's resistance for 10-20 seconds - engage like you're doing a lat pulldown
Relax completely and let your partner gently press your tricep toward your back for a deeper stretch, hold 10-20 seconds
Switch sides and repeat the entire sequence
form_cues: Think 'elbow to hip pocket' when contracting against resistance
Keep your torso tall like a stack of coins - don't lean or twist
Breathe out slowly during the stretch phase to help your muscles relax deeper
common_mistakes: Leaning sideways or forward instead of sitting upright throughout the stretch
Tensing up during the relaxation phase instead of letting the muscle go completely slack
Having the partner positioned too far to the side instead of directly behind
injury_prevention_tips: Partner should apply pressure gradually - no sudden jerking or bouncing movements
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or pinching in the shoulder joint

instructions: Standing straight up, lace your fingers together and open your palms to the ceiling. Keep your shoulders down as you extend your arms up.
To create a full torso stretch, pull your tailbone down and stabilize your torso as you do this. Stretch the muscles on both the front and the back of the torso.
exercises.name: Overhead Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart, interlace your fingers and flip your palms to face the ceiling
Press your palms up and straighten your arms overhead - imagine pushing the ceiling away
Pull your shoulders down away from your ears - think 'long neck, low shoulders'
Tuck your tailbone slightly under like you're zipping up tight jeans while keeping your ribs down
Hold for 20-30 seconds while breathing normally through your nose
form_cues: Imagine a string pulling your hands to the ceiling while your feet stay rooted to the floor
Create a 'tall spine' sensation like you're growing an inch taller
Think about stretching the front and back of your torso equally - not just arching backward
common_mistakes: Shrugging shoulders up toward ears instead of actively pressing them down
Arching the lower back excessively instead of keeping the core engaged
Holding your breath - this prevents muscles from fully relaxing into the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a micro-bend in your elbows if you feel strain in the joints
If you have shoulder issues, only raise arms to a comfortable height rather than forcing full overhead position

instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your elbow and wrist. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to extend the arm straight into the air as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the tricep by applying gentle pressure to the wrist. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Overhead Triceps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright with your partner behind you, raise one arm straight up and bend the elbow to touch your hand to your upper back
Your partner holds your elbow and wrist while you attempt to straighten your arm upward against their resistance for 10-20 seconds
Contract hard like you're trying to push through their grip - think 'press the ceiling'
Fully relax and let your partner gently push your wrist down toward your back for a deeper tricep stretch, hold 10-20 seconds
Switch arms and repeat the full sequence
form_cues: Keep your elbow pointing straight to the ceiling throughout - don't let it drift forward or out to the side
During contraction, imagine pushing a heavy weight straight overhead
Exhale slowly during the stretch phase to help the tricep release tension
common_mistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out to the side instead of staying close to your head
Rounding your upper back forward - maintain an upright, proud chest position
Partner pulling too aggressively on the wrist causing shoulder discomfort
injury_prevention_tips: Partner should apply pressure gradually and smoothly - never bounce or jerk the arm
Stop if you feel any sharp pain in the shoulder or elbow joint, not just muscle tension

instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and possibleposition the cable to shoulder height. If not, a low pulley will suffice.
With your side to the cable, grab the handle with both hands and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable.
With your feet positioned hip-width apart and knees slightly bent, hold the cable to the middle of your chest. This will be your starting position.
Press the cable away from your chest, fully extending both arms. You core should be tight and engaged.
Hold the repetition for several seconds before returning to the starting position.
At the conclusion of the set, repeat facing the other direction.
exercises.name: Pallof Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable at chest height, stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle with both hands at your sternum
Step away until there's tension on the cable - you should be about an arm's length from the pulley
Stand with feet hip-width, knees slightly bent, and brace your core like someone's about to punch your stomach
Press the handle straight out from your chest until arms are fully extended - the cable will try to rotate you but resist it
Hold for 2-3 seconds with arms locked out, then control the handle back to your chest - repeat for reps, then switch sides
form_cues: Imagine you're a statue - the cable is trying to twist you but you stay perfectly square to the front
Squeeze your abs and glutes like you're bracing for impact throughout the entire movement
Think 'push the cable, don't let the cable push you' - your torso shouldn't rotate even a millimeter
common_mistakes: Rotating the torso toward the cable instead of keeping hips and shoulders square
Leaning away from the cable or shifting weight to one leg
Using too much weight and compromising form - this is about stability, not strength
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the anti-rotation feeling before progressing
Keep your shoulders packed down and back - don't let them round forward

instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and position the cable to shoulder height.

With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. Align outstretched arm with cable.
With your feet positioned hip-width apart, pull the cable into your chest and grab the handle with your other hand. Both hands should be on the handle at this time.
Facing forward, press the cable away from your chest. You core should be tight and engaged.
Keeping your hips straight, twist your torso away from the pulley until you get a full quarter rotation.
Maintain your rigid stance and straight arms. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner. Your arms should be extended in front of you.
With the side tension still engaging your core, bring your hands to your chest and immediately press outward to a fully extended position. This constitutes one rep.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Pallof Press With Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable at chest height, stand sideways and grab with both hands, step away until there's tension
Pull the handle to your chest, then press straight out until your arms are fully extended
Keeping hips facing forward and arms locked, rotate your upper body away from the cable a full 90 degrees
Slowly rotate back to center with arms still extended, then pull the handle back to your chest
Press back out immediately and repeat the rotation - that's one rep, continue for your set then switch sides
form_cues: Hips stay locked forward like they're in cement - only your upper body rotates
Think 'proud chest leads the way' as you twist - don't collapse or round your shoulders
Your arms stay in one solid plank position - the rotation happens at your spine, not your elbows
common_mistakes: Rotating the hips along with the torso instead of isolating the upper body twist
Bending the arms during rotation instead of maintaining full extension
Moving too fast through the rotation losing control and stability
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than regular Pallof Press - the rotation increases difficulty significantly
Keep movements smooth and controlled - no jerking or momentum

instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.

Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells with a pronated grip (palms facing down) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench, then kneel facing the bench
Grab both dumbbells with palms facing down and rest your forearms flat on the bench with wrists hanging off the edge
Let the dumbbells pull your hands down toward the floor - this is your stretched starting position
Curl your knuckles up toward the ceiling as high as possible, squeezing the tops of your forearms
Lower back down slowly with control until you feel a stretch in your forearms - that's one rep
form_cues: Think 'knuckles to sky' when curling up - maximize the range of motion at the top
Your forearms stay glued to the bench like they're bolted down - only your wrists move
Squeeze at the top like you're trying to show off the muscles on top of your forearms
common_mistakes: Lifting the forearms off the bench instead of keeping them fully pressed down
Using momentum by rocking your body instead of isolating the wrist movement
Gripping too tight with fingers instead of letting the weight rest in your palms
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight - forearms fatigue quickly and form breaks down fast
If you feel sharp pain in the wrist joint (not muscle burn), reduce weight or range of motion

instructions: Start out by placing a barbell on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a pronated grip (palms down) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Down Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a barbell on one side of a flat bench and kneel facing the bench
Grab the barbell with both hands palms facing down, rest your forearms flat on the bench with wrists hanging over the edge
Let the barbell pull your hands down toward the floor to get a full stretch in your forearms
Curl your knuckles upward toward the ceiling as high as you can, squeezing the top of your forearms hard
Control the barbell back down to the stretched position - repeat for reps
form_cues: Imagine you're revving a motorcycle - that upward wrist curl motion
Forearms are superglued to the bench - zero movement except at the wrist joint
Get full range - go from 'hands drooping down' to 'knuckles pointing up' on every rep
common_mistakes: Peeling forearms off the bench to cheat the weight up
Only using partial range of motion instead of maximizing the curl and stretch
Loading too much weight and turning it into a momentum exercise
injury_prevention_tips: Use a weight where you can control every rep - this is an isolation exercise, not a strength test
Stop if you feel pain in your wrist joints or elbow tendons

instructions: Start out by placing a barbell on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a supinated grip (palms up) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Up Barbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a barbell on one side of a bench, kneel facing the bench with your torso upright
Grab the barbell with palms facing up and rest your forearms completely flat on the bench, wrists hanging off the edge
Let the bar roll down toward your fingertips to get a full stretch in your forearms
Curl the bar up toward your body by flexing your wrists as high as possible - squeeze your forearms
Lower the bar back down with control until you feel the stretch return - that's one rep
form_cues: Think about 'fingertips to forearms' - curl the bar as close to your arms as possible
Your forearms are cemented to the bench - imagine they're in a cast and only your wrists can move
At the bottom, let the bar roll to your fingertips for maximum stretch before curling back up
common_mistakes: Lifting the forearms or elbows off the bench to help move the weight
Not using full range - missing the fingertip roll at the bottom or full flex at the top
Going too heavy and sacrificing the isolation for bouncy, momentum-driven reps
injury_prevention_tips: Start lighter than you think - forearms burn out quickly and form deteriorates fast
Keep your wrists in a natural path of motion - don't force them into uncomfortable angles

instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells with a supinated grip (palms up) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to inhale during this part of the exercise.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench, kneel facing the bench
Grab both dumbbells with palms facing up, rest your forearms flat on the bench with wrists hanging over the edge
Let the dumbbells roll toward your fingertips to stretch your forearms - this is the starting position
Curl your wrists up toward your body as high as possible, squeezing your forearms at the top
Lower back down slowly, letting the weight roll to your fingertips again - repeat for reps
form_cues: Think 'curl the weight to your forearms' - get maximum contraction at the top
Let the dumbbells roll out to your fingertips at the bottom for a full stretch
Forearms stay welded to the bench - imagine someone's holding them down
common_mistakes: Lifting forearms off the bench to assist the movement instead of pure wrist isolation
Not allowing the dumbbells to roll down to fingertips, cutting range of motion short
Using too much weight and relying on body English instead of strict form
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight - these are small muscles that fatigue rapidly
If you feel tendon pain (sharp, specific pain vs. muscle burn), reduce weight or stop

instructions: Lie down with your feet on the floor, heels directly under your knees.
Lift only your tailbone to the ceiling to stretch your lower back. (Don't lift the entire spine yet.) Pull in your stomach.
To go into a bridge, lift the entire spine except the neck.
exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor directly under your knees, arms relaxed at your sides
First, just tilt your pelvis up by pressing your lower back flat into the floor - think 'tuck your tailbone under'
Pull your belly button toward your spine to engage your core
From the tilt position, squeeze your glutes and lift your hips up until your body forms a straight line from knees to shoulders
Hold for 2-3 seconds at the top, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Think 'imprint your spine into the floor' during the pelvic tilt before lifting
Squeeze your glutes like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks at the top of the bridge
Imagine a straight plank from your knees through your hips to your shoulders - no sagging or overarching
common_mistakes: Overarching the lower back at the top instead of maintaining the pelvic tilt
Pushing through your toes instead of driving through your heels
Lifting too high and hyperextending the spine instead of stopping at neutral alignment
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck relaxed and neutral - don't tuck your chin or look around during the movement
If you feel lower back strain, focus on the glute squeeze and don't lift as high

instructions: Lay on your side, supporting your weight on your forearm and on a foam roller placed on the outside of your lower leg. Your upper leg can either be on top of your lower leg, or you can cross it in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Raise your hips off of the ground and begin to roll from below the knee to above the ankle on the side of your leg, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.
exercises.name: Peroneals-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with a foam roller under the outside of your lower leg, between your knee and ankle
Support your upper body on your forearm - imagine you're doing a side plank but with the roller under your calf
Place your top leg crossed in front for stability, or stack it on top
Roll slowly up and down the outside of your shin, pausing anywhere that feels tight for 20-30 seconds
form_cues: Think about rolling the 'outside seam' of your lower leg where your shin meets your calf
When you hit a tender spot, take 3 deep breaths before moving on
Keep your core engaged like you're bracing for a punch to stay stable
common_mistakes: Rolling too fast without pausing on tight spots - this is massage, not cardio
Rolling directly over the shin bone instead of staying on the meaty outside part
Letting your hips sag toward the floor - maintain that side plank tension
injury_prevention_tips: Never roll directly on bone - stay on the muscle tissue only
If you feel sharp pain or numbness, ease off the pressure immediately

instructions: In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. This will be your starting position.

With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is inverted, with the inside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Peroneals Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you
Loop a resistance band, belt, or towel around the ball of one foot
Lift your heel slightly off the ground and keep your leg straight
Pull the band to rotate the inside of your foot toward you - like you're trying to show someone the sole of your foot
Hold the stretch for 15-20 seconds, feeling it on the outside of your lower leg
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to turn your foot 'pigeon-toed' while someone resists you
You should feel the stretch along the outside edge of your shin and calf
Pull with steady pressure - no bouncing or jerking
common_mistakes: Pulling the toes down toward the floor instead of rotating the foot inward
Bending the knee which reduces the stretch effectiveness
Using too much force and causing cramping in the foot
injury_prevention_tips: Start with gentle pressure and gradually increase - this is a sensitive area
Stop immediately if you feel cramping and shake out your foot

instructions: Lay on a ball so that your upper back is on the ball with your hips unsupported. Both feet should be flat on the floor, hip width apart or wider. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending the hips using your glutes and hamstrings, raising your hips upward as you bridge.
Pause at the top of the motion and return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Physioball Hip Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on an exercise ball so your shoulder blades rest on top, with your head and neck supported
Plant both feet flat on the floor, hip-width or wider, knees bent at 90 degrees
Start with your hips dropped slightly below knee level
Squeeze your glutes hard and drive your hips up until your body forms a straight line from knees to shoulders
Hold at the top for 1-2 seconds, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Pretend you're trying to leave a butt print on the ceiling - squeeze those glutes hard at the top
Imagine balancing a broomstick across your hips to knees - keep that line straight
Drive through your heels like you're pushing the floor away from you
common_mistakes: Pushing through the toes instead of the heels, which shifts work to the quads
Arching the lower back at the top instead of using glute power
Letting the ball roll around - keep your upper back stable and centered
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck in neutral - don't crane your head forward or back
If you feel lower back strain, you're arching too much - focus on glute squeeze only

instructions: Pin presses remove the eccentric phase of the bench press, developing starting strength. They also allow you to train a desired range of motion.

The bench should be set up in a power rack. Set the pins to the desired point in your range of motion, whether it just be lockout or an inch off of your chest. The bar should be moved to the pins and prepared for lifting.

Begin by lying on the bench, with the bar directly above the contact point during your regular bench. Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement.
You can take a standard bench grip, or shoulder width to focus on the triceps. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart.
Drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.
Return the bar to the pins, pausing before beginning the next repetition.
exercises.name: Pin Presses
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up safety pins in a power rack at your desired height (chest level, mid-range, or lockout)
Lie on the bench with the barbell resting on the pins, positioned over your chest contact point
Plant your feet firmly under you, arch your upper back, and squeeze your shoulder blades together like you're crushing a pencil between them
Grip the bar with hands at shoulder width or slightly wider, wrists straight
Drive the bar explosively upward until your arms lock out, focusing on tricep power
Lower back to the pins with control and pause completely before the next rep
form_cues: Imagine your shoulder blades are trying to meet behind your spine - stay retracted the entire time
Drive your feet into the ground like you're leg pressing the earth away from you
Think about 'bending the bar' in your hands to create tension and stability
Explode up like you're trying to throw the bar through the ceiling
common_mistakes: Starting the next rep with momentum instead of pausing completely on the pins
Letting your shoulder blades spread apart as you press - maintain that retraction
Flaring elbows out wide which reduces tricep activation and increases shoulder stress
injury_prevention_tips: Always use safety pins and test the setup with light weight first
Keep wrists stacked directly over elbows - no bending or excessive wrist extension

instructions: Sit with your buttocks on top of a foam roll. Bend your knees, and then cross one leg so that the ankle is over the knee. This will be your starting position.

Shift your weight to the side of the crossed leg, rolling over the buttocks until you feel tension in your upper glute. You may assist the stretch by using one hand to pull the bent knee towards your chest. Hold this position for 10-30 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Piriformis-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a foam roller with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor
Cross one ankle over the opposite knee in a 'figure 4' position
Shift your weight toward the side of the crossed leg - lean into that hip
Roll slowly in small circles until you find a tender spot in your upper glute/hip area
Once you find tension, hold for 20-30 seconds while taking deep breaths
form_cues: Think about sitting on your 'back pocket' area where your glute meets your hip
Use your opposite hand to gently pull the crossed knee toward your chest for a deeper release
Imagine melting into the roller with each exhale - let gravity do the work
common_mistakes: Rolling on the center of the glute instead of the upper outer area near the hip
Moving too fast without pausing on tight spots
Tensing up when you hit a sore spot - breathe and relax into it
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid rolling directly on your tailbone - stay on the meaty part of the glute
If you feel sciatic nerve pain shooting down your leg, ease off immediately and adjust position

instructions: Get into a prone position on the floor, supporting your weight on your toes and your forearms. Your arms are bent and directly below the shoulder.
Keep your body straight at all times, and hold this position as long as possible. To increase difficulty, an arm or leg can be raised.
exercises.name: Plank
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on your forearms and toes, with elbows directly under your shoulders
Create a straight line from your head through your heels - like you're a wooden plank
Squeeze your glutes, brace your abs like someone's about to punch your stomach, and hold
Look at the floor slightly in front of your hands to keep your neck neutral
Breathe steadily and hold the position for your target time
form_cues: Imagine balancing a glass of water on your lower back - don't let it spill by sagging or piking
Squeeze your glutes so hard you could crack a walnut between your cheeks
Pull your elbows toward your toes (without actually moving them) to engage your core more
Think about making your body as rigid as a steel beam
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag toward the floor which strains the lower back
Piking your hips up in the air like a mountain, which makes it easier but less effective
Holding your breath - breathe normally even while bracing
injury_prevention_tips: If your lower back hurts, reset your form - engage glutes harder and tuck your pelvis slightly
Keep your neck neutral - don't crane your head up or let it hang down

instructions: Grab two wide-rimmed plates and put them together with the smooth sides facing outward
Use your fingers to grip the outside part of the plate and your thumb for the other side thus holding both plates together. This is the starting position.
Squeeze the plate with your fingers and thumb. Hold this position for as long as you can.
Repeat for the recommended amount of sets prescribed in your program.
Switch arms and repeat the movements.
exercises.name: Plate Pinch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab two weight plates and place them together with the smooth sides facing outward
Use your fingers on one side and thumb on the other to pinch both plates together
Stand up straight with the plates hanging at your side, arm fully extended
Squeeze as hard as you can, like you're trying to crush the plates together
Hold for as long as possible, then carefully set them down and switch hands
form_cues: Imagine you're crushing an aluminum can between your fingers and thumb
Keep your wrist neutral - don't let it bend or flex
Focus on squeezing with your fingertips, not your whole hand
Breathe steadily - don't hold your breath during the hold
common_mistakes: Using plates that are too heavy and compromising grip before even starting
Letting your wrist bend which reduces the training effect on your grip
Dropping the plates when fatigued - lower them carefully to avoid injury
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter plates and work up gradually - this exercise can cause finger strain
If you feel sharp pain in your finger joints, stop immediately and reduce the weight

instructions: Lie down on the floor or an exercise mat with your legs fully extended and your upper body upright. Grab the plate by its sides with both hands out in front of your abdominals with your arms slightly bent.

Slowly cross your legs near your ankles and lift them up off the ground. Your knees should also be bent slightly. Note: Move your upper body back slightly to help keep you balanced turning this exercise. This is the starting position.
Move the plate to the left side and touch the floor with it. Breathe out as you perform that movement.

Come back to the starting position as you breathe in and then repeat the movement but this time to the right side of the body. Tip: Use a slow controlled movement at all times. Jerking motions can injure the back.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Plate Twist
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your legs extended, then lean back slightly and lift your feet a few inches off the ground
Bend your knees slightly and cross your ankles for stability
Hold a weight plate with both hands at arm's length in front of your chest
Rotate your torso to the left, touching the plate to the floor beside your hip
Return to center, then rotate right and touch the floor on the other side - that's one rep
form_cues: Imagine you're sitting in a 'V' position like a boat - keep that angle the whole time
Rotate from your core, not your arms - pretend your shoulders and the plate are glued together
Touch the floor gently like you're tapping a hot stove, then come back to center with control
Keep your chest up proud - don't round your upper back forward
common_mistakes: Moving only your arms side to side instead of rotating your entire torso
Dropping your feet to the ground which makes it easier but less effective
Using momentum and swinging the plate instead of controlled rotation
injury_prevention_tips: Keep movements slow and controlled - jerking can strain your lower back
If your lower back hurts, lean back less and keep your feet on the ground until you build strength

instructions: For this movement a wooden floor or similar is needed. Lay on your back with your legs extended. Place a gym towel or a light weight underneath your heel. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the knee, keeping your other leg straight.
Continue bringing the heel closer to you, sliding it on the floor.
At full knee flexion, reverse the movement to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Platform Hamstring Slides
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back on a smooth floor (wood or tile works best) with one leg extended
Place a towel or weight plate under the heel of your working leg
Keep your other leg straight and resting on the floor for stability
Slowly drag your heel toward your butt by bending your knee, sliding the towel along the floor
Pull your heel as close as possible, then slide it back out to straighten your leg completely
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to pull your heel through the floor - create friction and resistance
Your heel should stay in contact with the floor/towel the entire time - never lift it
Think about 'scraping gum off your shoe' as you pull your heel toward you
Squeeze your hamstring and glute at the fully bent position before extending
common_mistakes: Lifting your heel off the ground which eliminates the sliding resistance
Using your hip flexors to pull instead of your hamstring - focus on the back of your thigh
Moving too fast without controlling both the pull and the extension
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back flat on the floor - don't arch as you slide
If you feel cramping in your hamstring, ease up and stretch between sets

instructions: Hold a dumbbell at the base with both hands and stand straight up. Move your legs so that they are wider than shoulder width apart from each other with your knees slightly bent.
Your toes should be facing out. Note: Your arms should be stationary while performing the exercise. This is the starting position.
Slowly bend the knees and lower your legs until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Make sure to inhale as this is the eccentric part of the exercise.
Press mainly with the heel of the foot to bring the body back to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Plie Dumbbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold one dumbbell vertically with both hands at the top weight plate, arms hanging straight down
Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed out at 45 degrees
Keep your chest up and core braced, with a slight bend in your knees to start
Lower down by bending your knees and pushing them out toward your toes, dropping your hips straight down
Go until your thighs are parallel to the floor, then drive through your heels to stand back up
form_cues: Imagine you're sliding your back down a wall - keep your torso upright, don't lean forward
Push your knees out toward your pinky toes - think 'knees over toes' in a wide stance
Pretend you're sitting down between your legs, not back onto a chair
Drive through your heels like you're trying to spread the floor apart
common_mistakes: Letting your knees cave inward instead of tracking over your toes
Leaning your torso forward which shifts work from legs to lower back
Rising onto your toes instead of keeping your heels planted firmly
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your knees tracking in line with your toes - never let them collapse inward
If you feel lower back strain, you're leaning too far forward - stay more upright

instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor. Place yourself in a pushup position, on your toes with one hand on the ground and one hand holding the kettlebell, with your elbows extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by lowering yourself as low as you can, keeping your back straight.

Quickly and forcefully reverse direction, pushing yourself up to the other side of the kettlebell, switching hands as you do so. Continue the movement by descending and repeating the movement back and forth.
exercises.name: Plyo Kettlebell Pushups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor and get into pushup position with one hand on the ground and one hand gripping the kettlebell handle
Lower yourself down into a deep pushup, keeping your body in a straight line from head to heels
Explosively push up with enough force to leave the ground briefly, switching which hand is on the kettlebell mid-air
Land softly with the opposite hand on the kettlebell and immediately descend into the next rep
Continue alternating sides with controlled, explosive reps
form_cues: Think 'explode like a spring' on the way up - generate enough power to get airtime
Keep your core rock-solid like a plank throughout - no sagging hips or piking up
Land softly with bent elbows to absorb the impact, then immediately flow into the next rep
common_mistakes: Not generating enough explosive power to properly switch hands mid-air
Letting hips sag or pike up during the transition, breaking the plank position
Landing with locked elbows instead of absorbing the impact with bent arms
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular explosive pushups before adding the kettlebell and hand-switching element
Land with control - don't let your body crash down, especially on the wrist holding the kettlebell

instructions: In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. This will be your starting position.

With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is everted, with the outside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Posterior Tibialis Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with legs extended, loop a resistance band, belt, or towel around the ball of one foot
Keep your leg straight and lift your heel slightly off the ground
Pull the band to rotate the outside edge of your foot toward you - like you're trying to show someone the outer edge of your sole
Hold the stretch for 10-20 seconds feeling tension along the inside of your shin and ankle
Release slowly and switch to the other foot
form_cues: Think 'rotate the pinky-toe side of your foot toward your face'
Keep your leg completely straight - no bending at the knee to maximize the stretch
Pull gently and progressively deeper - don't yank the band suddenly
common_mistakes: Bending the knee instead of keeping the leg fully extended
Pulling the foot straight toward you (dorsiflexion) instead of rotating it outward (eversion)
Using too much force too quickly instead of easing into the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Stop if you feel sharp pain in the ankle joint - you should only feel a stretch in the shin and calf muscles
Progress the stretch gradually over multiple sessions rather than forcing maximum range immediately

instructions: Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart and toes pointing out slightly.
Squat down and grasp bar with a closed, pronated grip. Your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder width apart outside knees with elbows fully extended.
Place the bar about 1 inch in front of your shins and over the balls of your feet.
Your back should be flat or slightly arched, your chest held up and out and your shoulder blades should be retracted.
Keep your head in a neutral position (in line with vertebral column and not tilted or rotated) with your eyes focused straight ahead. Inhale during this phase.

Lift the bar from the floor by forcefully extending the hips and the knees as you exhale. Tip: The upper torso should maintain the same angle. Do not bend at the waist yet and do not let the hips rise before the shoulders (this would have the effect of pushing the glutes in the air and stretching the hamstrings.
Keep elbows fully extended with the head in a neutral position and the shoulders over the bar.
As the bar raises keep it as close to the shins as possible.
As the bar passes the knees, thrust your hips forward and slightly bend the knees to avoid locking them. Tip: At this point your thighs should be against the bar.
Keep the back flat or slightly arched, elbows fully extended and your head neutral. Tip: You will hold your breath until the next phase.
Inhale and then forcefully and quickly extend your hips and knees and stand on your toes.

Keep the bar as close to your body as possible. Tip: Your back should be flat with the elbows pointed out to the sides and your head in a neutral position. Also, keep your shoulders over the bar and arms straight as long as possible.
When your lower body joints are fully extended, shrug the shoulders upward rapidly without letting the elbows flex yet. Exhale during this portion of the movement.
As the shoulders reach their highest elevation flex your elbows to begin pulling your body under the bar.

Continue to pull the arms as high and as long as possible. Tip: Due to the explosive nature of this phase, your torso will be erect or with an arched back, your head will be tilted back slightly and your feet may lose contact with the floor.
After the lower body has fully extended and the bar reaches near maximal height, pull your body under the bar and rotate the arms around and under the bar.
Simultaneously, flex the hips and knees into a quarter squat position.
Once the arms are under the bar, inhale and then lift your elbows to position the upper arms parallel to the floor. Rack the bar across the front of your collar bones and front shoulder muscles.
Catch the bar with an erect and tight torso, a neutral head position and flat feet. Exhale during this movement.
Stand up by extending the hips and knees to a fully erect position.
Lower the bar by gradually reducing the muscular tension of the arms to allow a controlled descent of the bar to the thighs. Inhale during this movement.
Simultaneously flex the hips and knees to cushion the impact of the bar on the thighs.
Squat down with the elbows fully extended until the bar touches the floor.
Start over at Phase 1 and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Power Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start with the bar over your mid-foot, feet shoulder-width apart, grip slightly outside your knees with straight arms and flat back
Drive through your legs to lift the bar, keeping it close to your shins - think 'push the floor away'
Once the bar passes your knees, explosively extend your hips, knees, and ankles while shrugging your shoulders up
As the bar reaches maximum height, quickly pull yourself under it, rotating your elbows forward to catch it on your front shoulders in a quarter squat
Stand up fully with the bar racked on your shoulders, then lower it back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'jump and shrug' at the explosive phase - launch the bar with your whole body
Keep the bar in a straight vertical line close to your body - imagine sliding it up your shins and thighs
Fast elbows at the catch - whip them around and under the bar like you're throwing them to the ceiling
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift away from the body instead of keeping it close throughout the pull
Bending the arms too early in the pull instead of keeping them straight until the explosive shrug
Catching the bar with elbows pointing down instead of rotating them up and forward
injury_prevention_tips: Learn the movement with PVC pipe or empty bar before adding weight - this is a technical lift
Keep your back flat or slightly arched throughout - never round your lower back under load

instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
The palms of the hands should be facing your torso. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight and the torso stationary, lift the weights out to your sides until they are about shoulder level height while exhaling.

Feel the contraction for a second and begin to lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling. Tip: Keep the palms facing down with the little finger slightly higher while lifting and lowering the weights as it will concentrate the stress on your shoulders mainly.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Power Partials
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand hanging at your sides, palms facing your thighs, feet shoulder-width apart
Keep your arms completely straight and raise both dumbbells out to your sides until they reach shoulder height
Your palms should face the floor at the top with your pinky fingers slightly higher than your thumbs - like pouring water from a pitcher
Pause briefly at shoulder height, squeezing your side delts
Lower the weights back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'pour the water out' at the top - pinky finger leads slightly higher than thumb
Keep your torso completely still like a statue - no leaning or swinging
Lead with your elbows slightly bent like you have a gentle curve in your arms, not locked straight
common_mistakes: Swinging the weights up using momentum instead of controlled shoulder movement
Shrugging shoulders up toward ears instead of keeping them down and away
Raising the weights above shoulder level, which shifts tension to the upper traps instead of side delts
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you think - this isolation movement requires strict form
Stop at shoulder height - going higher puts unnecessary stress on the shoulder joint

instructions: To perform this movement you will need a preacher bench and an E-Z bar. Grab the E-Z curl bar at the close inner handle (either have someone hand you the bar which is preferable or grab the bar from the front bar rest provided by most preacher benches). The palm of your hands should be facing forward and they should be slightly tilted inwards due to the shape of the bar.
With the upper arms positioned against the preacher bench pad and the chest against it, hold the E-Z Curl Bar at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the bar until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder height. Squeeze the biceps hard and hold this position for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the preacher bench with your upper arms resting flat on the pad and chest against it, grab an EZ-bar with palms facing up
Start with the bar at shoulder height with your biceps fully contracted
Slowly lower the bar down until your arms are fully extended and you feel a deep stretch in your biceps
Curl the bar back up by contracting your biceps, squeezing hard at the top when the bar reaches shoulder height
Pause for a second at the top, then repeat for your set
form_cues: Think 'biceps to forearms' - curl the bar toward your face with maximum contraction
Keep your upper arms glued to the pad like they're cemented down - zero movement at the shoulders
Squeeze at the top like you're trying to make your biceps pop out of your skin
common_mistakes: Lifting your upper arms off the pad to cheat the weight up
Using momentum by rocking your torso instead of strict bicep isolation
Not lowering all the way down, missing the full stretch at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Control the eccentric (lowering) phase - don't let the weight drop quickly, which can strain the bicep tendon
If you feel sharp pain in the elbow or bicep insertion point, reduce weight immediately

instructions: Place the upper part of both arms on top of the preacher bench as you hold a dumbbell in each hand with the palms facing each other (neutral grip).
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Rest both upper arms on the preacher bench pad, hold a dumbbell in each hand with palms facing each other (neutral grip)
Start with arms fully extended at the bottom, feeling a stretch in your biceps and forearms
Curl both dumbbells up toward your shoulders, keeping your palms facing each other throughout
Squeeze hard at the top when the dumbbells reach shoulder height - hold for one second
Lower the dumbbells back down with control to the fully stretched position and repeat
form_cues: Think 'hammers up' - maintain that neutral grip throughout like you're holding two hammers
Upper arms stay welded to the pad - imagine someone pressing them down
Squeeze at the top like you're crushing the dumbbell handles
common_mistakes: Rotating wrists during the curl instead of maintaining the neutral hammer grip
Peeling upper arms off the preacher pad to generate momentum
Stopping short at the top or bottom instead of using full range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Control the descent - don't let gravity drop the weights, which can stress the bicep tendons
This variation is often easier on the wrists than supinated curls, but stop if you feel any joint pain

instructions: To begin, lie down on a bench with a barbell resting on your chest. Position your legs so they are secure on the extension of the abdominal bench. This is the starting position.

While inhaling, tighten your abdominals and glutes. Simultaneously curl your torso as you do when performing a sit-up and press the barbell to an overhead position while exhaling. Tip: Use your arms to push the barbell out as you perform this exercise while still focusing on the abdominal muscles.
Lower your upper body back down to the starting position while bringing the barbell back down to your torso. Remember to breathe in while lowering the body.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Press Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on a decline bench with your feet secured, hold a barbell resting on your chest with hands at shoulder width
Simultaneously sit up while pressing the barbell overhead - coordinate both movements together
Tighten your abs and glutes hard throughout the entire movement to protect your lower back
At the top, you should be sitting upright with the barbell locked out overhead
Lower back down by bringing the bar to your chest as you descend to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'sit and press together' - one fluid motion, not two separate movements
Brace your core like someone's about to punch your stomach before initiating the sit-up
Drive the bar up as you curl your torso - the pressing helps pull you up
common_mistakes: Pressing the bar first then sitting up, or vice versa, instead of coordinating them simultaneously
Arching the lower back excessively instead of keeping abs and glutes engaged
Using too much weight, which compromises form and puts stress on the spine
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight to learn the coordination pattern - this is advanced movement
Keep your lower back supported by maintaining constant core tension throughout

instructions: You will need a partner for this exercise. Lay face down with your legs straight. Your assistant will place their hand on your heel.

To begin, flex the knee to curl your leg up. Your partner should provide resistance, starting light and increasing the pressure as the movement is completed. Communicate with your partner to monitor appropriate resistance levels.
Pause at the top, returning the leg to the starting position as your partner provides resistance going the other direction.
exercises.name: Prone Manual Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on the floor with legs straight, have your partner place their hand firmly on your heel
Curl your heel toward your glutes by bending your knee while your partner provides light resistance
Your partner should gradually increase resistance as you approach the fully curled position - communicate throughout
Pause at the top with your heel close to your glutes, then slowly extend your leg back down as your partner resists the lowering
Complete your reps, then switch legs if training one side at a time
form_cues: Think 'heel to glutes' - curl your heel as close as possible to your butt
Keep your hips pressed flat to the floor - don't let them lift up
Fight against your partner's resistance both directions - curl up AND lower down with control
common_mistakes: Lifting hips off the floor instead of isolating the hamstring curl
Partner providing too much resistance at the start instead of building gradually
Rushing through the eccentric (lowering) phase instead of controlling it against resistance
injury_prevention_tips: Partner should start with light pressure and increase gradually - constant communication is key
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or cramping in the hamstring

instructions: Begin standing a few feet in front of a low pulley with a rope or handle attached. Face away from the machine, straddling the cable, with your feet set wide apart.

Begin the movement by reaching through your legs as far as possible, bending at the hips. Keep your knees slightly bent. Keeping your arms straight, extend through the hip to stand straight up. Avoid pulling upward through the shoulders; all of the motion should originate through the hips.
exercises.name: Pull Through
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing away from a low cable pulley with the rope attachment between your legs, feet set wide apart
Reach back through your legs to grab the rope, then hinge at your hips sending your butt back as far as possible
Keep a slight bend in your knees and your back flat or slightly arched - this is the starting position
Drive your hips forward explosively by squeezing your glutes hard, standing up to full extension
The rope should travel through your legs as your hips extend - don't pull with your arms, drive with your hips
form_cues: Think 'hips back, hips forward' - this is all about the hip hinge, not a squat
Squeeze your glutes at the top like you're trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Keep your arms straight as railroad tracks - they're just holding the rope, your hips do all the work
common_mistakes: Squatting down instead of hinging at the hips and sending the butt back
Pulling with the arms and shoulders instead of driving through the hips
Not fully extending the hips at the top, missing the glute contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back flat or slightly arched throughout - never round your lower back
Start with light weight to master the hip hinge pattern before loading heavy

instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Pullups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab the pullup bar with palms facing away, hands at your chosen grip width (wide, medium, or close)
Hang with arms fully extended, then lean back slightly creating a small arch in your lower back with chest up
Pull yourself up by driving your elbows down and back toward your sides until the bar touches your upper chest
Squeeze your back muscles hard at the top for one second - think about pinching your shoulder blades together
Lower yourself down with control until your arms are fully extended and repeat
form_cues: Think 'elbows to back pockets' - drive your elbows down and behind you, not just bend your arms
Lead with your chest to the bar, not your chin - imagine trying to touch the bar with your sternum
Squeeze your lats at the top like you're crushing oranges in your armpits
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms only instead of initiating the movement with your back muscles
Craning your neck to get your chin over the bar instead of pulling your chest to the bar
Using momentum by kipping or swinging instead of strict, controlled reps
injury_prevention_tips: Don't drop straight down with locked elbows at the bottom - control the descent to protect your shoulders
If you can't do full pullups yet, use a resistance band or assisted pullup machine to build strength

instructions: With your hands wide apart, support your body on your toes and hands in a plank position. Your elbows should be extended and your body straight. Do not allow your hips to sag. This will be your starting position.
To begin, allow the elbows to flex, lowering your chest to the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position by extending the elbows. Exhale as you perform this step.
After pausing at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Push-Up Wide
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into plank position with hands placed wider than shoulder-width apart
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels - squeeze your glutes and brace your core
Lower your chest toward the floor by bending your elbows out to the sides
Go down until your chest is about an inch from the floor, then press back up until arms are fully extended
Pause briefly at the top and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to spread the floor apart with your hands to activate your chest more
Keep your body rigid like a plank of wood - don't let your hips sag or pike up
Think about pushing the floor away from you, not just lifting your body up
Squeeze your chest at the top like you're giving the floor a big hug
common_mistakes: Letting your hips drop toward the floor which strains the lower back
Not going deep enough - your chest should nearly touch the ground
Flaring elbows out too wide past 45 degrees which can stress the shoulders
injury_prevention_tips: Keep elbows at roughly 45 degrees from your body, not straight out to 90 degrees
If you feel shoulder pain, bring your hands slightly closer together

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands closer than shoulder width for a close hand position. Make sure that you are holding your torso up at arms' length.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your triceps and some of your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Push-Ups - Close Triceps Position
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into plank position with hands placed closer than shoulder-width apart, almost touching
Keep your elbows tucked close to your sides throughout the entire movement
Lower your chest toward the floor by bending your elbows straight back
Go down until your chest nearly touches the floor, then press back up explosively
Squeeze your triceps at the top and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to push your elbows into your back pockets - keep them glued to your sides
Think about 'breaking the bar' by trying to turn your hands outward to create tension
Your hands should form a diamond or triangle shape on the floor
Press through your palms like you're trying to leave handprints in the ground
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to the sides which shifts work from triceps to chest
Not keeping hands close enough together - they should be nearly touching
Leading with your head instead of keeping your body in a straight line
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists stacked under elbows to prevent wrist strain
If this is too difficult, start from your knees until you build strength

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart from each other holding your torso up at arms length.
Place your toes on top of a flat bench. This will allow your body to be elevated. Note: The higher the elevation of the flat bench, the higher the resistance of the exercise is.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Push-Ups With Feet Elevated
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place your feet up on a bench, box, or sturdy elevated surface
Get into plank position with hands shoulder-width apart on the floor
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels with core engaged
Lower your chest toward the floor by bending your elbows, going deeper than a regular push-up
Press back up powerfully until arms are fully extended and repeat
form_cues: The higher your feet, the more weight shifts to your upper chest and shoulders - start low
Imagine you're doing a decline bench press but with your bodyweight
Drive through the floor like you're trying to push the ground through the basement
Keep your neck neutral - look at a spot on the floor about a foot in front of your hands
common_mistakes: Starting with feet too high before building adequate strength
Letting your head drop down or crane up instead of maintaining neutral spine
Not going deep enough - the elevation allows for greater range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Progress gradually - start with 6-12 inch elevation before going higher
Keep core braced extra tight to prevent lower back arching under the increased load

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart from each other holding your torso up at arms length.
Place your toes on top of an exercise ball. This will allow your body to be elevated.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Push-Ups With Feet On An Exercise Ball
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into plank position with your hands on the floor, shoulder-width apart
Place your feet on top of an exercise ball with your weight on your toes or shins
Engage your core intensely to stabilize your body on the unstable ball
Lower your chest toward the floor with control, fighting to keep the ball still
Press back up powerfully while maintaining balance and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're balancing a tray of glasses on your back - stay perfectly stable
Squeeze your glutes like you're trying to crack a walnut to keep your hips from sagging
Think about creating a straight line that's frozen in cement - no wobbling
Engage your core like you're bracing for a gut punch throughout the entire movement
common_mistakes: Letting the ball roll around wildly instead of controlling it with core engagement
Going too fast which causes instability - move slowly and deliberately
Letting hips sag or pike up as you fatigue and lose core tension
injury_prevention_tips: Start with the ball against a wall if needed for stability practice
Keep movements slow and controlled - this is a stability exercise as much as strength

instructions: Get into pushup position on the toes with your hands just outside of shoulder width.
Perform a pushup by allowing the elbows to flex. As you descend, keep your body straight.
Do one pushup and as you come up, shift your weight on the left side of the body, twist to the side while bringing the right arm up towards the ceiling in a side plank.
Lower the arm back to the floor for another pushup and then twist to the other side.
Repeat the series, alternating each side, for 10 or more reps.
exercises.name: Push Up to Side Plank
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in standard push-up position with hands just outside shoulder-width
Perform one complete push-up with good form
As you press up, shift your weight onto your left hand and rotate your body into a side plank
Stack your right foot on top of your left and raise your right arm straight up toward the ceiling
Hold briefly, then rotate back down and perform another push-up before switching to the other side
form_cues: Think about 'opening up like a book' as you rotate into the side plank
Keep your body in a straight line even during the rotation - no sagging or piking
Your top arm should point directly at the ceiling - imagine a straight line from hand to hand
Squeeze your obliques as you rotate to engage your core fully
common_mistakes: Rushing the rotation and losing balance instead of moving with control
Letting hips drop toward the floor during the side plank portion
Not fully extending the top arm - it should reach straight up, not angle forward
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular push-ups and side planks separately before combining them
Keep your supporting wrist stacked under your shoulder to avoid strain

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart while holding your torso up at arms length.
Next, lower yourself downward until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Now breathe out and press your upper body back up to the starting position while squeezing your chest.
After a brief pause at the top contracted position, you can begin to lower yourself downward again for as many repetitions as needed.
exercises.name: Pushups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in plank position with hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart
Keep your body in a perfectly straight line from head to heels, core engaged
Lower yourself by bending your elbows, bringing your chest toward the floor
Go down until your chest is about an inch from the ground
Press through your palms to push back up to starting position and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're a straight wooden plank - no sagging at the hips or piking at the butt
Think about screwing your hands into the floor to create torque and shoulder stability
Lead with your chest, not your head - your nose and chest should reach the floor together
At the top, push the floor away so hard your shoulder blades spread slightly apart
common_mistakes: Letting your lower back sag toward the floor which strains the spine
Only going halfway down instead of achieving full range of motion
Leading with your head so it touches the floor before your chest
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral by looking at a spot on the floor about a foot in front of you
If you can't maintain good form, drop to your knees or use an elevated surface

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and body straight with your toes on the floor and the hands wider than shoulder width for a wide hand position and closer than shoulder width for a close hand position. Make sure you are holding your torso up at arms length.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Pushups (Close and Wide Hand Positions)
beginner_friendly_instructions: For wide grip: Place hands significantly wider than shoulder-width (chest emphasis)
For close grip: Place hands closer than shoulder-width, nearly touching (tricep emphasis)
Keep your body in a straight line with core braced and glutes squeezed
Lower your chest to the floor by bending your elbows
Press back up explosively and squeeze your chest or triceps at the top depending on grip
form_cues: Wide grip: Think about pulling the floor apart to activate more chest muscle
Close grip: Imagine pushing your elbows into your ribs to keep them tucked
Both grips: Your body should stay as rigid as steel throughout the movement
Visualize pushing the ground away from you with maximum force
