common_mistakes: Wide grip: Letting elbows flare out past 45 degrees which stresses shoulders
Close grip: Allowing elbows to wing out instead of staying tucked to sides
Changing hand position mid-set instead of committing to one grip variation
injury_prevention_tips: Wide grip can stress shoulders more - if you feel pain, bring hands slightly closer
Close grip requires strong triceps - start with fewer reps or knee push-ups if needed

instructions: Start off by rolling your torso forward onto the ball so your hips rest on top of the ball and become the highest point of your body.

Rest your hands and feet on the floor. Your arms and legs can be slightly bent or straight, depending on the size of the ball, your flexibility, and the length of your limbs. This also helps develop stabilizing strength in your torso and shoulders.
exercises.name: Pyramid
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place an exercise ball on the floor and position yourself so your hips rest on top of the ball
Extend your arms forward and place your hands flat on the floor
Extend your legs back and place your feet flat on the floor behind you
Your body should form an inverted 'V' shape with your hips at the highest point
Hold this position, focusing on keeping your torso and shoulders stable
form_cues: Imagine you're creating a tent with your body - hips are the peak
Think about actively pushing the ball down with your hips to engage your lower back and glutes
Spread your fingers wide on the floor like starfish to create a stable base
Breathe deeply and feel the stretch through your shoulders and lower back
common_mistakes: Letting the ball roll around instead of staying stable and centered
Collapsing your shoulders instead of actively supporting your upper body
Holding your breath - this is a stabilization exercise, keep breathing naturally
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a larger ball for more stability before progressing to smaller sizes
Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back from overextending

instructions: Lay on your side. Loop a belt, rope, or band around your top foot. Flex the knee and extend your hip, attempting to touch your glutes with your foot, and holding the belt with your hands. This will be your starting position.
With the belt being held over the shoulder or overhead, gently pull to increase the stretch in the quadriceps. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side on the floor or exercise mat
Loop a belt, strap, or resistance band around your top foot
Bend your top knee and pull your heel toward your glutes using the strap
Hold the strap overhead or over your shoulder to create tension
Gently pull to increase the stretch in your quadriceps and hold for 15-20 seconds
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to touch your heel to your butt cheek
Think about pushing your hip forward slightly to deepen the stretch through your quad and hip flexor
Keep your knees close together - don't let the top knee drift forward
Pull with steady, gentle tension - no bouncing or jerking
common_mistakes: Letting the top knee drift forward instead of keeping knees stacked
Pulling too aggressively which can cause cramping in the quad
Arching your lower back excessively - keep your core slightly engaged
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up before stretching - never stretch a cold muscle
If you feel sharp pain in your knee, reduce the intensity of the stretch

instructions: Lay facedown on the floor with your weight supported by your hands or forearms. Place a foam roll underneath one leg on the quadriceps, and keep the foot off of the ground. Make sure to relax the leg as much as possible. This will be your starting position.
Shifting as much weight onto the leg to be stretched as is tolerable, roll over the foam from above the knee to below the hip, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Quadriceps-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on the floor with a foam roller placed under one thigh
Support your upper body on your forearms in a plank-like position
Keep the other leg off to the side for balance and to reduce pressure
Roll slowly from just above your knee to just below your hip, pausing on tight spots
Hold any tender points for 20-30 seconds while breathing deeply, then switch legs
form_cues: Think about melting your quad muscle into the roller - relax the leg as much as possible
When you hit a tender spot, take 3-4 deep breaths before moving on
Roll in sections: lower quad near knee, mid-thigh, upper quad near hip
Shift slightly side to side to hit the outer and inner quad muscles
common_mistakes: Rolling too fast without pausing on tight spots - this isn't cardio
Keeping the quad muscle tensed instead of relaxing it into the roller
Rolling directly over the kneecap or hip bone - stay on the meaty muscle tissue
injury_prevention_tips: Never roll directly on joints, bony areas, or the IT band where it crosses the knee
If you feel sharp pain, tingling, or numbness, ease off immediately

instructions: Set up in a power rack with the bar on the pins. The pins should be set to the desired point; just below the knees, just above, or in the mid thigh position. Attach bands to the base of the rack, or secure them with dumbbells. Attach the other end to the bar. You may need to choke the bands to provide tension.

Position yourself against the bar in proper deadlifting position. Your feet should be under your hips, your grip shoulder width, back arched, and hips back to engage the hamstrings. Since the weight is typically heavy, you may use a mixed grip, a hook grip, or use straps to aid in holding the weight.

With your head looking forward, extend through the hips and knees, pulling the weight up and back until lockout. Be sure to pull your shoulders back as you complete the movement. Return the weight to the pins and repeat.
exercises.name: Rack Pull with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell on rack pins at your desired height (below knees, above knees, or mid-thigh), attach resistance bands from the rack base to the bar
Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the bar shoulder-width with your back arched and hips back to engage hamstrings
Look forward with chest up, then drive through your heels extending your hips and knees to pull the bar up and back
At lockout, pull your shoulders back hard and squeeze your shoulder blades together
Lower the bar back to the pins with control and repeat
form_cues: Think 'push the floor away' with your feet rather than pulling the bar up
Drive your hips forward at lockout like you're humping the bar - squeeze glutes hard
The bands add more resistance at the top, so finish strong by retracting your shoulders
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back instead of maintaining a flat or slightly arched position
Not fully locking out at the top and missing the shoulder retraction
Letting the bar drift forward instead of keeping it close to your body
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back neutral or slightly arched throughout - never round under load
Use a mixed grip, hook grip, or straps if needed to prevent grip failure with heavy weight

instructions: Set up in a power rack with the bar on the pins. The pins should be set to the desired point; just below the knees, just above, or in the mid thigh position. Position yourself against the bar in proper deadlifting position. Your feet should be under your hips, your grip shoulder width, back arched, and hips back to engage the hamstrings. Since the weight is typically heavy, you may use a mixed grip, a hook grip, or use straps to aid in holding the weight.
With your head looking forward, extend through the hips and knees, pulling the weight up and back until lockout. Be sure to pull your shoulders back as you complete the movement.
Return the weight to the pins and repeat.
exercises.name: Rack Pulls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the barbell on rack pins at your chosen height (below knees, above knees, or mid-thigh position)
Stand with feet under your hips, grip the bar shoulder-width, arch your back and push your hips back to load the hamstrings
With your head facing forward and chest up, extend through your hips and knees simultaneously to pull the weight up and back to lockout
At the top, forcefully pull your shoulders back and squeeze your shoulder blades together
Return the bar to the pins under control and repeat for reps
form_cues: Think 'leg press the ground' rather than pulling with your back
At lockout, imagine squeezing a pencil between your shoulder blades
Keep the bar path straight up - imagine sliding it along your legs
common_mistakes: Starting with hips too high, which reduces hamstring engagement and makes it a back-dominant pull
Not fully extending the hips at the top, missing the glute and trap contraction
Jerking the weight off the pins instead of creating tension before initiating the pull
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain a neutral or slightly arched spine - rounding the lower back under load is dangerous
Take the slack out of the bar before pulling - create tension smoothly rather than yanking

instructions: Place yourself on your hands knees on an exercise mat. Your head should be looking forward and the bend of the knees should create a 90-degree angle between the hamstrings and the calves. This will be your starting position.
Extend one leg up and behind you. The knee and hip should both extend. Repeat for 5-10 repetitions, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Rear Leg Raises
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on your hands and knees on an exercise mat with your back flat and head looking forward
Position your knees to create a 90-degree angle between your thighs and calves
Extend one leg straight back and up, straightening both the knee and the hip
Raise the leg as high as comfortably possible while keeping your back flat
Lower back to starting position and complete 5-10 reps before switching to the other leg
form_cues: Think 'reach your heel to the ceiling' as you extend the leg back and up
Keep your core tight like a plank - don't let your lower back sag or arch excessively
Squeeze your glute at the top of the movement like you're trying to flex it hard
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively instead of maintaining a neutral spine
Twisting the hips or rotating the torso instead of keeping them square to the floor
Moving too quickly with momentum instead of controlled, deliberate movements
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to protect your lower back from hyperextension
Don't force the range of motion - stop when you feel your back starting to arch

instructions: Position a bench inside a power rack, with the bar set to the correct height. Begin by anchoring bands either to band pegs or to the top of the rack. Ensure that you will be position properly under the bands. Attach the other end to the barbell.

Lie on the bench, tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement. However wide your grip, it should cover the ring on the bar.

Pull the bar out of the rack without protracting your shoulders. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart. Lower the bar to your lower chest or upper stomach. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times.
Pause when the barbell touches your torso, and then drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.
exercises.name: Reverse Band Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a bench in a power rack and attach bands from the top of the rack to the barbell (bands assist at the bottom, less at the top)
Lie on the bench with feet tucked under you, arch your back and retract your shoulder blades hard
Unrack the bar with a grip covering the rings, keeping shoulders retracted - lower the bar to your lower chest or upper stomach
Pause when the bar touches your torso, then explosively drive the bar up with maximum force
Lock out at the top with elbows tucked in throughout the movement
form_cues: Think 'bend the bar' in your hands like you're trying to break it in half
Drive your feet through the floor and your traps into the bench - create full-body tension
Explode off the chest like you're trying to throw the bar to the ceiling
common_mistakes: Protracting (rounding forward) the shoulders instead of keeping them retracted and pinned
Letting elbows flare out excessively instead of maintaining a tucked position
Bouncing the bar off the chest instead of pausing briefly before pressing
injury_prevention_tips: Keep shoulder blades retracted throughout - losing this position can stress the shoulder joint
The bands reduce weight at the bottom where you're weakest, allowing heavier lockout training

instructions: Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Set up the bands either on band pegs or attached to the top of the rack, ensuring they will be directly above the bar during the squat. Attach the other end to the bar.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe. Use care to return the barbell to the rack.
exercises.name: Reverse Band Box Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a box behind you in a power rack with bands attached from the top of the rack to the barbell on your back
Step under the bar, squeeze your shoulder blades together, and unrack with a tight arch in your lower back
Set your stance width (wider targets glutes/hamstrings, closer targets quads), then descend by pushing knees and butt out
Sit back onto the box keeping your shins perpendicular to the ground, pause and relax hip flexors without bouncing
Drive up explosively by pushing through your heels and spreading the floor with your feet
form_cues: Think 'sit back into a chair' not 'squat down' - send your hips back first
At the box, pause for a second - NO BOUNCING - then explode up like a spring
Lead with your head on the way up - where your head goes, your body follows
common_mistakes: Bouncing off the box instead of pausing and controlling the movement
Letting knees cave inward instead of actively pushing them out in line with toes
Losing the arch in your lower back at the bottom position
injury_prevention_tips: Never bounce off the box - this defeats the purpose and can injure your spine
The bands reduce load at the bottom where you're weakest, making it safer to train heavy

instructions: Set the bar up in a power rack. Attach bands to the top of the rack, using either bands pegs or the frame itself. Attach the other end of the bands to the bar.

Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward.
After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.
exercises.name: Reverse Band Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up the barbell on the floor in a rack with bands attached from the top of the rack to the bar
Position the bar over mid-foot with feet hip-width, bend at the hips to grip the bar shoulder-width apart
Lower your hips, contact the bar with your shins, arch your back, look forward, and take a big breath
Drive through your heels to pull the bar up, and once past your knees, aggressively pull the bar back while driving hips forward
Lower the bar by hinging at the hips and guiding it back to the floor with control
form_cues: Think 'leg press the earth away' rather than lifting with your back
Once past knees, think 'hips to the bar' and squeeze your glutes like you're cracking a walnut
Pull your shoulders back at the top like you're pinching a pencil between your shoulder blades
common_mistakes: Rounding the back at any point instead of maintaining a neutral or arched spine
Letting the bar drift forward instead of keeping it close to your body throughout
Not fully extending the hips at lockout, missing the glute and upper back contraction
injury_prevention_tips: The bands reduce weight at the bottom where you're in the weakest position, allowing safer heavy training
Keep your chest up and back arched throughout - rounding under load causes injury

instructions: Begin in a power rack with the pins and bar set at the appropriate height. After loading the bar, attach bands to the top of the rack, using either pegs or the frame itself. Attach the other end of the bands to the bar.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wide for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings.

Keep your head facing forward. With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips as much as possible. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Lower bar position necessitates a greater torso lean to keep the bar over the heels. Continue until you break parallel, which is defined as the crease of the hip being in line with the top of the knee.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe, until you have returned to the starting position.
exercises.name: Reverse Band Power Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up in a power rack with bands attached from the top to the loaded barbell, step under and position the bar across your upper back
Squeeze shoulder blades together, create a tight lower back arch, unrack and step back to your stance width
With chest up and core tight, push your knees and butt out as you descend, sitting back with your hips
Continue down until the crease of your hip is below the top of your knee (breaking parallel), keeping shins vertical
Drive up through your heels, pushing knees out, leading with your head until you return to standing
form_cues: Think 'spread the floor apart' with your feet as you descend and ascend
Sit back like you're reaching for a chair behind you - hips lead the descent
Drive up aggressively thinking 'head through the ceiling' to lead the ascent
common_mistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward instead of actively pushing them out in line with toes
Not descending deep enough - you must break parallel for a full squat
Losing tightness in the core or upper back, causing forward lean or rounding
injury_prevention_tips: Bands reduce load at the bottom where you're most vulnerable, allowing heavier training with less injury risk
Maintain that lower back arch throughout - never round your spine under load

instructions: Begin with a bar loaded on the floor inside of a power rack. Attach bands to the top of the rack, using either pegs or the frame itself. Attach the other end to the barbell.

Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip. Relax the shoulders, which in effect lengthens your arms.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.
exercises.name: Reverse Band Sumo Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a loaded barbell on the floor in a power rack with bands attached from the top to the bar
Position your feet very wide (near the collars) with the bar over mid-foot, bend at the hips and grip the bar inside your legs
Lower your hips, take a breath, look forward with chest up, then drive through the back half of your feet spreading them apart
As the bar passes your knees, lean back and drive your hips into the bar while pulling your shoulder blades together
Lower the weight by bending at the hips and controlling it back to the floor
form_cues: Think 'push the floor apart' with your feet as you pull - spread the ground with your heels
Once past knees, think 'hips to bar' - drive forward and squeeze glutes hard
Keep the bar close - imagine dragging it up your legs the entire way
common_mistakes: Starting with hips too high, which turns it into a conventional deadlift instead of sumo
Not spreading the floor with your feet, missing the key sumo mechanics
Letting the bar drift forward instead of maintaining contact with your legs
injury_prevention_tips: Bands reduce the weight at the bottom where sumo is hardest, making it safer for heavy loads
Keep your back neutral or slightly arched - never round your spine during the lift

instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a barbell at shoulder width with the elbows close to the torso. The palm of your hands should be facing down (pronated grip). This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding a barbell at shoulder-width with palms facing down (overhand grip), elbows close to your sides
Keep your upper arms completely stationary and curl the barbell up by contracting your biceps and forearms
Continue curling until the bar reaches shoulder height and your biceps are fully contracted
Squeeze hard at the top for one second, then slowly lower the bar back to the starting position
Repeat for your desired reps, maintaining strict form throughout
form_cues: Think 'knuckles to ceiling' - that overhand grip makes this a forearm-intensive movement
Keep your elbows pinned to your sides like they're glued there - zero swinging
Squeeze at the top like you're flexing your biceps and forearms as hard as possible
common_mistakes: Swinging the body or using momentum instead of strict curling motion
Letting elbows drift forward instead of keeping them locked at your sides
Going too heavy and compromising form - this hits forearms hard, use less weight than regular curls
injury_prevention_tips: Use significantly less weight than regular barbell curls - the pronated grip is much harder
If you feel wrist or elbow pain, reduce weight or switch to an EZ-bar for a more comfortable angle

instructions: Grab an EZ-bar using a shoulder width and palms down (pronated) grip.
Now place the upper part of both arms on top of the preacher bench and have your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps are fully contracted and the barbell is at shoulder height. Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the barbell until your upper arms are extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Barbell Preacher Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab an EZ-bar with an overhand grip (palms facing down) at shoulder-width
Place your upper arms on top of the preacher bench pad with arms fully extended - this is your starting position
Curl the bar up by contracting your biceps and forearms until the bar reaches shoulder height
Squeeze hard for one second at the top with biceps fully contracted
Slowly lower the bar back down until your arms are fully extended and biceps are stretched, then repeat
form_cues: Think 'forearms and biceps working together' - this hits both hard with that overhand grip
Upper arms stay cemented to the pad - imagine they're bolted down
Control the descent - don't let gravity drop the weight, which can strain tendons
common_mistakes: Lifting upper arms off the preacher pad to help move the weight
Using too much weight and relying on momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction
Not fully extending at the bottom, cutting the range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than regular preacher curls - the pronated grip significantly increases difficulty
Control the eccentric phase carefully - don't let the weight drop fast, which can stress the elbow and bicep tendons

instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a bar attachment that is attached to a low pulley using a pronated (palms down) and shoulder width grip. Make sure also that you keep the elbows close to the torso. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight or EZ bar to a low pulley cable machine
Stand facing the machine and grab the bar with an overhand grip (palms down), hands shoulder-width apart
Keep your elbows pinned to your sides and stand upright with feet shoulder-width apart
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders by bending only at the elbows, keeping upper arms still
Squeeze at the top for a second, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are glued to your ribs - they shouldn't move forward or back
Think about pulling your knuckles toward your shoulders, not your palms
Keep your wrists straight and neutral - don't let them curl back or flex forward
Squeeze your forearms at the top like you're crushing a tennis ball in each hand
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows drift forward as you curl, which reduces bicep and forearm engagement
Using momentum or swinging your body to lift the weight
Bending your wrists back which takes tension off the forearms
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral throughout - excessive wrist extension can cause strain
Start with lighter weight than regular curls since reverse grip is harder on forearms

instructions: Lie down on the floor with your legs fully extended and arms to the side of your torso with the palms on the floor. Your arms should be stationary for the entire exercise.
Move your legs up so that your thighs are perpendicular to the floor and feet are together and parallel to the floor. This is the starting position.
While inhaling, move your legs towards the torso as you roll your pelvis backwards and you raise your hips off the floor. At the end of this movement your knees will be touching your chest.
Hold the contraction for a second and move your legs back to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with arms at your sides, palms pressed into the floor for stability
Lift your legs so your thighs are perpendicular to the floor (90-degree angle at hips), with knees slightly bent
Using your lower abs, roll your pelvis backward and lift your hips off the floor, bringing your knees toward your chest
Squeeze your abs at the top for one second, then slowly lower your hips back down
Keep your upper back and head on the floor throughout the movement
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to touch your knees to your nose by curling your pelvis up
Think about scooping your lower abs to lift your hips, not using leg momentum
Press your lower back into the floor as you curl up - eliminate any arch
Move slowly like you're performing in slow motion - control is everything
common_mistakes: Using leg momentum to swing your knees forward instead of curling your pelvis
Letting your lower back arch off the floor during the movement
Going too fast and bouncing instead of controlled, deliberate movement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep movements slow and controlled - never use momentum or bounce
If you feel strain in your neck, you're pulling with your upper body - focus on lower abs only

instructions: To begin, lie down on an incline bench with the chest and stomach pressing against the incline. Have the dumbbells in each hand with the palms facing each other (neutral grip).

Extend the arms in front of you so that they are perpendicular to the angle of the bench. The legs should be stationary while applying pressure with the ball of your toes. This is the starting position.

Maintaining the slight bend of the elbows, move the weights out and away from each other (to the side) in an arc motion while exhaling. Tip: Try to squeeze your shoulder blades together to get the best results from this exercise.
The arms should be elevated until they are parallel to the floor.
Feel the contraction and slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on an incline bench set at 30-45 degrees, with your chest and stomach against the pad
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging straight down, palms facing each other
Keep a slight bend in your elbows and raise the weights out to the sides in an arc motion
Lift until your arms are parallel to the floor, squeezing your shoulder blades together
Lower the weights back down with control and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to squeeze a pencil between your shoulder blades at the top
Think about leading with your elbows, not your hands, as you lift
Visualize opening your arms like you're spreading wings
Keep the same elbow bend throughout - don't straighten or curl your arms
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and turning it into a rowing motion instead of a fly
Straightening your arms completely which stresses the elbow joints
Lifting the weights too high past parallel, which shifts work away from rear delts
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight - rear delts are small muscles that fatigue quickly
Keep a consistent slight bend in elbows throughout to protect the joints

instructions: To begin, lie down on an incline bench set at a 30-degree angle with the chest and stomach pressing against the incline.

Have the dumbbells in each hand with the palms facing down to the floor. Your arms should be in front of you so that they are perpendicular to the angle of the bench. Tip: Your elbows should have a slight bend. The legs should be stationary while applying pressure with the ball of your toes (your heels should not be touching the floor). This is the starting position.
Maintaining the slight bend of the elbows, move the weights out and away from each other in an arc motion while exhaling.

As you lift the weight, your wrist should externally rotate by 90-degrees so that you go from a palms down (pronated) grip to a palms facing each other (neutral) grip. Tip: Try to squeeze your shoulder blades together to get the best results from this exercise.
The arms should be elevated until they are level with the head.
Feel the contraction and slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Flyes With External Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on an incline bench at 30 degrees with chest against the pad
Hold dumbbells with palms facing down (pronated grip), arms hanging straight down
Raise the weights out to the sides in an arc while simultaneously rotating your wrists
As you lift, rotate your palms from facing down to facing each other (90-degree rotation)
Lift until arms are level with your head, squeeze, then lower with control
form_cues: Think about pouring out two pitchers of water as you lift - that's the rotation
Imagine your thumbs rotating from pointing down to pointing up toward the ceiling
Squeeze your shoulder blades together like you're crushing a grape between them
Lead with your elbows and let your hands follow
common_mistakes: Forgetting to rotate the wrists and just doing a standard reverse fly
Rotating too early or too late instead of smoothly throughout the lift
Using too much weight which prevents proper wrist rotation
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than standard reverse flyes since rotation adds complexity
Keep the movement smooth - jerky rotation can strain the shoulder rotator cuff

instructions: Stand erect while holding a barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing up).

Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The barbell should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the barbell as you breathe out, keeping the elbows close to the body and not doing any force with the forearm other than holding the weights. On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Grip Bent-Over Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing up), hands shoulder-width apart
Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor
Let the bar hang straight down from your shoulders with arms fully extended
Pull the bar up toward your lower chest/upper abs, keeping elbows close to your body
Squeeze your back muscles at the top, then lower with control
form_cues: Imagine pulling the bar into your belly button, not your chest
Think about driving your elbows back toward your back pockets
Keep your back flat like a table - you could balance a cup of water on it
Squeeze your lats and mid-back at the top like you're crushing a soda can between your shoulder blades
common_mistakes: Standing too upright instead of maintaining a proper hip hinge
Using your arms to curl the weight instead of pulling with your back
Letting your elbows flare out wide which reduces lat engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back flat and core braced throughout - never round your spine
Don't jerk the weight up - use smooth, controlled pulling motion

instructions: Start by setting a bar attachment (straight or e-z) on a high pulley machine.

Facing the bar attachment, grab it with the palms facing up (supinated grip) at shoulder width. Lower the bar by using your lats until your arms are fully extended by your sides. Tip: Elbows should be in by your sides and your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.
Slowly elevate the bar attachment up as you inhale so it is aligned with your chest. Only the forearms should move and the elbows/upper arms should be stationary by your side at all times.
Then begin to lower the cable bar back down to the original staring position while exhaling and contracting the triceps hard.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Grip Triceps Pushdown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight or EZ bar to a high pulley cable machine
Grab the bar with an underhand grip (palms facing up), hands shoulder-width apart
Pull the bar down using your lats until your arms are fully extended at your sides, elbows tucked in
Slowly let the bar rise up to chest level by bending only at the elbows
Push the bar back down explosively, squeezing your triceps hard at the bottom
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are bolted to your sides - they never move forward or back
Think about pushing your palms toward the floor with maximum force
Keep your wrists straight - don't let them bend backward or curl forward
Squeeze your triceps at the bottom like you're trying to flex them to maximum hardness
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows drift forward as you raise the bar, which reduces tricep tension
Using your shoulders or back to push the weight down instead of isolating triceps
Bending your wrists which takes tension off the triceps
injury_prevention_tips: Keep elbows stationary and tucked - movement should only occur at the elbow joint
Don't let the weight pull your arms up too fast on the eccentric - control the negative

instructions: Place your feet between the pads after loading an appropriate weight. Lay on the top pad, allowing your hips to hang off the back, while grasping the handles to hold your position.
To begin the movement, flex the hips, pulling the legs forward.
Reverse the motion by extending the hips, kicking the leg back. It is very important not to over-extend the hip on this movement, stopping short of your full range of motion.
Return by again flexing the hip, pulling the carriage forward as far as you can.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Hyperextension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load the machine and position your feet between the pads
Lie face-down on the pad with your hips hanging off the back edge, holding the handles
Start by flexing at the hips to bring your legs forward and down
Squeeze your glutes and hamstrings to extend your hips, kicking your legs backward
Stop just before full hip extension (don't overextend), then control the weight back to the start
form_cues: Think about squeezing your glutes to lift your legs, not arching your back
Imagine you're kicking through an invisible wall behind you
Stop the movement before you feel your lower back arch - glutes should do the work
Control the weight on the way down like you're resisting a strong resistance band
common_mistakes: Hyperextending the hips and arching the lower back excessively at the top
Using momentum to swing the legs up instead of controlled muscle contraction
Not going through full range by pulling legs forward enough at the start
injury_prevention_tips: Never overextend the hips past neutral - stop short of your full range to protect your back
Keep core engaged throughout to stabilize your spine

instructions: Adjust the handles so that they are fully to the rear. Make an appropriate weight selection and adjust the seat height so the handles are at shoulder level. Grasp the handles with your hands facing inwards. This will be your starting position.
In a semicircular motion, pull your hands out to your side and back, contracting your rear delts.
Keep your arms slightly bent throughout the movement, with all of the motion occurring at the shoulder joint.
Pause at the rear of the movement, and slowly return the weight to the starting position.
exercises.name: Reverse Machine Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the machine handles to the fully rear position and set the seat height so handles are at shoulder level
Sit facing the machine with your chest against the pad, grasping the handles with palms facing inward
With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles out to your sides and back in a semicircular arc
Squeeze your rear delts and upper back when the handles are fully back
Slowly return to the starting position with control and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to touch your elbows together behind your back
Think about pulling with your elbows, not your hands - elbows lead the movement
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the back like you're crushing a walnut between them
Keep your chest pressed firmly against the pad throughout the entire movement
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and turning it into a rowing motion with bent arms
Letting your torso come off the chest pad to use momentum
Straightening your arms completely which can stress the elbow joints
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain the same slight elbow bend throughout - don't lock out or bend more
Keep your chest pressed to the pad to isolate rear delts and prevent lower back involvement

instructions: Start by standing straight with a weighted plate held by both hands and arms fully extended. Use a pronated grip (palms facing down) and make sure your fingers grab the rough side of the plate while your thumb grabs the smooth side. Note: For the best results, grab the weighted plate at an 11:00 and 1:00 o'clock position.
Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other and the weighted plate should be near the groin area. This is the starting position.

Slowly lift the plate up while keeping the elbows in and the upper arms stationary until your biceps and forearms touch while exhaling. The plate should be evenly aligned with your torso at this point.
Feel the contraction for a second and begin to lower the weight back down to the starting position while inhaling
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Reverse Plate Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding a weight plate with both hands using an overhand grip (palms facing down)
Grab the rough side of the plate at the 11 o'clock and 1 o'clock positions with your fingers
Start with arms fully extended and the plate near your groin area
Curl the plate up by bending at the elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary and elbows tucked in
Lift until your forearms and biceps touch, squeeze for a second, then lower with control
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are pinned to an invisible wall - they don't move at all
Think about pulling your knuckles toward your shoulders
Keep the plate level and balanced throughout - don't let it tilt
Squeeze your forearms and biceps at the top like you're showing them off
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows drift forward which reduces muscle tension
Using body momentum or swinging to lift the weight
Letting the plate tilt forward or back instead of keeping it level
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a lighter plate than you think - reverse grip is harder on forearms
Keep wrists neutral - don't let them bend back excessively under the plate weight

instructions: Lie back on a flat bench. Using a close, supinated grip (around shoulder width), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked extended in front of you and perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest. Tip: Make sure that as opposed to a regular bench press, you keep the elbows close to the torso at all times in order to maximize triceps involvement.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your triceps muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Reverse Triceps Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench and grab a barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing up), hands shoulder-width apart
Unrack the bar and hold it straight above your chest with arms fully extended
Keep your elbows tucked close to your sides throughout the entire movement
Lower the bar slowly to the middle of your chest, feeling the stretch in your triceps
Press the bar back up explosively using your triceps, locking out at the top
form_cues: Imagine your elbows are trying to touch your ribs - keep them glued to your sides
Think about pushing the bar up toward the ceiling, not back toward your face
Press through your palms like you're trying to push through the ceiling
Take twice as long to lower the bar as you do to press it up
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out wide which turns it into a chest press instead of tricep focus
Lowering the bar too high on the chest instead of mid-chest
Using too much weight and losing the tucked elbow position
injury_prevention_tips: Keep elbows tucked tight to maximize tricep work and minimize shoulder stress
Use a spotter when learning this movement due to the awkward underhand grip

instructions: Lay down with your back on the floor. Place a foam roll underneath your upper back, and cross your arms in front of you, protracting your shoulders. This will be your starting position.

Raise your hips off of the ground, placing your weight onto the foam roll. Shift your weight to one side at a time, rolling over your middle and upper back. Pause at points of tension for 10-30 seconds.
exercises.name: Rhomboids-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with a foam roller positioned under your upper back, cross your arms over your chest to protract your shoulders
Lift your hips off the ground so your weight rests on the foam roller and your feet
Shift your weight to one side, rolling the foam roller across your middle and upper back
When you find a tight or tender spot, pause and hold pressure on that point for 10-30 seconds
Switch sides and repeat, covering your entire upper back area
form_cues: Think 'hug yourself tight' when crossing your arms - this spreads your shoulder blades apart to expose the rhomboids
Roll slowly like you're searching for buried treasure - pause when you find a tender spot
Use your feet to control the pressure - push down more for lighter pressure, lift hips higher for deeper pressure
common_mistakes: Rolling too quickly without pausing at tight spots to allow the tissue to release
Not crossing arms tightly enough, which prevents proper shoulder blade protraction
Rolling directly on the spine instead of staying to one side at a time
injury_prevention_tips: Never roll directly on your spine - always shift to one side to work the muscles beside it
If a spot is extremely painful, reduce pressure by lowering your hips or using your feet more

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place it on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck).
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance. Also maintain a straight back and keep the knees with a slight bend; never locked. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending (other than the slight initial bend we created during positioning) at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Now lift your toes by contracting the tibia muscles in the front of the calves as you breathe out.
Hold for a second and bring them back down as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Rocking Standing Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell on your upper back in a squat rack, step back to a shoulder-width stance with toes slightly pointed out
Rise up on your toes as high as possible, squeezing your calves hard at the top - hold for one second
Lower your heels back down slowly until you feel a stretch in your calves
Now lift your toes up toward your shins by contracting the muscles on the front of your lower legs - hold for one second
Lower your toes back down and repeat the entire sequence for your reps
form_cues: Think 'tippy-toes, then toes-to-sky' - you're rocking between calf raise and toe raise
At the top of the calf raise, imagine pushing through the ceiling with the balls of your feet
Keep your torso rock-solid and upright throughout - no leaning or swaying
common_mistakes: Bending at the knees during the movement instead of keeping them nearly locked with just a slight bend
Rushing through the movement instead of holding each position for a full second
Leaning forward or backward instead of maintaining an upright torso
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a slight bend in your knees throughout - never lock them completely
Start with light weight to get the coordination pattern down before loading heavy

instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using a wide grip.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.

Now repeat the same movements as described above except this time your torso will remain straight as you go up and the bar will touch the back of the neck instead of the upper chest. Tip: Use the head to lean forward slightly as it will help you properly execute this portion of the exercise.
Once you have lowered yourself back down to the starting position, repeat the exercise for the prescribed amount of repetitions in your program.
exercises.name: Rocky Pull-Ups/Pulldowns
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pullup bar with a wide overhand grip, hang with arms extended and lean back 30 degrees with chest out
Pull yourself up until the bar touches your upper chest, squeezing your back muscles hard - pause for one second
Lower back down to full arm extension with control
Now pull yourself up again, but this time keep your torso more upright and pull until the bar touches the back of your neck
Lower back down and alternate between chest pulls and behind-neck pulls for your reps
form_cues: First rep: think 'chest to bar' - lean back and pull the bar to your sternum
Second rep: think 'neck to bar' - stay more vertical and pull the bar behind your head
Squeeze your lats at the top of each rep like you're crushing oranges in your armpits
common_mistakes: Not alternating properly - you should switch between front and behind-neck on each rep
Using momentum or kipping instead of strict, controlled pulling
Not achieving full range - bar must touch your body at the top, arms must be fully extended at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Behind-neck pullups require good shoulder mobility - if you feel pinching, stick to front pulls only
Control the descent - never drop with locked elbows, which can injure your shoulders

instructions: Put a barbell in front of you on the ground and grab it using a pronated (palms facing down) grip that a little wider than shoulder width. Tip: Depending on the weight used, you may need wrist wraps to perform the exercise and also a raised platform in order to allow for better range of motion.
Bend the knees slightly and keep the shins vertical, hips back and back straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your back and arms completely straight at all times, use your hips to lift the bar as you exhale. Tip: The movement should not be fast but steady and under control.

Once you are standing completely straight up, lower the bar by pushing the hips back, only slightly bending the knees, unlike when squatting. Tip: Take a deep breath at the start of the movement and keep your chest up. Hold your breath as you lower and exhale as you complete the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Romanian Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width, feet hip-width apart
Start from standing position with slight knee bend and shins vertical - this is your starting position
Push your hips back while lowering the bar down your thighs, keeping your back completely straight and the bar close
Lower until you feel a deep stretch in your hamstrings (usually mid-shin height), keeping the bar path vertical
Drive your hips forward to return to standing, squeezing your glutes at the top
form_cues: Think 'push your hips to the wall behind you' - this is a hip hinge, not a squat
Imagine the bar is sliding down your legs on rails - keep it in contact with your body
At the bottom, feel the stretch in your hamstrings like rubber bands being pulled tight
common_mistakes: Squatting down by bending the knees too much instead of hinging at the hips
Rounding the back instead of keeping it completely straight or slightly arched
Letting the bar drift away from the body instead of maintaining contact with your legs
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back neutral or slightly arched at all times - rounding is dangerous under load
Don't lower past the point where you can maintain a flat back - flexibility determines your depth

instructions: Grab the rope with both hands above your head. Pull down on the rope as you take a small jump.
Wrap the rope around one leg, using your feet to pinch the rope. Reach up as high as possible with your arms, gripping the rope tightly.
Release the rope from your feet as you pull yourself up with your arms, bringing your knees towards your chest.
Resecure your feet on the rope, and then stand up to take another high hold on the rope. Continue until you reach the top of the rope.
To lower yourself, loosen the grip of your feet on the rope as you slide down using a hand over hand motion.
exercises.name: Rope Climb
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab the rope with both hands above your head, take a small jump and pull down on the rope
Wrap the rope around one leg and pinch it between your feet to create a foothold
Reach as high as possible on the rope with your arms, gripping tightly
Release your feet and pull yourself up with your arms while bringing your knees toward your chest
Re-pinch the rope with your feet, stand up on that foothold, and reach higher - repeat until you reach the top
form_cues: Think 'climb like a caterpillar' - reach high, pull up with arms, re-secure feet, stand, repeat
Pinch the rope tight with your feet like you're standing on a ledge - this saves your arm strength
When descending, loosen your foot grip slightly to slide down controlled, using hand-over-hand braking
common_mistakes: Not securing the rope properly with feet, forcing arms to do all the work and fatiguing quickly
Reaching too low with hands instead of maximizing height on each reach
Descending too fast without controlling speed with hands and feet
injury_prevention_tips: Build grip strength before attempting long climbs - grip failure at height is dangerous
Descend controlled - never just slide down quickly, which can cause rope burn and loss of control

instructions: Kneel 1-2 feet in front of a cable system with a rope attached.
After selecting an appropriate weight, grasp the rope with both hands reaching overhead. Your torso should be upright in the starting position.
To begin, flex at the spine, attempting to bring your rib cage to your legs as you pull the cable down.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return to the starting position.
These can be done with twists or to the side to hit the obliques.
exercises.name: Rope Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel 1-2 feet in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment, grab the rope with both hands overhead
Start with your torso upright, holding the rope near your head or upper neck
Crunch forward by flexing your spine, trying to bring your rib cage down toward your legs as you pull the rope down
Squeeze your abs hard at the bottom position, pause for one second
Slowly return to the upright starting position with control, resisting the weight on the way up
form_cues: Think 'curl your spine like a shrimp' - round forward bringing ribs to hips
Imagine someone punched you in the stomach - that crunch forward feeling
Keep your hips stationary - the movement happens at your spine, not your hips
common_mistakes: Using hip flexion to pull the weight down instead of spinal flexion (abs)
Moving too fast with momentum instead of slow, controlled crunching
Not returning to full extension at the top, cutting the range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the spinal flexion pattern - don't let the weight pull you forward
Keep your hips planted - if they lift or shift, you're using too much weight

instructions: Attach a rope to a high pulley and make your weight selection. Stand a couple feet back from the pulley with your feet staggered and take the rope with both hands. Lean forward from the hip, keeping your back straight, with your arms extended up in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, extend the shoulder to pull the rope down to your thighs.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, squeezing your lats.
Return to the starting position without allowing the weight to fully rest on the stack.
exercises.name: Rope Straight-Arm Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a high cable pulley, stand a few feet back with feet staggered holding the rope overhead
Lean forward from your hips keeping your back straight, with arms extended up in front of you
Keeping your arms completely straight, pull the rope down in an arc until it reaches your thighs
Pause at the bottom, squeezing your lats hard like you're crushing something in your armpits
Return the rope to the overhead position with control, stopping just before the weight stack touches
form_cues: Think 'arms are stiff boards' - no bending at the elbows throughout the movement
Imagine you're doing a lat pulldown but with straight arms - the arc motion
At the bottom, squeeze your lats like you're trying to hold a tennis ball in your armpit
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows to help pull the weight down instead of keeping arms locked straight
Using too much weight and rocking the body instead of isolating the lats
Not achieving full range - rope should go from overhead to thighs
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you think - this isolation exercise requires strict form
If you feel excessive strain in your shoulders, reduce weight or check your form

instructions: Stand up straight with your legs together, holding a bodybar or broomstick.
Hold the pole behind your hips with a wider than shoulder width grip. Your palms should be down and your thumbs facing out.
Slowly lift your arms up behind your head. Don't force it if it gets hard to lift further.
exercises.name: Round The World Shoulder Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet together holding a broomstick or bodybar behind your hips with a wide overhand grip
Keep your palms facing down and thumbs pointing outward
Slowly lift your arms up and back, raising the bar behind your body toward your head
Go as far as comfortable - don't force the range if it becomes difficult
Hold at your maximum comfortable range for 10-20 seconds, then lower back down
form_cues: Think 'draw a rainbow behind your body' with the bar path
Keep your elbows straight throughout - don't bend them to cheat the range
If it gets tough, that's your limit for now - don't force past that point
common_mistakes: Using too narrow of a grip, which makes the stretch too intense and limits range
Bending the elbows to get the bar higher instead of working within your true flexibility
Arching the lower back excessively to compensate for shoulder tightness
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a very wide grip - you can narrow it gradually as your mobility improves
Never force this stretch - shoulder joint stress can cause injury

instructions: It's easiest to get into this stretch if you start standing up, put one leg behind you, and slowly lower your torso down to the floor.
Keep the front heel on the floor (if it lifts up, scoot your other leg further back).

Place your hands on either side of your front leg. To get more out of this stretch, push your butt up toward the ceiling, and then gradually lower it back toward the floor. You'll Stretch the hip flexor of the back leg and the hamstring and buttocks of the front.
exercises.name: Runner's Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start standing, step one leg far back into a lunge position and slowly lower your torso toward the floor
Place both hands on the ground on either side of your front foot, keep your front heel flat on the floor
Your back leg should be extended behind you with knee off the ground (or resting lightly)
Push your hips up toward the ceiling to intensify the hamstring stretch, then lower them back down toward the floor to stretch the hip flexor
Alternate between hip up and hip down positions to get a dynamic stretch, hold for 20-30 seconds total
form_cues: Think 'hips up stretches hamstring, hips down stretches hip flexor' - you get both in one position
Keep your front heel glued to the floor - if it lifts, scoot your back leg further back
Imagine you're a sprinter in the starting blocks, then push your butt to the sky
common_mistakes: Letting the front heel lift off the ground, which reduces the stretch effectiveness
Rounding the back instead of keeping it relatively straight during the movement
Not moving dynamically between the two positions - static holding only gets one muscle group
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a shorter lunge stance and gradually increase as your flexibility improves
Don't force the stretch - ease into it gradually and breathe through any tension

instructions: Lie down on the floor placing your feet either under something that will not move or by having a partner hold them. Your legs should be bent at the knees.

Elevate your upper body so that it creates an imaginary V-shape with your thighs. Your arms should be fully extended in front of you perpendicular to your torso and with the hands clasped. This is the starting position.
Twist your torso to the right side until your arms are parallel with the floor while breathing out.
Hold the contraction for a second and move back to the starting position while breathing out. Now move to the opposite side performing the same techniques you applied to the right side.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Russian Twist
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet secured under something stable or held by a partner
Lean your torso back to create a V-shape between your thighs and upper body, extend arms straight out with hands clasped
Twist your torso to the right until your arms are parallel to the floor, keeping the V-angle constant
Pause for one second, then rotate back to center
Immediately twist to the left side with the same technique, pause, return to center - that's one rep
form_cues: Think 'rotate from your core, not your arms' - your arms just follow your torso
Maintain the V-shape the entire time - don't sit up or lean back further as you twist
Breathe out as you twist to each side, breathe in as you return to center
common_mistakes: Moving only the arms instead of rotating the entire torso
Losing the V-position by sitting up or rounding the back during the twist
Twisting too fast with momentum instead of controlled, deliberate rotation
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout - letting it relax can strain your lower back
Start without weight to master the movement pattern before adding a medicine ball or plate

instructions: Take a pronated grip on a pull-up bar.
From a hanging position, raise yourself a few inches without using your arms. Do this by depressing your shoulder girdle in a reverse shrugging motion.
Pause at the completion of the movement, and then slowly return to the starting position before performing more repetitions.
exercises.name: Scapular Pull-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, arms fully extended
Without bending your elbows at all, pull your shoulder blades down and together
You should rise up just a few inches (2-4 inches) from the dead hang position
Pause for a second at the top while squeezing your shoulder blades
Slowly return to the full hanging position and repeat
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to put your shoulder blades in your back pockets - pull them down
Think about reverse shrugging - the opposite of hunching your shoulders up
Your arms stay completely straight like locked steel rods
Visualize squeezing a tennis ball between your shoulder blades at the top
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows and turning it into a partial pull-up
Not fully relaxing the shoulders at the bottom - let them elevate completely
Using momentum or kipping instead of pure shoulder blade movement
injury_prevention_tips: Master this movement before progressing to full pull-ups to build shoulder stability
Keep your core engaged to prevent excessive swinging

instructions: To begin, lie down with your back pressed against the floor or on an exercise mat (optional). Your arms should be fully extended to the sides with your palms facing down. Note: The arms should be stationary the entire time.
With a slight bend at the knees, lift your legs up so that your heels are about 6 inches off the ground. This is the starting position.
Now lift your left leg up to about a 45 degree angle while your right leg is lowered until the heel is about 2-3 inches from the ground.
Switch movements by raising your right leg up and lowering your left leg. Remember to breathe while performing this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Scissor Kick
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with arms at your sides, palms pressed down for stability
Lift both legs about 6 inches off the ground with a slight bend in your knees
Raise your left leg to about 45 degrees while lowering your right leg to 2-3 inches off the floor
Switch legs in a scissoring motion - right leg up, left leg down
Continue alternating in a controlled rhythm while breathing steadily
form_cues: Imagine you're cutting with scissors - smooth, controlled alternating motion
Press your lower back flat into the floor - don't let it arch up
Keep your core braced like someone's about to drop something on your stomach
Your legs should never touch the ground - maintain constant tension
common_mistakes: Letting your lower back arch off the floor which can strain your spine
Moving too fast with momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement
Raising your head and neck off the floor which causes neck strain
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel lower back discomfort, place your hands under your glutes for support
Keep your head and neck relaxed on the floor throughout the movement

instructions: Secure a band close to the ground and place a bench a couple feet away from it.
Seat yourself on the bench and secure the band behind your ankles, beginning with your legs straight. This will be your starting position.
Flex the knees, bringing your feet towards the bench. You may need to lean back slightly to keep your feet from striking the floor.
Pause at the completion of the movement, and then slowly return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Seated Band Hamstring Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure a resistance band close to the ground and sit on a bench a couple feet away
Loop the band around your ankles and start with your legs fully extended
Bend your knees and pull your heels toward the bench, keeping your upper legs stationary
You may need to lean back slightly to keep your feet from hitting the floor
Pause at full contraction, then slowly straighten your legs back to the start
form_cues: Think about pulling your heels to your butt using only your hamstrings
Imagine trying to dig your heels into the floor behind you
Keep your upper legs glued to the bench - only your lower legs move
Squeeze your hamstrings at the fully bent position like you're cramping them on purpose
common_mistakes: Using your hips to help pull instead of isolating the hamstrings
Going too fast and losing tension at the bottom of the movement
Not fully extending your legs at the start position
injury_prevention_tips: Control the extension phase slowly - don't let the band snap your legs straight
If you feel cramping, reduce the resistance and stretch between sets

instructions: Sit on a Military Press Bench with a bar behind your head and either have a spotter give you the bar (better on the rotator cuff this way) or pick it up yourself carefully with a pronated grip (palms facing forward). Tip: Your grip should be wider than shoulder width and it should create a 90-degree angle between the forearm and the upper arm as the barbell goes down.

Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip length, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms. Hold at about shoulder level and slightly in front of your head. This is your starting position.
Lower the bar down to the collarbone slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Barbell Military Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a military press bench with a barbell resting behind your head at shoulder level
Grip the bar wider than shoulder-width with palms facing forward
Press the bar straight up overhead until your arms are fully locked out
Lower the bar slowly back down to your collarbone level with control
Press back up explosively and repeat
form_cues: Think about pushing the bar through the ceiling in a straight vertical line
Keep your core braced tight like you're wearing a weightlifting belt
Imagine your head is on a track - tuck it back slightly as the bar passes your face
At the top, lock out hard like you're trying to push your shoulders to your ears
common_mistakes: Arching your lower back excessively to help press the weight
Pressing the bar forward instead of straight up overhead
Not lowering the bar deep enough - it should reach collarbone level
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout to protect your lower back
Use a spotter or safety bars when working with heavy weights

instructions: Start out by sitting at the end of a flat bench with a barbell placed on top of your thighs. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.
Grip the bar with your palms facing down and make sure your hands are wider than shoulder width apart from each other. Begin to lift the barbell up over your head until your arms are fully extended.
Now lower the barbell behind your head until it is resting along the base of your neck. This is the starting position.

While keeping your feet and head stationary, move your waist from side to side so that your oblique muscles feel the contraction. Only move from side to side as far as your waist will allow you to go. Stretching or moving too far can cause an injury to occur. Tip: Use a slow and controlled motion.
Remember to breathe out while twisting your body to the side and in when moving back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Barbell Twist
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the end of a flat bench with a barbell (use just the bar or light weight)
Press the bar overhead until your arms are fully extended
Lower the bar behind your head to rest at the base of your neck
Keeping your feet and head stationary, rotate your torso slowly from side to side
Move only as far as comfortable - don't force excessive rotation
form_cues: Think about twisting from your core, not just moving your arms side to side
Imagine your upper body is a turret rotating on a fixed base (your hips)
Keep the movement slow and controlled - this isn't a race
Breathe out as you twist to each side, breathe in as you return to center
common_mistakes: Twisting too far and risking spinal injury - stay within comfortable range
Moving too fast with jerky motions instead of smooth, controlled rotation
Letting your hips and feet move instead of isolating the obliques
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weight - this exercise is about movement quality, not load
Stop immediately if you feel any sharp pain in your back or spine

instructions: Sit down at the end of a flat bench with a dumbbell in one arm using a neutral grip (palms of the hand facing you).
Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up.

The upper arm with the dumbbell should be close to the torso and aligned with it (lifted up until it is parallel to the floor while the forearms are pointing towards the floor as the hands hold the weights). Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearms and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arm stationary, use the triceps to lift the weight as you exhale until the forearm is parallel to the floor and the whole arm is extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: Seated Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the end of a flat bench holding a dumbbell in one hand with a neutral grip
Bend forward at the waist until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor, keeping your back straight
Raise your upper arm so it's parallel to the floor and close to your torso, with your forearm hanging down (90-degree angle)
Extend your arm back by straightening at the elbow until your entire arm is parallel to the floor
Squeeze your tricep at the top, then lower back to 90 degrees with control
form_cues: Imagine your upper arm is bolted in place - only your forearm moves
Think about kicking your hand back behind you like you're elbowing someone
Keep your elbow high and locked in position throughout the entire set
Squeeze your tricep at full extension like you're flexing it as hard as possible
common_mistakes: Letting your upper arm drop or swing during the movement
Using momentum to swing the weight back instead of controlled tricep contraction
Not achieving full extension at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back flat and core braced to protect your lower back in the bent position
Don't go too heavy - this is an isolation exercise that requires strict form

instructions: Place a couple of dumbbells looking forward in front of a flat bench.
Sit on the end of the bench with your legs together and the dumbbells behind your calves.
Bend at the waist while keeping the back straight in order to pick up the dumbbells. The palms of your hands should be facing each other as you pick them. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your torso forward and stationary, and the arms slightly bent at the elbows, lift the dumbbells straight to the side until both arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you lift the weights. (Note: avoid swinging the torso or bringing the arms back as opposed to the side.)
After a one second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Bent-Over Rear Delt Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the end of a bench with dumbbells placed behind your calves
Bend forward at the waist while keeping your back straight to pick up the dumbbells
Hold the dumbbells with palms facing each other, arms hanging down
Keep a slight bend in your elbows and raise the dumbbells straight out to your sides until arms are parallel to the floor
Squeeze for one second at the top, then lower with control
form_cues: Think about leading with your elbows, not your hands - elbows go up first
Imagine you're spreading your wings like a bird taking flight
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like pinching a pencil between them
Keep your torso completely still - locked in a forward lean position
common_mistakes: Swinging your torso up to help lift the weights using momentum
Bringing your arms back behind you instead of straight out to the sides
Using too much weight and turning it into a rowing motion
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight - rear delts are small muscles that fatigue quickly
Keep your back flat in the bent position to avoid lower back strain

instructions: Sit down at the end of a flat bench with a dumbbell in both arms using a neutral grip (palms of the hand facing you).
Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up.

The upper arms with the dumbbells should be close to the torso and aligned with it (lifted up until they are parallel to the floor while the forearms are pointing towards the floor as the hands hold the weights).
