Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearms and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to lift the weight as you exhale until the forearms are parallel to the floor and the whole arm is extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the end of a flat bench holding dumbbells in both hands with neutral grips
Bend forward at the waist until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor
Raise both upper arms parallel to the floor, close to your torso, with forearms hanging down at 90 degrees
Extend both arms back simultaneously until they're fully straight and parallel to the floor
Squeeze your triceps at full extension, then lower back to starting position
form_cues: Think about your upper arms being welded in place - they never move
Imagine kicking both hands straight back like a double elbow strike
Keep both elbows high and locked in position throughout
Squeeze your triceps at the top like you're trying to show maximum definition
common_mistakes: Letting your upper arms drop or swing as you fatigue
Using body momentum to help swing the weights back
Not achieving full lockout at the top - go until arms are completely straight
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain a flat back throughout to protect your spine in the bent position
Start light and focus on perfect form before increasing weight

instructions: Sit on the floor with your knees bent and your partner standing behind you. Extend your arms straight behind you with your palms facing each other. Your partner will hold your wrists for you. This will be the starting position.
Attempt to flex your elbows, while your partner prevents any actual movement.

After 10-20 seconds, relax your arms while your partner gently pulls your wrists up to stretch your biceps. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is appropriate to prevent injury or overstretching.
exercises.name: Seated Biceps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your knees bent and your partner standing behind you
Extend your arms straight behind you with palms facing each other
Have your partner hold your wrists firmly
Try to flex your elbows and curl your arms while your partner prevents any movement (isometric contraction)
After 10-20 seconds of effort, relax and let your partner gently pull your wrists up to stretch your biceps
form_cues: Think about trying to curl your hands toward your shoulders with maximum effort
Engage your biceps fully but don't strain - use about 70-80% max effort
Breathe normally during the isometric hold - don't hold your breath
During the stretch phase, communicate clearly with your partner about intensity
common_mistakes: Pushing too hard during the isometric phase which can cause injury
Not communicating with your partner during the stretch portion
Holding your breath during the contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Always communicate clearly with your partner - tell them when to stop stretching
Never let your partner force the stretch too far - stay within comfortable range

instructions: For this exercise you will need access to a low pulley row machine with a V-bar. Note: The V-bar will enable you to have a neutral grip where the palms of your hands face each other. To get into the starting position, first sit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided making sure that your knees are slightly bent and not locked.
Lean over as you keep the natural alignment of your back and grab the V-bar handles.

With your arms extended pull back until your torso is at a 90-degree angle from your legs. Your back should be slightly arched and your chest should be sticking out. You should be feeling a nice stretch on your lats as you hold the bar in front of you. This is the starting position of the exercise.

Keeping the torso stationary, pull the handles back towards your torso while keeping the arms close to it until you touch the abdominals. Breathe out as you perform that movement. At that point you should be squeezing your back muscles hard. Hold that contraction for a second and slowly go back to the original position while breathing in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Cable Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a low cable row machine with feet on the platform, knees slightly bent
Grab the V-bar handle with a neutral grip (palms facing each other)
Sit upright at 90 degrees with your chest out, back slightly arched, arms extended forward
Pull the handle toward your torso, keeping your arms close to your body, until it touches your abs
Squeeze your back muscles hard for one second, then slowly return to starting position
form_cues: Imagine pulling the handle into your belly button, not your chest
Think about driving your elbows straight back toward your back pockets
Keep your chest proud and up like a superhero pose throughout
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the back like you're crushing a grape between them
common_mistakes: Leaning too far back on the pull which uses momentum instead of muscle
Rounding your back instead of keeping it straight with a slight arch
Using your arms to curl the weight instead of pulling with your back muscles
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso stationary - don't rock back and forth to move the weight
Maintain a slight arch in your lower back to protect your spine

instructions: Adjust the weight to an appropriate amount and be seated, grasping the handles. Your upper arms should be about 90 degrees to the body, with your head and chest up. The elbows should also be bent to about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending through the elbow, pressing the handles together above your head.
After pausing at the top, return the handles to the starting position. Ensure that you maintain tension on the cables.
You can also execute this movement with your back off the pad and alternate hands.
exercises.name: Seated Cable Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the cable machine seat and grab the handles with upper arms at 90 degrees to your body, elbows bent 90 degrees
Keep your chest up, head forward, and core braced
Press the handles up and together above your head until your arms are fully extended
Pause briefly at the top, then slowly lower the handles back to the starting position maintaining tension on the cables
Repeat for your desired reps - you can also do this with alternating arms for variety
form_cues: Think 'push the handles to meet at the top' like you're forming a triangle overhead
Keep your shoulders down and back - don't let them shrug up toward your ears
Drive through your shoulders like you're trying to push through the ceiling
common_mistakes: Leaning back excessively to help press the weight instead of maintaining an upright torso
Not bringing the handles all the way together at the top, missing full contraction
Letting the cables go slack at the bottom - maintain constant tension throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to protect your lower back from hyperextending
Don't let the weight pull your shoulders forward - maintain retracted shoulder blades

exercises.description: Seated calf raise performed on a machine
instructions: Sit on the machine and place your toes on the lower portion of the platform provided with the heels extending off. Choose the toe positioning of your choice (forward, in, or out) as per the beginning of this chapter.

Place your lower thighs under the lever pad, which will need to be adjusted according to the height of your thighs. Now place your hands on top of the lever pad in order to prevent it from slipping forward.
Lift the lever slightly by pushing your heels up and release the safety bar. This will be your starting position.
Slowly lower your heels by bending at the ankles until the calves are fully stretched. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Raise the heels by extending the ankles as high as possible as you contract the calves and breathe out. Hold the top contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Machine Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine with the balls of your feet on the platform and heels hanging off the edge
Place your thighs under the lever pad (adjust height to fit), rest your hands on top of the pad
Push your heels up slightly to lift the lever and release the safety bar - this is your starting position
Lower your heels as far down as possible, feeling a deep stretch in your calves
Drive up through the balls of your feet as high as possible, squeezing your calves hard at the top for one second
form_cues: Think 'heels to the floor, then toes to the ceiling' - maximize the range on both ends
At the bottom, let your heels drop like you're trying to touch the floor beneath the platform
At the top, squeeze your calves like you're trying to make them pop
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of controlling the stretch and using a deliberate contraction
Not going through full range of motion - missing either the deep stretch or the peak contraction
Using too much weight and relying on momentum instead of strict calf contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Control the eccentric (lowering) phase - don't let the weight drop quickly
Start with lighter weight to build calf strength and flexibility before progressing

instructions: Sit up straight on an exercise mat.
Bend one knee and put that foot on the floor to stabilize the torso.
Straighten your other leg and flex your ankle.
Using a band, towel, or your hand if you can reach, pull the toes toward you. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.
exercises.name: Seated Calf Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright on an exercise mat with one knee bent and foot flat on the floor for stability
Extend your other leg straight out in front of you with ankle flexed (toes toward you)
Use a resistance band, towel, or your hand to gently pull your toes toward your body
Hold the stretch for 10-20 seconds feeling tension through your calf
Release and switch to the other leg
form_cues: Think 'pull toes to nose' - active dorsiflexion to maximize the calf stretch
Keep your back straight and upright - don't round forward to reach
Pull gradually and steadily - no yanking or bouncing
common_mistakes: Bending the extended knee instead of keeping it completely straight
Rounding the back to reach the foot instead of using a band or towel
Pulling too aggressively causing pain instead of a comfortable stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Progress the stretch gradually - don't force maximum range on the first session
If you feel sharp pain in your Achilles tendon, back off the intensity

instructions: Sit down on a flat bench with a barbell or E-Z Bar in front of you in between your legs. Your legs should be spread with the knees bent and the feet on the floor.

Use your arms to pick the barbell up and place the back of your upper arms on top of your inner thighs (around three and a half inches away from the front of the knee). A supinated grip closer than shoulder width is needed to perform this exercise. Tip: Your arm should be extended at arms length and the barbell should be above the floor. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the barbell back to starting position as your breathe in. Tip: Avoid swinging motions at any time.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Close-Grip Concentration Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a flat bench with feet spread wide, place a barbell or EZ-bar between your legs
Lean forward and rest the back of your upper arms on your inner thighs (about 3.5 inches above your knees)
Grab the bar with a close, underhand grip with arms fully extended - bar should hover above the floor
Curl the bar up by contracting your biceps, keeping upper arms locked on your thighs
Squeeze hard at the top when the bar reaches shoulder level, then lower with control
form_cues: Think 'upper arms are cemented to thighs' - zero movement at the shoulders
Curl the bar in a tight arc toward your face, squeezing your biceps hard
Close grip emphasizes the inner/long head of the biceps - feel it working
common_mistakes: Lifting upper arms off the thighs to cheat the weight up
Using momentum by rocking the torso instead of strict bicep isolation
Not fully extending at the bottom, cutting range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep upper arms firmly planted on thighs throughout - don't let them shift
Use controlled motion - no swinging or jerking the weight

instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
Rotate the palms of the hands so that they are facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights and start twisting the wrists once the dumbbells pass your thighs so that the palms of your hands face forward at the end of the movement. Make sure that you contract the biceps as you breathe out and make sure that only the forearms move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position as your breathe in and as you rotate the wrists back to a neutral grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand hanging at arm's length, elbows close to your torso
Start with palms facing your body (neutral grip) - this is the starting position
Curl the weights up while rotating your wrists so palms face forward at the top
Squeeze your biceps hard when dumbbells reach shoulder height, hold for one second
Lower the dumbbells back down while rotating wrists back to neutral, fully extending your arms
form_cues: Think 'hammer grip to supinated grip' - rotate your wrists as you curl up
Elbows stay glued to your sides like they're pinned there - only forearms move
Squeeze at the top like you're flexing in a mirror - maximum bicep contraction
common_mistakes: Swinging the torso or using momentum instead of strict bicep contraction
Not rotating the wrists fully - missing the supination component of the curl
Letting elbows drift forward or out instead of keeping them locked at your sides
injury_prevention_tips: Control both the concentric (up) and eccentric (down) phases - no dropping the weight
Keep your back supported against the bench to prevent lower back strain

instructions: Sit on the end of a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
Rotate the palms of the hands so that they are facing inward in a neutral position. This will be your starting position.
While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the dumbbells out and up, turning the palms out as you lift and keeping your forearms in line with your outer deltoids. Tips:

Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position as your breathe in. Remember to rotate your arms as you lower the dumbbells so that you can switch back to a neutral grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Dumbbell Inner Biceps Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the end of a flat bench with dumbbells in each hand at arm's length, elbows close to torso
Start with palms facing inward in a neutral grip
Curl the dumbbells out and up in a wide arc, rotating palms outward as you lift
Keep your forearms in line with your outer deltoids throughout the curl - wide path
Squeeze at shoulder height, then lower back down while rotating back to neutral grip
form_cues: Think 'curl out to the sides' not straight up - create a wide arc with the dumbbells
Rotate your pinkies up and out as you curl to hit the inner biceps head
Upper arms stay stationary - imagine they're in a brace
common_mistakes: Curling straight up instead of out in a wide arc, missing the inner bicep emphasis
Not rotating the wrists enough, keeping palms too neutral
Moving the upper arms instead of keeping them locked in position
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than regular curls - the outward arc makes this more challenging
Control the descent - rotating and lowering simultaneously requires coordination

instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on the floor in front of a flat bench.
Sit down on the edge of the flat bench with your legs at about shoulder width apart. Make sure to keep your feet on the floor.

Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against your thighs with the palms of the hands facing down. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge of your thighs.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.

Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to inhale during this part of the exercise. Tip: Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
When finished, simply lower the dumbbells to the floor.
exercises.name: Seated Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the edge of a bench with feet shoulder-width apart, dumbbells in hands
Rest your forearms on your thighs with palms facing down, wrists hanging over the edge of your knees
Let the dumbbells pull your hands down toward the floor - this is the stretched starting position
Curl your wrists up by lifting your knuckles toward the ceiling
Lower back down with control until you feel the stretch in your forearms - repeat
form_cues: Think 'knuckles to sky' on the way up - curl just your wrists, not your whole arms
Forearms stay glued to your thighs - imagine they're velcroed down
Squeeze the top of your forearms at the peak of the curl
common_mistakes: Lifting forearms off the thighs to help move the weight
Using only partial range - not getting full stretch at the bottom or full curl at the top
Going too heavy and turning it into a swinging motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - forearm muscles fatigue quickly and form deteriorates fast
If you feel sharp wrist pain (not muscle burn), reduce weight immediately

instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on the floor in front of a flat bench.
Sit down on the edge of the flat bench with your legs at about shoulder width apart. Make sure to keep your feet on the floor.

Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against your thighs with the palms of the hands facing up. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge of your thighs.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.

Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to inhale during this part of the exercise. Tip: Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
When finished, simply lower the dumbbells to the floor.
exercises.name: Seated Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the edge of a bench with feet shoulder-width, hold dumbbells with palms facing up
Rest your forearms flat on your thighs with wrists hanging over the edge of your knees
Let the dumbbells roll toward your fingertips to get a full forearm stretch
Curl your wrists up toward your body as high as possible, squeezing your forearms
Lower back down with control, letting the weight roll to your fingertips again
form_cues: Think 'curl weight to forearms' - maximize that wrist flexion at the top
Let the dumbbells roll to fingertips at the bottom for the full stretch
Forearms are cemented to your thighs - only your wrists move
common_mistakes: Not letting the weight roll down to fingertips, missing the full stretch
Lifting forearms off thighs to assist the movement
Using too much weight and relying on momentum instead of wrist isolation
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight - this is an isolation exercise for small muscles
Control the descent - don't let the weights drop quickly which can strain tendons

instructions: Grab a couple of dumbbells and sit on a military press bench or a utility bench that has a back support on it as you place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs.
Clean the dumbbells up one at a time by using your thighs to bring the dumbbells up to shoulder height at each side.
Rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing forward. This is your starting position.
As you exhale, push the dumbbells up until they touch at the top.
After a second pause, slowly come down back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support, place dumbbells upright on your thighs
Kick the dumbbells up one at a time using your thighs to help bring them to shoulder height
Rotate your wrists so palms face forward - this is your starting position with dumbbells at shoulder level
Press the dumbbells straight up until they touch at the top, fully extending your arms
Pause for one second at the top, then lower back down to shoulder height with control
form_cues: Think 'drive the weights to meet at the ceiling' - press straight up, not forward
Keep your core tight and back against the pad throughout
At the top, clink the dumbbells together lightly for full contraction
common_mistakes: Arching the back excessively to help press the weight instead of keeping it supported
Pressing forward instead of straight up, which reduces shoulder activation
Not bringing the dumbbells all the way down to shoulder level on each rep
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back pressed firmly against the pad to protect your lower back
Don't let the dumbbells drop too low past shoulder level - this can stress the shoulder joints

instructions: Sit on a bench with the legs stretched out in front of you slightly below parallel and your arms holding on to the sides of the bench. Your torso should be leaning backwards around a 45-degree angle from the bench. This will be your starting position.
Bring the knees in toward you as you move your torso closer to them at the same time. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
After a second pause, go back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Flat Bench Leg Pull-In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with legs extended straight out slightly below parallel, arms holding the sides of the bench
Lean your torso back about 45 degrees - this is your starting position with core engaged
Pull your knees toward your chest while simultaneously bringing your torso closer to your knees
Squeeze your abs hard at the contracted position, pause for one second
Extend your legs back out and lean your torso back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'crunch your knees and chest together' - both move toward each other
Squeeze your abs like someone's about to punch your stomach at the top
Control both directions - don't just let your legs fall back out
common_mistakes: Only moving the legs and keeping torso stationary instead of crunching together
Letting feet touch the ground between reps, losing constant tension on the abs
Using momentum by swinging instead of controlled ab contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back neutral - don't arch excessively when extending legs
Hold onto the bench firmly to maintain stability and control throughout

instructions: Sit on a mat with your right leg extended in front of you and your left leg bent with your foot against your right inner thigh.
Lean forward from your hips and reach for your ankle until you feel a stretch in your hamstring. Hold for 15 seconds, then repeat for your other side.
exercises.name: Seated Floor Hamstring Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a mat with your right leg extended straight in front of you
Bend your left leg and place the sole of your left foot against your right inner thigh
Keep your back straight and hinge forward from your hips (not your lower back)
Reach toward your right ankle or foot until you feel a stretch in your hamstring
Hold for 15-20 seconds, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about folding forward from your hips like closing a book, not rounding your back
Imagine trying to bring your chest to your thigh, not your head to your knee
Keep your extended leg's knee straight but not locked - there should be a tiny micro-bend
Flex your toes back toward you to intensify the stretch in your hamstring and calf
common_mistakes: Rounding your spine instead of hinging from the hips
Bouncing to try to reach further which can cause injury
Bending the extended leg's knee to make it easier
injury_prevention_tips: Never bounce or force the stretch - use gentle, steady pressure
Keep your back straight to avoid lower back strain

instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your legs bent, your partner standing behind you. Stick your arms straight out to your sides, with your palms facing the ground. Attempt to move them as far behind you as possible, as your assistant holds your wrists. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your elbows straight, attempt to move your arms to the front, with your partner gently restraining you to prevent any actual movement for 10-20 seconds.
Now, relax your muscles and allow your partner to gently increase the stretch on the shoulders and chest. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.
exercises.name: Seated Front Deltoid
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright on the floor with knees bent, your partner standing behind you
Extend your arms straight out to your sides with palms facing down, reaching as far back as comfortable
Your partner holds your wrists in this stretched position
Try to bring your arms forward for 10-20 seconds while your partner resists (no actual movement)
Relax and let your partner gently push your arms further back to deepen the stretch for 10-20 seconds
form_cues: Think about trying to clap your hands in front of you while your partner prevents it
Keep your elbows locked straight throughout the isometric contraction
During the stretch phase, imagine opening your chest like a book
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch - don't tense up
common_mistakes: Using too much force during the isometric phase which can cause injury
Bending your elbows instead of keeping them straight
Not communicating with your partner about stretch intensity
injury_prevention_tips: Always communicate clearly with your partner about comfort level
Never let your partner force the stretch beyond what feels comfortable

instructions: In a seated position with your knees bent, cross one ankle over the opposite knee. Your partner will stand behind you. Now, lean forward as your partner braces your shoulders with their hands. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to push your torso back for 10-20 seconds, as your partner prevents any actual movement of your torso.
Now relax your muscles as your partner increases the stretch by gently pushing your torso forward for 10-20 seconds.
exercises.name: Seated Glute
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with knees bent, cross your right ankle over your left knee (figure-4 position)
Your partner stands behind you with hands on your shoulders
Lean forward from your hips while your partner braces your shoulders
Try to push your torso backward for 10-20 seconds while your partner prevents movement
Relax and let your partner gently push your torso forward to deepen the glute stretch for 10-20 seconds
form_cues: Think about trying to sit up straight while your partner pushes you forward
Keep your crossed ankle pressing down on your opposite knee to open the hip
Imagine folding forward from your hips, not rounding your back
Breathe out as you relax into the stretch to go deeper
common_mistakes: Rounding your back instead of hinging from the hips
Pushing too hard during the isometric phase
Not keeping the crossed ankle firmly on the opposite knee
injury_prevention_tips: Communicate constantly with your partner about comfort levels
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain in your hip or knee

instructions: Set up a box in a power rack. The pins should be set at an appropriate height. Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders, not on top of your traps. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders.

Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back. Keep your head facing forward. With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the bar tight, bend forward at the hips as much as possible. If you set the pins to what would be parallel, you not only have a safety if you fail, but know when to stop.
Pause just above the pins and reverse the motion until your torso it upright.
exercises.name: Seated Good Mornings
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a box in a power rack with safety pins at appropriate height
Sit on the box with a barbell across your upper back (not on your neck)
Keep your chest up, core braced, and create an arch in your lower back
Hinge forward at the hips as far as possible while keeping your back tight (stop just above the pins)
Pause briefly, then reverse the motion by driving your hips forward to return torso upright
form_cues: Imagine you're bowing forward while keeping your spine as stiff as a board
Think about pushing your chest down toward the floor while keeping your back arched
Keep the bar tight on your back like it's glued there - don't let it shift
Drive your hips forward to return upright, not by pulling with your back
common_mistakes: Rounding your back which puts dangerous stress on your spine
Going too deep past the safety pins without control
Using too much weight before mastering the movement pattern
injury_prevention_tips: Always use safety pins set at an appropriate height
Keep your core braced and back arched throughout the entire movement

instructions: In a seated position with your legs extended, have your partner stand behind you. Now, lean forward as your partner braces your shoulders with their hands. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to push your torso back for 10-20 seconds, as your partner prevents any actual movement of your torso.
Now relax your muscles as your partner increases the stretch by gently pushing your torso forward for 10-20 seconds.
exercises.name: Seated Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with both legs extended straight in front of you
Your partner stands behind you with hands on your shoulders
Lean forward from your hips while your partner braces your shoulders
Try to push your torso backward for 10-20 seconds while your partner prevents movement
Relax and let your partner gently push your torso forward to deepen the hamstring stretch for 10-20 seconds
form_cues: Think about trying to bring your chest toward your thighs, not your head to your knees
Hinge from your hips like a drawbridge, keeping your back straight
During the stretch, imagine reaching your chest forward, not down
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch with each exhale
common_mistakes: Rounding your spine instead of maintaining a straight back
Bending your knees to make it easier
Pushing too hard during the isometric contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep constant communication with your partner about stretch intensity
Never bounce or force the stretch - use gentle, progressive pressure

instructions: Loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. Sit down with both legs extended . This will be your starting position.
Leaning forward slightly, pull on the belt to draw the toes of your foot back. Hold this position for 10-20 seconds and then repeat with the other leg.
exercises.name: Seated Hamstring and Calf Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with both legs extended straight in front of you
Loop a belt, strap, or resistance band around the ball of one foot
Lean forward slightly from your hips while keeping your back straight
Pull on the belt to draw your toes back toward you
Hold for 15-20 seconds feeling the stretch in your hamstring and calf, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about pulling your toes toward your shin to feel it in your calf
Keep your knee straight but not hyperextended - maintain a micro-bend
Imagine trying to touch your chest to your thigh, not your head to your knee
Pull with steady, gentle pressure - no yanking or jerking
common_mistakes: Rounding your back instead of hinging from the hips
Bending the knee to reduce the stretch intensity
Pulling too aggressively which can cause cramping
injury_prevention_tips: Use gentle, progressive tension - never yank or bounce
If you feel cramping, release immediately and shake out your leg

instructions: Place a neck strap on the floor at the end of a flat bench. Once you have selected the weights, sit at the end of the flat bench with your feet wider than shoulder width apart from each other. Your toes should be pointed out.

Slowly move your torso forward until it is almost parallel with the floor. Using both hands, securely position the neck strap around your head. Tip: Make sure the weights are still lying on the floor to prevent any strain on the neck. Now grab the weight with both hands while elevating your torso back until it is almost perpendicular to the floor. Note: Your head and torso needs to be slightly tilted forward to perform this exercise.
Now place both hands on top of your knees. This is the starting position.
Slowly lower your neck down until your chin touches the upper part of your chest while breathing in.
While exhaling, bring your neck back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Head Harness Neck Resistance
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the end of a flat bench with feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed out
Lean forward with torso nearly parallel to the floor and secure the neck harness around your head
Grab the weight with both hands and elevate your torso until nearly perpendicular to the floor
Place both hands on your knees (head and torso tilted slightly forward) - this is the start
Slowly lower your chin toward your chest, then raise your head back to starting position
form_cues: Think about nodding 'yes' in an exaggerated, slow motion
Keep the movement smooth and controlled - no jerking or bouncing
Imagine your head is moving through thick honey - deliberate and slow
At the bottom, your chin should gently touch your upper chest
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing control of the movement
Moving too fast which can strain the delicate neck muscles
Not maintaining proper torso position throughout the set
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight - neck muscles are delicate and easily injured
Never jerk or use momentum - keep all movements slow and controlled

instructions: Adjust the machine lever to fit your height and sit on the machine with your back against the back support pad.

Place the back of lower leg on top of padded lever (just a few inches under the calves) and secure the lap pad against your thighs, just above the knees. Then grasp the side handles on the machine as you point your toes straight (or you can also use any of the other two stances) and ensure that the legs are fully straight right in front of you. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, pull the machine lever as far as possible to the back of your thighs by flexing at the knees. Keep your torso stationary at all times. Hold the contracted position for a second.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Leg Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the machine so the pad rests on the back of your lower legs (just below your calves)
Sit with your back against the pad and secure the lap pad across your thighs above your knees
Start with legs fully extended, holding the side handles for stability
Curl your legs back as far as possible by bending at the knees, bringing the pad toward your glutes
Squeeze your hamstrings at full contraction, then slowly return to the starting position
form_cues: Think about pulling your heels to your butt using only your hamstrings
Imagine trying to touch your heels to the back of the bench
Keep your torso completely still - glued to the back pad throughout
Squeeze your hamstrings at the top like you're trying to cramp them
common_mistakes: Lifting your butt off the seat to help curl the weight
Using momentum and swinging the weight instead of controlled contraction
Not going through full range - curl as far back as possible
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso pressed against the back pad to avoid lower back involvement
Control the eccentric (lowering) phase - don't let the weight crash down

instructions: Sit on a bench with the legs stretched out in front of you slightly below parallel and your arms holding on to the sides of the bench. Your torso should be leaning backwards around a 45-degree angle from the bench. This will be your starting position.
Bring the knees in toward you as you move your torso closer to them at the same time. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
After a second pause, go back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Leg Tucks
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the end of a bench with legs extended slightly below parallel
Hold the sides of the bench for support, lean your torso back about 45 degrees
Simultaneously pull your knees toward your chest while bringing your torso forward
Meet in the middle in a tucked position, squeezing your abs
Extend back out to the starting position with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about folding yourself like a jackknife - both ends meet in the middle
Imagine trying to touch your knees to your chest and your chest to your knees at the same time
Squeeze your abs at the tucked position like you're crushing a can between your ribs and hips
Keep the movement smooth and controlled, not jerky or rushed
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing your legs instead of controlled ab contraction
Not bringing your torso forward enough - both torso and legs should move
Letting your feet touch the ground at the extended position which reduces tension
injury_prevention_tips: Keep movements controlled - never swing or use momentum
If you feel lower back strain, don't extend your legs as far out

instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a dumbbell in your right hand.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.

Lean forward and place your right forearm on top of your upper right thigh with your palm down. Tip: Make sure that the back of the wrist lies on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the dumbbell as far as possible as you keep a tight grip on the dumbbell. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Now curl the dumbbell as high as possible as you contract the forearms and as you exhale. Keep the contraction for a second before you lower again. Tip: The only movement should happen at the wrist.
Perform for the recommended amount of repetitions, switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench holding a dumbbell in one hand with an overhand grip (palm down)
Place your forearm on top of your thigh with your wrist hanging over your knee
Start by lowering the dumbbell as far as possible by extending your wrist
Curl the dumbbell up as high as possible by flexing your wrist, contracting your forearm
Hold the top contraction for one second, then lower with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about your forearm being glued to your thigh - only your wrist moves
Imagine you're trying to point your knuckles toward the ceiling at the top
Keep a tight grip on the dumbbell throughout - don't let it roll in your hand
Move slowly and deliberately - this is about control, not speed
common_mistakes: Lifting your forearm off your thigh which reduces forearm isolation
Using too much weight and losing the full range of motion
Letting the dumbbell roll in your hand instead of maintaining a firm grip
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight - forearm muscles are smaller and fatigue quickly
Keep your forearm pressed firmly to your thigh throughout the movement

instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a dumbbell in your right hand.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.

Lean forward and place your right forearm on top of your upper right thigh with your palm up. Tip: Make sure that the front of the wrist lies on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the dumbbell as far as possible as you keep a tight grip on the dumbbell. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Now curl the dumbbell as high as possible as you contract the forearms and as you exhale. Keep the contraction for a second before you lower again. Tip: The only movement should happen at the wrist.
Perform for the recommended amount of repetitions, switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with feet flat and wider than shoulder-width, hold a dumbbell in your right hand
Place your right forearm on your right thigh with palm facing up, wrist hanging over the edge of your knee
Lower the dumbbell as far down as possible while maintaining a tight grip
Curl the dumbbell up as high as you can by flexing your wrist, squeezing your forearm at the top
Hold for one second at the top, lower with control, then repeat for reps before switching arms
form_cues: Think 'wrist curl only' - your forearm stays glued to your thigh
Let the weight roll to your fingertips at the bottom for maximum stretch
Squeeze your forearm at the top like you're flexing it hard
common_mistakes: Lifting the forearm off the thigh to help curl the weight
Not using full range - missing the fingertip roll or the peak flex
Going too heavy and using momentum instead of isolated wrist movement
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight - forearm muscles fatigue very quickly
Control the descent - don't let the weight drop suddenly

instructions: To get into the starting position, first sit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided making sure that your knees are slightly bent and not locked.
Lean over as you keep the natural alignment of your back and grab the single handle attachment with your left arm using a palms-down grip.

With your arm extended pull back until your torso is at a 90-degree angle from your legs. Your back should be slightly arched and your chest should be sticking out. You should be feeling a nice stretch on your lat as you hold the bar in front of you. The right arm can be kept by the waist. This is the starting position of the exercise.

Keeping the torso stationary, pull the handles back towards your torso while keeping the arms close to it as you rotate the wrist, so that by the time your hand is by your abdominals it is in a neutral position (palms facing the torso). Breathe out as you perform that movement. At that point you should be squeezing your back muscles hard.

Hold that contraction for a second and slowly go back to the original position while breathing in. Tip: Remember to rotate the wrist as you go back to the starting position so that the palms are facing down again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform the same movement with the right hand.
exercises.name: Seated One-arm Cable Pulley Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the cable row machine with feet on the platform and knees slightly bent, grab the single handle with your left hand using an overhand grip
Pull back until your torso is at 90 degrees, back slightly arched, chest out with your arm fully extended - this is your starting position
Pull the handle toward your torso while keeping your arm close to your body, rotating your wrist so the palm faces your abs at the end
Squeeze your back muscles hard, hold for one second
Slowly return to starting position while rotating wrist back to overhand grip, then repeat for reps before switching arms
form_cues: Think 'elbow to hip' - drive your elbow straight back, not out to the side
Rotate your wrist during the pull like you're starting a lawnmower
Squeeze your lat at the end like you're crushing something in your armpit
common_mistakes: Rotating your torso instead of keeping it stationary throughout
Not rotating the wrist, missing the forearm and lat engagement
Using momentum by rocking back and forth instead of controlled pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso stationary - core should be braced throughout
Don't jerk the weight - create smooth, controlled tension

instructions: Sit up straight on an exercise mat.
Touch the soles of your feet together with your feet six to eight inches in front of your hips.
Place one hand on the floor beside you and your other hand behind your head.
Lift your elbow to the ceiling as you incline your torso to the other side. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.
exercises.name: Seated Overhead Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright on an exercise mat with the soles of your feet together, feet 6-8 inches in front of your hips
Place one hand on the floor beside you for support and the other hand behind your head with elbow pointing up
Lift your overhead elbow toward the ceiling while leaning your torso sideways to the opposite side
Hold the stretch for 10-20 seconds feeling the stretch along the side of your torso
Switch sides and repeat
form_cues: Think 'elbow to ceiling' as you lean - create a long arc along your side body
Sit up tall before leaning - don't collapse or round forward
Breathe deeply into the stretched side to enhance the stretch
common_mistakes: Rotating forward instead of pure side-bending
Collapsing at the waist instead of maintaining length through the torso
Holding your breath instead of breathing through the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Move gradually into the stretch - don't force maximum range immediately
Keep your hips anchored - both sit bones should stay grounded

instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing up; hands spaced about shoulder width.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.
Lean forward and place your forearms on top of your upper thighs with your palms up. Tip: Make sure that the front of the wrists lay on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible while inhaling and keeping a tight grip.
Now curl bar up as high as possible while flexing the forearms and exhaling. Hold the contraction at the top for a second and Tip: Only the wrist should move.
exercises.name: Seated Palm-Up Barbell Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench holding a barbell with an underhand grip at shoulder-width, feet wider than shoulders
Lean forward and rest your forearms on your thighs with palms up, wrists hanging over your knees
Lower the bar as far as possible while maintaining a tight grip
Curl the bar up as high as possible by flexing your wrists and contracting your forearms
Hold the contraction for one second at the top, then lower with control
form_cues: Think 'forearms are bolted down' - only your wrists move
Let the bar roll to your fingertips at the bottom for the full stretch
Squeeze your forearms hard at the top like you're flexing them
common_mistakes: Lifting forearms off thighs to help curl the weight
Not achieving full range - missing the fingertip roll or peak contraction
Using body momentum by rocking instead of pure wrist isolation
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight - forearms burn out fast
Control the eccentric phase - don't let the bar drop quickly

instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing down; hands spaced about shoulder width.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.
Lean forward and place your forearms on top of your upper thighs with your palms down. Tip: Make sure that the back of the wrists lay on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible while inhaling and keeping a tight grip.
Now curl bar up as high as possible while flexing the forearms and exhaling. Hold the contraction at the top for a second and Tip: Only the wrist should move.
exercises.name: Seated Palms-Down Barbell Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench holding a barbell with an overhand grip at shoulder-width, feet wider than shoulders
Lean forward with forearms resting on your thighs, palms down with wrists hanging over your knees
Lower the bar as far as possible while keeping a tight grip
Curl the bar up as high as you can by extending your wrists and flexing the top of your forearms
Hold for one second at the top, then lower with control
form_cues: Think 'knuckles to ceiling' on the way up
Forearms stay glued to your thighs - zero movement except at the wrists
Get full range - hands drooping down to knuckles pointing up
common_mistakes: Peeling forearms off thighs to cheat the weight up
Using only partial range instead of maximizing the curl
Loading too heavy and relying on momentum
injury_prevention_tips: Use significantly lighter weight than palms-up curls - this variation is harder
Stop if you feel sharp wrist or elbow pain

instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and sit at the end of a flat bench with your feet firmly on the floor. Hold the dumbbells with your palms facing in and your arms straight down at your sides at arms' length. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the dumbbells to your side with a slight bend on the elbow and the hands slightly tilted forward as if pouring water in a glass. Continue to go up until you arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this movement and pause for a second at the top.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Side Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the end of a flat bench with dumbbells at your sides, arms straight down, palms facing in
Keep your torso completely stationary and lift the dumbbells out to your sides with a slight elbow bend
Tilt your hands slightly forward like pouring water as you raise to shoulder height
Pause for one second at the top with arms parallel to the floor
Lower the dumbbells back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'pour water from a pitcher' - pinky finger leads slightly higher
Keep your torso like a statue - no leaning, swinging, or rocking
Stop at shoulder height - going higher shifts work to traps
common_mistakes: Swinging or using momentum instead of controlled shoulder movement
Raising dumbbells above shoulder level, which reduces deltoid tension
Shrugging shoulders up instead of keeping them down and away
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you think - strict form is essential
Don't go above shoulder height to avoid shoulder joint stress

exercises.description: Seated triceps press peformed with a bench and an overhead dumbbell
instructions: Sit down on a bench with back support and grasp a dumbbell with both hands and hold it overhead at arm's length. Tip: a better way is to have somebody hand it to you especially if it is very heavy. The resistance should be resting in the palms of your hands with your thumbs around it. The palm of the hand should be facing inward. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semi-circular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the dumbbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Triceps Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support, hold a dumbbell overhead at arm's length with both hands
Keep your upper arms close to your head with elbows pointing up and perpendicular to the floor
Lower the dumbbell behind your head in a semicircular motion until your forearms touch your biceps
Drive the weight back up using your triceps until arms are fully extended overhead
Pause briefly at the top, then repeat for your set
form_cues: Think 'elbows to ears' - keep them close to your head throughout
Upper arms are frozen - only your forearms move
Lower behind your head like you're scratching your upper back
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to the sides instead of keeping them close
Moving the upper arms instead of keeping them stationary
Not lowering to full depth - missing the complete stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Have someone hand you the weight if it's heavy to avoid shoulder strain
Keep movements controlled - don't let the weight drop behind your head

instructions: Put a bench in front of a low pulley machine that has a barbell or EZ Curl attachment on it.
Move the bench far enough away so that when you bring the handle to the top of your thighs tension is created on the cable due to the weight stack being moved up.
Now hold the handle with both hands, palms up, using a shoulder-width grip.
Step back and sit on the bench with your feet about shoulder width apart, firmly on the floor.
Lean forward and place the forearms on your thighs with the back of your wrists over your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible, while inhaling and keeping a tight grip.
Now curl the bar up as high as possible while contracting the forearms. Tip: Only the wrist should move; not the forearms.
After a second contraction at the top go back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Seated Two-Arm Palms-Up Low-Pulley Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a bench in front of a low pulley with a bar attachment, adjust distance so there's tension when the bar is at thigh height
Sit on the bench holding the bar with both hands palms up at shoulder-width
Lean forward with forearms on your thighs, wrists hanging over your knees
Lower the bar as far as possible while inhaling and maintaining grip
Curl the bar up as high as you can by contracting your forearms, hold for one second at the top
form_cues: Think 'wrists only' - forearms stay completely still on your thighs
Constant tension from the cable makes this harder than free weight version
Squeeze hard at the top like you're showing off your forearm muscles
common_mistakes: Moving forearms instead of isolating the wrist movement
Not maintaining tension - letting the weight stack touch between reps
Using body English instead of pure forearm contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - cable tension is constant and very fatiguing
Control both directions - don't let the cable yank your wrists down

instructions: Grab a dumbbell with each hand and stand up erect.

Clean (lift) the dumbbells to the chest/shoulder level and then rotate your wrists so that your palms are facing towards you as if you were getting ready to perform an Arnold Press. This will be your starting position.

Now start extending your left arm overhead as you rotate the wrist so that the palm of your hand faces forward as you go up. Your elbows should come out also as you lift the weight. Simultaneously, you will also be bending from your hip to your opposite side. Tip: If you perform the exercise correctly, is should look as if you are trying to reach for something overhead on the right hand side of your body, but with your left arm. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
Once you reach the top position breathe in. Then, with the weight fully extended overhead and you bent over to your right hand side, begin the movement to the left side.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: See-Saw Press (Alternating Side Press)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand erect holding dumbbells at chest/shoulder level with palms facing you (Arnold press starting position)
Press your left arm overhead while rotating your wrist so the palm faces forward, simultaneously bend sideways to your right
At the top you should be reaching overhead to your right side with your left arm fully extended
Reverse the movement and immediately press your right arm overhead while bending to the left side
Continue alternating sides in a see-saw motion for your reps
form_cues: Think 'reach for something overhead and to the side' with each press
As one arm presses up, your torso bends away from that side - it's a coordinated movement
Rotate your wrist from palm-in to palm-forward as you press
common_mistakes: Pressing straight up instead of combining it with the side bend
Not rotating the wrist during the press
Moving too fast without coordinating the press and bend properly
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than regular overhead presses - this requires more control and coordination
Engage your core throughout to protect your lower back during the side bending

instructions: Attach a single handle to a low cable.
After selecting the correct weight, stand a couple feet back with a wide-split stance. Your arm should be extended and your shoulder forward. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by retracting the shoulder and flexing the elbow. As you pull, supinate the wrist, turning the palm upward as you go.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Shotgun Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a single handle to a low cable pulley and select your weight
Stand a few feet back in a wide split stance with your working arm fully extended and shoulder forward
Pull the handle toward you by retracting your shoulder blade and bending your elbow
As you pull, rotate your wrist from overhand to underhand (palm up) at the end of the movement
Pause briefly with your elbow back and palm up, then return to the extended starting position
form_cues: Think 'pull like starting a lawn mower' - retract shoulder then bend elbow with wrist rotation
Drive your elbow straight back, not out to the side
Wide stance provides stability - keep your torso relatively still
common_mistakes: Not retracting the shoulder first, starting the pull with just the arm
Forgetting to supinate (rotate palm up) during the pull
Rotating the torso excessively instead of keeping it stable
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the shoulder retraction and wrist rotation pattern
Keep your core braced to prevent twisting or losing balance

instructions: With shoulders relaxed and arms resting loosely at your sides (or in your lap if you're seated), gently roll your shoulders forward, up, back, and down.
Reverse direction. You can do this exercise alternating shoulders or both at the same time.
exercises.name: Shoulder Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit with arms relaxed at your sides
Roll your shoulders forward in a circular motion: up toward your ears, forward, down, and back
Complete 5-10 circles in this direction with smooth, controlled movement
Reverse the direction: roll shoulders up, back, down, and forward
You can do both shoulders together or alternate one at a time
form_cues: Think about drawing the biggest circles possible with your shoulders
Keep your arms completely relaxed and loose - they're just along for the ride
Imagine your shoulders are gears turning smoothly in both directions
Move slowly and deliberately - this isn't a race
common_mistakes: Moving too fast and losing the circular motion
Tensing your arms or hands instead of keeping them relaxed
Making tiny circles instead of using full range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement smooth and pain-free throughout
If you feel clicking or grinding, reduce the range of motion slightly

instructions: To begin, stand on an exercise band so that tension begins at arm's length. Grasp the handles and lift them so that the hands are at shoulder height at each side.
Rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing forward. Your elbows should be bent, with the upper arms and forearms in line to the torso. This is your starting position.
As you exhale, lift the handles up until your arms are fully extended overhead.
exercises.name: Shoulder Press - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on the center of a resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart
Grab the handles and lift them to shoulder height with elbows bent at 90 degrees
Rotate your wrists so palms face forward (this is the starting position)
Press the handles straight up overhead until your arms are fully extended
Lower back down to shoulder height with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about pushing through the ceiling in a straight vertical path
Keep your core braced tight like you're wearing a weightlifting belt
Imagine pressing your shoulders to your ears at the top lockout
Don't let the band pull you forward - maintain an upright torso
common_mistakes: Leaning back or arching your lower back to help press the weight
Pressing the handles forward instead of straight up overhead
Not fully extending your arms at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to protect your lower back
Start with lighter resistance bands and progress gradually

instructions: Relax your arms to your sides and raise your shoulders up toward your ears, then back down.
exercises.name: Shoulder Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit with arms relaxed at your sides
Raise your shoulders straight up toward your ears as high as possible (shrug motion)
Hold at the top for 1-2 seconds
Lower your shoulders back down to the relaxed starting position
Repeat for several reps with slow, controlled movement
form_cues: Imagine you're trying to touch your ears with your shoulders
Think about lifting your shoulders straight up, not rolling them forward or back
At the top, squeeze like you're holding something between your shoulders and ears
Lower with control - don't just let them drop
common_mistakes: Rolling shoulders forward or backward instead of straight up
Moving too fast without holding the contraction at the top
Tensing your neck excessively
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement strictly vertical - no rotation
If you feel neck strain, you're tensing too much - relax your neck muscles

instructions: Reach your left arm across your body and hold it straight.
exercises.name: Shoulder Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit upright with good posture
Reach your left arm straight across your body at chest height
Use your right hand to gently pull your left arm closer to your chest
Hold the stretch for 15-20 seconds, feeling it in your left shoulder
Switch arms and repeat on the other side
form_cues: Think about pulling your arm across your chest, not up or down
Keep your shoulders level - don't let the stretching shoulder hike up
Imagine you're trying to look behind you while your arm stays in place
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch with each exhale
common_mistakes: Pulling the arm at the elbow instead of closer to the shoulder
Hunching the opposite shoulder or twisting your torso
Pulling too aggressively instead of using gentle, steady pressure
injury_prevention_tips: Never force the stretch - use gentle, progressive tension
Keep your torso facing forward throughout the stretch

instructions: First lie on your left side, bending your left knee in front of you to stabilize your torso (use your abdominal muscles as well to hold you upright).

Straighten your right leg and rest the right foot on the floor behind your left. Straighten your right arm over your head and gently pull on your right wrist to stretch the entire right side of the body. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Side-Lying Floor Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your left side with your left knee bent in front of you for stability
Straighten your right leg and place your right foot on the floor behind your left foot
Extend your right arm overhead along the floor
Use your left hand to gently pull on your right wrist, stretching your entire right side
Hold for 15-20 seconds, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about creating a long, continuous curve from your right foot through your fingertips
Imagine someone is pulling your right hand and right foot in opposite directions
Feel the stretch along your entire right side from hip to shoulder
Breathe deeply - your ribcage should expand into the stretch
common_mistakes: Rolling forward or backward instead of staying stacked on your side
Not straightening the top leg fully
Pulling too hard on the wrist instead of gentle, sustained tension
injury_prevention_tips: Engage your core to keep your torso stable and prevent rolling
Use gentle pull on the wrist - let gravity do most of the work

exercises.name: Side Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with your elbow directly under your shoulder, forearm on the ground
Stack your feet on top of each other or stagger them for more stability
Lift your hips off the ground until your body forms a straight line from head to feet
Hold this position while keeping your core engaged and hips up
Lower down with control, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about pushing your hip toward the ceiling to maintain height
Imagine you're a plank of wood - perfectly straight from head to feet
Keep your top shoulder pulled back - don't let it roll forward
Squeeze your obliques like you're crushing a walnut with your side muscles
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag toward the floor as you fatigue
Piking your hips up too high instead of maintaining a straight line
Rolling forward or backward instead of staying stacked on your side
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your elbow directly under your shoulder to avoid strain
If your hips start to sag, end the set - don't compromise form

exercises.name: Side Jackknife
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your right side with legs extended and stacked, right arm extended on the floor
Place your left hand behind your head for support
Simultaneously lift your left leg and upper body toward each other, crunching your left oblique
Try to bring your left elbow toward your left knee
Lower back down with control and repeat before switching sides
form_cues: Think about closing like a jackknife - both ends moving toward each other
Imagine your left side is being scrunched up like an accordion
Focus on using your obliques to create the movement, not momentum
Squeeze your obliques at the top like you're crushing a can with your side
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing up instead of controlled oblique contraction
Pulling on your head with your hand which can strain the neck
Not lifting your upper body enough - both sides should move equally
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your hand behind your head for support only - don't pull on it
Move slowly and with control to protect your lower back

instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and stand with a straight torso and the dumbbells by your side at arms length with the palms of the hand facing you. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso in a stationary position (no swinging), lift the dumbbells to your side with a slight bend on the elbow and the hands slightly tilted forward as if pouring water in a glass. Continue to go up until you arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this movement and pause for a second at the top.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Side Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing inward
Keep a slight bend in your elbows throughout the movement
Raise the dumbbells out to your sides with hands tilted forward slightly (like pouring water)
Lift until your arms are parallel to the floor, pause for one second
Lower back down slowly to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Think about leading with your elbows, not your hands - elbows go up first
Imagine you're pouring out two pitchers of water at the top of the movement
Keep your torso completely still like it's frozen in ice
Visualize your arms as wings spreading out to your sides
common_mistakes: Swinging your body or using momentum to lift the weights
Lifting too high above shoulder level which reduces delt activation
Straightening your arms completely which puts stress on the elbows
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a consistent slight bend in your elbows throughout
Use lighter weight to maintain strict form - this is an isolation exercise

instructions: In a standing position, hold a pair of dumbbells at your side. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your elbows slightly bent, raise the weights directly in front of you to shoulder height, avoiding any swinging or cheating.
At the top of the exercise move the weights out in front of you, keeping your arms extended.
Lower the weights with a controlled motion.
On the next repetition, raise the weights in front of you to shoulder height before moving the weights laterally to your sides.
Lower the weights to the starting position.
exercises.name: Side Laterals to Front Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides with a slight elbow bend
Rep 1: Raise the weights directly in front of you to shoulder height, then move them out to your sides, then lower
Rep 2: Raise the weights out to your sides first, then bring them to the front, then lower
Alternate this pattern: frontsidesdown, then sidesfrontdown
Keep movements smooth and controlled throughout
form_cues: Think about drawing a T-shape in the air with the dumbbells
Keep your arms at shoulder height as you transition from front to sides
Imagine you're on train tracks - movements are controlled and deliberate
Maintain the same slight elbow bend throughout all positions
common_mistakes: Dropping the weights between transitions instead of keeping them elevated
Using momentum or swinging instead of controlled movement
Straightening or bending your elbows as you transition
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight - this is a complex movement that requires control
Keep your core braced to prevent using your lower back

instructions: Stand next to a chair, which you may hold onto as a support. Stand on one leg. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your leg straight, raise it as far out to the side as possible, and swing it back down, allowing it to cross the opposite leg.
Repeat this swinging motion 5-10 times, increasing the range of motion as you do so.
exercises.name: Side Leg Raises
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on one leg next to a chair, holding it lightly for balance support
Keep your free leg straight and swing it out to the side as far as comfortable
Let it swing back down across your body past your standing leg
Continue this controlled swinging motion for 5-10 reps, gradually increasing range of motion
Switch legs and repeat
form_cues: Think about creating a pendulum swing with your leg
Imagine your leg is loose and relaxed like a rope
Let momentum carry your leg through the full range - don't force it
Keep your torso upright - don't lean side to side as you swing
common_mistakes: Leaning your torso to help lift the leg instead of keeping upright
Swinging too aggressively at the start before you're warmed up
Bending the knee instead of keeping the leg straight
injury_prevention_tips: Start with small range of motion and gradually increase as you warm up
Keep movements controlled - don't let the leg swing wildly

instructions: Start off by lying on your right side and bend your right knee in front of you to stabilize the torso.
Rest your head on your right hand or shoulder. Lift your left leg upward and hold it by the back of the knee (easier) or the foot (harder).
Pull your left knee in toward your left shoulder and simultaneously press your foot or knee down to the floor. To intensify this stretch, straighten your left leg. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Side Lying Groin Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your right side with right knee bent in front of you for stability, rest your head on your right hand
Lift your left leg up and grab it behind the knee (easier) or at the foot (harder)
Pull your left knee toward your left shoulder while simultaneously pressing your foot or knee down toward the floor
To intensify, straighten your left leg while maintaining the pull and press
Hold for 10-20 seconds, then switch to the other side
form_cues: Think 'knee to shoulder, foot to floor' at the same time - these opposing forces create the stretch
For easier version, keep leg bent; for harder, straighten it out
Breathe deeply to help the muscles relax into the stretch
common_mistakes: Rolling backward or forward instead of staying on your side
Not maintaining the downward press on the leg, which reduces stretch intensity
Tensing up instead of relaxing into the position
injury_prevention_tips: Progress gradually - start with bent knee version before attempting straight leg
Don't force the stretch - ease into it gradually over multiple sessions

instructions: Start with your shoulders relaxed, gently tilt your head towards your shoulder.
Assist stretch with a gentle pull on the side of the head.
exercises.name: Side Neck Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit with shoulders relaxed and down
Gently tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear toward your shoulder
Place your hand on the same side of your head and apply gentle downward pressure to increase the stretch
Hold for 10-20 seconds feeling the stretch along the opposite side of your neck
Return to center and repeat on the other side
form_cues: Think 'ear to shoulder' but don't force it - let gravity and gentle hand pressure do the work
Keep shoulders down and relaxed - don't let them creep up toward your ears
Tilt straight to the side, not forward or backward
common_mistakes: Rotating the head forward or back instead of pure side tilt
Shrugging the opposite shoulder up, which reduces the stretch
Pulling too hard with your hand instead of gentle assistance
injury_prevention_tips: Apply very gentle pressure - neck muscles are delicate
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or tingling down your arm

instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using a wide grip.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at a wide grip, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up while leaning to the left hand side until the bar almost touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space (no swinging) and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second of contraction, inhale as you go back to the starting position.

Now, pull your torso up while leaning to the right hand side until the bar almost touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second of contraction, inhale as you go back to the starting position.
Repeat steps 3-6 until you have performed the prescribed amount of repetitions for each side.
exercises.name: Side To Side Chins
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pullup bar with wide overhand grip, hang with arms extended and lean back 30 degrees with chest out
Pull yourself up while leaning to the left until the bar touches your upper chest on the left side
Squeeze your back hard, pause for one second, then lower back down to the starting position
Immediately pull yourself up again, this time leaning to the right until the bar touches your upper chest on the right side
Lower back down and repeat, alternating left and right pulls for your set
form_cues: Think 'pull to one shoulder' not straight up - create a diagonal pull path
Keep your torso stable - the lean comes from pulling toward one side, not swinging
Squeeze the lat on the side you're pulling to like you're crushing something in that armpit
common_mistakes: Swinging or using momentum instead of controlled pulling
Not leaning enough to each side, turning it into a regular pullup
Losing the back arch and chest-up position during the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular pullups before attempting this advanced variation
Control the descent - don't drop straight down with locked elbows

instructions: This stretch works best standing. Cross your left arm over the midline of your body and hold the left wrist in your right hand down at the level of your hips. Start the stretch with a bent left arm.
Slowly straighten, pull, and lift it up to shoulder height, as pictured. Feel this stretch originate in your back, not your shoulders, and don't pull too hard on the shoulders joint. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Side Wrist Pull
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright and cross your left arm across your body at hip level with elbow bent
Grab your left wrist with your right hand
Slowly straighten your left arm while pulling it across and lifting it up to shoulder height
Feel the stretch originating in your upper back and shoulder, not just the arm
Hold for 10-20 seconds, then switch sides
form_cues: Think 'pull across and up' - combine the horizontal pull with vertical lift
