The stretch should be felt in your back and rear shoulder, not painfully in the joint
Keep your shoulders down as you perform the stretch
common_mistakes: Yanking the arm instead of smooth, gradual lifting and pulling
Pulling too hard on the shoulder joint causing pain instead of a back stretch
Hunching forward instead of maintaining upright posture
injury_prevention_tips: Don't pull aggressively on the shoulder joint - this should be a gentle stretch
Stop if you feel pinching or sharp pain in the shoulder

instructions: Begin by moving the pulleys to the high position, select the resistance to be used, and take a handle in each hand.

Step forward in front of both pulleys with your arms extended in front of you, bringing your hands together. Your head and chest should be up as you lean forward, while your feet should be staggered. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your left arm in place, allow your right arm to extend out to the side, maintaining a slight bend at the elbow. The right arm should be perpendicular to the body at approximately shoulder level.
Return your arm back to the starting position by pulling your hand back to the midline of the body.
Hold for a second at the starting position and repeat the movement on the opposite side. Continue alternating back and forth for the prescribed number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Single-Arm Cable Crossover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set both cables to high position, hold a handle in each hand and step forward with arms extended and hands together at center
Keep your left arm stationary at the midline while extending your right arm out to the side at shoulder level with slight elbow bend
Pull your right hand back to the center, bringing it to meet your left hand
Hold for one second, then repeat on the left side while keeping right arm stationary
Continue alternating arms for your prescribed reps
form_cues: Think 'hug a tree one arm at a time' - same arc motion as a fly but alternating
Keep your chest up and core tight - maintain that forward lean throughout
Squeeze your chest as you bring your arm back to center
common_mistakes: Moving both arms instead of keeping one stationary
Letting the moving arm drop below or rise above shoulder level
Using momentum by rocking instead of controlled chest contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the single-arm control pattern
Keep a slight bend in the elbow throughout - don't lock it straight

instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or securely anchor it in a corner. Load the bar to an appropriate weight.
Raise the bar from the floor, taking it to your shoulders with one or both hands. Adopt a wide stance. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by extending the elbow, pressing the weight up. Move explosively, extending the hips and knees fully to produce maximal force.
Return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Single-Arm Linear Jammer
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a barbell in a landmine attachment or corner, load it with weight
Lift the bar to your shoulder with one hand, adopt a wide stance - this is your starting position
Explosively press the bar up and forward by extending your arm while driving through your hips and knees
Fully extend your hips, knees, and arm at the top for maximum force
Return the bar to your shoulder and repeat for reps before switching arms
form_cues: Think 'full-body explosion' - drive with your legs as you press the bar
The bar travels in an arc up and forward, not straight up
Extend everything at once - hips, knees, and arm for maximum power
common_mistakes: Pressing with arm only instead of using leg drive for power
Not fully extending the hips and knees at the top
Leaning back excessively instead of driving forward
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to learn the explosive coordination pattern
Brace your core throughout to protect your lower back

instructions: Begin laying prone on the ground. Move yourself into a position supporting your weight on your toes and one arm. Your working arm should be placed directly under the shoulder, fully extended. Your legs should be extended, and for this movement you may need a wider base, placing your feet further apart than in a normal push-up.
Maintain good posture, and place your free hand behind your back. This will be your starting position.
Lower yourself by allowing the elbow to flex until you touch the ground.
Descend slowly, and reverse direction be extending the arm to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Single-Arm Push-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into pushup position but place only one arm on the ground directly under your shoulder, extend the other arm behind your back
Widen your foot stance more than a regular pushup for better stability
Lower yourself by bending your working arm until your chest touches the ground
Push back up explosively, fully extending your arm to return to the starting position
Complete your reps on one side before switching arms
form_cues: Think 'wider stance for balance' - feet further apart than normal pushups
Keep your body in a rigid plank - don't let hips sag or twist
Lower slowly, push up explosively
common_mistakes: Rotating or twisting the torso instead of staying square
Not going deep enough - chest should touch the ground
Letting hips sag or pike up during the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Master regular pushups and archer pushups before attempting single-arm
Place the free hand on an elevated surface at first if full single-arm is too difficult

instructions: Position a box in a rack. Secure a band or rope in place above the box.
Standing in front of it, step onto the box to a full standing position, letting your other leg remain unsupported. Hold onto the band for balance
. Continue stepping up and down on the same leg before switching to the opposite side.
exercises.name: Single-Leg High Box Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a high box in a rack with a band or rope above it for balance support
Stand in front of the box and grab the band/rope for support
Step up onto the box with one leg, bringing yourself to a full standing position on top
Keep your other leg unsupported throughout the movement
Step back down with control and repeat for reps before switching legs
form_cues: Think 'drive through your heel' on the working leg to power yourself up
Use the band just for balance, not to pull yourself up
Stand fully erect at the top - complete hip and knee extension
common_mistakes: Using the band to pull yourself up instead of the working leg doing the work
Not standing fully upright at the top, cutting range short
Letting the non-working leg touch the box for assistance
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a lower box height and progress gradually
Focus on controlled movement - don't bounce or use momentum

instructions: Seat yourself in the machine and adjust it so that you are positioned properly. The pad should be against the lower part of the shin but not in contact with the ankle. Adjust the seat so that the pivot point is in line with your knee. Select a weight appropriate for your abilities.
Maintaining good posture, fully extend one leg, pausing at the top of the motion.
Return to the starting position without letting the weight stop, keeping tension on the muscle.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Single-Leg Leg Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in the leg extension machine and adjust it so the pad rests on your lower shin, not your ankle
Adjust the seat so the pivot point aligns with your knee joint
Fully extend one leg, pausing briefly at the top with your quad contracted
Lower the weight back down with control without letting it fully rest on the stack
Complete all reps on one leg before switching to the other
form_cues: Think 'squeeze your quad at the top' like you're trying to make it pop
Control both directions - don't let the weight drop back down
Keep your back against the pad and grip the handles for stability
common_mistakes: Using momentum by swinging the leg instead of controlled extension
Not fully extending at the top, missing the quad contraction
Letting the weight rest between reps, losing constant tension
injury_prevention_tips: Single-leg is harder than bilateral - start with lighter weight than you'd use for both legs
Keep movements smooth - jerking can stress the knee joint

instructions: With a wide stance, hold a dumbell with both hands, grasping the head of the dumbbell instead of the handle. Your arms should be extended and hanging at the waist. This will be your starting position.
Raise the weight until it is above shoulder level, keeping your arms extended. Your torso and hips should remain stationary throughout the movement.
Return to the starting position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Single Dumbbell Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with a wide stance holding one dumbbell with both hands, gripping the head (top) of the dumbbell
Start with arms extended and the dumbbell hanging at waist level
Raise the dumbbell straight up until it's above shoulder level, keeping your arms extended throughout
Keep your torso and hips stationary - no leaning or swinging
Lower the dumbbell back to waist level with control and repeat
form_cues: Think 'hands stay together, arms stay straight' - lift like a pendulum
Your torso is a statue - all movement comes from your shoulders
Stop above shoulder level, not overhead - this targets front delts
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows during the lift instead of keeping arms extended
Swinging or using hip momentum instead of strict shoulder work
Leaning back to help lift the weight
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you think - extended arms create long leverage
Stop at or slightly above shoulder height to avoid excessive shoulder strain

instructions: Lay on the floor with your feet flat and knees bent.
Raise one leg off of the ground, pulling the knee to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by driving through the heel, extending your hip upward and raising your glutes off of the ground.
Extend as far as possible, pause and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Single Leg Glute Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with both feet flat on the floor, knees bent
Raise one leg off the ground and pull that knee toward your chest
Drive through the heel of your planted foot to lift your hips off the ground
Raise your hips as high as possible, squeezing your glute at the top
Pause briefly, then lower back down with control and repeat before switching legs
form_cues: Think about pushing your heel through the floor to engage your glute
Imagine trying to leave a butt print on the ceiling - squeeze hard at the top
Keep your core braced to prevent arching your lower back excessively
Drive your hips straight up, not forward or back - maintain a straight line from knee to shoulder
common_mistakes: Pushing through your toes instead of your heel which shifts work to quads
Arching your lower back at the top instead of using glute power
Not raising your hips high enough - go until your body is in a straight line
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back from hyperextension
If you feel cramping in your hamstring, focus more on the glute squeeze

exercises.description: Sit-up performed in the traditional manner
instructions: Lie down on the floor placing your feet either under something that will not move or by having a partner hold them. Your legs should be bent at the knees.
Place your hands behind your head and lock them together by clasping your fingers. This is the starting position.
Elevate your upper body so that it creates an imaginary V-shape with your thighs. Breathe out when performing this part of the exercise.
Once you feel the contraction for a second, lower your upper body back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat and secured (under something or held by a partner)
Place your hands behind your head with fingers interlaced
Raise your upper body off the floor, curling up until your torso forms a V-shape with your thighs
Pause for one second at the top while squeezing your abs
Lower back down to the starting position with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about curling your ribcage toward your pelvis, not just sitting straight up
Imagine you're rolling up like a carpet - segment by segment
Keep your chin slightly tucked - there should be a fist-sized space between chin and chest
Exhale forcefully as you curl up to maximize ab contraction
common_mistakes: Pulling on your head with your hands which strains the neck
Using momentum to swing up instead of controlled ab contraction
Letting your feet lift off the ground which reduces ab engagement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your hands behind your head for support only - never pull on your neck
If you feel neck strain, cross your arms over your chest instead

instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue until you have squatted a portion of the way down, but are above parallel, and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. Repeat for 5-10 repetitions.
exercises.name: Sit Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, arms at your sides or extended forward for balance
Begin lowering down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back
Descend about halfway down (stopping well above parallel)
Immediately and explosively reverse direction, standing back up quickly
Repeat for 5-10 dynamic reps, building a rhythm
form_cues: Think about 'sitting back' into a chair that's slightly too high
Imagine a spring coiling as you go down, then explosively releasing
Keep your chest up and core braced throughout the movement
This is a dynamic warm-up - move with controlled speed, not slow motion
common_mistakes: Going too deep instead of stopping above parallel as intended
Moving too slowly - this should be dynamic and rhythmic
Letting your knees cave inward instead of tracking over your toes
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your weight distributed through your whole foot - don't rise onto your toes
Start with smaller range of motion and gradually increase as you warm up

instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled connected by a rope or chain. Load the sled to a light weight.
Face the sled, backing up until there is some tension in the line. Hold your hands directly above your head with your elbows extended. This will be your starting position.
Walk backwards, keeping your arms raised above your head. Avoid jerky movements.
exercises.name: Sled Overhead Backward Walk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled via rope or chain, load it with light weight
Face the sled and back up until there's tension in the line
Hold the handles directly overhead with arms fully extended
Walk backward smoothly, keeping your arms locked overhead
Maintain steady, controlled steps - avoid jerky movements
form_cues: Think about keeping your arms 'locked out' overhead like supporting a ceiling
Imagine balancing a tray on your hands - keep them steady and level
Take smooth, deliberate steps backward - feel the terrain with your feet
Keep your core braced tight to stabilize your torso and arms
common_mistakes: Letting your arms drift forward or back instead of staying directly overhead
Taking jerky, uncontrolled steps which destabilizes the load
Arching your lower back excessively - maintain neutral spine
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight to master the movement pattern
Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back from the overhead load

instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled using a chain or rope. Load the sled to an appropriate load.

Facing away from the sled, step away until there is tension in the line. Raise your hands above your head, keeping them together, palms facing each other. Your elbows should be pointed upward with the elbows flexed. This will be your starting position.
Extend through the elbow to straighten the arm. Ensure that your upper arm stays in position to isolate the triceps.
Upon full extension, step forward to take the slack out of the line. You may keep your feet staggered for more stability.
exercises.name: Sled Overhead Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled, load appropriately, and face away from it
Step forward until there's tension, then raise both hands overhead with elbows bent and pointed up
Your hands should be close together above your head with elbows flexed
Extend your arms by straightening at the elbows only, keeping upper arms stationary
Once fully extended, step forward to take up slack and repeat
form_cues: Think about your upper arms being bolted in place - only your forearms move
Imagine pushing your hands straight up toward the sky
Keep your elbows pointed forward and up, not flaring out to the sides
Squeeze your triceps hard at full lockout before stepping forward
common_mistakes: Letting your upper arms drift forward as you extend, reducing tricep isolation
Stepping forward before achieving full elbow lockout
Allowing your elbows to flare out wide instead of staying close together
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to prevent arching your lower back
Maintain strict upper arm position to isolate triceps and protect shoulder

instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled connected by a rope or chain. Load the sled to a light weight.

Face the sled, backing up until there is some tension in the line. Take both handles at arms length at about waist level. Bend the knees slightly and keep your chest and head up. This will be your starting position.
Without flexing the elbow, pull the handles upward and apart, performing a reverse fly with some external rotation. Your palms should be facing forward as you do this.
Return to the starting position, taking a couple steps back to take the slack out of the line.
exercises.name: Sled Reverse Flye
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled with rope/chain, load lightly, and face the sled
Back up until there's tension, holding handles at waist level with arms extended
Bend your knees slightly, keep chest and head up
Pull the handles upward and apart in a reverse fly motion, rotating palms to face forward
Return to start and take a couple steps back to reset tension
form_cues: Think about leading with your elbows, pulling them up and back
Imagine you're trying to squeeze a pencil between your shoulder blades
As you pull, rotate your hands so your palms face forward - like opening a book
Keep your arms relatively straight - this is a fly, not a row
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows too much and turning it into a rowing motion
Not externally rotating your palms as you pull
Using your lower back to help pull instead of isolating rear delts
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your chest up and back flat to avoid lower back strain
Use light weight - rear delts are small muscles that fatigue quickly

instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled connected by a rope or chain. Load the sled to an appropriate weight. Face the sled, backing up until there is some tension in the line.
With a handle in each hand, bend the knees slightly, keep your head and chest up, and begin with your arms extended.
To initiate the movement, flex the elbow as you retract your shoulder blades, pulling the sled towards you.
Take a step or two back to get tension in the line and repeat.
exercises.name: Sled Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled, load appropriately, and face the sled
Back up until there's tension, holding a handle in each hand with arms extended
Bend your knees slightly, keep head and chest up
Pull the sled toward you by bending your elbows and retracting your shoulder blades
Take a step or two backward to reset tension and repeat
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows straight back toward your back pockets
Imagine trying to touch your elbows together behind your back
Keep your chest proud and up like a superhero throughout
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of each pull
common_mistakes: Rounding your back or hunching forward as you pull
Using your arms to curl the weight instead of pulling with your back
Not fully retracting your shoulder blades at the end of the pull
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain a neutral spine throughout - never round your lower back
Keep your core braced to protect your back under load

instructions: Place an incline bench underneath the smith machine. Place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the incline bench and make sure your shoulders are aligned right under the barbell.
Using a shoulder width pronated (palms forward) grip, lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with a slight bend at the elbows. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe out, lift the bar up until your arms are fully extended. Note: The contraction should be felt around the shoulders.
After a second pause, bring the bar back down to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Smith Incline Shoulder Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set an incline bench under a Smith machine, position the bar at near-full arm extension height
Lie on the bench with shoulders aligned under the bar, using a shoulder-width overhand grip
Unrack the bar and hold it straight above you with a slight elbow bend
Lower the bar to just above your upper chest with control
Press the bar back up until your arms are fully extended, squeezing your shoulders
form_cues: Think about pressing the bar up toward the ceiling, not back toward your face
Imagine your shoulders doing most of the work, not your chest or triceps
Keep a consistent slight bend in your elbows - don't lock them out completely
Focus on feeling the contraction in your front and side delts
common_mistakes: Pressing with your chest instead of isolating the shoulders
Locking out your elbows completely which reduces shoulder tension
Arching your back off the bench to help press the weight
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back pressed against the bench throughout
Use lighter weight than you would for chest press - this targets shoulders

instructions: With the bar at thigh level, load an appropriate weight.

Stand with the bar behind you, taking a shoulder-width, pronated grip on the bar and unhook the weight. You should be standing up straight with your head and chest up and your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by shrugging your shoulders straight up. Do not flex the arms or wrist during the movement.
After a brief pause return the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before engaging the hooks to rack the weight.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Behind the Back Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the Smith machine bar at thigh level and load appropriate weight
Stand with the bar behind you, take a shoulder-width overhand grip and unrack it
Stand upright with arms fully extended and the bar resting against your glutes
Shrug your shoulders straight up as high as possible without bending your arms
Pause briefly at the top, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Think about trying to touch your shoulders to your ears
Imagine lifting your shoulders straight up, not rolling them forward or back
Keep your arms completely straight like locked steel rods
Squeeze your traps hard at the top of the shrug for maximum contraction
common_mistakes: Rolling your shoulders in a circular motion instead of straight up and down
Bending your arms or wrists during the movement
Using momentum to bounce the weight instead of controlled shrugging
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement strictly vertical - no rotation or rolling
Don't overload the weight - focus on full range of motion and contraction

instructions: Place a flat bench underneath the smith machine. Now place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the flat bench. Using a pronated grip that is wider than shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, lock the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a flat bench under the Smith machine, set the bar at near-full arm extension height when lying down
Lie on the bench and grip the bar wider than shoulder-width with an overhand grip
Unrack the bar and hold it straight above your chest with arms locked
Lower the bar slowly to your mid-chest while inhaling
Press the bar back up explosively using your chest muscles, exhaling and locking out at the top
form_cues: Think about pushing the bar away from your chest, not just up
Imagine trying to bend the bar in your hands to create tension
Lower slowly - it should take twice as long to lower as to press up
Squeeze your chest hard at the top like you're giving a massive bear hug
common_mistakes: Bouncing the bar off your chest instead of controlled touch
Not lowering the bar all the way to your chest - use full range of motion
Pressing too fast on the way up and too slow on the way down (should be opposite)
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your feet flat on the floor and maintain a slight arch in your lower back
Don't lift your head or glutes off the bench during the press

instructions: Set the barbell attached to the smith machine to a height that is about 2 inches below your knees.
Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up.

Now grasp the barbell using an overhand (pronated) grip and unlock it from the smith machine rack. Then let it hang directly in front of you as your arms hang extended perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the barbell as you breathe out, keeping the elbows close to the body and not doing any force with the forearm other than holding the weights. On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Bent Over Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the Smith machine bar to about 2 inches below knee height
Bend at the waist with knees slightly bent, back straight and nearly parallel to the floor, head up
Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, unlock it and let it hang with arms fully extended
Pull the bar toward your lower chest, keeping elbows close to your body and squeezing back muscles at the top
Lower the bar with control back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'elbows to ceiling' - drive them up and back, not out to the sides
Keep your torso angle constant - no rocking or cheating
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like you're pinching a pencil
common_mistakes: Rocking the torso up and down instead of keeping it stationary
Pulling with arms instead of driving with the back
Using too much weight and losing the strict form
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back flat or slightly arched throughout - never round under load
The Smith machine fixed path is helpful but still requires core stability

instructions: Place a block or weight plate below the bar on the Smith machine. Set the bar to a position that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step onto the plates with the balls of your feet and place the bar on the back of your shoulders.
Take the bar with both hands facing forward. Rotate the bar to unrack it. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as high as possible by pushing off of the balls of your feet, flexing your calf at the top of the contraction. Your knees should remain extended. Hold the contracted position for a second before you start to go back down.
Return slowly to the starting position as you breathe in while lowering your heels.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a block or plate under the Smith machine bar, set bar to appropriate height
Step onto the block with balls of feet, position bar on back of shoulders and unrack
Rise up on your toes as high as possible, flexing your calves hard at the top, knees extended
Hold the peak contraction for one second
Lower your heels back down slowly until you feel a full stretch in your calves
form_cues: Think 'heels to floor, toes to ceiling' - maximize range at both ends
At the top, squeeze like you're trying to make your calves pop
Keep knees locked but not hyperextended throughout
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of controlled stretch and contraction
Bending knees during the movement which reduces calf isolation
Not going through full range - missing either the deep stretch or peak contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Control the descent - don't let your heels drop suddenly
Start with lighter weight than you think - the Smith machine adds stability allowing heavier loads

instructions: Place a flat bench underneath the smith machine. Place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the flat bench. Using a close and pronated grip (palms facing forward) that is around shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest. Tip: Make sure that as opposed to a regular bench press, you keep the elbows close to the torso at all times in order to maximize triceps involvement.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your triceps muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, lock the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Close-Grip Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench under the Smith machine with bar at arm's length height
Grab the bar with a close grip (around shoulder width), palms forward, and unrack
Lower the bar slowly to your mid-chest, keeping elbows tucked close to your sides
Pause briefly when the bar touches your chest
Press the bar back up explosively using your triceps, lock out arms and hold for one second
form_cues: Think 'elbows glued to ribs' - this is key for tricep emphasis vs chest
Lower twice as slow as you press up - controlled eccentric is critical
Press straight up, not toward your face or feet
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out wide, turning it into a chest press instead of triceps
Going too fast on the descent, missing the controlled eccentric
Using grip too narrow, which can stress wrists and elbows
injury_prevention_tips: Keep elbows tucked throughout - flaring stresses the shoulder joints
Shoulder-width grip is ideal - narrower can cause wrist pain

instructions: Position a decline bench in the rack so that the bar will be above your chest. Load an appropriate weight and take your place on the bench.
Rotate the bar to unhook it from the rack and fully extend your arms. Your back should be slightly arched and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your arms, lowering the bar to your chest.
Pause briefly, and then extend your arms to push the weight back to the starting position.
After completing the desired number of repetitions, rotate the bar to rack the weight.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Decline Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a decline bench under the Smith machine so the bar is above your chest
Lie on the bench, unrack the bar and fully extend arms with shoulder blades retracted and back slightly arched
Lower the bar to your lower chest by bending your arms
Pause briefly when the bar touches your chest
Press the bar back up to full arm extension, then re-rack after completing your set
form_cues: Think 'drive the bar away from your chest' - explosive pressing motion
Keep shoulder blades pinched together throughout - don't let them protract
Bar should touch your lower chest, not upper chest or neck
common_mistakes: Letting shoulder blades come apart (protract) during the press
Bouncing the bar off the chest instead of pausing briefly
Not maintaining the back arch and shoulder retraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep feet securely locked in the decline bench supports
Maintain shoulder blade retraction to protect your shoulder joints

instructions: Position the bar at knee height and load it to an appropriate weight.

Take a pronated grip on the bar outside of shoulder width and unhook the bar from the machine. Your arms should be fully extended with your head and chest up. Your elbows should be pointed out with your shoulders back and down. Your hips should be back, loading the tension into the hamstrings. This will be your starting position.
Initate the movement by forcefully extending the hips and knees, accelerating into the bar. Ensure that you keep your arms straight during this part of the motion.
Upon full extension, rebend the hips and knees to lower your receiving position.
Allow the arms to flex at this point, rotating the elbows around the bar to receive it on your shoulders.
Extend through the hips and knees to come to a standing position with the bar racked on your shoulders to complete the movement.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Hang Power Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bar at knee height, grab it with overhand grip outside shoulder width and unrack
Start with arms straight, chest up, shoulders back, hips loaded back with tension in hamstrings
Explosively extend hips and knees simultaneously, driving up with your legs - keep arms straight
As you reach full extension, quickly drop under the bar by rebending hips and knees
Rotate elbows around and under the bar to catch it on your shoulders, then stand fully upright
form_cues: Think 'jump and drop' - explosive leg drive then quickly get under the bar
Arms stay straight until full extension, then whip elbows around fast
Catch the bar on your shoulders with elbows pointing forward
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms too early instead of keeping them straight during the initial drive
Not extending fully before dropping under the bar
Slow elbow rotation - you need to whip them around quickly to catch properly
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the explosive timing and elbow rotation
Keep your back neutral throughout - no rounding under load

instructions: Position a bench in the rack and load the bar to an appropriate weight. Lie down on the bench, placing the bottom of your feet against the bar. Unlock the bar and extend your legs. You may need to use your hands to assist you. For added stability grasp the sides of the Smith Machine. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by rotating your pelvis, flexing your spine to raise your hips off of the bench. Maintain a slight bend in the knees throughout the motion.
After a brief pause, return the hips to the bench.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Hip Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a bench under the Smith machine bar, lie down and place the bottom of your feet against the bar
Unrack the bar by extending your legs (use hands to help if needed), grasp the sides of the machine for stability
Rotate your pelvis and flex your spine to lift your hips off the bench, keeping a slight knee bend
Pause briefly at the top with hips elevated
Lower your hips back to the bench with control
form_cues: Think 'curl your tailbone to your chest' - it's a pelvic tilt, not a leg press
Abs do the work - you're crunching your lower body toward your upper body
Keep constant tension - don't rest hips fully on the bench between reps
common_mistakes: Using legs to press the bar instead of abs pulling the hips up
Not maintaining the slight knee bend, turning it into a leg press
Resting completely between reps instead of maintaining ab tension
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - this is harder than it looks and easy to use too much weight
Keep movements controlled - don't let momentum take over

instructions: Place an incline bench underneath the smith machine. Place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the incline bench and make sure your upper chest is aligned with the barbell. Using a pronated grip (palms facing forward) that is wider than shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your upper chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Incline Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set an incline bench under the Smith machine with bar at arm's length height when lying down
Lie on the bench aligning your upper chest with the bar, grab with a wide pronated grip and unrack
Lower the bar slowly to your upper chest
Pause for one second at the bottom
Press the bar back up using your chest muscles, lock arms out and hold briefly before the next rep
form_cues: Think 'upper chest to bar' - the incline targets your upper pecs
Take twice as long lowering as pressing - slow eccentric builds strength
Drive through your feet and keep your butt on the bench throughout
common_mistakes: Lowering the bar to mid or lower chest instead of upper chest
Arching back excessively to help lift the weight
Pressing too fast without controlling the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulders retracted and pressed into the bench
Don't use excessive weight - the incline angle reduces your pressing strength

instructions: Position a Smith machine bar a couple feet off of the ground. Ensure that it is resting on the safeties. After loading the bar to an appropriate weight, lie underneath the bar. Place the middle of your feet on the bar, tucking your knees to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by driving through your feet to move the bar upward, extending the hips and knees. Do not lock out your knees.
At the top of the motion, pause briefly before returning to the starting position.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Leg Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set Smith machine bar a couple feet off the ground on the safeties, load appropriate weight
Lie underneath with the middle of your feet on the bar, knees tucked to chest
Drive through your feet to extend your hips and knees, pressing the bar up
Stop just before locking out your knees at the top
Pause briefly, then lower back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'push through your heels' not your toes
Don't lock out knees at the top - keep a micro-bend to maintain tension
Control both directions - don't let the weight crash down
common_mistakes: Locking knees fully at the top, which removes tension and stresses joints
Letting lower back round or lift off the ground
Using too much range by bringing knees too close to chest on the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back pressed to the ground throughout
Stop before your lower back starts to round at the bottom of the movement

instructions: With the bar at thigh level, load an appropriate weight.

Take a wide grip on the bar and unhook the weight, removing your off hand from the bar. Your arm should be extended as you stand up straight with your head and chest up. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the elbow, raising the upper arm with the elbow pointed out. Continue until your upper arm is parallel to the floor.
After a brief pause, return the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before engaging the hooks to rack the weight.
exercises.name: Smith Machine One-Arm Upright Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bar at thigh level, take a wide grip with one hand and unrack, removing your other hand
Stand upright with working arm fully extended at your side
Pull the bar up by bending your elbow and raising your upper arm until your upper arm is parallel to the floor
Keep your elbow pointed out to the side throughout the movement
Pause briefly at the top, then lower back to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'elbow leads the way' - drive it up and out to the side
Your elbow should be level with or slightly above your wrist at the top
Stand tall - don't lean to help lift the weight
common_mistakes: Raising the bar too high, above shoulder level, which can impinge the shoulder
Leaning or twisting instead of keeping torso upright and stable
Pulling straight up instead of out to the side with the elbow
injury_prevention_tips: Stop when upper arm is parallel to floor - going higher can cause shoulder impingement
Use lighter weight than bilateral upright rows - single-arm requires more stability

instructions: To begin, place a flat bench (or preferably one with back support) underneath a smith machine. Position the barbell at a height so that when seated on the flat bench, the arms must be almost fully extended to reach the barbell.

Once you have the correct height, sit slightly in behind the barbell so that there is an imaginary straight line from the tip of your nose to the barbell. Your feet should be stationary. Grab the barbell with the palms facing forward, unlock it and lift it up so that your arms are fully extended. This is the starting position.
Slowly begin to lower the barbell until it is level with your chin while inhaling.
Then lift the barbell back to the starting position using your shoulders while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Overhead Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust bench to upright position under Smith machine, sit with bar at upper chest height
Grab the bar with a pronated grip wider than shoulders, unrack and position at upper chest
Press the bar straight up overhead until arms are fully extended
Pause briefly at the top with arms locked out
Lower the bar with control back to upper chest level
form_cues: Think 'press straight up' - the bar path should be vertical
Drive through your shoulders like you're trying to push through the ceiling
Keep your core braced and back supported against the bench
common_mistakes: Pressing forward instead of straight up, which reduces shoulder activation
Arching the back excessively to help lift the weight
Not lowering all the way to upper chest, cutting range short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back firmly against the bench pad to protect your lower back
The Smith machine guides the bar path, but you still need stable shoulder positioning

instructions: To begin, first set the bar to a position that best matches your height. Step under it and position the bar across the back of your shoulders.
Take the bar with your hands facing forward, unlock it and lift it off the rack by extending your legs. 3

Move one foot forward about 12 inches in front of the bar. Extend the other leg out in front of you, holding it off the ground. Look forward at all times and maintain a neutral or slightly arched spine. This will be your starting position.
Maintaining good posture, lower yourself by flexing the knee and hip, going down as far as flexibility allows.
Pause briefly at the bottom and then return to the starting position by driving through the heel of your foot, extending the knee and hip.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Pistol Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the Smith machine bar to appropriate height and position it across your upper back
Unrack the bar and move one foot forward about 12 inches in front of the bar
Extend your other leg straight out in front of you, holding it off the ground
Lower yourself by bending the knee and hip of your planted leg, going as deep as flexibility allows
Drive through your heel to return to the starting position, then repeat before switching legs
form_cues: Think about sitting back and down, keeping your chest up throughout
Imagine balancing on one leg while keeping the other leg straight like a tightrope walker
Drive through your heel like you're pushing the floor through the basement
Keep your extended leg active and engaged - don't let it drop
common_mistakes: Letting your knee cave inward instead of tracking over your toes
Rounding your back as you descend - maintain neutral spine
Not going deep enough - use your full available range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your knee tracking in line with your toes throughout the movement
Build strength with regular squats and split squats before attempting pistol squats

instructions: Adjust the barbell on the smith machine to fit your height and align a raised platform right under the bar.
Stand on the platform with the heels of your feet secured on top of it with the balls of your feet extending off it. Position your toes facing forward with a shoulder width stance.

Now, place your shoulders under the barbell while maintaining the foot positioning described and push the barbell up by extending your hips and knees until your torso is standing erect. The knees should be kept with a slight bend; never locked. This will be your starting position. Tip: The barbell on your back is only for balance purposes.

Raise the balls of your feet as you breathe out by extending your toes as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position for a second before you start to go back down.
Slowly go back down to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering the balls of your feet and toes.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Reverse Calf Raises
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the bar on the Smith machine and position a raised platform directly underneath it
Stand on the platform with your heels secured on top, balls of feet and toes hanging off the edge
Position the bar across your upper back, unrack it, and stand erect with knees slightly bent
Raise the balls of your feet by extending your toes as high as possible, flexing your calves
Hold for one second at the top, then slowly lower back down to the starting position
form_cues: Think about rising up onto your tiptoes as high as you possibly can
Imagine trying to reach the ceiling with the tops of your feet
Keep your knees slightly bent and stationary throughout - they never move
Squeeze your calves at the top like you're flexing them for a photo
common_mistakes: Bending or straightening your knees during the movement
Not going through full range - rise as high as possible on your toes
Bouncing at the bottom instead of controlled, smooth movement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep knees slightly bent but locked in that position - never fully extend
Start with light weight to avoid Achilles tendon strain

instructions: To begin, first set the bar on the height that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side (palms facing forward), unlock it and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the bar to appropriate height on the Smith machine and position it across your upper back
Unrack the bar by extending your legs and straightening your torso
Position feet shoulder-width apart with toes slightly pointed out, head up, back straight
Lower by bending your knees until your thighs are just below parallel to the floor
Drive through your heels to raise the bar back to starting position
form_cues: Think about sitting back into a chair, not just bending your knees
Imagine spreading the floor apart with your feet as you drive up
Keep your chest proud and up like a superhero throughout the movement
Your knees should stay over your toes - create an imaginary vertical line
common_mistakes: Letting your knees travel too far forward past your toes
Rounding your back or looking down instead of maintaining neutral spine
Not going deep enough - break parallel for full range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout to protect your lower back
Ensure knees track in line with toes - never let them collapse inward

instructions: To begin, set the bar on the smith machine to a height that is around the middle of your thighs. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, grasp the bar using a pronated (palms forward) grip that is shoulder width apart. You may need some wrist wraps if using a significant amount of weight.

Lift the bar up by fully extending your arms while keeping your back straight. Stand with your torso straight and your legs spaced using a shoulder width or narrower stance. The knees should be slightly bent. This is your starting position.

Keeping the knees stationary, lower the barbell to over the top of your feet by bending at the waist while keeping your back straight. Keep moving forward as if you were going to pick something from the floor until you feel a stretch on the hamstrings. Exhale as you perform this movement

Start bringing your torso up straight again as soon as you feel the hamstrings stretch by extending your hips and waist until you are back at the starting position. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Stiff-Legged Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the Smith machine bar to mid-thigh height and grasp it with an overhand, shoulder-width grip
Unrack the bar and stand with legs shoulder-width or narrower, knees slightly bent
Lower the bar toward the floor by hinging at your hips, keeping your back straight
Continue until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then reverse the movement
Return to the starting position by extending your hips and straightening your torso
form_cues: Think about pushing your hips back like closing a car door with your butt
Imagine you're bowing forward while keeping your spine as stiff as a board
Keep the bar close to your legs - it should almost brush your shins and thighs
Feel the stretch in your hamstrings like a rubber band being pulled
common_mistakes: Rounding your back which puts dangerous stress on your spine
Bending your knees too much and turning it into a regular deadlift
Letting the bar drift away from your body instead of keeping it close
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back flat and neutral throughout - never round your spine
Start with light weight to master the hip hinge movement pattern

instructions: To begin, set the bar on the smith machine to a height that is around the middle of your thighs. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, grasp the bar using a pronated (palms forward) grip that is shoulder width apart. You may need some wrist wraps if using a significant amount of weight.
Lift the barbell up and fully extend your arms with your back straight. There should be a slight bend at the elbows. This is the starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the bar as you exhale. The bar should be close to the body as you move it up. Continue to lift it until it nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the bar, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Smith Machine Upright Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the Smith machine bar to mid-thigh height and grasp it with an overhand, shoulder-width grip
Unrack the bar and stand with arms fully extended, back straight, slight elbow bend
Lift the bar up close to your body by leading with your elbows
Continue until the bar nearly touches your chin, with elbows higher than forearms
Lower the bar back down slowly with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows up toward the ceiling, not the bar
Imagine you're zipping up a jacket from waist to chin
Keep the bar so close it almost brushes your torso as it travels up
Lead with your elbows - they should always be higher than your hands
common_mistakes: Pulling the bar too high above your chin which can impinge the shoulder
Letting the bar drift away from your body instead of keeping it close
Using momentum or swinging instead of controlled lifting
injury_prevention_tips: Stop when the bar reaches chin level - don't go higher to avoid shoulder impingement
Keep your torso stationary throughout the movement

instructions: To begin, place a flat bench 2-3 feet behind the smith machine. Then, set the bar on the height that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side (palms facing forward), unlock it and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.
Position your legs by placing one foot slightly forward under the bar and extending your other leg back and place the top of your foot on the bench. This will be your starting position

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knee as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calf becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knee should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knee is past that imaginary line (if it is past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten your leg again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: Smith Single-Leg Split Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a flat bench 2-3 feet behind the Smith machine and set the bar to appropriate height
Position the bar across your upper back, unrack it, and step forward
Place your rear foot on top of the bench behind you, front foot positioned under the bar
Lower by bending your front knee until your thigh is below parallel
Drive through your front heel to return to starting position, then repeat before switching legs
form_cues: Think about dropping your back knee straight down toward the floor
Imagine you're an elevator going straight down, not forward or back
Keep your front knee tracking over your toes throughout the movement
Drive through your front heel like you're pushing the floor away from you
common_mistakes: Letting your front knee travel too far forward past your toes
Leaning your torso too far forward instead of staying upright
Not going deep enough - your front thigh should be below parallel
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your front knee in line with your toes - never let it collapse inward
Start with bodyweight or light weight to master the balance before loading heavy

instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take a wide snatch grip. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the pull. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward.

There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back. Full extension should be violent and abrupt, and ensure that you do not prolong the extension for longer than necessary.
exercises.name: Snatch Pull
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with a barbell on the floor, take a wide snatch grip with hands well outside shoulder-width
Lower your hips with weight on heels, back straight, chest up, shoulders slightly in front of the bar
First pull: Drive through heels to extend knees, keeping back angle the same and arms straight
Second pull: As the bar reaches mid-thigh, explosively extend hips, knees, and ankles in a jumping motion
Finish fully extended and slightly leaning back - the bar should accelerate upward with speed
form_cues: Think about the first pull as pushing the floor away, not lifting the bar
Imagine exploding upward like you're jumping as high as possible during the second pull
Keep the bar close to your body throughout - it should brush your thighs
The second pull should be violent and abrupt - maximum speed and power
common_mistakes: Pulling with your arms too early instead of using leg and hip drive
Not being explosive enough in the second pull - this needs to be violent
Letting the bar drift away from your body during the pull
injury_prevention_tips: Master the movement pattern with light weight before adding serious load
Keep your back flat and core braced throughout to protect your spine

instructions: For this exercise anchor a band to the ground. We used an incline bench and anchored the band to the base, standing over the bench. Alternatively, this could be performed standing on the band.
To begin, pull the band behind your head, holding it with a pronated grip and your elbows up. This will be your starting position.
To perform the movement, extend through the elbow to to straighten your arms, ensuring that you keep your upper arm in place.
Pause, and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Speed Band Overhead Triceps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a resistance band to the ground (stand on it or attach to bench base)
Pull the band behind your head, holding it with an overhand grip and elbows pointing up
Start with elbows bent and hands behind your head
Extend through your elbows to straighten your arms overhead, keeping upper arms stationary
Pause briefly at full extension, then return to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about your upper arms being nailed in place - only your forearms move
Imagine pressing your hands straight up toward the ceiling
Keep your elbows pointing forward and up, not flaring out to the sides
Squeeze your triceps hard at full lockout
common_mistakes: Letting your upper arms drift forward as you extend
Moving too slowly - this should be performed with speed for power development
Allowing your elbows to flare out wide instead of staying close together
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to prevent arching your lower back
Maintain strict upper arm position throughout the movement

instructions: Attach bands to the bar that are securely anchored near the ground. You may need to choke the bands to get adequate tension.

Use a box of an appropriate height for this exercise. Load the bar to a weight that still requires effort, but isn't so heavy that speed is compromised. Typically, that will be between 50-70% of your one rep max.
Position the bar on your upper back, shoulder blades retracted, back arched and everything tight head to toe. This will be the starting position.
Unrack the bar and position yourself in front of the box. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box, ensuring that you descend under control and don't crash onto the surface.
Pause briefly, and explode off of the box, extending through the hips and knees.
exercises.name: Speed Box Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell with bands attached near the ground, on a box of appropriate height
Load the bar to 50-70% of your 1RM - enough to require effort but maintain speed
Position the bar on your upper back with shoulder blades retracted and everything tight
Sit back onto the box under control, descending smoothly without crashing
Pause briefly on the box, then explode up by extending hips and knees as fast as possible
form_cues: Think about sitting back aggressively, not just bending your knees
Imagine coiling a spring on the box, then releasing it with maximum force
Explode off the box like you're trying to jump through the ceiling
Keep everything tight - this is about speed and power, not relaxation
common_mistakes: Crashing onto the box instead of descending under control
Pausing too long on the box which kills the stretch reflex
Moving too slowly on the ascent - this should be explosive
injury_prevention_tips: Don't use too much weight - speed is the priority, not load
Maintain tight form throughout - don't let speed compromise technique

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

Begin to raise the bar as fast as possible without involving momentum as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position. Note: You should perform these exercises as fast as possible but without breaking perfect form and without involving momentum.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Speed Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell in a squat rack and position it across your upper back
Unrack the bar and position feet shoulder-width with toes slightly pointed out
Lower down until your thighs are below parallel, maintaining perfect form
Explode upward as fast as possible by driving through your heels
Focus on maximum speed while maintaining technique - no momentum or form breakdown
form_cues: Think about descending with control, then launching upward like a rocket
Imagine a spring coiling slowly, then releasing explosively
Keep your chest up and core braced throughout - speed doesn't mean sloppy
Drive through your heels like you're trying to push the floor through the basement
common_mistakes: Using too much weight which compromises speed - lighter is better
Breaking form for the sake of speed - technique must remain perfect
Using momentum or bouncing instead of controlled descent followed by explosive ascent
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter loads (50-70% 1RM) to prioritize speed over weight
Never sacrifice form for speed - maintain perfect technique throughout

instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand with a pronated grip. Your feet should be wide with your hips and knees extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by pulling both of the dumbbells to one side next to your hip, rotating your torso.
Keeping your arms straight and the dumbbells parallel to the ground, rotate your torso to swing the weights to your opposite side.
Continue alternating, rotating from one side to the other until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Spell Caster
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet wider than shoulders holding dumbbells at your sides with palms down, arms straight
Pull both dumbbells to your right hip by rotating your entire torso, keeping arms straight and parallel to the ground
Immediately swing both dumbbells across to your left hip, rotating your torso like you're casting a spell or swinging a bat
Keep the motion fluid and controlled - the dumbbells should stay parallel to the ground throughout
Continue rotating side to side in a rhythmic motion for your set
form_cues: Think 'swing a baseball bat' - your torso rotates powerfully while arms stay straight
Dumbbells stay parallel to the floor like you're carrying two trays
Your abs control the rotation - feel them working to decelerate and reverse direction
common_mistakes: Bending the arms instead of keeping them straight and locked
Using arms to swing instead of rotating from the core
Moving too fast without control, losing the mind-muscle connection with your abs
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout - don't let your lower back hyperextend
Use lighter weight than you think - the extended arms create long leverage

instructions: Begin in a prone position on the floor. Support your weight on your hands and toes, with your feet together and your body straight. Your arms should be bent to 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by raising one foot off of the ground. Externally rotate the leg and bring the knee toward your elbow, as far forward as possible.
Return this leg to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Spider Crawl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a low plank position with forearms on the ground, elbows bent 90 degrees, feet together
Lift your right foot off the ground and bring your right knee toward your right elbow as far forward as possible
Your knee should travel outside your body - think Spider-Man climbing a wall
Return your right foot to the starting position with control
Immediately repeat with your left leg, alternating sides for your set
form_cues: Think 'Spider-Man climbing' - your knee comes up and forward outside your body
Keep your hips level - don't let them rotate or sag as you bring your knee up
Drive your knee as far forward as possible - try to touch your elbow
common_mistakes: Letting hips sag or pike up instead of maintaining plank position
Not bringing knee far enough forward - aim for maximum range
Rotating the torso instead of keeping shoulders square to the ground
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core tight to prevent lower back sagging
Move deliberately - don't rush through the reps

instructions: Start out by setting the bar on the part of the preacher bench that you would normally sit on. Make sure to align the barbell properly so that it is balanced and will not fall off.

Move to the front side of the preacher bench (the part where the arms usually lay) and position yourself to lay at a 45 degree slant with your torso and stomach pressed against the front side of the preacher bench.
Make sure that your feet (especially the toes) are well positioned on the floor and place your upper arms on top of the pad located on the inside part of the preacher bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing up) at about shoulder width apart or slightly closer from each other.
Slowly begin to lift the barbell upwards and exhale. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the barbell back to the starting position as your breathe in. .
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Spider Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place an EZ curl bar on the seat of a preacher bench, then move to the front side
Lean face-down against the angled pad at 45 degrees with your stomach and chest pressed against it, toes planted firmly
Reach over the top of the pad and grab the bar with an underhand grip at shoulder width, arms fully extended
Curl the bar up toward your face by contracting your biceps, keeping your upper arms glued to the pad
Squeeze hard at the top for one second, then lower with control until arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think 'curl to your nose' - bring the bar straight up toward your face
Upper arms are welded to the pad - zero movement except at the elbows
Squeeze at the top like you're flexing for a photo - peak bicep contraction
common_mistakes: Peeling your upper arms or chest off the pad to help curl the weight
Not fully extending at the bottom, missing the complete stretch
Using momentum or swinging instead of pure bicep contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your feet firmly planted for stability - this prevents sliding
Control the negative - don't let the weight drop suddenly

instructions: Sit in a chair so your back is straight and your feet planted on the floor.
Interlace your fingers behind your head, elbows out and your chin down.
Twist your upper body to one side about 3 times as far as you can. Then lean forward and twist your torso to reach your elbow to the floor on the inside of your knee.
Return to upright position and then repeat for your other side.
exercises.name: Spinal Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright in a chair with feet flat on the floor, interlace your fingers behind your head with elbows out wide
Tuck your chin down toward your chest slightly
Rotate your upper body to the right as far as comfortable, pulsing three times to deepen the twist
From the twisted position, lean forward and try to touch your right elbow to the inside of your right knee
Return to upright, then repeat the entire sequence on your left side
form_cues: Think 'twist, twist, twist, then dive' - three pulses in the twist then lean forward
Keep your hips anchored - all rotation comes from your mid and upper back
As you lean forward, reach your elbow down toward the floor inside your knee
common_mistakes: Moving your hips instead of keeping them stationary and square
Forcing the stretch instead of easing into it gradually
Holding your breath - breathe deeply to enhance the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Move gently into the twist - don't jerk or force the rotation
Stop if you feel any sharp pain in your back or neck

instructions: Position yourself into a staggered stance with the rear foot elevated and front foot forward.
Hold a dumbbell in each hand, letting them hang at the sides. This will be your starting position.
Begin by descending, flexing your knee and hip to lower your body down. Maintain good posture througout the movement. Keep the front knee in line with the foot as you perform the exercise.
At the bottom of the movement, drive through the heel to extend the knee and hip to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Split Squat with Dumbbells
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand in a split stance with your rear foot elevated on a bench behind you, front foot flat on the ground
Hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides with arms straight - this is your starting position
Lower yourself down by bending your front knee and hip, keeping your torso upright and core tight
Descend until your front thigh is parallel to the ground or slightly below
Drive through your front heel to stand back up, extending your knee and hip to return to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'drop straight down' - your torso stays vertical like an elevator
Front knee tracks over your toes - don't let it cave inward
Drive through your heel like you're pushing the floor away
common_mistakes: Leaning forward excessively instead of staying upright
Letting the front knee collapse inward instead of tracking straight
Not going deep enough - aim for thigh parallel or below
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to protect your lower back
Don't let your front knee shoot forward past your toes excessively

instructions: Being in a standing position. Jump into a split leg position, with one leg forward and one leg back, flexing the knees and lowering your hips slightly as you do so.
As you descend, immediately reverse direction, standing back up and jumping, reversing the position of your legs. Repeat 5-10 times on each leg.
exercises.name: Split Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start standing with feet together, arms relaxed at your sides
Jump explosively into a split stance with one leg forward and one leg back, flexing both knees as you land
As soon as you land in the lunge position, immediately explode back up
While airborne, switch your leg positions - front leg goes back, back leg comes forward
Land softly in the opposite split stance and immediately repeat for 5-10 reps per leg
form_cues: Think 'split jump switch' - you're alternating which leg is in front each rep
Land softly on the balls of your feet with knees slightly bent to absorb impact
Use your arms for momentum - swing them naturally as you jump
common_mistakes: Landing stiff-legged instead of with a soft knee bend
Not jumping high enough to fully switch leg positions in the air
Pausing between reps instead of maintaining continuous explosive movement
injury_prevention_tips: Land with control - focus on soft, quiet landings
Start with smaller jumps and work up to more explosive heights

instructions: Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible. Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, and be sure to move your head out of the way as the bar leaves the shoulders.

At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible. In the brief moment the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athlete effort to push the bar up will drive them down. The feet should move forcefully to just outside the hips, turned out as necessary. Receive the bar with your body in a full squat and the arms fully extended overhead.
Keeping the bar aligned over the front of the heels, your head and chest up, drive throught heels of the feet to move to a standing position. Carefully return the weight to floor.
exercises.name: Squat Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start with the barbell racked on your front shoulders, feet hip-width, then perform a small dip by bending your knees slightly without moving hips back
Explosively drive through your heels to reverse direction powerfully, moving your head back as the bar leaves your shoulders
As your feet leave the floor, aggressively move them out wider than hips with toes turned out, simultaneously pushing yourself under the bar
Catch the bar overhead with arms locked out while dropping into a full squat position - you should be receiving the bar at the bottom
Stand up from the squat position while keeping the bar overhead and stable, then carefully return the weight
form_cues: Think 'dip, drive, drop, catch' - four distinct phases happening quickly
As you drive up, your feet go out and you go down under the bar simultaneously
Catch in a full squat with bar overhead - it's a squat catch, not standing
common_mistakes: Not driving explosively enough during the dip and drive phase
Moving feet too slowly - they need to snap into receiving position
Trying to catch the bar while standing instead of dropping into a full squat
injury_prevention_tips: Master power cleans and overhead squats separately before combining them
