Start with PVC pipe or empty bar to learn the timing and footwork

instructions: Set up the bands on the sleeves, secured to either band pegs, the rack, or dumbbells so that there is appropriate tension.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wide for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips as much as possible. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Lower bar position necessitates a greater torso lean to keep the bar over the heels. Continue until you break parallel, which is defined as the crease of the hip being in line with the top of the knee.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe, until you have returned to the starting position.
exercises.name: Squat with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up resistance bands attached to the barbell sleeves and secured to the rack or floor, creating tension at the top position
Step under the bar, place it on your upper traps, squeeze shoulder blades together and create a tight arch in your lower back
Unrack and step back, feet wide with toes slightly out, head forward and core braced
Initiate descent by pushing knees and butt out, sitting back with hips while keeping shins vertical, descend until hip crease is below knee level
Drive through your heels, push knees out, and explode upward leading with your head until you return to standing
form_cues: Think 'sit back into a chair' - hips go back, not knees forward
Bands make it harder at the top - fight to lock out completely and stand tall
Push your knees out hard - imagine spreading the floor apart with your feet
common_mistakes: Letting knees cave inward as bands pull them in - actively push them out
Not sitting back enough, resulting in knees traveling too far forward
Losing tightness at the top as bands pull you down - stay braced
injury_prevention_tips: Bands increase difficulty at lockout - reduce barbell weight accordingly
Keep your chest up and back tight throughout - don't round forward

instructions: To set up the chains, begin by looping the leader chain over the sleeves of the bar. The heavy chain should be attached using a snap hook. Adjust the length of the lead chain so that a few links are still on the floor at the top of the movement.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wide for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips as much as possible. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Lower bar position necessitates a greater torso lean to keep the bar over the heels. Continue until you break parallel, which is defined as the crease of the hip being in line with the top of the knee.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe, until you have returned to the starting position.
exercises.name: Squat with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach heavy chains to the barbell using lead chains and snap hooks, adjust so some links remain on floor at standing position
Step under the bar, position it across your upper back, squeeze shoulder blades and rotate elbows forward creating tension
Unrack with a tight lower back arch, step back into wide stance with toes slightly out, head facing forward
Push knees and butt out to begin descent, sit back with hips maximally, keeping shins vertical, descend until hip crease is below knee top
Drive through heels with knees pushed out, lead with your head and maintain head-to-toe tightness as you stand back up
form_cues: Think 'chains get lighter as you go down' - the bottom is easier, the top is harder
Sit back like you're reaching for a chair far behind you
Explode out of the hole - chains reward aggressive acceleration at the top
common_mistakes: Not sitting back enough, allowing knees to travel forward excessively
Decelerating at the top instead of accelerating through full lockout
Losing upper back tightness and letting the bar pull you forward
injury_prevention_tips: Chains add most resistance at lockout - reduce bar weight accordingly
Maintain rigid core throughout - chains create unique loading demands

instructions: To begin, first set the bar on a rack to just below shoulder level. Position a weight plate on the ground a couple feet back from the rack. Once the bar is loaded, step under it and place the back of your shoulders across it.
Hold on to the bar with both hands and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straighten your torso.
Step away from the rack and adopt a wide stance with the toes slightly pointed out, with one foot on the weight plate. Keep your head up at all times. This will be your starting position.
Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and hips. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees.
Raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heels of your feet as you extend the hips and knees.
At the top of the movement, side step, bringing your feet together on the opposite side of the plate.
Using your inside foot, push the weight plate, sliding it across the floor to where you were just standing.
Place your inside foot on the weight plate, adopting a wide stance for the next repetition.
exercises.name: Squat with Plate Movers
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell on a rack below shoulder height, place a weight plate on the floor a couple feet behind the rack
Step under the bar with it across your upper back, unrack it and step back, placing one foot on the weight plate in a wide stance
Descend into a squat by bending knees and hips until thighs are just below parallel to the ground
Drive through your heels to stand back up, then at the top, side-step to bring both feet together on the opposite side of the plate
Use your inside foot to push/slide the weight plate across the floor to where you were standing, then step onto the plate for the next rep
form_cues: Think 'squat, stand, step together, slide plate' - four distinct movements per rep
One foot stays on the plate for each squat - alternate which foot per rep
Slide the plate smoothly - don't kick it
common_mistakes: Moving the plate before fully completing the squat rep
Stepping too far laterally, making the plate slide difficult
Not maintaining squat depth consistency throughout the set
injury_prevention_tips: Use a smooth floor surface for plate sliding - avoid rough concrete
Keep your core braced during the lateral stepping and plate moving

instructions: To start out, make sure that the exercise band is at an even split between both the left and right side of the body. To do this, use your hands to grab both sides of the band and place both feet in the middle of the band. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.

When holding the bands, they should be the same height on each side. You should be using a pronated grip (palms facing forward) and have the handles of the bands next to your face for this exercise. This is the starting position.
Slowly start to bend the knees and lower the legs so that your thighs are parallel to the floor while exhaling.
Use the heel of your feet to push your body up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Squats - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on the middle of the band with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the handles at shoulder height with palms forward
Push your hips back like sitting into a chair, keeping your chest proud and weight in your heels
Lower until your thighs are parallel to the floor - imagine sitting down onto a low bench behind you
Drive through your heels to stand up, squeezing your glutes at the top like you're crushing a walnut between your cheeks
Keep tension in the band throughout - it should pull you forward, making you work harder to stay upright
form_cues: Push your knees out against an imaginary resistance band around them - keep them tracking over your toes
Chest up, eyes forward - imagine a string pulling your sternum toward the ceiling
Break at the hips first, not the knees - like you're reaching your butt back to touch a wall behind you
Feel the band trying to pull you forward and fight to keep your torso vertical
common_mistakes: Letting knees cave inward instead of pushing them out over the toes
Rounding the lower back by not engaging the core or breaking at the knees first
Rising onto the toes instead of keeping weight distributed through the whole foot
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout like someone's about to punch your stomach
Never let your knees shoot forward past your toes - the shin should stay relatively vertical

instructions: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand. Raise the dumbbells to your shoulders with your palms facing forward and your elbows pointed out. This will be your starting position.
Extend one arm to press the dumbbell straight up, keeping your off hand in place. Do not lean or jerk the weight during the movement.
After a brief pause, return the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the opposite side, continuing to alternate between arms.
exercises.name: Standing Alternating Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing forward and elbows out to the sides
Brace your core tight and keep your body completely still - imagine you're a statue from the waist down
Press one dumbbell straight up until your arm is fully extended, keeping the other dumbbell stationary at shoulder height
Lower the dumbbell back down with control to shoulder height, then immediately press the opposite side
Continue alternating sides, maintaining a steady rhythm without swaying or leaning
form_cues: Press the weight straight up like you're pushing through the ceiling, not forward or backward
Keep your ribs down and abs tight - don't arch your back or lean away from the weight
Think about pressing the weight up while simultaneously pressing your opposite foot into the ground for stability
Your torso should be rock solid - imagine balancing a glass of water on your head
common_mistakes: Leaning to the side or backward to help lift the weight instead of keeping the torso vertical
Using momentum by bouncing or jerking the weight up rather than a controlled press
Letting the non-working arm drift down from shoulder height
injury_prevention_tips: Don't go so heavy that you need to arch your back - if you're leaning, the weight is too heavy
Keep a slight bend in your knees to reduce stress on your lower back

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the bar on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck).
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. The knees should be kept with a slight bend; never locked. This will be your starting position. Tip: For better range of motion you may also place the ball of your feet on a wooden block but be careful as this option requires more balance and a sturdy block.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Barbell Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up the barbell on your upper traps in a squat rack, step back with feet shoulder-width apart and toes pointed slightly out
Start with your heels flat on the ground or on a raised block for extra range, keeping your knees slightly bent throughout
Rise up onto the balls of your feet as high as possible, like you're trying to reach something on a high shelf
Squeeze your calves hard at the top for one second - imagine pushing the ground away from you
Lower your heels back down slowly with control until you feel a deep stretch in your calves
form_cues: Push through the big toe and first two toes - that's where your calf power comes from
Think about making yourself as tall as possible at the top of each rep
Keep your ankles straight - don't let them roll in or out during the movement
Imagine your calves are springs compressing and exploding upward
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of controlling the eccentric and getting a full stretch
Bending the knees more during the raise, which turns it into a squat movement
Rushing the reps instead of focusing on the squeeze at the top and stretch at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your knees in a fixed, slightly bent position - never locked straight
Don't use a weight so heavy that your ankles wobble or you lose balance

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for easier pick up of the bar. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Your back should be kept straight while performing this exercise. This will be your starting position.
Elevate the barbell overhead by fully extending your arms while breathing out.
Hold the contraction for a second and lower the barbell back down to the starting position by inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Barbell Press Behind Neck
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the bar at shoulder height in a rack, position it on your upper traps behind your neck, then step back with feet shoulder-width apart
Keep your head in a neutral position looking straight ahead, with your core braced and back straight
Press the bar straight up overhead by extending your arms fully, moving your head slightly forward to clear the path
Pause briefly at the top with arms fully extended
Lower the bar back down with control to the starting position behind your neck
form_cues: Think about pressing the bar up and slightly forward so it travels in a straight vertical line
Keep your elbows pointed out to the sides, not flared back behind you
Squeeze your glutes and abs tight to prevent arching your lower back
Imagine pushing yourself away from the bar rather than pressing the bar away from you
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively to help press the weight up
Letting the bar drift too far behind the head instead of keeping it close to vertical
Using momentum by dipping with the legs instead of strict pressing
injury_prevention_tips: Only use this exercise if you have excellent shoulder mobility - if it feels uncomfortable, stick to front presses
Keep the weight moderate and never go to failure on this exercise due to the vulnerable shoulder position

instructions: With a dumbbell in one hand and the palm facing your torso, bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up.

The upper arm should be close to the torso and parallel to the floor while the forearm is pointing towards the floor as the hand holds the weight. Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearm and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to lift the weights as you exhale until the forearms are parallel to the floor and the whole arm is extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: Standing Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a dumbbell in one hand, hinge forward at the hips until your torso is almost parallel to the floor with your back flat
Position your upper arm parallel to the floor and close to your torso, with your forearm hanging straight down (90-degree angle at the elbow)
Keeping your upper arm completely still, extend your elbow to straighten your arm until the dumbbell is in line with your body
Squeeze your tricep hard at the top for one second - imagine flexing it like you're showing it off
Lower the dumbbell back down with control to the starting 90-degree position
form_cues: Lock your upper arm in place like it's glued to your side - only your forearm should move
Think about kicking the dumbbell straight back behind you, not up or down
Keep your back flat like a tabletop - imagine balancing a cup of water on your lower back
At full extension, your whole arm should form one straight line from shoulder to hand
common_mistakes: Letting the upper arm drop down or swing during the movement instead of keeping it stationary
Rounding the back or letting the torso rotate to help lift the weight
Not fully extending the arm at the top, cutting the range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to protect your lower back in the bent-over position
Use a lighter weight if you can't keep your upper arm still - this is an isolation movement

instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand and the palms facing your torso, bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up. The upper arms should be close to the torso and parallel to the floor while the forearms are pointing towards the floor as the hands hold the weights. Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearms and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to lift the weights as you exhale until the forearms are parallel to the floor and the whole arms are extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to their starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand, hinge forward at the hips until your torso is almost parallel to the floor with a flat back
Position both upper arms parallel to the floor and tucked close to your sides, forearms hanging straight down at 90 degrees
Keeping your upper arms locked in place, extend both elbows simultaneously to straighten your arms behind you
Squeeze both triceps hard at full extension for one second
Lower the dumbbells back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Pretend your upper arms are pinned against your sides with tape - they shouldn't move at all
Think about driving your knuckles straight back toward the wall behind you
Keep your back flat as a board - imagine wearing a stiff backpack that won't let you round
Feel the burn in the back of your arms as you squeeze at the top
common_mistakes: Using momentum by rocking the torso back and forth instead of isolating the triceps
Letting the elbows flare out to the sides instead of keeping them tucked close to the body
Not achieving full arm extension at the top of the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your core hard throughout to support your spine in the bent-over position
Keep a slight bend in your knees to take pressure off your lower back

instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a cable curl bar that is attached to a low pulley. Grab the cable bar at shoulder width and keep the elbows close to the torso. The palm of your hands should be facing up (supinated grip). This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the curl bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Biceps Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing the low pulley with feet shoulder-width apart, grab the bar with an underhand grip at shoulder width
Pin your elbows to your sides and keep them there throughout - imagine they're glued to your ribs
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders by bending at the elbows, squeezing your biceps hard
Pause at the top when your biceps are fully contracted - finish the movement like you're doing a double bicep pose
Lower the bar back down slowly and with control until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Keep your elbows locked in one spot beside your torso - they shouldn't move forward or backward
Think about bringing your pinky finger toward your shoulder to maximize the bicep squeeze
Your shoulders should stay down and back - don't let them round forward
Resist the cable on the way down - imagine slowly lowering something fragile
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drift forward during the curl, which takes tension off the biceps
Using momentum by swinging the torso or leaning back to help lift the weight
Dropping the weight quickly on the way down instead of controlling the eccentric
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists straight and neutral - don't bend them back or curl them forward
Maintain tension in your core to prevent your lower back from arching

instructions: Clasp your hands behind your back with your palms together, straighten arms and then rotate them so your palms face downward.
Raise your arms up and hold until you feel a stretch in your biceps.
exercises.name: Standing Biceps Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand up tall and clasp your hands together behind your back with your palms touching
Straighten both arms completely, then rotate your hands so your palms face down toward the floor
Slowly raise your clasped hands upward behind you as high as comfortable
Hold this position for 20-30 seconds while breathing normally, feeling the stretch across your biceps and chest
form_cues: Keep your chest lifted and shoulders pulled back - imagine pinching a pencil between your shoulder blades
Don't lean forward - stay upright with your ears over your shoulders
The stretch should be felt primarily in the front of your arms and across your chest
Breathe deeply and try to relax into the stretch rather than forcing it
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows instead of keeping the arms completely straight
Hunching the shoulders forward instead of keeping them back and down
Forcing the stretch too aggressively, which can strain the shoulder joint
injury_prevention_tips: Only raise your arms to a comfortable height - you should feel a stretch, not pain
Keep the movement slow and controlled, never jerking or bouncing

instructions: Place a loaded bar at shoulder level in a rack. With a pronated grip at shoulder width, begin with the bar racked across the front of your shoulders. This is your starting position.
Initiate the lift by extending the elbows to press the bar overhead. Avoid locking out the elbow as you move the weight behind your head.
Lower the bar down to the back of the head until your elbow forms a right angle.
Lift the bar back over your head by extending the elbows
Lower the bar down to the starting position.
Alternate in this manner until you complete the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Bradford Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start with the barbell racked across the front of your shoulders at shoulder height, using an overhand grip at shoulder width
Press the bar overhead but don't lock out - stop just before your elbows fully extend and bring the bar behind your head
Lower the bar down to the back of your head until your elbows form a 90-degree angle
Press the bar back up and over your head, again stopping before lockout
Lower the bar back down to the starting position in front of your shoulders, then repeat this front-to-back pattern
form_cues: Think of this as a continuous arc over your head - the bar never fully stops moving
Keep constant tension on your shoulders by never locking out your elbows
Your head should move slightly forward and back to make room for the bar path
Brace your core hard like you're about to take a punch to keep your torso stable
common_mistakes: Locking out the elbows at the top, which removes tension from the shoulders
Using too much weight and arching the lower back excessively to complete the reps
Moving too quickly instead of maintaining controlled, deliberate transitions
injury_prevention_tips: Use significantly lighter weight than your normal overhead press - this is a high-volume shoulder exercise
Only perform this if you have good shoulder mobility and no existing shoulder issues

instructions: Position dual pulleys to chest height and select an appropriate weight. Stand a foot or two in front of the cables, holding one in each hand. You can stagger your stance for better stability.
Position the upper arm at a 90 degree angle with the shoulder blades together. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the rest of the body stationary, extend through the elbows to press the handles forward, drawing them together in front of you.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Standing Cable Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set dual cable handles to chest height, grab one in each hand, and step forward a foot or two with a staggered stance for stability
Start with your arms bent at 90 degrees, elbows back, and shoulder blades squeezed together like you're pinching a pencil between them
Press both handles forward simultaneously, bringing them together in front of your chest until your arms are fully extended
Squeeze your chest hard at the peak contraction - imagine hugging a tree
Slowly return the handles back to the starting position with control, feeling the stretch across your chest
form_cues: Think about pushing the handles forward and slightly together, not just straight out
Keep your chest up and shoulders back throughout - don't let your shoulders round forward
Your torso should stay completely still - all the movement comes from your arms
Drive through your front foot to maintain stability as you press
common_mistakes: Letting the shoulders roll forward at the start, which reduces chest engagement
Using the body to rock or lean forward to help press the weight
Letting the cables pull your arms back too far, which can strain the shoulder joint
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core tight to prevent your lower back from arching during the press
Don't let your arms get pulled back beyond a comfortable stretch position at the start

instructions: Connect a standard handle on a tower, and move the cable to the lowest pulley position.

With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. Your outstretched arm should be aligned with the cable.
With your feet positioned shoulder width apart, squat down and grab the handle with both hands. Your arms should still be fully extended.
In one motion, pull the handle up and across your body until your arms are in a fully-extended position above your head.
Keep your back straight and your arms close to your body as you pivot your back foot and straighten your legs to get a full range of motion.
Retract your arms and then your body. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Standing Cable Lift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the cable to the lowest position with a standard handle, stand sideways to the tower and grab the handle with both hands
Step away to create tension, feet shoulder-width apart, squat down with arms fully extended toward the low pulley
In one explosive motion, pull the handle diagonally up and across your body until your arms are fully extended overhead
Keep your back straight and pivot your back foot as you straighten your legs for full range
Return to the squat position in a slow, controlled manner and repeat for reps, then switch sides
form_cues: Think 'sword unsheathing' - pull diagonally from low to high across your body
Rotate through your core as you lift - your abs drive the movement, not your arms
Pivot your back foot like you're throwing a baseball - full body rotation
common_mistakes: Bending arms instead of keeping them extended throughout
Not rotating torso enough, turning it into just an arm movement
Rising too fast without control on the way back down
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back straight throughout - don't round forward as you squat
Start with light weight to master the diagonal pulling pattern

instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and move the cable to the highest pulley position.

With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. Your outstretched arm should be aligned with the cable.
With your feet positioned shoulder width apart, reach upward with your other hand and grab the handle with both hands. Your arms should still be fully extended.
In one motion, pull the handle down and across your body to your front knee while rotating your torso.
Keep your back and arms straight and core tight while you pivot your back foot and bend your knees to get a full range of motion.
Maintain your stance and straight arms. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Standing Cable Wood Chop
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable to highest position, stand sideways to the tower and grab the handle overhead with both hands, arms extended
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, starting position is with arms reaching up toward the high pulley
Pull the handle down and across your body toward your opposite front knee while rotating your torso
Keep your arms straight and pivot your back foot while bending your knees to complete the chop motion
Return to the starting position with control, then repeat for reps before switching sides
form_cues: Think 'chopping wood' - powerful diagonal motion from high to low
Rotate from your core like you're swinging an axe - full torso engagement
Arms stay straight like you're holding a long pole - no bending at elbows
common_mistakes: Bending elbows during the movement instead of keeping arms locked
Not rotating torso enough, making it an arm-dominant movement
Standing too upright instead of bending knees for full range
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight to protect your lower back during rotation
Control the return to starting position - don't let the cable yank you back

exercises.description: Standing calf raise performed on a machine
instructions: Adjust the padded lever of the calf raise machine to fit your height.

Place your shoulders under the pads provided and position your toes facing forward (or using any of the two other positions described at the beginning of the chapter). The balls of your feet should be secured on top of the calf block with the heels extending off it. Push the lever up by extending your hips and knees until your torso is standing erect. The knees should be kept with a slight bend; never locked. Toes should be facing forward, outwards or inwards as described at the beginning of the chapter. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Machine Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the machine pads to your height, position your shoulders under the pads with balls of feet on the platform, heels off
Extend your hips and knees to unrack the weight, standing upright with a slight knee bend - never lock your knees
Rise up on your toes as high as possible, extending your ankles and flexing your calves hard
Hold the peak contraction for one second at the top
Lower your heels slowly until you feel a full stretch in your calves, then repeat
form_cues: Think 'tiptoes to ceiling' - rise as high as possible on the balls of your feet
At the top, squeeze like you're trying to make your calves pop
At the bottom, get a full stretch - heels below the level of your toes
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of controlled stretch and contraction
Bending knees during the movement which reduces calf isolation
Not achieving full range - missing either the stretch or the peak squeeze
injury_prevention_tips: Keep knees slightly bent but stationary throughout - never locked or bending
Lower slowly - don't let your heels drop suddenly

instructions: Taking a dumbbell in your working hand, lean forward. Allow your working arm to hang perpendicular to the ground with the elbow pointing out. This will be your starting position.
Flex the elbow to curl the weight, keeping the upper arm stationary. At the top of the repetition, flex the biceps and pause.
Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Concentration Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a dumbbell in one hand and lean forward at the waist, letting your working arm hang straight down
Your elbow should point outward with your upper arm perpendicular to the ground - this is the starting position
Curl the weight up by bending your elbow, keeping your upper arm completely still
At the top, squeeze your bicep hard and pause for one second
Lower the dumbbell back to full extension with control, then repeat for your set
form_cues: Think 'upper arm is frozen in space' - only your forearm moves
Lean forward enough that gravity pulls straight down on the dumbbell
Squeeze at the top like you're flexing for a photo
common_mistakes: Moving the upper arm forward or back instead of keeping it stationary
Not leaning forward enough, reducing the stretch at the bottom
Using momentum or swinging instead of controlled curling
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back neutral as you lean forward - don't round excessively
Control both the lifting and lowering phases equally

exercises.description: Standing calf raise performed with dumbbells
instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding two dumbbells in your hands by your sides. Place the ball of the foot on a sturdy and stable wooden board (that is around 2-3 inches tall) while your heels extend off and touch the floor. This will be your starting position.

With the toes pointing either straight (to hit all parts equally), inwards (for emphasis on the outer head) or outwards (for emphasis on the inner head), raise the heels off the floor as you exhale by contracting the calves. Hold the top contraction for a second.
As you inhale, go back to the starting position by slowly lowering the heels.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.
exercises.name: Standing Dumbbell Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold dumbbells at your sides, place the balls of your feet on a 2-3 inch elevated surface with heels hanging off
Start with your heels touching the floor or slightly below, maintaining an upright torso
Rise up on your toes as high as possible by contracting your calves, exhaling as you lift
Hold the top position for one second with calves fully flexed
Lower your heels back down slowly until you feel a full stretch, then repeat
form_cues: Think 'heels to floor, then toes to sky' - maximize the range at both ends
At the top, imagine you're trying to see over a tall fence - full calf contraction
Dumbbells hang at your sides like deadweight - don't use them for momentum
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom instead of pausing for the stretch
Not elevating high enough at the top to fully contract calves
Bending at the knees or hips instead of staying upright
injury_prevention_tips: Use a stable, secure platform - don't let it wobble or shift
Control the descent - resist the weight on the way down

instructions: Standing with your feet shoulder width apart, take a dumbbell in each hand. Raise the dumbbells to head height, the elbows out and about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Maintaining strict technique with no leg drive or leaning back, extend through the elbow to raise the weights together directly above your head.
Pause, and slowly return the weight to the starting position.
exercises.name: Standing Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding dumbbells at head height, elbows out at 90 degrees
Keep your torso upright and core braced - no leg drive or leaning back
Press both dumbbells straight up overhead by extending your elbows until arms are fully extended
Pause briefly at the top with dumbbells together above your head
Lower the weights slowly back to the starting position at head height with control
form_cues: Think 'press straight up like an elevator' - vertical path only
Your torso is a statue - strict form, zero body English
At the top, imagine trying to touch the ceiling with the dumbbells
common_mistakes: Leaning back to help press the weight instead of maintaining upright posture
Using leg drive by dipping down before pressing
Pressing the dumbbells forward instead of straight overhead
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight to protect your lower back
Don't use excessive weight that forces you to cheat the movement

instructions: To begin, stand straight with a dumbbell in each hand using a pronated grip (palms facing down). Your arms should be fully extended while your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Dumbbell Reverse Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing down (overhand grip)
Keep your upper arms stationary and pinned to your sides - this is your starting position
Curl the dumbbells up toward your shoulders by bending your elbows, keeping palms down throughout
Contract your biceps and forearms hard at the top, hold for one second
Lower the dumbbells back to full extension with control, maintaining the palms-down grip
form_cues: Think 'knuckles up' - palms stay facing the floor the entire time
Upper arms are glued to your sides - imagine holding a newspaper against your ribs
This works your forearms harder than regular curls - you'll feel the burn on top of your forearms
common_mistakes: Rotating palms to supinated (palms up) position during the curl
Letting elbows drift forward instead of keeping them pinned back
Using momentum by swinging instead of strict curling
injury_prevention_tips: Use significantly lighter weight than regular curls - this variation is harder
Keep your wrists neutral - don't let them bend backward or forward

instructions: Hold the dumbbells in front of your thighs, palms facing your thighs.
Keep your arms straight with a slight bend at the elbows but keep them locked. This will be your starting position.
Raise the dumbbells in a semicircular motion to arm's length overhead as you exhale.
Slowly return to the starting position using the same path as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Dumbbell Straight-Arm Front Delt Raise Above Head
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with dumbbells in front of your thighs, palms facing your legs, arms straight with a slight elbow bend
Lock your arms in this slightly bent position - they won't bend more during the movement
Raise the dumbbells in a wide arc motion straight out in front and all the way overhead
At the top, your arms should be fully extended above your head
Lower back down along the same arc path with control until dumbbells return to your thighs
form_cues: Think 'rainbow arc' - wide semicircular path from thighs to overhead
Arms are locked in a slightly bent position like you're holding two big beach balls
Lead with your knuckles - they trace the arc path
common_mistakes: Bending elbows more during the lift instead of keeping arms locked
Using momentum or swinging instead of controlled raising
Not going all the way overhead, stopping at shoulder height
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight - the extended arms and overhead range create long leverage
Keep your core tight to avoid arching your back excessively

instructions: To begin, stand up with a dumbbell held by both hands. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart from each other. Slowly use both hands to grab the dumbbell and lift it over your head until both arms are fully extended.
The resistance should be resting in the palms of your hands with your thumbs around it. The palm of the hands should be facing up towards the ceiling. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head with elbows in and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the dumbbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold one dumbbell with both hands and lift it overhead to full arm extension
The dumbbell should rest in your palms with thumbs around it, palms facing up
Keep your upper arms close to your head with elbows pointing up - this is the starting position
Lower the dumbbell behind your head in a semicircular motion until your forearms touch your biceps
Drive the weight back up using your triceps until arms are fully extended overhead again
form_cues: Think 'elbows to ears' - keep them close to your head and pointing straight up
Upper arms are frozen - only your forearms move like a hinge
Lower behind your head like you're scratching between your shoulder blades
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to the sides instead of staying close to your head
Moving the upper arms instead of keeping them locked in position
Not lowering deep enough - get full forearm-to-bicep contact
injury_prevention_tips: Control the descent - don't let the weight drop suddenly behind your head
If using heavy weight, have someone hand it to you to avoid shoulder strain

instructions: Grasp a dumbbell in each hand with a pronated (palms forward) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The dumbbells should be resting on top of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the dumbbells as you exhale. The dumbbells should be close to the body as you move it up and the elbows should drive the motion. Continue to lift them until they nearly touch your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the dumbbells, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Dumbbell Upright Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells with palms facing you, arms extended down with dumbbells resting on your thighs
Keep your back straight and maintain a slight bend in your elbows
Lift the dumbbells by driving your elbows up and out to the sides, keeping dumbbells close to your body
Continue lifting until the dumbbells nearly reach chin level, with elbows higher than your wrists
Pause for one second at the top, then lower slowly back to the starting position
form_cues: Think 'elbows lead the way' - they should be higher than your hands throughout
Pull the dumbbells straight up your body like they're on rails close to your torso
At the top, imagine you're zipping up a jacket - hands travel up the centerline
common_mistakes: Lifting dumbbells too high, above chin level, which can cause shoulder impingement
Letting the dumbbells drift away from your body instead of staying close
Using momentum or swinging instead of controlled lifting
injury_prevention_tips: Stop at chin level - going higher can impinge your shoulders
Keep your torso stationary - no leaning back to help lift the weight

instructions: Start by standing with your back about two to three feet away from a bench or step.
Lift one leg behind you and rest your foot on the step,either on your instep or the ball of your foot, whichever you find most comfortable.
Keep your supporting knee slightly bent and avoid letting that knee extend out beyond your toes. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Standing Elevated Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand about 2-3 feet in front of a bench or step with your back facing it
Lift one leg behind you and place the top of your foot on the bench - find a comfortable position on either your instep or ball of foot
Keep a slight bend in your standing leg and maintain an upright posture
Gently push your hips forward to increase the stretch in the front of your elevated thigh
Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch legs
form_cues: Stand tall like a string is pulling your head toward the ceiling - don't lean forward
Think about tucking your tailbone under slightly to increase the quad stretch
Keep your standing knee soft, never locked, and tracking over your toes
The stretch should be felt in the front of your thigh, not in your knee
common_mistakes: Letting the standing knee extend too far forward beyond the toes, which can strain the knee
Leaning forward at the waist instead of keeping the torso upright
Forcing the stretch too aggressively, which can cause knee discomfort
injury_prevention_tips: Hold onto a wall or support if needed for balance - this stretch requires stability
Stop immediately if you feel any pain in your knee joint - only stretch to mild tension

instructions: To begin, stand straight with a barbell in your hands. You should grip the bar with palms facing down and a closer than shoulder width grip apart from each other.
Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. Your elbows should be slightly bent. This is the starting position.
Lift the barbell up until it is directly over your head while exhaling. Make sure to keep your elbows slightly bent when performing each repetition.
Once you feel the contraction, begin to lower the barbell back down to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Front Barbell Raise Over Head
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding a barbell with a narrow overhand grip (closer than shoulder width), arms hanging in front of your thighs
Keep a slight bend in your elbows and brace your core tight
Raise the bar in a smooth arc up in front of you, continuing all the way overhead until your arms are fully extended above your head
Pause briefly at the top, then lower the bar back down the same path to the starting position with control
Keep the movement smooth and controlled throughout
form_cues: Think about drawing a big arc in the air with the barbell from your thighs to overhead
Lead with your knuckles pointing up toward the ceiling as you raise the bar
Keep your ribs down and core tight - don't arch your back as the bar goes overhead
Imagine you're lifting the bar along a wall right in front of your face
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively as the bar goes overhead instead of maintaining a neutral spine
Using momentum by swinging the bar up rather than raising it with controlled shoulder strength
Locking out the elbows completely, which takes tension off the shoulders
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight to ensure you have the shoulder mobility for this full range of motion
Keep your core braced throughout to protect your lower back from hyperextension

instructions: Place your right heel on a step with your knee extended and lean forward to grab your right toe with your right hand. Your left knee should be slightly bent and your back should be straight.
Support your weight on your left leg and place your left hand on your left thigh.
Pull your right toes toward your knee until you feel a stretch in your calf.
exercises.name: Standing Gastrocnemius Calf Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place your right heel on a step or platform with your right leg completely straight
Keep your left leg slightly bent for support with your left hand resting on your left thigh
Lean forward and reach your right hand to grab your right toes
Gently pull your toes toward your knee until you feel a stretch in your calf
Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch to the other leg
form_cues: Keep your stretching leg completely straight - imagine it's locked like a plank
Pull from your toes, not your ankle, to maximize the calf stretch
Keep your back straight and hinge forward from the hips, not rounding your spine
Think about flexing your foot up toward your shin as you pull
common_mistakes: Bending the knee of the stretching leg, which reduces the effectiveness of the stretch
Rounding the back instead of maintaining a straight spine while reaching forward
Pulling too aggressively, which can cause cramping in the calf
injury_prevention_tips: Pull gently and progressively - never yank or bounce the stretch
Support your weight securely on your standing leg to avoid losing balance

instructions: Being by looping a belt, band, or rope around one foot. While standing, place that foot forward.
Bend your back leg, while keeping the front one straight. Now raise the toes of your front foot off of the ground and lean forward.
Using the belt, pull on the top of the foot to increase the stretch in the calf. Hold for 10-20 seconds and repeat with the other foot.
exercises.name: Standing Hamstring and Calf Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Loop a belt, resistance band, or rope around one foot and hold the ends in your hands
Step that foot forward while keeping the back leg bent and the front leg completely straight
Lift your front toes off the ground and lean your torso forward slightly from the hips
Use the belt to pull the top of your foot toward you, increasing the stretch in your calf and hamstring
Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch legs
form_cues: Keep your front leg locked straight like a board - no bend in the knee
Think about pushing your hips back like you're closing a car door with your butt
Pull your toes toward your shin to maximize the calf and hamstring stretch
Keep your chest proud and back flat - don't round your spine
common_mistakes: Bending the front knee, which defeats the purpose of the hamstring stretch
Rounding the lower back instead of hinging from the hips with a neutral spine
Not pulling hard enough on the belt to create an adequate stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Use gradual tension with the belt - don't pull suddenly or aggressively
Keep your weight balanced and secure on your back leg to avoid losing balance

instructions: Begin standing on one leg, holding to a vertical support.
Raise the unsupported knee to 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Open the hip as far as possible, attempting to make a big circle with your knee.
Perform this movement slowly for a number of repetitions, and repeat on the other side.
exercises.name: Standing Hip Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on one leg while holding a wall or support for balance
Lift your free leg with the knee bent to 90 degrees in front of you
Slowly open your hip out to the side as far as comfortable, making a circular motion with your knee
Continue the circle by bringing your knee around to the back, then returning to the front starting position
Perform 5-10 slow circles in one direction, then reverse directions, and repeat on the other leg
form_cues: Make the biggest circle you can with your knee - think about drawing a large circle in the air
Keep your standing leg stable and strong - imagine it's rooted to the ground
Move slowly and with control - this is about mobility, not speed
Your hips should be doing all the work while your torso stays still and upright
common_mistakes: Moving too quickly and using momentum instead of controlled hip movement
Leaning or swaying the torso instead of keeping it stable and upright
Making tiny circles instead of maximizing the range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Use a wall or support for balance - don't try to do this freestanding until you're comfortable
Stop if you feel any pinching or sharp pain in the hip joint

instructions: Stand up straight with the spine vertical, the left foot slightly in front of the right.

Bend both knees and lift the back heel off the floor as you press the right hip forward. You can't get a thorough, deep stretch in this position, however, because it's hard to relax the hip flexor and stand on it at the same time. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Standing Hip Flexors
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright with your left foot slightly in front of your right in a short staggered stance
Bend both knees slightly and lift your back heel off the ground
Gently press your right hip forward while keeping your torso upright and vertical
You should feel a stretch in the front of your right hip and thigh
Hold for 15-20 seconds, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about tucking your tailbone under and pushing your hips forward at the same time
Keep your chest up and spine vertical - imagine a string pulling your head to the ceiling
Don't lean back - the stretch comes from the forward hip motion, not torso position
Squeeze your glute on the stretching side to deepen the hip flexor stretch
common_mistakes: Leaning backward with the torso instead of keeping it vertical
Not pushing the hips forward enough to create an adequate stretch
Arching the lower back excessively instead of maintaining a neutral spine
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement gentle and controlled - this is a mild stretch best done as a warm-up
For a deeper hip flexor stretch, use a kneeling lunge position instead

instructions: Stand up with a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso. Your legs should be at about shoulder's width apart from each other.
Rotate the palms of the hands so that they are facing inward in a neutral position. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights out while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Your wrist should turn so that when the weights are fully elevated you have supinated grip (palms facing up).
Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Tip: Keep the forearms aligned with your outer deltoids.
Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position as your breathe in. Remember to rotate the wrists as you lower the weight in order to switch back to a neutral grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Inner-Biceps Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding a dumbbell in each hand with arms hanging at your sides and palms facing inward (neutral grip)
Pin your elbows to your sides and keep them stationary throughout
Curl the weights up and outward, rotating your wrists so your palms face up as the dumbbells reach shoulder height
Squeeze your biceps hard at the top for one second, keeping your forearms aligned with your outer shoulders
Lower the dumbbells back down while rotating your wrists back to neutral, returning to the starting position
form_cues: Think about curling the weights up and out like you're tracing the sides of a barrel
Rotate your wrists throughout the movement - start neutral, finish with palms up
Keep your elbows glued to your sides like they're pinned there with magnets
At the top, your forearms should point slightly outward, not straight ahead
common_mistakes: Not rotating the wrists enough, which reduces the bicep engagement
Letting the elbows drift forward instead of keeping them locked at your sides
Using momentum by swinging the torso or shoulders to help lift the weight
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists neutral during the transition - don't force excessive rotation
Use a lighter weight than standard curls since the rotating motion makes this more challenging

instructions: Take a slightly wider than hip distance stance with your knees slightly bent.
Place your right hand on your right hip to support the spine.
Raise your left arm in a vertical line and place your left hand behind your head. Keep it there as you incline your torso to the right.
Keep your weight evenly distributed between both legs (don't lean into your left hip). Switch sides.
exercises.name: Standing Lateral Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet slightly wider than hip-width apart and knees slightly bent
Place your right hand on your right hip for support
Raise your left arm straight up overhead and place your left hand behind your head
Lean your torso to the right side, keeping your weight evenly distributed between both feet
Hold for 20-30 seconds feeling the stretch along your left side, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about reaching up and over like you're trying to touch the opposite wall with your elbow
Keep both feet planted firmly - don't shift your weight or lean into one hip
Imagine you're sandwiched between two walls - only bend sideways, not forward or back
Breathe deeply into the stretched side to enhance the stretch
common_mistakes: Shifting weight into one hip instead of keeping it centered between both feet
Rotating or twisting the torso instead of purely bending to the side
Bending forward or backward instead of maintaining a lateral (side) bend
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the stretch gentle - you should feel a stretch, not pain, along your side
Don't force the movement - let gravity assist rather than pulling aggressively

instructions: Adjust the machine lever to fit your height and lie with your torso bent at the waist facing forward around 30-45 degrees (since an angled position is more favorable for hamstrings recruitment) with the pad of the lever on the back of your right leg (just a few inches under the calves) and the front of the right leg on top of the machine pad.
Keeping the torso bent forward, ensure your leg is fully stretched and grab the side handles of the machine. Position your toes straight. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, curl your right leg up as far as possible without lifting the upper leg from the pad. Once you hit the fully contracted position, hold it for a second.
As you inhale, bring the legs back to the initial position. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Perform the same exercise now for the left leg.
exercises.name: Standing Leg Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the machine pad to fit your height and position yourself bent forward at the waist about 30-45 degrees, holding the side handles
Place the pad behind your right calf (just below the calf muscle) with your right leg fully extended and toes pointing straight
Curl your right heel up toward your butt as high as possible without lifting your thigh off the support pad
Squeeze your hamstring hard at the top for one second
Lower your leg back down with control until fully extended, then repeat for all reps before switching legs
form_cues: Think about kicking your heel straight back to your butt, not up or out to the side
Keep your hips pressed against the pad - they shouldn't lift or rotate during the curl
Your thigh should stay completely still and pressed into the pad throughout
Squeeze your hamstring at the top like you're trying to touch your heel to your butt
common_mistakes: Lifting the thigh off the pad to help curl the weight up, which reduces hamstring isolation
Using momentum by swinging the leg rather than controlled hamstring contraction
Not achieving full range of motion by either not curling high enough or not fully extending
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso stationary and bent forward - don't rock back and forth
Use a weight that allows full range of motion without compromising form

instructions: Start by standing to the right side of a low pulley row. Use your left hand to come across the body and grab a single handle attached to the low pulley with a pronated grip (palms facing down). Rest your arm in front of you. Your right hand should grab the machine for better support and balance.
Make sure that your back is erect and your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.
Begin to use the left hand and come across your body out until it is elevated to shoulder height while exhaling.
Feel the contraction at the top for a second and begin to slowly lower the handle back down to the original starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: Standing Low-Pulley Deltoid Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand to the right of a low pulley, grab the handle with your left hand using an overhand grip, and hold your right hand on the machine for support
Start with your left arm hanging across the front of your body with the cable crossing in front of you
Keep your back straight, feet shoulder-width apart, and core braced
Raise your left arm out and across your body in an arc until it reaches shoulder height, leading with your elbow
Pause at the top for one second, then lower back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think about leading with your elbow, not your hand - keep a slight bend in the elbow throughout
Your arm should move in an arc like you're pouring water from a pitcher at the top
Keep your torso completely still - imagine you're a statue from the waist down
At the top, your arm should be at shoulder height with your thumb pointing down slightly
common_mistakes: Using momentum by swinging the torso or leaning to help lift the weight
Raising the arm too high above shoulder height, which can cause shoulder impingement
Shrugging the shoulder up toward the ear instead of keeping it down and stable
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blade down and back throughout the movement - don't let it elevate
Use lighter weight and focus on perfect form - this is a shoulder isolation exercise

instructions: Grab a single handle with your left arm next to the low pulley machine. Turn away from the machine keeping the handle to the side of your body with your arm fully extended. Now use both hands to elevate the single handle directly above the head with the palm facing forward. Keep your upper arm completely vertical (perpendicular to the floor) and put your right hand on your left elbow to help keep it steady. This is the starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the single handle. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: Standing Low-Pulley One-Arm Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a single handle from the low pulley with your left hand, turn away from the machine with arm extended
Use both hands to raise the handle directly overhead with palm facing forward, place your right hand on your left elbow for stability
Keep your upper arm vertical next to your head - this is your starting position
Lower the handle behind your head in a semicircular motion until your forearm touches your bicep
Drive the handle back up using your triceps until your arm is fully extended overhead, then repeat before switching arms
form_cues: Think 'elbow to ceiling' - keep your upper arm pointing straight up throughout
Only your forearm moves - upper arm is locked in place like a statue
Lower behind your head like you're scratching between your shoulder blades
common_mistakes: Letting the elbow drift forward or to the side instead of staying vertical
Moving the upper arm instead of keeping it stationary
Not lowering deep enough for full tricep stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Use your free hand on your elbow to keep it stable and prevent drift
Control the cable tension - don't let it yank your arm down

instructions: Start by placing a barbell that is about chest high on a squat rack. Once you have selected the weights, grab the barbell using a pronated (palms facing forward) grip. Make sure to grip the bar wider than shoulder width apart from each other.
Slightly bend the knees and place the barbell on your collar bone. Lift the barbell up keeping it lying on your chest. Take a step back and position your feet shoulder width apart from each other.

Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip length, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms. Hold at about shoulder level and slightly in front of your head. This is your starting position.
Lower the bar down to the collarbone slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Military Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell at chest height on a rack, grab it with a pronated grip wider than shoulder-width
Position the bar on your collarbone, lift it slightly, then step back with feet shoulder-width apart
Press the bar overhead until arms are locked out, then lower to just in front of your head at shoulder level - this is your starting position
Lower the bar to your collarbone slowly while inhaling
Press the bar back overhead by extending your arms fully while exhaling
form_cues: Think 'bar stays in front of your face' - it should never be behind your head
Drive straight up like you're trying to push through the ceiling
Keep your core braced tight like you're about to take a punch
common_mistakes: Leaning back excessively to help press the weight
Letting the bar drift too far forward or backward instead of vertical path
Not lowering all the way to collarbone, cutting range short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to protect your lower back
Don't hyperextend your back - maintain neutral spine

instructions: To begin, stand straight while holding a weight plate by the ridge at arm's length in each hand using a neutral grip (palms facing in). You feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. This will be your starting position.
Lower the plates until the fingers are nearly extended but can still hold weights. Inhale as you lower the plates.
Now raise the plates back to the starting position as you exhale by closing your hands.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.
exercises.name: Standing Olympic Plate Hand Squeeze
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a weight plate by the smooth ridge in each hand at arm's length using a pinch grip
Your palms should face each other with fingers gripping one side and thumb on the other
Lower the plates by opening your hands until your fingers are nearly extended but still gripping
Squeeze your hands closed to raise the plates back to the starting position
Repeat for your prescribed reps, focusing on the crushing grip sensation
form_cues: Think 'pinch and squeeze' - your fingers and thumb work against each other
Lower slowly until you feel like the plate might slip, then squeeze hard
Your grip does all the work - arms stay extended and relaxed
common_mistakes: Using plates that are too heavy and dropping them
Not lowering far enough - you need the stretch at the bottom
Bending arms to help instead of pure grip work
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter plates than you think - grip strength fatigues quickly
Have a safe drop zone in case you lose your grip

instructions: Start out by grabbing single handle next to the low pulley machine. Make sure you are far enough from the machine so that your arm is supporting the weight.

Make sure that your upper arm is stationary, perpendicular to the floor with elbows in and palms facing forward. Your non lifting arm should be grabbing your waist. This will allow you to keep your balance.
Slowly begin to curl the single handle upwards while keeping the upper arm stationary until your forearm touches your bicep while exhaling. Tip: Only the forearm should move.
Hold the contraction position as you squeeze the bicep and then lower the single handle back down to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms while performing this exercise.
exercises.name: Standing One-Arm Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a single handle attached to the low pulley, step back until your arm is supporting the weight
Stand with your working arm at your side, upper arm perpendicular to the floor with elbow in and palm facing forward
Place your non-working hand on your waist for balance
Curl the handle upward by bending your elbow until your forearm touches your bicep, keeping upper arm stationary
Squeeze your bicep at the top for one second, then lower with control back to full extension
form_cues: Think 'upper arm glued in place' - it should be perfectly still throughout
Curl straight up toward your shoulder, not across your body
Constant cable tension makes this harder than dumbbells - squeeze at the top
common_mistakes: Letting your elbow drift forward as you curl
Using your shoulder to help lift instead of pure bicep work
Not maintaining tension - letting the weight rest at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso stable - don't lean or twist to help curl the weight
Control both directions - resist the cable on the way down

instructions: Stand on the back side of an incline bench as if you were going to be a spotter for someone. Have a dumbbell in one hand and rest it across the incline bench with a supinated (palms up) grip.

Position your non lifting hand at the corner or side of the incline bench. The chest should be pressed against the top part of the incline and your feet should be pressed against the floor at a wide stance. This is the starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the dumbbell upward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbell is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms while performing this exercise.
exercises.name: Standing One-Arm Dumbbell Curl Over Incline Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand behind an incline bench, hold a dumbbell with an underhand grip and rest your arm across the angled pad
Press your chest against the top of the bench with feet wide for stability, your non-working hand grips the bench corner
Start with your working arm fully extended down the bench - this is your starting position
Curl the dumbbell up by bending your elbow while keeping your upper arm pressed against the pad
Squeeze at the top for one second when your bicep is fully contracted, then lower with control
form_cues: Think 'arm welded to the bench' - it should never lift off the pad
The incline creates a prestretch - embrace the difficult bottom position
Squeeze like you're showing off your bicep peak at the top
common_mistakes: Peeling your upper arm off the bench to help curl the weight
Not maintaining chest contact with the bench throughout
Using momentum instead of slow, controlled curling
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your feet wide and planted - this prevents you from sliding
Use lighter weight than regular curls - the incline makes it harder

instructions: To begin, stand up with a dumbbell held in one hand. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart from each other. Now fully extend the arm with the dumbbell over your head. Tip: The small finger of your hand should be facing the ceiling and the palm of your hand should be facing forward. The dumbbell should be above your head.
This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arm close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearm touch your bicep. Tip: The upper arm should remain stationary and only the forearm should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the dumbbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: Standing One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell overhead with one arm fully extended, pinky finger facing the ceiling
Keep your upper arm vertical next to your head with elbow pointing straight up - this is your starting position
Lower the dumbbell behind your head in a semicircular motion until your forearm touches your bicep
Keep your elbow in close to your head throughout the movement
Drive the dumbbell back up using your triceps until your arm is fully extended, then repeat before switching arms
form_cues: Think 'elbow to ear' - keep it tucked close to your head throughout
Upper arm is frozen vertical - only your forearm moves like a hinge
Lower behind your head like you're combing your hair from the back
common_mistakes: Letting your elbow flare out to the side instead of staying close to your head
Moving the upper arm instead of keeping it locked in position
Not achieving full range - get your forearm to touch your bicep
injury_prevention_tips: Control the descent - don't let the dumbbell drop suddenly behind your head
Start lighter than you think - single-arm requires more stability

instructions: To begin, stand up holding a barbell or e-z bar using a pronated grip (palms facing forward) with your hands closer than shoulder width apart from each other. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart.
Now elevate the barbell above your head until your arms are fully extended. Keep your elbows in. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head and elbows in, perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the barbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Overhead Barbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width holding a barbell or EZ bar overhead with a pronated grip, hands closer than shoulder-width
Fully extend your arms overhead with elbows pointing forward - this is your starting position
Keep your upper arms vertical next to your head with elbows in throughout the movement
Lower the bar behind your head in a semicircular motion until your forearms touch your biceps
Drive the bar back up using your triceps until your arms are fully extended overhead
form_cues: Think 'elbows forward and in' - they point ahead of you, not out to the sides
Upper arms are pillars - they don't move, only your forearms hinge
Lower the bar behind your head like you're scratching your upper back
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out wide instead of keeping them tucked in
Moving the upper arms forward and back instead of keeping them vertical
Not lowering deep enough to get full tricep stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to prevent arching your lower back
Control the barbell path - don't let it crash down behind your head

instructions: Start by having a dumbbell in one hand with your arm fully extended to the side using a neutral grip. Use your other arm to hold on to an incline bench to keep your balance.
