Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. Now slowly lift the dumbbell up until you create a 90 degree angle with your arm. Note: Your forearm should be perpendicular to the floor. Continue to maintain a neutral grip throughout the entire exercise.
Slowly lift the dumbbell up until your arm is fully extended. This the starting position.
While inhaling lower the weight down until your arm is at a 90 degree angle again.

Feel the contraction for a second and then lift the weight back up towards the starting position while exhaling. Remember to hold on to the incline bench and keep your feet positioned to keep balance during the exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: Standing Palm-In One-Arm Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a dumbbell at your side with arm extended using a neutral grip (palm facing in), use your other hand to hold an incline bench for balance
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, raise the dumbbell to create a 90-degree angle with your forearm perpendicular to the floor
Press the dumbbell straight up until your arm is fully extended - this is your starting position
Lower the dumbbell back down to the 90-degree position while inhaling
Press back up to full extension while exhaling, maintaining the neutral grip throughout
form_cues: Think 'hammer grip press' - your palm faces inward the entire time
Press straight up like you're pushing through the ceiling
Use the bench for balance but don't lean on it - your core does the stabilizing
common_mistakes: Rotating the dumbbell during the press instead of maintaining neutral grip
Leaning too heavily on the bench instead of using core for balance
Pressing at an angle instead of straight up vertically
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your feet wide and stable to maintain balance
Don't go too heavy on single-arm - focus on control

instructions: Start by having a dumbbell in each hand with your arm fully extended to the side using a neutral grip. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. Now slowly lift the dumbbells up until you create a 90 degree angle with your arms. Note: Your forearms should be perpendicular to the floor. This the starting position.
Continue to maintain a neutral grip throughout the entire exercise. Slowly lift the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended.
While inhaling lower the weights down until your arm is at a 90 degree angle again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Palms-In Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding dumbbells at your sides with arms extended, palms facing each other
Raise both dumbbells until your arms form 90-degree angles with forearms perpendicular to the floor - this is your starting position
Press both dumbbells straight up overhead by extending your arms fully while maintaining the neutral grip
Pause briefly at full extension
Lower the dumbbells back down to the 90-degree position with control while inhaling
form_cues: Think 'neutral grip throughout' - palms face each other from start to finish
Press straight up like an elevator - vertical path only
Your forearms stay perpendicular to the floor the entire movement
common_mistakes: Rotating the dumbbells during the press instead of keeping palms facing in
Pressing forward or back instead of straight overhead
Using leg drive or leaning back to help press the weight
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight to maintain upright posture
The neutral grip is easier on shoulders - don't rotate to make it harder

instructions: Start by standing straight and holding a barbell behind your glutes at arm's length while using a pronated grip (palms will be facing back away from the glutes) and having your hands shoulder width apart from each other.
You should be looking straight forward while your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.
While exhaling, slowly elevate the barbell up by curling your wrist in a semi-circular motion towards the ceiling. Note: Your wrist should be the only body part moving for this exercise.
Hold the contraction for a second and lower the barbell back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
When finished, lower the barbell down to the squat rack or the floor by bending the knees. Tip: It is easiest to either pick it up from a squat rack or have a partner hand it to you.
exercises.name: Standing Palms-Up Barbell Behind The Back Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell behind your glutes at arm's length with a pronated grip (palms facing away from you), hands shoulder-width
Stand upright with feet shoulder-width apart, arms fully extended - this is your starting position
Curl the barbell up behind you by extending your wrists in a semicircular motion toward the ceiling
Only your wrists should move - arms and shoulders stay completely still
Hold the contraction for one second at the top, then lower back down with control
form_cues: Think 'wrist extension only' - imagine your forearms are bolted in place
Curl upward behind you like you're trying to touch the bar to your lower back
This works the top of your forearms - you'll feel the burn there
common_mistakes: Moving your arms or shoulders instead of isolating wrist movement
Using too much weight and losing control of the bar
Not achieving full range of motion in the wrist curl
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - this is an awkward position and wrists fatigue quickly
Keep your torso upright - don't lean forward or back

instructions: Start off with your feet hip-distance apart.
Bend your knees slightly to keep them soft and springy.
You may want to move your pelvis forward and backward and back few times before holding the tailbone forward in this stretch.
exercises.name: Standing Pelvic Tilt
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart and knees slightly bent to keep them soft
Place your hands on your hips for awareness of the movement
Practice tilting your pelvis forward and backward a few times to find the range of motion
Tilt your pelvis forward by tucking your tailbone under, engaging your glutes and abs
Hold the forward tilt position for 15-30 seconds, then release and repeat
form_cues: Think about tucking your tailbone under like you're a dog putting its tail between its legs
Imagine flattening your lower back against an imaginary wall behind you
Your hips should rock forward while your chest stays in place
Feel your glutes and abs engage as you tuck your pelvis
common_mistakes: Moving the entire torso instead of just rotating the pelvis
Locking the knees instead of keeping them soft and slightly bent
Holding your breath instead of breathing naturally through the hold
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement gentle and controlled - this is a mobility drill, not a strength exercise
Don't force the range of motion beyond what feels comfortable

instructions: Attach a rope to a high pulley and select an appropriate weight.
Stand with your back to the cable tower. Take the rope with both hands over your shoulders, holding it to your upper chest. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by flexing the spine, crunching the weight down as far as you can.
Hold the peak contraction for a moment before returning to the starting position.
exercises.name: Standing Rope Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a high pulley and select your weight, then stand with your back to the cable tower
Grab the rope with both hands and position it over your shoulders against your upper chest
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, core braced, and maintain a stable lower body
Crunch forward by flexing your spine, bringing your elbows toward your hips as far as possible
Squeeze your abs hard at the bottom, pause for one second, then return to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about crunching down like you're trying to bring your ribs to your hips
Your hips and legs should stay completely still - all movement comes from spinal flexion
Imagine curling into a ball from the top down, not bending at the waist
Exhale forcefully as you crunch down and squeeze your abs like you're being punched in the stomach
common_mistakes: Bending at the hips instead of flexing the spine, which turns it into a hip hinge movement
Using the arms to pull the rope down instead of using the abs to crunch the spine
Standing too far from the cable tower, which reduces the resistance at the contracted position
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral - don't pull your head forward with the rope
Start with lighter weight to master the spinal flexion pattern before loading heavy

instructions: Stand with your feet hip-distance apart, one foot slightly in front of the other.
Bend both knees, keeping your back heel on the floor. Switch sides.
exercises.name: Standing Soleus And Achilles Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, placing one foot slightly in front of the other
Bend both knees while keeping your back heel firmly planted on the ground
Shift your weight forward slightly to increase the stretch in the lower calf and Achilles of your back leg
Hold for 20-30 seconds feeling the stretch deep in the lower calf near the ankle
Switch legs and repeat
form_cues: Keep your back heel glued to the floor - if it lifts, you're not stretching the soleus
Think about pushing your knee forward over your toes while keeping the heel down
The stretch should be felt lower in the calf, closer to the ankle than the gastrocnemius stretch
Keep your torso upright - don't lean forward
common_mistakes: Lifting the back heel off the ground, which defeats the purpose of the stretch
Keeping the legs too straight instead of bending both knees
Not shifting weight forward enough to feel the stretch in the lower calf
injury_prevention_tips: This stretch targets the soleus, which is best stretched with a bent knee
Hold onto support if needed for balance

instructions: Stand with some space in front and behind you.
Bend at the waist, keeping your legs straight, until you can relax and let your upper body hang down in front of you. Let your arms and hands hang down naturally. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.
exercises.name: Standing Toe Touches
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart and legs completely straight
Take a deep breath, then slowly bend forward at the hips, letting your upper body hang down
Keep your legs locked straight and let your arms and hands hang naturally toward the floor
Relax completely and let gravity pull you deeper into the stretch
Hold for 10-20 seconds, breathing normally, then slowly roll back up one vertebra at a time
form_cues: Think about hinging from your hips, not rounding your back from the start
Let your head and neck be completely heavy and relaxed - imagine you're a rag doll
Focus on lengthening your hamstrings rather than forcing your hands to touch the floor
Breathe deeply and try to relax deeper into the stretch with each exhale
common_mistakes: Bouncing or using momentum to try to touch the toes, which can strain the hamstrings
Bending the knees to make it easier, which reduces the effectiveness
Holding tension in the upper body instead of completely relaxing and letting gravity do the work
injury_prevention_tips: Never bounce or force this stretch - use gentle, sustained pressure only
If you can't reach your toes, that's completely fine - let your hands hang wherever they naturally reach

instructions: To begin, stand up with both arms fully extended above the head holding one end of a towel with both hands. Your elbows should be in and the arms perpendicular to the floor with the palms facing each other while your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.

Now communicate with your partner so that he/she can grip the other side of the towel to apply resistance. Keeping your upper arms close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the towel. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Standing Towel Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding one end of a towel with both hands, arms extended straight overhead
Keep your elbows close to your head with upper arms perpendicular to the floor, palms facing each other
Have a partner grab the other end of the towel below your hands to provide resistance
Lower the towel behind your head in a semicircular arc by bending your elbows until your forearms touch your biceps
Press the towel back up to the starting position using your triceps, then repeat
form_cues: Keep your elbows pinned close to your ears throughout - don't let them flare out to the sides
Think about only moving your forearms while your upper arms stay completely still
Imagine your elbows are hinges that only bend backward, not side to side
Communicate with your partner to maintain steady, consistent resistance
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows flare out to the sides instead of keeping them tight to the head
Moving the upper arms forward and back instead of keeping them stationary
Partner providing inconsistent resistance that makes the movement jerky
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light resistance and communicate clearly with your partner
Don't let your lower back arch - keep your core engaged throughout

instructions: Stand facing a box or bench of an appropriate height with your feet together. This will be your starting position.

Begin the movement by stepping up, putting your left foot on the top of the bench. Extend through the hip and knee of your front leg to stand up on the box. As you stand on the box with your left leg, flex your right knee and hip, bringing your knee as high as you can.
Reverse this motion to step down off the box, and then repeat the sequence on the opposite leg.
exercises.name: Step-up with Knee Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a box or bench at an appropriate height with your feet together
Step up onto the box with your left foot, driving through your heel to lift yourself up
As you stand fully on the box with your left leg, drive your right knee up as high as possible toward your chest
Pause briefly at the top in a single-leg standing position with knee raised
Step back down with control, then repeat on the opposite leg
form_cues: Drive through your heel, not your toes, to power yourself up onto the box
Think about standing up tall and proud at the top - full hip extension
Drive your non-working knee up explosively like you're trying to knee someone in the chest
Keep your chest up and core tight throughout the entire movement
common_mistakes: Pushing off with the ground leg instead of using the leg on the box to lift yourself up
Not driving the knee high enough at the top of the movement
Leaning forward excessively instead of maintaining an upright torso
injury_prevention_tips: Choose a box height where your thigh is parallel or slightly above parallel when your foot is on top
Control the descent - don't just drop off the box

instructions: Grasp a bar using an overhand grip (palms facing down). You may need some wrist wraps if using a significant amount of weight.
Stand with your torso straight and your legs spaced using a shoulder width or narrower stance. The knees should be slightly bent. This is your starting position.

Keeping the knees stationary, lower the barbell to over the top of your feet by bending at the hips while keeping your back straight. Keep moving forward as if you were going to pick something from the floor until you feel a stretch on the hamstrings. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Start bringing your torso up straight again by extending your hips until you are back at the starting position. Exhale as you perform this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Stiff-Legged Barbell Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an overhand grip, feet shoulder-width or narrower, with a slight bend in your knees
Keep your back straight, chest up, and core braced throughout
Push your hips back and lower the bar by hinging at the hips, keeping the bar close to your legs
Lower until you feel a deep stretch in your hamstrings, typically when the bar reaches mid-shin or the top of your feet
Drive your hips forward to stand back up to the starting position, squeezing your glutes at the top
form_cues: Think about pushing your hips back to touch a wall behind you, not squatting down
Keep the bar travelling in a straight line close to your legs - imagine scraping your shins
Your back should stay flat like a tabletop throughout - no rounding
Feel the stretch in your hamstrings like they're rubber bands being pulled tight
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back instead of maintaining a neutral spine throughout
Bending the knees more during the descent, which turns it into a regular deadlift
Letting the bar drift away from the body instead of keeping it close
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your knees in a fixed, slightly bent position - they shouldn't move during the exercise
Use a lighter weight than regular deadlifts as this variation is more demanding on the hamstrings and lower back

instructions: Grasp a couple of dumbbells holding them by your side at arm's length.
Stand with your torso straight and your legs spaced using a shoulder width or narrower stance. The knees should be slightly bent. This is your starting position.

Keeping the knees stationary, lower the dumbbells to over the top of your feet by bending at the waist while keeping your back straight. Keep moving forward as if you were going to pick something from the floor until you feel a stretch on the hamstrings. Exhale as you perform this movement
Start bringing your torso up straight again by extending your hips and waist until you are back at the starting position. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Stiff-Legged Dumbbell Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides with arms straight, feet shoulder-width or narrower, and a slight bend in your knees
Keep your torso straight, chest proud, and core tight
Push your hips back and lower the dumbbells toward the floor by hinging at the waist, keeping your back flat
Continue lowering until you feel a strong stretch in your hamstrings, typically when the dumbbells reach mid-shin level
Drive your hips forward to return to the starting position, squeezing your glutes at the top
form_cues: Think about reaching your butt back to close a car door behind you
The dumbbells should travel down close to your legs in a straight vertical line
Keep your shoulder blades pulled back and chest up - imagine someone pulling a string from your sternum forward
Your hamstrings should feel like tight guitar strings at the bottom of the movement
common_mistakes: Squatting down by bending the knees more instead of hinging at the hips
Rounding the spine forward to try to reach lower instead of stopping when the hamstrings are stretched
Letting the dumbbells swing away from the body instead of keeping them close
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain a fixed, slight knee bend throughout - don't let them move
Stop the descent when you feel a strong hamstring stretch, not when the weights touch the floor

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your legs stationary, move your torso forward by bending at the hips while inhaling. Lower your torso until it is parallel with the floor.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by elevating your torso back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Stiff Leg Barbell Good Morning
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a barbell in a squat rack at shoulder height, position it on your upper traps, and step back with feet shoulder-width apart
Stand tall with your head up, back straight, and legs nearly straight with just a slight knee bend
Push your hips back and hinge forward at the hips, lowering your torso until it's parallel to the floor
Keep the bar balanced on your back and your spine neutral throughout the entire movement
Drive your hips forward to raise your torso back up to the starting position
form_cues: Think about bowing forward from the hips like you're greeting someone, not rounding your back
Push your hips back first, then let your torso hinge forward naturally
Keep your back flat like a board throughout - imagine balancing a broomstick along your spine
Your head should stay in line with your spine - don't look up or down
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back instead of maintaining a neutral spine throughout
Bending the knees excessively during the movement, which turns it into a squat
Going too heavy too soon, which compromises form and can injure the lower back
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight to master the hip hinge pattern with a loaded barbell
This exercise places significant stress on the lower back - keep your core braced hard throughout

instructions: To begin, stand straight with your feet shoulder width apart from each other. Place your hands on your hips. This is the starting position.

Now slowly inhale as much air as possible and then start to exhale as much as possible while bringing your stomach in as much as possible and hold this position. Try to visualize your navel touching your backbone.
One isometric contraction is around 20 seconds. During the 20 second hold, try to breathe normally. Then inhale and bring your stomach back to the starting position.
Once you have practiced this exercise, try to perform this exercise for longer than 20 seconds. Tip: You can work your way up to 40-60 seconds.
Repeat for the recommended amount of sets.
exercises.name: Stomach Vacuum
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place your hands on your hips
Take a deep breath in, filling your lungs completely
Exhale all the air out while simultaneously pulling your stomach in as far as possible toward your spine
Hold this contracted position for 20 seconds while trying to breathe normally with shallow breaths
Release and return to normal breathing, then repeat for multiple sets
form_cues: Visualize your belly button trying to touch your spine - suck it in as far as possible
Think about pulling your stomach up and in, not just in
Try to maintain the vacuum while taking small, shallow breaths - don't hold your breath the entire time
Your transverse abdominis should feel tight like a corset around your midsection
common_mistakes: Holding the breath completely instead of trying to breathe lightly during the hold
Not pulling the stomach in far enough to engage the deep core muscles
Tensing the entire body instead of focusing tension specifically in the abdominal area
injury_prevention_tips: Start with shorter holds (10-15 seconds) and gradually work up to 40-60 seconds
Stop if you feel dizzy or lightheaded - this means you're holding your breath too much

instructions: Place a dumbbell standing up on a flat bench.

Ensuring that the dumbbell stays securely placed at the top of the bench, lie perpendicular to the bench (torso across it as in forming a cross) with only your shoulders lying on the surface. Hips should be below the bench and legs bent with feet firmly on the floor. The head will be off the bench as well.

Grasp the dumbbell with both hands and hold it straight over your chest at arms length. Both palms should be pressing against the underside one of the sides of the dumbbell. This will be your starting position.Caution: Always ensure that the dumbbell used for this exercise is secure. Using a dumbbell with loose plates can result in the dumbbell falling apart and falling on your face.
While keeping your arms straight, lower the weight slowly in an arc behind your head while breathing in until you feel a stretch on the chest.
At that point, bring the dumbbell back to the starting position using the arc through which the weight was lowered and exhale as you perform this movement.
Hold the weight on the initial position for a second and repeat the motion for the prescribed number of repetitions.
exercises.name: Straight-Arm Dumbbell Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a dumbbell standing upright at the top of a flat bench, then lie perpendicular across the bench with only your shoulders on it
Your hips should be below bench level, feet planted wide on the floor, head hanging off the bench
Grasp the dumbbell with both hands palms-up against the underside, hold it straight above your chest with arms extended
Lower the dumbbell in a wide arc behind your head while keeping arms straight, until you feel a deep stretch in your chest
Pull the dumbbell back to starting position using the same arc path, squeezing your chest and lats at the top
form_cues: Think 'rainbow arc' - the dumbbell traces a wide semicircle behind and over your head
Arms stay locked with just a slight bend - don't let your elbows flex more
Feel the stretch in your ribcage like you're opening your chest cavity
common_mistakes: Bending elbows during the movement, turning it into a tricep extension
Not going deep enough - you should feel a strong chest and lat stretch at the bottom
Lifting hips up during the movement instead of keeping them low and stable
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the dumbbell is secure - loose plates can be dangerous overhead
Keep your hips low to protect your lower back from hyperextension

instructions: You will start by grabbing the wide bar from the top pulley of a pulldown machine and using a wider than shoulder-width pronated (palms down) grip. Step backwards two feet or so.

Bend your torso forward at the waist by around 30-degrees with your arms fully extended in front of you and a slight bend at the elbows. If your arms are not fully extended then you need to step a bit more backwards until they are. Once your arms are fully extended and your torso is slightly bent at the waist, tighten the lats and then you are ready to begin.
While keeping the arms straight, pull the bar down by contracting the lats until your hands are next to the side of the thighs. Breathe out as you perform this step.
While keeping the arms straight, go back to the starting position while breathing in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Straight-Arm Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a wide bar from the high pulley with an overhand grip wider than shoulders, step back about two feet
Bend forward at the waist about 30 degrees with arms fully extended in front, slight elbow bend
Keeping your arms straight, pull the bar down in an arc by contracting your lats until it reaches your thighs
Squeeze your lats hard at the bottom position
Return the bar to the starting position with control, maintaining straight arms throughout
form_cues: Think 'pushing down on something' - use your lats to drive the bar down, not your arms
Your arms are just hooks - all the pulling power comes from your back
Imagine closing your lats down like shutting big wings
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows significantly, which recruits biceps instead of lats
Standing too upright instead of maintaining the forward lean
Using momentum by rocking back and forth instead of controlled lat contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a slight elbow bend throughout - fully locked elbows can stress the joint
Maintain the torso angle - don't let your body jerk upright as the weight pulls

instructions: Place a loaded barbell on the end of a bench. Standing on the bench behind the bar, take a medium, pronated grip. Stand with your hips back and chest up, maintaining a neutral spine. This will be your starting position.
Row the bar to your torso by retracting the shoulder blades and flexing the elbows. Use a controlled movement with no jerking.
After a brief pause, slowly return the bar to the starting position, ensuring to go all the way down.
exercises.name: Straight Bar Bench Mid Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a loaded barbell on the end of a flat bench, stand on the bench behind the bar
Bend at the hips with chest up and neutral spine, grab the bar with an overhand grip at medium width
Row the bar up to your torso by retracting your shoulder blades and bending your elbows
Pull in a controlled motion without jerking until the bar touches your torso
After a brief pause, lower the bar all the way back down with control
form_cues: Think 'shoulder blades first' - retract them before bending your elbows
Drive your elbows back like you're elbowing someone behind you
Chest stays up and proud - imagine a string pulling your sternum forward
common_mistakes: Rounding your back instead of maintaining neutral spine
Using jerking motions instead of smooth, controlled pulls
Not pulling all the way to your torso, cutting the range short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your spine neutral throughout - no rounding under load
Balance carefully on the bench - ensure stable footing before rowing

instructions: Place a bar on the ground behind the head of an incline bench.
Lay on the bench face down. With a pronated grip, pick the barbell up from the floor, keeping your arms straight. Allow the bar to hang straight down. This will be your starting position.
To begin, raise the barbell out in front of your head while keeping your arms extended.
Return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Straight Raises on Incline Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a barbell on the ground behind the head of an incline bench, lie face down on the bench
Reach down and grab the bar with an overhand grip, lifting it slightly off the ground with arms fully extended
Let the bar hang straight down from your shoulders - this is your starting position
Raise the barbell out in front of your head in an arc while keeping your arms extended
Pause briefly at the top, then return to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'front raise from prone' - you're lifting against gravity in a unique angle
Arms stay straight like they're locked - minimal elbow bend
Your rear delts and upper back do the work, not your arms
common_mistakes: Bending elbows during the raise instead of keeping arms extended
Using too much weight and jerking the bar up with momentum
Not maintaining chest contact with the bench throughout
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - this is an awkward angle with long leverage
Keep your chest pressed firmly to the bench for stability

instructions: Begin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip. Relax the shoulders, which in effect lengthens your arms.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.
exercises.name: Sumo Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet very wide (near barbell collars) with the bar over mid-foot, toes pointed slightly out
Bend at the hips to grip the bar with arms inside your legs directly below shoulders
Lower your hips while keeping chest up and head forward, take a breath and brace your core
Drive through the back half of your feet, spreading the floor apart as you extend hips and knees simultaneously
As the bar passes your knees, drive your hips into the bar and pull your shoulder blades together, then lower with control
form_cues: Think 'spread the floor' - push your feet outward as you drive up
Drive through your heels, not your toes - weight stays back
Hips and shoulders rise together - don't let your hips shoot up first
common_mistakes: Starting with hips too high, which turns it into a conventional deadlift
Not spreading the knees out wide enough during the pull
Letting the shoulders round forward instead of staying back and tight
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your spine neutral throughout - maintain natural arch in lower back
Don't jerk the bar - create tension before you pull

instructions: To deadlift with short bands, simply loop them over the bar before you start, and step into them to set up. Ensure that they under the back half of your foot, directly where you are driving into the floor.

Begin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.
exercises.name: Sumo Deadlift with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Loop resistance bands over the barbell, step into them so they're under the back half of your feet
Set up in sumo stance: feet very wide near collars, bar over mid-foot, grip inside your legs
Lower hips with chest up and head forward, take a breath and brace
Drive through your heels while spreading the floor apart, extending hips and knees together
As the bar passes knees, drive hips forward into the bar and retract shoulder blades, then lower with control
form_cues: Think 'accelerate through lockout' - bands make the top harder so push hard to finish
Spread the floor like you're doing leg presses with your feet
Bands create increasing resistance - fight to lock out completely
common_mistakes: Decelerating at the top where bands are hardest - you need to accelerate through
Not keeping feet pressing outward throughout the lift
Letting bands pull you forward - keep weight on your heels
injury_prevention_tips: Reduce barbell weight to account for band resistance at lockout
Ensure bands are secure under your feet before pulling

instructions: You can attach the chains to the sleeves of the bar, or just drape the middle over the bar so there is a greater weight increase as you lift. Attempt to keep the ends of the chains away from the plates so you don't hit them when you lower the weight.

Begin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip. Relax the shoulders, which in effect lengthens your arms.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.
exercises.name: Sumo Deadlift with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach chains to the barbell sleeves or drape them over the bar, keep chain ends away from plates
Set up in sumo stance: feet very wide near collars, bar over mid-foot, grip inside legs with arms relaxed
Lower hips while keeping chest up and looking forward, take a breath and brace your core
Drive explosively through the back of your feet while spreading the floor, extend hips and knees
As bar passes knees, lean back and drive hips into the bar with shoulder blades retracted, lower with control
form_cues: Think 'chains get heavier as you stand' - the top requires more acceleration
Explode through lockout - chains reward aggressive finishing
Pull the slack out before lifting - create tension in the chains first
common_mistakes: Slowing down at lockout instead of accelerating through the hardest part
Not maintaining the wide knee position throughout
Letting chains make noise by hitting plates - keep them positioned away
injury_prevention_tips: Reduce bar weight to account for chain resistance at lockout
Accelerate aggressively to prevent stalling where chains add most weight

instructions: To begin, lie straight and face down on the floor or exercise mat. Your arms should be fully extended in front of you. This is the starting position.

Simultaneously raise your arms, legs, and chest off of the floor and hold this contraction for 2 seconds. Tip: Squeeze your lower back to get the best results from this exercise. Remember to exhale during this movement. Note: When holding the contracted position, you should look like superman when he is flying.
Slowly begin to lower your arms, legs and chest back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.
exercises.name: Superman
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor or mat with arms fully extended straight out in front of you
Simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground as high as possible
Squeeze your lower back hard and hold this flying position for 2 seconds while exhaling
You should look like Superman flying - everything off the ground except your hips
Lower everything back down slowly while inhaling, then repeat
form_cues: Think 'flying Superman' - arms reaching forward, legs reaching back, chest up
Squeeze your lower back and glutes like you're trying to touch your heels to your head
Hold the top position - don't just bounce up and down
common_mistakes: Not lifting high enough - really arch back and lift everything
Rushing through reps instead of holding the contraction for 2 seconds
Holding your breath instead of exhaling during the contraction
injury_prevention_tips: Start with shorter hold times if you have lower back issues
Don't force excessive range - work within comfortable extension

instructions: Adjust the straps so the handles are at an appropriate height, below waist level.
Begin standing and grasping the handles. Lean into the straps, moving to an incline push-up position. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, lean further into the suspension straps, bringing your body closer to the ground, allowing your shoulders to extend, raising your arms up and over your head.
Maintain a neutral spine and keep the rest of your body straight, your shoulders being the only joints allowed to move.
Pause during the peak contraction, and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Suspended Fallout
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set suspension straps below waist level, grasp the handles and lean into them in an incline plank position
With arms straight, this is your starting position
Keeping your arms locked straight, lean forward into the straps allowing your arms to raise up and over your head
Your body gets closer to the ground as your shoulders extend - only your shoulders move, spine stays neutral
Pause at maximum extension when your body is closest to the ground, then pull back to starting position
form_cues: Think 'ab wheel in the air' - your body extends forward and down like a moving plank
Your core fights to keep your spine neutral as your arms go overhead
Arms stay straight the entire time - this is all about shoulder flexion and core stability
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag or pike up instead of maintaining neutral spine
Bending your arms during the movement
Not going deep enough into the extended position
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced tight throughout to protect your lower back
Adjust strap height to make it easier if you can't maintain form

instructions: Anchor your suspension straps securely to the top of a rack or other object.

Leaning into the straps, take a handle in each hand and move into a push-up plank position. You should be as close to parallel to the ground as you can manage with your arms fully extended, maintaining good posture.
Maintaining a straight, rigid torso, descend slowly by allowing the elbows to flex.
Continue until your elbows break 90 degrees, pausing before you extend to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Suspended Push-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor suspension straps securely at the top of a rack, grab a handle in each hand
Lean into the straps and move into a push-up plank position, body as close to parallel with the ground as possible
Maintain a rigid, straight torso with arms fully extended - this is your starting position
Lower yourself slowly by bending your elbows while keeping your body straight
Continue until elbows bend past 90 degrees, pause, then press back up to full extension
form_cues: Think 'body is a rigid plank' - no sagging or piking throughout
The straps create instability - your core works overtime to stay stable
Lower slow, press up explosively while maintaining perfect form
common_mistakes: Letting hips sag or pike up instead of maintaining plank position
Not going deep enough - elbows should break 90 degrees
Moving too fast without control, letting the straps swing
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged throughout to protect your lower back
Control the instability - don't let the straps swing wildly

instructions: Secure a set of suspension straps with the handles hanging about a foot off of the ground. Move yourself into a pushup plank position facing away from the rack.
Place your feet into the handles. You should maintain a straight posture, not allowing the hips to sag. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the knees and hips, drawing the knees to your torso. As you do so, anteriorly tilt your pelvis, allowing your spine to flex.
At the top of the controlled motion, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Suspended Reverse Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure suspension straps with handles about a foot off the ground, then get into a plank position facing away with feet in the handles
Hold a strong plank with arms straight, core tight, and hips level - don't let them sag
Pull your knees toward your chest by flexing your hips and abs, letting your pelvis tilt forward
At the top, your knees should be tucked up near your torso with your spine slightly rounded
Extend your legs back out to the plank position with control
form_cues: Think about pulling your knees to your elbows like you're doing a cannonball
Tilt your pelvis under as you crunch - imagine tucking your tailbone toward your belly button
Keep your shoulders stable over your hands throughout - don't let them shift backward
Control the extension back out - don't just let your legs swing back
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag in the plank position, which reduces ab engagement and strains the lower back
Using momentum to swing the legs rather than controlled ab contraction
Not achieving enough hip and spinal flexion at the top of the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced hard throughout to protect your lower back in the plank position
Don't let your lower back hyperextend when returning to the plank

instructions: Suspend your straps at around chest height. Take a handle in each hand and lean back. Keep your body erect and your head and chest up. Your arms should be fully extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow to initiate the movement. Protract your shoulder blades as you do so.
At the completion of the motion pause, and then return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Suspended Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set suspension straps at chest height, grab a handle in each hand, and lean back with straight arms and body
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels, chest up, and core tight
Pull yourself up by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together
At the top, your hands should be at chest level with elbows pulled back behind you
Lower yourself back down with control until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows back into your pockets, not just bending your arms
Squeeze your shoulder blades together like you're pinching a pencil between them
Keep your body rigid like a plank throughout - don't let your hips sag or pike up
Lead with your chest, not your chin - imagine someone pulling your sternum forward
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag or pike up, breaking the straight body line
Pulling with the arms only instead of retracting the shoulder blades
Shrugging the shoulders up toward the ears at the top of the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain a neutral spine throughout - don't let your lower back hyperextend
Start with a more upright body angle if the movement is too difficult

instructions: Suspend your straps so the handles are 18-30 inches from the floor.
Facing away from the setup, place your rear foot into the handle behind you. Keep your head looking forward and your chest up, with your knee slightly bent. This will be your starting position.
Descend by flexing the knee and hips, lowering yourself to the ground. Keep your weight on the heel of your foot and maintain your posture throughout the exercise.
At the bottom of the movement, reverse the motion, extending through the hip and knee to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Suspended Split Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set suspension straps 18-30 inches off the ground and face away, placing your rear foot into one handle
Stand on your front leg with your chest up, head forward, and a slight bend in your front knee
Lower yourself down by bending your front knee and hip, keeping your weight in your front heel
Descend until your front thigh is parallel to the ground or your rear knee is close to the floor
Drive through your front heel to stand back up, keeping your torso upright throughout
form_cues: Think about dropping your back knee straight down toward the floor, not stepping back
Keep your weight in the heel of your front foot - you should be able to wiggle your front toes
Your front shin should stay relatively vertical - don't let your knee shoot too far forward
Imagine a string pulling your chest up toward the ceiling to maintain an upright posture
common_mistakes: Leaning too far forward instead of keeping the torso upright
Letting the front knee cave inward instead of tracking over the toes
Not going deep enough or descending too quickly without control
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight only before adding any external load
Keep your core braced to prevent your lower back from arching excessively

instructions: Begin in a standing position.

Press two lightweight plates together with your hands. Hold the plates together close to your chest to create an isometric contraction in your chest muscles. Your fingers should be pointed forward. This is your starting position.
Squeeze the plates between your palms and extend your arms directly out in front of you in a controlled motion.
Pause at the top of the motion, and then slowly return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Svend Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding two lightweight plates pressed together at chest level with both hands
Squeeze the plates hard between your palms with fingers pointing forward, creating constant tension in your chest
Press the plates straight out in front of you with control until your arms are fully extended
Pause at full extension while maintaining the squeeze between the plates
Slowly bring the plates back to your chest, keeping constant pressure between them throughout
form_cues: Think about crushing the plates together throughout the entire movement - constant tension is key
Press the plates forward in a straight line like you're pushing someone away
Your chest should feel engaged the entire time, not just at the squeeze
Imagine trying to crack a walnut between the plates with your palms
common_mistakes: Releasing the squeeze pressure during the pressing motion
Using plates that are too heavy, which makes it impossible to maintain the isometric squeeze
Pressing the plates up or down instead of straight forward at chest level
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light plates (2.5-5 lbs each) - the squeeze creates most of the difficulty
Keep your core braced and avoid arching your back as you press

instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or in a corner to keep it from moving. Load an appropriate weight onto your end.
Stand over the bar, and position a Double D row handle around the bar next to the collar. Using your hips and legs, rise to a standing position.
Assume a wide stance with your hips back and your chest up. Your arms should be extended. This will be your starting position.
Pull the weight to your upper abdomen by retracting the shoulder blades and flexing the elbows. Do not jerk the weight or cheat during the movement.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: T-Bar Row with Handle
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load a barbell into a landmine or corner, add weight to your end, and position a V-handle around the bar
Stand over the bar with a wide stance, hips back, chest up, and arms extended holding the handle
Pull the weight to your upper abdomen by driving your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades together
Keep your torso at roughly a 45-degree angle and maintain a neutral spine throughout
Lower the weight back down with control until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows back toward your hips, not up toward your shoulders
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like you're crushing a can between them
Keep your hips back and chest up - imagine you're trying to show off your chest logo
Let the lats do the work, not your biceps - think about pulling with your elbows
common_mistakes: Jerking or using momentum from the hips and legs to lift the weight
Rounding the back instead of maintaining a neutral spine
Not achieving full range of motion by either not pulling high enough or not fully extending
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced hard throughout to protect your lower back
Don't go so heavy that you need to use momentum - keep it controlled and strict

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbells up, clean the dumbbells one arm at a time so that you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width. Note: when holding the dumbbells in front of you, make sure your arms are wider than shoulder width apart from each other using a pronated (palms forward) grip. Allow your elbows to point out. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, slowly move the dumbbells in and down in a semi circular motion until they touch the upper chest while inhaling. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times and do not move the upper arms nor rest the dumbbells on the chest.

As you breathe out, move the dumbbells up using your triceps and the same semi-circular motion but in reverse. Attempt to keep the dumbbells together as they move up. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down again slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
exercises.name: Tate Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding dumbbells above your chest with arms wider than shoulder-width and elbows pointing out
Start with the dumbbells together above your chest, palms facing forward
Lower the dumbbells in a semicircular motion inward and down until they touch your upper chest
Keep your upper arms stationary and pointed out to the sides throughout - only your forearms should move
Press the dumbbells back up in a reverse arc using your triceps, bringing them back together at the top
form_cues: Think about drawing inward arcs with the dumbbells as they come down to your chest
Your elbows should stay pointed out to the sides the entire time - they're fixed in position
Imagine your upper arms are glued to an invisible platform - only your forearms move
At the bottom, the dumbbells should touch your upper chest right at nipple level
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows come down alongside the body instead of keeping them pointed out
Moving the upper arms during the press instead of keeping them stationary
Using momentum or bouncing the weights off the chest
injury_prevention_tips: Use significantly lighter weight than your normal pressing exercises
Lower the weight slowly - it should take twice as long to lower than to press up

instructions: Begin in a seated, upright position. Start by extending your legs in front of you in a V.
With your hands on the floor, lean forward as far as possible. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.
exercises.name: The Straddle
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you in a wide V shape
Sit up tall with your hands on the floor in front of you
Slowly walk your hands forward, leaning your torso toward the floor between your legs
Go as far as comfortable, feeling the stretch in your inner thighs and hamstrings
Hold for 10-20 seconds, breathing deeply and relaxing into the stretch
form_cues: Keep your back as straight as possible - lead with your chest, not your head
Think about reaching your chest toward the floor, not just your hands
Your legs should stay extended and rotated so your kneecaps point up toward the ceiling
Breathe deeply and try to relax deeper into the stretch with each exhale
common_mistakes: Rounding the back excessively to try to reach farther forward
Bending the knees to make the stretch easier
Forcing the stretch too aggressively, which can strain the adductors
injury_prevention_tips: Only spread your legs as wide as is comfortable - don't force an extreme split position
Never bounce in this position - use gentle, sustained pressure only

instructions: To begin, sit down on the abductor machine and select a weight you are comfortable with. When your legs are positioned properly, grip the handles on each side. Your entire upper body (from the waist up) should be stationary. This is the starting position.
Slowly press against the machine with your legs to move them away from each other while exhaling.

Feel the contraction for a second and begin to move your legs back to the starting position while breathing in. Note: Remember to keep your upper body stationary to prevent any injuries from occurring.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Thigh Abductor
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the abductor machine with your legs positioned against the pads and select an appropriate weight
Grip the handles on each side and sit upright with your entire upper body stationary
Press your legs outward against the pads, spreading them apart as far as the machine allows
Squeeze your glutes at the fully abducted position for one second
Slowly bring your legs back together to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about pushing your knees out against the pads, not just your feet
Keep your upper body completely still - imagine you're wearing a rigid back brace
Squeeze your glutes at the peak of the movement like you're trying to spread the floor apart
Control the return - don't let the weight slam back together
common_mistakes: Using momentum by rocking the upper body back and forth
Going too heavy and not achieving full range of motion
Rushing the movement instead of using controlled, deliberate presses
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your upper body stationary to avoid putting strain on your lower back
Don't force the range of motion beyond what your hip mobility allows

instructions: To begin, sit down on the adductor machine and select a weight you are comfortable with. When your legs are positioned properly on the leg pads of the machine, grip the handles on each side. Your entire upper body (from the waist up) should be stationary. This is the starting position.
Slowly press against the machine with your legs to move them towards each other while exhaling.

Feel the contraction for a second and begin to move your legs back to the starting position while breathing in. Note: Remember to keep your upper body stationary and avoid fast jerking motions in order to prevent any injuries from occurring.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Thigh Adductor
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the adductor machine with your legs spread apart against the pads and select your weight
Grip the handles and sit upright with your upper body completely stationary
Press your legs inward against the pads, bringing your knees together
Squeeze your inner thighs hard at the fully adducted position for one second
Slowly allow your legs to spread back apart to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about squeezing your knees together like you're trying to crush a ball between them
Keep your back flat against the pad and your chest up - don't lean forward
Your torso should be rock solid - all movement comes from the inner thighs
Feel the contraction in your inner thighs as you bring your knees together
common_mistakes: Using jerky, fast motions instead of controlled presses
Leaning forward with the torso to help bring the legs together
Not achieving full adduction at the peak of the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid fast, jerking motions which can strain the adductor muscles
Keep your upper body completely still to prevent lower back injury

instructions: To begin, lie down on the floor or an exercise mat with your back pressed against the floor. Your arms should be lying across your sides with the palms facing down.

Your legs should be touching each other. Slowly elevate your legs up in the air until they are almost perpendicular to the floor with a slight bend at the knees. Your feet should be parallel to the floor.
Move your arms so that they are fully extended at a 45 degree angle from the floor. This is the starting position.
While keeping your lower back pressed against the floor, slowly lift your torso and use your hands to try and touch your toes. Remember to exhale while perform this part of the exercise.
Slowly begin to lower your torso and arms back down to the starting position while inhaling. Remember to keep your arms straight out pointing towards your toes.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Toe Touchers
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with arms at your sides and legs together, then lift your legs until they're nearly perpendicular to the floor with a slight knee bend
Extend your arms at a 45-degree angle from the floor, pointing toward your feet
Keep your lower back pressed against the floor and crunch your torso up, reaching your hands toward your toes
Try to touch or come as close as possible to your toes at the top of the crunch
Lower your torso and arms back down with control to the starting position
form_cues: Think about reaching your fingers toward the ceiling first, then toward your toes
Your lower back should stay glued to the floor - don't let it arch up
Exhale forcefully as you crunch up and try to touch your toes
Keep your legs as still as possible - the movement comes from your abs crunching
common_mistakes: Using momentum by swinging the arms instead of controlled ab contraction
Letting the lower back arch off the floor, which reduces ab engagement
Dropping the legs or letting them swing to help with the crunch
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back pressed flat against the floor throughout to protect your spine
If you can't keep your legs up, bend your knees more or rest them against a wall

instructions: Stand upright holding an exercise ball with both hands. Extend your arms so the ball is straight out in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Rotate your torso to one side, keeping your eyes on the ball as you move. Now, rotate back to the opposite direction. Repeat for 10-20 repetitions.
exercises.name: Torso Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding an exercise ball with both hands, arms fully extended straight out in front of you
Keep your eyes focused on the ball throughout the movement
Rotate your torso to your right side as far as comfortable while keeping the ball at arm's length
Rotate back through center and continue to your left side
Continue alternating rotations for 10-20 repetitions total
form_cues: Think 'eyes follow the ball' - your head and torso rotate together
Your hips stay square and facing forward - all rotation comes from your core
Arms stay locked straight out - the ball stays the same distance from your chest
common_mistakes: Rotating your hips instead of keeping them stationary
Bending your arms and bringing the ball closer to your body
Moving too fast without control or full range
injury_prevention_tips: Move smoothly and controlled - no jerking or bouncing
Keep your core engaged throughout to support your spine

instructions: For this exercise load a trap bar, also known as a hex bar, to an appropriate weight resting on the ground. Stand in the center of the apparatus and grasp both handles.
Lower your hips, look forward with your head and keep your chest up.
Begin the movement by driving through the heels and extend your hips and knees. Avoid rounding your back at all times.
At the completion of the movement, lower the weight back to the ground under control.
exercises.name: Trap Bar Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load a trap bar (hex bar) with appropriate weight, stand in the center and grasp both handles
Lower your hips, keep your chest up and head looking forward
Drive through your heels to extend your hips and knees simultaneously, keeping your back flat
Stand fully upright at the top with shoulders back
Lower the weight back to the ground with control, maintaining a flat back throughout
form_cues: Think 'push the floor away' - drive through your heels like a leg press
Chest up, back flat - imagine a broomstick along your spine
The trap bar allows a more upright torso than conventional deadlifts
common_mistakes: Rounding your back at any point during the lift
Letting your hips shoot up first instead of rising with your shoulders
Not achieving full hip extension at the top
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your spine neutral throughout - never round your back under load
Drive evenly through both feet - don't shift weight side to side

instructions: Start with a dumbbell in each hand and your palms facing your torso. Keep your back straight with a slight bend in the knees and bend forward at the waist. Your torso should be almost parallel to the floor. Make sure to keep your head up. Your upper arms should be close to your torso and parallel to the floor. Your forearms should be pointed towards the floor as you hold the weights. There should be a 90-degree angle formed between your forearm and upper arm. This is your starting position.
Now, while keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and use your triceps to lift the weights until the arm is fully extended. Focus on moving the forearm.
After a brief pause at the top contraction, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Tricep Dumbbell Kickback
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold dumbbells with palms facing in, bend forward at the waist until torso is nearly parallel to the floor, slight knee bend
Keep your head up and back straight, bring your upper arms close to your torso and parallel to the floor
Start with forearms pointing down creating a 90-degree angle at your elbows - this is your starting position
Keeping upper arms stationary, extend your forearms back until your arms are fully extended
Squeeze your triceps at the top, pause briefly, then lower back to the 90-degree position with control
form_cues: Think 'upper arms are frozen' - they stay glued to your sides, only forearms move
At the top, your entire arm should be parallel to the floor like a straight line
Squeeze your triceps hard at full extension like you're flexing them
common_mistakes: Swinging the upper arms instead of keeping them stationary
Not fully extending at the top, missing the peak contraction
Using momentum by rocking your torso instead of isolated tricep work
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back flat throughout - don't round your spine
Use lighter weight to maintain strict form - this is an isolation exercise

instructions: Bring right arm across your body and over your left shoulder, holding your elbow with your left hand, until you feel a stretch in your tricep. Then repeat for your other arm.
exercises.name: Tricep Side Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Bring your right arm across your body and over your left shoulder
Use your left hand to grasp your right elbow
Gently pull your elbow further across and down until you feel a stretch in your right tricep
Hold for 10-20 seconds breathing deeply
Release and repeat on the opposite side
form_cues: Think 'elbow behind your head' - pull it across and behind
The stretch should be felt along the back of your upper arm
Keep your shoulders relaxed and down
common_mistakes: Pulling too aggressively instead of gentle, sustained pressure
Hunching your opposite shoulder up instead of keeping it relaxed
Not holding long enough - aim for 10-20 seconds
injury_prevention_tips: Pull gently - never force a stretch
Keep breathing normally - don't hold your breath

instructions: Attach a rope to a low pulley. After selecting an appropriate weight, grasp the rope with both hands and face away from the cable.

Position your hands behind your head with your elbows point straight up. Your elbows should start out flexed, and you can stagger your stance and lean gently away from the machine to create greater stability. This will be your starting position.
To perform the movement, extend through the elbow while keeping the upper arm in position, raising your hands above your head.
Squeeze your triceps at the top of the movement, and slowly lower the weight back to the start position.
exercises.name: Triceps Overhead Extension with Rope
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a low pulley, grasp it with both hands and face away from the cable
Position your hands behind your head with elbows pointing straight up, stagger your stance and lean slightly away from the machine
Start with elbows flexed and rope behind your head - this is your starting position
Extend through your elbows to raise your hands overhead while keeping upper arms stationary
Squeeze your triceps at full extension, then slowly lower the rope back behind your head
form_cues: Think 'elbows stay pointing up' - they don't move forward or to the sides
Lean away from the machine slightly for stability and better leverage
Drive the rope straight up overhead like you're throwing something
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to the sides instead of pointing straight up
Moving the upper arms forward instead of keeping them vertical
Standing too upright without the stabilizing lean
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to protect your lower back during the lean
Control the cable on the way down - don't let it pull you back

exercises.description: Cable triceps pushdown performed with a bar
instructions: Attach a straight or angled bar to a high pulley and grab with an overhand grip (palms facing down) at shoulder width.

Standing upright with the torso straight and a very small inclination forward, bring the upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor. The forearms should be pointing up towards the pulley as they hold the bar. This is your starting position.

Using the triceps, bring the bar down until it touches the front of your thighs and the arms are fully extended perpendicular to the floor. The upper arms should always remain stationary next to your torso and only the forearms should move. Exhale as you perform this movement.
After a second hold at the contracted position, bring the bar slowly up to the starting point. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Triceps Pushdown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight or angled bar to a high pulley, grab with an overhand grip at shoulder width
Stand upright with a slight forward lean, bring your upper arms close to your sides and perpendicular to the floor
Start with forearms pointing up toward the pulley holding the bar - this is your starting position
Push the bar down using your triceps until it touches the front of your thighs with arms fully extended
Hold for one second at the bottom, then raise the bar back to starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'upper arms glued to ribs' - they stay pinned to your sides throughout
Push straight down like you're pushing down on a table
Lock out completely at the bottom - squeeze your triceps hard
common_mistakes: Letting elbows drift forward or away from your body
Using momentum by leaning forward excessively
Not achieving full extension at the bottom
injury_prevention_tips: Keep upper arms stationary - moving them can stress your shoulders
Control the weight on the way up - don't let it jerk your arms back

instructions: Attach a rope attachment to a high pulley and grab with a neutral grip (palms facing each other).

Standing upright with the torso straight and a very small inclination forward, bring the upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor. The forearms should be pointing up towards the pulley as they hold the rope with the palms facing each other. This is your starting position.

Using the triceps, bring the rope down as you bring each side of the rope to the side of your thighs. At the end of the movement the arms are fully extended and perpendicular to the floor. The upper arms should always remain stationary next to your torso and only the forearms should move. Exhale as you perform this movement.
After holding for a second, at the contracted position, bring the rope slowly up to the starting point. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Triceps Pushdown - Rope Attachment
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a high pulley and grab with a neutral grip (palms facing each other)
Stand upright with slight forward lean, upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor
Start with forearms pointing up holding the rope - this is your starting position
Push the rope down while spreading each end to the sides of your thighs until arms are fully extended
Hold the contraction for one second with rope ends pulled apart, then return to starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'push down and apart' - the rope ends spread as you extend
At the bottom, pull the rope ends away from each other to maximize tricep contraction
Upper arms stay frozen against your sides like they're in a cast
common_mistakes: Not spreading the rope apart at the bottom, missing peak contraction
Letting elbows move forward or away from your torso
Using body momentum by excessive leaning instead of isolated tricep work
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your upper arms stationary to protect your shoulder joints
Control the ascent - don't let the cable snap your arms back up

instructions: Attach a V-Bar to a high pulley and grab with an overhand grip (palms facing down) at shoulder width.

Standing upright with the torso straight and a very small inclination forward, bring the upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor. The forearms should be pointing up towards the pulley as they hold the bar. The thumbs should be higher than the small finger. This is your starting position.

Using the triceps, bring the bar down until it touches the front of your thighs and the arms are fully extended perpendicular to the floor. The upper arms should always remain stationary next to your torso and only the forearms should move. Exhale as you perform this movement.
After a second hold at the contracted position, bring the V-Bar slowly up to the starting point. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Triceps Pushdown - V-Bar Attachment
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a V-Bar to a high pulley and grab with an overhand grip at shoulder width
Stand upright with slight forward lean, bring upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor
Start with forearms pointing up toward the pulley, thumbs higher than pinky fingers - this is your starting position
Using your triceps, push the V-Bar down until it touches the front of your thighs with arms fully extended
Hold for one second at the bottom, then raise the V-Bar back to starting position with control
form_cues: Think 'thumbs stay high' - maintain the V-Bar angle throughout
Push straight down with upper arms locked to your sides
Full lockout at the bottom - make your triceps work
common_mistakes: Rotating the V-Bar during the movement instead of maintaining grip angle
Allowing elbows to drift away from your torso
Not fully extending at the bottom of the movement
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your upper arms stationary against your sides throughout
Control the negative - resist the weight on the way back up

instructions: Reach your hand behind your head, grasp your elbow and gently pull. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.
exercises.name: Triceps Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Reach your right hand behind your head, letting your right elbow point upward
Use your left hand to grasp your right elbow from behind
Gently pull your elbow further behind your head until you feel a stretch in your right tricep
Hold for 10-20 seconds while breathing normally
Release and switch to stretch your left tricep
form_cues: Think 'elbow to the sky, hand down your back' - maximize the stretch
The stretch should be felt along the back of your upper arm
Keep your torso upright - don't lean to the side
common_mistakes: Pulling too hard instead of gentle, sustained pressure
Leaning to one side instead of staying upright
Rushing the stretch - hold for the full duration
injury_prevention_tips: Pull gently - stretches should never be painful
Breathe deeply throughout the stretch

instructions: To begin, lie down on the floor or an exercise mat with your back pressed against the floor. Your arms should be lying across your sides with the palms facing down.

Your legs should be crossed by wrapping one ankle around the other. Slowly elevate your legs up in the air until your thighs are perpendicular to the floor with a slight bend at the knees. Note: Your knees and toes should be parallel to the floor as opposed to the thighs.
Move your arms from the floor and cross them so they are resting on your chest. This is the starting position.
While keeping your lower back pressed against the floor, slowly lift your torso. Remember to exhale while perform this part of the exercise.
Slowly begin to lower your torso back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Tuck Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with legs elevated, thighs perpendicular to the floor with knees bent, ankles crossed
Cross your arms over your chest - this is your starting position
While keeping your lower back pressed to the floor, slowly curl your torso up toward your knees
Exhale as you crunch up, squeezing your abs at the top
Slowly lower back down while inhaling, maintaining the leg position throughout
form_cues: Think 'curl your chest toward your knees' - it's a crunch, not a sit-up
Lower back stays glued to the floor - no arch or gap
Legs stay locked in position - they don't move at all
common_mistakes: Pulling with your neck instead of curling with your abs
Letting your lower back lift off the floor
Moving your legs instead of keeping them stationary
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back pressed to the floor throughout
Don't pull on your neck - the lift comes from your abs

exercises.description: Preacher curl performed with dumbbells
instructions: Grab a dumbbell with each arm and place the upper arms on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The dumbbell should be held at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weights up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Dumbbell Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench and rest your upper arms flat on the pad, holding dumbbells with arms extended
Keep your chest against the bench and upper arms completely stationary on the pad
Curl the dumbbells up toward your shoulders by bending your elbows until fully contracted
Squeeze your biceps hard at the top for one second
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly with control until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about bringing your pinkies toward your shoulders to maximize the bicep squeeze
Your upper arms should be glued to the pad - they shouldn't lift or move at all
Lower the weight slowly - take twice as long to lower as you do to curl up
At the bottom, feel a full stretch in your biceps but don't hyperextend the elbow
common_mistakes: Lifting the upper arms off the pad to help curl the weight up
Using momentum by rocking the body instead of strict arm curling
Not lowering all the way down to full extension, cutting the range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend your elbows at the bottom - maintain a slight bend
