Use lighter weights than standing curls since the preacher bench removes momentum

instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.
Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.
Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet, push your hips back into a hinge position with a flat back
Explosively extend your hips and legs, swinging the kettlebells up toward your shoulders
As the bells rise, rotate your wrists so your palms face forward and catch them at shoulder level
The kettlebells should rest on the outside of your forearms with elbows tucked in
Lower the kettlebells back down by reversing the motion and repeat
form_cues: Think about jumping explosively while the kettlebells just come along for the ride
Catch the bells softly at shoulder level - don't let them crash into your wrists
Your elbows should point forward and stay close to your body in the rack position
Drive through your heels and explode with your hips like you're performing a jump
common_mistakes: Muscle curling the kettlebells up with your arms instead of using hip power
Letting the kettlebells flip over and bang your wrists in the catch
Rounding the back at the start position instead of maintaining a neutral spine
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light kettlebells to master the hip hinge and catch technique
Keep your core braced hard throughout to protect your lower back during the explosive movement

instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you swing the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so, so that the palms face forward. Squat down a few inches and reverse the motion rapidly driving both kettlebells overhead. Immediately after the initial push, squat down again and get under the kettlebells. Once the kettlebells are locked out, stand upright to complete the exercise.
exercises.name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders in the rack position with palms facing forward
Dip down a few inches by bending your knees quickly, then explosively drive upward
As you drive, press the kettlebells overhead using the momentum from your legs
Immediately dip under the kettlebells by squatting down again as they lock out overhead
Stand up to full height with the kettlebells locked out overhead, then lower and repeat
form_cues: Think dip, drive, dip - two quick dips with an explosive drive in between
The first dip is shallow and fast, then explode up and drop under the bells
Use your legs to launch the kettlebells - your arms just guide them overhead
Lock your arms out solid at the top and squeeze your glutes for stability
common_mistakes: Pressing with the arms instead of using leg drive to propel the kettlebells
Not dipping under the kettlebells for the second time, which makes the lockout harder
Excessive dip on the first part instead of a quick, shallow dip
injury_prevention_tips: Master the single-arm jerk before attempting the two-arm version
Keep your core braced and glutes squeezed when the bells are overhead to protect your lower back

instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you swing the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so, so that the palms face forward.

Press the kettlebells up and out. As the kettlebells pass your head, lean into the weights so that the kettlebells are racked behind your head. Make sure to contract your lats, butt, and stomach for added stability.
exercises.name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Military Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders with palms facing forward
Press both kettlebells straight up overhead, keeping your core tight and glutes squeezed
As the kettlebells pass your head, lean forward slightly so they finish behind your head
Lock out your arms fully at the top with the kettlebells positioned behind your head
Lower the kettlebells back to your shoulders with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about pressing straight up, then leaning into the bells as they pass your head
Squeeze your lats, glutes, and abs hard to create a stable platform for pressing
Your biceps should end up near your ears at the top with bells slightly behind your head
Don't arch your back - keep your ribs down and core braced tight
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively to help press the weight overhead
Not leaning into the kettlebells, which leaves them in front instead of behind the head
Pressing the kettlebells forward instead of straight up and then back
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core and glutes engaged throughout to prevent lower back hyperextension
Use lighter weight than you would for a barbell press - this variation is more challenging

instructions: Place two kettlebells in front of your feet. Bend your knees slightly and then push your butt out as much as possible as you bend over to get in the starting position.
Grab both kettlebells and pull them to your stomach, retracting your shoulder blades and flexing the elbows. Keep your back straight. Lower and repeat.
exercises.name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two kettlebells in front of your feet, bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips with a flat back
Grab both kettlebells with your arms extended, maintaining a strong hinged position
Pull both kettlebells to your stomach by driving your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades together
Keep your back flat and torso stationary throughout the pull
Lower the kettlebells back down with control and repeat
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows back toward your hips, not up toward your shoulders
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like you're crushing a can between them
Keep your hips pushed back and chest proud - maintain the hip hinge throughout
Your back should stay flat as a table through the entire movement
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back instead of keeping a neutral spine throughout
Using momentum by rocking the torso up and down to help lift the weight
Pulling with the biceps instead of initiating the movement with the back
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced hard to protect your lower back in the hinged position
Don't go so heavy that you can't maintain a flat back throughout

instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.
Grab the pull-down bar with the palms facing your torso (a supinated grip). Make sure that the hands are placed closer than the shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

As you breathe out, pull the bar down until it touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the fully contracted position and keep the elbows close to your body. The upper torso should remain stationary as your bring the bar to you and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, while breathing in, slowly bring the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Underhand Cable Pulldowns
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a lat pulldown machine with the bar attached to the top pulley, grab it with an underhand grip closer than shoulder-width
Lean back about 30 degrees with your chest up, creating a slight arch in your lower back
Pull the bar down to your upper chest by driving your elbows down and back
Squeeze your lats hard at the bottom for one second, keeping your elbows close to your body
Slowly return the bar to the starting position with arms fully extended and repeat
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows down toward your back pockets
Lead with your chest, not your chin - imagine trying to touch the bar with your upper chest
Squeeze your lats at the bottom like you're crushing oranges in your armpits
Your forearms should just be hooks - let your back do all the pulling
common_mistakes: Leaning back too far or using momentum to swing the weight down
Letting the elbows flare out to the sides instead of keeping them close to the body
Using the biceps to curl the weight instead of pulling with the back
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso stationary - don't rock back and forth during the movement
Don't pull the bar below your upper chest, which can strain the shoulder joint

instructions: While seated, bend forward to hug your thighs from underneath with both arms.
Keep your knees together and your legs extended out as you bring your chest down to your knees. You can also stretch your middle back by pulling your back away from your knees as your hugging them.
exercises.name: Upper Back-Leg Grab
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your legs extended straight out in front of you
Bend forward and wrap both arms underneath your thighs, hugging them from below
Keep your knees together and legs straight as you pull your chest down toward your knees
For a deeper upper back stretch, pull your back away from your knees while hugging them
Hold for 20-30 seconds, breathing deeply into the stretch
form_cues: Think about rounding your upper back like a cat stretching
Pull your shoulder blades apart by reaching forward with your arms
Keep your legs completely straight - lock your knees
Breathe into your upper back and feel it expand with each inhale
common_mistakes: Bending the knees to make the stretch easier, which reduces effectiveness
Not actively pulling away from the legs to stretch the upper back
Holding your breath instead of breathing deeply through the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Don't force the stretch - use gentle, progressive pressure
If you can't reach your legs, use a towel or strap to loop around your feet

instructions: Clasp fingers together with your thumbs pointing down, round your shoulders as you reach your hands forward.
exercises.name: Upper Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit upright and clasp your hands together in front of you with thumbs pointing down
Round your shoulders forward as you reach your clasped hands away from your body
Push your shoulder blades apart and feel the stretch across your upper back
Hold for 15-30 seconds while breathing normally
form_cues: Think about spreading your shoulder blades as far apart as possible
Round your upper back like you're forming a C-shape with your spine
Reach your hands forward like you're pushing against a wall
Feel the stretch between your shoulder blades in the upper back
common_mistakes: Not rounding the shoulders forward enough to get a proper stretch
Shrugging the shoulders up instead of keeping them down and rounded forward
Not reaching far enough forward with the arms
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement gentle - you should feel a comfortable stretch, not pain
Don't hold your breath - breathe naturally throughout the stretch

instructions: Grasp a barbell with an overhand grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The bar should be resting on the top of your thighs with your arms extended and a slight bend in your elbows. Your back should also be straight. This will be your starting position.

Now exhale and use the sides of your shoulders to lift the bar, raising your elbows up and to the side. Keep the bar close to your body as you raise it. Continue to lift the bar until it nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion, and should always be higher than your forearms. Remember to keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Upright Barbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an overhand grip slightly narrower than shoulder-width, arms extended with the bar resting on your thighs
Keep your back straight and core braced throughout
Pull the bar up along your body toward your chin, leading with your elbows pointing up and out to the sides
Continue until the bar nearly reaches chin level with your elbows higher than your forearms
Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Think about leading with your elbows, not your hands - pull them up and out
Keep the bar close to your body as it travels up - imagine scraping it along your torso
Your elbows should always be higher than your wrists throughout the movement
At the top, your arms should form a W shape with elbows high and wide
common_mistakes: Using a grip that's too narrow, which can cause shoulder impingement
Letting the bar drift away from the body instead of keeping it close
Using momentum by leaning back or swinging instead of strict pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Stop if you feel any shoulder pain - this exercise can be problematic for some people
Don't pull the bar higher than chin level, which can cause shoulder impingement

instructions: Grasp a straight bar cable attachment that is attached to a low pulley with a pronated (palms facing your thighs) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The bar should be resting on top of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the cable bar as you exhale. The bar should be close to the body as you move it up. Continue to lift it until it nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the bar, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Upright Cable Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight bar to a low pulley and grab it with an overhand grip slightly narrower than shoulder-width
Stand upright with the bar resting on your thighs, arms extended and back straight
Pull the bar up along your body toward your chin, driving your elbows up and out to the sides
Pause when the bar nearly touches your chin with elbows higher than your forearms
Lower the bar back down slowly with control to the starting position
form_cues: Lead with your elbows pointing up and out - they drive the entire movement
Keep the bar travelling close to your body in a straight vertical path
Think about lifting your elbows to the ceiling, not just pulling the bar up
Your torso should stay completely still - imagine you're a statue from the waist down
common_mistakes: Leaning backward or using momentum to help lift the weight
Letting the elbows drop below the level of the forearms during the pull
Shrugging the shoulders up toward the ears instead of leading with the elbows
injury_prevention_tips: Use a moderate grip width - too narrow can cause shoulder issues
Keep your torso stationary throughout to avoid lower back strain

instructions: To begin, stand on an exercise band so that tension begins at arm's length. Grasp the handles using a pronated (palms facing your thighs) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The handles should be resting on top of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the handles as you exhale. The handles should be close to the body as you move them up. Continue to lift the handles until they nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the handles, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the handles back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Upright Row - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on the band with feet hip-width apart, handles in hands with palms facing your thighs
Start with arms hanging straight down, band already under tension
Pull the handles straight up along your body like you're zipping up a jacket, leading with your elbows
Stop when your elbows reach shoulder height and handles are near your chin
Lower back down with control, maintaining tension in the band throughout
form_cues: Lead with your elbows - imagine your hands are just hooks, elbows do all the work
Think about pulling your elbows to the ceiling, not yanking the handles up
Keep the band so close to your body it almost grazes your shirt as it travels up
common_mistakes: Pulling too wide - elbows flare out to the sides instead of staying in front of the body
Using momentum and swinging the body backward to help lift the band
Shrugging shoulders up toward ears instead of keeping traps relaxed until the top
injury_prevention_tips: Stop if you feel pinching in the front of your shoulder - this move isn't for everyone
Keep tension on the band at the bottom - never let it go slack and snap

instructions: Extend both hands straight above your head, palms touching.
Slowly push your hands up and back, keeping your back straight.
exercises.name: Upward Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart and core engaged
Reach both arms straight overhead, pressing palms together like you're praying
Push your hands up and slightly back, feeling a stretch through your chest and lats
Hold for 15-30 seconds while breathing deeply
form_cues: Imagine someone is pulling your hands toward the ceiling with a string
Reach up and slightly back, like you're trying to touch the wall behind you
Keep your ribs down - don't let them flare forward as you reach back
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back excessively instead of keeping core engaged
Bending elbows or letting shoulders shrug up toward ears
Holding breath instead of breathing smoothly through the stretch
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly into the stretch - never bounce or force the range of motion
If you feel pinching in your shoulders, reduce how far back you reach

instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a V-Bar attached to the top pulley.
Adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.

Grab the V-bar with the palms facing each other (a neutral grip). Stick your chest out and lean yourself back slightly (around 30-degrees) in order to better engage the lats. This will be your starting position.

Using your lats, pull the bar down as you squeeze your shoulder blades. Continue until your chest nearly touches the V-bar. Exhale as you execute this motion. Tip: Keep the torso stationary throughout the movement.
After a second hold on the contracted position, slowly bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the prescribed number of repetitions.
exercises.name: V-Bar Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the pulldown machine, grab the V-bar with palms facing each other, arms fully extended
Lean back about 30 degrees and stick your chest out like you're showing off a logo on your shirt
Pull the bar down by driving your elbows toward your back pockets until the V-bar nearly touches your upper chest
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard at the bottom like you're crushing a walnut between them
Slowly let the bar rise back up, keeping tension in your lats the entire time
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows into your back pockets, not pulling with your hands
Imagine crushing a walnut between your shoulder blades at the bottom of each rep
Lead with your chest - bring the bar to your chest, not your chest to the bar
common_mistakes: Leaning back too far and turning it into a rowing motion instead of a pulldown
Using momentum and rocking the torso back and forth
Pulling with arms and biceps instead of initiating the movement with the lats
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced throughout - don't hyperextend your lower back
Control the weight on the way up - never let it yank your arms straight and pull your shoulders out of socket

instructions: Start by placing the middle of the V-bar in the middle of the pull-up bar (assuming that the pull-up station you are using does not have neutral grip handles). The V-Bar handles will be facing down so that you can hang from the pull-up bar through the use of the handles.

Once you securely place the V-bar, take a hold of the bar from each side and hang from it. Stick your chest out and lean yourself back slightly in order to better engage the lats. This will be your starting position.

Using your lats, pull your torso up while leaning your head back slightly so that you do not hit yourself with the chin-up bar. Continue until your chest nearly touches the V-bar. Exhale as you execute this motion.
After a second hold on the contracted position, slowly lower your body back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the prescribed number of repetitions.
exercises.name: V-Bar Pullup
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang a V-bar over the pull-up bar so the handles face down, then grab both handles with palms facing each other
Start in a dead hang with arms fully extended, chest out, slight lean back
Pull yourself up by driving your elbows down and back, tilting your head back slightly to avoid hitting the bar
Pull until your upper chest nearly touches the V-bar handles
Lower yourself down with control until arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about driving your elbows down toward the floor, not pulling your body up
Lead with your chest like you're trying to show someone your shirt logo
Imagine pulling the bar down to you, not pulling yourself up to the bar
common_mistakes: Using too much bicep and not enough lat - pulling with arms instead of back
Not going to full extension at the bottom - cutting range of motion short
Swinging or kipping to generate momentum instead of strict pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Don't drop into the bottom position - lower yourself with control to protect your shoulders
If this is too hard, use an assisted pull-up machine or resistance band for support

instructions: To begin, lie down on an exercise ball with your torso pressing against the ball and parallel to the floor. The ball of your feet should be pressed against the floor to help keep you balanced. Place a weighted plate under your chin or behind your neck. This is the starting position.
Slowly raise your torso up by bending at the waist and lower back. Remember to exhale during this movement.
Hold the contraction on your lower back for a second and lower your torso back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.
exercises.name: Weighted Ball Hyperextension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie facedown on an exercise ball with the ball under your hips and lower abs, feet pressed against the wall or floor
Hold a weight plate against your chest or behind your neck (start light!)
Begin with your torso angled down toward the floor, maintaining a slight bend
Lift your torso up by squeezing your glutes and lower back until your body forms a straight line
Lower back down with control, maintaining tension throughout
form_cues: Lead the movement by squeezing your glutes hard - imagine trying to crack a walnut between your cheeks
Think about lifting your chest toward the ceiling, not arching your back excessively
Keep your core tight like someone's about to punch you in the stomach
common_mistakes: Hyperextending at the top and arching the back too far instead of stopping at neutral spine
Using momentum and bouncing up and down instead of controlled movement
Letting the weight pull you down too fast on the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Start with no weight until you master the movement pattern
Never hyperextend beyond a straight line - your back should be flat at the top, not arched

instructions: To begin, lie down on an exercise ball with your left side of the torso (waist, hips and shoulder) pressed against the ball.

Your feet should be on the floor while your legs are crossed and hanging from the ball. Hold a weighted plate with your right hand directly to the right side of your head. Tip: Make sure the smooth side of the plate is resting against your head.
Place your left arm across your torso so that your palm is on your obliques. There should be a right angle between your left forearm and upper arm. This is the starting position.
Raise the side of your torso up by laterally flexing at the waist while exhaling.
Hold the contraction for a second and slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch sides and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: Weighted Ball Side Bend
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie sideways on an exercise ball with your left hip/waist on the ball, feet crossed and pressing into the floor for stability
Hold a weight plate against the right side of your head with your right hand, left hand across your torso
Start with your torso bent down toward the floor, feeling a stretch in your right obliques
Lift your torso up by crunching your right obliques, raising your right side toward the ceiling
Lower back down with control and repeat, then switch sides
form_cues: Think about bringing your right ribs toward your right hip, crunching sideways like closing a book
Imagine someone pulling your right shoulder straight up to the ceiling
Move only at the waist - your hips and legs stay locked in place
common_mistakes: Rotating the torso forward or backward instead of moving purely side-to-side
Using the bottom arm to push off the ball instead of letting the obliques do the work
Going too heavy too soon and losing balance on the unstable ball
injury_prevention_tips: Master this movement without weight first to build stability and control
Keep the movement controlled - the unstable ball makes it easy to lose form

exercises.description: Dips performed on a bench with added weight
instructions: For this exercise you will need to place a bench behind your back and another one in front of you. With the benches perpendicular to your body, hold on to one bench on its edge with the hands close to your body, separated at shoulder width. Your arms should be fully extended.

The legs will be extended forward on top of the other bench. Your legs should be parallel to the floor while your torso is to be perpendicular to the floor. Have your partner place the dumbbell on your lap. Note: This exercise is best performed with a partner as placing the weight on your lap can be challenging and cause injury without assistance. This will be your starting position.

Slowly lower your body as you inhale by bending at the elbows until you lower yourself far enough to where there is an angle slightly smaller than 90 degrees between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the elbows as close as possible throughout the movement. Forearms should always be pointing down.
Using your triceps to bring your torso up again, lift yourself back to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Weighted Bench Dip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set two benches parallel to each other, sit on one with hands gripping the edge beside your hips, heels on the other bench
Have a partner place a dumbbell or plate on your lap once you're in position
Slide your butt off the bench, supporting yourself with straight arms, body forming an L-shape
Lower yourself by bending elbows until they reach about 90 degrees, keeping elbows close to your body
Press through your palms to straighten arms and return to the top
form_cues: Keep your elbows pointing straight back like headlights, not flaring out to the sides
Think about pushing the bench away from you at the top, not just straightening your arms
Imagine your body is an elevator going straight up and down, not swinging forward
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out wide to the sides, putting excessive stress on the shoulder joint
Descending too low and going past 90 degrees, which can injure the front of the shoulder
Shrugging shoulders up toward ears instead of keeping shoulder blades down and back
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight only until you build strength and perfect the form
Stop immediately if you feel clicking or sharp pain in the front of your shoulder

instructions: Lie flat on your back with your feet flat on the ground or resting on a bench with your knees bent at a 90 degree angle.
Hold a weight to your chest, or you may hold it extended above your torso. This will be your starting position.
Now, exhale and slowly begin to roll your shoulders off the floor. Your shoulders should come up off the floor about 4 inches while your lower back remains on the floor.
At the top of the movement, flex your abdominals and hold for a brief pause.
Then inhale and slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position.
exercises.name: Weighted Crunches
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor, holding a weight plate or medicine ball on your chest
Keep your lower back pressed into the floor and chin slightly tucked
Curl your shoulders off the floor about 4 inches by contracting your abs, as if doing a mini sit-up
Squeeze your abs hard at the top and hold for a brief pause
Lower back down with control, keeping constant tension in your abs
form_cues: Think about bringing your ribs toward your hips, not your chest toward your knees
Imagine you're trying to flatten a pancake with your abs at the top of each rep
Curl up only 4 inches - picture rolling up just enough to slide a credit card under your shoulder blades
common_mistakes: Pulling on the neck or jutting the chin forward instead of keeping neck neutral
Using momentum and rocking back and forth instead of slow, controlled movement
Lifting too high and turning it into a sit-up, which takes tension off the abs
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back glued to the floor throughout - never let it arch up
If holding weight on chest bothers your neck, hold it extended overhead instead

instructions: Position a lightly loaded barbell across the back of your shoulders. You could also use a weighted vest, sandbag, or other type of resistance for this exercise.
The weight should be light enough that it doesn't slow you down significantly. Your feet should be just outside of shoulder width with your head and chest up. This will be your starting position.

Using a countermovement, squat partially down and immediately reverse your direction to explode off of the ground, extending through your hips, knees, and ankles. Maintain good posture throughout the jump.
As you return to the ground, absorb the impact through your legs.
exercises.name: Weighted Jump Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position a light barbell across your upper back (or wear a weighted vest), feet just outside shoulder width
Descend into a partial squat, only going down about a quarter of the way
Explode upward as powerfully as possible, extending through your hips and knees to jump off the ground
Land softly with bent knees to absorb the impact, immediately going into the next rep
form_cues: Think about exploding through the ground like you're trying to jump through the ceiling
Land soft like a cat - absorb the impact by bending your knees, not landing stiff-legged
Keep your chest up throughout - imagine a string pulling your sternum toward the sky
common_mistakes: Using too much weight, which slows you down and defeats the purpose of explosive power training
Squatting too deep before the jump, which increases injury risk with added weight
Landing with stiff legs instead of absorbing impact with bent knees
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light - this is about speed and power, not maximum load
Land softly every single rep - slamming down with weight on your back can injure your spine or knees

instructions: Attach a weight to a dip belt and secure it around your waist. Grab the pull-up bar with the palms of your hands facing forward. For a medium grip, your hands should be spaced at shoulder width. Both arms should be extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip.
You want to bring your torso back about 30 degrees while creating a curvature in your lower back and sticking your chest out. This will be your starting position.
Now, exhale and pull your torso up until your head is above your hands. Concentrate on squeezing yourshoulder blades back and down as you reach the top contracted position.
After a brief moment at the top contracted position, inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position with your arms extended and your lats fully stretched.
exercises.name: Weighted Pull Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach weight to a dip belt around your waist, then grab the pull-up bar with palms facing forward at shoulder width
Hang with arms fully extended, lean back about 30 degrees, chest out, slight arch in lower back
Pull yourself up by driving elbows down and back until your chin clears the bar
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard at the top like you're crushing a soda can between them
Lower yourself slowly and with control until arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows into your back pockets, not pulling your chin over the bar
Lead with your chest - imagine trying to touch the bar with your sternum, not your chin
Squeeze your shoulder blades down and back at the top like you're crushing a walnut between them
common_mistakes: Using too much bicep and not enough lat - initiating with arms instead of back
Not going to full extension at the bottom, which robs you of range of motion and lat stretch
Kipping or swinging to generate momentum instead of strict, controlled pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Only add weight once you can do 10+ strict bodyweight pull-ups with perfect form
Lower yourself with control - never drop into the bottom position with added weight

instructions: Standing upright, with feet at shoulder width and toes raised, use one hand to hold onto the beams of a squat rack and the opposite arm to hold a plate on top of your chest. This is your starting position.

As you use one arm to hold yourself, bend at the knees and slowly lower your torso toward the ground by bringing your pelvis and knees forward. Inhale as you go down and stop when your upper and lower legs almost create a 90-degree angle. Hold the stretch position for a second.
After your one second hold, use your thigh muscles to bring your torso back up to the starting position. Exhale as you move up.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.
exercises.name: Weighted Sissy Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart on your toes, holding a squat rack with one hand and a plate on your chest with the other
Keeping your torso upright, bend your knees and bring your pelvis and knees forward as you lean back
Lower until your upper and lower legs create nearly a 90-degree angle, keeping your torso straight
Hold for one second at the bottom, feeling the stretch in your quads
Drive through your thighs to bring your torso back up to the starting position
form_cues: Think about pushing your knees forward over your toes as you lean your torso back
Keep your torso in a straight line - imagine you're a plank leaning backward
Your knees should travel forward while your torso leans back at the same angle
Squeeze your quads hard on the way up to return to the starting position
common_mistakes: Letting the torso fold forward instead of maintaining a straight line from knees to shoulders
Not going deep enough to create the 90-degree angle at the knees
Losing balance by not using the rack for support
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a secure grip on the rack throughout - this exercise requires support
Start with bodyweight only before adding a plate to master the movement pattern

instructions: Start out by strapping the bands around the base of the decline bench. Place the handles towards the inside of the decline bench so that when lying down, you can reach for both of them.

Position your legs through the decline machine until they are secured. Now reach for the exercise bands with both hands. Use a pronated (palms forward) grip to grasp the handles. Position them near your collar bone and rotate your wrist to a neutral grip (palms facing the torso). Note: Your arms should remain stationary throughout the exercise. This is the starting position.

Move your torso upward until your upper body is perpendicular to the floor while exhaling. Hold the contraction for a second and lower your upper body back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Weighted Sit-Ups - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Strap resistance bands around the base of a decline bench with handles positioned inside
Secure your legs in the decline machine, then grab both band handles and position them near your collar bone
Hold the handles with a neutral grip (palms facing your torso) and keep your arms stationary
Crunch your torso up until your upper body is perpendicular to the floor
Lower back down with control to the starting position and repeat
form_cues: Think about curling your torso up like you're rolling up a carpet from the bottom
Keep the band handles locked at your collar bone - your arms shouldn't move
Exhale forcefully as you crunch up and squeeze your abs at the top
Control the descent - don't just drop back down
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arms instead of keeping them stationary and using only the abs
Using momentum by swinging up instead of controlled abdominal contraction
Not coming up to perpendicular, cutting the range of motion short
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral - don't pull your head forward with your hands
Start with lighter resistance bands and gradually progress as your abs get stronger

instructions: Start by positioning two flat benches shoulder width apart from each other. Stand on top of them and wrap the weighted belt around your waist with the amount of weight you feel comfortable with. Make sure your toes are facing out.
Once you are standing straight up with the weight hanging in between your legs, position your arms so that they are fully extended to the side of your body. This is the starting position.

Begin by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that are perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

Begin to move the body back up by pushing the floor of the flat bench with the ball of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position. Exhale as you perform this portion of the exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Weighted Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on two flat benches positioned shoulder-width apart with a weighted belt hanging between your legs, toes pointed slightly out
Stand upright with arms extended out to your sides for balance
Lower down by bending your knees while keeping your head up and torso straight
Descend until your thighs are slightly below parallel to the floor
Push through the balls of your feet to stand back up to the starting position
form_cues: Think about sitting back into a chair while keeping your chest proud
Your knees should track over your toes - imagine a straight line from knee to toe
Keep your weight distributed through your whole foot, not just your toes
Drive up through the balls of your feet like you're pushing the benches down
common_mistakes: Letting the knees travel too far forward past the toes, which stresses the knee joint
Rounding the back or leaning too far forward instead of staying upright
Not going deep enough - thighs should be below parallel
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the benches are stable and won't slide before starting the exercise
Start with lighter weight to get comfortable with the elevated, unstable position

instructions: Lie back on a flat bench with feet firm on the floor. Using a wide, pronated (palms forward) grip that is around 3 inches away from shoulder width (for each hand), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. The bar will be perpendicular to the torso and the floor. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wide-Grip Barbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with feet planted firmly on the floor, grab the bar with a wide overhand grip (about 3 inches wider than shoulder-width on each side)
Unrack the bar and hold it with locked arms directly above your chest
Lower the bar slowly to your mid-chest while inhaling
Pause for one second with the bar touching your chest
Drive the bar back up to the starting position while exhaling, squeezing your chest at the top
form_cues: Think about bending the bar apart as you lower it to engage your lats
Lower the bar to your mid-chest, not your neck or lower ribs
Push through the floor with your feet to create leg drive
At the top, squeeze your pecs together like you're doing a front lat spread
common_mistakes: Bouncing the bar off the chest instead of pausing for control
Letting the elbows flare too far out at 90 degrees, which can strain the shoulders
Arching the back excessively to reduce range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blades retracted and pressed into the bench throughout
Lower the weight twice as slow as you press it up for better muscle control

instructions: Lie back on a decline bench with the feet securely locked at the front of the bench. Using a wide, pronated (palms forward) grip that is around 3 inches away from shoulder width (for each hand), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. The bar will be perpendicular to the torso and the floor. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your lower chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie back on a decline bench with feet secured, grab the bar with a wide overhand grip (about 3 inches wider than shoulder-width on each side)
Unrack the bar and hold it with locked arms directly above your lower chest
Lower the bar slowly to your lower chest while inhaling
Pause for one second with the bar touching your lower chest
Press the bar back up to the starting position while exhaling, locking out and squeezing your chest
form_cues: Think about pressing the bar up and slightly back toward the rack
Lower the bar to your lower chest where you'd hit with a perfect chest bump
Keep your shoulder blades squeezed together and pulled down throughout
Squeeze your lower pecs hard at the top like you're flexing for a photo
common_mistakes: Lowering the bar too high on the chest, which shifts emphasis away from lower pecs
Not controlling the descent - letting gravity drop the bar
Letting the elbows flare out too wide, which can cause shoulder strain
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your feet firmly locked in the decline bench to prevent sliding
Take twice as long to lower the bar as you do to press it up

instructions: Lie down on a decline bench with both legs securely locked in position. Reach for the barbell behind the head using a pronated grip (palms facing out). Make sure to grab the barbell wider than shoulder width apart for this exercise. Slowly lift the barbell up from the floor by using your arms.
When positioned properly, your arms should be fully extended and perpendicular to the floor. This is the starting position.

Begin by moving the barbell back down in a semicircular motion as if you were going to place it on the floor, but instead, stop when the arms are parallel to the floor. Tip: Keep the arms fully extended at all times. The movement should only happen at the shoulder joint. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Now bring the barbell up while exhaling until you are back at the starting position. Remember to keep full control of the barbell at all times.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
When finished with your set, slowly lower the barbell back down until it is level with your head and release it.
exercises.name: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a decline bench with legs secured, reach back and grab a barbell with a wide overhand grip wider than shoulder-width
Lift the bar with straight arms until it's directly above your chest, perpendicular to the floor
Lower the bar in a semicircular arc behind your head, keeping arms fully extended
Stop when your arms are parallel to the floor, feeling a stretch in your chest and lats
Reverse the motion to bring the bar back up to the starting position
form_cues: Think about drawing a big arc in the air with the bar, like a rainbow
Keep your arms locked straight throughout - the movement only happens at the shoulders
Feel the stretch in your chest and lats as the bar goes back behind your head
Breathe in as you lower and exhale as you bring the bar back up
common_mistakes: Bending the elbows during the movement, which turns it into a different exercise
Going too far back past parallel, which can strain the shoulder joint
Using too much weight and losing control of the bar
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than you think - this exercise requires strict shoulder control
Keep full control of the barbell at all times - never let it drop or swing

instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Make sure that you adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.

Grab the bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

As you breathe out, bring the bar down until it touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work except for holding the bar; therefore do not try to pull down the bar using the forearms.

After a second at the contracted position squeezing your shoulder blades together, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched. Inhale during this portion of the movement.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wide-Grip Lat Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a lat pulldown machine and grab the wide bar with an overhand grip wider than shoulder-width
Lean back about 30 degrees, create a curve in your lower back, and stick your chest out
Pull the bar down to your upper chest by drawing your shoulders and upper arms down and back
Squeeze your back muscles hard at the bottom for one second
Slowly raise the bar back up with control until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows down to your sides, not just the bar
Lead with your chest toward the bar, not your chin
Squeeze your lats at the bottom like you're crushing walnuts in your armpits
Your forearms are just hooks - let your back muscles do all the work
common_mistakes: Using momentum by rocking back and forth instead of keeping the torso stationary
Pulling with the biceps instead of initiating the movement with the back
Leaning back too far, which turns it into more of a row than a pulldown
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your torso angle fixed throughout - don't rock to help pull the weight
Don't pull the bar below your upper chest, which can strain the shoulder capsule

instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Make sure that you adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.

Grab the bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso and head forward. Think of an imaginary line from the center of the bar down to the back of your neck. This is your starting position.

As you breathe out, bring the bar down until it touches the back of your neck by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work except for holding the bar; therefore do not try to pull down the bar using the forearms.

After a second on the contracted position squeezing your shoulder blades together, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched. Inhale during this portion of the movement.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wide-Grip Pulldown Behind The Neck
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a lat pulldown machine and grab the wide bar with an overhand grip wider than shoulder-width
Bring your torso and head forward so there's an imaginary line from the bar to the back of your neck
Pull the bar down until it touches the back of your neck by drawing your shoulders and upper arms down and back
Squeeze your shoulder blades together hard for one second
Slowly raise the bar back up with control until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about pulling the bar down behind your head, not to your traps
Keep your head tilted slightly forward to make room for the bar path
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom like pinching a pencil between them
Your upper torso should remain stationary - only your arms move
common_mistakes: Pulling the bar too low onto the upper traps instead of the neck
Not leaning forward enough, which makes the bar path difficult and dangerous
Using the biceps to curl the weight instead of pulling with the back
injury_prevention_tips: Only perform this if you have excellent shoulder mobility - if uncomfortable, stick to front pulldowns
Use lighter weight than front pulldowns as this variation is more demanding on the shoulders

instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using a wide grip.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar, bring your torso forward and head so that there is an imaginary line from the pull-up bar to the back of your neck. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up until the bar is near the back of your neck. To do this, draw the shoulders and upper arms down and back while slightly leaning your head forward. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wide-Grip Rear Pull-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with an overhand grip wider than shoulder-width
Lean your torso and head forward so there's an imaginary line from the bar to the back of your neck
Pull your torso up until the bar is near the back of your neck, leaning your head forward slightly
Squeeze your back muscles hard at the top for one second
Lower yourself back down with control until your arms are fully extended
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows down and back, not just lifting your body
Lead with your upper back, not your chin - imagine someone pulling your traps upward
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top like you're crushing a can between them
Keep your core tight and body stable - don't swing or use momentum
common_mistakes: Not leaning forward enough, which makes the bar path impossible
Pulling too high and hitting the back of your head on the bar
Using momentum by kipping or swinging instead of strict pulling
injury_prevention_tips: Only attempt this variation if you have very good shoulder mobility and can do regular pull-ups easily
Lean your head forward enough to make room for the bar - don't hit your head

instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a barbell at the wide outer handle. The palm of your hands should be facing forward. The elbows should be close to the torso. This will be your starting position.
While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wide-Grip Standing Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding a barbell with a wide overhand grip at the outer handles, arms extended with the bar at your thighs
Keep your elbows pinned to your sides and upper arms stationary
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders by contracting your biceps
Squeeze your biceps hard at the top for one second when the bar reaches shoulder level
Slowly lower the bar back down to the starting position with control
form_cues: Think about curling the bar up while keeping your elbows locked in place at your sides
Only your forearms should move - upper arms stay completely still
Squeeze your biceps at the top like you're doing a flex
Control the weight on the way down - don't just let it drop
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drift forward instead of keeping them locked at your sides
Using momentum by swinging the torso or leaning back to help lift the weight
Not achieving full range of motion by either not curling high enough or not fully extending
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists straight throughout - don't let them bend backward under the load
Use lighter weight than a normal grip curl as the wide grip is more challenging

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a wider-than-shoulder-width stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance, and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position.

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wide Stance Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the barbell on a rack at upper chest height, step under it and position it across your upper traps
Unrack the bar and step back, setting your feet wider than shoulder-width with toes pointed out 30-45 degrees
Keep your chest up and core braced, then push your hips back and bend your knees to descend
Lower until your hip crease drops just below your knee level (thighs parallel or slightly below)
Drive through your heels and midfoot to stand back up, squeezing your glutes at the top
form_cues: Push your knees out wide to follow your toes - imagine spreading the floor apart with your feet
Think about sitting back into a chair that's slightly behind you, not straight down
Keep your chest proud like you're showing off a logo on your shirt throughout the movement
common_mistakes: Knees caving inward instead of tracking over the toes in line with the wide stance
Leaning too far forward and turning it into a good morning instead of staying upright
Not going deep enough - cutting the range of motion short and staying too high
injury_prevention_tips: Actively push your knees out in the direction of your toes throughout the entire movement
Keep your weight balanced over midfoot - never let your heels come up or lean onto your toes

instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar using a pronated grip. Your arms and legs should be extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by quickly raising one knee as high as you can. Do not swing your body or your legs. 3
Immediately reverse the motion, returning that leg to the starting position. Simultaneously raise the opposite knee as high as possible.
Continue alternating between legs until the set is complete.
exercises.name: Wind Sprints
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar with a pronated (palms away) grip, arms and legs fully extended
Quickly drive one knee up as high as possible toward your chest, keeping your body still
Immediately reverse and drive that leg back down while simultaneously bringing the opposite knee up
Continue alternating knees in a rapid, controlled running motion while hanging
Keep your core tight throughout - don't swing or use momentum
form_cues: Think about doing high knees while hanging - same explosive knee drive you'd use while running
Keep your upper body completely still like a statue - only your legs move
Drive your knees up like you're trying to knee yourself in the chest
common_mistakes: Swinging the body back and forth instead of keeping torso stationary
Moving legs slowly or with low knee drive instead of explosive, rapid alternation
Gripping too loosely and losing hold of the bar mid-set
injury_prevention_tips: Use lifting straps if your grip gives out before your abs are fatigued
Keep your shoulders actively engaged and packed down - don't hang passively or let them shrug up

instructions: Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides and your legs straight. This will be your starting position.
Lift one leg and quickly cross it over your body, attempting to touch the ground near the opposite hand.
Return to the starting position, and repeat with the opposite leg. Continue to alternate for 10-20 repetitions.
exercises.name: Windmills
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with arms extended out to the sides in a T-position, legs straight
Lift one leg straight up, then swing it across your body toward the opposite hand
Try to touch the ground near your opposite hand while keeping your shoulders flat on the floor
Return to starting position and immediately repeat with the opposite leg
Continue alternating legs in a controlled, rhythmic motion
form_cues: Think about drawing a rainbow arc with your foot from one side to the other
Keep both shoulders pinned to the floor - imagine someone is holding them down
Move with control like a windshield wiper, not flinging your legs wildly
common_mistakes: Letting the opposite shoulder lift off the ground when reaching across
Bending the knee instead of keeping the leg straight throughout the movement
Moving too fast and using momentum instead of controlled, deliberate motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start with smaller range of motion if you have tight hips or lower back issues
Never force the stretch - only go as far as your mobility allows without pain

instructions: This is a three-part stretch. Begin by lunging forward, with your front foot flat on the ground and on the toes of your back foot. With your knees bent, squat down until your knee is almost touching the ground. Keep your torso erect, and hold this position for 10-20 seconds.

Now, place the arm on the same side as your front leg on the ground, with the elbow next to the foot. Your other hand should be placed on the ground, parallel to your lead leg, to help support you during this portion of the stretch.

After 10-20 seconds, place your hands on either side of your front foot. Raise the toes of the front foot off of the ground, and straighten your leg. You may need to reposition your rear leg to do so. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then repeat the entire sequence for the other side.
exercises.name: World's Greatest Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Step into a deep lunge position with your front foot flat and back foot on its toes, drop your back knee almost to the ground
Place the elbow of your front-leg-side arm on the ground next to your front foot, other hand on ground for support
Hold this deep hip stretch for 10-20 seconds, feeling it in your hip flexor and groin
Place both hands on either side of your front foot, lift your front toes off the ground and straighten that leg completely
Hold for 10-20 seconds to stretch your hamstring, then repeat the entire sequence on the other side
form_cues: In the lunge, think about driving your hips down and forward toward the ground to maximize hip flexor stretch
When straightening your leg, imagine pushing your hips back while keeping your chest toward your shin
Try to touch your chest to your thigh when straightening the leg - fold from the hips, not round your back
common_mistakes: Not dropping the hips low enough in the lunge position to get a proper hip flexor stretch
Rounding the back when straightening the leg instead of hinging from the hips
Rushing through the holds - spend the full 10-20 seconds in each position
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly between positions - never bounce or force yourself deeper into the stretch
If you can't get your elbow to the ground in part 2, use a yoga block or support hand instead

instructions: Start by standing straight with your feet being shoulder width apart from each other. Elevate your arms to the side of you until they are fully extended and parallel to the floor at a height that is evenly aligned with your shoulders. Tip: Your torso and arms should form the letter T: Your palms should be facing down. This is the starting position.

Keeping your entire body stationary except for the wrists, begin to rotate both wrists forward in a circular motion. Tip: Pretend that you are trying to draw circles by using your hands as the brush. Breathe normally as you perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Wrist Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, raise both arms straight out to your sides parallel to the floor
Your body should form a T-shape with arms fully extended and palms facing down
Keep your entire body still and begin rotating both wrists in forward circles
Complete the prescribed number of circles, then reverse direction and circle backwards
Focus on making full, controlled circles with your hands
form_cues: Imagine you're painting circles on a wall with a paintbrush held in your hands
Keep your arms perfectly still - movement only comes from the wrists, nothing else
Make big, exaggerated circles to maximize the range of motion
common_mistakes: Moving the entire arm or shoulder instead of isolating just the wrist joint
Making tiny circles instead of using full wrist range of motion
Letting arms drop or drift away from shoulder height
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly and smoothly - never jerk or force the wrist through uncomfortable ranges
If you feel any sharp pain or clicking, reduce the size of your circles

instructions: To begin, stand straight up grabbing a wrist roller using a pronated grip (palms facing down). Your feet should be shoulder width apart.

Slowly lift both arms until they are fully extended and parallel to the floor in front of you. Note: Make sure the rope is not wrapped around the roller. Your entire body should be stationary except for the forearms. This is the starting position.
Rotate one wrist at a time in an upward motion to bring the weight up to the bar by rolling the rope around the roller.
Once the weight has reached the bar, slowly begin to lower the weight back down by rotating the wrist in a downward motion until the weight reaches the starting position.
Repeat for the prescribed amount of repetitions in your program.
exercises.name: Wrist Roller
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a wrist roller device with palms facing down, arms extended straight in front at shoulder height
Keep your entire body still with only forearms moving - this is your starting position
Alternate rotating one wrist at a time in an upward motion, rolling the rope around the bar to raise the weight
Once the weight reaches the bar at the top, reverse the motion and slowly lower it back down
Repeat for the prescribed number of reps, keeping arms parallel to the floor throughout
form_cues: Think about revving a motorcycle throttle with alternating hands to wind up the rope
Keep your arms locked at shoulder height like someone is holding a bar across them
Focus on the forearm squeeze - really milk each rotation to maximize muscle contraction
common_mistakes: Letting arms drop below shoulder height when fatigued - this takes tension off the forearms
Using big arm movements instead of small, isolated wrist rotations
Rolling the weight up too quickly without controlling the descent
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight - this exercise is harder than it looks and burns out forearms quickly
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain in your wrists or elbows

instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing down; hands spaced about shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
Alternating between each of your hands, perform the movement by extending the wrist as though you were rolling up a newspaper. Continue alternating back and forth until failure.
Reverse the motion by flexing the wrist, rolling the opposite direction. Continue the alternating motion until failure.
exercises.name: Wrist Rotations with Straight Bar
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands shoulder-width apart, palms facing down, arms hanging straight
Begin alternating between your hands, extending one wrist up as if rolling up a newspaper
As that hand reaches maximum extension, the other hand begins its upward roll
Continue this rolling-up motion until your forearms are fatigued, then reverse direction
Flex your wrists in the opposite direction, rolling downward until failure
form_cues: Think about doing the wave with your hands - one goes up, the other starts as the first peaks
Imagine you're rolling dough or wrapping something around the bar with alternating hands
Keep the bar level - don't let one side dip as you alternate wrists
common_mistakes: Moving both hands at the same time instead of alternating smoothly
Using arms or shoulders to help instead of pure wrist flexion and extension
Not going through full range of motion - cutting the movement short
injury_prevention_tips: Start with just the bar or very light weight - wrist movements fatigue quickly
If you feel tendon pain, stop immediately and don't push through it

instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. The correct height should be anywhere above the waist but below the chest. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, lock your hands together and place the bar on top of your arms in between the forearm and upper arm.
Lift the bar up so that it is resting on top of your forearms. If you are holding the bar properly, it should look as if you have your arms crossed but with a bar running across them.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the ball of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Zercher Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell in a rack at waist to mid-chest height, lock your hands together and cradle the bar in your elbow crooks
Lift the bar out of the rack so it rests in the crook of your elbows with your arms crossed
Step back, set feet shoulder-width apart with toes slightly out, chest up and core braced
Squat down by pushing hips back and bending knees until thighs are just below parallel to the floor
Drive through your feet to stand back up, maintaining an upright torso throughout
form_cues: Think about holding a giant beach ball against your chest - keep elbows and chest up
Imagine sitting back into a chair while hugging the bar close to keep your torso upright
Keep your elbows high like you're showing someone your biceps in a front double bicep pose
common_mistakes: Letting the bar slip down toward your wrists instead of staying locked in your elbow crooks
Rounding forward at the bottom because the front-loaded bar pulls you forward
Setting feet too narrow, which makes it harder to stay upright with front-loaded weight
injury_prevention_tips: Wrap a towel or use a pad around the bar if it digs into your arms painfully
Start very light - this variation is much harder on your core and upper back than regular squats

exercises.description: Zottman curl performed with dumbbells
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
Make sure the palms of the hands are facing each other. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Your wrist should rotate so that you have a supinated (palms up) grip. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level.
Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Now during the contracted position, rotate your wrist until you now have a pronated (palms facing down) grip with the thumb at a higher position than the pinky.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back down using the pronated grip.
As the dumbbells close your thighs, start rotating the wrist so that you go back to a neutral (palms facing your body) grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Zottman Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing forward (neutral/hammer grip)
Curl the weights up while rotating your wrists so palms face up at the top, squeezing your biceps
At the top with biceps fully contracted, rotate your wrists so palms face down (pronated grip)
Slowly lower the dumbbells back down with palms facing down, controlling the negative
At the bottom, rotate wrists back to neutral/palms forward position and repeat
form_cues: Think curl up with palms up, lower down with palms down - it's all about the wrist rotation
Imagine you're showing off your biceps on the way up, then pouring out water on the way down
Control the eccentric (lowering) with palms down - this fries your forearms in the best way
common_mistakes: Forgetting to rotate wrists at the top and bottom - the rotation is what makes this unique
Dropping the weight too fast on the way down instead of controlling the eccentric
Using momentum and swinging the weights up instead of strict curling motion
injury_prevention_tips: Start light - the pronated eccentric is much harder on your forearms than you expect
Keep elbows pinned to your sides throughout - don't let them drift forward or back

exercises.description: Zottman preacher curl performed with dumbbells
instructions: Grab a dumbbell in each hand and place your upper arms on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The dumbbells should be held at shoulder height and the elbows should be flexed. Hold the dumbbells with the palms of your hands facing down. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells keeping the palms down until your upper arm is extended and your biceps are fully stretched.
Now rotate your wrists once you are at the bottom of the movement so that the palms of the hands are facing up.

As you exhale, use your biceps to curl the weights up until they are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height. Again, remember that to ensure full contraction you need to bring that small finger higher than the thumb.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and rotate your wrists so that the palms are facing down again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Zottman Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench with dumbbells, upper arms resting on the pad, start with palms facing down
Lower the dumbbells slowly with palms down until arms are fully extended at the bottom
At the bottom, rotate your wrists so palms now face up (supinated)
Curl the weights up with palms facing up until biceps are fully contracted at the top
At the top, rotate wrists back to palms-down position and repeat the controlled descent
form_cues: Think of it as reverse of regular Zottman - you lower with palms down, curl up with palms up
Keep your upper arms glued to the pad like they're stuck with velvet - they never move
Squeeze hard at the top with your pinky higher than your thumb to maximize bicep contraction
common_mistakes: Lifting elbows off the pad when curling up, which reduces bicep isolation
Rushing through the wrist rotations instead of making them deliberate and controlled
Using too much weight and losing the strict form this exercise requires
injury_prevention_tips: The preacher position isolates your biceps intensely - start lighter than regular curls
Never hyperextend your elbows at the bottom - keep slight tension even when fully extended
